Preface

At the Still Point of the Turning World

by LilaLuna

Summary

“You look like you just sprinted a mile,” Alice said, smirking. “Dr. Harkness give you a hard time today?”

Rio dropped into the seat across from her, pulling her scarf loose and letting out a sigh. “No, not really. She actually said I had a ‘fair interpretation.’”

Alice leaned forward, resting her chin on her hand. “And that made your entire week, didn’t it?”

Rio tried to brush it off, stirring sugar into her coffee. “She’s just — she has this presence, you know? The way she talks, the way she challenges you. It’s like she’s… magnetic.”

“Uh-huh.” Alice’s smirk deepened. “Magnetic. Sure. That’s the word we’re going with?”

“Oh, stop it,” Rio groaned, her cheeks heating.

-------

Or: Rio Vidal, a PhD student, finds herself enthralled with Dr. Agatha Harkness, her Modernist poetry seminar teacher, and her adorable son, Nicky.

Notes

College AU where Rio is a Phd student and Agatha is a professor, so it is totally age appropriate!

The title and every poem at the beginning are from the four sections of T. S Eliot's "Four Quartets."

 

Also: I made a Pinterest Board for this story, feel free to check it out! https://pin.it/80WPW8Ddg

Academic Fascination

*

*

*

Time present and time past

Are both perhaps present in time future,

And time future contained in time past.

If all time is eternally present

All time is unredeemable.

What might have been is an abstraction

Remaining a perpetual possibility

Only in a world of speculation.

         (T. S. Eliot, “Burnt Norton”, Four Quartet)

 

 

The seminar room at Hillman Hall was a relic of the 1950s: thick oak tables that refused to give up their polish, windows streaked with rain from the morning drizzle, and chairs that creaked with the weight of academic ambitions. Rio Vidal arrived early, as always, her bag slung over one shoulder and a steaming cup of tea balanced precariously in her hand. She liked the quiet of an empty classroom, the way the stillness echoed her thoughts before the arrival of her peers and, of course, Dr. Agatha Harkness.

 

Rio placed her tea on the table nearest the window and pulled out her copy of The Waste Land. The cover was battered, pages marked with an ocean of multicolored tabs. She stared at the familiar text, but her thoughts drifted, as they often did, to the professor who taught the seminar.

 

Dr. Harkness wasn’t like any academic Rio had encountered. She was sharp but never abrasive, her critiques incisive and unyieldling, as if she could strip the truth bare with a single glance. Her lectures carried the weight of someone who didn’t just teach literature but lived it, her voice weaving between the cadences of Eliot and the rebellion of Stein like she had known them personally. Her writing, too—critical essays interspersed with poetry—commanded reverence in the literary circles Rio desperately wanted to join.

 

The seminar door creaked open, and in walked Dr. Harkness herself, precisely on time. She carried nothing but a thin folder, her dark coat trailing behind her like a cape. She was tall, her posture upright, and her long brown hair was pinned up in a way that looked effortless but must have taken precision and years of practice. Her gaze swept the room, and Rio felt a jolt when their eyes met—a fleeting connection, heavy and charged – at least on Rio’s side - before the professor’s attention moved on.

 

“Good afternoon,” Dr. Harkness began, her voice rich and steady. She set her folder on the table and leaned against it, arms crossed. “Today, we’ll discuss framgentation—not just in Modernist poetry, but in how it reflects the fractured human condition. Eliot believed the poet’s role was to make order out of chaos. Do we agree?”

 

The question hung in the air, and Rio forced herself to focus. She’d prepared for this discussion. Her hand rose slightly, but not before a classmate chimed in with a carefully rehearsed answer about literary traditions. Dr. Harkness listened, nodding, before cutting in with a pointed, “And yet, does that answer the question I asked?”

 

Rio’s lips twitched into a smile. That was another thing about Dr. Harkess—her ability to unsettle without ever raising her voice.

 

When Rio finally spoke, it was after a moment of courage. “I think Eliot wasn’t trying to impose order so much as document the chaos. He couldn’t fix it; he could only reflect it back to us, fragmented, like a broken mirror.”

 

Dr. Harkness turned her gaze on Rio, and for a moment, the seminar room faded away. “A fair interpretation,” she said, her tone neutral, but her eyes lingered. “Though perhaps Eliot wasn’t as passive as you suggest. Can chaos itself be an artistic choice?”

 

Rio nodded, her heart pounding, and tried to answer as thoughtfully as she could. But the words came out in a jumble, her nerves betraying her. Dr. Harkness listened without interruption, raised a brow then pivoted to another student, giving Rio the space to exhale.

 

By the time the seminar ended, Rio felt both drained and exhilarated. As the students filed out, she lingered, pretending to pack her things slowly. Dr. Harkness was tucking her folder under one arm, her eyes already scanning the corridor beyond.

 

“Good insight today, Miss Vidal,” she said suddenly, her voice lower now that the room was nearly empty.

 

Rio froze, her cheeks warming. “Thank you, Dr. Harkness.”

 

The professor’s lips curved slightly, almost imperceptibly. Then, with a curt nod, she swept out of the room, leaving Rio alone in theempty room.

 

Fascination, Rio thought as she watched her go. It was a dangerous thing to feel, but she couldn’t seem to help herself.

 

Rio slung her bag over her shoulder and practically ran out of Hillman Hall, ignoring the curious glances of a few classmates. Her destination was clear: the small café tucked just off campus where Alice, her best friend and fellow PhD student but in musicology, was waiting.

 

Alice spotted her through the window and waved, her dark curls bouncing as she leaned back in her chair. By the time Rio burst through the door, slightly out of breath, Alice already had two steaming cups of coffee on the table.

 

“You look like you just sprinted a mile,” Alice said, smirking. “Dr. Harkness give you a hard time today?”

 

Rio dropped into the seat across from her, pulling her scarf loose and letting out a sigh. “No, not really. She actually said I had a ‘fair interpretation.’”

 

Alice’s eyebrows shot up. “High praise from the Ice Queen. Did she smile this time, or was it more of a grimace?”

 

Rio rolled hereyes but couldn’t hide the small, self-conscious grin tugging at her lips. “She… sort of smiled. I think.”

 

Alice leaned forward, resting her chin on her hand. “And that made your entire week, didn’t it?”

 

Rio tried to brush it off, stirring sugar into her coffee. “She’s just—she has this presence, you know? The way she talks, the way she challenges you. It’s like she’s… magnetic.”

 

“Uh-huh.” Alice’s smirk deepened. “Magnetic. Sure. That’s the word we’re going with?”

 

“Oh, stop it,” Rio groaned, her cheeks heating.

 

“I’m just saying,” Alice continued, clearly enjoying herself. “You’ve got a bit of a thing, and it’s adorable. No judgment. I mean, who wouldn’t be at least a little fascinated by the famously untouchable Agatha Harkness?”

 

“It’s not like that,” Rio protested, but her voice lacked conviction.

 

Alice sipped her coffee, watching Rio over the rim of her cup with a knowing gleam in her eye. “Look, I get it. She’s brilliant, intimidating, and probably smells like expensive books and disappointment. But just… be careful, okay? Fascinations have a way of becoming obsessions.”

 

Rio opened her mouth to respond, but the words didn’t come. Instead, she stared into her coffee, Alice’s teasing echoing in her mind. Fascination, obsession—what was the difference, really? And why did the thought of Dr. Harkness, with her imperious presence and unreadable expressions, make her feel both thrilled and utterly unmoored?

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, her teasing smirk fading into a grin. “Speaking of obsessions, don’t forget you’re drumming for us this Friday. It’s a big gig, and we need your rhythm to keep Jen  from going rogue again.”

 

Rio groaned, but a smile tugged at her lips. “Don’t remind me. I still have bruises from carrying that drum kit up for three flights of stairs last time.”

 

“Small price to pay for fame and glory,” Alice quipped, raising her coffee like a toast. “Besides, the crowd loves you. You might even get some groupies this time.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress a laugh. Playing with Alice’s band wasn’t something she had planned when she’d started her PhD, but it had become one of her favorite escapes. There was something freeing about letting loose on the drums, the rhythms drowning out the stress of thesis deadlines and seminar discussions.

 

“I’ll be there,” Rio said, pointing a mock-threatening finger at Alice. “But if Jen tries to change the setlist mid-performance again, I’m walking offstage.”

 

“Fair,” Alice replied, holding up her hands in surrender. “I already gave her the ‘don’t mess with Rio’ speech. Besides, you’re the bakcbone of the band. And between you and me, I think you secretly like it.”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “Maybe a little. But only because you’re in it.”

 

Alice beamed at her, leaning forward. “Good answer. Now, let’s plan this setlist. You’ve got two days to nail the tempo changes for our new song.”

 

As they dived into band logistics, Rio felt the weight of her morning seminar lift. The prospect of performing gave her something tangible to look forward to—a beat she could control in her world full of chaos. 

 

As Alice began sketching out the setlist on a napkin, Rio’s phone buzzed in her pocket. She glanced at the screen and saw Lilia’s name flashing. Excusing herself with a quick gesture, she stepped outside the café, the brisk air biting at her cheeks.

 

“Hi, Lilia,” Rio answered, her voice softening instinctively.

 

“Rio, sweetheart,” Lilia’s warm, familiar voice came through. “I was wondering if you’re coming to dinner tonight. I made that stew you like—the one with the chickpeas and all those spices. It’s been a while since we caught up.”

 

Rio smiled, the tension from her morning slipping away. “You didn’t have to go all out for me, Lilia.”

 

“Of course I did,” Lilia replied with mock indignation. “You’re working yourself to the bone. Someone’s got to make sure you eat something that’s not from a campus vending machine.”

 

Rio laughed. “Guilty as charged. Yeah, I can come by tonight. You’re too good to me, you know that?” She glanced at her watch. “I can come over after my dance class. I’m teaching the little ones today, so I might be a bit late, but I’ll be there.”

 

“Dance class? You’re still cramming your schedule full, aren’t you?” Lilia said, a mixture of affection and mild exasperation in her tone.

 

“It’s not that bad,” Rio protested lightly. “Besides, I love it. They’re a good group, they’re so cute you should see them, even if I do have to keep prying them off the barre every five minutes.”

 

Lilia laughed. “Well, as long as it’s not wearing you out. Come by when you’re done. Dinner will be waiting, and I expect to hear all about your day.”

 

“Deal,” Rio said with a smile. “See you tonight, Lilia.”

 

As she hung up and walked back into the café, the thought of her dance class filled her with a comforting sense of rhythm. It was another part of her life that kept her grounded—a space where she could share her love of movement with wide-eyed kids still discovering the magic of pliés and jetés. The promise of Lilia’s presence and her warm kitchen afterward made the long day ahead feel a little lighter.

 

After years of bouncing between foster homes, Lila had been the one constant in her life, taking her in at sixteen—a steady presence with a knack for tough love and perfectly spiced meals. She wasn’t family in the traditional sense, but she was home, in a way that mattered more.

 

When Rio returned to the table, Alice raised an eyebrow. “Lilia?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio said, sitting down and picking up her coffee. “She wants me to come to dinner tonight.”

 

Alice grinned. “Lucky you. Homemade food and a chance to escape the madness for a bit. Tell her I said hi.”

 

“I will,” Rio said, and for a moment, she let herself enjoy the warmth of the café, the hum of Alice’s band plans, and the promise of a home-cooked meal waiting for her later.

 

After finishing their coffees and finalizing the setlist for Friday’s gig, Rio and Alice gathered their things and headed toward the university library. The sprawling, ivy-covered building was a sanctuary for students juggling deadlines and academic ambitions, and Rio felt the usual mix of anticipation and dread as they pushed through the heavy wooden doors.

 

The library smelled of old paper and faint coffee, the kind of comforting scent that always reminded Rio of late nights buried in books. She followed Alice to their usual spot—a tucked-away corner on the second floor near the poetry section. It was quiet but close enough to a window to let in slivers of light on gloomy days like this one.

 

Alice plopped her bag onto the table and pulled out a thick stack of sheet music. “Alright, time to figure out how to make Bartók sound exciting to my supervisor,” she muttered, pulling a face.

 

Rio smiled as she set up her laptop and opened her notebook, its pages covered in handwritten notes for her thesis. “I’m sure you’ll manage,” she said. “You’re good at making even the most niche topics sound fascinating.”

 

“Right back at you, Miss ‘Modernism and the Language of Timelessness,’” Alice quipped. “Speaking of which, how’s that coming along? Or have you been too busy staring at Dr. Harkness to get anything done?”

 

Rio shot her a look but couldn’t help laughing. “I’ve been working on it. I’m still stuck on the section about the intersections between Eliot’s grasp of time and his poetic fragmentation. It feels like no matter how much I write, it’s never enough.”

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, spinning a pen between her fingers. “Sounds like classic imposter syndrome. You’re brilliant, Rio. Don’t let the ghosts of dead poets tell you otherwise.”

 

“Thanks,” Rio said softly, her smile fading into thoughtfulness as she turned to her laptop. She spent the next few hours alternating between writing and flipping through her dog-eared copy of The Waste Land.

 

Alice worked beside her, occasionally humming snatches of music under her breath, the sound a comforting counterpoint to the quiet buzz of the library. It was moments like these—focused, productive, and grounded in the presence of her best friend—that reminded Rio why she loved academia, even when it felt overwhelming.

 

As the light outside began to fade, Rio glanced at her watch. Her dance class was only a couple of hours away, and then, dinner with Lilia. It was going to be a long day, but for now, she felt ready to take it on.

 

 

The soft glow of a desk lamp illuminated Agatha Harkness’s office, the only souce of light in her otherwise dark office, illuminating the stacks of books and papers scattered across her desk. Outside, the campus had quieted, the bustle of the day replaced by the faint hum of distant conversations and footsteps.

 

Aatha sipped her tea—black, unsweetened, and long since gone cold—as she turned to the stack of essays awaiting her attention. Her fountain pen hovered in her hand, poised to strike out an errant phrase or scribble a curt remark in the margins. She took grading seriously, perhaps too seriously, treating it less like an academic chore and more like a craft.

 

Midway through the pile, she paused. An essay titled Fragmentation and the Search for Wholeness in Eliot’s Later Works caught her eye. It was written in the sharp, clear hand of Miss Vidal.

 

Agtha adjusted her glasses and began reading. By the second paragraph, her brow lifted in interest. By the third, she was leaning back in her chair, the faintest hint of a smile playing on her lips.

 

Miss Vidal’s analysis was incisive, her arguments carefully constructed and grounded in textual evidence. There was a subtlety to her insights—a willingness to engage with the uncertainty and contradictions in Eliot’s work rather than smoothing them over. Agatha found herself nodding as she read, her pen marking the margins not with corrections but with the occasional “good” or “yes.”

 

She reached the conclusion, which wove the essay’s threads into a cohesive and compelling argument. Agatha set the paper down and stared at it for a moment, her fingers drumming lightly against her desk. There was something about Miss Vidal’s work that lingered—an undercurrent of passion that felt both familiar and unepxected.

 

Pulling a sheet of grading sheets closer, she began to write her comments with deliberate care.

 

“Miss Vidal, this is an exceptional piece of work. Your analysis is thoughtful and well-articulated, and your willingness to engage with the complexities of Eliot’s later poetry demonstrates both intellectual rigor and creative insight. Keep pushing yourself to explore these ideas further—I suspect they have more to reveal to you.”

 

Agatha signed her name at the bottom, hesitating for the briefest moment before adding: “Well done.”

 

Setting the paper aside, she allowed herself another small smile before returning to the next essay in the pile. But even as she worked, Miss Vidal’s words stayed with her, a reminder that every so often, a student’s brilliance could cut through the routine like light through a crack in the door.

 

The sun had dipped below the horizon, casting Agatha’s office in a deep blue twilight. She rubbed her temples, feeling the fatigue of the day creeping in. Glancing at her watch, she realized it was time to wrap up. Her lips quirked into a rare smile as she gathered her things

 

Grading could wait, but her son could not.

 

Pushing back her chair, Agatha stood and draped her coat over her arm. Her son’s dance class was only a short drive from campus, and she cherished these moments of transition: the shift from her role as a demanding professor tosomething softer and more instinctual—a mother.

 

She locked her office and made her way through the quiet corridors of the English department, her heels echoing faintly against the stone floors. As she stepped outside, the crisp evening air greeted her, and she quickened her pace, eager to see her baby. No matter how draining her day had been, the sight of her son running toward her, his face flushed with the joy of movement, always made it worthwhile.

 

 

The dance center hummed with energy as Agatha stepped inside, the familiar scent of wood polish and faint traces of lavender in the air. She adjusted her coat and made her way toward the classroom where her son’s lesson was wrapping up, her heels muffled by the soft flooring.

 

Peeking through the large observation window, she scanned the room, her sharp gaze softening as she spotted her son – Nicky - among the group of children. He was laughing, his small frame moving with the carefree enthusiasm that only a six-year-old could muster.

 

But what caught Agatha’s attention wasn’t just her son—it was the figure crouched beside him, gently fixing the elastic of his little black ballet slipper.

 

Rio Vidal.

 

For a moment, Agatha stood frozen, a flicker of surprise darting through her. She’d known Miss Vidal was a multifaceted student, but she hadn’t anticipated seeing her here, guiding a group of children with the same focus and precision she displayed in her writing.

 

Rio’s voice carried across the room, calm yet encouraging. “Good job today, everyone! Remember, point your toes during your jetés—otherwise, I’ll have to start calling them bunny hops.”

 

The children giggled, her son included. Rio smiled warmly at them, her easy rapport with the kids evident in the way they crowded around her at the end of the class.

 

As the other children began to trickle out, Rio knelt again to meet Nicky at eye level. “You’ve been working so hard,” she said with a gentle smile, helping him gather his small dance bag. “Your balance is getting better every week. High five?”

 

He grinned, slapping her hand enthusiastically before running toward the door. As he exited the classroom, he spotted Agatha and lit up. “Mama!”

 

Agatha crouched to embrace him, pressing a kiss to his head. “Did you have fun, darling?”

 

“Yeah! Miss Rio said I did really good today!” he replied, his voice brimming with pride.

 

Agatha stood, her gaze drifting to Rio, who was tidying up the studio. Rio glanced up, and their eyes met. For a second, there was a flicker of recognition—surprise and a slight blush appearing across Rio’s face, quickly replaced by something more composed.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha said smoothly, stepping into the room with her son in toe.

 

“Dr. Harkness.” Rio’s voice was polite, her expression unreadable but tinged with a hint of curiosity.

 

“I wasn’t aware you were a teacher here,” Agatha said, her tone neutral but edged with intrigue.

 

io shrugged lightly, tucking a stray lock of hair behind her ear. “It’s something I do on the side. Keeps me sane between thesis chapters.” Her smile was faint, but genuine. “We take turns with the other teachers.”

 

Agatha’s son tugged at her hand, looking up at Rio with wide eyes. “Mama, Miss Rio’s the best! Can I show you my plié?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly. “Perhaps another time, darling.” She glanced at Rio again, a spark of approuval in her sharp blue gaze. “It seems your talents extend beyond academia, Miss Vidal.”

 

Rio tilted her head slightly, her blush returning. “Oh, it’s just something I enjoy. And the kids are amazing.”

 

Agatha smiled softly, and said her goodbye, echoed by an enthusiastic but tired Nicky, hanging off her arm, almreay pulling her forward.

 

As Agatha escorted her son out of the studio, her mind lingered on the unexpected encounter. There was more to Rio Vidal than met the eye—and, somehow, that only made her all the more intriguing.

 

*

*

*

Quiet Night

*

*

*

Words move, music moves

Only in time; but that which is only living

Can only die. Words, after speech, reach

Into the silence.

Only by the form, the pattern,

Can words or music reach

The stillness, as a Chinese jar still

Moves perpetually in its stillness.

       (Eliot, “Burnt Norton”, Four Quartets)

 

 

The dance center emptied out slowly, the sounds of laughter and scuffling feet fading into the crisp evening air as Rio locked up the studio. She slung her bag over her shoulder, her muscles pleasantly sore from the day’s lessons. The encounter with Dr. Harkness lingered in the back of her mind, unexpected and strangely significant, though she brushed the thought aside as she made her way toward Lilia’s house.

 

The walk wasn’t far—Lilia’s small, cozy home was nestled just off campus, tucked into a quiet neighborhood lined with tall trees. The warm glow of the porch light greeted Rio as she climbed the steps and rang the doorbell.

 

Moments later, the door swung open to reveal Lilia, her warm smile framed by soft curls that had gone gray over the years. “There’s my girl,” she said, pulling Rio into a hug that smelled of spices and fresh bread. “Come in, you must be starving.”

 

“Always,” Rio said, stepping inside and shedding her coat. The house was as inviting as ever, filled with the scent of Lilia’s cooking and the faint crackle of a fire in the living room.

 

“Sit, sit,” Lilia urged, gesturing to the small kitchen table already set with mismatched plates and bowls. “How was your day?”

 

Rio sank into a chair, letting out a long breath. “Busy. Classes, grading, dance…oh, and Dr. Harkness showed up to pick up her kid from my class.”

 

Lilia’s eyebrows shot up as she ladled stew into a bowl for Rio. “Dr. Harkness? Your professor? Small world.”

 

“Tell me about it,” Rio said, shaking her head. “It felt…weird, seeing her there. Like she stepped out of the seminar room and into my other life. But her kid’s adorable. He’s in my six-year-old group.”

 

Lilia chuckled, setting the bowl in front of Rio. “Sounds like fate’s having a bit of fun with you. And how are you holding up with everything else? Thesis work? Band rehearsals?”

 

Rio picked up her spoon, letting the rich aroma of the stew soothe her. “It’s a lot, but I’m managing. The band’s got a gig this Friday, and my supervisor actually liked my latest draft, so…progress.”

 

“Good.” Lilia sat across from her, a knowing look in her eyes. “Just don’t forget to take care of yourself in the process. You’ve got a lot on your plate, but you’re not in this alone, you know.”

 

Rio met her gaze and smiled, a wave of gratitude washing over her. “I know, Lilia. Thanks for always reminding me.”

 

They ate in comfortable silence for a while, the soft clink of spoons against bowls filling the space.

 

After dinner, as the evening settled into a quiet hum, Rio stood up and helped Lilia clear the table. The familiar routine felt comforting, like a small ritual that tethered her to this place—this home—that had been her refuge for years.

 

As Lilia moved into the living room to clean up, Rio wandered slowly around the house, her eyes drawn to the framed photographs hanging on the walls. She had seen them countless times before, but tonight, they felt different. The images seemed to capture more than just moments frozen in time—they held memories, stories of her life before she came to Lilia, of the woman who had become her anchor in the stomr.

 

One photo caught her attention—Lilia, ten years younger, standing on a beach with a wide smile, her arms wrapped around a younger version of Rio. SHe felt a pang of nostalgia. She could almost hear the laughter in the photo, the carefree energy that had once felt so foreign to her.

 

Rio traced the edges of the frame with her fingers, the weight of the years suddenly more apparent. She remembered the first time Lilia had took her in, a scared, angry teenager who had known nothing but the instability of the foster care system. At the time, she hadn’t trusted anyone—least of all a stranger offering a roof over her head. But Lilia had been patient, always steady, always there, guiding her through those rough years with unwavering tryst and strength.

 

Moving on, Rio’s gaze landed on another photo—this one taken at a ballet recital. A teenage Rio clad in a blue leotard and her hair up in a bun stood with a bright, shy smile, Lilia’s arm draped around Rio’s shoulders who was holding a bunch of flowers, their faces both flushed with pride. It had been her very first glower bouqet. Rio could see in the picture how far she had come, how much Lilia had helped her rebuild herself, piece by piece.

 

She paused at a larger framed portrait on the wall near the hallway, one that always caught her eye. It was of the two of them, smiling together at a small family gathering, arms wrapped around each other like they belonged. Lilia’s face radiated warmth, and Rio looked so much younger, maybe seventeen or eighteen, her features softer, her expression more guarded than it was now.

 

Rio leaned closer to the photo, studying her younger self—the girl who had been so lost, so broken. She barely recognized her. It was hard to imagine that person was the same one who stood here now, a PhD student, a dance teacher, someone who had found a place in the world.

 

Lilia appeared in the doorway, watching her quietly for a moment before speaking. “You always spend a little extra time with those pictures,” she said softly, her voice gentle.

 

Rio smiled faintly, turning to meet Lilia’s eyes. “I guess I get lost in them sometimes.”

 

Lilia nodded, crossing the room to stand beside her. “I keep them around to remind myself of how far we’ve come. Of how much you’ve grown.”

 

Rio swallowed the lump in her throat, her emotions welling up unexpectedly. “I still can’t believe you took me in,” she said, her voice thick with emotion. “I never would have made it without you.”

 

Lilia placed a hand on her shoulder, her touch firm and reassuring. “You made it, Rio. You always had it in you. I just helped you find your way.”

 

The words hung in the air, and for a long moment, Rio allowed herself to feel the weight of them—the depth of their meaning. She wasn’t sure where she would be without Lilia, but in this moment, she knew exactly where she was: home.

 

She looked at the photos one last time, taking a deep breath, before finally pulling away. “Thank you, Mom,” she whispered. It was a word she didn’t use all the time, but it held weight when she did.

 

Lilia simply nodded, her eyes soft. “Always, sweet girl. Always.”

 

In the large Harkness home, the quiet of the evening settled in Agatha’s big yet cozy living room. She moved with ease, setting aside her long blue coat and placing her bag on the couch before glancing at the clock. It was a little later than usual, but Nicky had still been full of energy when she’d picked him up from his dance class but Nicky, as always, had found a second wind after his brief nap in the car. He was never too tired to talk about dance.

 

 

“Alright, my little dancer,” Agatha said gently as she entered Nicky’s room, her voice warm yet firm with the authority of a mother who had long since perfected the art of bedtime routines. “Time to get into bed.”

 

Nicky, with his ever-present enthusiasm, jumped onto his bed and wriggled under the covers, his eyes wide with excitement. “Mama, Miss Rio said I did really good today! I did my jump just like she showed me. And she laughed when I did it, Mama! She said I had really good balance!”

 

Agatha’s lips quirked at the mention of Miss Rio. Nicky’s admiration for his dance teacher was clear—he could hardly stop talking about her, his face glowing with pride. “That’s wonderful, sweetheart,” Agatha said, sitting down beside him on the edge of the bed. “It sounds like Miss Rio is a really good teacher.”

 

“Yeah! She said I’m getting better, Mama.” Nicky grinned, his small hand reaching up to grasp Agatha’s. “I’m going to be a ballerino like her, Mama, but I’ll be better!”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, brushing a lock of hair from his forehead. “You’re already a little ballerino, Nicky. You’ll be great.” She paused, her fingers tracing the edge of the blanket. “You really like Miss Rio, don’t you?”

 

Nicky nodded, his face lighting up. “She’s nice,” he said, his voice turning softer, sleep creeping in at the edges. “She’s always laughing, and she helps me when I don’t get things right.” He paused, his brows furrowing in thought before he added, “And she smells nice too! Like… flowers.”

 

Agatha raised an amused brow. “Flowers?”

 

“Yeah! Like the park. Or maybe like the sun.” Nicky yawned, his grip on her hand loosening. “I like Miss Rio, Mama.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened as she stroked his hair, her thoughts turning inward. She had only briefly interacted with Rio Vidal at the dance center, but hearing Nicky talk so freely about her, his admiration so genuine, made Agatha even more curious. There was something about her student, something more than the impressive academic talent she showed in class.

 

The way she taught children—patient, encouraging, seemingly able to make them feel seen and valued—had been evident even in their brief exchange at the dance center. But Agatha could tell there was more beneath the surface, something she hadn’t quite placed yet.

 

“Sounds like Miss Rio is a very special teacher,” Agatha said, her voice quiet as she watched Nicky’s eyes flutter with sleep.

 

“She is!” Nicky murmured, his voice already growing drowsy. “She says I’m getting better, Mama…”

 

“I have no doubt,” she murmured, pressing a lingering kiss to his forehead and bringing his blue stuffed dragon closer to his chest. “Get some rest now, sweetheart. I love you more than the moon.”

 

“More than the stars?” he mumbled sleepily.

 

Agatha smiled, smoothing his curls one last time. “More than the stars.”

 

AsNicky drifted off to sleep, his soft breathing filling the room, Agtaha sat for a moment longer, her mind still on her student. There was something undeniably intriguing about Rio Vidal. And as the quiet stretched on, her curiosity deepened, pulling her thoughts back to the girl who had been so effortlessly kind and skiled with Nicky, and who, in Agatha’s eyes, carried a certain mystery that was hard to ignore.

 

 

A few days later, Agatha stood at the front of the seminar room. Her seminar on Modernist poets was always well attended, and she was used to the quiet buzz of eager minds settling into their seats. The chairs clinked softly, papers shuffled, and the scent of freshly brewed coffee lingered in the air—an essential part of every class.

 

Agatha took a deep breath, her gaze sweeping over the room, noting the familiar faces of her students, including the ever-focused Rio Vidal. Rio sat near the front in the second row, as always, her posture straight, her attention ready. She hadn’t missed a single seminar since the semester began, and Agatha found herself watching Rio’s concentration, her curiosity about the student only growing since their unexpected encounter at the dance center.

 

“Good morning, everyone,” Agatha said, her voice carrying effortlessly across the room. “Today, we’ll be exploring T.S. Eliot’s The Waste Land, with a focus on its fragmented structure and its exploration of disillusionment in the post-war world. I know it’s a lot to digest, but I expect you all to bring your insights, as always.”

 

There was a murmur of assent from the students as Agatha moved to the whiteboard, scribbling down the key points for the day’s discussion. Her sharp eyes flicked over to Rio, who was already flipping through her notes, her pen poised to take careful, methodical annotations.

 

As the class progressed, Agatha guided the students through Eliot’s dense imagery and fragmented verses. She had a way of drawing out connections that seemed buried beneath the surface, a skill that kept even the most hesitant of students engaged. Rio, as expected, had already dived deep into the text, her insights cutting through the surface of the material with ease. Agatha found herself drawn to Rio’s answers, the thoughtfulness in her responses, the way she challenged the traditional readings of Eliot’s work.

 

“Miss Vidal, would you care to expand on your point about Eliot’s use of fragmentation as a reflection of post-war anxiety?” Agatha asked, her voice smooth but carrying an underlying curiosity that was hard to hide.

 

Rio glanced up, her eyes focused but calm, her hand trambling the only sign of her nervousness. “Of course, Dr. Harkness. I think Eliot’s fragmented style mimics the fractured nature of human consciousness during that time. The chaos of the modern world is reflected not just in the themes but in the structure of the poem itself. It’s as though the poet is trying to piece together something lost or irretrievable, but the pieces never quite fit.”

 

Agatha leaned against the desk, her gaze fixed on Rio, noting the passion in her delivery, the confidence in her voice despite the quiet intensity she always carried. There was something about Rio’s approach to literature—something reflective, yet raw—that made Agatha feel both impressed and intrigued.

 

“That’s an excellent observation,” Agatha responded, her tone warmer than usual. “Eliot’s use of fragmentation might indeed suggest an inherent disintegration in how we perceive the world—this constant attempt to make sense of the chaos around us.”

 

The class continued, but Agatha found herself paying closer attention to Rio. Her mind wandered slightly, thinking back to their encounter at the dance center, her son’s glowing praise of Rio’s teaching, and the effortless warmth she’d exuded. There was more to Rio than met the eye, and Agatha couldn’t help but wonder about the layers beneath her composed exterior. The thoughtful, articulate student in front of her seemed like a far cry from the carefree, slihhtly chaotic dance instructor who had interacted with her son only days ago.

 

As the seminar came to a close, Agatha dismissed the class, and the students gathered their things. Rio paused, gathering her notes slowly, her fingers brushing against the edges of the pages as she stood. She glanced at Agatha, and for a moment, their eyes met—a silent exchange passing between them.

 

“Thank you for the discussion, Dr. Harkness,” Rio said, her voice soft but sincere.

 

“Always a pleasure, Miss Vidal,” Agatha replied, her curiosity piqued once more. “I look forward to hearing more of your insights as the semester progresses.”

 

Rio gave her a small smile and a nod before heading out, leaving Agatha standing there for a moment longer, her thoughts swirling around the enigmatic student who continued to captivate her attention in ways she hadn’t expected.

 

 

Friday night arrived with the familiar hum of excitement in the air of the campus’s bar. Rio stood backstage, her drumsticks in hand, the cool evening air filtering through the back door of the venue. The bar was dimly lit, filled with anticipation as people chatted and sipped their drinks. The sound of a band tuning their instruments and the occasional burst of laughter made the space feel alive, buzzing with energy.

 

Alice, standing beside her, adjusted her bass while Jen tuned in her guitar, and flashed Rio a wide grin. “Ready for this?” she asked, her voice full of playful excitement. Her outfit—girly, pink, with a bit of sparkle—was as bold as her personality, contrasting Rio’s more understated look in a simple black tee and jeans, her hair loose around her face, sotfening her features.

 

“Always,” Rio replied, giving a quick nod. Her heart raced with the familiar mix of nerves and exhilaration. It had been a while since she had played a live gig with Alice’s band (madz of three people really), and she was itching for the adrenaline rush of the crowd, the beat of the drums pulsing through her veins.

 

The sound of the opening chords broke through their conversation as the lights dimmed and the crowd grew louder. The stage manager gave them a nod, signaling it was their turn to take the stage.

 

“Let’s rock this,” Alice said, clapping Rio’s shoulder before they made their way to the stage, joining the rest of the band.

 

The crowd’s energy hit them immediately as they took their positions. The bass rumbled in Rio’s chest, and the rhythm section took hold of the room like an electric charge. As the first notes rang out, Rio could feel the beat taking over, her body moving instinctively with the rhythm. Her hands flew across the drum kit with practiced precision, hitting the toms and cymbals with the ease of someone who had spent countless hours perfecting the craft. THe music was like an extension of her body, flowing from her limbs, and the audience could feel it too—the way she became one with the beat.

 

The band played through their set, and Rio was lost in the music. The lights, the cheers, the pulse of the crowd—it all melted away, leaving only the sound of their instruments filling the air. She could see Alice grinning on stage, her bass thloud, her energy contagious. For a moment, Rio felt like she could do this forever—feel the rush of the music, feel alive in the moment. It was a stark contrast to the quieter life she led outside the spotlight.

 

Halfway through the set, the music reached a crescendo, the crowd swaying with the rhythm as they fed off the band’s energy. Alice leaned toward Rio, shouting over the music, “This is our best crowd yet! They love us!”

 

Rio grinned in return, drumming harder, faster, and feeling the rhythm of the room like an electric current. Every beat was a statement, every crash of the cymbals an echo of her heartbeat, and for the first time in days, her mind felt free—no worries, no responsibilities, just the music.

 

As the final song of their set approached, Alice turned to her, giving a knowing look. Rio nodded in response, a slight grin tugging at her lips. It was time for their signature closing number. Alice’s fingers moved to the first note, and Rio took a deep breath, her hands hovering over the drumsticks, ready to unleash.

 

The final notes echoed through the club as the band finished their set, the crowd erupting into applause. Rio’s heart pounded in her chest, her body buzzing with the echoes of the performance. She could feel the sweat on her brow, the adrenaline still coursing through her veins.

 

As the lights brightened and the applause continued, Rio exchanged a quick look with Alice.

 

“You were amazing out there,” Alice said as they made their way offstage, still buzzing with the energy of the performance.

 

“Thanks,” Rio replied, her smile wide. “You were awesome too.”

 

The band gathered backstage, catching their breath and high-fiving each other. It was a moment of camaraderie, and Rio reveled in it, even as her mind drifted slightly—perhaps just for a moment—to the things waiting for her offstage, like her thesis, her classes, and her curious professor, Dr. Harkness. But for now, the night was theirs, and Rio had no intention of letting go of the thrill of the gig just yet.

 

Jen, the band’s guitarist, stood nearby, her fingers still lightly vibrating from the final strums of the set. As a PhD student in chemistry, she was the type to approach both her academic work and her music with a meticulous yet passionate attitude, sometimes haughty but always loyal. While her field was worlds away from the music scene, Jen had always been able to balance both worlds with ease. Her eyes sparkled with the same intensity whether she was discussing chemical reactions or laying down a killer riff on her guitar.

 

“Nice work out there, Rio,” Jen said, leaning against the wall as she wiped the sweat from her forehead with the back of her hand. Her voice was warm, and she flashed Rio a grin.

 

“Thanks, Jen,” Rio replied, returning the smile. “You were on fire tonight.”

 

Jen chuckled, adjusting the strap of her guitar as she looked around at the others. “You know, it’s always a rush. Feels good to let go of the academic stuff for a while.”

 

Rio laughed softly. “Tell me about it. I think the only time I’m not thinking about dead poets or my thesis is when I’m playing drums with you guys.”

 

Jen raised an eyebrow, her smile teasing. “You mean there’s more to you than just those things? I thought I was the only one who could balance science and music.”

 

“I try,” Rio replied with a wink, picking at her always-present forest green nail polish, feeling the post-performance glow still buzzing in her veins.

 

Jen grinned and glanced toward Alice, who was already chatting with some of the audience members who had come over to congratulate them. “Well, I may be a chemistry nerd, but this… this makes it all worth it.” She paused for a moment. “Though, I could really use a drink right now.”

 

“Agreed,” Rio said, adjusting her own jacket. “Let’s grab something before we all collapse into bed.”

 

The group gathered their things, packing up their instruments and heading out into the cool night air, their laughter and chatter blending with the hum of the campus nightlife. 

 

*

*

*

 

 

A New Supervisor

*

*

*

To be conscious is not to be in time

But only in time can the moment in the rose-garden,

The moment in the arbour where the rain beat,

The moment in the draughty church at smokefall

Be remembered; involved with past and future.

Only through time time is conquered.

            (T. S Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

It wasn’t long after the band’s gig that the news came. She was sitting in the small library nook on campus, sipping her coffee, when she received the email. Her PhD supervisor, who had guided her through the early stages of her thesis, had been offered a higher position at another college across the country and had decided to take it to advance his career. The decision had come suddenly, and as a result, Rio would need to be reassigned to a new supervisor.

 

Rio stared at her screen, rereading the email as if the words might change the second time around.

 

Her supervisor was leaving.

 

Just like that, the already precarious balance she had been maintaining—the endless cycle of research, writing, adjusting, and rewriting—felt like it had shifted beneath her.

 

She wasn’t particularly fond of him, but he had been a constant. She had learned how to work with his expectations, how to anticipate his feedback, how to navigate his sometimes overly critical comments without taking them to heart. And now, after months of careful academic maneuvering, she was being thrown into the unknown.

 

She let out a slow breath, her fingers tightening around her coffee cup. A reassignment. That meant a new supervisor, a new dynamic, a new set of expectations. And at this stage in her PhD, that could be either a blessing r a disaster.

 

A chair scraped across the floor nearby, snapping her out of her thoughts.

 

“Okay, you’re making that face,” Alice said, dropping into the seat across from her.

 

Rio blinked. “What face?”

 

“The ‘I just got an email that ruined my week’ face.” Alice leaned forward, propping her chin on her hand. “So, spill.”

 

Rio turned her laptop around so Alice could see the email. As Alice scanned it, her eyebrows lifted. “Damn. He really just up and left, huh?”

 

“Apparently.” Rio leaned back in her chair, rubbing her temple. “And now I get reassigned to… someone.”

 

Alice pursed her lips. “Someone better? Because, no offense, but he was not my favorite person.”

 

Rio let out a dry laugh. “No argument there. But at least I knew what to expect. Now I have to figure out how to impress someone else, make sure they don’t tear aparteverything I’ve already written, and hope they don’t have some entirely different vision for my thesis.”

 

Alice tapped a finger against her mug. “You know… this could actually be a good thing.”

 

Rio shot her a look. “Do you know how risky this is?”

 

Alice shrugged. “Sure, but also—your last guy wasn’t exactly inspiring. Maybe this new person will actually get your work. Maybe they’ll push you in the right ways.”

 

Rio sighed, drumming her fingers on the table. “Or maybe they’ll make my life a living hell.”

 

Alice smirked. “Ah, yes. The thrilling gamble of academia.”

 

Roi groaned, slumping forward dramatically. “Why did I do this to myself?”

 

Alice patted her hand sympathetically. “Because you’re brilliant, dedicated, and a little masochistic.”

 

Rio snorted. “That last part is definitely true.”

 

Alice took a sip of her coffee. “So… when do you find out who your new supervisor is?”

 

Rio glanced back at her screen. “It says they’ll inform me by the end of the week.”

 

Alice grinned. “Perfect. That gives us a few days to stress-drink about it.”

 

Rio huffed a laugh, but the tension in her shoulders didn’t quite ease. No matter how Alice spun it, the uncertainty still loomed over her.

 

She just had to hope that whoever was assigned to her wasn’t about to turn her entire PhD into a nightmare.

 

 

And indeed, on Friday, at noon sharp, the answer came.

 

She had been sitting in the library again, her laptop open, but her focus shot. Her fingers tapped a restless rhythm against the table as she refreshed her inbox for what had to be the twentieth time in the last five minutes. Around her, students chatting, the librarian shushing them, and pages flipping barely registered.

 

Then—

 

New Email: PhD Supervision Reassignment.

 

She jumped on it as if it held the universe’s secrets, eager to discover who had her fate between their hands.

 

She scanned the formal pleasantries, barely registering them. But as she scrolled down the email, her breath caught in her throat, and she felt like the world had stopped turning.

 

Because there, in the middle of the email was the name of her new supervisor: Dr. Agtaha Harkness.

 

The words blurred for a second.

 

Rio’s grip tightened on the edge of her laptop as her brain fought to process what she was seeing.

 

Dr. Harkness had agreed to take Rio on as a new student.

 

her mind swirled. This was unexpected, to say the least. It had always been a subtle pull—a fascination she couldn’t quite shake—toward Dr. Hakness. Agtaha had a way of seeing things that made Rio question her own perspectives. And now, she was about to work under her direct supervision.

 

The transition wouldn’t be easy, but Rio couldn’t deny the underlying excitement. This was a challenge, and something about it felt both intimidating and exhilarating. Agtaha, with her fierce intellect and commanding aura, was not the type of professor to let anything slide. She had a reputation for pushing her students to their limits, a trait Rio had seen firsthand in her seminars. But maybe that was exactly what Rio needed—someone who would help her refine her ideas, push her boundaries, and perhaps even help her discover parts of herself she hadn’t yet explored.

 

The thought lingered in her mind as she closed her laptop and gathered her things. She couldn’t help but wonder: What would it be like, working directly with Dr. Harkness? And what did this shift mean for her own academic journey?

 

A few hours later, after a long morning of classes and research, Rio met Alice for lunch at their usual spot on campus—an outdoor café near the library. They grabbed their usual order, and as they sat down at a small table under the shade of a tree, Rio couldn’t help but feel a little anxious. She had barely processed the news of her supervisor transfer, but now she was faced with telling Alice and bear her endless teasing.

 

“Hey, I’ve got something to tell you,” she said, leaning forward a little. “You’re not going to believe it.”

 

Alice raised an eyebrow, her curiosity piqued. “Oh? This sounds good.”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment before she dropped the bomb. “You remember my old supervisor left, right?”

 

Alice huffed, offended. “Of course, I remember. Girl, I’m not that dumb.”

 

Rio ignored her. “Well, I’ve been assigned a new one.”

 

Alice’s eyes widened, and she leaned in, clearly eager for more. “Who?”

 

Rio swallowed, the name suddenly feeling strange in her mouth. “Dr. Agatha Harkness.”

 

“No freaking way.”

 

Rio let out a laugh—short, disbelieving. “Oh, it’s real.”

 

Alice blinked. Then grinned. “Holy shit. Your academic crush is now your supervisor?”

 

“Don’t call it that,” Rio hissed, glancing around like someone might overhear.

 

Alice ignored her, leaning in like she had just been handed the juiciest gossip of the year. “How did this happen? I mean, I know you’re one of the top students in the department, but Agatha freaking Harkness doesn’t just take people in.”

 

Rio exhaled sharply, raking a hand through her hair. “I don’t know. I mean, I guess my research aligns with her interests, but… I never thought she’d actually—” She shook her head, still processing. “She must have chosen me.”

 

Alice smirked. “Well, obviously. And look, you’ve been obsessed with her work for years. This could be amazing.”

 

“Or terrifying.” Rio sank back into her chair. “She’s—she’s Dr. Harkness, Alice. Have you seen the way she eviscerates people in class when they don’t meet her standards? What if she hates my thesis? What if she tears apart everything I’ve done so far?”

 

Alice shrugged. “Then she makes you better. That’s kind of what you signed up for with a PhD, right?”

 

Rio groaned. “Not this level of intensity.”

 

Alice sipped her coffee, watching her with amused eyes. “So… what’s the plan?”

 

Rio inhaled deeply, willing herself to think. “I guess I set up a meeting. Try to figure out where she stands. And—” She ran a hand down her face. “Try not to completely panic before then.”

 

Alice grinned, raising her coffee cup like a toast. “Good luck with that.” She leaned back in her seat before bursting into a knowing grin. “Oh. My. God. Rio Vidal, you are so screwed.”

 

Rio’s face flushed instantly, her hands awkwardly wrapping around her coffee cup. “What do you mean?”

 

Alice wiggled her eyebrows, leaning back in her chair with a teasing smirk. “Oh, come on. The Agatha Harkness? The one you’ve been staring at in class for months? The one who practically exudes ‘I’m too cool for you’ energy? You’re about to spend a lot of time with her, aren’t you?”

 

Rio groaned, resting her forehead on her hand. “It’s not like that, Alice. I mean, yes, she’s… intimidating. But she’s also brilliant. And she’s going to be my supervisor. It’s, uh, professional.”

 

“Oh, sure,” Alice teased, sipping her drink. “Professional. If by ‘professional’ you mean you’re going to be spending hours in her office, just the two of you, discussing modernist poets and somehow—somehow—I don’t see how that will not reinforce your intense, intellectual crush. You sure it’s your thesis you’re writing about? Because it sounds like you’re writing about her.”

 

Rio let out a long, exasperated sigh. “You’re ridiculous. It’s not like that. It’s just that… she’s really smart, okay? And she’s justmy new supervisor. It’ll be fine.”

 

Alice raised an eyebrow. “Fine, sure. I’m just saying… if you ever need a distraction from all that, you know where to find me. Just remember—professional.” She emphasized the word with a teasing wink, making Rio roll her eyes.

 

“You’re impossible,” she muttered, trying to hide the flush creeping up her neck.

 

“Yeah, but you love me anyway.” Alice grinned. “But seriously, I’m excited for you. Agatha Harkness? That’s a huge deal. Just… don’t forget about us little people when you’re deep in your thesis and making profound discoveries about obscure poets and stuff.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, her nerves easing a bit under Alice’s lighthearted teasing. “I promise I won’t forget you, babe. You’ll still have me around to play drums at your gigs, even if I’m drowning in academic work.”

 

“That’s the spirit!” Alice clinked her cup against Rio’s. “Now, go and conquer that thesis of yours. And don’t let Dr. Harness bite you with her intellectual powers. Even if I’m sure you wouldn’t even mind.”

 

“Alice!” Rio cried out, blushing to the tip of her ears and coving her face with her hands, shaking her head. “I’ll try my best.”

 

As they continued chatting, Rio couldn’t shake the feeling of butterflies in her stomach. There was no denying it—this new chapter with Agatha Harkness as her supervisor was going to be a challenge. But a part of her couldn’t help but feel that it might also be an opportunity for something more, even if she wasn’t sure yet what that was.

 

 

The day of Rio’ first formal meeting with her new supervisor arrived sooner than she had expected. No amount of preparation had eased the low hum of nerves that had settled in her stomach the moment she’d woken up that morning.

 

She had spent hours going over her thesis notes the night before, marking key points in the margins, reviewing every potential weak spot Agatha might pick apart. It hadn’t done much to steady her. Because this—having Agatha Harkness as her supervisor—was entirely different from sitting in her seminar, absorbing her lectures, and attempting to impress from a comfortable distance.

 

Now, there was no distance.

 

Rio arrived at the faculty building early, walking down the quiet corridor with slow, measured steps. The hallway smelled faintly of old paper and coffee, the usual scent of academia. The overhead lights buzzed softly, the only sound accompanying her footsteps. She clenched her thesis notebook a little tighter in her hand as she approached Agtah’s office.

 

Through the small window on the door, she could see her new supervisor at her desk, adjusting a neat stack of papers, flipping through them with effortless precision. The sight sent a fresh wave of nerves through Rio.

 

She inhaled deeply, forcing herself to calm the slight tremor in her fingers before raising a hand and knocking. The sound felt loud against the hush of the hallway, echoing more than she’d anticipated.

 

A pause. Then—

 

“Come in.”

 

Agatha’s voice, rich and smooth, carried easily through the door.

 

Rio pushed it open and stepped inside.

 

The office was exactly as she had imagined it—warm, but not in a comforting way. More in the way of controlled intellect, carefully curated over time. Floor-to-ceiling bookshelves lined the walls, crammed with volumes on literature, philosophy, history, even a few psychology texts. A reading lamp cast a soft golden glow over the desk, where Agtaha sat with her usual air of quiet command.

 

She was dressed in a crisp white button-down, sleeves cuffed at her elbows, her dark hair falling neatly well past her shoulders. There was something effortless about her presence, something completely self-assured. As Rio stepped further inside, Agatha looked up, her sharp eyes locking onto her student with unsettling focus.

 

For a brief moment, Rio was hyperaware of herself—her brown corduroy overalls, the long-sleeved green shirt she’d thrown on that morning, the slight scuff on the toe of her well-worn Converse. She felt young. Unpolished.

 

And Agatha—well, she had never once seemed anything less than composed.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha greeted, her voice even, unreadable. She gestured toward the chair opposite her desk. “Please, take a seat.”

 

Rio obeyed without hesitation, lowering herself into the chair as she gripped her notebook tightly in her lap.

 

She swallowed against the nervous energy bubbling in her chest as she sat down, shifting slightly in the chair. The room smelled faintly of old books and black tea, the kind of scent that felt timeless, as if it had always existed in this space. Agatha regarded her with that same unreadable expression she always carried in class—cool, assessing, giving away nothing.

 

“Before we discuss the specifics of your thesis,” Agatha began, folding her hands atop her desk, “let’s establish expectations.”

 

Rio straightened slightly, nodding.

 

Agtaha’s gaze remained steady. “I assume you’re aware that I have high standards for mystudents.”

 

Obviously. rio had spent the past two years watching her eviscerate half-hearted arguments in seminar discussions with surgical precision. It was part of what made her so fascinating. Rio cleared her throat. “Yes, Dr. Harkness.”

 

“Good,” Agatha replied, as if she had never expected any other answer. “I agreed to take you on because I see potential in your work. But I also expect discipline, precision, and intellectual curiosity.” She leaned back slightly, studying Rio with the same analytical sharpness that she used on poetry. “Do you believe you can meet those expectations?”

 

Rio felt her pulse in her throat but forced herself to hold Agatha’s gaze. “Yes.” Her voice came out steadier than she expected. “I do.”

 

Agatha inclined her head slightly, something like approval flickering across her otherwise unreadable features. “Good. Now, I’d like to hear more about your work. I’ve read the latest draft your previous supervisor forwarded me, but I need to hear it from you.”

 

Rio straightened slightly, feeling the weight of Agatha scrutiny settle over her like a heavy cloak. Her palms were damp against the surface of her notebook, but she didn’t let herself falter. This was it—her first real chance to prove herself.

 

“Yes,” she began, clearing her throat. “I’ve been thinking a lot about the way Death is represented in poetry—not just as a theme, but as a presence that lingers behind the words, shaping the tone and structure of the poems even when it isn’t explicitly named. For many Modernist poets, Death isn’t just a subject to be written about—it’s something that seeps into the very fabric of their work, influencing the rhythm, the language, even the way time is perceived within the poem. It’s almost as if Death is a figure waiting in the wings, silent but omnipresent.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, her expression unreadable but clearly intrigued. “Go on,” she murmured, steepling her fingers in front of her.

 

Rio took a breath, her confidence growing as she found her rhythm. “I’m particularly interested in how poets like T.S. Eliot, Ezra Pound, and William Carlos Williams engage with death in their work—not always in overt ways, but in a way that lingers in the background. Eliot’s Prufrock, for instance, is soaked in existential dread—not just the fear of literal death, but the death of meaning, of purpose, of selfhood. There’s a profound anxiety about time slipping away, about being forgotten before one even truly exists.

 

“And then there’s Pound’s In a Station of the Metro—a two-line poem, deceptively simple, but haunted by the idea of transience, of lives flickering and vanishing before they can be grasped. It reads almost like an epitaph, a fleeting moment preserved just before it’s lost forever. And Williams—Spring and All is fascinating in how it plays with destruction and rebirth. The prose and verse sections seem to kill and resurrect each other, a cycle that mirrors life and death itself. His treatment of death is so deeply tied to perception, to the way we see and experience the world.”

 

Agatha listened intently, her eyes never once leaving Rio’s face. There was no nodding, no interruptions, just an unwavering gaze that made Rio feel as though every word she spoke was being weighed, measured, tested.

 

“And what do you think this ‘presence of Death’ ultimately means for these poets?” Agatha asked at last. “Why is it so central to their work? What are they trying to do with it?”

 

Rio hesitated, turning the question over in her mind. This was the heart of her thesis—the part she had been struggling to articulate with absolute clarity. Dr. Harkness was dead on. She swallowed and pushed forward.

 

“I think it’s tied to their sense of disillusionment,” she said. “These poets were grappling with the aftermath of World War I. Death wasn’t an abstract concept for them—it was real, immediate. It lingered in cities reduced to rubble, in the loss of an entire generation. But it wasn’t just about physical death. It was about the death of ideals, of certainty, of the belief that the world was ordered and meaningful.”

 

Rio met Agatha’s eyes for a second before refocusing and jumping right back in.

 

“Modernist poetry reflects that sense of fragmentation—how do you write about a world that no longer makes sense? How do you find meaning in it? Death isn’t just an ending in these poems—it’s a rupture, a loss of coherence. It shapes the way time moves in their work, the way memories surface and dissolve, the way identity itself becomes unstable, becomes noise and then turns into silence. I think,” she added, voice quieter but firm, “this silence is particularly loud.”

 

Agatha was silent for a moment, considering. Then, finally, she nodded, her expression still unreadable. “Interesting,” she murmured, tapping her pen against the desk. “You’re framing Death as both a literal and structural force. I think there’s potential in that argument. But what’s your angle, Miss Vidal? What’s your precise argument?”

 

A flicker of excitement sparked in Rio’s chest at the challenge. She was used to being asked what she thought, but Agatha was pushing her to go deeper. She was asking how.

 

“I want to argue that Modernist poets use Death not just as a theme, but as a lens through which they examine the breakdown of meaning in the modern world,” Rio said, her words coming faster now. “It’s not just something they write about—it structures their work, like a second writer shaping the text from within. Death dictates the way their poems unfold, the way thoughts fragment, the way time becomes unstable. It’s the underlying force that gives shape to their existential questions, their anxieties about identity, their relationship with memory and loss.”

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, her fingers tapping rhythmically on the desk as she absorbed Rio’s words. “You have a solid concept here, Miss Vidal. I’m intrigued by your interpretation of Death as an invisible structural force rather than just a subject.” A brief pause, then—“But I need to see more. More textual analysis. More rigor in your close readings. You can’t just present an idea—you have to prove it. I want to see you push beyond the obvious connections. Consider how Death functions in relation to alienation, to identity, to modernity itself. Don’t settle for a surface reading.”

 

Rio nodded quickly, already scribbling notes in the margins of her notebook. “Of course. I’ve already started looking at a few passages, but I’ll go deeper—especially in how death interacts with their treatment of time and perception.”

 

Agtha gave a small, approving nod. “Good. And be prepared to challenge your own readings. I expect rigor in your analysis. I will be watching closely.” She met Rio’s gaze, sharp and steady. “This will not be easy work, Miss Vidal. But if you’re truly committed to it, it will beworth it.”

 

Rio swallowed, feeling the weight of Agatha’s expectations settle over her. But strangely, she didn’t feel overwhelmed. If anything, she felt energized. Agatha wasn’t just testing her—she was pushing her toward something greater, something sharper, something real.

 

“I won’t disappoint you, Dr. Harkness,” Rio said, voice steady. “I am committed to this.”

 

Agatha studied her for a moment, then allowed a slow, knowing smile to appear on her lips. It was the kind of smile that carried both approval and a challenge.

 

“We’ll see, Miss Vidal,” she murmured. “We’ll see.”

 

She tapped a stack of papers on her desk. “I have some notes. Quite a few, actually.”

 

Rio exhaled through her nose, bracing herself. “I expected as much.”

 

Agatha’s lips quirked, as if mildly amused. “Then let’s begin.”

 

And for the next hour, they did. Agatha was relentless—precise, exacting, cutting through weak arguments with a single question. But she was never means or belittling. She pushed, but she never dismissed. She challenged, but she also listened.

 

And to Rio’s own surprise and a little to Agatha’s too, Rio kept up.

 

She countered, she adjusted, she thought on her feet. The nerves never fully faded, but something inside her settled.

 

This was going to be hard.

 

But she had never wanted anything more.

 

 

After the meeting with Dr. Harkness, Rio stepped out of the office feeling like she had just run a marathon. The conversation had been intense, challenging, relentless in a way she hadn’t quite expected, and yet… she had held her own. The weight of Agatha’s expectations pressed against her, lingering like a phantom presence, but so did the fire it had sparked in her. This was it. This was the kind of intellectual rigor she had craved. And now, she had to live up to it.

 

Her mind was a tangle of thoughts, spinning too fast for her to sit with them. She knew herself well enough to recognize that if she didn’t move, she would spiral—turning every word, every glance, every pause from that meeting over in her mind until she’d picked it apart to nothing.

 

So she headed straight to the dance studio.

 

Ballet had always been her escape. The one place where thinking stopped and instinct took over. It was a different kind of challenge, a different kind of discipline—one that existed outside of words, where her body spoke in ways language never could. Here, there was no thesis to defend, no pages to analyze. Just movement. Just music. Just breath.

 

The scent of polished wood and faint traces of rosin welcomed her as she stepped inside, the quiet hum of the studio overhead lights lights filling the space. The room was nearly empty at this hour—just her and the floor-to-ceiling mirrors reflecting her own tension back at her. She stood still for a moment, exhaling slowly, letting the silence settle over her.

 

Shrugging off her jacket, she peeled away the day’s stress along with it, leaving behind the weight of academia as she stepped toward the barre. She stripped down to just a light sweater draped over her well-loved green leotard—a gift from Lilia when she had first been accepted into the PhD program—and a pair of black shorts. Her hair, still slightly mussed from the day, was quickly twisted into a bun to keep it from falling in front of her face.

 

She met her own gaze in the mirror. Steady. Breathe.

 

Riio sighed, rolling her shoulders back, and moved toward the barre at the far end of the studio. The wood felt cool beneath her fingers as she settled into position, her body instinctively falling into the familiar routine. Plié, tendu, dégagé. Each movement stretched through her muscles, warming them, grounding her. The tightness in her chest didn’t vanish entirely, but with every extension of her leg, with every controlled breath, she could feel the anxiety beginning to loosen.

 

She knew she wouldn’t be able to outrun her thoughts completely—she never did. They always lingered, circling at the edges of her mind, waiting for a quiet moment to creep back in. But dance gave her space. Space to breathe, to focus, to quiet the relentless pressure that had been sitting so heavy on her shoulders. With every pirouette, she let a little more of the uncertainty melt away. With every leap, she reached for something beyond the expectations pressing down on her—beyond the weight of Dr. Harkness’ challenge, beyond the constant push to prove herself.

 

After a while, she sank down onto the floor, stretching her legs out in front of her. Her fingers worked instinctively as she tightened the ribbons of her pointe shoes, looping them around her ankles with precision. The sound of soft piano music filtered through the studio speakers. She flexed her feet, rolling through her ankles, feeling the familiar resistance of the shoes molding to her.

 

Then she rose, stepping into the center of the room.

 

She took a deep breath, letting everything else fall away.

 

The moment her foot pressed into the floor for the first movement, the rest of the world disappeared.

 

She let herself sink into the music, her body flowing effortlessly from one motionto the next. Hhe rise and fall of her chest matched the tempo, her limbs carving shapes through the air with a grace that felt instinctive, inevitable. She knew these steps as well as she knew herself. The way her arms extended through a développé, the precise angle of her turnout, the stretch of her body as she pulled into an arabesque—it was all second nature.

 

Then, the music swelled, and Rio let go.

 

She moved into a grand jeté, her body soaring through the air, every muscle engaged in the perfect balance of strength and surrender. The rush of momentum filled her veins, lifting her, freeing her. In that single, weightless moment, she was nothing but motion and energy. No thesis deadlines, no imposter syndrome, no lingering gaze of a brilliant, enigmatic professor dissecting her every word.

 

Just movement. Just freedom.

 

She landed with quiet control, her muscles absorbing the impact as she transitioned smoothly into another turn, another leap, another moment of flight. The sweat on her back cooled against her skin, her pulse quick but steady, her breathing deep and even. She pushed herself harder, spinning, extending, losing herself entirely in the dance.

 

By the time she finally slowed, chest rising and falling with exertion, her thoughts had settled. The pressure of her PhD, the stress of proving herself—it was all still there, waiting for her outside this room. But here, in this moment, she was just Rio.

 

Not a student. Not a musician. Not someone living under the watchful eye of Dr. Harkness.

 

Just a dancer.

 

Just herself.

 

The stillness of the studio wrapped around Rio as she stood there, catching her breath. The music had stopped, leaving only the rhythmic pounding of her heartbeat in her ears. Sweat dampened the back of her neck, and she rolled her shoulders, exhaling slowly. The familiar ache in her muscles was a welcome sensation—a reminder that she was here, in her body, present in the moment, instead of spiraling into endless academic anxieties.

 

She turned toward the mirror, pressing her hands to her hips as she studied her reflection. Her chest still rising and fell with exertion, her green leotard clinging to her like a second skin. Stray pieces of hair had escaped her loose bun, framing her face in messy wisps. She looked… lighter. Less weighed down than she had felt when she first walked in.

 

But the moment of peace was interrupted by the sharp chirp of her phone vibrating against the bench where she had tossed her things. Rio sighed, crossing the room and picking it up, half-expecting a new flood of emails about her thesis or a reminder from Alice about band rehearsal.

 

Instead, it was a text from Lilia.

 

Lilia : I made too much food again. You coming over?

 

A small smile tugged at Rio lips. Of course she did. Lilia had a habit of cooking as though she were feeding an entire dinner party rather than just herself. And Rio knew—without having to ask—that this was her way of making sure she ate something other than coffee and stress.

 

Rio : Be there in twenty.

 

Rio set her phone down and grabbed her sweater, tugging it over her leotard before gathering the rest of her things. The tension in her shoulders hadn’t completely disappeared, but it was more manageable now, no longer clawing at the back of her mind like it had been earlier.

 

But right now, none of that mattered.

 

Right now, there was a warm meal waiting for her and the quiet, steady presence of someone who had been there for her through everything.

 

And for tonight, that was enough.

 

The walk to Lilia’s house was brisk, the evening air cool against Rio's flushed skin as she made her way across campus. She clutched the strap of her dance bag a little tighter, losing herself in the familiar rhythm of her steps.

 

By the time she reached Lilia’s house, the scent of something rich and savory drifted from the open window above. Rio inhaled deeply, already feeling a sense of comfort settle over her. She climbed the stairs two at a time, pushing open the door without knocking.

 

Lilia was in the kitchen, standing over the stove, her dark and silver curls pulled into a messy bun, a wooden spoon in her hand as she stirred a pot of something that smelled amazing.

 

“You’re early,” Lilia said without turning around, her voice warm and knowing.

 

Rio dropped her bag by the couch and leaned against the counter, peering into the pot. “You’re the one who bribed me with food,” she pointed out, eyeing the bubbling tomato sauce with open appreciation. “What is this?”

 

“Rigatoni with homemade marinara,” Lilia replied, grabbing a ladle and giving Rio a teasing glance. “And before you ask, yes, I made garlic bread. And no, you can’t steal a piece before we sit down.”

 

Rio groaned dramatically, but her stomach growled in response, betraying just how little she’d eaten all day. She hopped onto the counter, watching as Lilia moved around the kitchen. The warmth of the room, the scent of fresh basil and simmering tomatoes—it was all so familiar, so safe.

 

For a moment, neither of them spoke, the only sounds filling the space were the soft clatter of dishes and the faint sizzle of sauce in the pan. Rio let herself sink into the silence, into the unspoken understanding that always existed between them.

 

Then Lilia glanced at her, arching a brow. “So,” she said casually, “how was the meeting?”

 

Rio exhaled, running a hand through her damp hair. “Intense.”

 

Lilia smirked, plating the pasta. “Of course it was. You’re working with Dr. Harkness.”

 

Rio gave her a look. “You say that like she’s some kind of academic boogeyman.”

 

“From what you told me, she kind of is,” Lilia shot back, handing her a plate before grabbing her own. “But I know you. You like a challenge.”

 

Rio twirled her fork through the pasta, considering that. “Yeah. I do.” She hesitated, then added, “But it’s… different with her. She’s sharp, Lilia. Everything she says has weight to it. And she expects a lot.”

 

Lilia watched her for a moment, then took a sip of her water. “And that scares you?”

 

Rio frowned, pushing the pasta around on her plate before sighing. “No,” she admitted. “Not exactly. It’s more like… I don’t want to fail.”

 

Lilia reached across the table, nudging Rio hand. “You won’t.”

 

Rio looked up, meeting her gaze. There was no doubt in Lilia’s expression—just quiet certainty, like the one Rio had leaned on more times than she could count.

 

She took a bite of her pasta, chewing thoughtfully before finally saying, “Yeah. I won’t.”

 

And for the first time that evening, she beleived it.`

 

 

After dinner, Rio found herself sprawled on Lilia’s couch, her stomach pleasantly full and her limbs heavy with exhaustion. The warmth of the meal lingered, but so did the weight of her thoughts. She picked at the edge of the old throw blanket draped over the armrest, her mind drifting back to the meeting, the way every word the professor had said seemed to embed itself in her brain like a challenge waiting to be unraveled.

 

Lilia plopped down beside her, nudging rio’s foot off the cushion to make space. “You look like you’re thinking too hard,” she observed, tucking one leg under herself. “I thought dancing was supposed to help with that.”

 

Riio sighed, tipping her head back againts the couch. “It did. For a while. But my brain doesn’t have an off switch, apparently.”

 

Lilia gave her a knowing look. “No kidding.”

 

Rio shot her a playful glare but didn’t argue. Instead, she exhaled deeply and let her eyes wander around the room. The soft glow of the old floor lamp in the corner, the framed photographs on the bookshelf—snapshots of moments that had shaped their lives. One of Rio and Lilia, taken years ago, laughing at something neither of them could probably remember now. Another of Rio with Alice, drumsticks tucked behind her ear, mid-soundcheck at some tiny venue. They were reminders of who she was outside of academia, outside of the pressure.

 

Lilia followed her gaze and smirked. “You know, you are allowed to think about things other than your thesis.”

 

“Am I?” Rio teased, nudging her with her foot. “Because I feel like Dr. Harkness would strongly disagree.”

 

Lilia rolled her eyes. “She can’t own your every waking thought, sweet girl. You’re not just your PhD. You’re the girl who loses her mind over new drumsticks or new pointe shoes. You’re the person who’d rather stay up arguing about whether or not ‘Spring and All’ is a hopeful poem than get a full night’s sleep. You’re the one who learned how to make pancakes at 3 a.m. because you were convinced it was a necessary life skill.”

 

Rio snorted. “It is a necessary life skill.”

 

Lilia grinned, satisfied. “My point is—you’re more than this one thing, no matter how much your thesis looms over your soul like an academic specter of doom.”

 

Rio huffed a laugh but let the words sink in. It was easy to get caught up in it all, to feel like her entire worth was tied to her research, to meeting expectations. But Lilia was right—she was more than this.

 

After a beat, Lilia stood, stretching. “C’mon. Let’s do something that doesn’t involve thinking. Movie night.”
