Rio groaned. “If you put on some weird French art film again, I swear—”

 

“I make one mistake, and you never let me live it down.”

 

“Three hours, Lilia. Three. Hours. And nothing happened.”

 

Lilia laughed, already grabbing the remote. “Fine. No weird Eurpean art films. Your pick.”

 

Rio sighed dramatically but took the remote. Maybe a dumb comedy was exactly what she needed.

 

 

That evening, after a long day of teaching, grading, and meetings, Agatha sat in her study at home, papers scattered across the desk before her, trying to vanquish her own solitude.

 

She exhaled, rolling the stiffness from her shoulders. It was almost time to pick up Nicky from Wanda’s. Her longtime friend had, as usual, been kind enough to get him from school, letting him play with her twin boys, Tommy and Billly, for a while. Agatha usually welcomed the extra time—it allowed her to get work done, to maintain the structure of her ever-demanding schedule. But tonight, her mind was frustratingly unfocused, her attention slipping through her fingers like fine sand.

 

She had essays to grade, research projects to review, and yet she caught herself staring at nothing, her fingers resting lightly on the edge of a manuscript she had barely skimmed. It was as though a thread of thought had unraveled, tugging her in a direction she wasn’t sure she wanted to follow.

 

Rio Vidal.

 

She hadn’t meant to linger on it, but the memory of their meeting resurfaced unbidden, diruupting her usual discipline. There was nothing extraordinary about it on the surface—it had been professional, productive, no different from the dozens of student meetings she held each semester. And yet, something about it unsettled her.

 

Rio had been composed, articulate, sharp. Agata had expected as much. But there was something else—something about the way she spoke with such quiet conviction, the way she leaned into her ideas, not with arrogance but with a steady, deliberate confidence. She had held Agatha’s gaze without hesitation, unafraid to challenge, to push deeper, to think.

 

It wasn’t often that a student impressed her so quickly. Agatha wasn’t easily impressed in general. She had built a career on her high standards, on demanding the best from those she taught. But Rio had already begun to carve out a space in Agatha’s mind, lingering there like an unfinished sentence.

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, running a hand through her long chestnut hair.

 

Perhaps it was just academic intrigue. It should be just academic intrigue. Rio was intelligent, and intelligence always caught Agatha”s attention. She had seen glimpses of that sharp mind before—like in her seminar a few weeks ago, when Rio had spoken about The Waste Land with a rare depth, her insights precise and thoughtful, her passion evident even in the careful restraint of her voice.

 

And yet… it wasn’t just the intellect that stood out. It was the way Rio carried herself, the contrast of certainty and something else—something quieter, more difficult to name. A guardedness? A weight she wasn’t quite revealing? Agtaha had spent enough years reading between the lines—both in texts and in people—to know when something was being left unsaid.

 

She tapped her pen against the desk, frowning slightly.

 

Maybe it was that familiarity that unsettled her. The way Rio reminded her, just a little, of a version of herself from years ago. The same hunger to prove something, the same quiet intensity. Agatha had spent much of her own academic journey learning to sharpen herself into something untouchable, refining her intellect into a weapon, her solitude into a shield. She wondered if Rio had begun to do the same.

 

And then there were the overalls.

 

Agtaha exhaled sharply through her nose, a small, almost unwilling smirk ghosting across her lips.

 

No. Don’t go there.

 

She sat up, shaking the thought away, reaching for the stack of essays as if sheer force of will could snap her out of it. This was nothing more than professional curiosity. That was all. Rio was bright, promising, worthy of attention—but no more than any other exceptional student Agata had mentored over the years.

 

Still, as she reached for her pen, her fingers hovered over the page for just a beat too long.

 

With an irritated sigh, she pushed back from the desk and stood, grabbing her coat. It was time to get Nicky. Maybe some fresh air would clear her head.

 

Agatha stepped out into the crisp evening air, locking the door behind her. She welcomed the walk—it wasn’t far to Wanda’s, and she needed the movement, the sharp cold against her skin, something to ground her.

 

Her mind, however, refused to cooperate.

 

Her student’s image curled in the back of her mind, stubbornly refusing to be dismissed. Agatha prided herself on her ability to compartmentalize, to separate the professional from the personal, to keep firm boundaries between what mattered and what was merely passing distraction.

 

And yet.

 

She turned a corner, boots clicking steadily against the pavement.

 

This wasn’t the first time a student had caught her attention—she had mentored plenty of bright minds over the years, watched them flourish, challenged them, shaped them. It was part of the job. But this was different. There was something about rio that tugged at Agatha’s focus in a way she wasn’t entirely comfortable with.

 

Maybe it was just the familiarity—the echoes of herself in Rio' determination, in the sharp way she spoke about her work, in the way she seemed to hold something back, just beneath the surface. A quiet sort of weight, an edge of vulnerability wrapped in intellect.

 

Agatha had seen it before, in herself, in others. She had long since learned that curiosity—true curiosity—was dangerous. It made you want to look closer, to unravel, to understand.

 

And understanding was not always safe.

 

She reached Wanda’s house and took a steadying breath before knocking on the door.

 

A few moments later, it swung open to reveal Wanda, her red hair slightly disheveled, her expression warm but tired. “You’re late,” she teased, leaning against the doorframe. “Deep in thought? Or just buried under papers again?”

 

Agatha gave her a pointed look. “Both.”

 

Wanda smirked. “Figures. Come in.”

 

Agatha stepped inside, immediately met with the distant sound of laughter and the unmistakable chaos of three children playing. Nicky was on the living room floor, utterly enthralled in a game with Billy and Tommy, the three of them surrounded by an assortment of action figures and Legos in a battlefield that only children could understand.

 

Her son looked up when he saw her, his bright blue eyes the exact same shade as hers lighting up. “Mama!”

 

The warmth that spread through Agatha’s chest was immediate, dissolving whatever lingering thoughts had followed her here. She crouched slightly as Nicky ran toward her, wrapping his arms around her in a tight hug.

 

“Had fun?” she asked, smoothing a hand over his messy curls.

 

He nodded enthusiastically. “Billy and Tommy and I built a space fortress! And then a giant dragon attacked! But don’t worry, we won.”

 

Agatha chuckled, glancing at Wanda, who shrugged. “I take no credit for this elaborate storyline.”

 

Agatha smirked, then stood, adjusting Nicky’s coat as he slipped into his shoes. “Come on, then. Let’s get home.”

 

As they stepped back into the night, Nicky slipping his small hand into hers, Agatha felt herself settle. Whatever intrusive thoughts had plagued her earlier could wait.

 

For now, she had something more important to focuson.

 

Agatha and Nicky walked home through the quiet streets, the city humming around them in its usual rhythm. The cold air nipped at their cheeks, but Nicky didn’t seem to mind—he swung their joined hands slightly, his small fingers curled tightly around hers, his energy still buzzing from his playtime with Billly and Tommy.

 

Agatha glanced down at him. “Tired?”

 

Nicky shook his head with the determination of a child who would rather collapse mid-step than admit to exhaustion. “Nope.”

 

She smirked. “Liar.”

 

He giggled but didn’t argue.

 

When they reached their house, Agatha unlocked the door and ushered him inside, the warmth of home wrapping around them instantly. Nicky kicked off his shoes in the haphazard way all six-year-olds did, and Agatha sighed as she bent to line them up properly by the door.

 

“I will teach you to put them away correctly one day,” she muttered.

 

“No, you won’t,” Nicky said matter-of-factly, already making a beeline for the couch.

 

Agatha sighed but didn’t press the issue. “Go wash up before bed,” she called after him as he climbed onto the cushions.

 

“Five minutes!” he negotiated.

 

“Now, Nicky.”

 

He groaned dramatically but obeyed, dragging his feet as he trudged toward the bathroom. Agatha used the brief moment of quiet to slip into the kitchen, setting a kettle on the stove. She pulled down a mug, selecting a tea bag from the tin in the cupboard. The simple routine helped clear her mind, offering a small reprieve from the weight of the day.

 

When the water finally boiled, she poured it over the tea bag and let the steam curl up toward her face, gogging her glasses. A deep breath in, a slow breath out. The quiet was welcome, but it wouldn’t last.

 

Sure enough, a few minutes later, Nicky appeared in the doorway, hands  freshly washed, dressed in his pajamas—an old set with tiny rockets on them, slightly too small but still his favorite. He padded over to the table and plopped down in a chair, swinging his legs.

 

Agatha arched an eyebrow. “Teeth?”

 

He groaned. “Yes.”

 

She gave him a long, scrutinizing look.

 

“Yes,” he insisted.

 

“Mm-hmm.”

 

Satisfied for now, she took a sip of her tea, then leaned against the counter, watching as Nicky fiddled with one of the tiny plastic dinosaurs he had smuggled into the kitchen.

 

“Can I have a story tonight?” he asked, not looking up.

 

Agatha sighed, feigning exasperation. “Another one?”

 

“Yes,” he said, grinning. “A good one.”

 

“They’re all good.”

 

Nicky considered this. “Some are extra good.”

 

Agatha smirked, shaking her head as she set down her tea. “Fine. Go get in bed.”

 

He shot up from his chair and ran off toward his room, triumphant.

 

By the time Agatha followed, he was already tucked beneath the blankets, Blue Dragon snug in his arms, waiting expectantly. She sat on the edge of the bed.

 

“What’ll it be tonight?” she asked.

 

“Something with dragons.”

 

Agatha hummed thoughtfully. “Dragons, huh? Well, I might know a tale about a very clever little knight and the dragon that he outwitted…”

 

Nicky gasped, fully invested already. “Tell me!”

 

And so, Agatha began, her voice soft in the dim glow of the bedside lamp. As the words wove their way through the quiet night, Nicky’s eyelids grew heavier, his small body sinking deeper into the blankets. By the time she reached the end of the story, his breathing was slow, even. Asleep.

 

Agatha exhaled, allowing herself a small moment of peace as she watched him.

 

Then, carefully, she stood, switched off the lamp, and slipped out of the room, closing the door behind her with a quiet click.

 

Finally alone, she returned to the living room, picking up her tea—now lukewarm—and sinking onto the couch. The day had been long. The week ahead would be longer.

 

 

*

*

*

 

Café Encounters

*

*

*

Time and the bell have buried the day,

The black cloud carries the sun away.

Will the sunflower turn to us, will the clematis

Stray down, bend to us; tendril and spray

Clutch and cling?

          (Eliot, “Burnt Norton”, Four Quartets)

 

 

The afternoon had the crisp bite of early autumn, the kind of cool air that made the warmth of a coffee cup feel like a small luxury and the sky was a soft, pale blue, streaked with wisps of clouds. It was the perfect kind of day to tuck into a familiar corner, away from the weight of deadlines and expectations, and that was exactly what Rio, Alice, and Jen had done.

 

The café, a cozy little spot nestled on the quieter side of campus, was as lively as ever. The scent of espresso and freshly baked pastries curled through the air, mingling with the gentle hum of conversation and the occasional burst of laughter from a nearby table. The three of them had claimed their usual spot by the window, where they could watch the steady stream of students passing by, bundled in scarves and jackets against the cool breeze.

 

Jen leaned back in her chair, her dark brows arched in amusement, one leg casually draped over the other. “So, just so we’re all clear,” she said, smirking at Alice, “we’re definitely playing at the right venue this time? Because I, for one, would love to avoid another ‘surprise gig’ situation.”

 

Alice groaned dramatically, burying her face in her hands. “I will never live that down, will I?”

 

Rio grinned, stirring a bit of cinnamon into her latte. “Not a chance.”

 

Jen leaned back in her chair, a smirk tugging at the corner of her lips. “I’m just saying, Alice, if we do show up to the wrong venue again, at least this time we’ll be prepared for it.”

 

Alice groaned, dramatically dragging her hands down her face. “It was one time! And in my defense, the email was very unclear.”

 

Rio grinned, stirring a bit of cinnamon into her coffee. “I don’t know, Al, I think you just have a talent for chaos.”

 

Alice shot her a look, but the corners of her mouth twitched upward. “Says the person who nearly missed our last set because she got locked in the green room.”

 

Jen snorted, nearly spilling her tea. “Oh, that was legendary.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but laughed. “That was not my fault. The door handle literally broke off in my hand. That’s just bad venue maintenance.”

 

Alice pointed her spoon at her. “I still had to stall with an impromptu monologue about the history of punk drumming while you banged on the door like a trapped ghost.”

 

Jen grinned. “And that monologue, by the way, was entirely unnecessary. We would have survived without it.”

 

“Excuse me,” Alice said, feigning offense. “The audience was riveted.”

 

“The audience was confused,” Rio corrected, taking a sip of her coffee.

 

Alice huffed. “Details. And your weren’t there.”

 

Jen shook her head, a laugh slipping past her lips before she sat forward, her expression shifting slightly. “Speaking of upcoming gigs, though—are we ready for Saturday’s set? We’re playing that new song, right?”

 

Rio tapped her fingers against the side of her cup, thinking. “I think so. We ran it a couple of times last practice, but I wouldn’t mind going over it again. The transition in the bridge still feels a little messy.”

 

Alice nodded. “Yeah, agreed. And I think I need to tweak the harmonies in the chorus. They’re not quite clicking yet.”

 

Jen smirked. “Translation: you need an excuse to belt dramatically in my face until you get it right.”

 

Alice grinned. “That is exactly what I need.”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head.

 

The bell above the café door chimed, its familiar jingle lost beneath the steady hum of conversation and the occasional clatter of mugs being set down too hard on wooden tables. Yet, for Rio, the sound may as well have been a thunderclap. Her head snapped toward the entrance, her attention immediately caught by the familiar presence stepping inside.

 

Agatha Harkness.

 

Of course.

 

She entered with the same composure that Rio had come to associate with her—dressed in sharply tailored black slacks and a dark coat, her movements precise, her posture straight as ever. She moved with quiet authority, her expression unreadable, flanked by two colleagues who seemed to naturally fall into place beside her, as though even they knew to follow her lead.

 

“Is that Dr. Harkness?” Alice asked, her voice cutting through Rio’s moment of fixation. She had clearly caught the way Rio’s attention had locked onto Agatha the second she walked in.

 

Rio didn’t answer right away. Her gaze followed Agatha as she crossed the café, her coat shifting slightly as she walked, before she took a seat in the corner of the room. It wasn’t a dramatic moment. It wasn’t some cosmic coincidence. Agatha was just here, like any other professor grabbing coffee with colleagues. And yet, Rio felt it—the flutter in her chest, the nervous jolt that made no logical sense.

 

She forced herself to look away, only to find Jen watching her with a knowing smirk. “You’re staring,” she said, stirring her drink leisurely.

 

Rio blinked, caught off guard. “I’m not staring,” she muttered, but even as the words left her lips, she felt the heat creeping up her neck. “I just… notice.”

 

Jen snorted. “Uh-huh. Noticing just happens to involve intense, laser-focused observation?”

 

Rio rolled her eyes and stood abruptly, grabbing her empty cup. “I’m getting another coffee.”

 

Alice arched an eyebrow. “Are you? Or are you just getting a better angle?”

 

Rio shot her a glare. “I need more caffeine.”

 

Jen grinned, clearly enjoying every second of this. “Sure, sure. Let’s get another round, then.”

 

They made their way to the counter, but despite her best efforts, Rio’s eyes flickered back toward Agatha’s table. She told herself it was accidental, but the moment her gaze landed on Agatha, she realized her mistake.

 

Because Agatha was already looking at her.

 

Their eyes met across the room, a moment of wordless recognition that sent a spark of something—anticipation? Nervous energy? Rio couldn’t tell—straight through her.

 

Agatha’s expression didn’t betray anything. There was no obvious amusement, no warmth, no acknowledgment beyond the quiet intensity of her gaze. But something in the way she held Rio’s stare made the air feel heavier, charged with an unspoken understanding. It wasn’t just a casual glance—it was sharp, deliberate, like she was assessing something, searching for something.

 

Rio’s breath caught in her throat, her fingers tightening slightly around her empty cup. Then, just as quickly as the moment arrived, she looked away, forcing herself to focus on the counter in front of her.

 

“Okay,” Alice whispered beside her, eyes wide with amusement. “Now you’re definitely staring.”

 

Rio exhaled sharply, turning toward her friend with an exasperated look. “For the last time, I’m not staring.”

 

Jen leaned in, still grinning. “You know she’s not that scary, right? She’s just a professor.”

 

Rio scoffed. “I know that.”

  

Jen nudged her gently. “It’s just a coffee shop, Rio. No need to act like you’re in some sort of thriller.”

 

Rio forced a laugh, though the uneasy feeling in her stomach didn’t fade. She took a deep breath, trying to focus on the conversation again, but her mnd kept returning to that brief exchange. What was that look? Was it just her imagination, or was there something more behind Dr Harkness’s eyes?

 

 

As Rio, Alice, and Jen settled back into their small table near the window, Rio pushed the moment with Dr Harkness from her mind, focusing instead on the conversation with her friends.

 

Alice was mid-sentence, animatedly talking about the band’s upcoming gig, her hands gesturing as she outlined the setlist she was debating. Jenwas already poking holes in the logistics, while Rio attempted to stay engaged. But despite the comfort of their familiar banter, her thoughts felt scattered, her attention divided by something dessed in purpke.

 

Then, the door swung open with a sharp jingle, cutting through the café’s warm hum of noise.

 

Rio didn’t mean to look. But something in her tensed, her body reacting before her mind even caught up. Her gaze flicked toward the entrance, drawn by a pull she should have learned to ignore by now.

 

Maya.

 

Her ex.

 

She walked in like she owned the place. Ugh. Effortlessly put-together, striking in that way that had always made her hard to forget. Dark eyes sharp, a smirk already playing at the corner of her lips, she scanned the café as if she were expecting to find someone she knew. And, of course, she did find someone.

 

Rio’s stomach tightened as Maya’s gaze landed on her almost immediately, recognition flashing in her expression before shifting into something more playful. And then, that grin—wide, teasing, knowing. Rio barely had a second to process it before Maya was making a beeline for their table, moving with the kind of confidence that had once been intoxicating, and now just felt like a storm rolling in before Rio had a chance to brace herself.

 

“Well, well, well.” Maya’s voice was warm, familiar, laced with that casual amusement that always made it sound like she was in on some inside joke. “If it isn’t Rio and her intellectual squad.” She waved at Alice and Jen with exaggerated enthusiasm before tilting her head. “This seat taken?”

 

Alice and Jen exchanged glances—equal parts unimpressed and unsurprised. Jen arched an eyebrow but said nothing, while Alice took a slow, deliberate sip of her coffee, making it abundantly clear she had no intention of making Maya feel particularly welcome.

 

Rio, on the other hand, felt the tension coil in her chest.

 

Maya had always been like this. Bold. Intrusive. Inescapable. She had a way of inserting herself into spaces without hesitation, like she belonged there, like no one would dare tell her otherwise. And Rio, despite everything, despite how things had ended, found herself defaulting to old instincts.

 

She forced a smile, nodding stiffly. “Sure. Sit down.”

 

Maya casually plopped herself down beside Rio, taking no issue with the awkwardness of the situation. Rio could feel the proximity of her ex, the familiar scent of Maya’s perfume, the warmth of her body too close for comfort. Maya’s fingers brushed against Rio’s arm as she adjusted in her seat, and it made Rio’s pulse quicken, both with uneasiness and the uncomfortable weight of history.

 

Maya smirked, clearly catching the way Rio’s shoulders tensed. “Relax, Ree,” she murmured, voice just low enogh that only Rio could hear. “I’m not here to cause trouble.”

 

Rio exhaled slowly, staring down at the swirl of foam in her coffee.

 

Somehow, she didn’t quite believe her.

 

 

 

Agatha sat at her table, her colleagues’ conversation only halfly-heard. Discussions of departmental politics, upcoming conferences, and research grants should have occupied her mind, but instead, her gaze kept flickering—against her better judgment—toward the table near the window.

 

Rio’s table.

 

Agatha wasn’t actively listening, not really, until she saw the moment unfold.

 

A woman had joined Rio and her friends. Blond hair, sharp features, a casual confidence that made her presence impossible to ignore. Agatha’s eyes took in the way Rio stiffened, just slightly, at the woman’s arrival, the way her smile tightened before relaxing into something guarded.

 

They knew each other.

 

Intimately.

 

There was an ease between them that was both startling and… unsettling. They leaned in close, stiffly laughing at something Rio’s friend had said, the connection between them palpable even from across the room. The way Maya casually touched Rio’s arm, how Rio flinched slightly away, the way their conversation flowed, as though they shared some past unspoken bond—it stirred something in Agatha’s chest. Something she couldn’t quite place.

 

Agatha’s fingers tightened around the edge of her coffee cup as she watched.

 

A sharp, unfamiliar pang of discomfort shot through Agatha. She didn’t like it. She didn’t like the way Rio’s eyes closed in on the girl when she spoke, the way her lips curled into that faint, uncomfortable scowl. It was a look Agatha hadn’t seen from Rio before, not in their meetings or seminars. What was that?

  

Agatha forced herself to look back at her colleagues, to pretend to care about the discussion on faculty research proposals, but her mind kept drifting, bits of irritation prickling in her thoughts. The woman’s presence, the way she seemed to naturally fill the space between them, the way she belonged so effortlessly in Rio’s world—it made Agatha’s own thoughts feel jagged, fragmented.

 

She hated the feeling.

 

Agatha’s grip on her coffee cup tightened, and she felt a rush of frustration at herself for even caring about something so trivial. Rio was a student, nothing more. And the woman was part of her circle—whatever that meant for Rio, it was a chapter she didn't need to read.

 

But still, a quiet voice in the back of her mind insisted that she didn’t like seeing Rio so… close with someone else. Agatha couldn’t help it. She couldn’t stop herself from looking at them again, her gaze lingering just a moment too long before she forced her eyes away.

 

Focus, she told herself. Focus on your colleagues.

 

But it was hard, very hard, not to be distracted by the subtle tension hanging in the air, the way Rio seemed to withdraw just slightly whenever that woman leaned in too close, yet always allowing it. As if there was a pull there, something Agatha didn’t fully understand but felt intensely.

 

It wasn’t her place to feel this way. Agatha had already established that in her mind, yet the thought remained.

 

Focus, she reminded herself again.

 

But Agatha knew that something had shifted in her, and it wasn’t just her curiosity about Rio’s intellectual prowess. Something deeper had stirred, something she wasn’t ready to confront.

 

 

Maya didn’t linger long. Just long enough to disrupt the air, to remind Rio of her presence, to stir something unresolved before slipping away as effortlessly as she had arrived. With a final teasing remark and a grin that felt just a little too knowing, she turned and strolled out of the café, leaving behind the faintest trace of perfume and the unmistakable weight of tension.

 

The door swung shut behind her, the bell’s chime fading into the low hum of conversation around them, but Rio still felt like she was holding her breath. When she finally let it out, it was slow, measured, as if releasing too much air at once might make everything unravel. Her fingers tightened around her coffee cup, seeking some kind of grounding, something solid amid the sudden unease coiling in her chest.

 

Alice was the first to break the silence. “You okay?” Her usual teasing tone was gone, replaced by something softer, more careful. She had seen it—the way Rio’s entire posture had shifted the second Maya walked in, the way her eyes had darkened with something too tangled to name.

 

Jen leaned back in her chair, arms crossed, her sharp eyes flicking toward the door as if Maya might come waltzing back in just to cause more chaos. “That was… a lot,” she said bluntly. “She still has that whole ‘look at me, I own the world’ thing going on.”

 

Rio let out a dry laugh, but it didn’t quite reach her eyes. “Yeah. She always did.”

 

Her voice was quieter than she intended, lost somewhere between exhaustion and frustration. It wasn’t just Maya’s confidence, or the way she always managed to draw her attention without even trying—it was the history. The long, complicated, messy history that Rio had spent so much time trying to leave behind. But history didn’t just disappear, did it? It lingered. It resurfaced when you least expected it, when you wanted it least.

 

“I wish I didn’t have to see her again,” Rio muttered after a moment, her voice low. “After everything… I thought it was over. I thought I could move on.”

 

Alice reached across the table and squeezed Rio’s hand. “You have moved on. She just likes to pretend you haven’t. That’s her problem, not yours.”

 

Jen nodded in agreement. “Yeah, and you don’t have to let her get under your skin. She wants that. She thrives on that.” She leaned forward, her voice firm but not unkind. “You don’t owe her your time, your energy, or even a second thought. She’s not your problem anymore.”

 

Rio nodded, though the knot in her chest didn’t loosen. It wasn’t just Maya’s presence that unsettled her—it was the flood of memories that came with it. The late nights filled with passionate arguments that always ended with either fiery reconciliations or icy silence, always teetering between love and destruction. The way Maya could make Rio feel alive one second and trapped the next, like she was always walking a tightrope between exhilaration and exhaustion. And worst of all—the way it had ended.

 

Maya’s unforgivable betrayal. The cold, finality of her walking away without hesitation, without so much as a second glance. Leaving Rio to pick up the pieces alone, to sit with the wreckage of something that had once felt too big, too intense to ever collapse.

 

She swallowed hard and took a deep breath, pushing the memories back down where they belonged. “I’ll be fine,” she murmured, though the words rang hollow in her own ears. “It just… caught me off guard.”

 

Alice and Jen exchanged a glance—quick, unreadable, but Rio caught it anyway. They wouldn’t push, not now. They knew her well enough to recognize when to let things lie.

 

Instead, Alice gave her a small, reassuring smile and changed the subject, steering the conversation toward something lighter. Something that didn’t feel like it carried the weight of a past Rio wasn’t ready to unpack.

 

Across the café, Agtaha watched the scene unfold from her corner, her colleagues chatting away about the upcoming department review. Her sharp eyes took in the tension in Rio’s posture, the slight slump of her shoulders as she stared at her coffee cup, her friends offering quiet comfort.

 

It wasn’t Agatha’s place to wonder what had unsettled her so. It certainly wasn’t her place to feel this quiet, inexplicable pull of concern. And yet, she did.

 

With a practiced air of indifference, Agatha tore her gaze away, focusing instead on the discussion at her own table. She forced herself to engage, offering a well-placed remark here and there. But her thoughts kept circling back, wondering what had caused the crack in Rio’s usually composed exterior.

 

This is none of your concern, she reminded herself firmly.

 

Agatha turned her attention back to her colleagues, forcing herself to engage with the conversation, but the image of Rio’s troubled expression lingered in her mind.

 

Rio, meanwhile, forced herself to take another sip of coffee, trying to steady the tremor in her hands. Maya might have left, but the echoes of her presence lingered, and Rio hated how easily she could still get under her skin.

 

“Let’s talk about something else,” she said finally, her voice firmer. “Anything else.”

 

Alice nodded quickly, launching into a story about one of their band rehearsals gone hilariously wrong, and Jen chimed in with a quip about their setlist for the gig. Rio appreciated their efforts, even if the tension in her chest didn’t fully ease.

 

She glanced out the window, watching as the sun dipped lower in the sky. Maya was gone now, but the storm she’d stirred in Rio’s mind would take longer to settle. She lifted her coffee cup to her lips, her hands steady despite the storm inside her, and silently vowed to herself that she wouldn’t let Maya undo all the progress she’d made.

 

Not again.

 

 

That night, Rio sat curled up on the couch in Lilia’s house, a mug of chamomile tea cradled in her hands as she recounted the events of the day.

 

Across from her, Lilia sat in her well-worn armchair, the same one she had always favored—the one Rio had found comfort in since she was a teenager, seeking refuge in Lilia’s home. Lilia listened intently, her expression darkening with every detail Rio recounted. When Rio finally mentioned Maya’s sudden, uninvited appearance at the café, Lilia’s jaw tightened, her brows knitting together in unmistakable displeasure.

 

“She walked right up to your table, uninvited?” Lilia asked sharply, her voice carrying that protective edge Rio had grown to expect whenever Maya’s name came up.

 

Rio nodded, her fingers tightening around the mug. “Yeah, like she belonged there. Same old Maya, I guess.” She forced a half-hearted shrug, but the tension in her posture made it clear it wasn’t as simple as she wanted it to be.

 

Lilia exhaled sharply, shaking her head. “That girl has some nerve. After what she put you through, she has no business showing her face around you. None.”

 

Rio gave a small shrug, though the tension in her shoulders betrayed her attempt to downplay it. “It’s fine, Lilia. She didn’t stay long, and I’m not letting it get to me.”

 

Lilia gave her a long, measured look, unconvinced. “Rio, sweet girl,” she said, her voice quieter but no less firm. “It’s not fine. You’ve worked too hard to move on just for her to waltz back in and shake you up like this. She doesn’t deserve a second of your energy.”

 

Rio swallowed hard, her fingers tracing the rim of her mug. “I know,” she admitted, her voice barely above a whisper. “Alice and Jen said the same thing. And they’re right. You’re right. But…” She hesitated, inhaling deeply before continuing. “Seeing her again—it just brought everything back. The mess, the hurt. I hate that she still has that effect on me.”

 

For a moment, Lilia said nothing. Then, with the same quiet, steady care she had always shown Rio, she stood from her chair and moved to the couch, sitting beside her. Without hesitation, she wrapped an arm around Rio’s shoulders and pulled her close, like she had done countless times before—when Rio was younger, when the world felt too heavy, when she just needed to be held.

 

“It’s okay to feel like that,” Lilia murmured, her voice gentle but certain. “But don’t forget how far you’ve come. You’re not the girl she hurt anymore, Rio. You’ve built a life without her, a life she has no claim to. You decide who gets a place in it. And Maya? She doesn’t get to take up space in your head or your heart—not anymore.”

 

Rio exhaled slowly, leaning into the embrace, letting Lilia’s words settle the ache in her chest. She wasn’t sure if she fully believed them yet, but she wanted to.

 

“Thanks,” she whispered, her voice small but steady. “I needed that.”

 

Lilia tightened her hold on Rio for a brief moment before pulling back just enough to meet her eyes, her gaze steady and unwavering. “You don’t ever have to face her alone, you hear me?” she said, voice firm with quiet conviction. “If she ever shows up again, you tell her exactly where she can go. And if you can’t, you call me, and I’ll do it for you.”

 

Rio couldn’t help the small, tired smile that tugged at her lips. “I think that might scare her off for good.”

 

“Good.” Lilia huffed, crossing her arms as if daring fate to test her. “She deserves worse after the way she treated you. You’re worth more than she could ever give you, Rio.”

 

The words landed deep, settling into places Maya had left fractured. Lilia had always been that steady force, the reminder of love that didn’t take more than it gave, of stability that didn’t come with conditions.

 

Rio exhaled, slow and measured, letting the weight of the day roll off her shoulders. “I know,” she said, and this time, she meant it. Her voice was stronger, steadier. “You’re right. I’ve moved on, and she doesn’t get to change that.”

 

Lilia gave her knee a firm, reassuring pat. “That’s my girl.” Then, as if sensing the moment had gotten just a little too heavy, she leaned back against the couch with a dramatic sigh. “Now, finish your tea, and let’s find something ridiculous to watch on TV. Something with bad acting, worse dialogue, and at least one explosion that makes no sense.”

 

Rio chuckled, the tension in her chest finally starting to ease. “You have very specific criteria for terrible movies.”

 

“I’ve had years to perfect my taste,” Lilia quipped, reaching for the remote. “What time’s your class tomorrow?”

 

“Eleven.”

 

“Good. Because you’re spending the night here,” Lilia said matter-of-factly. “Your room’s ready—I changed the sheets yesterday.”

 

Rio shook her head, smiling at the sheer determination in the older lady’s voice. No room for debate, no need for argument.

 

“Yes, ma’am,” she said with mock solemnity, and Lilia huffed, satisfied.

 

*

*

*

The Dance Recital

*

*

*

As, in a theatre,

The lights are extinguished, for the scene to be changed

With a hollow rumble of wings, with a movement of darkness on darkness.

         

          (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next morning, Rio walked into the lecture hall, her satchel slung over one shoulder and a takeaway coffee in her hand, her bag heavy with the tin box of cookies Lilia had made for her. The chatter of students filled the room, a mix of early-morning grogginess and last-minute cramming. She slid into her usual seat near the window, pulling out her notebook and pen as she sipped her coffee.

 

Today was a new day, and Rio was determined to focus on what mattered—her work, her goals, and, for the next hour, Dr. Harkness’s seminar.

 

Agatha entered the room a few minutes later, her presence as captivating as ever. She wore a tailored navy blazer over a sleek white shirt and wide deep purple pants, her hair swept back neatly. Her sharp blue eyes scanned the room briefly before she set her papers down at the podium. The room quieted almost instantly as the students turned their attention to her.

 

“Good morning,” Agatha began, her voice clear and measured. “Today, we’ll be continuing our discussion of the tension between life and finality in Modernist poetry. Specifically, we’ll examine how certain poets use Death as a metaphorical lens to explore identity and time. I know this subject is particularly interesting for some of you, so I figured sharing out insights might help everyone.”

 

Rio sat up straighter, her pen poised over her notebook. This was her territory—the themes that had captivated her for years and the focus of her thesis. As Agatha began quoting lines from T.S. Eliot and W.B. Yeats, Rio couldn’t help but feel a spark of excitement. Agatha’s insight into the material was as sharp as ever, and Rio found herself completely engrossed.

 

At one point, Agatha’s gaze flicked toward Rio as she posed a question to the class: “How does Yeats’s use of the mythological figure of Leda frame his understanding of mortality as intertwined with transformation?”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment before raising her hand. Agatha acknowledged her with a small nod, her expression unreadable but attentive.

 

“Well,” Rio began, her voice steady despite the subtle flutter of nerves, “Yeats uses Leda as a representation of forced transformation—an unavoidable encounter with something that fundamentally changes her. It mirrors how mortality forces us to confront the limits of our existence while also propelling us toward growth, even if it’s painful.”

 

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her lips curving into a faint smile. “An astute observation, Miss Vidal. Yeats does, indeed, frame Leda’s experience as both an ending and a beginning—a violent upheaval that reshapes the world as much as the self.”

 

Rio felt a small flicker of pride at the compliment, though she quickly focused back on her notes, avoiding the curious glances of her classmates.

 

The rest of the seminar passed in a blur of analysis and discussion, and by the end of it, Rio’s notebook was filled with scribbles of ideas and connections she wanted to explore further. As the students began packing up, Agatha lingered at the front of the room, organizing her papers.

 

As the lecture hall emptied, Rio lingered at her seat, pretending to organize her notes as she watched the other students shuffle out. Agatha remained at the front of the room, meticulously arranging her papers and sliding them into a sleek leather folder. Rio’s heart thudded in her chest, but she told herself it was just a friendly, responsible gesture. It wasn’t about finding an excuse to talk to Dr. Harkness. Definitely not.

 

Taking a deep breath, she walked down the aisle, her steps echoing in the now-quiet room. Agatha looked up as Rio approached, her sharp eyes softening slightly in recognition.

 

“Miss Vidal,” she said, her tone neutral but not unkind. “Is there something you need?”

 

Rio smiled, hoping she looked more casual than she felt. “Yes, uh, sort of. I sent you an email earlier this week, but I just wanted to remind you in person—Nicky’s ballet recital is on Saturday. He’s been really excited about it, and I figured it might be helpful to have a heads-up.”

 

Agatha’s expression shifted, a faint smile tugging at the corners of her lips. “Ah, yes. The recital. Thank you for reminding me—I did see the email, but it’s been a busy week. I appreciate the follow-up.”

 

Rio nodded, her fingers fidgeting with the strap of her satchel. “Of course. It’s no problem. He’s been practicing so hard; I’m sure he’ll do great. The kids are always adorable during these recitals.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, a sound Rio realized she didn’t hear often. “Adorable and, at times, unpredictable. I’ve attended enough of these to know that much.”

 

Rio laughed, relaxing slightly. “True. Last year, one of the kids got stage fright and ended up holding hands with their teacher for the whole performance. It was honestly kind of sweet.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, her gaze briefly flicking to Rio with a glint of curiosity. “And let me guess, you were the supportive teacher, right?”

 

Rio smiled, a hint of sheepishness in her expression. “Guilty as charged. The little lady just needed a bit of reassurance. It’s hard being six and performing in front of a crowd.”

 

Agatha’s smile lingered, and for a moment, the formal distance between professor and student seemed to blur. “It sounds like you’re very good with the children,” she said.

 

“I try,” Rio replied, feeling a warmth spread through her chest at the subtle compliment. “They make it easy. Nicky especially—he’s such a sweet kid.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened further, a flicker of pride crossing her face. “He is. Though he’s not always so sweet at home, I assure you.”

 

Rio laughed at that, though she couldn’t quite shake the awareness of how close they were standing now, the air between them charged with something she couldn’t quite name. She felt the urge to say more, to keep the conversation going, but she also didn’t want to overstep.

 

“Well,” she said finally, stepping back slightly, “I just wanted to make sure you knew about the recital. The kids are looking forward to seeing their families there.”

 

“I’ll be there,” Agatha said, her tone firm but warm. “Thank you for reminding me.”

 

Rio nodded, her cheeks feeling warm. “Great. I’ll see you Saturday, then.”

 

Agatha gave a small nod of acknowledgment, and Rio turned to leave, her heart fluttering in a way that was entirely unprofessional but impossible to ignore.

 

As she stepped out into the hallway, she couldn’t help but smile to herself. It was just a small moment, a brief exchange—but it had been enough to brighten her day.

 

 

The morning sun filtered through the curtains of Agatha’s home, casting a warm glow across the living room. Nicky sat on the edge of the couch, his tiny feet swinging nervously, the elastic straps of his ballet shoes snug against his ankles. His recital outfit—a crisp white shirt and black pants—was neatly pressed, but he kept fiddling with the hem of his shirt, his brow furrowed in worry.

 

“I don’t think I can do it, Mama,” he said, his voice small. “What if I mess up? Everyone will be watching.”

 

Agatha knelt down in front of him, resting her hands gently on his knees. Her gaze softened as she took in the sight of her son, so tiny yet burdened with such big feelings.

 

“Nicholas,” she said, her voice calm and steady, “it’s completely normal to feel nervous. It means you care about what you’re doing, and that’s a good thing.”

 

Nicky looked up at her, his wide eyes brimming with uncertainty. “But what if I forget the moves?”

 

Agatha smiled, brushing a stray curl from his forehead. “You’ve been practicing so hard, sweetheart. You know the routine. And even if you make a mistake, it’s not the end of the world. What matters is that you go out there and try your best.”

 

He bit his lip, his feet still swinging. “But what if they laugh at me?”

 

Agatha’s expression grew serious, her hands giving his knees a reassuring squeeze. “No one will laugh at you, Nicky. Everyone there is rooting for you. And do you know why?”

 

He shook his head slightly.

 

“Because they love watching you shine,” she said. “You’re brave, you’re talented, and you’ve worked so hard for this. Everyone in that audience, including me, is there to support you.”

 

Nicky’s lips twitched into a small smile. “Even you?”

 

“Especially me,” Agatha said, her smile widening. “I’m your biggest fan, after all. And if you get nervous, just look for me in the crowd. I’ll be right there, cheering you on.”

 

Her words seemed to steady him, and he nodded slowly. “Okay,” he said, his voice a little stronger.

 

Agatha stood and held out her hand. “Come on, then. Let’s go show everyone how amazing you are.”

 

Nicky slid off the couch, slipping his hand into hers. As they walked toward the door, he glanced up at her, his nerves still there but now accompanied by a spark of determination.

 

“Thanks, Mama,” he said softly.

 

Agatha squeezed his hand, her heart swelling with pride and love. “Always, sweetheart.”

 

 

As they stepped outside into the crisp autumn air, Nicky’s steps grew steadier, his head held a little higher. Agatha couldn’t help but smile as she watched him—her son, her brave little dancer—ready to take on the world, one jump at a time.

 

The parking lot of the dance center buzzed with excitement, filled with the chatter of parents and the squeals of children dressed in recital attire. Agatha guided Nicky through the crowd, her hand resting lightly on his shoulder. Despite his earlier nerves, he seemed to be holding himself together, his small face a mixture of concentration and anticipation.

 

As they approached the entrance, the familiar figure of Rio Vidal came into view. She stood near the door, clipboard in hand, her long dark hair pulled back into a sleek ponytail. She wore a fitted black ensemble—a soft cardigan over her usual dance leggings and light pink ballet flats—that marked her as both professional and approachable. Her smile was warm as she greeted each child by name, offering quick words of encouragement and calm reassurances to the parents.

 

When her eyes landed on Nicky and Agatha, her smile widened, and she crouched slightly to meet Nicky’s gaze.

 

“Hey there, superstar!” Rio said brightly, her voice filled with genuine warmth. “Ready for the big day?”

 

Nicky hesitated for a moment before nodding shyly, his fingers gripping the edge of his shirt. “I think so,” he murmured.

 

Rio chuckled softly and leaned in just a bit. “You’re going to do amazing, Nicky. Remember, we’ve practiced this a hundred times. You’ve got it in the bag.”

 

Agatha watched the exchange, a small smile tugging at her lips. There was an ease to Rio’s presence, a way she seemed to instinctively know how to put the children—and their parents—at ease.

 

“Thank you, Miss Vidal,” Agatha said, her tone more formal than she intended. “He’s been looking forward to this for weeks.”

 

“It’s my pleasure,” Rio replied, straightening and glancing briefly at Agatha. There was a flicker of something in her expression—respect, curiosity—but she quickly turned her attention back to Nicky.

 

“Okay, champ,” Rio said, offering Nicky a high-five. “Go join your friends in the green room. We’ll be starting soon.”

 

Nicky returned the high-five with a small grin before scampering off, his earlier hesitation momentarily forgotten.

 

Agatha’s gaze lingered on her son for a moment before shifting back to Rio. “You have a way with them,” she remarked, her tone softer now.

 

Rio shrugged lightly, a faint blush coloring her cheeks. “They make it easy. Plus, it’s hard not to root for them when they’re this dedicated. Nicky’s been a joy to teach.”

 

Agatha nodded, her lips curving into a faint smile. “He’s very fond of you.”

 

Rio’s blush deepened, but she returned the smile. “He’s a great kid. You’ve done a wonderful job with him.”

 

There was a moment of quiet between them, the bustling noise of the other parents and children fading into the background. Agatha felt the pull of Rio’s steady gaze, and for a fleeting second, the boundary between professor and student blurred once more.

 

“Well,” Rio said, breaking the silence with a lighthearted tone, “I should go make sure the kids are ready. We wouldn’t want any wardrobe malfunctions or missing ballet shoes.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, nodding. “Of course. Thank you, Miss Vidal.”

 

Rio gave a small, respectful nod before disappearing into the crowd, clipboard in hand. Agatha watched her go, an odd mix of admiration and curiosity stirring within her.

 

Shaking the thought from her mind, she turned her attention back to the recital hall, ready to take her seat and cheer on her son.

 

The lights dimmed in the recital hall, and a soft wave of hushed murmurs rippled through the audience. Agatha settled into her seat, her hands clasped in her lap as she waited for the performance to begin. Around her, parents leaned forward with cameras at the ready, their faces a mix of anticipation and pride.

 

The curtain rose slowly, revealing a row of tiny dancers standing in perfect formation. Nicky was front and center, his small figure practically glowing under the stage lights. Agatha couldn’t help but smile as she spotted him, his face a careful mask of focus and determination.

 

The piano music began, and the children moved into their first position, their tiny arms and legs mirroring the basic steps they’d practiced countless times. Agatha’s heart swelled as she watched Nicky concentrate, his little brow furrowing with effort. He was so earnest, so utterly himself, that it brought a lump to her throat.

 

As the performance continued, Agatha’s gaze drifted toward the wings. There, just out of sight of the audience, was Rio. She stood at the edge of the stage, her body angled slightly toward the dancers, her attention wholly on them.

 

Agatha observed as Rio moved in perfect synchrony with the children, her hands lifting gracefully, her feet subtly marking the rhythm. She wasn’t performing for the audience but for the kids, providing them with a quiet anchor. Her face was alight with encouragement, and every now and then, she mouthed a gentle “You’ve got this” or “Keep going.”

 

When one of the little dancers hesitated, looking momentarily lost, Rio stepped slightly forward, her movements exaggerated just enough to guide the child back on track. The little one’s face lit up with recognition, and they quickly rejoined the routine.

 

Agatha found herself mesmerized—her attention split between her son and Rio’s unwavering focus and care. It wasn’t just her technical skill or her graceful movements; it was the quiet dedication she showed to the children. The way she gave all of herself to ensure their success.

 

A small, unexpected warmth bloomed in Agatha’s chest. There was something profoundly endearing about the way Rio carried herself—so poised, so quietly assertive, yet so tender in her interactions with the kids.

 

Nicky executed his final move—a slightly wobbly pirouette—and Agatha’s attention snapped back to the stage. The audience erupted in applause as the children beamed and took their bows, their pride radiating from their tiny forms.

 

Agatha clapped along with the crowd, her heart swelling as Nicky waved shyly in her direction. But as the curtain fell and the applause began to fade, her gaze instinctively returned to the wings, where Rio stood with a proud, almost maternal smile.

 

Agatha couldn’t help but think that Rio was more than just a regular student. She was a force—graceful and grounded, with a heart so big it seemed to encompass everyone around her.

 

And for the first time in a long while, Agatha allowed herself the smallest indulgence of curiosity, wondering what it was about Rio Vidal that made her feel so… drawn.

 

The other age groups had their turns, some were clearly more experienced than others and Agatha slowly lost focus on what was happening on stage, as her son was no longer the star of the show, and that there was no one to watch in the wings anymore, not that Agatha would ever admit that to anyone, not even herself.

 

As the show ended, the head of the dance school, a cheerful woman with a stern but warm presence, strode out onto the stage as the children took their final bows and scurried off to the wings. The audience, still buzzing with applause and chatter, quieted as she raised a hand for attention.

 

“Ladies and gentlemen,” she began, her voice warm and bright, “before we conclude this wonderful recital, we have one more surprise for you.”

 

Agatha noticed a ripple of curiosity sweep through the audience. She leaned slightly forward, intrigued.

 

“Our amazing dance teachers, who have worked tirelessly to prepare your children, have put together a little something special to end the day on a high note,” the headmistress continued. “Please join me in giving them a warm round of applause!”

 

The crowd erupted into cheers as the curtains parted once more. Agatha’s eyes immediately searched the line of teachers stepping onto the stage. And there she was—Rio Vidal.

 

Dressed in a sleek black leotard and flowing dance pants, like all the other teachers, Rio looked completely at ease under the bright lights. Her posture was straight and confident, her expression calm yet focused. She took her place among the other teachers, her movements fluid and practiced as they arranged themselves in formation.

 

The music began—a vibrant, rhythmic piece with a contemporary flair. The teachers launched into their routine, a seamless blend of modern and classical styles that showcased their individual talents while weaving them together into a cohesive, breathtaking performance.

 

Agatha’s eyes, however, were fixed solely on Rio. Her movements were a revelation—graceful yet powerful, every step deliberate and filled with energy. Her expressions were subtle but captivating, a quiet joy radiating from her as she moved. Rio was in her element, a stark contrast to the poised but reserved demeanor Agatha had come to know in the classroom.

 

As the routine progressed, Rio executed a series of intricate turns and leaps, her body seemingly weightless as she commanded the stage. The audience reacted with gasps and applause, clearly as entranced as Agatha. But what struck Agatha most wasn’t just Rio’s technical brilliance; it was the sheer passion she exuded.

 

Here was someone utterly alive, completely immersed in the moment.

 

By the time the performance reached its climax—a synchronized sequence that ended with the teachers forming a tableau—the audience was on its feet, cheering and applauding wildly. Agatha found herself clapping along, her usually reserved demeanor swept away by the infectious energy of the performance.

 

As the teachers bowed and the curtains began to close, Agatha couldn’t stop herself from lingering on Rio’s face. She looked radiant, her smile wide and genuine as she exchanged laughs and high-fives with her fellow teachers.

 

For a moment, Agatha wondered if she’d ever seen anyone so captivating. Then, catching herself, she forced her thoughts back into the appropriate box.

 

Rio Vidal was her student, of course she cared. Like any other student.

 

But as the applause continued to echo around her, Agatha couldn’t ignore the small voice in her mind whispering that perhaps Rio Vidal was something more.

 

As the applause thundered through the recital hall, Agatha’s gaze swept across the audience. Amidst the standing ovation, her eyes caught sight of an older woman standing near the back of the room, clapping enthusiastically and cheering loud enough to stand out even in the boisterous crowd.

 

The woman was striking, with an air of warmth and pride that radiated from her, her curly grey hair bunched on her head in a messy silver bun and exuding comfort with her patterned shawl. She had a confident stance, her hands moving energetically as she applauded, her expression beaming. Agatha noted the way her gaze was fixed on Rio, unmistakably directed at her and filled with unmistakable affection.

 

From the stage, Rio glanced toward the woman and smiled—a bright, genuine smile that softened her usually composed features. Then she waved, small but unmistakably directed at the woman.

 

The exchange was quick, but it left Agatha with a curious twinge she couldn’t quite place. She turned her attention back to the woman, wondering who she was. A relative, perhaps? A friend? She didn’t look like Rio at all, so maybe not her mom.

 

The thought lingered as the teachers exited the stage and the headmistress returned to thank everyone for attending. Agatha clapped politely, her mind still half-focused on the brief interaction between Rio and the woman in the audience.

 

As people began gathering their belongings and moving toward the exits, Agatha stayed seated for a moment longer, her thoughts swirling. She wasn’t sure why it mattered—Rio’s personal connections were none of her business. But something about the pride and affection in that woman’s gaze stirred a quiet curiosity in her.

 

Eventually, Agatha rose, shaking off the thought. She had Nicky to fetch, a recital to celebrate, and little time to dwell on questions that didn’t concern her.

 

Still, as she wove her way through the departing crowd, the image of Rio’s body moving on stage lingered in her mind, accompanied by the faintest sense of intrigue.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Celebrations and Questioning

*

*

*

Chill

Fingers of yew be curled

Down on us? After the kingfisher's wing

Has answered light to light, and is silent, the light is still

At the still point of the turning world.

       

       (Eliot, “Burnt Norton”, Four Quartets)

 

 

After the recital ended and the families began to filter out of the dance center, Rio stayed behind to help the other teachers tidy up the studio and ensure all the kids left with their belongings. She exchanged warm goodbyes with a few lingering parents, offering final words of congratulations to the excited children still buzzing from their performances.

 

As the last of the families departed, Rio grabbed her bag from the back office and made her way outside, where she spotted Lilia waiting near the entrance.

 

“Hey, sweet girl,” Lilia greeted with a wide smile, pulling Rio into a quick hug. “You were amazing up there. I swear, every time I see you dance, it’s like watching magic.”

 

Rio laughed softly, a faint blush coloring her cheeks. “Thanks, Lilia. And thanks for coming. You didn’t have to, you know.”

 

“Of course I did,” Lilia replied, mock-offended. “You think I’m going to miss a chance to cheer for you, even if you’re not a little kid anymore? Not a chance.”

 

Rio grinned, the warmth of Lilia’s unwavering support easing some of the fatigue from the day. “Well, I appreciate it. Want to grab a drink to celebrate?”

 

Lilia’s smile widened. “Thought you’d never ask. Let’s go.”

 

The two of them strolled to a cozy bar a few blocks away, the kind of place with dim lighting, mismatched furniture, and a quiet hum of conversation. They found a small table near the back, settling in with a sense of ease born from years of familiarity.

 

“To a successful recital,” Lilia said, raising her glass of wine as Rio lifted her own, a cider sparkling in the dim light.

 

“To the best cheerleader I could ever ask for,” Rio replied, clinking her glass against Lilia’s.

 

As they sipped their drinks, the conversation turned to the recital. Lilia couldn’t stop gushing about how adorable the kids were, particularly Nicky, whom she remembered Rio mentioning fondly in their chats.

 

“That little boy in the middle—Nicky, right?” Lilia asked. “He was so focused. It was the cutest thing.”

 

Rio chuckled, her expression softening. “Yeah, he’s a sweetheart. Works really hard, too. His mom is really involved. She’s one of those parents who’s so on top of things, but not in a pushy way. He’s lucky.”

 

Lilia leaned forward, smirking. “And what about his mom? Is she lucky to have you as his teacher?”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, though she couldn’t hide the faint smile tugging at her lips. “She’s my professor, Lilia. Let’s not start that conversation.”

 

“Oh, I’m not starting anything,” Lilia teased, leaning back in her chair with a knowing look. “Just making an observation. But seriously, you were incredible tonight. You should be proud of yourself.”

 

“Thanks,” Rio said, her voice quieter now, touched by the sincerity in Lilia’s tone. “I am. And it means a lot to have you here.”

 

They stayed at the bar for a while longer, reminiscing about old times and catching up on the little details of their lives. For Rio, the evening was a reminder of how lucky she was to have someone like Lilia in her corner—someone who had always believed in her, even when she struggled to believe in herself.

 

As Rio sipped her cider, Lilia’s voice drifted in and out of focus. She nodded and smiled at the right moments, but her mind kept circling back to a moment earlier that evening—when she had caught sight of Professor Harkness in the audience.

 

Agatha had been sitting near the middle, her dark hair neatly swept back, her posture as composed as ever. But there had been something different about her tonight. Gone was the cool, imposing air of the seminar room. Instead, she had looked softer, warmer, her sharp gaze replaced by something gentler as she watched her son on stage.

 

And then there was Nicky.

 

Rio had seen the little boy’s nerves as he arrived that evening, clinging to his mother’s hand like it was a lifeline. She’d heard Agatha’s soothing words, quiet but firm, coaxing Nicky into a smile. The memory made Rio smile now.

 

It was so unlike the Agatha she saw in class—the one who wielded words like weapons and demanded excellence from her students with a single arched brow. This Agatha was tender, patient, and undeniably loving. Watching her interact with her son had stirred something in Rio, though she couldn’t quite put her finger on it.

 

“She really is something, huh?”

 

Rio blinked, startled to find Lilia watching her with a raised eyebrow.

 

“What?” Rio asked, flustered.

 

“Whoever you’re thinking about,” Lilia said, her smirk widening. “You’ve got that look on your face. The dreamy one.”

 

“I don’t have a look,” Rio protested, though her cheeks burned.

 

“Sure you don’t,” Lilia teased, taking another sip of her wine. “So, who is it? Someone at the recital?”

 

Rio hesitated, her fingers tracing the rim of her glass. “It’s not like that. I was just… thinking about Professor Harkness.”

 

Lilia’s eyebrows shot up. “Oh, really? And what about the good doctor has you so distracted tonight?”

 

“It’s nothing,” Rio said quickly, though the words felt hollow even to her. “I just—she was there for Nicky, her son. The one we just talked about. And she was just… different than I expected.”

 

“Different how?” Lilia pressed, leaning forward.

 

Rio hesitated, searching for the right words. “In class, she’s so… precise. Intimidating, even. But tonight, she was softer. You could see how much she cares about him. The way she talks to him, the way she looks at him—it’s like the rest of the world disappears.”

 

Lilia tilted her head, her expression softening. “Sounds like she made an impression. Be careful though. Some lines shouldn’t be blurred you know.”

 

Rio shrugged, trying to downplay the flutter of emotions rising in her chest. “I know, I know. I guess it’s just surprising. Seeing someone like her—someone who always seems so in control—be so human.”

 

Lilia’s smirk returned, though it was gentler this time. “Well, maybe you’re starting to see her for who she really is, not just who she is in the classroom.”

 

Rio didn’t respond, her thoughts too tangled to untangle. All she knew was that the image of Agatha Harkness, leaning down to whisper something encouraging to her son, had rooted itself firmly in her mind—and no matter how much she tried, she couldn’t quite shake it. Lilia was a product of her time, having been a teenager in the late 70s, where lines were less strict and she knew she could be of good advice, but she wasn’t ready for that discussion.

 

 

After leaving the bar, Rio made her way back to her campus apartment. The night air was crisp, carrying the faint scent of rain that had fallen earlier in the afternoon. She walked briskly, her bag slung over one shoulder, her thoughts scattered between the evening’s events and the tasks awaiting her at the library.

 

She climbed the stairs to her apartment, unlocking the door to the familiar, slightly cluttered space she called home. Books and papers were strewn across the small desk by the window, her old ballet shoes rested in the corner near her bed, and a mug sat forgotten on the coffee table. Plants were everywhere, on most of the surface, even hung above the window and on the shelves in her very small kitchen.

 

Rio set her things down and went straight to her room, rifling through her closet for something more comfortable to wear. She changed into a soft hoodie and jeans, tying her hair back into a loose bun. Her reflection in the mirror was tired but determined. A long evening of research with Alice loomed ahead, but instead of focusing on the books and notes waiting for her, her mind kept circling back to one thing—or rather, one person.

 

Rio had seen her professor in many different lights—stern and commanding in the seminar room, sharp and witty during one-on-one meetings—but tonight had added a new layer. Seeing Agatha as a mother, so attentive and tender with Nicky, had caught Rio off guard. It was an intimacy she hadn’t expected, a warmth that lingered in her thoughts long after the recital had ended.

 

She sat on the edge of her bed, staring at her phone. A part of her wanted to text Alice, to distract herself with her friend’s sharp humor and easy banter. But instead, she leaned back against the pillows, letting her thoughts wander.

 

The image of Agatha, standing in the audience, clapping proudly as Nicky danced, wouldn’t leave her mind. The way she had softened when her son looked at her, the subtle but undeniable joy in her expression—it was so unlike the composed, almost untouchable Dr. Harkness Rio had come to know in class.

 

Rio sighed, rubbing her temples. “Get it together, Vidal,” she muttered to herself. “She’s your professor, not—”

 

Not what? Not someone she could be intrigued by? Not someone she could admire beyond an academic context?

 

Shaking her head, Rio forced herself to her feet, grabbing her backpack and laptop. She needed to get to the library before Alice started texting her snarky reminders about being late.

 

Still, as she locked her apartment and headed out into the night, her thoughts remained frustratingly preoccupied. No matter how much she tried to push Agatha Harkness out of her mind, the professor’s shadow lingered, refusing to be ignored.

 

 

The campus library was quiet, its usual hum of activity replaced by the soft rustle of pages and the muted clicking of keyboards. It was late enough that most students had already called it a night, but Rio knew she and Alice thrived in the stillness of these late hours.

 

When Rio stepped inside, she spotted Alice right away. Her friend was sprawled across a table near the philosophy section, her laptop open and surrounded by a chaotic array of notes, textbooks, and an oversized coffee cup. As always, Alice looked like she was simultaneously working on three different things and somehow thriving.

 

“You’re late,” Alice greeted without looking up, tapping furiously at her keyboard.

 

“You’re early,” Rio shot back, sliding into the chair across from her.

 

Alice finally looked up, raising an eyebrow. “I’m always early. You’re just chronically distracted.”

 

Rio ignored the jab, pulling out her laptop and notepad. “What are you working on?”

 

“Analyzing the use of leitmotifs in The Ring Cycle,” Alice replied with a dramatic sigh. “It’s either genius or torture. Possibly both.”

 

Rio smiled faintly, pulling up her own notes. “Sounds about right for you.”

 

As they worked, the silence between them settled into an easy rhythm. The occasional sound of a turning page or a whispered comment broke the quiet, but mostly they focused on their respective projects.

 

For Rio, though, focusing was easier said than done. Her notes blurred together, her thoughts drifting back to Agatha. The recital, her effortless grace in the seminar room, her quiet but powerful presence—it all swirled in Rio’s mind, unbidden and distracting.

 

“You’re doing it again,” Alice said, breaking the silence.

 

Rio blinked, startled. “Doing what?”

 

Alice gave her a knowing look. “Spacing out. Thinking about her, aren’t you?”

 

“I’m not—”

 

“You are,” Alice interrupted, smirking. “It’s written all over your face. So, what was it this time? Another brilliant comment in class? Or are you still stuck on the recital?”

 

Rio groaned, dropping her head into her hands. “Alice, I swear—”

 

“Hey, no judgment,” Alice said, holding up her hands in mock surrender. “I’m just saying, maybe you should lean into it. It’s obviously rattling around in there for a reason.”

 

“She’s my professor,” Rio muttered, her voice muffled against her hands.

 

“And?” Alice countered. “Doesn’t mean you can’t think she’s fascinating. Or, you know, intimidatingly gorgeous.”

 

Rio’s head shot up, her cheeks burning. “Alice!”

 

“What?” Alice said, grinning unapologetically. “You know I’m right.”

 

Rio sighed, shaking her head but unable to stop a small smile from tugging at her lips. “I’m never telling you anything ever again.”

 

“You love me,” Alice replied, spinning her laptop toward Rio. “Now, stop brooding and tell me if this analysis makes sense.”

 

Rio leaned forward, grateful for the distraction. Still, as they worked late into the night, her thoughts occasionally strayed.

 

After a few more hours, Alice stretched dramatically, gathering her books and laptop. “Alright, I’m calling it. If I keep staring at this screen, I’m going to go blind or mad—or both.”

 

Rio glanced up from her own laptop, smirking. “Already giving up?”

 

“Excuse me, I’ve been here for hours,” Alice shot back, slinging her bag over her shoulder. “Unlike some people, I don’t survive on coffee and denial.”

 

Rio laughed softly, leaning back in her chair. “Fair enough. I’ll see you tomorrow?”

 

“Yep. Try not to stay too late,” Alice said, waving as she headed toward the exit.

 

With Alice gone, the library felt even quieter. Rio returned to her work, forcing herself to focus, but the distraction of her swirling thoughts made progress slow. Finally, she decided to pack up for the night.

 

The campus was eerily still as she stepped out of the library, her breath visible in the cool night air. She adjusted her bag on her shoulder and started down the path, the glow of the lampposts casting long shadows.

 

As she rounded a corner, Rio nearly collided with someone coming the opposite way. She staggered back, startled, and looked up to see none other than Agatha Harkness standing in front of her, her hand on her arm to steady her.

 

“Oh! Professor Harkness,” Rio stammered, her voice breaking the quiet.

 

Agatha’s eyebrows lifted slightly, though her expression remained composed. “Miss Vidal. Burning the midnight oil, I see.”

 

Rio flushed, struggling to recover. “Uh, yes. Just wrapping up some research. What about you? Late meeting?”

 

Agatha nodded, her posture as effortless as ever. “Faculty business. Would rather have stayed with Nicky after his big day, but they didn’t give me a choice. It ran later than expected.”

 

The lamplight caught the faint sheen of weariness in Agatha’s eyes, but her presence was as intimidating as ever. Rio suddenly felt self-conscious, acutely aware of the contrast between her casual hoodie and jeans and Agatha’s perfectly tailored coat. She realized that Agatha’s hand was still on her arm, and Agatha, following her gaze, immediately let her go.

 

For a moment, they stood in silence, the night pressing in around them. Rio shifted her weight, unsure if she should excuse herself or say something else.

 

“You should be careful walking alone this late,” Agatha said finally, her voice calm but firm. “Campus is quiet, but that doesn’t mean it’s always safe.”

 

“I’m okay,” Rio said quickly. “The library’s not far from my apartment.”

 

Agatha studied her for a moment, then gave a small nod. “Still, it’s good to stay aware.”

 

“Thank you,” Rio said softly, the warmth of Agatha’s concern catching her off guard.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a faint smile, barely there but unmistakable. “Goodnight, Miss Vidal.”

 

“Goodnight, Professor,” Rio replied, watching as Agatha turned and walked away, her figure disappearing into the shadows.

 

As Rio continued her own path back to her apartment, her heart thudded in her chest. The encounter was brief, almost mundane, yet it left her feeling as though the night air had shifted somehow, charged with an energy she couldn’t quite name.

*

*

*

 

Impromptu Invitation

*

*

*

Sudden in a shaft of sunlight

Even while the dust moves

There rises the hidden laughter

Of children in the foliage

Quick now, here, now, always—

Ridiculous the waste sad time

Stretching before and after.

         (T. S. Eliot, “Burnt Norton”, Four Quartets)

 

 

The sound of distorted guitar chords and drum beats echoed through the small rehearsal space as Rio adjusted her drum kit. The band was in the thick of practice for their upcoming gig, with Alice on the keyboard and Jen shredding on her guitar. The energy in the room was lively, but Rio couldn’t shake the sense that something was… different.

 

It wasn’t the music. That was as tight as ever, their years of playing together creating an effortless synergy. No, it was something else—something between Alice and Jen.

 

They’d always had a good rapport, but tonight, there was an added layer of familiarity to their banter, a warmth that hadn’t been there before. Jen leaned closer than usual when they talked, her sharp, playful remarks met with Alice’s soft smiles. At one point, Jen reached over to fix a loose strap on Alice’s keyboard, her fingers brushing Alice’s hand in a way that seemed more intentional than casual.

 

Rio’s sticks faltered on the cymbal, and she had to cover her slip by pretending to adjust her stool.

 

Alice noticed. “You good back there, Vidal?”

 

“Fine,” Rio replied quickly, rolling her shoulders. “Just need to get comfortable.”

 

“Comfort is key,” Jen quipped, her grin directed more at Alice than at Rio.

 

Alice laughed, her gaze lingering on Jen for a beat longer than necessary before she turned back to her keyboard.

 

Yep. Something had definitely shifted.

 

Rio didn’t mind—she was happy for her friends if something was happening between them. But it was… strange. She’d always seen Alice as the steady one, the one least likely to fall into the chaos of feelings. Seeing her now, with a softness in her eyes and an ease in her laughter, was almost surreal.

 

“Alright, let’s run that last song again,” Alice said, her tone all business as she gestured to Jen. “And try not to show off too much this time.”

 

“No promises,” Jen shot back, winking.

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t help smiling. She counted them in, the steady beat of the drums grounding her as they launched into the song.

 

By the end of rehearsal, the tension in the room had settled into something more comfortable. They packed up their gear, chatting about the setlist for their gig, but Rio noticed how Alice and Jen stayed close to each other, their casual touches and glances speaking volumes.

 

As they walked out of the studio, Alice nudged Rio. “You were quiet tonight. Everything okay?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio said, smirking. “Just trying to keep up with all the comfort happening in there.”

 

Alice blinked, then groaned. “Oh, no. Don’t start.”

 

“I didn’t say anything,” Rio said innocently.

 

“You didn’t have to,” Alice grumbled, but her cheeks were a little pink as she shoved her hands in her pockets.

 

Behind them, Jen called out, “What’s going on up there?”

 

“Nothing!” Alice yelled back, glaring at Rio.

 

Rio just laughed, her spirits lifting. Whatever was happening between Alice and Jen, it was good. She didn’t need to understand it fully to know that.

 

The walk back to campus was filled with casual conversation, but Rio couldn’t help noticing how Alice and Jen fell into step beside each other, their conversation flowing easily in a way that felt new. Jen carried Alice’s keyboard case without being asked, and Alice nudged her shoulder playfully as they joked about one of the songs they’d practiced.

 

Rio walked slightly behind them, watching with quiet amusement. Alice, normally so guarded and practical, seemed lighter around Jen, her usual sharpness tempered by a warmth that Rio rarely saw outside their closest moments.

 

When they reached the student center, where they would part ways, Jen lingered. “You sure you’re good carrying this back to your apartment?” she asked Alice, gesturing to the keyboard case.

 

Alice rolled her eyes, smirking. “I’ve carried it a million times. I’ll survive, mom.”

 

Jen grinned. “Fine. Just don’t say I didn’t offer.”

 

As Alice turned to go, Jen hesitated, then called after her, “Hey, don’t forget to check your email. I sent over those chord changes.”

 

“I’ll get to it,” Alice replied, waving as she walked away.

 

Jen watched her go for a moment, then turned back to Rio, her expression shifting into something more neutral. “She’s stubborn.”

 

“Always,” Rio agreed, her tone light. “You’re good for her, though.”

 

Jen raised an eyebrow, her lips curving into a faint smile. “You think so?”

 

Rio shrugged. “Yeah. She hasn’t looked this happy in a while.”

 

For a moment, Jen seemed taken aback, but then she nodded, slinging her guitar strap over her shoulder. “Well, let’s see how long I can keep that streak going.”

 

“Good luck,” Rio teased.

 

Jen gave her a two-fingered salute before heading off into the night.

 

Rio stood there for a moment, watching her friends disappear into the distance. There was a warm satisfaction in seeing them find something special in each other, but it also stirred a strange ache in her chest—something she couldn’t quite name.

 

With a sigh, Rio turned and headed toward her own apartment. As much as she was happy for Alice, she couldn’t help wondering why her own life felt so… complicated in comparison. Her thoughts, predictably, drifted to Agatha again.

 

“Stop it,” she muttered to herself as she walked. But the thought of Agatha’s quiet strength, her presence, and the way she softened around her son wouldn’t leave her mind.

 

By the time Rio reached her apartment, she was exhausted, both physically and mentally. She collapsed onto her bed, staring up at the ceiling, and let her thoughts wander.
