Alice and Jen had found something unexpected, something that seemed to just fit. Rio couldn’t help wondering if she would ever find that for herself—and what it might look like if she did.

 

 

The crisp morning air carried the scent of fallen leaves as Agatha and Nicky strolled through the park. Nicky skipped ahead, clutching a small bag of birdseed he’d insisted on bringing to feed the pigeons. Agatha watched him fondly, her hands tucked into the pockets of her coat, her usual poised demeanor softened by the casual outing.

 

“Not too far, Nicky,” she called as he darted toward a cluster of birds near a bench.

 

“I won’t, Mama!” he shouted back, already scattering seeds with dramatic enthusiasm.

 

Agatha shook her head, a small smile tugging at her lips. It was rare for her to take time away from her usual schedule of teaching, writing, and meetings, but she’d promised Nicky they’d spend the morning together. She was glad she had.

 

As she walked toward where Nicky was crouched, another figure came into view—a familiar one.

 

Rio Vidal was seated on the edge of the bench near the pigeons, a notebook balanced on her knees raised to her chest and a pen in her hand. She was dressed casually in a leather jacket and jeans, her dark hair loose and windswept by the breeze. Her focus was entirely on the page in front of her, her pen moving in steady strokes.

 

Agatha hesitated for a moment, caught off guard. It wasn’t the first time she’d seen Rio outside of class—there was the dance recital, of course—but something about this chance encounter felt unexpectedly intimate.

 

“Mama!” Nicky’s voice broke her reverie as he ran back toward her. “Can I use the rest of the seeds? There’s a squirrel over there!”

 

Agatha nodded, her attention shifting back to him. “Go ahead, but don’t chase it.”

 

As Nicky raced off, Agatha turned back toward the bench, only to see that Rio had looked up and spotted her. Their eyes met, and Rio smiled—a warm, slightly surprised expression that made Agatha’s chest tighten inexplicably.

 

“Professor Harkness,” Rio said, closing her notebook and standing. “Good morning.”

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha replied, her tone calm and measured as always, though her heart beat a fraction faster. “I didn’t expect to see you here.”

 

“I come here to write sometimes,” Rio explained, tucking the notebook into her bag. “It’s quieter than the library sometimes, and the fresh air helps me think.”

 

Agatha nodded, glancing toward where Nicky was now crouched by a tree, offering seeds to a particularly bold squirrel. “We’re here for him, of course,” she said, her voice softening.

 

Rio followed her gaze, smiling. “He’s really sweet. He talks about you all the time in class, you know.”

 

“Oh?” Agatha raised an eyebrow, intrigued.

 

“Yeah,” Rio said, her smile widening. “You’re his hero. He told me he wants to be as smart and cool as his mom when he grows up.”

 

Agatha felt a rare flush of warmth rise to her cheeks. She glanced away, watching Nicky with an expression that was both fond and slightly embarrassed. “He’s a bit biased, I think.”

 

“I don’t know,” Rio said, her tone light but sincere. “He might be onto something.”

 

Agatha looked back at her, caught off guard by the comment. There was no teasing in Rio’s voice—just a quiet admiration that felt almost… personal.

 

Before Agatha could respond, Nicky came running back, his cheeks flushed with excitement. “Mama, the squirrel took the seed from my hand!”

 

“Did it?” Agatha said, crouching slightly to meet his gaze. “You must have been very patient.”

 

“I was! Oh hi Miss Rio, did you see it?” Nicky turned to Rio, his eyes bright.

 

“I missed it,” Rio said, crouching to his level. “But it sounds amazing. Maybe you’ll have to show me again next time.”

 

“Okay!” Nicky beamed, clearly pleased.

 

Agatha straightened, watching the easy way Rio interacted with her son. The dynamic between them was effortless, natural, and Agatha felt an unfamiliar pang of… what? Longing? Curiosity?

 

“We should let you get back to your writing,” Agatha said finally, her voice carefully neutral.

 

“Oh, I was about to leave anyway,” Rio replied, standing again. “It was nice running into you both.”

 

As Rio slung her bag over her shoulder and started down the path, Nicky waved enthusiastically after her. “Bye, Miss Rio!”

 

“Bye, Nicky,” Rio called back, her smile lingering even as she walked away. But before she could get too far, her pulse quickened as a spark of boldness flared—an uncharacteristic urge to close the small gap between herself and Professor Harkness, to bridge the distance of formality that usually defined their interactions.

 

She turned back, clutching the strap of her bag like it was the only thing grounding her courage. “Professor Harkness?”

 

Agatha, who had been watching Nicky skip in circles around a tree, looked up. “Yes?”

 

Rio took a half step forward, her voice steady despite the flutter in her chest. “Um, I just thought I’d mention—my band is playing at O’Malley’s this Friday night. It’s nothing fancy, but if you’re free, it might be fun.”

 

Agatha blinked, her poised demeanor softening into something gentler. For a moment, she didn’t respond, as if weighing the invitation more seriously than Rio had expected.

 

“That’s kind of you to mention,” Agatha said at last, a faint smile touching her lips. “I’ll see if I can make it. I don’t know if…”

 

Rio’s heart skipped, though she kept her tone light. “No pressure. Just thought I’d let you know.”

 

Nicky, now tugging on his mother’s sleeve, piped up, “Are you in a band, Miss Rio? Like a real band?”

 

Rio laughed, crouching to meet his curious gaze. “A real band. I even play the drums.”

 

“Whoa!” Nicky’s eyes widened with delight. “That’s so cool! Mama, can I go to her band thing?”

 

Agatha chuckled, gently smoothing Nicky’s hair. “It’s at a bar, sweetheart. That’s not exactly a place for six-year-olds.”

 

Nicky pouted for a moment before brightening again. “Will you go, then? You can tell me all about it!”

 

“We’ll see,” Agatha said, her tone kind but noncommittal.

 

Rio straightened, giving Nicky a playful grin. “Maybe I’ll play an extra cool drum solo just for you.”

 

“Yes!” Nicky pumped his fist, clearly thrilled at the idea.

 

“Take care, Miss Vidal,” Agatha said, her voice tinged with something warmer than usual as she gently steered Nicky back toward the path.

 

“You too,” Rio replied, her courage fading into a soft, lingering smile as she watched them walk away.

 

As she finally turned to leave the park, her heart raced—not from nerves but from the thrill of having taken a chance. Whether or not Agatha showed up on Friday, she’d done something she never thought she’d have the nerve to do.

 

Agatha watched her go, the crisp air suddenly feeling warmer. Nicky tugged at her hand, breaking her thoughts.

 

“Mom, can we go to the playground now?”

 

“Of course,” she said, her voice steady as she took his hand. But as they walked, her mind wandered back to Rio, her words, her presence, and the unexpected way she seemed to slip so easily into Agatha’s carefully controlled world.

 

 

As Rio walked away from the park, her heart raced, each step quicker than the last. The cool breeze against her face did little to calm the flush creeping up her neck and cheeks.

 

What were you thinking, Vidal?

 

Her internal monologue spiraled as she replayed the moment over and over. She’d invited Professor Harkness—her PhD supervisor—to her band’s gig at a bar. A bar.

 

She groaned under her breath, clutching the strap of her bag tightly. “Smooth. Really smooth,” she muttered to herself, weaving through the park paths as though walking faster would somehow help her escape the weight of her embarrassment.

 

Why had she done it? She’d been perfectly fine chatting about the park, Nicky, and squirrels. But then that spark of courage—no, foolishness—had flared, and the words had just spilled out. And now, she couldn’t take them back.

 

What if she actually shows up?

 

Rio winced at the thought. The idea of performing in front of a crowd had never fazed her before; she loved the stage, the music, the energy. But the thought of Agatha Harkness sitting in the audience, her piercing gaze assessing—not papers or seminar contributions, but her—was enough to make Rio want to sink into the ground.

 

She stopped walking, taking a deep breath to steady herself. “Okay, calm down,” she said aloud, earning a curious glance from an elderly man walking his dog. She shot him a sheepish smile and resumed walking.

 

It wasn’t as if Agatha had said she’d come. She’d just said she’d see if she could make it. That was probably her polite way of declining without hurting Rio’s feelings. And honestly, Rio hoped that was the case.

 

But what if she does come?

 

The thought sent another wave of panic crashing through her. She could already hear Alice and Jen teasing her mercilessly about it during rehearsal.

 

“Oh, relax,” she told herself, finally slowing her pace. “You’re overthinking this.”

 

But no matter how many times she repeated it, the flutter of anxiety—and something else she didn’t quite want to name—lingered in her chest all the way back to campus.

 

 

Later that evening, Agatha sat in her study, her desk illuminated by the soft glow of a desk lamp. Papers were spread before her—essays waiting to be graded—but her attention wasn’t on them. Instead, her thoughts drifted to the park, to Rio’s invitation, and to the unexpected boldness in her student’s voice as she extended it.

 

It had been such a simple thing—a casual mention of a Friday night band performance. Yet it lingered in Agatha’s mind, unsettled and persistent, like a thread she couldn’t untangle.

 

She leaned back in her chair, tapping her pen lightly against the wood. Could she really go?

 

There was no rule forbidding it, of course. Professors were allowed lives outside of academia. But Rio wasn’t just a student—she was her student now, assigned under her supervision for the PhD program.

 

And yet…

 

Agatha thought of Rio crouched beside Nicky, patiently listening to his excited chatter, the way she’d waved goodbye with that warm, easy smile. She thought of how Nicky had lit up at the mention of Rio being in a band, his awe at the idea of her playing the drums.

 

Her lips curved into a small, reluctant smile. It wasn’t just Nicky who’d been caught off guard. Seeing Rio outside the carefully structured world of academia had shifted something—nudged the perception Agatha held of her. Rio was not just the brilliant young scholar she saw in seminars or the calm, confident teacher guiding children at the recital. She was multifaceted, dynamic.

 

But did that justify showing up?

 

Agatha frowned, running her fingers through her hair. If she went, what would it mean? For Rio? For herself? Would it blur the professional boundaries she so carefully maintained?

 

Nicky’s words replayed in her mind. “Will you go, then? You can tell me all about it!”

 

Agatha sighed, resting her chin on her hand. Maybe it didn’t have to mean anything. Maybe it could just be about indulging her curiosity and supporting a student who, despite her composed exterior, had mustered the courage to invite her.

 

She glanced at the stack of essays on her desk. There was still time to decide. Friday was days away.

 

For now, she resolved to focus on her work—but as she picked up her pen, her thoughts betrayed her, drifting once again to the vision of Rio Vidal behind a drum set, her presence as electric and mysterious as her intellect.

*

*

*

 

 

Will She, Won’t She

*

*

*

[...] but the sudden illumination—

We had the experience but missed the meaning,

And approach to the meaning restores the experience

In a different form, beyond any meaning

We can assign to happiness.

        (T. S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

By the time Friday afternoon rolled around, Rio was a bundle of nerves. Her usual pre-gig excitement had been replaced with an anxious knot twisting in her stomach. She paced the small stretch of her apartment, muttering under her breath as she double-checked her outfit, her drumsticks, and even the setlist.

 

Maybe she won’t come. Maybe she forgot.

 

But what if she didn’t?

 

Unable to keep it to herself any longer, she grabbed her phone and texted Alice:

 

Rio: Are you at the bar yet? I need to talk.

 

The reply came almost instantly:

 

Alice: Getting there. What’s up? Nervous?

 

Rio grimaced. Nervous didn’t even begin to cover it.

 

Rio: More like I might’ve done something really stupid.

 

By the time Rio arrived at O’Malley’s, her drumsticks in hand and anxiety written all over her face, Alice was already at the bar, sipping a beer. She raised an eyebrow as Rio slid into the seat next to her.

 

“So, what’s this about doing something stupid?” Alice asked, her tone light and teasing.

 

Rio hesitated, then leaned in closer, lowering her voice. “Okay, don’t freak out. But… I kind of invited Dr. Harkness to the show.”

 

For a second, Alice just blinked at her. Then, she burst out laughing, nearly spilling her drink. “You what?”

 

“I know, I know!” Rio groaned, burying her face in her hands. “It was a heat-of-the-moment thing, and I didn’t think she’d actually come, but now I can’t stop thinking about it.”

 

Alice grinned, leaning back in her chair. “Rio, you invited your professor—your supervisor—to watch you play drums in a grungy bar. That’s amazing.”

 

“It’s not amazing. It’s horrifying,” Rio muttered.

 

Alice tilted her head, her grin widening. “Oh, come on. Worst-case scenario, she doesn’t show up, and you spent a week panicking for nothing. Best-case scenario, she does come, and we get to see you lose your cool on stage. Honestly, I’m rooting for the second option.”

 

Rio groaned again, her cheeks burning. “You’re not helping.”

 

“But I am,” Alice said, patting her shoulder. “Look, if she comes, it’s because she wants to. You’re not dragging her here against her will. And if she doesn’t, who cares? Either way, you’re still going to kill it tonight.”

 

Rio sighed, fiddling with her drumsticks. “I don’t know. It just feels… weird. Like I crossed some kind of boundary.”

 

“Relax,” Alice said, giving her a reassuring smile. “You’re allowed to have a life, Rio. Even if it includes being ridiculously fascinated by your professor.”

 

“I’m not—”

 

“Sure you’re not.” Alice winked, cutting her off. “Now, let’s get to soundcheck before Jen starts texting us death threats.”

 

Rio reluctantly followed Alice toward the stage, her heart still racing. The bar was starting to fill up, and she scanned the crowd, half-hoping and half-dreading seeing a familiar face.

 

Please don’t come, she thought. Then, a beat later: But if you do…

 

She didn’t let herself finish the thought.

 

 

As Friday afternoon stretched into evening, Agatha sat in her living room, a glass of wine untouched on the coffee table in front of her. Nicky was happily occupied with his new building set, chattering to himself as he constructed a tiny fortress on the rug.

 

Agatha, however, was a world away.

 

Rio Vidal’s invitation lingered in her thoughts, an echo she hadn’t been able to shake all week. It had been a casual offer, tossed out with more courage than Rio probably intended to reveal, and yet it had stirred something in Agatha—a flicker of interest she hadn’t entirely welcomed.

 

Her gaze drifted to the clock. If she left now, she could easily make it to O’Malley’s before the band started. But should she?

 

There were a dozen reasons not to go. It wasn’t exactly professional, showing up to a student’s band performance. There was the question of boundaries, of appearances, of how it might be perceived by others. Agatha was well aware of the fine line she walked as a professor, particularly now that Rio was under her direct supervision.

 

But then there was the other side of the argument—the quieter, more personal side she rarely let herself indulge.

 

Agatha thought of Nicky at the park, looking up at Rio like she was the coolest person in the world. Of Rio’s easy smile and the way her eyes had sparkled with that nervous, fleeting hopefulness as she extended the invitation. There had been no expectation in it, no attempt to curry favor or blur the lines of their relationship. It had been a simple, genuine moment, offered without pretense.

 

And, she had to admit, she was curious. Curious about this other side of Rio, the one that existed beyond the seminar room and the dance studio.

 

“Mama?” Nicky’s voice cut into her thoughts, and she looked over to find him holding up a lopsided piece of his fortress. “Do you think this should go on top or on the side?”

 

Agatha smiled, leaning forward to inspect his work. “I think it’s perfect just as it is.”

 

He beamed, turning back to his creation, and Agatha’s heart softened.

 

Maybe it wouldn’t be such a terrible thing, she thought, reaching for her glass of wine and sipping it slowly. Just this once.

 

The clock ticked forward. Agatha sat back, still undecided. There was time yet to make a choice, but the weight of it pressed against her, urging her to decide.

 

Agatha exhaled sharply, leaning back on the couch as the decision settled in her chest. She was going.

 

But it didn’t mean anything. It wasn’t unusual for a professor to support a student’s extracurricular activities. It wasn’t about Rio. It was about curiosity and support , she told herself, about broadening her understanding of the people she taught, so she could help them better.

 

Still, the flutter in her chest betrayed her attempt to keep it purely professional.

 

She picked up her phone and dialed Wanda.

 

“Hey, Aggie!” Wanda’s warm voice answered almost immediately. “What’s up?”

 

Agatha smiled despite herself. “I need a favor. Are you free tonight to watch Nicky for a couple of hours?”

 

“Depends,” Wanda teased. “What’s the occasion? A hot date?”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes, though Wanda couldn’t see it. “Hardly. One of my students invited me to see their band play at a bar.”

 

There was a beat of silence, and then Wanda laughed. “A bar? Aggie, that’s a little out of your usual scene, isn’t it?”

 

“Don’t start,” Agatha warned, her tone half-serious.

 

“I’m just saying,” Wanda said, still amused. “You’re really going to a bar on a Friday night for a student? Must be a special student.”

 

“It’s not like that,” Agatha said firmly, though she could feel a blush creeping up her neck. “She’s… unique. Brilliant, really. And she works hard. I thought it might be nice to see this other side of her.”

 

“Uh-huh.” Wanda’s voice was laced with playful skepticism.

 

“Wanda.”

 

“Alright, alright,” Wanda relented, her laughter softening. “I’ll come over. What time do you need me?”

 

“Seven should be fine.”

 

“I’ll be there.”

 

“Thank you,” Agatha said, genuinely grateful.

 

As she hung up, she glanced at the clock and stood. There was still time to change her mind, but she knew she wouldn’t. This wasn’t about Rio. It was just a chance to see something different, to step outside her routine.

 

That was all.

 

 

Backstage at O’Malley’s, the air buzzed with pre-show energy. Jen was fine-tuning her guitar, Alice was tapping out a quick rhythm on the edge of a table, and Rio was… pacing.

 

“Will you relax, Rio?” Alice said, not even looking up as she adjusted her drumsticks. “You’re making me nervous, and I’m the calm one.”

 

“I’m fine,” Rio muttered, though the edge in her voice betrayed her. She played the strap of her drum bag for the third time, glancing toward the slightly cracked door leading to the stage and the growing crowd beyond.

 

“Sure you are,” Alice teased, her lips curling into a knowing smirk. “Totally fine. Except for the part where you keep peeking out there like you’re waiting for someone special.”

 

“I’m just checking the crowd,” Rio said quickly, trying—and failing—to sound casual.

 

Alice raised an eyebrow. “You’ve checked the crowd six times already. And the last time I checked, Lilia doesn’t exactly frequent grungy college bars.”

 

“Can you not?” Rio hissed, her cheeks burning.

 

“Oh, come on. Just admit it,” Alice said, leaning her drumsticks against the wall. “You’re hoping Dr. Harkness shows up.”

 

“I’m not—” Rio started, but Alice’s pointed look cut her off.

 

“Okay, maybe a little,” Rio admitted, running a hand through her hair. “But it’s not what you think.”

 

“Oh, sure it’s not,” Alice said, smirking. “You’re just really passionate about faculty engagement in student bands.”

 

Rio shot her a glare but couldn’t help the small, nervous laugh that escaped. “Shut up.”

 

“Relax,” Alice said, standing and giving Rio a reassuring pat on the back. “Even if she does show, it’ll be fine. She’s just another person in the crowd. And if she doesn’t? No big deal. Either way, we’re gonna kill it tonight.”

 

Rio nodded, though her stomach still churned. She couldn’t help herself—she glanced toward the door again, her pulse quickening as the faint sound of the growing crowd reached her ears.

 

She didn’t know what she was hoping for more—that Agatha would show up, or that she wouldn’t.

 

The moment arrived. The band’s name was called, and the crowd erupted into cheers as Rio, Alice, Jen, and the others stepped onto the stage. The bar was packed, the low hum of chatter and clinking glasses giving way to a buzz of anticipation.

 

Rio took her place behind the drum kit, her heart pounding in rhythm with the beat she was about to unleash. She gripped her drumsticks tightly, forcing herself to focus. Whether or not she was here didn’t matter now. This was her moment.

 

Alice adjusted her mic, grinning at the crowd. “Good evening, O’Malley’s! We’re Three of Swords, and we’re so stoked to be here tonight. Let’s make some noise!”

 

The first song kicked off with a driving bassline, Jen’s guitar roaring to life as Rio found her rhythm. The music took over, drowning out everything else—the nerves, the doubts, the wondering. On stage, Rio felt invincible, the steady crash of her cymbals and the sharp crack of her snare drum grounding her in the moment.

 

She didn’t see Agatha slip into the bar a few minutes later, pausing near the entrance as the music washed over her.

 

Agatha lingered for a moment, scanning the room. It was crowded, dimly lit, and alive with energy. Not her usual scene, and yet… she found herself intrigued. Her gaze settled on the stage, where Rio was a haunting presence behind the drum kit.

 

Even in the chaos of the performance, Rio’s focus was sharp, her movements precise yet fluid. She wasn’t just playing; she was in it, the music coursing through her with a palpable intensity.

 

Agatha moved further into the bar, finding a spot near the back where she could watch without being noticed. She crossed her arms, leaning against the wall as she took it all in—the raw power of the music, the energy of the crowd, and Rio, utterly transformed under the stage lights.

 

For a brief moment, Agatha let herself be carried by the music, the steady pulse of the drums resonating in her chest.

 

She’s good, Agatha thought, her lips curving into the faintest of smiles. She couldn’t help but stare at Rio, in her deep green almost see-through blouse, the top two buttons left open, letting a black lacy undershirt peak through, her hair wild around her head and her make-up a tad heavier than usual. She was mesmerizing.

 

Boy I’m in trouble.

 

 

The final chord rang out, the echo lingering in the air before the bar erupted into applause. Rio leaned back, letting the drumsticks fall from her hands as she caught her breath. The performance had flown by in a blur of sound and motion, her nerves forgotten in the adrenaline of the stage.

 

She exchanged a triumphant grin with Alice and Jen before standing and waving to the crowd. They were cheering loudly, faces lit with excitement, but it wasn’t until Rio scanned the room that she caught sight of a familiar figure near the back.

 

Agatha Harkness.

 

Rio’s heart did an odd little stutter. Agatha was standing with her arms crossed, her expression composed but unmistakably attentive. Her dark eyes were fixed on the stage, on her, and for a split second, Rio forgot how to breathe.

 

She blinked, half-convinced she was imagining it. But no, Agatha was very much there, framed by the low light of the bar’s sconces.

 

“Hey, Rio,” Alice said, giving her a light nudge as they started moving offstage. “Earth to Vidal. You coming?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio said quickly, snapping out of it. She grabbed her sticks and followed the others, but her mind was still stuck on the image of Agatha in the crowd.

 

Backstage, Alice gave her a knowing look. “Saw someone out there, didn’t you?”

 

“No,” Rio lied, too quickly.

 

Alice smirked. “Sure. Whatever you say.”

 

Rio didn’t bother answering, her thoughts too tangled. The adrenaline from the performance was still pumping through her veins, but now it was mingled with a nervous energy she hadn’t expected.

 

She came.

 

The realization hit her all over again as she sat down, trying to calm her racing thoughts. Agatha had come. And somehow, knowing that felt bigger than it should.

 

Rio fidgeted backstage, her hands restless as she glanced at the door to the bar, wondering if she should go over and speak to Agatha. The crowd was thinning out now, but Agatha was still there, leaning against the bar, a glass of white wine in hand, watching the last few patrons filter out.

 

“Hey, Alice,” Rio muttered, pacing back and forth. “What do you think? Should I go talk to her?”

 

Alice, who had just finished packing away her gear, raised an eyebrow at her. “Oh, now you’re asking for advice? After all the teasing you’ve done about not caring if she shows up?”

 

“Shut up,” Rio groaned, pinching the bridge of her nose. “I’m serious. I don’t know if I should. She’s a professor. I’m a student. I’m probably already weird enough for inviting her in the first place.”

 

Alice looked at her like she was insane. “Are you hearing yourself right now? You’re overthinking it. You invited her because she’s your professor, and it’s a student thing. She came to support you. That’s a huge deal! You should go thank her for coming.”

 

Rio bit her lip, pacing again. “But… what if it’s weird? What if I’m too… forward?”

 

“Forward?” Alice repeated, her voice incredulous. “Rio, you’re over here practically having a panic attack because your professor came to see you perform. I think ‘forward’ is the least of your worries.”

 

Rio paused, glancing at her friend, a bit of humor slipping through her nervousness. “You think it’s a bad idea?”

 

“I think it’s a fantastic idea,” Alice said, her grin widening. “Go. You’ll regret it if you don’t.”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, but Alice’s certainty had a way of quieting her doubts. She took a deep breath. “Alright, fine. But if I embarrass myself, I’m blaming you.”

 

“You won’t embarrass yourself,” Alice said confidently, giving Rio a reassuring push toward the door. “Now go. I’ll be right behind you.”

 

With one last glance at Alice, Rio steeled herself. This time, there was no turning back. She was going to go thank Agatha. And who knows? Maybe it wouldn’t be so bad. Maybe it would even be… good.

 

She walked toward the bar, her heart in her throat, as she approached Agatha.

 

Her professor was dressed more casually than usual, but still stunning in her midnight blue shirt, tucked into dark-washed tailored jeans that made her look…

 

Vidal, what are you even thinking, get yourself together.

 

As Rio approached Agatha, her mind raced, but her steps were steady, like a drumbeat she could no longer ignore. The closer she got, the more she could feel her heartbeat thrumming in her chest, the adrenaline from the performance still coursing through her veins. Agatha looked up as Rio neared, her sharp gaze softening for a brief moment when she recognized who was walking toward her.

 

“Dr. Harkness,” Rio began, her voice almost too quiet as she stopped a few feet away. She fought the urge to fidget with her hands, forcing them to remain at her sides. “I just wanted to… thank you for coming tonight.”

 

Agatha’s lips curled into a faint smile, and she pushed off from the wall, her posture as poised as ever, but there was something warm in her expression now. “It was my pleasure, Miss Vidal,” she said, her voice rich and steady. “You were incredible up there. The performance was… impressive.”

 

Rio felt a heat rise in her cheeks. “I’m glad you liked it,” she said quickly. “I mean, we’ve been working really hard.”

 

Agatha’s eyes gleamed with something unreadable, and she tilted her head slightly, her gaze flicking briefly to the band still milling about in the background. “It’s clear. You’ve got a lot of talent, Rio. It’s not easy to capture a crowd like that, especially with such energy.”

 

Rio swallowed, suddenly unsure of how to respond. Agatha’s praise was unexpected, and it felt different from the academic feedback she was used to. It felt… personal.

 

“I—thank you,” Rio said, her voice faltering slightly. She quickly glanced down at the floor, then back at Agatha, trying to steady her racing heart. “I didn’t think you’d come, honestly. I didn’t expect it.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, stepping a little closer, her gaze flicking to Rio with a sharp yet somehow gentle intensity. “Why wouldn’t I? I said I’d come, didn’t I? It’s important to support students, especially when they’re… passionate about something.” Her eyes held Rio’s for a beat longer than necessary, and Rio felt a shiver of something — anticipation, excitement — pass through her.

 

“I guess I just thought you’d be busy or something,” Rio said quickly, unsure how to navigate the sudden tension that seemed to fill the space between them. “You know, with work and everything.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, the sound smooth and melodic. “I have my moments of free time too. Besides, I was sure your band’s performance was worth the effort.” She glanced toward the exit where the last few patrons were trickling out. “I’m glad I made it. It was… refreshing.”

 

There was a quiet pause, the air between them thick with unspoken words. Rio’s nerves flared again, but she was determined to hold her ground.

 

“Are you… heading out soon?” Rio asked, her voice sounding a little unsure of itself.

 

Agatha regarded her for a moment, her gaze softening, before she answered. “I think I’ll stay a little longer, actually. If that’s alright.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat, but she nodded, her words feeling like they were stuck in her throat. “Of course. I just… I wasn’t sure if you wanted to stay or—”

 

“I’ll stay,” Agatha said again, a playful hint in her tone that made Rio’s breath catch. 

 

“Okay… I need to go backstage, help the other tidy up a bit but… I’ll see you around?”

 

Agatha gave a nod, her lips curling into a subtle but knowing smile. “I’ll be here.”

 

Rio turned to leave, but her heart was still racing, the weight of the brief exchange hanging in the air long after she stepped away. She could feel Agatha’s eyes on her back, and something told her that this was only the beginning.

 

As the night wore on, the bar slowly emptied out, but Rio and the band stayed, lingering around the stage, talking among themselves. Alice, as usual, was full of energy, bouncing between conversations with Jen and making plans for the next rehearsal. But despite her outwardly relaxed demeanor, Rio could feel her friend’s gaze drifting toward Agatha every so often.

 

At some point, Alice caught Rio looking, her eyes narrowing with a knowing grin.

 

“You know,” Alice said, leaning toward Rio with a mischievous glint in her eyes, “I think it’s time to go make things interesting.”

 

Rio frowned, not quite following her friend’s line of thinking. “What do you mean?”

 

But Alice was already making a beeline for the bar, her mission clear. Rio’s heart dropped into her stomach as she watched her friend march right up to Agatha, who was still standing near the back of the room, now sipping a drink.

 

“Here we go,” Rio muttered to herself, her hand instinctively moving to her face in embarrassment. She could feel her cheeks heating up, even from across the room.

 

Alice’s voice rang out, louder than Rio would’ve liked. “Hi, I’m Alice! You must be Dr. Harkness! I’ve heard all about you.”

 

Agatha, who had been deep in conversation with someone else, turned at the sudden interruption, her expression polite but guarded. Rio could see the brief flicker of surprise in Agatha’s eyes before she composed herself, her gaze scanning the new intruder.

 

“Ah,” Agatha replied with a smile that was, unsurprisingly, just as controlled and perceptive as ever. “And you are?”

 

“Alice,” she said brightly, sticking out her hand like they were old friends. “I’m Rio’s best friend. You know, the Rio Vidal, the one you just saw on stage.” Her grin was teasing but warm, as if she was proud of Rio’s performance—though Rio had no doubt the whole thing had the potential to be slightly embarrassing for her.

 

Agatha eyed her hand briefly before shaking it, her grip firm but cool. “Nice to meet you, Alice. I’m afraid Rio hasn’t mentioned much about her band.” Her tone was polite, but Rio could sense the subtle shift in Agatha’s demeanor—she was definitely sizing Alice up, in the same way she always did in class.

 

Alice, undeterred by Agatha’s more reserved response, continued her chatter. “Well, we’re a package deal, you see. Rio, me, and Jen here. I’m a musicology PhD student, so I guess I’m technically also a scholar of sorts, but with a little more groove. You know how it is. But you! I’ve heard nothing but amazing things about you from Rio, especially about your classes and your seminars.”

 

Rio, at this point, was doing everything she could to avoid looking directly at the two of them, her face a bright shade of red as Alice continued to gush. She kept glancing at the stage, pretending to adjust her equipment, even though there was nothing to adjust. It was almost painful to hear Alice be so… obnoxiously charming.

 

Agatha, though, remained unfazed, her cool composure never slipping. “I’m sure Rio has been very kind with her words. We do have a very interesting seminar series. I look forward to seeing how it all unfolds.”

 

“Wait, wait,” Alice interjected, leaning in with a wide grin, “Did you actually see Rio play? Because she’s amazing up there. You should come to the next one, I bet Rio would appreciate it. Right, Rio?”

 

Alice shot her a wink from across the room, and Rio couldn’t help but feel a little caught between a rock and a hard place. She wasn’t sure if Alice was trying to make things less awkward or just completely make a scene, but either way, the last thing Rio wanted was to hear her professor talk about how good her playing was.

 

But to Rio’s surprise, Agatha looked at her for a moment, her gaze piercing through the space between them. She seemed to be thinking for a beat before she nodded slowly.

 

“I may very well take you up on that,” Agatha replied, her voice smooth but still holding that subtle authority. “It was a… rather enjoyable performance. I’ll keep an eye on the calendar.”

 

Rio blinked, her heart suddenly beating in her throat again. Had Agatha just… said that? Was she implying that she might actually show up again?

 

Before she could respond, Alice, of course, was already moving on, her enthusiastic nature carrying her to the next subject.

 

“Well, if you do decide to come back, we’ll make sure Rio saves you a seat,” Alice teased, winking at her again as she finally turned to head back to where Rio was standing.

 

Rio stood there, trying her best not to look completely mortified. As Alice rejoined her, she shot Rio a sly look. “I think she’s into you.”

 

Rio groaned, burying her face in her hands. “Shut up, Alice.”

 

But deep down, despite the discomfort and the teasing, there was a spark of something—something that made her heart race again. As if Agatha’s presence wasn’t as strange as Rio had first thought. Maybe it was something more.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Deeper and Deeper

*

*

*

Here is a place of disaffection

Time before and time after

In a dim light: neither daylight

Investing form with lucid stillness

Turning shadow into transient beauty

With slow rotation suggesting permanence

Nor darkness to purify the soul

Emptying the sensual with deprivation

Cleansing affection from the temporal.

 

          (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next morning, the sunlight streamed through the kitchen window as Agatha prepared breakfast. Nicky sat at the table, kicking his legs back and forth, his cereal spoon hovering mid-air as his curious little mind worked overtime.

 

“Mama,” he began, his tone that telltale mix of innocence and determination.

 

“Yes, darling?” Agatha replied without looking up, focused on buttering toast.

 

“Yesterday, you went to see Miss Rio’s band, right?”

 

Agatha paused, the knife still in her hand, her brow lifting slightly. She turned to face her son, who was looking at her with wide, curious eyes. “I did,” Agatha answered carefully, setting the knife down.

 

“Did you see them play?” he asked, leaning forward on the table now, his cereal entirely forgotten.

 

“I did,” she admitted, returning to her task, though she could feel the weight of his gaze.

 

“What kind of band is it? Is it, like, a rock band? Or one of those with guitars and drums and stuff?”

 

Agatha couldn’t help but smile faintly at his enthusiasm. “Yes, it’s that kind. They play music with guitars, drums, and other instruments. Very lively.”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up. “Was Miss Rio playing the drums? I bet she’s really good at it! She’s good at everything!”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, finally turning around to fully engage in the conversation. “She was playing the drums, and yes, she’s quite talented.”

 

Nicky grinned, sitting back in his chair with a look of triumph, as if he’d known all along. “Can I go see them play next time? Please, Mommy?”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, folding her arms. “That might not where children should be.”

 

Nicky pouted but quickly perked up again. “But you went! If you can go, maybe I can too. I really want to see Miss Rio play the drums. I bet it’s so cool.”

 

Agatha sighed, shaking her head with a soft laugh. “You’re persistent, aren’t you?”

 

“It’s important!” Nicky declared. “Miss Rio is the best teacher ever, and I want to see her do more stuff!”

 

Agatha didn’t reply immediately. Instead, she turned back to her toast, a thoughtful expression on her face. Her son’s unbridled admiration for Rio was both endearing and a little unsettling. She couldn’t deny the growing curiosity within herself either—about Rio’s many facets, about how someone so young carried herself with such passion and strength.

 

“We’ll see,” she said finally, her voice gentle but firm.

 

“Promise?” Nicky pressed, his grin widening.

 

“I said ‘we’ll see,’” she repeated with mock sternness, though the corners of her lips betrayed her amusement.

 

“Okay,” Nicky said, clearly satisfied for now. He returned to his cereal with a happy hum, leaving Agatha to her thoughts.

 

As she poured herself a cup of tea, Agatha couldn’t help but wonder how her life had suddenly intertwined so unexpectedly with Rio Vidal’s.

 

The day stretched ahead, warm and golden, as Agatha decided to devote the entire day to her son. It wasn’t often that she could set aside her workload entirely, but after the recital and the previous night at the bar, she felt like taking a step back and focusing on Nicky.

 

“What do you want to do today, sweetheart?” Agatha asked as they finished breakfast, sipping her tea as Nicky wolfed down the last of his cereal.

 

He looked up at her, his face lighting up with excitement. “Can we go to the park again? And maybe get ice cream after?”

 

Agatha smiled. “The park and ice cream? You’re easy to please.”

 

“Parks are the best!” he declared, already bouncing out of his chair to grab his shoes.

 

An hour later, they were strolling through the park, the air crisp and refreshing. Nicky darted ahead to the playground, and Agatha found a bench nearby, keeping a watchful eye on him as he climbed and slid with uncontainable energy. Other parents sat around her, some chatting, others engrossed in books or their phones.

 

Agatha let herself relax, savoring the rare, tranquil moment. Nicky’s laughter rang out, a sound so pure it made her heart swell. She couldn’t help but think about how quickly he was growing—each day a little more independent, a little more curious.

 

After a while, Nicky ran back to her, his cheeks flushed from exertion. “Mom, did you see that? I went down the twisty slide backwards!”

 

“I did,” Agatha said with mock seriousness. “Very impressive.”

 

Nicky giggled. Then his face lit up with another idea. “Can we go feed the ducks?”

 

“Let’s go, then,” Agatha agreed, standing and brushing off her coat.

 

They wandered over to the pond, where Nicky gleefully tossed breadcrumbs to a group of waddling ducks. Agatha joined in, watching as the ducks squabbled over the treats.

 

“Do you think the ducks know Miss Rio?” Nicky asked suddenly, breaking her train of thought.

 

Agatha stifled a laugh. “I don’t think so, darling. I’m pretty sure they stay in the park.”

 

“Well, if she came here more, they might know her,” Nicky reasoned with the seriousness only a six-year-old could muster.

 

“I suppose so,” Agatha replied, humor dancing in her voice.

 

After their duck-feeding adventure, Nicky tugged on her hand. “Now ice cream?”

 

“As promised,” she said with a nod.

 

They walked to the little cart near the park entrance, where Nicky debated for several minutes between chocolate and strawberry before finally choosing both. Agatha opted for a simple cone of vanilla, which she licked absentmindedly as Nicky happily devoured his treat.

 

“Do you think Miss Rio likes ice cream?” Nicky asked between bites.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “You seem very interested in Miss Rio today.”

 

“She’s cool,” Nicky said matter-of-factly. “And I bet she likes chocolate, just like me.”

 

Agatha chuckled, brushing a stray strand of hair from her face. “I suppose that’s possible.”

 

As the afternoon wore on, they returned home, where Nicky insisted on building a fort in the living room. Agatha let him take the lead, handing him cushions and blankets as he constructed his masterpiece.

 

By the time evening rolled around, Nicky was curled up in his fort with a book, his energy finally waning. Agatha sat nearby with her own book, stealing glances at him every so often.

 

“Today was the best,” he murmured, his voice heavy with sleep.

 

Agatha smiled softly. “I’m glad you think so, darling.”

 

And as she watched him drift off, she couldn’t help but feel grateful for the quiet, simple moments like these.

 

 

Rio woke up to the soft sound of rain tapping against her window. The overcast light filtered through her curtains, casting a muted glow over her small apartment. She stretched lazily, her body still sore from the performance and the whirlwind of emotions the night before.

 

It was rare for Rio to have an entire Saturday free—no classes to teach, no meetings, and no pressing deadlines that couldn’t wait until tomorrow. She decided to take full advantage of it.

 

After a quick shower, she brewed herself a pot of strong coffee while she watered her numerous plants and settled by the window with her notebook. The rain outside set a soothing rhythm, and she let herself write freely, her thoughts spilling onto the pages without inhibition.

 

Most of it wasn’t for her thesis—just fragments of ideas, poetic musings, and sketches of moments that had stayed with her. She found herself scribbling something about the way Professor Harkness had looked at her last night, a glint of pride and something else in her sharp blue eyes. Rio’s pen hovered over the page for a moment before she shook her head, closed the notebook, and set it aside.

 

By late morning, the rain had eased into a light drizzle. Rio slipped on a sweater and boots, deciding to walk to the campus bookstore. She wandered through the aisles, picking up a new collection of essays for her research and a slim volume of poetry that caught her eye.

 

With her purchases tucked under her arm, she headed to a nearby café. It was a quiet spot, the kind of place where she could linger with her books without being disturbed. She ordered a latte and a croissant, finding a seat by the window.

 

Her thoughts drifted as she sipped her coffee. She thought about Alice and Jen, how something was undeniably blooming between them, and she wondered what it would mean for their little group. She thought about her performance last night, the rush of adrenaline as she played, and the way her heart had skipped when she spotted Agatha in the crowd.

 

She sighed, shaking her head at herself. Get a grip, Rio. She’s your professor.

 

The rest of the day passed in peaceful solitude. Back at her apartment, Rio curled up with a book, the soft hum of rain outside a constant companion. By the time the sun set, the sky was a deep slate gray, and she felt the weight of the quiet day settle over her like a blanket.

 

As she climbed into bed, her thoughts lingered on the unexpected ways her life had shifted recently—Agatha’s presence in her academic world, the tentative steps forward with her band, and the small moments that seemed to carry more weight than they should.

 

She drifted off to sleep, her dreams a jumble of poetry, music, and the faint echo of a warm voice saying her name.

 

 

The next day, the sun was now bright but not overbearing as Rio made her way to the café where she and Alice had agreed to meet. The streets were quieter than usual, the Sunday calm casting a relaxed spell over campus life.

 

When Rio arrived, she found Alice already seated at a corner table, her fingers drumming nervously against the rim of her coffee cup. It wasn’t often that Alice looked anything less than self-assured, and the sight of her friend fidgeting piqued Rio’s curiosity.

 

“Hey,” Rio said as she slid into the chair across from her. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost.”

 

Alice glanced up, her eyes wide and a little hesitant. “Oh, it’s not a ghost. Just… a thing.”

 

Rio arched an eyebrow, leaning forward with a sly smile. “A thing, huh? Sounds serious.”

 

Alice groaned, dropping her head into her hands. “It is. It’s so serious that I think my brain might explode if I don’t get it out.”

 

Rio laughed. “Well, don’t explode on me. What’s going on?”

 

Alice took a deep breath, sitting up straighter. Her fingers wrapped tightly around her coffee cup, and for a moment, she stared at it as if it held all the answers. Then, with a sigh, she finally said, “I think I’m in love with Jen.”

 

Rio blinked, caught off guard even though she’d seen this coming for weeks. “Alice,” she said slowly, a grin spreading across her face. “That’s amazing!”

 

Alice groaned again, slumping in her chair. “No, it’s not. It’s terrifying. What if she doesn’t feel the same? What if I ruin everything?”

 

“Alice,” Rio said firmly, reaching across the table to place a comforting hand on her friend’s arm. “First of all, have you seen the way Jen looks at you? She’s got it bad.”

 

Alice’s eyes darted up, a spark of hope flickering behind her nervous expression. “You think so?”

 

“I know so,” Rio said with a chuckle. “The way she was practically glued to your side after our last gig? Come on. She’s into you.”

 

Alice bit her lip, her fingers tapping a frantic rhythm against the table. “Okay, but what if I’m wrong? What if I say something and it gets weird?”

 

“Then you’ll deal with it,” Rio said simply. “You’re brave, Alice. You always go for what you want. Why should this be any different?”

 

Alice sighed, nodding slowly. “You’re right. I know you’re right. I just… this feels bigger, you know? Like it really matters.”

 

“Because it does,” Rio said gently. “But that’s a good thing. If it matters, it’s worth the risk.”

 

Alice smiled weakly, her fingers finally stilling. “Thanks, Rio. You’re annoyingly good at this whole advice thing.”

 

“Don’t mention it,” Rio said with a grin. “But seriously, just talk to her. You’ll feel better.”

 

“I will,” Alice promised, a determined glint returning to her eyes. “Soon.”

 

Alice abruptly changed the subject. “What are you doing tonight? Do you want to catch a movie? Or a drink?”

 

“Sorry I can’t, you know Sunday nights are Lilia nights.” Rio said, a smile on her face.

 

Alice raised her hands in the air. “Of course, sorry I forgot. Can you tell her to invite me next time? I miss her lasagnas.”

 

Rio chuckled. “Oh, she will love to hear it. Consider yourself a guest next week.” Alice pumped her fist in the air in victory.

 

They spent the rest of the afternoon talking about anything and everything, the heavy tension in Alice’s shoulders slowly easing. By the time they parted ways, Alice looked more like herself, and Rio couldn’t help but feel proud of her friend.

 

As Rio walked back to her apartment, she thought about how much things were shifting around her—Alice and Jen, her own tangled feelings for Agatha, and the delicate balance of her world. Change was in the air, and though it was daunting, it also felt oddly exciting.

 

 

By late afternoon, Rio found herself on the familiar path to Lilia’s house. The Sunday ritual was as steady as the turning of the seasons—a quiet anchor in her otherwise hectic life. No matter how busy things got, there was always this pocket of time reserved for home-cooked meals, easy conversation, and the grounding presence of the woman who had taken her in when she’d had nowhere else to go.

 

When Rio arrived, Lilia was already on the porch, wiping her hands on a kitchen towel. Her face lit up when she spotted Rio.

 

“There’s my girl,” Lilia said warmly, pulling her into a tight hug.

 

“Hey, Lilia,” Rio replied, the tension from the week melting away at her touch.

 

The house smelled like roasted vegetables and fresh herbs, and Rio’s stomach growled in anticipation as she followed Lilia into the kitchen. The table was already set, the mismatched plates and glasses lending a charm that always made the place feel like home.

 

“How was your week?” Lilia asked as she stirred a pot on the stove.

 

Rio leaned against the counter, stealing a piece of bread from a nearby basket and dove into the retelling of her week. Lilia listened with rapt interest, reacting when appropriate and giving advice when solicitated, while she busied herself at the counter. Rio tried to help a few times but was whisked away every time. She ended up on the high stool opposite Lilia, munching on vegetables offered to her every few minutes.

 

As they settled into dinner, the conversation flowed easily. They talked about the band’s gig, Alice’s nervous confession earlier that day, and even Rio’s academic life, though she carefully avoided mentioning Agatha again.

 

When it was time to leave, Lilia handed her a container of leftovers, as she always did. “Take care of yourself this week, alright kid? And tell Alice I said hi.”

 

“I will,” Rio promised, hugging her tightly before heading out into the night. “By the way, I told her she was invited next Sunday. She specifically asked for your lasagnas.”

 

Lilia laughed. “That girl, I swear. Tell her she’s got it.”

 

With one last kiss to the cheek, Rio went on her way, tightening her jacket around her shoulder. As she walked back to campus, the streets quiet and the air crisp, Rio felt a sense of calm settle over her. Sundays with Lilia always reminded her of who she was and where she came from. And that, no matter what the week ahead might hold, she could handle it.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Drunken Encounters

*

*

*

[...] The Word in the desert

Is most attacked by voices of temptation,

The crying shadow in the funeral dance,

The loud lament of the disconsolate chimera.

 

           (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

Monday morning came with the sharp chill of early winter creeping through the cracks of Rio’s apartment windows. She groaned as her alarm went off, pulling the blanket tighter around her. Mornings like this made her wish she didn’t have to leave the warm cocoon of her bed.

 

But duty called—there were classes to attend, papers to read, and, as always, the looming presence of her thesis demanding attention. She rolled out of bed, muttering curses under her breath, and went through her morning routine on autopilot: coffee, quick shower, and a mental pep talk in the mirror.

 

The campus was alive with its usual Monday bustle when Rio arrived, students hurrying to their first lectures of the week. She made her way to the English department, where she had a seminar scheduled with Agatha later in the day.

 

Her first stop was the library. She found her usual corner desk and spread out her notes, her mind trying to refocus after the calm of the weekend. As much as she loved her Sundays with Lilia, it always took a little effort to transition back into the academic grind.

 

By mid-morning, her phone buzzed with a text from Alice:

 

Alice: How’s your Monday going? Wanna grab lunch after class?

 

Rio smirked, typing a quick reply.

 

Rio: Only if you bring me good gossip about Jen.

 

Alice’s response came almost immediately: You’re relentless, Vidal.

 

With a grin, Rio tucked her phone away and returned to her work.

 

When it was time for Agatha’s seminar, Rio felt the familiar flutter of nerves in her stomach. She was early, as usual, and found herself lingering by the door. Students began trickling in, and finally, Agatha herself appeared, her presence commanding as always.

 

“Good morning, everyone,” Agatha greeted as she strode into the room. Her voice had the same measured warmth that always set the tone for her classes.

 

The seminar began, and Rio tried her best to focus on the discussion. Agatha had a way of drawing out insights from even the quietest students, her sharp intellect matched by an understated patience. Today, she spoke about the intersection of mortality and creativity in Modernist poetry—a topic that hit close to Rio’s research.

 

At one point, Agatha’s gaze lingered on her, and Rio felt her cheeks flush despite herself. She knew she had to speak up, if only to hide her reaction.

 

“I think the idea of death as a silent collaborator in Modernist works is fascinating,” Rio said. “It’s not just a theme; it’s almost a presence, shaping the very structure of the poetry itself.”

 

Agatha’s lips quirked into a small, approving smile. “An intriguing observation, Miss Vidal. Care to elaborate?”

 

As Rio spoke, she felt herself relax, the words coming more easily. Agatha listened intently, her expression thoughtful, and Rio couldn’t help but feel a quiet thrill at holding her attention.

 

When the seminar ended, Rio stayed behind, pretending to organize her notes as the other students filed out. She glanced at Agatha, who was gathering her own materials, and for a brief moment, she considered saying something.

 

But the nerves got the better of her, and she simply said, “Thank you for the seminar, Dr. Harkness,” before hurrying out.

 

The day wasn’t over yet, but as Rio headed to meet Alice for lunch, she couldn’t shake the warmth of Agatha’s approval or the way her heart had skipped when their eyes met.

 

 

The afternoon was heavy with the threat of rain as Rio left the library, her bag slung over one shoulder and her head buried in her notes. She barely noticed the world around her until she walked straight into someone.

 

“Oh, sorry—” she began, looking up, only to freeze when she saw who it was.

 

Maya.

 

The sight of her ex brought a sinking feeling to Rio’s stomach. Maya, with her perfect posture and that ever-so-slightly condescending smirk, looked like she was exactly where she wanted to be.

 

“Well, well,” Maya said, brushing imaginary dust off her sleeve. “If it isn’t Rio Vidal. Still tripping over your own feet, I see. Weird for a so-called dancer, really.”

 

Rio clenched her jaw, willing herself to stay calm. “It’s called being busy, Maya. Some of us don’t have time to linger in doorways.”

 

Maya tilted her head, her smirk deepening. “Busy, huh? Is that what you’re calling it these days? I saw your little band performance the other night. Very… quaint.”

 

Rio’s blood boiled, but she forced a smile. “I didn’t know you were there. I would have said hi—maybe pointed you to the exit.”

 

Maya let out a mock laugh. “Always the comedian. I just happened to be there with some friends. I guess it’s cute that you’re still playing at being a rock star.”

 

Rio’s fists tightened around the strap of her bag. “What do you want, Maya?”

 

“Nothing,” Maya said lightly, her eyes scanning Rio like she was a puzzle to be solved. “Just passing by and thought I’d say hi. Can’t let old times go to waste, can we?”

 

“Old times are best left in the past,” Rio shot back, stepping around her.

 

But Maya wasn’t done. “You know, you’ve always been good at pretending you’re fine. But I can tell you’re still the same mess you were back then. Some things never change, do they?”

 

The words hit Rio harder than she wanted to admit, but she didn’t turn back. She didn’t give Maya the satisfaction of a response, walking away with her heart pounding and her jaw clenched so tightly it hurt.

 

By the time she reached her apartment, her head was spinning, and the encounter replayed in her mind like a bad song stuck on repeat. Maya had always known how to cut deep, and she still hadn’t lost her touch.

 

Rio dropped her bag and leaned against the kitchen counter, letting out a shaky breath. The frustration and hurt bubbled up inside her, and she knew there was only one way to deal with it tonight.

 

She grabbed her phone and texted Alice:

 

Rio: I need a drink. You in?

 

The reply came seconds later:

 

Alice: Always. See you at the bar in 30.

 

Rio exhaled, already feeling a bit lighter. A drink, a distraction, and a little company were exactly what she needed to shake off the weight of Maya’s venomous words. Tonight, she wasn’t going to dwell—she was going to let it all go, at least for a little while.

 

 

The bar was noisy, a steady hum of chatter and laughter blending with the low thrum of music, but Rio and Alice were in their own little bubble. After Maya’s harsh words, Rio had fully leaned into the evening, determined to drown the lingering bitterness in one too many drinks. Alice was being supportive, had matched her drink for drink, though she was handling it much better than Rio was.

 

At some point, Alice’s phone buzzed loudly on the table. She glanced at the screen, her lips curling into a knowing smile as she answered.

 

“Jen,” she said, her voice suddenly softer, and Rio groaned dramatically.

 

“Oh, come on,” Rio slurred, swirling the last remnants of her drink in its glass. “I don’t need to witness your disgustingly cute whatever-this-is right now.”

 

Alice smirked, holding up a finger as she listened to Jen on the other end. “Yeah, I can come over. I’ll be there in fifteen,” she said, hanging up and pocketing her phone.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow. “You’re leaving me for chemistry Jen?”

 

“Always,” Alice said with a teasing grin. “But seriously, are you gonna be okay getting home? You’ve had… a lot.”

 

“I’m fine,” Rio insisted, though her words were slightly slurred. “I can totally make it back. Campus isn’t far.”

 

Alice gave her a skeptical look but ultimately relented. “Text me when you’re home, okay? And don’t get into any trouble.”

 

“Trouble? Me?” Rio asked, feigning offense.

 

Alice laughed, giving her a quick hug before grabbing her coat and heading out. Rio watched her go, the realization that she was now alone hitting her in waves.

 

She wobbled slightly as she stood, grabbing her bag and heading for the door. The cold air outside was a sharp contrast to the warm haze of the bar, and it hit her like a brick wall.

 

“Okay, okay,” she muttered to herself, taking a deep breath and setting off in what she hoped was the direction of her apartment.

 

The streets were quieter now, the occasional hum of a passing car or the rustle of leaves in the breeze her only companions. Rio’s mind was foggy, her steps uneven, but she was determined.

 

“I got this,” she whispered, though she stumbled slightly on the curb.

 

Her thoughts kept drifting to Maya’s words, to the sting of them and how they lingered. And then, inevitably, to Agatha—her poised, commanding professor, who seemed so far removed from the chaos of Rio’s own life. The thought of her brought a pang of something unfamiliar, something Rio wasn’t ready to name.

 

“Focus, Vidal,” she muttered, steadying herself against a lamppost.

 

The night was crisp and quiet as Agatha made her way to her car, the weight of an evening spent grading essays still heavy on her shoulders. The undergraduates’ grasp of modernist poetry had left much to be desired, and her mind swirled with a mix of exhaustion and frustration as she dug in her bag for her keys.

 

At first, she didn’t notice the figure on the sidewalk. A blur of unsteady motion caught the edge of her vision, someone weaving clumsily as if the very concept of a straight line was foreign to them. Agatha’s hand stilled on her bag as she turned toward the figure, her sharp eyes narrowing.

 

Agatha paused, her brow furrowing as recognition dawned. “Miss Vidal?”

 

The woman stopped mid-step, teetering slightly as she turned toward Agatha’s voice. Recognition flickered in Rio’s glazed eyes, though it took a moment to settle. “Dr. Harkness!” she exclaimed, her voice too loud and unnervingly cheerful. She gave an uncoordinated wave, nearly overbalancing herself. “Fancy seeing you here.”

 

Agatha’s brow furrowed as she stepped closer, the harsh glow of a nearby streetlamp illuminating Rio’s flushed cheeks and unfocused gaze. “Miss Vidal,” she said again, her voice firmer this time. “Are you alright?”

 

“I’m fine,” Rio said, though the way she swayed on her feet betrayed her words. “Just… heading home. Or trying to.”

 

Agatha crossed her arms, the sternness she reserved for particularly disruptive students creeping into her demeanor. “You don’t look fine. Have you been drinking?”

 

Rio blinked at her, her expression caught somewhere between defiance and sheepishness. “Maybe a little,” she admitted, her words slurring slightly. “Okay, maybe a lot. But, uh… it’s fine. I’m good.” She punctuated her statement with a half-hearted thumbs-up that only made her stumble further.

 

“Good is not the word I’d use,” Agatha muttered under her breath as she reached out instinctively to steady Rio, her hands firm on the younger woman’s shoulders. “You’re swaying like a tree in a storm.”

 

“I like trees,” Rio replied absently, her head lolling slightly as she looked up at the older woman. Her grin was wide but unfocused, and Agatha felt her frown deepen.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha said, her tone softening as concern replaced irritation. “Where are you trying to go?”

 

“Home,” Rio mumbled, her expression briefly sobering. “But it’s… far. And the ground keeps… moving.” She gestured vaguely at the sidewalk, as though it had personally wronged her.

 

Agatha sighed, glancing around the empty street. The quiet was deceptive, offering no real assurance of safety. It was painfully clear that Rio wouldn’t make it home on her own in her current state. Agatha crouched slightly to meet Rio’s unfocused gaze. “Miss Vidal, do you have someone I can call? A friend, family member—someone who can come and get you?”

 

Rio frowned, her brow furrowing deeply as if the question required intense concentration. After a moment, she started rummaging through her bag, the effort clumsy and slow. Finally, she pulled out her phone, holding it out to Agatha with unsteady hands. “Call Lilia,” she slurred, her words stretching like syrup.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow as she took the phone, glancing down at it. “Lilia?” she repeated, her tone skeptical. “Who is Lilia?”

 

Rio leaned heavily against a nearby lamppost, her expression almost comically serious. “Lilia’s… Lilia,” she said, as though that explained everything. Her explanation—or lack thereof—was punctuated by a small hiccup that seemed to amuse her.

 

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose and exhaled through her teeth. “Of course. Very illuminating,” she muttered under her breath. Holding back the urge to lecture Rio about the consequences of her choices, she focused instead on unlocking the phone. Thankfully, Rio hadn’t set a password, a security oversight Agatha made a mental note to address later.

 

Scrolling through the contacts, she found one labeled simply “Lilia” and tapped the name. The phone rang twice before a warm, concerned voice answered. “Rio? Is everything alright?”

 

“Not exactly,” Agatha replied, keeping her tone professional. “This is Dr. Agatha Harkness. I’m one of Rio’s professors. I found her trying to walk home, and… she’s quite inebriated. I was hoping you might be able to come and get her.”

 

There was a brief pause on the other end before the voice returned, tinged with exasperation and worry. “Oh, that girl. My car’s in the shop, so I can’t get there right now. But if you could drop her off at my place, I’d be grateful. I’m just a few blocks from campus.”

 

Agatha hesitated, glancing at Rio, who was now humming softly to herself and swaying gently in time with music only she could hear. “Alright,” she said. “I’ll bring her to you. Can you text the address?”

 

“Of course, I’ll send it to Rio’s phone right away. Thank you for looking out for her, Dr. Harkness,” Lilia said warmly before hanging up.

 

The call ended, and within seconds, the phone buzzed with a message. Agatha opened it, scanning the address before tucking the phone back into Rio’s bag. She turned to Rio, who was now staring up at the lamppost like it held the secrets of the universe. “Alright, Miss Vidal,” Agatha said, placing a steadying hand on Rio’s arm. “Let’s get you to Lilia’s.”

 

Rio’s head lolled toward her, a lazy grin spreading across her face. “You’re the best, Dr. Harkness. Did anyone ever tell you that?”

 

Agatha huffed a quiet laugh as she began guiding Rio toward her car. “Not under these circumstances, no,” she said, unlocking the passenger door and carefully helping Rio into the seat.

 

As she buckled Rio in, the younger woman tilted her head and squinted at Agatha. “You’ve got a nice voice,” Rio said suddenly, her words drifting. “It’s like… warm tea. Or, like, a fuzzy blanket. Does that make sense?”

 

Agatha paused, caught off guard by the unexpected compliment. “I’m not sure I’d describe my voice as a fuzzy blanket,” she replied dryly, stepping back and shutting the door.

 

Sliding into the driver’s seat, she glanced over at Rio, who was now leaning her head against the window, her breath fogging the glass. The drive to Lilia’s wasn’t far, but Agatha couldn’t help the lingering sense of responsibility pressing on her. Rio might have been reckless tonight, but there was something vulnerable about her that made Agatha’s usual stern demeanor soften, if only slightly.

 

The drive was short, and Rio dozed lightly in the passenger seat, her head lolling against the window. When they arrived, Agatha helped her out of the car and walked her to the front door.

 

The door opened before Agatha could even knock, as if the person on the other side had been waiting. A familiar older woman stood in the doorway—the same one Agatha had seen at the dance recital, the one who had cheered so loudly and unabashedly for Rio. Her presence had been striking even then, her energy magnetic and her devotion to Rio impossible to miss.

 

“Lilia, I presume?” Agatha said, her tone composed but curious.

 

The woman nodded, her sharp, assessing eyes sweeping over Rio with a mix of emotions Agatha couldn’t quite parse—relief, concern, and a touch of exasperation. “That’s me,” she said, her voice steady but warm. “And you must be Dr. Harkness. Please, come in.”

 

Agatha stepped inside, steadying Rio as they crossed the threshold. The house was small but cozy, filled with mismatched furniture and the faint scent of lavender. A knitted throw lay draped over the back of the couch, and framed photos cluttered the walls—most of them of Rio, smiling brightly or caught mid-laugh.

 

“Let’s get her on the couch,” Lilia said, already moving ahead of them. Agatha guided Rio to the soft cushions, lowering her down carefully. Rio let out a soft groan, her head lolling to the side as she sank into the comfort.

 

“I’ll grab her some water,” Lilia said briskly, disappearing into the kitchen before Agatha could offer to help. The sound of running water filled the small space, mingling with the faint hum of a heater.

 

Agatha straightened, brushing a stray strand of hair from her face. Her gaze drifted to Rio, who was blinking slowly, her hands clutching at the edges of the couch as if trying to anchor herself. Despite her disheveled state, there was something childlike about the way she curled into herself, her usual fiery energy dimmed but not extinguished, as if being in this house brought out another version of her.

 

Lilia returned moments later with a glass of water, kneeling in front of Rio. “Here, drink this,” she said, her tone firm but affectionate. She pressed the glass into Rio’s hands, steadying it when the younger woman’s grip wavered. “All of it, silly girl. You need it.”

 

Rio pouted but obeyed, sipping slowly at first before draining the glass with a small hiccup. Lilia took it back and set it on the coffee table, her hands lingering for a moment on Rio’s knee as she studied her with a maternal intensity that made Agatha pause.

 

“Thank you for bringing her home,” Lilia said, finally turning to Agatha. Her voice was softer now, the initial edge of concern giving way to gratitude. “I don’t know what would’ve happened if you hadn’t found her.”

 

“It’s no trouble,” Agatha replied, though her eyes lingered on Lilia, trying to piece together the connection between the two women. “I’m glad I was there.”

 

Lilia sat down beside Rio, brushing a few strands of hair away from her face. “This one,” she said with a small, rueful smile. “She’s got a good heart, but she doesn’t always think things through. I swear, she’s going to be the death of me one day.”

 

Rio made a soft noise of protest, her eyes half-lidded as she murmured, “Not true. I’m a delight.”

 

Lilia laughed, the sound warm and rich. “A delight who can’t walk in a straight line after a few too many drinks.”

 

Agatha allowed herself a small smile at their exchange, though her curiosity continued to simmer beneath the surface. There was a story here, a dynamic that spoke of years of familiarity and trust. She glanced at the photos on the wall again—pictures of Rio at various ages, some with Lilia and others on her own. It was clear that Lilia wasn’t just a friend or a landlord. She was something more, though Agatha didn’t yet have the context to understand what.

 

As Agatha turned to leave, her hand already on the doorknob, Lilia’s voice stopped her.

 

“Dr. Harkness,” Lilia said warmly, “would you like to stay for some tea? It’s the least I can offer after you went out of your way to bring my Rio here safely.”

 

Agatha hesitated, her instinct to decline warring with her curiosity. It was late, and she had papers still waiting for her at home, and a babysitter to relieve. But the image of Lilia cheering so fervently for Rio at the recital lingered in her mind, along with the way Rio had immediately given her Lilia’s name. This woman clearly meant something important to her student, and Agatha couldn’t deny her interest in learning more.

 

“If it’s not too much trouble,” Agatha finally said, stepping back inside and closing the door behind her.

 

Lilia smiled, the expression warm enough to melt any lingering hesitation. “Not at all. Make yourself comfortable. I’ll put the kettle on.”

 

Agatha glanced at Rio, who was now sprawled on the couch, clutching her glass of water like it was a lifeline. Her eyes were half-closed, her breaths slow and steady as if she were on the verge of falling asleep.

 

“She’ll be fine,” Lilia said as she passed through the cozy living room toward the kitchen. “She’s not a heavy drinker, so nights like these are rare. But every once in a while… Believe me, she will hear about it.”

 

There was a teasing affection in her words, the kind reserved for someone you cared for deeply but still wanted to shake some sense into. Agatha allowed herself a small smile and sank into an armchair opposite the couch. The room, though modest, had an undeniable warmth. Bookshelves lined one wall, crammed with everything from well-worn classics to mystery novels with eye-catching spines, lots of plants. A faint scent of lavender lingered in the air, likely from the candle flickering softly on a nearby table.

 

Her gaze wandered to the photos that adorned the walls. They were snapshots of a life lived in stages, most of them featuring Rio at various ages. In one, a teenage Rio stared at the camera with an expression that wavered between defiance and vulnerability. And then there were the ones with Lilia—a younger version of the woman standing proudly beside Rio at a high school event, or the two of them smiling in a kitchen, mid-laugh.

 

“You seem very close,” Agatha remarked, nodding toward one photo in particular—the one of teenage Rio, her arms crossed, her gaze sharp and unyielding.

 

Lilia appeared in the doorway, holding two steaming mugs. She followed Agatha’s gaze to the photo, her expression softening as she handed one of the mugs to her guest. “She’s a daughter to me,” Lilia said, settling into the chair opposite Agatha. “She came to me when she was sixteen. Foster care hadn’t been kind to her, but even then, she was fierce. I could tell right away she was special.”

 

Agatha wrapped her hands around the warm mug, leaning forward slightly. She hadn’t known that Rio had been a foster kid. “She’s never mentioned it,” she said carefully, not wanting to overstep.

 

Lilia chuckled, the sound carrying a mix of pride and quiet sadness. “She doesn’t like to dwell on it. Can’t say I blame her. The system… it leaves scars. But even at her worst, she had this fire in her. This refusal to give up, no matter how hard things got.”

 

Agatha sipped her tea, leaning forward slightly. “It sounds like you’ve been the steady presence she needed. That’s rare for someone who’s been through the system.”

 

Lilia’s smile widened, though it didn’t quite reach her eyes. “I’d like to think so. I tried to give her a home, stability… the kind of love she should’ve had from the start. But…” Her voice softened, and her fingers idly traced the edge of her mug. “Sometimes I wonder how much she’s let me in, even after all these years. She’s got this wall, you know? She lets you close, but not too close.”

 

Agatha nodded, her gaze drifting back to Rio, who now seemed fast asleep. “I’ve seen that wall,” she admitted. “In class, she’s sharp and confident, but sometimes it feels like she’s holding something back.”

 

Lilia sighed, her expression distant for a moment before she refocused on Agatha. “That’s Rio. She’s brilliant, stubborn, and so full of potential it makes me ache sometimes. But she’s also carrying things she doesn’t know how to put down. I just do my best to be here for her, whether she asks for it or not.”

 

Agatha’s respect for Lilia deepened as she listened. There was a quiet strength to her, a resilience born from years of shouldering the role of caretaker for someone who had likely resisted being cared for at all. 

 

“You’ve done more for her than most would,” Agatha said finally, her voice gentle but firm. “That kind of consistency… it matters.”

 

Lilia smiled again, this time with a touch of gratitude. “Thank you, Dr. Harkness. That means a lot, coming from you. She’s told me about you before, you know. Said you’re one of the few people who sees her potential.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, surprised. “She said that?”

 

“She wouldn’t admit it outright, of course,” Lilia said with a small laugh. “But I know her well enough to read between the lines.”

 

There was a pause, the warmth of the tea in Agatha’s hands grounding her as she hesitated to ask her next question. “Do you have children of your own?”

 

Lilia’s eyes flickered with a trace of something unspoken, but her smile remained kind. “No. Rio is the closest I’ve had to that. She’s enough.”

 

Agatha nodded slowly, sensing there was more beneath Lilia’s words, but she chose not to pry. Instead, Lilia shifted the conversation with a curious tilt of her head. “And you?” she asked, her gaze inquisitive but warm. “You mentioned being her professor, but do you have children, Dr. Harkness?”

 

“I do,” Agatha replied, her voice softening instinctively, as it always did when she spoke about her son. “A boy. Nicky. He’s six.”

 

At that, Lilia’s face lit with recognition, her smile broadening. “Of course! Rio mentioned him after the recital. She couldn’t stop talking about how charming he is and how much she enjoys teaching his class. She said he was quite the star that day.”

 

A small, genuine smile tugged at Agatha’s lips, and for a moment, the stern professor façade fell away. “He’s quite taken with her as well. I’ve never seen him so excited for a class before. It’s all ‘Miss Vidal this’ and ‘Miss Vidal that’ at home.”

 

“That doesn’t surprise me,” Lilia said, her tone warm. “Rio has a way with children. I think it’s because she remembers what it was like not to have that kind of connection growing up. She doesn’t just teach them—she sees them.”

 

Agatha nodded, her fingers tapping lightly against her mug. “That’s a rare gift,” she said, her tone contemplative.

 

“It is,” Lilia agreed. Her lips curved into a teasing smile as she added, “And she mentioned you were there at the recital. Sitting right up front, cheering Nicky on like the proudest mom in the room.”

 

A faint flush crept up Agatha’s neck, but she maintained her composed exterior, sipping her tea before responding. “It was a lovely performance,” she said simply, though the hint of a smile betrayed her fondness.

 

Lilia chuckled knowingly but didn’t press the matter further. Instead, she glanced down at Rio, who had shifted slightly in her sleep, her brow furrowing as if caught in a dream. Lilia reached over, brushing a stray curl from Rio’s face with a tenderness that didn’t go unnoticed by Agatha.

 

“She’s quite lucky to have you,” Agatha said softly, her gaze lingering on the scene before her.

 

Lilia smiled, her hand still resting lightly on Rio’s shoulder. “I’m the lucky one,” she said simply. “Like I told you, Rio came to me when she was sixteen. She just needed someone to believe in her. That’s all it takes sometimes—to know someone has your back, even when you don’t believe in yourself.”
