Agatha’s fingers tightened slightly around the mug as she absorbed Lilia’s words. “She’s very bright,” she offered after a moment, her tone carrying genuine admiration. “Her ideas for her thesis are some of the most compelling I’ve read in years. She has a way of thinking that’s… different. Unique.”

 

Lilia’s face lit up with pride, her eyes glimmering with the kind of joy that only came from hearing someone recognize the person you love most. “She’s always had a way of seeing things others don’t,” Lilia said. “But she’s hard on herself. Too hard sometimes. She carries so much pressure to prove herself, and I just wish she could see what I see in her.”

 

Agatha nodded, taking another sip of tea. She had seen that same relentless drive in Rio—her sharp wit, her thoughtful insights, and, beneath it all, a vulnerability that surfaced in fleeting, unguarded moments.

 

“And you?” Lilia asked, tilting her head slightly, her gaze steady and curious. “Why did you go out of your way tonight? You didn’t have to.”

 

Agatha hesitated, caught slightly off guard by the directness of the question. Her instinct was to give a polite, professional answer, something distant and detached. But something in Lilia’s tone—gentle but probing—made her reconsider.

 

“I would’ve done the same for any of my students,” she began carefully, though even as she said it, the words didn’t sit right. She paused, glancing at Rio, who was still curled up on the couch, her breathing soft and even. “But… Rio is different. She has a spark, a presence. It’s hard not to notice her. Hard not to care.”

 

Lilia’s lips curved into a knowing smile, and she let out a quiet chuckle. “She has that effect on people,” she said, her voice warm.

 

The room settled into a comfortable silence, the only sounds the faint hum of the heater and the occasional soft rustle as Rio shifted in her sleep. Agatha cradled her mug, the tea’s warmth radiating through her hands, grounding her in a way she hadn’t expected.

 

“I saw you at the recital,” Agatha said after a moment, breaking the quiet. She set her mug down on the coffee table, her gaze flicking to Lilia. “You were cheering for her.”

 

Lilia’s expression softened, a fondness brightening her eyes. “Of course I was,” she said simply. “She worked so hard with those kids. Seeing her up there—performing, teaching, thriving—it’s everything I hoped for her. She’s built a life she can be proud of, and I’ll never stop cheering her on for that.”

 

Agatha felt an unexpected warmth spread in her chest at Lilia’s words. There was something so genuine, so unwavering about the way she spoke of Rio. It reminded Agatha of her own quiet pride for Nicky, of the way she’d cheer him on in anything he chose to do.

 

“She really is lucky to have you,” Agatha repeated, her voice quieter now.

 

Lilia shook her head with a soft laugh, her gaze drifting to Rio. “I think I’m the lucky one. She’s taught me more than I could ever teach her. Resilience, courage, how to find joy even when life tries to take it from you.” She glanced back at Agatha, her expression thoughtful. “She doesn’t let many people in, you know. So if she’s let you see even a fraction of who she really is, that means something.”

 

Agatha nodded, unsure how to respond to that. She glanced at Rio again, noting the way her features had softened in sleep, the usual intensity of her expression replaced with a rare, peaceful vulnerability.

 

After a moment, Lilia broke the silence. “She really did mention you, you know,” she said, her tone light but carrying an undercurrent of meaning.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow. “Did she?”

 

“Oh, yes,” Lilia said with a sly smile. “She talks about you more than she realizes. Always with that mix of frustration and admiration that tells me you’re someone she respects. Even if she’d never admit it outright.”

 

Agatha let out a soft laugh, shaking her head. “That sounds about right.”

 

Lilia’s eyes gleamed with amusement. “Rio’s a handful, but she’s worth it. She just needs people in her life who see her for who she is, not who she tries to be.”

 

The words lingered in the air, settling into Agatha’s mind like a seed waiting to grow.

 

After they finished their tea, Agatha rose to leave, thanking Lilia for the hospitality.

 

“Thank you again, Dr. Harkness,” Lilia said as she walked her to the door. “For everything. For looking out for her.”

 

“Please,” Agatha said, offering a small smile. “Call me Agatha.”

 

Lilia nodded, her expression softening. “Agatha, then. I hope this won’t be the last time we see you.”

 

Agatha inclined her head in acknowledgment before stepping out into the cool night air. As she made her way to her car, she couldn’t shake the feeling that tonight had been more than just a favor for a student. She had stepped into a deeper layer of Rio Vidal’s world—a world that was raw, complex, and unexpectedly captivating.

 

Sliding into the driver’s seat, Agatha allowed herself a rare moment of reflection. She hadn’t anticipated Rio becoming anything more than a name on her roster, another bright mind in a sea of students. But now, she wasn’t so sure. There was something about Rio—about her resilience, her fire, and the people who cared for her—that intrigued Agatha more than she cared to admit.

 

And as she drove away, the faint glow of Lilia’s porch light fading in her rearview mirror, she found herself quietly determined to understand that spark even more.

*

*

*

 

Sorry About That

*

*

*

The dove descending breaks the air

With flame of incandescent terror

Of which the tongues declare

The one discharge from sin and error.

The only hope, or else despair

Lies in the choice of pyre of pyre—

To be redeemed from fire by fire.

 

    (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next day, as Agatha stood in front of the lecture hall, she noticed that something was off. Rio Vidal, usually so focused and engaged, sat at the back of the room with her gaze fixed on the desk in front of her, her posture slumped in a way that suggested she was miles away. Her usual sharp, perceptive eyes were dull, and she didn’t seem to be following the discussion as she usually did.

 

Agatha’s eyes lingered on her for a moment before she refocused on the material at hand. She could feel the shift in the air, an unspoken tension in the room. While she’d always prided herself on being able to read her students, Rio had never been one to wear her emotions so openly, but today it was undeniable—something was wrong.

 

She tried to keep her thoughts on the lecture, but her mind kept drifting back to Rio. Was she still affected by the night before, by the events at the bar – that she wasn’t sure she could remember much considering the state she had found her in -  and their conversation afterwards? Agatha wasn’t sure, but she could sense a change, an undercurrent of something more than just the usual tiredness from a long week.

 

After class ended, as students filed out, Agatha approached Rio, who was gathering her things slowly.

 

“Miss Vidal,” she said gently, her voice low enough not to draw attention. “Is everything all right?”

 

Rio froze for a moment, her hand hovering over her notebook. She looked up at Agatha, her expression guarded, before she forced a small smile.

 

“Yeah, I’m fine,” she said, her voice softer than usual. “Just… a bit tired.”

 

Agatha didn’t buy it, but she didn’t press. She gave Rio a long, searching look. “If you need to talk, you know where to find me.”

 

For a moment, Rio just stared at her, as if considering something, but then she nodded, closing her bag and standing up. “Thanks, Dr. Harkness,” she muttered before quickly walking out of the room.

 

Agatha watched her go, a sense of unease settling in her chest. She had a feeling Rio was far from fine, and it troubled her more than she wanted to admit.

 

 

Later that day, as the campus quieted down, Rio found herself standing outside Agatha’s office. She had been thinking about it all afternoon—about the way she had acted last Friday night, about the lingering looks and the conversation that had felt too personal, too much. She felt embarrassed for her behavior, for inviting her professor to something as trivial as a band gig, for the way it had all felt too much like… well, something else.

 

Taking a deep breath, she knocked on the door, her stomach twisting with nerves.

 

“Come in,” Agatha’s voice called from inside.

 

Rio entered, her heart racing, trying to muster some composure. Agatha was sitting at her desk, scribbling on a piece of paper. She looked up when Rio stepped in, her eyes soft but curious, like she was expecting her.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha said, her voice warm but still formal. “What can I do for you?”

 

Rio swallowed hard, gathering her words. “I just… I wanted to apologize for Friday night and inviting you,” she said, her voice quieter than usual. “I don’t know what I was thinking, really. I guess I got a little carried away.”

 

Agatha set down her pen and leaned back in her chair, her gaze thoughtful. “There’s no need to apologize, Rio. You didn’t do anything wrong.”

 

“I’m sorry if I made you uncomfortable,” Rio continued, her hands fidgeting with the strap of her bag. “I know I probably crossed some boundaries.”

 

Agatha looked at her, something unreadable in her expression, before she spoke again, her voice gentle but firm. “I don’t think you crossed any boundaries, Miss Vidal. It’s clear that you’re passionate about what you do, and it’s always nice to see a student so… alive, I suppose.”

 

Rio felt her heart thud in her chest at the unexpected softness in Agatha’s voice. She didn’t know if it was relief or something else, but the tension in her shoulders eased just a little.

 

“I guess I just… I wasn’t sure if it was appropriate to invite you, or if you even wanted to go,” Rio admitted, her gaze dropping to the floor. “I didn’t want it to be weird or anything.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened, and she stood up from her desk, walking around to the other side where Rio stood. “It wasn’t weird,” she said, her voice low. “And I’m glad you invited me. I think sometimes we forget that there’s a person behind the title, behind the role of ‘professor.’”

 

Rio nodded, but she was still unsure. “I just… I didn’t want to make things awkward between us. I know I’m your student, and I don’t want to make anything feel strange.”

 

Agatha paused for a moment, considering her words carefully. “Rio,” she said, her voice calm but with a trace of something more genuine beneath it, using her first name for the first time, “we are all more than just the roles we play. And if anything, I admire your confidence. You don’t need to apologize for being yourself. But if you ever feel uncomfortable or if you feel like you’ve crossed a line, just let me know. I want this to be a space where you feel comfortable to learn and grow, not to feel constrained by fear.”

 

Rio blinked, her heart stuttering slightly at Agatha’s words. She wasn’t used to such openness from someone in her position—especially not from someone like Agatha, who had always seemed so composed, so distant.

 

“I’ll… try not to overthink things so much,” Rio said, a small smile tugging at her lips.

 

Agatha gave a small, understanding smile in return. “We all overthink things sometimes. But you’re doing just fine, Rio.”

 

For a brief moment, their eyes met, and Rio felt something stir inside her, an odd mixture of relief and confusion. It was hard to tell if it was just the weight of the day lifting or something else entirely, but for once, she didn’t mind.

 

“Thanks, Dr. Harkness,” Rio said, her voice quieter now, more assured.

 

“Anytime,” Agatha replied, her gaze lingering on her for just a moment longer than usual before she turned back to her desk, signaling the end of the conversation.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, standing in the doorway, before she took a deep breath and stepped back into the conversation.

 

“Oh, and… I also wanted to apologize for last night,” she said, her voice quieter than before, almost sheepish. “I didn’t mean to put you in that position. I know it must have been uncomfortable for you, having to take me home when I was so… drunk. I didn’t even realize how out of control I was.”

 

Agatha’s eyes softened, and she didn’t look upset, just calm. “You don’t need to apologize for that, Rio. It wasn’t a problem either, I’d rather have you safe with me, than alone and vulnerable in the streets.”

 

But Rio pressed on, her gaze dropping to the floor, her words tumbling out. “I just… I don’t know why I let myself get so drunk. I don’t want you to think… I don’t know. That I don’t know how to handle myself, or that I’m some kind of mess. I don’t want you to see me like that.”

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, considering Rio’s words carefully. Her voice was measured, calm, and yet there was something softer in it now. “Everyone has moments where they lose control, Rio. It’s part of being human. And it’s not about how we fall, but how we get back up. Besides, it wasn’t an imposition. I just made sure you got home safely. It didn’t even take that long.”

 

Rio raised her eyes to meet Agatha’s, seeing nothing but understanding there, no judgment. “I appreciate that,” Rio said quietly. “I didn’t want to put you out, and I definitely didn’t want you to think badly of me. I don’t usually get like that, but… it was just a rough night, and I guess I couldn’t handle it well.”

 

Agatha smiled faintly at the rambling, a touch of warmth in her expression. “It happens to the best of us. You don’t need to apologize. We all have our moments. Just be kind to yourself, Rio. You’ve got enough on your plate without carrying guilt around for things you can’t control.”

 

Rio felt a weight lift from her shoulders as Agatha’s words sank in. She nodded slowly, a quiet sense of relief settling over her. “Thanks, Dr. Harkness. That means a lot. Really.”

 

“You’re welcome,” Agatha replied with a small smile, her gaze lingering on Rio for a moment longer before she turned back to her desk, a silent signal that the conversation was coming to an end, this time for good.

 

Rio took a deep breath and, for the first time in days, felt something akin to peace. She had apologized for her mistakes, and Agatha, in her usual composed way, had handled it with nothing but grace and kindness. For all the uncertainty she’d been feeling lately, something about Agatha’s calm, reassuring presence made Rio feel like things could be okay.

 

Rio left the office with a sense of quiet gratitude, still uncertain about the path ahead but feeling, for the first time in a while, that perhaps she wasn’t as alone in this as she had felt before.

 

 

The next day, as Rio and Alice sat down at their usual spot in the campus café for lunch, Alice wasted no time in asking the question that had been on her mind since the night before.

 

“So, how did you get home after you left to go to Jen’s?” Alice asked, eyeing Rio with a mischievous glint in her eyes. “I was half-expecting you to end up passed out in the bar, and you didn’t answer my text asking if you made it home.”

 

Rio froze for a second, her spoon paused midair as she glanced at Alice. She hadn’t expected the question so directly, and a slight flush crept up her neck. She hesitated, unsure how much she should say. After all, it had been an eventful night, and now that she thought about it, it felt like a lifetime ago.

 

“I… um,” Rio started, but she didn’t get very far before Alice’s teasing tone continued.

 

“Wait, don’t tell me you walked home drunk? That’s an accident waiting to happen!” Alice pressed, leaning forward, clearly feeling guilty about having left her friend to fend for herself.

 

Rio let out a breath, running a hand through her hair. “No, actually… it wasn’t like that. I got… uh, help. Dr. Harkness, actually,” she said, her voice a little quieter now.

 

Alice’s eyebrows shot up in surprise. “Wait—what? She took you home?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio muttered, her face reddening even more. “She found me on my way home. I… I was very drunk. And, I guess I wasn’t doing too well walking, so she called Lilia for me and drove me to her place.”

 

Alice sat back in her chair, her grin widening. “So, your professor… took you home? That’s… unexpected.”

 

Rio groaned and buried her face in her hands for a moment. “It was embarrassing. I was all over the place. I couldn’t even walk straight.” She could feel the awkwardness rising up in her chest again. “I just don’t want her to think badly of me.”

 

Alice chuckled, trying to stifle her laughter. “Oh, Rio, that’s actually kind of cute. I mean, Dr. Harkness is all cool and composed, and then here she is, taking care of you like you’re a damsel in distress.”

 

“Yeah, well, I didn’t want to make it a thing,” Rio muttered. “But she was really kind about it. I guess… I guess I was lucky.”

 

“Kind about it?” Alice asked, her tone teasing. “Oh, I’m sure she was. I mean, if my professor took me home to my pseudo mom after a night of getting plastered, I’d probably never be able to look them in the eye again.” She leaned in closer. “So, tell me—did anything else happen? Did she stay with you?”

 

Rio nearly choked on her drink at Alice’s comment, but she quickly recovered. “No! Nothing like that. She just dropped me off at Lilia’s and made sure I was okay before she left. I think they talked a little, but I think I passed out on the couch.” Rio added, hiding her face in her hands in embarrassment.

 

Alice eyed her suspiciously, a mischievous smirk tugging at her lips. “Sure, sure. I’m not buying it. Guess, I’ll have to ask Lilia.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes. “I swear, Alice, she was just being… nice. Nothing happened. I think she just didn’t want me to do something stupid.”

 

Alice didn’t look convinced, but she let out a sigh, clearly enjoying teasing Rio but deciding to back off for the moment. “Alright, alright. I’m not going to push. But it’s kind of sweet, in a weird way, don’t you think? Your professor looking out for you like that.”

 

Rio shrugged, though inside, she felt a twinge of warmth at the thought. “I guess. It’s just… I didn’t expect it. I didn’t expect her to be so… kind. It’s not how I imagined her at all.”

 

Alice gave her a knowing look. “I mean, I’ve always said you had a thing for strong, capable women.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes again, though she couldn’t help the small, involuntary smile that tugged at her lips. “Stop it. It’s not like that.”

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms. “Sure, Rio. Whatever you say.”

 

For the rest of lunch, Alice continued to tease Rio about the unexpected encounter, but Rio couldn’t shake the image of Agatha from her mind. The way she had helped her, the way she had seemed so genuinely concerned without making it weird. For a moment, she felt… something she couldn’t quite place, and it made her a little uneasy.

 

Still, she couldn’t deny the fact that it was nice to feel cared for, even if it came from an unexpected source.

 

As Rio was finishing her lunch with Alice, her phone buzzed in her pocket. She pulled it out to see Lilia’s name on the screen. With a quick glance at Alice, she answered, holding the phone to her ear.

 

“Hey, Lilia,” Rio said, her voice light.

 

“Hey, kiddo,” Lilia’s familiar warm tone greeted her. “How are you feeling today? Better after last night?”

 

Rio leaned back in her chair, rubbing her temples slightly. “Yeah, much better,” she replied, trying to sound casual. “I’m not exactly proud of myself, but… yeah, I’m good now.”

 

Lilia chuckled on the other end of the line. “I imagine not. It’s not every day your professor has to play the role of designated driver. But I’m glad you’re okay. That was quite the… situation, huh?”

 

Rio winced, feeling the blush creep up again. “Yeah, a situation. I didn’t mean to make it a big deal.”

 

“You didn’t make it a big deal,” Lilia reassured her. “You just had a rough night. You’re allowed to, you know? We all have our moments. Next time, maybe just give me a heads up, okay?”

 

Rio smiled faintly at the reassurance, grateful for Lilia’s always soothing presence. “Thanks, I’ll try. And thanks for everything last night. I know it wasn’t your night and you might have had other plans.”

 

“It wasn’t a problem, Rio,” Lilia said, her voice soft but firm. “I’m always here for you. Don’t forget that.”

 

Rio’s throat tightened slightly at the words. “I won’t,” she whispered, feeling the sincerity of Lilia’s care. “I really appreciate it, Lilia. I don’t know what I would’ve done without you.”

 

“Well, you don’t have to figure that out,” Lilia said with a laugh. “I’ve got your back. Now, I’ll let you go, but if you need anything else, call me, okay? I’ll be around.”

 

“Okay,” Rio said, her voice thick with gratitude. “Thanks again. I’ll talk to you soon.”

 

“Take care, sweetheart,” Lilia replied before the call ended.

 

As Rio hung up the phone, she looked over at Alice, who had been silently watching the conversation.

 

“You okay?” Alice asked, her voice softer now. “Are you in trouble with Lilia?”

 

Rio nodded, a smile tugging at her lips. “Yeah. Just… I don’t know. It’s been a lot, you know? But no, Lilia’s been pretty cool about the whole thing. She knows I know how much trouble she got it when she was my age.”

 

Alice gave her a knowing look. “That sounds like Lilia. But hey, you’ve got people who care about you, Rio. That’s what matters.”

 

Rio let out a small breath, feeling a mix of relief and something else. “I guess so.”

 

Her phone buzzed again, this time a text from Lilia: Remember, if you need to talk, I’m here anytime.

 

Rio read it and smiled before putting her phone down. “I know,” she murmured quietly to herself, grateful for the people in her life who made sure she wasn’t alone.

 

 

That night, after the day’s work was done and the house was quiet, Agatha sat in her study, surrounded by papers and books that usually occupied her attention. But tonight, her mind kept drifting away from the academic concerns she usually buried herself in. Her thoughts kept returning to Rio—specifically, to everything Lilia had revealed to her last night once she had been sure Rio was safe and sound.

 

The conversation had started innocuously enough, with Lilia offering tea after Agatha had dropped Rio off. But as they spoke, Lilia had offered pieces of information that Agatha hadn’t expected. She had learned about Rio’s past—about the foster care system, had gotten a glimpse of the challenges she had faced growing up, and how Lilia had been the one constant in Rio’s life when so much had been unstable. She had also mentioned the close relationship Rio had with her, the kind of support Lilia had offered her over the years.

 

It wasn’t just the facts of Rio’s past that lingered in Agatha’s mind, but the way Lilia spoke of her. There was a warmth in her voice when she talked about Rio, a kind of quiet pride in how far Rio had come despite the odds stacked against her. It made Agatha’s thoughts about Rio deepen, and the softening of her usual skepticism towards people, especially students, became evident.

 

There was something in the way Rio carried herself, even when she wasn’t aware of it. A vulnerability hidden under a layer of strength. Agatha had always admired resilience, but something about Rio was different. The way she handled herself in the classroom, how she had been so unguarded when she’d had to rely on her that night. It was all adding up to a picture that Agatha hadn’t fully understood until now.

 

She sipped her tea, letting the warmth of the cup settle in her hands, her thoughts circling back to last night, when she had ended up taking Rio home. The image of Rio, unsteady and apologetic, still lingered in her mind. It wasn’t just the way Rio had looked, disoriented and yet trusting towards her in her inebriation. It was how she had trusted her enough to let her take control of the situation, even when it must have felt like she was losing control of herself.

 

Agatha had seen it before in her work as a professor—students who seemed so composed on the outside, but who hid so much beneath the surface. Rio wasn’t like that, she was much more than a broken little thing hiding behind a mask. There was a fragility to her, something raw and real that Agatha couldn’t ignore. And now, with everything Lilia had shared, Agatha found herself thinking about Rio in ways she hadn’t expected. She found herself wondering about the story behind Rio’s quiet strength, what it was that had shaped her into the woman she was today.

 

The more she thought about it, the more Agatha realized that Rio had intrigued her long before their awkward encounter that night. The way Rio’s eyes had glimmered with something more when she had shared her research, how fiercely she defended her ideas in class, even when she wasn’t sure of herself, the way she had been so confident on stage. Agatha could sense there was more to her, more layers waiting to be peeled back. And that fascinated her more than she cared to admit.

 

She leaned back in her chair, the quiet stillness of the house surrounding her, and she allowed herself a rare moment of introspection. She tried to push away the flicker of something else she was feeling—a spark that she hadn’t expected to feel toward one of her students. It was a dangerous thought, one that she didn’t have time to entertain, but it was there, lurking at the edges of her mind.

 

A student was a student even if they were grown adults, and Agatha knew the boundaries she had to maintain. She knew how easy it could be to let herself get swept up in the fascination of someone like Rio. She wasn’t a young woman anymore, and she had responsibilities—both as a professor and as a mother. The thought of mixing personal feelings with professional ones was something she couldn’t allow herself. But still, as she set her empty tea cup down and gazed out the window into the dark night, she couldn’t deny the strange pull Rio had on her, one that had only intensified over time.

 

She pushed her thoughts away, turning back to the work that waited for her. But in the back of her mind, Rio’s name echoed faintly, like a song she couldn’t forget.

 

*

*

*

 

Baby Sitting

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

Dawn points, and another day

Prepares for heat and silence.

Out at sea the dawn wind

Wrinkles and slides. I am here

Or there, or elsewhere. In my beginning.

 

      (T.S. Eliot. “East Coker.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

 

The day had been long, drawn out by an exhausting lecture and the endless trickle of students filtering through her office hours. By the time Agatha finished responding to the last question, closed her laptop, and leaned back in her chair, she finally allowed herself a moment to breathe.

 

And then, like an ill-timed punchline, reality set in.

 

The conference.

 

She was supposed to leave early the next morning for a day-long event—something that had been etched into her schedule for weeks. That wasn’t the problem. The problem was that her carefully laid plans had just fallen apart.

 

Her usual babysitter had canceled at the last minute. And Wanda, reliable as she was, was completely swamped with her own work commitments and had already sent her twins to their grandparents on her husband’s side. Agatha had already run through every other viable option—colleagues who owed her favors, friends who had helped in the past—but each possibility collapsed under scrutiny.

 

It was a logistical nightmare, one she had neither the time nor the energy to deal with. She pinched the bridge of her nose, exhaling sharply as she turned the problem over in her mind.

 

And then, quite suddenly, a name surfaced.

 

Rio.

 

She hesitated, considering the potential awkwardness of the situation. It wasn’t exactly professional to ask a student to babysit your child. But she was desperate, and there wasn’t anyone else. Plus, there had been something in Rio’s demeanor, her presence, that made Agatha feel like she could trust her with Nicky. The memory of the way she had reassured him before the recital only comforted her in the thought that Rio might be the person she needed.  

 

The thought of asking her made Agatha’s stomach churn with a combination of reluctance and, unexpectedly, a small tinge of hope.

 

With a sigh, Agatha gathered her papers and walked out of her office. The hallway was quiet, the last of the students trickling out for the day as she began her search for her student. She spotted Rio at the end of a corridor, making her way toward the library. Agatha hesitated for only a second before speaking out.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha called out, her voice carrying just enough authority to catch Rio’s attention.

 

Rio turned, a bit surprised to hear her name. “Dr. Harkness?” she said, pausing.

 

Agatha closed the distance between them with careful, measured steps, aware of how strange this request was—how personal. How unprofessional. But she was out of options.

 

“I hope I’m not catching you at a bad time,” Agatha began, trying to sound casual despite the awkwardness. “But I have a rather unusual request, and I understand if it’s too much, but I’m in a bit of a bind.” She paused, glancing around to make sure no one was within earshot.

 

“I’m attending a conference tomorrow, and my regular babysitter is unavailable. Nicky is a bit too young to stay home alone, and my friend Wanda has work commitments she can’t change. I was wondering…” She hesitated, feeling a strange nervousness building up. “Would you be willing to watch him for a few hours tomorrow evening? Because he already knows you and everything. Just until I’m back.”

 

Rio blinked, clearly taken aback by the request. For a moment, she wasn’t sure she had heard Agatha right. Babysitting? For Agatha’s son?

 

Her mind stumbled over itself for a moment, trying to process the sheer domesticity of the request. She had, of course, always liked Nicky—he was a sweet kid, funny and bright. She had felt oddly protective of him ever since the recital, when she had seen just how much he idolized his mother. And it wasn’t as if she had plans tomorrow night.

 

Still. This was Dr. Harkness. Asking her.

 

Rio hesitated for half a second too long, and Agatha took it as a refusal.

 

“I understand if you’re uncomfortable with it,” she said quickly, her voice carefully neutral. “I know it’s an unusual request, and I wouldn’t normally put a student in this position, but given the circumstances—”

 

“I’ll do it.”

 

The words tumbled out of Rio’s mouth before her brain had fully caught up.

 

Agatha blinked, caught off guard. “You—really?”

 

Rio nodded, finding her footing now. “Yeah. It’s no problem. I mean, I teach kids, I’ve been around them my whole life. Nicky’s great—I’d be happy to help.”

 

Something in Agatha’s posture softened just slightly. Relief flickered over her face, though she still looked vaguely surprised that Rio had agreed so readily.

 

“That’s… very kind of you,” she said, her voice quieter now. “Are you sure? It’s not an imposition?”

 

Rio smiled, shoving her hands into her pockets. “If it was, I wouldn’t have said yes.”

 

Agatha let out a slow breath, the tension in her shoulders finally easing for the first time all day. She hadn’t realized just how much stress she’d been carrying until now—until Rio’s quiet, easy agreement lifted the weight of her unsolvable dilemma.

 

“Thank you, Rio,” she said, and for once, there was no strict professionalism in her tone, just genuine relief. “I really appreciate it. You’re saving me in a big way. I’ll send you the details and make sure Nicky has everything he needs.”

 

Rio, still processing how this turn of events had happened, offered a small smile. “No problem. I’ll bring him home after dance class.”

 

Agatha gave a curt nod, but something in her expression softened at Rio’s words.

 

“If you give me your number, I’ll text you later with the address,” she said, pulling out her own phone. “And if anything comes up, just let me know. Thank you again. I owe you one.”

 

Rio hesitated for only a second before handing over her phone, her pulse skipping unreasonably fast as Agatha typed in her number. When Rio took it back, she glanced at the new contact—A. Harkness. Professional. No unnecessary familiarity. It suited Agatha perfectly.

 

With that, Agatha gave a small nod and turned to leave, her sharp heels clicking softly against the floor as she disappeared down the corridor.

 

Rio stood frozen for a moment, staring at the contact name on her screen as if it might suddenly change into something else. What the hell just happened?

 

Babysitting. For Agatha Harkness’s kid. Tomorrow night.

 

The thought was so bizarre she almost laughed out loud. Of all the ways she had imagined being around Agatha outside of class, this was not even remotely on the list. And yet…

 

Rio slipped her phone back into her pocket and walked toward the exit, her mind still reeling. A part of her was nervous—not about taking care of Nicky, but about what it meant to be invited, however indirectly, into Agatha’s personal life.

 

Because that’s what this was.

 

This wasn’t office hours, or a lecture hall, or an academic discussion. This was her, stepping into Agatha’s world in a way she never had before. She would be in her home, trusted with the one person Agatha seemed to truly let her guard down for.

 

Rio exhaled as she pushed open the doors and stepped outside into the crisp evening air. Not what I expected when I started my PhD, she thought wryly, shoving her hands into her jacket pockets.

 

But somehow, it felt… right.

 

 

By late afternoon the next day, as the golden light of the setting sun streamed through the dance center’s tall windows, Rio found herself slipping into the familiar rhythm of teaching. It was muscle memory by now—guiding her students through their warm-ups, offering corrections with steady hands, and watching as they slowly but surely grasped the movements.

 

She wasn’t the one teaching the little ones’ class today, instead have been scheduled for the junior team.

 

But beneath her usual focus, something else hummed in the back of her mind. The rest of her evening stretched ahead like uncharted territory. Babysitting Agatha Harkness’s son wasn’t something she had ever imagined herself doing, but somehow, it felt strangely fitting.

 

As her class wrapped up, Rio rolled her shoulders, the familiar ache of a good teaching session settling in. She waved off her last student and made her way toward the entrance of the studio, where she was supposed to pick up Nicky from his own class.

 

She spotted him before he saw her—a small bundle of energy, bouncing on his feet as he chatted animatedly with his other dance instructor. The moment his eyes landed on her, his entire face lit up with excitement.

 

“Miss Rio!” Nicky’s voice rang through the space as he practically launched himself toward her.

 

Rio grinned, crouching down to his level. “Hey there, buddy. How was class today? What did you learn?”

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled as he held up a brightly colored ribbon. “We did a dance with ribbons! Look! Miss Geraldine even said I could keep it!” He twirled it through the air, his tiny feet bouncing in place as he eagerly demonstrated the movement.

 

Rio laughed, genuinely delighted by his enthusiasm. “Wow, that’s amazing! You’ve got some serious skills. Keep this up, and you’re going to be an incredible dancer one day.”

 

He beamed at her praise, stuffing the ribbon into his bag before reaching for her hand. “Ready to go home?” she asked, giving his fingers a light squeeze.

 

“Yeah! Let’s go!” he chirped, swinging their joined hands as they made their way to the parking lot.

 

As they strolled through the parking lot, Rio reached into her pocket and pulled out her phone, quickly dialing Agatha’s number. The call connected after just a couple of rings.

 

“Hello, Dr. Harkness, it’s Rio,” she said, adjusting her grip on Nicky’s hand as he swung their arms back and forth. “Nicky just finished his dance class, and we’re heading to your place now. We’ll be there soon. Just thought I should keep you updated.”

 

Agatha’s voice came through the speaker, lower than usual, as if she were whispering. “Thank you so much, Rio. I really appreciate this. You’re helping me out more than you know.”

 

Rio could hear the faint murmur of voices in the background, no doubt the conference still in full swing. Agatha sounded tired but composed, her usual precise articulation softened by what Rio could only assume was exhaustion.

 

“No problem at all,” Rio replied easily, giving Nicky’s hand a small squeeze. “We’re going to have a great time, right, Nicky?”

 

The little boy perked up. “Yeah! It’s going to be so fun!”

 

Rio laughed, before turning her attention back to the call. “So don’t worry about a thing. Focus on your conference, and we’ll see you when you get back.”

 

Agatha exhaled a breath that almost sounded relieved. “I should be home quite late, but I’ll try not to wake Nicky when I get in.” There was a small pause before she added, more sincerely, “Thank you again, Rio. Truly.”

 

Something about the way she said it sent a warmth through Rio’s chest. She pushed it aside, keeping her tone light. “It’s really no trouble. Nicky’s great company.”

 

Agatha hummed in acknowledgment before they said their goodbyes. As Rio tucked her phone away, she glanced down at Nicky, who was still beaming up at her.

 

“Was that Mama?” he asked.

 

“Yup,” Rio confirmed as they reached the car. “She says she’ll be home late, but we’ll have fun in the meantime.”

 

Nicky nodded, seemingly unbothered. “That’s okay! Can we watch a movie later?”

 

“We’ll see, buddy. First, let’s get home.”

 

Rio helped him into the car seat Agatha had lent her for the occasion, making sure the straps were secure before climbing into the driver’s seat. As she started the car and pulled out onto the road, she felt an odd mix of emotions settle over her—excitement, nerves, and something else she couldn’t quite place.

 

Maybe it was just the novelty of it all. Spending an evening with Nicky, in Agatha’s home, stepping just a little further into a world that had always felt just out of reach.

 

From the backseat, Nicky swung his legs and asked, “Are we going to see Mama soon?”

 

“Probably not tonight, kiddo. She will be here when you wake up tomorrow, though.” Rio answered, hoping that it wouldn’t trigger a meltdown from the little boy. The child was surprisingly fine with the idea of spending the evening with only Rio. “And I bet she’ll be happy to hear about your ribbon dance!”

 

Nicky beamed. “Yeah, Mama’s going to love it!”

 

Rio chuckled. “I think so too.”

 

 

 The drive to the Harkness’ house took about twenty minutes, during which Nicky talked nonstop, filling the car with his animated chatter. He told Rio all about his ribbon dance, his favorite part of class, and even a detailed account of a squirrel he had seen outside the dance studio earlier that day. Rio nodded along, chiming in at all the right moments, finding his enthusiasm strangely grounding.

 

When she pulled into the driveway, she took a moment to take in the house in front of her. It was big but not ostentatious—modern, sleek, yet still warm in a way that made it feel like a home rather than just a house. The glow of the porch light cast a soft hue over the front steps, and Rio could see potted plants arranged neatly along the windowsill. It was exactly the kind of place she would have imagined for Agatha—put together but lived-in, elegant but practical.

 

As soon as Rio unbuckled him, Nicky wriggled out of his seat and sprinted toward the front door, bouncing on the balls of his feet as he waited for her. She followed at a more measured pace, fishing the spare key Agatha had given her this morning out of her pocket. Unlocking someone else’s front door felt oddly intimate, but she pushed the thought aside and turned the key.

 

“Okay, in you go, Nicky,” Rio said, stepping inside and flicking on the hall light.

 

Nicky didn’t hesitate, practically vibrating with energy as he tugged at her sleeve. “Can we do something fun, Miss Rio?” he asked, his eyes wide with excitement.

 

Rio smiled, crouching down to his level as she helped him unbutton his coat. “You know, you can just call me Rio when we’re not at the studio. All my friends call me that, and you’re my friend, right?”

 

Nicky beamed. “Yeah! I’m your friend, Rio!”

 

She hung up his coat and set her own bag down near the door. “So, what do you want to do?”

 

Nicky scrunched up his nose, clearly giving the question deep consideration. After a dramatic pause, he gasped. “Can we make cookies?”

 

Rio laughed. “Cookies? You got it. Let’s get the kitchen ready.”

 

“Yes!” Nicky cheered, already darting ahead. His enthusiasm was infectious, and Rio found herself grinning as she followed him toward the kitchen.

 

As Rio stepped further into Agatha’s home, she was struck by the contrast between this space and the one she usually associated with her professor. Agatha’s office, with its shelves of carefully arranged books and its cool, intellectual air, had always felt slightly untouchable—like stepping into a place where emotions were secondary to thought. But here, in the quiet glow of her house, Agatha’s world unfolded in an entirely new way.

 

The warmth of the space wrapped around Rio almost immediately. Soft lighting cast a golden hue over the wooden floors and plush furniture, and there was an unmistakable feeling of lived-in comfort. A few small toys were scattered across the floor near the couch, evidence of a child’s imagination left mid-adventure. On the mantle above the fireplace, a framed photo of Agatha and Nicky caught Rio’s eye—Agatha, mid-laugh, holding Nicky close as he grinned at the camera. She looked so different from the sharp, enigmatic professor Rio had grown used to. Softer. Happier.

 

Rio’s heart Riot a little faster, but not in a nervous way. She felt oddly comfortable here, especially with Nicky pulling her into the kitchen to help with cookies.

 

As Nicky chattered excitedly in the kitchen, Rio couldn’t help but feel a quiet admiration for Agatha. She had expected her life to be neat and composed, something orderly and intellectual, but seeing Agatha with Nicky, with the way she balanced work and motherhood, made Rio feel like she had only seen half of the woman she was. It made Agatha feel more real. Rio found herself wanting to learn more about that part of her, to understand how the brilliant, commanding professor could be so effortlessly tender with her son.

 

She glanced around the house once more, taking it all in—the toys, the books, the subtle signs of a life well-lived, and felt a quiet sense of peace.

 

Rio followed the excited boy into the spacious kitchen. The space was as stylish as the rest of the house, with marble countertops and sleek cabinets, but with various touches of warmth here and there.

 

On the fridge, among a few neatly arranged notes and reminders, was a colorful drawing. A child’s rendering of a tall figure (Agatha, no doubt) holding hands with a smaller one (Nicky). Above them, a bright yellow sun beamed down, and written in large, careful letters was: “Me and Mama!”

 

Rio’s chest tightened unexpectedly.

 

She had never really pictured Agatha in this way—not just as a professor or an intimidating academic presence, but as someone who came home to bedtime stories, tiny hand-drawn masterpieces, and the boundless love of a child who clearly adored her. The image settled deep inside her, stirring something she couldn’t quite name.

 

“Miss Rio, come on!”

 

Nicky’s voice snapped her out of her thoughts, his small hand grabbing hers and tugging her toward the counter. She laughed, allowing herself to be pulled along, the warmth of his grip anchoring her.

 

“Do you know where the baking stuff is?” Rio asked, rolling up her sleeves.

 

Nicky nodded confidently. “Mama and I make muffins sometimes! I know where everything is!” He scampered over to one of the lower cabinets and started pulling out mixing bowls with the precision of a kid on a mission.

 

Rio watched him with a smile, already pulling out her phone to search for a simple cookie recipe. This was already turning out to be a more fun evening than she had anticipated.

 

“All right, Chef Nicky,” she said, placing the phone on the counter. “Let’s make some magic happen.”

 

Finding the ingredients was easy enough—Agatha’s kitchen was neatly organized, everything in its rightful place. Rio set the sugar, flour, eggs, and chocolate chips on the counter, then turned to see Nicky struggling to climb onto the stool beside her. His little hands gripped the edge as he hoisted himself up, determination etched on his face.

 

With a chuckle, Rio scooped him up and placed him on the counter. “There you go, buddy. No need to scale the furniture like a ninja.”

 

Nicky giggled, swinging his feet beneath him. “I’m not a ninja, Rio! I’m a dragon!”

 

“Ah, my mistake.” Rio grinned. “Well, Mr. Dragon, you ready to make some cookies?”

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically, but then his face turned skeptical. “Are you sure you know how, Miss Rio?” He peered up at her with wide, serious eyes, as if the success of their entire evening depended on her answer.

 

Rio gasped, hand to her chest. “Are you doubting my cookie-making abilities?”

 

He giggled but remained unconvinced.

 

“I’ll have you know,” she said, grabbing a mixing bowl, “I’m a cookie expert. But I still need a top-notch assistant to make sure they turn out perfect.”

 

His face lit up. “I can do that!”

 

“Good.” She handed him a measuring cup. “Then let’s get started.”

 

Together, they mixed the dough, with Rio guiding Nicky through each step. He was in charge of stirring, though the flour ended up more on his hands (and the counter) than in the bowl. When they added the chocolate chips, Nicky tried to sneak a few into his mouth, but Rio caught him mid-act.

 

“Hey, hey! Those are for the cookies!” she scolded playfully.

 

“But I have to make sure they taste good!” Nicky argued, already chewing.

 

Rio sighed dramatically. “Fine. Quality control is important, I guess.” She popped a chocolate chip into her mouth too, making him giggle.

 

By the time they finished shaping the dough onto the baking sheet, Nicky’s small hands were coated in flour and chocolate. Rio wiped a bit off his nose with her thumb before sliding the tray into the oven.

 

“Now we wait,” she announced, dusting off her hands. “Got any ideas for what we should do?”

 

Nicky tapped his chin thoughtfully. “Hmm… can we read a book?”

 

“Absolutely.” Rio followed him into the living room, where he immediately flopped onto the couch, grabbing a well-loved picture book from the coffee table. He nestled against her side as he flipped through the pages, eagerly pointing at the illustrations.

 

“This one’s about a dragon,” he informed her. “But he’s a nice dragon, not a scary one.”

 

Rio played along, reacting to his enthusiastic commentary with exaggerated gasps and nods of agreement. “A friendly dragon, huh? That’s the best kind.”

 

The warmth of the house, the quiet hum of their voices, and the soft weight of Nicky leaning against her—all of it settled something inside Rio that she hadn’t even realized was restless.

 

Before long, the rich scent of warm chocolate filled the house, and the oven beeped.

 

“Cookies!” Nicky shouted, bolting off the couch and racing to the kitchen.

 

Rio laughed as she followed, carefully pulling the tray from the oven. The cookies were golden brown, slightly uneven in shape, but undeniably delicious-looking.

 

She placed them on a cooling rack while Nicky practically vibrated with excitement beside her.

 

“Okay, okay,” she said, waving her hands. “They need a minute to cool, or we’ll burn our tongues.”

 

Nicky groaned dramatically but waited, eyes locked on the cookies as if willing them to cool faster.

 

After a few minutes, Rio handed him one. He grabbed it eagerly, holding it in both hands like it was a treasure, before taking a big bite. His eyes went wide.

 

“Mmm!” he hummed, mouth full. “These are the best cookies ever, Miss Rio!”

 

Rio took a bite of her own and nodded approvingly. “Not bad, huh? I think we make a pretty great team.”

 

Nicky beamed, already reaching for a second cookie.

 

As Rio watched him, completely content with his sugar-filled evening, she felt something settle deep in her chest. There was something so simple, yet so meaningful, about this moment—sitting in Agatha’s kitchen, baking cookies with her son, feeling like she belonged, even if just for a night.

 

 

As the evening wore on and Agatha still hadn’t returned, Rio found herself still on the couch with Nicky, who was now winding down from the excitement of their cookie-making adventure. He was curled up on the couch, eyes heavy with sleep but still holding onto the last bits of energy. Rio sat beside him, gently rubbing his back as he snuggled closer to her, his small body warm and comforted by the simple presence of someone looking after him.

 

Rio shifted slightly, brushing a few stray curls from his forehead. “You getting sleepy, buddy?” she murmured, her voice low and soothing.

 

Nicky nodded, though he made no move to leave the warmth of their spot. “Rio, can you tell me a story?” he asked, his words slurred with drowsiness.

 

Rio smiled, glancing at the clock. It wasn’t too late, but she knew Nicky needed his rest. “Okay, but just a short one, alright?”

 

She stood carefully, taking his hand to help him off the couch. “Come on, let’s get you ready for bed first.”

 

Nicky made a tired noise of protest but didn’t fight her as she led him up the stairs, her hand steady against his back to make sure he didn’t stumble in his sleepy state. The upstairs hallway was dimly lit, the soft glow from a small nightlight casting gentle shadows on the walls. Agatha had mentioned Nicky’s bedtime routine earlier in the day, and Rio followed it as best as she could—helping him change into his pajamas, reminding him to brush his teeth, making sure his stuffed dragon was in its rightful place on his pillow.

 

When he was finally tucked under the blankets, Nicky blinked up at her expectantly, waiting for his promised story.

 

Rio thought for a moment before settling into the chair beside his bed, her voice hushed. “Alright, let’s see… Once upon a time, there was a little boy who loved to dance. He danced everywhere she went—through the fields, in the village square, even when it rained, he twirled through the puddles.”

 

Nicky listened with half-lidded eyes, his breathing slowing as Rio continued.

 

“One day, he wandered into a magical forest, where the trees whispered secrets, and the flowers swayed to music only they could hear. As he danced along the winding path, he met a talking rabbit who needed help finding his way home, a shy owl who had never learned how to fly, and a family of fireflies who had lost their glow.”

 

She glanced at Nicky, watching the way his small fingers curled against the blanket as he clung to the sound of her voice. “So he danced for them,” Rio continued, her voice softer now. “He showed the rabbit how to follow the rhythm of the wind, taught the owl to trust the beat of his own wings, and helped the fireflies remember the joy of their own light.”

 

Nicky let out a tiny sigh, his hand sleepily reaching for Rio’s sleeve again, his grip loose but present.

 

“He wasn’t a prince, or a hero with a sword,” Rio murmured, “but she had something special—a heart big enough to share, and a kindness that changed the world around her.”

 

By the time the story came to an end, Nicky was already slipping into sleep, his small body fully relaxed against the mattress. Rio carefully adjusted the blanket around him, tucking it in just the way she imagined Agatha would. She hesitated for a moment, watching the steady rise and fall of his chest, feeling something settle deep within her—a quiet, unexpected connection.

  

 

The door creaked open as Agatha stepped into the dimly lit living room, the cool night air still lingering on her coat. She hadn’t expected to be out so late, but the conference had run longer than anticipated. Now, as she stepped into the quiet of her home, the first thing that caught her eye was Rio.

 

There she was, sitting on the couch, legs curled up beneath her, a book open in her hands. The soft glow from the lamp above cast a gentle light on her face, highlighting the features Agatha had come to watch more and more — the focused student, the eager learner, the caring dance teacher, the lively drummer. But tonight, here in this private space, Rio looked different. She looked… comfortable. At ease. Like she belonged here.

 

For a moment, Agatha just stood there, watching her, the sight stirring something unfamiliar in her chest. She had seen Rio in class, always poised, always trying to impress, but here in her living room, there was a quiet intimacy that felt almost surreal. Seeing Rio in her own environment was strange. She wasn’t just a student anymore. She was someone who could step into her life, into her world, and make it feel less lonely somehow.

 

“Rio,” Agatha finally said, her voice soft, hesitant in a way she hadn’t meant it to be.

 

Rio’s head lifted, her eyes widening for just a second before recognition set in. A small smile touched her lips, effortless, natural. “Oh, hey, Dr. Harkness.”

 

Agatha caught the slight shift in Rio’s posture—how she straightened just a little, as if remembering who she was speaking to, yet there was no tension, no urgency to retreat into formality. She had been comfortable here. That was what struck Agatha most. Rio had settled into the house as if it were familiar, as if it had welcomed her just as easily as Nicky had.

 

Agatha paused for a moment before she said, “You can call me Agatha when we’re not in class. No need for formalities when you’re here.” She said it with a lightness in her voice, trying not to sound too caught off guard by the unexpected ease of the moment.

 

Rio blinked, then nodded, her cheeks flushing slightly. “Right. Of course. Agatha,” she repeated, testing the name on her tongue. It felt different, more personal. The air between them shifted just slightly, the boundary that had always been there now just a little bit smaller. Agatha noticed it immediately, the subtle change in how they both held themselves, how Rio’s posture softened, how Agatha couldn’t seem to look away from her.

 

“I hope Nicky wasn’t too much trouble,” Agatha added, shaking off the strange feeling as she stepped fully into the room. She rolled her shoulders slightly, allowing herself to exhale now that she was home. She slipped off her coat, draping it over the arm of a chair, and set her bag down with a quiet sigh. The night had stretched on longer than she had anticipated, and though the conference had been productive, she was grateful to finally be home.

 

Rio, still seated on the couch, tilted her head slightly and smirked. “No trouble at all. We made cookies.” Her voice was lighter than usual, a warmth in her tone that she almost seemed to catch herself trying to suppress. “There are some left on the counter if you want one.”

 

Agatha glanced toward the kitchen, the faint scent of something sweet still lingering in the air. The thought of coming home to freshly baked cookies wasn’t something she had expected, but it made the house feel… softer, more lived-in, as if Rio’s presence had left something behind even in such a short span of time.

 

“He’s great,” Rio continued, stretching slightly as she closed her book. “We had a good time.” Then, with a teasing lilt in her voice, she added, “I think he likes me better than his usual sitter.”

 

Agatha chuckled, the sound quiet but genuine. “I wouldn’t be surprised. He can be hesitant with new people, but once he warms up to someone, he’s all in.” She shook her head fondly. “And if cookies were involved, you definitely won him over for life.”

 

Rio grinned. “So what you’re saying is, I’m officially on the permanent babysitter list?”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, amusement dancing in her eyes. “It’s looking that way.”

 

For a moment, the conversation drifted into silence—not the awkward, searching kind, but something easy, something settled. Agatha found herself surprised by how natural it felt, standing here in the dim light of her living room, speaking with Rio as if this were just any other evening, as if it were normal for her to be here, for them to share this kind of quiet familiarity.

 

“I didn’t mean to stay so late,” Agatha admitted, running a hand through her hair as if to shake off the weight of the evening. “But thank you for staying with him. I really appreciate it.”

 

Rio met her gaze, and something in the way she looked at her made Agatha pause. There was no expectation, no formality—just sincerity, a quiet understanding that felt different from their usual dynamic.

 

“Anytime, Agatha,” Rio said simply, her voice steady, certain.

 

The name lingered in the air between them, soft but carrying a weight that neither of them fully acknowledged. Agatha felt it settle somewhere in her chest, an almost imperceptible shift in the space between them.

 

Strange.

 

But somehow… right.

 

After a Riot, she finally said, “Would you like some tea? You’ve been reading for a while. I could use a bit of quiet myself.”

 

Rio nodded, a small but genuine smile on her lips. “I’d love some, thank you.”

 

As Agatha moved toward the kitchen to prepare it, she couldn’t help but glance back at Rio, still curled up on the couch, a quiet part of her feeling like she was seeing this student for the first time. There had been a lot of those lately.

 

Agatha returned to the living room with two steaming cups of tea, the soft scent of chamomile filling the air. As she set them down on the coffee table, she noticed Rio had moved slightly, her legs now tucked neatly underneath her, sitting up with a careful balance of curiosity and caution. Her eyes, once warm and open, now held a new intensity, as though the atmosphere had subtly shifted. Agatha couldn’t help but feel the change too.

  

“Thank you,” Rio said softly, her fingers brushing against the warm cup before bringing it to her lips. Her voice, though steady, carried an undertone that Agatha wasn’t used to hearing from her.

 

“Of course,” Agatha replied, sitting across from her, trying to keep her own composure in check. Her eyes couldn’t help but trace the curve of Rio’s jaw, the way the light seemed to settle around her in a way that felt too intimate, too personal. She quickly looked away, taking a slow sip of her tea, trying to steady the quiet storm inside her.

 

For a moment, neither of them spoke. They simply drank their tea, both of their minds clearly preoccupied, yet neither willing to break the silence too soon.

 

Rio cleared her throat, her gaze flickering up to meet Agatha’s. “I… uh, I just wanted to say again, thank you for trusting me with Nicky tonight. I know it must not have been easy.”

 

Agatha tilted her head slightly, watching her. There was something in Rio’s voice that wasn’t just politeness—it was careful, deliberate, as though she knew exactly what it meant to be trusted with something precious.

 

Agatha’s lips curled into a small smile, though she was suddenly aware of the way her pulse quickened, the way this moment felt heavier than it should. “You don’t have to thank me, Rio.” Her voice was softer than intended. “If anything, I should be thanking you. You were a huge help tonight. I don’t know what I would’ve done otherwise.”

 

She hesitated, then added, “Nicky’s a good kid. He’s lucky to have someone like you looking out for him when I can’t.”

 

Rio blinked, like she hadn’t expected that, and then something in her expression shifted. A slow, quiet smile formed—not the confident grin Agatha was used to seeing from her, but something gentler. More honest.

 

“He’s great,” Rio murmured. “Really.” Her voice dropped just slightly, like she was admitting something she wasn’t sure she should. “I’ve spent so much time with kids like him… kids who like just a little bit more attention. So when I can, I try to give them a little extra.”

 

Agatha watched her closely, her mind racing with thoughts of what Rio had just shared—of the quiet compassion that seemed to lie just beneath the surface of her usual composed demeanor. She had spent years trying to balance her world between academia and motherhood, never quite sure if she was doing enough for Nicky, if she was being enough for him. And yet, here was Rio—young, bold, bright Rio—who had stepped into her home tonight and simply understood. Not just Nicky, but the weight of it all. The unspoken fears. The quiet loneliness of it.

 

Agatha’s fingers tightened slightly around her mug as she studied Rio, her mind racing through everything she had learned about her tonight—about this other side of her, the one that had nothing to do with the eager student or the passionate musician. It was a side of Rio that had nothing to prove and everything to give.

 

And somehow, that made her even more dangerous.

 

Rio’s dark eyes met hers again, steady and unwavering, and for a moment, Agatha found herself lost in them—swimming in something neither of them had put into words, yet both could feel pressing against the quiet space between them.

 

The room felt smaller, the soft hum of the night outside barely cutting through the weight of the moment. Agatha should have looked away, should have reached for something—her tea, her book, anything—but she didn’t. Instead, she let herself hold Rio’s gaze, let herself feel the warmth curling at the edges of something she wasn’t sure she was ready to name.

 

“You’re very different from how I imagined,” Agatha found herself saying, before she could stop herself.

 

It wasn’t a calculated observation. It wasn’t the kind of thing she would normally say, but there it was, slipping past her lips—quiet, unguarded.

 

Rio’s brows lifted slightly, intrigued rather than offended. “Different how?”

 

Her voice was light, but there was something beneath it—curiosity, maybe, or something deeper, something testing the boundaries of what they were in this moment. The question lingered between them like an invitation, like a thread waiting to be pulled.

 

Agatha hesitated, exhaling softly as she glanced down at the untouched tea in her hands. She had thought about Rio more than she wanted to admit. More than she should. At first, it had been easy to categorize—student, drummer, stubbornly intelligent, sharp with a confidence that made her stand out in a room. But then came moments like this, when the image she had crafted of Rio unraveled at the edges, revealing something softer, something unexpected.

 

“I don’t know,” Agatha admitted at last, shaking her head with a small, self-conscious laugh. “Just… more than I expected.”

 

She looked up at Rio again, and this time, she let herself smile—genuine, unforced. It wasn’t the professional smile she wore in lectures or the polite one she gave colleagues at conferences. It was real. It felt almost like a release, like breathing a little easier now that the words were out in the open.

 

Rio’s lips curved, her expression shifting into something thoughtful. She tilted her head slightly, as if weighing Agatha’s words before deciding how much of herself to give in return.

 

“I get that,” Rio said after a moment, her voice quieter, more careful. “People always expect me to be… something else. I guess I don’t always fit the mold they put me in.”

 

Agatha’s heart skipped just slightly at the way she said it—so matter-of-fact, but with an undercurrent of something deeper. She knew that feeling too well. The feeling of being seen one way while knowing there were entire parts of herself that no one even thought to look for.

 

And Rio definitely had more layers than Agatha had ever considered before tonight.

 

Agatha set her tea down, watching Rio with careful curiosity, aware of the way her pulse thrummed just a little too fast, the way this moment felt almost dangerous in its stillness. “I think most people are more than what they appear to be,” she murmured.

 

Rio hummed softly in response, her gaze flickering down for a second before returning to Agatha’s with something unreadable, something Agatha wasn’t sure she wanted to define.

 

The silence stretched, but it wasn’t uncomfortable. It wasn’t something either of them felt the need to break.

 

Agatha was the first to break the stillness, though it took more effort than she expected. “I should… let you get some rest. I know you’ve had a long day.”

 

Rio nodded, her expression slightly wistful, but there was something in her gaze that told Agatha she wasn’t quite ready to leave, Agatha could tell. And if she was being honest with herself, she wasn’t sure she was ready to let her go, either.

 

“Thank you, again,” Rio said as she stood, the quiet finality in her voice carrying more weight than simple politeness. Her movements were unhurried, as if part of her was waiting for Agatha to say something—anything—to make her stay just a little longer. “I really did enjoy tonight. And I mean it—anytime you need me for Nicky… I’m here.”

 

Agatha’s lips parted, and for a second, she considered saying something more, letting herself reach for the unspoken thing between them. But instead, she swallowed it down, offering Rio a small, grateful smile.

 

“I know,” she said softly. “And I appreciate it. More than you know.”

 

Rio lingered for a fraction of a second longer, her dark eyes searching Agatha’s face like she was memorizing something, tucking it away for later. Then, with a small nod, she turned toward the door, her footsteps slow and deliberate, as if she, too, felt the weight of the moment stretching between them.

 

Agatha followed her with her gaze, watching as Rio slipped on her jacket, as her fingers hesitated on the doorknob before finally pulling it open. A rush of cold night air swept into the warm space between them, a stark contrast to the lingering heat of everything unsaid.

 

“Goodnight, Agatha,” Rio murmured, and the way she said her name—soft, unguarded—sent something curling deep in Agatha’s chest.

 

“Goodnight, Rio.”

 

The door clicked shut behind her, and Agatha let out a breath she hadn’t realized she was holding. The room felt quieter now, emptier, as if something tangible had left with Rio, something Agatha wasn’t quite ready to name.

 

She exhaled slowly, rubbing her fingers over her temple before moving to clean up the forgotten tea cups on the table. The house was silent except for the faint ticking of the clock, but Agatha’s mind was far from still.

 

The feeling hadn’t dissipated. If anything, it had only grown stronger.

 

And as she stood there, staring at the door Rio had just walked through, she knew—this wasn’t the end of something.

 

It was the beginning.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

You comments are keeping me alive and going, keep them coming and I'll be the happiest!!!!!

Down Bad

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

You say I am repeating

Something I have said before. I shall say it again.

Shall I say it again? In order to arrive there,

To arrive where you are, to get from where you are not,

You must go by a way wherein there is no ecstasy.

 

            (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

 

As Agatha walked into the lecture hall the next day, the air felt different. The familiar hum of students settling into their seats was accompanied by an unspoken tension that she couldn’t quite shake off. Her gaze briefly flickered across the room, landing on Rio, who sat in her usual spot, her expression serene but her body language slightly more guarded than usual.

 

Agatha couldn’t help but notice the subtle shift. It wasn’t anything dramatic—there were no overt signs of discomfort or awkwardness—but there was a certain quietness, a deeper focus to the way Rio was sitting. Her shoulders were slightly squared, her chin tilted just a little higher, as if she were bracing herself for something.

 

It wasn’t just Rio, though. Agatha could feel the change in the room as a whole. The students seemed to be a little more aware of the space between them, a little more conscious of their place in the class, as if the dynamic had subtly adjusted overnight.

 

Agatha’s heart thudded against her chest, the words she had shared with Rio the previous night—so carefully measured and laden with meaning—lingering in the back of her mind. She had tried to dismiss them, but they had stayed with her, settling into her thoughts like a seed that refused to be ignored.

 

As she took her place at the front of the room, Agatha cleared her throat, attempting to push the uneasy feeling aside. She started the class as usual, but her eyes couldn’t help but dart back to Rio more often than before. There was something magnetic in her presence now, a connection Agatha hadn’t anticipated.

 

Rio, for her part, was just as focused as ever, but her eyes seemed to linger on Agatha just a fraction longer than necessary. Their gazes met once, twice, and every time it was like a little electric spark traveled between them—something they both felt, but neither spoke aloud.

 

It was subtle—too subtle for anyone else to notice—but Agatha could feel it, could sense the quiet understanding growing between them, like a hidden thread weaving its way through the fabric of their interactions. It wasn’t something either of them had asked for, but it was undeniably there. And with every glance, every unspoken word, it pulled them closer together.

 

After a particularly intense discussion about Williams and his wheelbarrow, Agatha caught herself lingering on the way Rio’s lips curved slightly when she disagreed with a point. It was almost as if Rio’s passion for the subject was mirrored in the way she held herself—poised, but with a fierce undercurrent that Agatha had never noticed quite so vividly before.

 

When class ended, Agatha closed her notebook slowly, giving herself a moment to breathe. The room began to empty, but Rio remained seated, her fingers lightly tapping the surface of her desk as she appeared lost in thought. Agatha couldn’t resist the urge to approach her.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha began, her voice gentle but firm, as if anchoring herself in the present. “You’re quiet today. Everything alright?”

 

Rio’s eyes lifted to meet hers, a soft smile tugging at her lips, though there was something in her gaze that made Agatha’s heart skip. “Yeah, just… thinking,” Rio replied, her voice carrying an almost unspoken weight, a quiet admission that Agatha couldn’t quite place. “I’ve been doing a lot of that lately.”

 

Agatha nodded, her mind racing as she held her gaze. The words that lingered between them were thick with possibility, but she couldn’t find the right ones to bridge the gap. Instead, she chose to let the silence speak for itself.

 

“Well, don’t overthink it,” Agatha said with a half-smile, though her heart was pounding a little faster than she cared to admit. “I’ll see you next class.”

 

As Rio stood up, their eyes met once again. And for a moment, it felt like time had stopped, the weight of their unspoken connection pressing down on them both. There was a tension between them now that hadn’t been there before—an uncharted territory neither had ventured into, but both were clearly aware of.

 

“See you, Dr. Harkness,” Rio replied quietly, her voice soft, almost like a promise. And then she was gone, leaving Agatha standing there, the room suddenly too quiet, too still.

 

Agatha watched her go, her thoughts swirling as she stood rooted to the spot. Something had definitely changed between them. And Agatha knew, deep down, that it couldn’t be ignored any longer.

 

She could feel the pull, and it was undeniable.

 

 

As Rio made her way out of the lecture hall, her thoughts buzzed, swirling around one thing, one person—Agatha Harkness. It was almost impossible to focus on anything else. Her mind kept returning to the way Agatha’s voice had sounded when she spoke to her, how her gaze had lingered just a little too long when they exchanged glances.

 

God, Rio thought, her hands pressing against the cool metal of the door as she stepped outside. I’m down bad.

 

It wasn’t just the way Agatha spoke—though that was enough to send a thrill down her spine every time. It wasn’t even the way she commanded the room, effortlessly drawing the attention of every student without seeming to try. No, it was more than that. It was the way Agatha looked at her sometimes. The way she saw her, as if no one else in the world mattered at that moment but Rio.

 

And it didn’t make sense. Not at all. Agatha was her professor—her supervisor. She was older, experienced, and far too composed for someone like Rio, who was still figuring everything out. Rio had always been careful not to cross lines, to keep her boundaries in check, but lately, those boundaries felt more and more like they were shifting. Every interaction with Agatha made it harder to ignore the way her heart beat a little faster, the way her stomach did flips when their eyes met.

 

Rio paused on the steps, pressing her palm against her forehead as if she could physically stop the thoughts from overwhelming her. It’s just a crush, she told herself. That’s all it is. Just a fleeting little thing. Get over it.

 

But deep down, Rio knew it wasn’t that simple. This was more than a casual infatuation. There was a weight to it, an intensity that made her feel like she was on the edge of something dangerous, something she didn’t know how to handle. Agatha wasn’t just anyone. She was powerful, intelligent, and so unbelievably captivating. Every word that came from her lips seemed to carry more meaning than it should.

 

And the worst part? Rio thought, her chest tightening. I think she knows. She’s got to know.

 

The way Agatha had looked at her after class, the way she’d spoken so gently, as if her presence in the room was important. Rio had tried to brush it off, but the truth was, it had been hard to ignore the way she felt seen, in a way she hadn’t experienced before.

 

Rio took a deep breath, forcing herself to move, to keep walking. But no matter how hard she tried, the thoughts of Agatha lingered in her mind, like an unshakable tune playing on repeat.

 

Maybe I’m not down bad for her, but damn, she’s got a hold on me, Rio thought, the weight of her feelings pressing down harder than before. And I don’t even know what to do about it.

 

For now, though, there was nothing she could do. She had to focus on her thesis, on the band, on everything else. But as she walked through campus, the idea that Agatha Harkness was more than just her professor, that she could be something else entirely, was impossible to ignore.

 

And as much as Rio wanted to forget about it, to push it all aside, she couldn’t. Because now more than ever, the lines between student and professor felt blurred—and Rio wasn’t sure she wanted to draw them back again.

 

 

The next morning, as Rio walked across campus, still feeling the weight of everything that had been swirling in her mind, she realized she couldn’t keep bottling it up. She needed to talk to someone. Alice, of course, would be the perfect person. They’d been through everything together, and Rio trusted her with just about everything—except maybe this.

 

But today, as they sat at a coffee shop during a break, Alice noticed something was off.

 

“You okay?” Alice asked, eyeing Rio carefully as she stirred her coffee.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, then let out a long breath. “It’s… Agatha,” she muttered, staring down into her cup.

 

Alice raised an eyebrow. “Ah, Professor Harkness. The one who’s been making your heart race for the last couple of months?”

 

Rio groaned, resting her forehead in her hands. “I don’t know what’s going on. I mean, it’s just a stupid crush, right? I’m being ridiculous.”

 

Alicedindn't back down. “Well, you’re not the first person to have a crush on their professor, Rio. It’s not that unusual.”

 

Rio shot her a pointed look. “Yeah, but she’s my supervisor. It’s… complicated. I’m confused. I don’t know how to deal with it.”

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, her lips curling into a mischievous smile. “Okay, I did some research.” She paused, watching Rio’s eyes widen. “I looked up the guidelines in the student handbook. About relationships between PhD students and their supervisors.”

 

Rio’s eyes narrowed. “What? Alice, no—”

 

“No, hear me out!” Alice waved her hands dramatically. “It’s not forbidden. At least, not technically. As long as both parties are adults, it’s not like there’s some big rule that says it’s illegal or anything. It’s just not encouraged, because of all the power dynamics and, you know, the potential for awkwardness.”

 

Rio blinked, processing. “You actually read that?”

 

“Yeah, well, you’re my best friend. Of course I did. You didn’t think I’d let you spiral about this without a little bit of research, did you?”

 

Rio rubbed her temples. “You’re being ridiculous.”

 

Alice leaned forward, her tone softening. “Listen, I’m not saying you should go for it or anything. But I just want you to know that it’s not the end of the world, and you’re not breaking any rules if you—” She stopped herself, grinning. “If you, I don’t know, did something about it.”

 

Rio shook her head quickly, a blush creeping up her neck. “Stop. Seriously. Agatha would never want me like that. She’s my professor. I’m just… being weird, okay?”

 

Alice laughed, tapping her fingers on the table. “I’m not saying you’re going to jump into a relationship with her tomorrow, Rio. I just think you should acknowledge that whatever’s going on here, it’s probably more than just a passing crush. And maybe, just maybe, you should talk about it. Before you go insane trying to figure it all out yourself.”

 

Rio huffed, her thoughts still clouded with confusion. “I don’t know if I can talk to her about this. It feels… it feels like everything would be ruined if I said something. Like, it’s so stupid. She’s my supervisor. This is all so messed up.”

 

Alice looked at her seriously for a moment, then cracked a smile. “You’re not the first person to get all tangled up in something like this. But remember—nothing is ever as simple as it seems. And maybe the only way to really figure this out is to stop running from it.”

 

Rio didn’t know how to respond to that. Her stomach churned at the thought of confronting Agatha about it. It felt impossible. There was just no way.

 

“Anyway,” Alice said, standing up and grabbing her coat, “just think about it. No pressure.”

 

Rio sat there for a long moment, the weight of Alice’s words sinking in. She had to admit—deep down, part of her did want to talk to Agatha. To at least acknowledge whatever this was between them. But the fear, the uncertainty, made her feel like she was standing at the edge of something that could break everything.

 

It wasn’t just a crush. It felt bigger than that. And for now, Rio had no idea how to make sense of it.
