Rio knew she needed to focus on something else before she completely spiraled. She couldn’t keep fixating on Agatha, or how the thought of her made her heart race and her stomach twist. She needed an outlet—something to distract her. The band was always a safe place.

 

So, that evening, Rio threw herself into practice, letting the rhythms of the drums ground her. She had a rehearsal with the band later that night, and she was determined to leave her thoughts about Agatha behind for a few hours. But, as always, the music offered only temporary relief. The beats echoed in her mind, but the moment she let her guard down, her thoughts wandered back to her professor.

 

Alice could tell Rio was distracted, her usual energy a little more subdued than usual. As they played through a new song, Rio’s drumming was tight but lacked the passion she usually brought to their performances. Jen shot her a glance, but Rio just forced a smile, brushing it off.

 

“Everything okay?” Alice asked, catching Rio’s eye during a break.

 

Rio nodded quickly, shifting the conversation before Alice could press any further. “Yeah, yeah. Just… lots of things on my mind, I guess.” She forced another smile, trying to shake off the lingering tension.

 

But even as she said the words, she knew it wasn’t enough. It wasn’t just about the band, or even the stress of her thesis—it was Agatha. She couldn’t stop thinking about her, the way her voice sounded when she was stern in class, and the way she smiled that was just a little too kind when they talked one-on-one.

 

By the time practice ended, Rio was exhausted, but not from the music. It was the same weight she’d been carrying all week. She was still tangled in that web of uncertainty, and she had no idea how to untangle it. She’d hoped that losing herself in the music would give her some peace, but instead, it had only amplified her frustration.

 

On her way back to her apartment, she passed by the dance studio. A class was ending, and she caught a glimpse of some of the kids she taught. The familiar faces were like a balm to her frazzled mind, and she found herself stepping inside. She hadn’t planned to, but the urge to move, to feel her body in motion, was too strong to ignore.

 

Rio quickly changed into her dance clothes and stood at the barre, stretching as the class filed out. The rhythmic motions calmed her, but her thoughts—like a song on repeat—kept returning to Agatha. The way she seemed to watch her, the quiet moments between them after class, and how that one simple conversation, after their gig, had made everything feel… different.

 

She danced through the evening, pushing herself harder than usual, using every movement to try and quiet the storm in her head. She swirled across the floor, each step more powerful than the last, but the one thing she couldn’t shake was the nagging thought: What if Agatha felt the same way?

 

She couldn’t keep hiding behind the music, and she knew it. But tonight, she would try.

 

 

As Rio danced her frustrations away, Agatha sat at her desk at home, papers scattered in front of her, the faint glow of the lamp illuminating her tired eyes. The conference she had attended had been exhausting, and the late-night work she’d done catching up on grading didn’t help ease her mind.

 

But it wasn’t the workload that kept her up tonight—it was Rio.

 

Agatha had tried to ignore the pull she felt toward her student, tried to convince herself that her thoughts were just that—thoughts. Yet every time she saw Rio in class, every time their eyes met in passing, it felt like something deeper. The subtle shifts in their interactions were not lost on Agatha, and the confusion was growing.

 

She hadn’t planned on feeling this way. Rio was her student, and she was her supervisor. That should be enough to set clear boundaries. And yet… whenever Rio smiled at her, or when they shared a quiet moment together, it stirred something Agatha hadn’t felt in a long time—a longing, an attraction, and a sense of vulnerability that she couldn’t seem to escape.

 

The tea with Rio at her house after she had babysat Nicky, the way Rio had taken care of him, had only added to her confusion. It was one thing to see her in the classroom, where the structure was clear. But in her home, around her son, Rio had been so different—so warm, so grounded. And the kindness she showed her son had unsettled Agatha in ways she hadn’t expected.

 

She could still hear Rio’s soft laugh as they shared that quiet conversation. The ease between them, despite the distance that should have been there, had felt almost… natural. And when Rio had said her name for the first time, something inside her had jolted.

 

As the hours dragged on, Agatha found herself returning to the same thoughts again and again. She had always prided herself on being professional, on keeping personal and academic lives separate. But this… this was something different. Something far more complicated.

 

She stared at the stack of papers in front of her, but she couldn’t focus on them. All she could think about was Rio—her energy, her passion, her gentle presence. How every time their paths crossed, Agatha’s heart seemed to beat just a little faster.

 

The silence of the room grew heavier, the ticking of the clock the only sound breaking through her thoughts. Agatha pushed her chair back, rubbing her temples. She was overwhelmed, and she hated the feeling. She hated how she couldn’t keep her thoughts in check when it came to Rio.

 

What am I doing? she wondered, her hands gripping the edge of the desk. She had always been in control, always so sure of herself. But now? With Rio? Everything felt like it was slipping, slowly but steadily, into something she didn’t know how to handle.

 

And so, she stayed there, sitting in the dimly lit room, the weight of her thoughts pressing down on her. Even though she was so very aware of the professional boundary that should exist between them, the connection she felt with Rio — subtle and undeniable — made her question everything she thought she knew about herself.

 

For the first time in a long time, Agatha didn’t have the answers.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

I know what you’re all waiting for—it’s coming, I promise! Just hang in there for a couple more chapters. I swear, it’ll be worth the wait!

Love you all, you comments give me life :)

Academic Meeting

Chapter Notes

Guys!! I just got tickets to Gigi Perez’s concert in Paris! AHHH! 😭🙌 You already know I’ll be screaming my heart out to “Sailor Song,” but let’s be real… my brain’s gonna be stuck on Agatha and Rio with all the edits I’ve seen of them lately 😂💕

See the end of the chapter for more notes

*

*

*

 

Where is there an end of it, the soundless wailing,

The silent withering of autumn flowers               

Dropping their petals and remaining motionless;

Where is there and end to the drifting wreckage,

The prayer of the bone on the beach, the unprayable

Prayer at the calamitous annunciation?

 

                  (T.S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next day, Rio tried to push her thoughts of Agatha aside. She had to focus—on her thesis, her little dance students, and the band. She couldn’t afford to get caught up in whatever was happening between them. It was complicated, and she knew it. It had to be the stress of the semester, the tension from being in Agatha’s class, and the confusion that came with seeing her outside of it.

 

But no matter how hard she tried to convince herself that she was overthinking, the truth lingered in the back of her mind, stubbornly persistent. Every glance she shared with Agatha, every soft word, every subtle moment where their hands brushed—it all added up. And now, after babysitting Nicky and the tea at Agatha’s house, it felt like something more was being hinted at, something more real.

 

She couldn’t get the image of Agatha out of her head. The way Agatha looked at her, the way she seemed to genuinely care about her. Rio had spent so long in her own head, distracted by the chaos of life, that she hadn’t let herself focus on another person in a long time. But with Agatha? It felt different. Too different.

 

She sighed, watching the band practice in the studio, trying her best to immerse herself in the music. Alice was playing her usual loud guitar riffs, Jen was adjusting the sound, and Rio’s drumsticks clicked against the cymbals in rhythm. But her mind wasn’t fully here. It never fully was these days.

 

“You’ve been zoning out a lot lately,” Alice remarked, glancing over at her after a particularly long pause between beats. “Everything okay?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio replied, her voice quieter than usual. “Just tired.”

 

Alice raised an eyebrow, clearly unconvinced. “Tired, huh? You sure it’s not something else? You’ve been acting a little… distracted. Something on your mind?”

 

Rio hesitated. She could feel Alice’s piercing gaze on her, waiting for an answer with her knowing glance as if she knew exaclty what was on her friend's mind. But Rio couldn’t say it. Couldn’t bring herself to admit that she was thinking about her professor again, the one woman she knew she shouldn’t be thinking about.

 

“It’s nothing,” Rio muttered, shifting her focus back to the drums. She knew Alice wouldn’t let it slide for long, but she didn’t feel ready to talk about it again with Alice — not yet.

 

Later, as the band wrapped up their rehearsal and they all gathered their things, Alice leaned in with a mischievous grin. “So, when are you going to tell Agatha about our next gig? Maybe she’ll actually come back.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat at the mention of Agatha’s name. She smiled, a little awkwardly. “I don’t know. She’s… busy with work and everything.”

 

“Oh, right,” Alice teased, winking. “I’m sure she’s very busy.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t hide the small blush creeping up her neck. “Stop it, Alice.”

 

That night, as Rio sat in her small apartment, trying to work on her thesis, her phone buzzed. It was a message from Lilia.

 

“How are you holding up, darling? Anything exciting happening at school?”

 

Rio smiled at the message, knowing Lilia would always be there to offer comfort and guidance. She typed back quickly, telling her about her day and the latest band rehearsal, but she kept the other thoughts hidden, tucking them away in the back of her mind.

 

She wasn’t ready to confront them just yet.

 

But as the evening wore on, the quiet buzz of her phone interrupted her thoughts once more. It was an email from Agatha.

 

“I’ve been thinking about your thesis topic. I’d like to meet sometime this week to discuss your progress and some ideas I have. Let me know when you’re available.”

 

The email was short, professional. But Rio couldn’t help the way her heart fluttered at the thought of meeting Agatha again. Her thoughts immediately went to how she had felt during their last meeting—those moments of connection, however brief, that seemed to speak volumes.

 

Get a grip, Rio thought, forcing herself to breathe deeply. She knew she had to focus on her work, not get distracted by anything else. But no matter how many times she told herself that, the pull toward Agatha was growing stronger with every passing day.

 

She hit reply, agreeing to meet Agatha in a few days, and closed her laptop. For now, all she could do was wait. And think. And hope she didn’t make a fool of herself when the time came.

 

 

The meeting was set for mid-afternoon in Agatha’s office, a quiet, serene space filled with bookshelves brimming with literary works. Agatha had asked Rio to come by so they could discuss her thesis — an academic subject, something to keep their conversation grounded. But as soon as Rio stepped into the room, the air between them felt charged in a way it hadn’t before.

 

Rio took a seat across from Agatha’s desk, her hands folded in her lap. She had dressed carefully, opting for something simple but professional—no distractions. She wasn’t sure what to expect, but she knew that whatever it was, she needed to focus.

 

“Thank you for meeting with me,” Rio said, trying to keep her tone light. “I appreciate it.”

 

Agatha nodded, offering a soft smile. “Of course. I’ve been thinking about your thesis, and I think it has great potential. »

 

And just like that, they were off, talking a subject they were both passionate about.

 

Rio nodded to very thing Agatha said, her gaze lingering on Agatha’s face as the professor spoke. She was socomposed, so sharp, her words resonating in a way Rio hadn’t expected. She hadn’t realized how much she would hang on every word Agatha spoke, how the sound of her voice seemed to sink under her skin.

 

Agatha looked up from her notes, meeting Rio’s gaze for just a moment longer than necessary. It was quick, but it was enough to send a jolt of recognition through both of them.

 

Rio felt her breath catch in her chest as Agatha leaned back slightly in her chair, still holding her gaze. “That’s a good place to start,” Agatha continued. “But perhaps you could explore how death shows up in their writing, both directly and through omission. The presence of Death, and the absence of Death, their duality. How they mingle together to become one.”

 

Rio swallowed hard, nodding quickly. She was trying to concentrate, to listen, but the way Agatha’s words seemed to echo in her mind… it was hard to keep her thoughts in line.

 

“Right. Of course,” she said, barely managing to keep her voice steady. She pulled out her notes, trying to hide the sudden heat rising in her cheeks. “I’ll look into that. Thanks, Dr. Harkeness.”

 

“Agatha.” The single word hung in the air, making Rio’s pulse spike. Agatha had said it so casually, but something about the way it sounded—so familiar—felt like a subtle invitation.

 

Rio’s throat went dry as she glanced up at Agatha, who was still watching her with an expression that was both professional and something else—something that Rio couldn’t quite place. It felt as though they were standing on the edge of something unspoken, something precariously close to crossing a line neither of them had been ready to acknowledge.

 

“Thank you, Agatha,” Rio finally managed to say. She had to break the silence before she completely lost herself in the moment.

 

Agatha nodded, her lips curling into a tight smile. “No problem. I’m looking forward to seeing where you take this.”

 

Rio stood up, gathering her notes, but the moment felt charged in a way it hadn’t before. Agatha’s presence was a weight in the room, and Rio couldn’t help but notice how close they were, how Agatha’s gaze lingered just a second longer than necessary.

 

“Let me know if you need any further guidance on your direction,” Agatha said as Rio moved toward the door. “I’m happy to help.”

 

“Of course,” Rio responded, though her voice was quieter now, tinged with something she couldn’t quite explain. “See you later… Agatha.” As she stepped into the hallway, she felt the weight of Agatha’s gaze on her back, and she couldn’t shake the feeling that something had changed between them.

 

As the door clicked shut behind her, Rio’s heart raced in her chest. What was that? She couldn’t stop herself from thinking about Agatha, about the way their conversation had unfolded, and how hard it was to separate the professional from something much more personal.

 

She couldn’t be sure what this was—whether it was just academic admiration or something else entirely. But one thing was clear: whatever it was, it was only getting more complicated.

 

 

That evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the weight of the day pressed heavily on her chest, Rio grabbed her phone and dialed Lilia’s number. The warmth of Lilia’s voice answered almost immediately, and the familiar sound brought a small measure of relief.

 

“Rio! How’s my girl?” Lilia greeted cheerfully.

 

“Hey, Lilia,” Rio said, trying to keep her voice light, though she suspected Lilia would sense the undertone of unease anyway. “I was wondering… is it okay if I come over for dinner tonight?”

 

There was a pause, and Rio could almost see Lilia tilting her head in curiosity. “Of course, sweetheart. You don’t even have to ask. Everything okay?”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, her hand tightening around her phone. “Yeah,” she said quickly, forcing a small laugh. “I just… need some good company, you know? And your cooking.”

 

Lilia didn’t press further, though Rio could tell she was tempted. “Well, you’re in luck. I made too much arroz con pollo, just like the one you like, and I was just thinking it’d be nice to share it. Come on over whenever you’re ready.”

 

“Thanks, Lilia. I’ll be there soon,” Rio said, her shoulders relaxing slightly as she hung up.

 

When she arrived, the cozy scent of spices and home cooked food greeted her as Lilia opened the door. She was wearing her usual warm smile, her apron dusted with flour from what Rio suspected was an earlier baking experiment.

 

“Come on in,” Lilia said, ushering Rio inside. “You look like you’ve had a day. Sit down, I’ll fix you a plate.”

 

Rio let herself be led to the small kitchen table, where she sat and watched Lilia bustle around, humming softly. It was a kind of comfort she hadn’t realized she’d been craving—Lilia’s house, with its slightly mismatched furniture, walls lined with family photos, and the gentle hum of life in every corner, always felt like a refuge.

 

“So,” Lilia said as she set down a steaming plate of food in front of Rio, “what’s on your mind, sweet girl? You don’t have to tell me everything, but I know something’s eating at you.”

 

Rio hesitated, swirling her fork through the rice. “It’s nothing, really. Just… school stuff. My thesis. You know how it is.”

 

Lilia raised an eyebrow but didn’t push. “School stuff, huh? Well, whatever it is, you’ll figure it out. You always do. And if you need me to set anyone straight…” She gave a playful grin, her tone teasing but her protective streak unmistakable.

 

Rio managed a small laugh. “I’ll let you know.”

 

As they ate, the conversation drifted to lighter topics—old stories, updates on Lilia’s neighbors, and the latest antics of her cat. For a little while, Rio let herself get lost in the normalcy, the safety of this space.

 

When dinner was over, Lilia brought out a slice of peach cobbler for dessert, insisting that Rio couldn’t leave without something sweet.

 

“Gracias, Lilia,” Rio said softly, as she scraped the last bite from her plate.

 

“Anytime, my love,” Lilia replied, reaching across the table to squeeze her hand.

 

By the time Rio left, the knot of tension in her chest had loosened just enough to breathe. She didn’t have all the answers, but for tonight, that was okay.

 

 

The next morning, Rio arrived at the dance center just as the sunlight began filtering through the studio’s large windows, casting warm, golden rays across the polished wooden floor. It was her favorite time of the week: ballet class with the little ones. Their energy, curiosity, and occasional silliness were infectious, and teaching them always felt like a reset button for her chaotic mind.

 

As she tied her hair into a neat bun, a group of tiny voices echoed down the hallway, growing louder as the kids approached. They burst into the room like a bundle of giggles and excitement, their little ballet shoes tapping against the floor.

 

As the children filed into the studio, Rio noticed a familiar, dark-haired boy trailing slightly behind the others. Nicky, Agatha’s son, clutched his small dance bag and looked around the room with wide eyes before spotting Rio. His face immediately lit up, and he waved enthusiastically.

 

“Hi, Miss Rio!”

 

“Hi, Nicky,” Rio replied warmly, kneeling to greet him. “Ready for class?”

 

He nodded vigorously. “I practiced my pliés with Mama last night!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but smile at the image of Agatha Harkness, poised and composed in her academic world, crouching in a living room to help her son with ballet. “Well, let’s see how much you’ve improved, superstar.”

 

 The other kids were also quick to demand her attention, as always.

 

“Miss Rio! Miss Rio!” a little girl called, tugging at her leg. “I also practiced my pliés at home! And my jumps”

 

“Did you?” Rio crouched down to her level, smiling as the child demonstrated. “Very nice, but remember, knees out, okay? Like this.” She showed the proper form, and the child nodded earnestly.

 

“Miss Rio, I got new shoes!” another chimed in, proudly lifting a pink slippered foot.

 

“They’re beautiful,” Rio said warmly, standing up and clapping her hands to get their attention. “Alright, everyone, to the barre! Let’s warm up.”

 

The class began with stretches and basic movements. Rio moved through the rows, gently correcting postures and offering encouragement. The children followed her lead, some with improving form, others with wobbly determination.

 

One of the younger ones, a shy girl named Sophie, struggled with her balance during a little dégagé. She frowned, her small brows furrowed in frustration.

 

“Don’t worry, Sophie,” Rio said, kneeling beside her. “Even the best dancers fall sometimes. Let’s try it together, okay?” She held Sophie’s hand and guided her through the motion, earning a timid but triumphant smile.

 

Rio kept an eye on Nicky the whole time. He was clearly trying hard to focus, his little brow furrowing with determination as he copied her movements. He wasn’t the most coordinated dancer, but his enthusiasm made up for it.

 

During tendus, he wobbled a bit too far and stumbled, landing on his bottom with a small “oof.”

 

“Oh no! Are you okay?” Rio asked, hurrying over.

 

Nicky nodded, his cheeks turning pink. “I’m okay. Falling’s part of the learning, right?”

 

Rio’s heart melted at his resilience. “That’s exactly right. You’re a quick learner.” She extended a hand to help him up.

 

“Thanks, Miss Rio,” he said, brushing off his pants and hopping back into line.

 

As the class progressed, the room filled with laughter and tiny triumphs. By the end, the kids were buzzing with excitement, proudly showing off their progress to each other.

 

“Alright, everyone,” Rio announced as the class wrapped up, “you did amazing today! Give yourselves a big round of applause!”

 

The children clapped enthusiastically, and as they gathered their belongings, a few lingered to hug Rio goodbye.

 

As the children began trickling out with their parents, Nicky lingered near her.

 

“Miss Rio?”

 

“Yes, Nicky?”

 

“Do you think Mama will come to the next recital?” His voice was soft, uncertain.

 

Rio crouched to his level, her smile reassuring. “I’m sure she will. She’s really proud of you, you know.”

 

Nicky beamed at her answer, his small chest puffing up. “Okay. I’ll practice extra hard!”

 

He waved goodbye as his sitter arrived to pick him up, leaving Rio alone in the now-empty studio. She chuckled to herself as she gathered her things, the image of Nicky’s determined little face warming her heart.

 

Rio sighed contentedly, leaning against the barre. Despite everything swirling in her life, these classes grounded her in a way nothing else could.

 

She turned off the studio lights and grabbed her bag, heading toward the lobby. Another class was about to begin, but for her, the rest of the day lay ahead—a mix of research, writing, and, undoubtedly, thoughts of her professor sneaking into her mind when she least expected it.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

What you're all waiting for is getting closer and closer...

This Stops Now

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

There is the final addition, the failing

Pride or resentment at failing powers,

The unattached devotion which might pass for devotionless,

In a drifting boat with a slow leakage,

The silent listening to the undeniable

Clamour of the bell of the last annunciation.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot; “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

That night, as exhaustion overtook her, Agatha fell into a restless sleep. The weight of the day seemed to blur as her subconscious took over, and soon she found herself in a dream that felt too vivid, too real.

 

She was back at the recital, seated in the front row. The stage lights were warm and golden, casting long, dramatic shadows. The children had just finished their performance, and applause echoed in the room. Agatha’s gaze was fixed on the wings, where Rio stood, guiding the children offstage with her usual grace and patience.

 

Then, unexpectedly, Rio stepped forward onto the stage. The audience faded into a distant hum as Rio began to dance. It wasn’t like the ballet performances Agatha had grown accustomed to seeing Nicky attempt—it was something more raw, more expressive. Her movements were fluid, deliberate, and magnetic.

 

Agatha couldn’t look away. There was something intoxicating about the way Rio moved, the way she seemed to pour herself into every step, every twist of her body, leaving Agatha’s chest tight with an unfamiliar longing.

 

Rio turned her head mid-spin, her gaze locking with Agatha’s in the crowd. Her expression was unreadable, but her eyes burned with intensity. Agatha felt as though she were being drawn in, the distance between them shrinking without either of them moving.

 

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, though her lips hadn’t moved.

 

The sound of her name in Rio’s voice reverberated in Agatha’s mind, sending a thrill down her spine. The spotlight seemed to dim, leaving only the two of them bathed in a soft, ethereal glow.

 

Rio stepped closer, her hand reaching out as if to touch Agatha’s cheek—

 

Agatha woke with a start, her breath catching in her throat. The room was dark and silent, the dream still clinging to her like a second skin. She ran a hand through her hair, her heart racing as the images replayed in her mind.

 

“This is ridiculous,” she muttered under her breath, but the flush in her cheeks and the lingering ache in her chest betrayed her words.

 

She lay back down, staring at the ceiling, unable to shake the dream.

 

Agatha sighed as she swung her legs over the edge of the bed, the dream’s vivid remnants still clinging to her like static. Sleep was clearly a lost cause. She padded softly down the hallway, her bare feet cool against the floorboards.

 

She peeked into Nicky’s room, her heart softening at the sight of him curled up in his bed, one hand clutching his stuffed dinosaur. The steady rhythm of his breathing brought her some comfort, grounding her in the quiet normalcy of the moment.

 

“Sweet dreams, love,” she whispered, brushing a stray curl from his forehead before quietly pulling the door closed.

 

Back in her study, she switched on the lamp, the warm glow spilling over her desk. A stack of essays loomed in front of her—an ever-present reminder of her responsibilities. “Might as well make use of this insomnia,” she muttered, settling into her chair and picking up the top paper.

 

She froze when her eyes landed on the name typed neatly at the top: Rio Vidal.

 

“Of course,” she murmured, a dry laugh escaping her lips. It was almost comical how the universe seemed intent on putting Rio at the forefront of her mind tonight.

 

Agatha exhaled and began to read. As usual, Rio’s work was exemplary—sharp, insightful, and brimming with passion. Her analysis of the pervasive shadow of trauma and silenced voices in poetry was hauntingly beautiful, her voice confident yet tinged with a vulnerability that struck a chord in Agatha.

 

She found herself lingering over certain phrases, rereading them not just for their academic merit but for the glimpses they offered into Rio’s mind. There was a rawness in her writing, a deep understanding of grief and mortality that felt almost too personal.

 

“Brilliant,” Agatha murmured, making a note in the margin. Her pen hesitated for a moment before she added, “Your insights continue to impress, Miss Vidal. Your voice is one of a kind.”

 

As she set the paper aside, Agatha leaned back in her chair, rubbing her temples. The dream, the paper, the lingering emotions—all of it swirled together in her chest, refusing to settle.

 

“I need to get a grip,” she muttered, standing and heading for the kitchen to make herself some tea. But as she waited for the kettle to boil, her thoughts drifted back to Rio, to the way her eyes sparkled when she spoke of her thesis, the quiet confidence in her demeanor, the graceful way she moved both in and out of the classroom.

 

Agatha shook her head, trying to dismiss the warmth spreading through her. It’s just fascination, she told herself. Pure admiration for a bright student. Nothing more.

 

But the whisper of doubt in the back of her mind suggested otherwise.

 

Agatha pressed her palms flat against the countertop, the cool surface grounding her as the kettle began to whistle. She moved mechanically, pouring the boiling water over a tea bag, letting the steam rise and swirl around her. But the ritual didn’t calm her tonight.

 

In the back of her mind, she knew it wasn’t just fascination or admiration. It was something more. Something she didn’t want to name, didn’t dare to name.

 

She took a sip of tea, the heat sliding down her throat, but it didn’t burn away the truth that had been quietly building.

 

Rio had awakened something in her—something Agatha hadn’t felt in years.

 

Her fascination had turned into a kind of preoccupation. The moments they spent together, whether in the formal confines of her office or the fleeting encounters outside class, lingered far longer than they should have. The memory of Rio curled up on her couch, reading and waiting for her to come home, felt oddly intimate in a way that kept her awake at night.

 

And the way her heart had fluttered when Rio called her Agatha, the way she’d agreed to it so easily, as though it were natural—too natural.

 

“This is dangerous,” Agatha whispered into the stillness, her tea forgotten in her hands.

 

She wasn’t naïve. She knew the risks of crossing certain lines, and she had no intention of doing so. But no matter how firmly she told herself this, her thoughts betrayed her, replaying stolen glances and quiet moments between them.

 

The sound of the clock ticking in the corner brought her back to the present. Agatha set the mug down with a soft thud, her resolve hardening.

 

“This needs to stop,” she said to herself, her tone firmer this time.

 

She would focus on being Rio’s professor, her mentor, her guide. Nothing more. Because allowing it to be more—allowing herself to acknowledge the feelings she didn’t want to name—would jeopardize everything.

 

And yet, as she moved to turn off the kitchen light, the image of Rio’s smile lingered, a soft glow she couldn’t quite extinguish. She shook her head, forcing her head to quiet down.

 

As she settled back in bed, a new wave of determination washing through her.

 

This ended now.

 

 

Agatha stepped into the classroom with her usual confidence, the steady click of her heels punctuating the quiet hum of pre-class chatter. She reminded herself of her resolve: today, she would be the model of professionalism, nothing more.

 

She wouldn’t indulge the wayward thoughts that had been creeping into her mind or the subtle pull she felt toward Rio Vidal. This was her domain—a space of intellect and discipline. Emotions had no place here.

 

“Good morning,” she greeted the class with a brisk nod, setting her leather-bound notebook on the desk. Her gaze swept across the room, briefly settling on Rio before moving on. It took every ounce of her willpower not to linger. Rio looked tired but focused, her pen already poised for notes.

 

The seminar began smoothly, with Agatha launching into an analysis of E. E. Cummings’ Tulips and Chimneys. She kept her tone measured and her interactions strictly academic. No stray glances, no warm smiles. Just her lecture and the occasional question to the group.

 

But as the minutes ticked by, the detachment felt wrong. It wasn’t her.

 

When Rio raised her hand to contribute, Agatha almost hesitated before nodding and calling on her. “Miss Vidal,” she said, her voice carefully neutral her tone sharp.

 

Rio faltered briefly but pressed on. Her response was thoughtful, weaving in an analysis of the aesthetic of fragmentation as occupying both the positive and negative space of the page in Cummings’ work. Her insight was sharp, her delivery impassioned, and for a moment, Agatha’s resolve faltered. She could feel the class watching Rio with admiration, but Agatha’s own reaction went deeper. She had always respected her student’s intellect, but now it felt like a tug she couldn’t ignore.

 

“That’s an interesting interpretation,” Agatha replied, her voice cool. “Though it seems to lack sufficient textual evidence. Your argument could benefit from more grounding in the poem’s language.”

 

Rio’s eyes flickered with a mix of confusion and hurt, but she nodded politely and sank back into her seat.

 

Agatha hated herself instantly. It wasn’t that Rio’s point lacked merit—if anything, it had been one of the most insightful contributions of the session so far. But Agatha couldn’t let herself soften, couldn’t risk slipping into familiar ease.

 

The rest of the class passed in a blur of stilted discussion. Agatha kept her tone impersonal, her interactions brisk. When another student repeated an idea Rio had already presented, Agatha praised them without acknowledging Rio’s earlier contribution.

 

By the end of the hour, a palpable tension hung in the air. Agatha dismissed the class without so much as a glance in Rio’s direction.

 

As the students packed up, Rio lingered at her desk, organizing her notes with deliberate slowness. Agatha felt the weight of her presence but didn’t look up.

 

“Have a good day, Professor,” Rio said softly as she passed the desk.

 

Agatha only managed a nod, her throat too tight to form words.

 

When the door closed behind Rio, Agatha slumped in her chair, head in her hands. Her attempt at professionalism had crossed into coldness, and she’d taken it out on the one student who didn’t deserve it.

 

It wasn’t supposed to feel like this. It wasn’t supposed to hurt.

 

 

Rio felt the shift the moment Agatha walked into the classroom that day. The usual warmth, subtle and steady like a low-burning ember, had been replaced by something distant and cold. It wasn’t overt, but it didn’t need to be—Rio had always been finely attuned to the way people carried themselves, and today, Agatha seemed different.

 

At first, Rio told herself she was imagining it. Agatha Harkness wasn’t known for being overtly warm, especially in a professional setting. But the curt tone, the sharp responses, the lack of acknowledgment—those were new, and they stung more than she wanted to admit.

 

By the time the seminar ended, Rio’s chest felt heavy with a mix of confusion and unease. She replayed the class in her mind as she walked back to her apartment. Had she said something wrong? Did her analysis truly lack evidence, or was Agatha simply having a bad day?

 

Her stomach churned with the thought that it might be something else entirely.

 

Maybe she regrets letting things get so casual.

 

That possibility gnawed at her more than it should have. Rio had always been careful, even when her feelings for Agatha had started to grow beyond admiration. She’d kept her tone neutral during office hours, avoided lingering too long after class—she’d done everything to stay professional.

 

And yet, here she was, fretting over what felt like a rejection.

 

By the time she reached her building, Rio was exhausted—not from the walk, but from the emotional weight she’d been carrying all day. She slumped onto her couch, staring at the ceiling, willing herself to stop overthinking.

 

But the truth was, it hurt.

 

Not just because Agatha had been cold, but because Rio had begun to hope—against all reason—that maybe there was something more.

 

And today had felt like the sharp closing of a door she hadn’t even realized she’d been standing in front of.

 

 

That evening, Agatha sat at the kitchen table with a glass of wine in one hand and a pile of essays in front of her. She hadn’t been able to focus all day, and her thoughts kept returning to Rio.

 

Her decision to be strictly professional had seemed logical—necessary, even. But the way Rio’s face had fallen during class… Her thoughts kept circling back to the day’s class and the way Rio’s shoulders had seemed a little more slumped, her voice a little quieter. It hadn’t been her intention to be cruel. Agatha had merely wanted to create distance, to remind them both of their boundaries. Agatha had told herself that being professional was the right thing to do—for both of them. But the cold distance she’d forced between them had felt wrong in every possible way.

 

Instead, it seemed she’d only succeeded in hurting Rio, and the knowledge sat like a lead weight in her chest.

 

Her brooding was interrupted when Nicky shuffled into the kitchen in his dinosaur pajamas, holding a stuffed dragon under one arm.

 

“Mommy?” he said softly, hugging the dragon close.

 

“Yes, sweetheart?” Agatha forced herself to smile at him, though her chest felt tight.

 

“Do you think dance class made Miss Rio sad today?” he asked, his little brow furrowed.

 

The question struck her like a blow. She blinked, caught off guard. “What makes you think she was sad?”

 

Nicky looked down at his dragon, fiddling with its tail. “She didn’t smile as much. And when she did, it wasn’t the same. Like…” He searched for the right words. “Like her heart wasn’t happy.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard, guilt twisting in her stomach.

 

“Maybe…” Nicky continued, “she didn’t like dance today?”

 

The innocence of his question made Agatha’s heart ache. “Oh, sweetheart,” she murmured, pulling him into her lap. She pressed a kiss to his head, inhaling the comforting scent of his shampoo.

 

Dance class hadn’t made Rio sad. Agatha had.

 

Nicky nestled against her, still holding his dragon. “I like Miss Rio,” he said sleepily. “She’s the best teacher.”

 

“I know you do,” Agatha replied softly, stroking his hair. “She’s wonderful.”

 

And I hurt her today, she thought.

 

Agatha sighed, pressing a kiss to Nicky’s temple. “Thank you for telling me, sweetheart.”

 

As she tucked Nicky into bed later that night, his innocent question lingered in her mind. She had tried to protect herself, to create boundaries, but all she had done was make someone she cared about feel small.

 

Agatha sat on the edge of Nicky’s bed, watching his little chest rise and fall in sleep. She resolved to fix things—to apologize, somehow.

 

But more than that, she resolved to stop running from the truth that had been building quietly in her heart: she cared about Rio. Perhaps too much. But pretending otherwise wasn’t an option anymore. At some point, honesty would be necessary.

 

 

The next morning, Agatha stopped by the local café near campus for her usual coffee. She had been up most of the night, alternating between grading papers and trying to suppress the growing guilt over her behavior toward Rio.

 

She was stirring her coffee absentmindedly when a familiar voice broke through her thoughts.

 

“Dr. Harkness?”

 

Agatha looked up to see Lilia standing a few feet away, balancing a tray of pastries and a cup of tea. She was as composed as Agatha remembered from their first meeting, her warm smile slightly disarming.

 

“Lilia,” Agatha said, straightening in her seat. “What a surprise.”

 

Lilia chuckled. “Small world, isn’t it? Mind if I join you for a moment?”

 

Agatha gestured to the seat across from her. “Not at all.”

 

As Lilia settled into the chair, Agatha found herself studying the older woman, remembering the protective, almost maternal energy she’d radiated the night Rio had been drunk. It was clear she cared deeply for Rio. They talked about everything and anything for a bit.

 

“Speaking about work, how’s my Rio doing?” Lilia asked casually as she sipped her tea.

 

Agatha hesitated, her guilt flaring again. “She’s been quiet in class lately,” she admitted, trying to keep her tone neutral.

 

Lilia frowned, setting down her cup. “I’ve noticed the same thing. She’s been… off. I can’t put my finger on it. She didn’t even say much when she came over for dinner the other night, and that’s not like her.”

 

Agatha felt a pang in her chest. “Did she say why?”

 

Lilia shook her head. “No, and I didn’t want to push. But something’s weighing on her, I can tell. She’s good at hiding it, but not from me.” She gave Agatha a pointed look, as if trying to gauge her reaction.

 

Agatha managed a small nod, her mind racing. She couldn’t help but wonder how much of Rio’s mood was because of her.

 

“Rio’s resilient, though,” Lilia continued, her voice tinged with pride. “She’s been through a lot, but she always finds her way back. Still, I worry. She doesn’t let many people in, you know?”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened. She wanted to ask more, to understand what Lilia meant, but she knew it wasn’t her place.

 

Instead, she offered a quiet, “I’ll keep an eye on her.”

 

Lilia smiled, but her gaze lingered on Agatha, as though she was trying to decipher something unspoken. “I’m glad Rio has someone like you in her corner,” she said finally.

 

Agatha forced a polite smile, her guilt growing tenfold, but as Lilia left, her words hung heavy in the air.

 

Someone like me? Agatha thought bitterly. All I’ve done is push her away.

 

She finished her coffee, but the bitterness on her tongue had little to do with the drink. If Lilia, someone who clearly knew Rio inside and out, was worried, then perhaps Agatha needed to stop pretending she could keep her distance.

 

 

Rio spent the afternoon in the dance center, her favorite escape from the spiraling weight of her thoughts. The rhythmic thud of the piano keys and the soft shuffling of the children’s feet as they practiced their steps filled the room with a soothing energy. But despite her best efforts to focus, a part of her mind remained snagged on the coldness that had seeped into Dr. Harkness’s demeanor.

 

As the kids left class, waving excitedly and chattering about their next recital, Rio leaned against the barre, exhaling slowly.

 

Snap out of it, Vidal, she scolded herself silently. She had promised herself she wouldn’t let this situation drag her down further. Yet, no matter how many times she told herself it didn’t matter—that Agatha’s distant behavior was probably just a fluke—it still hurt.

 

And it stung even more to realize how much she wanted Agatha’s approval.

 

“Miss Rio?”

 

She looked up to see Nicky standing at the door, his tiny dance bag slung over his shoulder. He hesitated, then padded over to her.

 

“What’s up, buddy?” she asked, crouching down to his level.

 

He wrung his hands. “Are you sad?”

 

Rio blinked, startled. “What makes you say that?”

 

“You look sad,” he said simply, his wide, earnest eyes searching her face. “Mama says people shouldn’t hide their feelings.”

 

Rio smiled faintly, her heart softening. “I’m okay, Nicky. Just had a lot on my mind. But thank you for asking—that’s very sweet of you.”

 

The boy grinned, clearly satisfied with her answer. “Okay. I’ll tell Mama you’re not sad anymore.”

 

Her stomach twisted at the mention of Agatha, she didn’t think she would have been a subject of conversation between mother and son, but she quickly pushed it aside. “That sounds like a plan. Now, scoot—your mom’s probably waiting.”

 

As Nicky bounded out of the studio, Rio straightened and grabbed her bag. She was determined to shake this off, even if it meant faking it until she made it. She couldn’t let her feelings for Agatha—whatever they were—consume her.

 

She pulled out her phone and texted Alice: Are you free tonight? I need a distraction.

 

Alice’s response was almost immediate: Always. Bring wine.

 

Rio smiled, tucking her phone away. She would push forward, even if it was easier said than done. Because the alternative—letting this spiral of confusion and rejection take over—wasn’t an option.

 

Rio arrived at Alice’s apartment a little while later, carrying two bottles of wine, the weight of the glass offering her some small sense of stability. She knocked on the door, and within seconds, it swung open to reveal Alice, already grinning in anticipation.

 

“You’re here! I’ve got the perfect spot on the couch ready,” Alice said with a wink, pulling her inside. “What’s the deal, huh? You’ve been texting me like a fiend all day, and now you’re bringing more wine than I thought you would. Sounds like a serious mood to me.”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “It’s complicated. I think I’ve made everything more complicated than it needs to be.”

 

Alice led her to the couch and grabbed a corkscrew, uncorking one of the bottles and pouring them each a glass. “Complicated sounds like a special kind of disaster. Spill.”

 

Rio took a sip of the wine, savoring the warmth as it slid down her throat. She hesitated, unsure where to start. “It’s about Agatha.”

 

Alice raised an eyebrow, leaning back against the arm of the couch. “Ahh, of course. I should’ve known. You’ve been out of sorts for weeks now. What happened?”

 

Rio set her glass down on the coffee table, her fingers fidgeting around the base. “I don’t know… she’s been distant. Like, really distant. It's been a few days an I haven’t been able to shake it off. I don’t even know if she cares about me outside of being her student.”

 

Alice tilted her head. “What makes you think she doesn’t care? Because she’s been a little colder in class?”

 

Rio nodded. “Yeah, and I’ve tried to give her space, but I feel it, Alice. It’s like… she’s pulling away. And it hurts, especially because I don’t know why. I thought… I thought there was something there before, you know?”

 

Alice sipped her wine thoughtfully, tapping the side of her glass. “Maybe it’s more complicated for her than it is for you? Like, maybe she’s trying to keep it professional and she doesn’t know how to handle whatever this is.”

 

“I don’t know,” Rio murmured. “She’s been so cold. It feels like she doesn’t even want to look at me, like she’s… regretting everything. Don’t get me wrong, there is nothing to regret, nothing happened. I just want things to go back to normal.”

 

Alice gave her a knowing look. “But you don’t want them to be normal, do you? You’re craving something else—something more.”

 

Rio froze, meeting her friend’s gaze. She didn’t even have to say it out loud. Alice always understood.

 

“I don’t know what I’m supposed to do with this,” Rio admitted quietly, her voice almost a whisper. “I’m not sure if I want to forget about it or… make it work somehow.”

 

Alice placed a hand on Rio’s shoulder. “Rio, look. I know it’s messy, but what you feel is real. And the fact that Agatha is so complicated about it only makes it more real, you know?”

 

Rio let out a long breath. “But what if it’s just my imagination? What if I’m reading too much into everything and making things worse than they are?”

 

“Then we’ll deal with that when it happens,” Alice said with a grin. “But until then, we’re drinking wine and making bad decisions tonight.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh. Alice was always the right kind of distraction when things got too heavy.

 

“Bad decisions sound good right about now,” Rio said, leaning back into the couch, her fingers tapping the side of her glass. “I just need to figure out what to do next.”

 

Alice raised her glass with a smirk. “One step at a time, my friend. And for now, that step is enjoying this wine and getting out of your head for a little while.”

 

Rio nodded, taking another sip, feeling the wine beginning to work its magic. Maybe she wasn’t going to solve everything tonight, but at least for now, she didn’t have to think about it.

 

 

Rio woke with a groan, the familiar dull throb of a hangover quickly reminding her of last night’s excess. She blinked, squinting at the clock on the wall. Her heart skipped a beat. 8:15. She was late for class.

 

She shot up from the couch, her limbs stiff and heavy, the remnants of her wine-induced haze still clouding her thoughts. Alice was still asleep, sprawled on the opposite side of the couch, a blanket tangled around her legs. Rio didn’t have time to be quiet. She threw off the pajamas Alice had leant her and threw on the nearest clothes, the same outfit she’d worn the night before—now crinkled and slightly disheveled from the spontaneous couch nap.

 

Panic set in as she rushed to grab her bag and dashed out the door.

 

By the time Rio entered the lecture hall, she was out of breath, her face flushed from the rush. She hadn’t even had a chance to check herself in the mirror, but she knew she looked disheveled. Her hair was wild, her shirt wrinkled, and her eyes were slightly bloodshot from both the alcohol and lack of sleep.

 

And then, of course, her gaze met Agatha’s.

 

She tried to shake off the sudden wave of anxiety, but Agatha’s expression was unmistakable. It was brief, almost imperceptible, but Rio could tell. There was something in the way Agatha’s gaze lingered on her for just a moment too long.

 

She noticed.

 

Rio’s heart sank. She felt a sudden pang of self-consciousness. Was it the way she looked? Agatha wasn’t exactly the type to comment on appearances, but Rio could tell something was bothering her. As she made her way to her seat, she tried to shake it off, but she couldn’t stop the thought from nagging at her—Agatha must think I was with someone else last night.

 

Her mind raced as she sat down, her heart still pounding. She was late, and worse, her professor was clearly looking at her. It wasn’t just a glance—it was a stare, a subtle flicker of something unreadable.

 

But Agatha did nothing to acknowledge it. She was all business as usual. She began the lecture, her tone detached, professional, and steady, but Rio could swear there was a new coldness to it today. Was it just her, or had Agatha’s demeanor shifted yet again?

 

Meanwhile, Agatha was having her own internal battle. Seeing Rio so disheveled, so unpolished as she entered the room stirred something deep within her. She didn’t know why it bothered her so much. Maybe it was the fact that Rio had spent the night out, and it wasn’t with her. Agatha couldn’t help but feel an unexpected jealousy gnaw at her.

 

She watched Rio settle into her seat, trying to act casual, but Agatha couldn’t shake the feeling that something had changed. What did that mean? she wondered, but quickly pushed the thought aside, focusing on the lecture.

 

She told herself not to think too much into it. Rio is her student. That was it. No more, no less. Agatha couldn’t afford to feel any other way about her—especially not jealousy.

 

But despite her best efforts to push it away, the thought lingered, as did the nagging delicious unease that now seemed to follow her whenever Rio was around.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

Don't hate me, it's for the plot. 💜💚

One Moment In Time

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

Love is itself unmoving,

Only the cause and end of movement,

Timeless, and undesiring

Except in the aspect of time

Caught in the form of limitation

Between un-being and being.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

As Agatha walked across campus, her mind still slightly distracted by the morning’s lecture and her complicated thoughts about Rio, something caught her eye—a brightly colored flier pinned to a bulletin board. It was hard to miss, the bold letters and striking design almost daring anyone to glance at it.

 

“Three of Swords – Live Friday Night!”

 

Her gaze lingered on the flier. The band’s name jumped out at her. Three of Swords. She felt a flicker of recognition. Rio’s band, of course. She remembered the energy of the night, Rio on stage, the rawness of the music filling the air, and the way Rio had looked when she’d caught her eye in the crowd. She couldn’t help but feel a slight shift in her chest at the memory.

 

The date for the gig was this Friday night. It was almost strange to see it in print, as if a reminder had slipped its way into her consciousness. The last time had been unexpected and she had been invited. This time, however, Agatha couldn’t help but wonder if she should go again. There had been something about the way Rio had performed, something that lingered with her long after the night had ended. But had promised herself to distance herself, to put an end to what could very easily into dangerous territory.

 

Her phone buzzed, breaking her out of her thoughts. She quickly glanced at it but couldn’t quite shake the feeling that she was being drawn to the idea of going again. It had been a spontaneous choice the first time, but now there was that pull again—a curiosity, yes, but something more.

 

Maybe it was the way Rio had looked at her then. Or the way Agatha had found herself looking at Rio. She couldn’t exactly pinpoint it, but there was something unresolved. Agatha knew she should keep her distance, that she couldn’t get more involved than she already was.

 

Maybe just one more time, and then never again—she told herself. But deep down, she already knew that it wouldn’t be just one more time.

 

She tucked the flier into her bag, her fingers lingering on it for just a moment longer than necessary.

 

She just couldn’t stay away.

 

 

The night had finally arrived. The low hum of anticipation buzzed in the air, the kind of energy that could only come before a live performance. The band members, already backstage, could feel the familiar mix of excitement and nerves knotting their stomachs as they prepared for their set.

 

Rio stood with her back to the wall, eyes closed, trying to center herself. She could hear Alice and Jen chatting and warming up nearby, but her mind was elsewhere. She had spent the whole day pushing the thought of Agatha’s rejection out of her head, but now, as the night approached, the reminder of her professor’s absence loomed. Agatha had come to the last performance because she had invited her, and Rio had caught glimpses of her in the crowd, but now—tonight—there was an unfamiliar weight in her chest. She couldn’t stop thinking about what it would mean if Agatha showed up again. She didn’t think she would, considering the way things were between them at the moment, and she hadn’t invited her. But still, she couldn’t help but hope.

 

Just focus on the music, she told herself, though the mantra wasn’t as soothing as it usually was. She took a deep breath, trying to focus on the drumsticks in her hands, tapping them against the side of her leg rhythmically, trying to find the steady beat.

 

Alice noticed her distant expression and smirked. “Nervous about something besides the performance?” she teased, nudging Rio with her elbow.

 

Jen laughed from across the room, strumming a few chords on her guitar. “Oh, we know what’s going on. You’re still thinking about the professor, aren’t you?”

 

Jen didn’t know the whole thing but has noticed the admiration Rio had for her supervisor and had joined in on the teasing.

 

Rio shot them both a look of mock annoyance, but deep down, she knew they were right. The memory of Agatha’s cool demeanor, her gaze that lingered just a bit too long at the last gig, made her stomach twist with something far more complicated than just nerves.

 

“Can we not talk about her right now?” Rio muttered, though a blush crept up her neck, betraying her. “Let’s just focus on the show. That’s the only thing that matters tonight.”

 

“Right, right,” Alice said with a wink, although she couldn’t completely hide her grin. “You got it, Rio. Just… try not to blush too much if she shows up, okay?”

 

Before Rio could respond that she wouldn’t, the manager poked his head into the room, giving them the signal that they were about to go on.

 

“Five minutes, people!” he called.

 

With a collective breath, the band stood up from their seats and gathered around their instruments. Rio adjusted her drum kit, checking the tuning of everything. The music was what she loved—what she had always loved—but there was something about the weight of tonight that made it different.

 

The chatter from the crowd outside the venue grew louder, the anticipation swelling with every passing moment. The lights dimmed, and the opening song was cued.

 

“Alright,” Rio muttered under her breath. “Let’s do this.”

 

And with that, she walked onto the stage, her heart pounding—but this time, she wasn’t sure if it was just the music she was nervous about.

 

The first chords rang out, the energy of the crowd hit her, and the band was in motion. Rio settled into the rhythm, her focus shifting to the sound of her drumsticks striking the skins. She was back in the music, no longer thinking about anything else. Or at least, she tried not to.

 

But as the performance continued, there was one thing Rio couldn’t ignore.

 

In the back of the crowd, a familiar face watched her from the shadows. Against all odds, Agatha was there.

 

 

Agatha stood at the back of the crowd, her eyes fixed on the stage, watching Rio with a fascination that she couldn’t quite shake off. The way Rio moved, the energy she exuded—there was something captivating about her. It wasn’t just the raw power of the music or the way she hit the drums with such intensity. It was the way she seemed completely absorbed, lost in the rhythm, and how her focus seemed to pull Agatha in, making everything else blur into the background.

 

Here, on stage, the young woman was so unapologetically herself. The way Rio’s eyes sparkled with passion, the way she leaned into the music—it was like watching someone come alive in front of her eyes, and Agatha couldn’t look away.

 

As Agatha watched Rio, she noticed everything about her in a way she hadn’t before. The way her hair framed her face—wild and untamed in the best possible way—made her look so effortlessly beautiful. The way her hands remained graceful, despite the force of her movements, the way her eyes sparkled with the thrill of the music—it all made Agatha’s pulse quicken, her thoughts straying to places she hadn’t wanted to go.

 

Rio’s outfit, simple yet striking, seemed to add to her charm. It wasn’t flashy, but it suited her perfectly, the kind of casual attire that somehow made her look both carefree and completely confident. Her black oversized shirt hung loosely on her frame, the fabric soft and flowing in the dim glow of the stage lights, almost as though it had been designed to accentuate her every movement. With every subtle shift of Rio’s body, the shirt caught the light, sending small ripples across the fabric, causing it to shimmer in the most tantalizing way. It highlighted the curves of her arms, the lines of her collarbone—those soft, elegant contours that Agatha had somehow found herself memorizing, no matter how hard she tried not to. And then there was the way the shirt grazed the curve of her neck, unbuttoned a few buttons more than necessary, the delicate space just below her jaw that seemed to beckon for Agatha’s attention and lower…

 

No.

 

It was when Rio took a moment to glance at the audience, locking eyes with Agatha for a split second, that Agatha felt something shift in her chest. The connection was brief, but it was enough to send a jolt of awareness through her. Her heart fluttered, and in that moment, it was as if the entire world around them disappeared.

 

She caught herself, pushing the thought away immediately, trying to focus on the music, on the band, on anything but the way Rio was making her feel. But it didn’t work. Every note, every strum of the guitar, every beat of the drums—Agatha noticed it all, but it was Rio who dominated her thoughts. She felt herself falling, little by little, into something she couldn’t control.

 

 

When Rio spotted Agatha in the crowd, her heart skipped a beat. It wasn’t just the surprise of seeing her there—it was the rush of emotions that came with it. She hadn’t expected Agatha to show up tonight. After all, she hadn’t even told her when the gig was happening, and Agatha had been so distant all week, keeping their interactions purely professional in class. The sight of her, standing there, her posture poised and her eyes locked on Rio, brought something to the surface that Rio hadn’t anticipated.

 

The music seemed to intensify in Rio’s ears, her heartbeat matching the rhythm of the drums, but it wasn’t just the adrenaline of performing. No, it was the way Agatha was looking at her, like she was truly seeing her in a way that made everything feel different. Her gaze wasn’t just assessing—there was something deeper, something more personal. Rio felt a warmth spread through her chest, an undeniable pull that sent a jolt of electricity through her body.

 

For a brief moment, she faltered, her focus wavering as she locked eyes with Agatha, but it was only for an instant. The connection between them, brief yet intense, gave Rio a burst of energy, something she couldn’t quite explain. It was as though her entire body was alive with a new kind of fire, her movements sharper, more confident, more alive than before. She didn’t know why, but seeing Agatha there, even after the way the professor had been keeping her distance, made everything feel like it mattered.

 

It was confusing, exhilarating, and frightening all at once. She wanted to break the distance between them, wanted to do something—anything—that would make that look Agatha had given her real. But for now, all she could do was keep playing, keep performing, letting the music carry her through the tension that lingered in the air between them.

 

As the song came to an end, Rio caught her breath, her eyes searching for Agatha in the crowd once again. She couldn’t tell if it was the excitement of the performance or the effect Agatha had on her, but there was no denying that something had shifted. She couldn’t get the image of Agatha’s gaze out of her mind, and it was making it harder to focus on anything else.

 

She exited the stage before her thoughts could linger any longer. Agatha had made it clear that she didn’t want anything to do with her. But why was she here then?

 

As the buzz of the performance faded, Rio slipped out the back door of the venue, letting it creak shut behind her. The cool night air was a shock against her flushed skin, still warm from the stage lights and the pulsing energy of the crowd. She let out a deep breath, the adrenaline from the show coursing through her veins like a wild current. She loved performing, but it always left her feeling a little unmoored, as if the rush had taken a piece of her she wasn’t ready to give up.

 

Reaching into her jacket pocket, Rio pulled out a slightly crumpled pack of cigarettes. Her hands trembled faintly as she tapped one out and lit it with a flick of her lighter. The sharp scent of tobacco mixed with the faint tang of city air, grounding her. She leaned back against the cool brick wall, her head tilting up to look at the stars barely visible above the streetlights.

 

The muffled hum of music and voices from inside the venue carried faintly on the air, but out here, it was quieter. Calmer. She closed her eyes, taking a long drag from her cigarette and letting the smoke curl lazily out of her lips.

 

Her solitude lasted only a moment. Footsteps echoed faintly from the alleyway, measured and deliberate. Rio didn’t open her eyes, assuming it was just another band member or someone sneaking out for their own moment of peace.

 

“Mind if I join you?”

 

The voice was low, smooth, and immediately recognizable. Rio’s eyes snapped open, her pulse quickening for an entirely different reason. She turned her head to see Agatha standing a few feet away, her hands tucked casually into the pockets of her long coat. The dim glow of the streetlamp caught the glint of her necklace and cast shadows across her sharp, elegant features.

 

Before Rio could respond, Agatha stepped closer, her gaze flicking to the cigarette between Rio’s fingers. Without asking, she plucked it from her hand, her movements so smooth that Rio didn’t even think to protest. Agatha brought the cigarette to her lips, taking a deliberate drag, her eyes never leaving Rio’s.

 

Rio watched, her breath catching for reasons she didn’t fully understand. Agatha exhaled slowly, the smoke curling in the air between them like some kind of spell. “Nasty habit,” Agatha remarked, but not handing the cigarette back to Rio.

 

Rio snorted softly. “You’re one to talk.” Her lips twitched, but she didn’t smile. Instead, she leaned back against the wall, her eyes narrowing slightly as she studied Agatha. “You don’t seem like the type to hang around backstage at gigs like this.”

 

“And you don’t seem like the type to need a smoke break to collect yourself,” Agatha countered smoothly, her voice calm but probing.

 

Rio watched her, her heart thumping in her chest. It felt surreal. There was something about the way Agatha stood there, so composed, yet so close, that made Rio feel… exposed. Not just physically, but emotionally. It was as if everything she had been trying to suppress, all the feelings that had been building up in her chest, were suddenly on the verge of spilling out.

 

For a moment, they both stood in silence, the only sound the occasional hiss of the cigarette burning and the distant hum of the night. Rio wasn’t sure if Agatha had come out here to say something, or if she was just seeking a bit of solitude too. Either way, Rio didn’t know how to break the silence. She wasn’t sure what to say, or if she should say anything at all.

 

There was no safety in Agatha’s presence, not in the way Rio usually defined it. Agatha wasn’t soft edges and soothing words. She was edges honed sharp, her calm presence stripping away the protective armor Rio had spent years perfecting. It left her feeling raw, unguarded, as if every thought she’d been keeping locked away had suddenly risen to the surface, ready to spill over with one wrong move.

 

Agatha took a slow drag from the cigarette, her eyes briefly breaking away to watch the smoke dissipate into the night air. Her movements were unhurried, each one precise, as though she were in no rush to break the tension stretching between them. But Rio could feel it—Agatha’s awareness, her ability to read the spaces people didn’t want to share. And it made Rio want to hide even as she fought the pull to stay.

 

When Agatha finally glanced back at her, Rio felt herself stiffen. That unreadable expression made her stomach twist in knots. Was it curiosity? Amusement? Or something else entirely? Whatever it was, it unsettled her in a way that was equal parts thrilling and terrifying.

 

Agatha held her gaze for what felt like an eternity, then exhaled, the smoke leaving her lips in a steady stream. Still, she said nothing, though her presence spoke volumes. Rio thought she might’ve preferred if Agatha would just say something—anything—to break the spell. But then Agatha extended the cigarette, her hand brushing against Rio’s as she passed it back.

 

“Thanks,” Agatha murmured, her voice so soft it barely cut through the quiet.

 

The contact was fleeting, no more than a second, but it left Rio’s skin tingling, as though Agatha’s touch had somehow left an imprint. She took the cigarette back, her fingers lingering over the filter as if it might hold the answer to whatever was happening between them.

 

Rio inhaled deeply, but even the smoke didn’t seem to ground her this time. Her mind was racing, her pulse hammering in her ears. She told herself she was imagining it, the way Agatha’s presence seemed to draw out emotions she’d buried long ago. It wasn’t real, she reasoned. It couldn’t be. And yet, the air between them felt alive with unspoken possibilities.

 

Agatha shifted slightly, leaning back against the wall beside Rio. The move felt deliberate, almost casual, but the space between them felt even smaller now, like they were occupying the same breath of air. Rio wasn’t sure if she wanted to move away or lean in closer, to say something or keep the silence intact.

 

“You’re quiet tonight,” Agatha said finally, her voice low and smooth, with just a hint of something teasing beneath the surface.

 

Rio glanced at her, lips twitching into the faintest of smirks. “You’re the one who came out here. Figured you wanted the quiet.”

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a knowing smile, her gaze flicking to the cigarette still between Rio’s fingers. “Maybe I did. But quiet doesn’t mean empty.”

 

The words hung in the air, heavier than they should’ve been. Rio turned them over in her mind, trying to figure out if Agatha meant something more, or if she was just reading too much into things.

 

“You always talk in riddles, or is it just for me?” Rio asked, her voice laced with an edge of sarcasm that felt safer than letting her real feelings show.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, the sound low and warm. “Maybe it’s just for you,” she said, her tone light but her gaze anything but.

 

Rio felt her breath hitch. For a moment, it was like the rest of the world didn’t exist—the distant music, the muffled laughter from inside, the city buzzing beyond the alley. It all faded away, leaving just the two of them in this strange, intimate bubble.

 

“I don’t get you,” Rio said, the words slipping out before she could stop them.

 

Agatha turned her head, her eyes meeting Rio’s with that same piercing intensity. “Maybe you’re not supposed to.”

 

The response wasn’t what Rio expected, but it didn’t surprise her either. Agatha always seemed to operate just outside the lines of what was predictable, and it was part of what made her so maddening—and so captivating.

 

Finally, Rio found her voice, though it felt like a fragile thing. “You didn’t have to come out here,” she said, trying to sound casual, but the tremble in her words betrayed the vulnerability she couldn’t hide.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened for just a split second, her lips pressing into a thin line before she spoke. “I wanted to,” she replied, her tone simple but weighted with something more. She shoved her hands deep into her pockets, the movement so casual it almost made the moment feel normal, when nothing about it was. “You were good up there.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat. She wasn’t sure if Agatha was talking about the performance or something else, something unsaid that hung in the air between them like a secret neither of them was ready to share. The way Agatha’s eyes lingered on her made Rio want to ask, but the words wouldn’t come. Not now, not when everything felt too delicate, too fragile to risk.

 

They both stood there for a few more moments, the silence between them now thick with unspoken things. Agatha’s presence was overwhelming, but it wasn’t uncomfortable. It was like something had shifted—something delicate, fragile, and Rio couldn’t help but wonder if Agatha felt it too.

 

Rio’s fingers twitched, the only movement breaking the stillness as she reached for the cigarette. She stubbed it out in the ashtray beside her, the sudden motion feeling too loud, too final. She didn’t want to break the moment, but it was slipping away, too quiet and too full of things she couldn’t name. She stood there, eyes fixed on the ground, unsure of what to do, what to say. There was so much weight in the air, in the way Agatha stood so close, and yet there was a space between them that felt like an abyss.

 

The tension grew heavier, thickening in the air as Agatha shifted, her weight slightly moving as though she was preparing to say something. Rio could feel it—a shift in the energy, like Agatha was about to speak, to explain something, maybe to apologize. Rio’s heart pounded in her chest as she braced for it. She thought she could read it in Agatha’s stance, in the way she opened her mouth, but before Agatha could say whatever was on her mind, something in Rio snapped.

 

Without thinking, without fully realizing what she was doing, Rio closed the distance between them. She stepped forward, her breath shallow as she moved instinctively, drawn to Agatha like a magnet. She reached up, her hand trembling, betraying her as she cupped Agatha’s face. The moment her skin made contact with Agatha’s, everything seemed to pulse with something electric, something undeniable. Her heart raced, and she almost expected Agatha to pull back, to question it, but there was no time for that. Her hand moved on its own accord, and before she could second-guess herself, Rio kissed her.

 

The world seemed to freeze for a moment, as though time itself had decided to hold its breath. Rio’s mind went blank, her heart pounding in her chest as her lips met Agatha’s in a brief, electrifying kiss. It was everything and nothing all at once—soft, quick, yet determined, as though the kiss was the culmination of something they both hadn’t been able to express until now. Every nerve in Rio’s body seemed to wake up, alive with the sensation of it, but just as quickly as it had started, Rio pulled away.

 

Her breath came out in sharp, uneven gasps, her wide eyes locked on Agatha in stunned disbelief. She hadn’t meant for it to happen. She hadn’t planned it. It was reckless, impulsive—everything she usually kept tightly under control. Her hands dropped to her sides, her face burning with embarrassment. It was as though the entire world had just shifted beneath her feet, and she was unsure how to stand on it anymore.

 

“I’m sorry,” she said quickly, her voice trembling. “I—I shouldn’t have done that.” The words felt foreign on her tongue, and she regretted them as soon as they left her mouth. Her mind raced, her thoughts chaotic and unorganized. She couldn’t make sense of it, couldn’t reconcile what she had just done with everything she had known to be true. It was like the earth had tilted, and she was falling, helpless to stop it.

 

Before she could apologize again, before she could stumble over more words, Agatha’s hand reached out. It was soft at first, but it held a quiet power. Agatha’s fingers gently touched her lips, stilling the apology that had started to form. Rio froze, looking up at Agatha with confusion, guilt, and a thousand questions swirling in her mind.

 

But before Rio could find her bearings, Agatha acted. In one swift motion, she pulled Rio back into a kiss.

 

This time, there were no apologies, no hesitation. Agatha’s kiss was firm, deep, and unmistakably real. It wasn’t tentative or uncertain. It was a quiet assertion, a statement in itself—an unspoken declaration that this was right, that it was something more than the brief, stolen moment Rio had tried to run from. Agatha’s lips were warm, insistent, pulling Rio closer as though she were the gravity that held Rio in orbit, her presence both grounding and consuming.

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat, the pulse in her ears deafening, and in that instant, everything else faded into the background. There was no more room for thought, no more space for the doubts that had clouded Rio’s mind just moments before. All that remained was the sensation of Agatha’s kiss—daring, intense, and overwhelmingly powerful. Rio’s body responded before her mind could catch up, her hands lifting to rest on Agatha’s wrists, feeling the warmth of her skin through the fabric. The kiss deepened, and Rio’s chest tightened as Agatha’s arms wound around her neck, pulling her in closer, if that was even possible.

 

In that moment, everything felt like it was exactly where it was meant to be—perfectly balanced, yet completely out of control. Rio felt a surge of emotion, of heat, running through her veins. It was raw and exhilarating, a feeling she couldn’t quite name but didn’t want to escape. And for a fleeting moment, she let herself be lost in it, allowed herself to surrender to the connection, to the pull between them.

 

When Agatha finally pulled away, just enough to catch her breath, her blue eyes were dark, intense, and searching Rio’s face as if she were trying to read her very soul. The space between them was charged, heavy with unspoken words and the residue of the kiss still lingering in the air.

 

“Don’t apologize,” Agatha whispered, her voice low, thick with something that Rio couldn’t quite place—something raw, vulnerable, and dangerous. “You’re not the only one who’s been struggling with this.”

 

The words hit Rio like a wave, washing over her and leaving her breathless. She stood there, frozen, her heart pounding in her chest as the weight of what had just happened pressed down on her. She had kissed her professor. She had kissed Agatha—someone she had admired, respected, and tried to keep at a distance for so long. And now, in this strange, electric moment, Agatha was telling her that she had been struggling too.

 

Rio’s head spun, her thoughts tangled in a chaotic mess. “I—I didn’t know if…” she managed to say, her voice unsteady as she fought to process the rush of emotions swirling inside her. “I thought…”

 

Agatha didn’t let her finish. A soft, almost imperceptible laugh escaped her lips, the sound rich with a mix of relief and something else—something deep and knowing. Her thumb brushed against Rio’s cheek, tender, yet firm, as if to ground them both in the reality of what was happening.

 

“You’re not the only one who’s confused,” Agatha said again, her eyes softening, the tension between them shifting from uncertainty to something more comfortable, more intimate. “But we’ll figure it out, won’t we?”

 

The words settled over Rio like a blanket, wrapping her in the warmth of Agatha’s quiet certainty. The vulnerability that had held her captive moments before began to ease, replaced by a fragile hope. She didn’t know what this was—what it could be—but the way Agatha was looking at her, the way she was holding her, made it feel like something possible, even inevitable.

 

Rio didn’t know what to say, how to explain the surge of feelings bubbling up in her chest. She had been running from this for so long—this connection, this pull she couldn’t deny. But now, with Agatha standing there, so close, so real, something shifted in her. She could feel the weight of this new reality between them, and it didn’t feel impossible anymore. It felt like something they could navigate together.

 

A gentle silence passed between them, but it wasn’t uncomfortable. It was a silence filled with understanding, with a sense that they were both on the verge of something, unsure of exactly what it was, but unwilling to pull away from it.

 

Just as Rio opened her mouth to respond, to say something—anything—more, the sharp sound of footsteps echoed down the alley, cutting through the quiet like a knife. Rio flinched, as if burned, and instinctively took a step back, her heart leaping in her chest. The unmistakable voice of Alice rang out, full of her usual playful mischief.

 

“Rio!” Alice called, her voice bright and teasing, clearly unaware of the tension in the air. “There you are. I was wondering where you—”

 

Alice rounded the corner and stopped dead in her tracks, her gaze darting between Rio and Agatha.
