Agatha’s smile deepened, and she leaned in to kiss Rio gently, her lips warm against Rio’s. It was a kiss that spoke of comfort and closeness, of the deep bond they shared. There was nothing rushed about it. Just the quiet, tender acknowledgment of everything they meant to each other.

 

When they pulled away, Agatha rested her forehead against Rio’s, her hands still gently holding her face, as if to keep her there forever.

 

“We’ve been dancing around this for so long,” Agatha said, her voice soft and almost amused. “I think I’ve been waiting for this moment longer than I realized.”

 

Rio chuckled lightly, the sound of it almost relieved. “I think I have too. But… it feels right now. With you.”

 

The world outside seemed to fade away, the busy campus life, the papers and the meetings—everything but this moment, this quiet space, felt unimportant. All that mattered was this. What they had. What they were.

 

“I’m glad,” Agatha murmured, her smile growing, the warmth between them undeniable. “Because I don’t think I could love you any more than I already do.”

 

They stayed a few minutes longer, soaking in the moment, before a noise down the hall brought them back to reality. Rio secured her bag on her shoulder and Agatha eventually opened the door.

 

Just before slipping out, Rio glanced back, a knowing smile on her lips. “See you later, Dr. Harkness.”

 

Agatha smiled back, her expression private and fond. “See you later, Ms. Vidal.”

 

Just before she left, Rio turned around and mouthed, “Lunch tomorrow? My place?”

 

Agatha laughed softly and nodded.

 

As the door closed behind Rio, Agatha leaned against her desk, exhaling slowly. Mixing business and pleasure with Rio was a balancing act—one they were pulling off with care and discretion. And yet, every stolen moment, every shared look, made the risk feel undeniably worth it.

 

The sunlight streaming through the windows of Rio’s apartment bathed the room in a warm, golden glow, illuminating the array of vibrant green plants perched on the windowsill. Their leaves reached toward the light, adding a sense of life and tranquility to the cozy space. The faint scent of herbs and spices lingered in the air, mingling with the inviting aroma of freshly cooked pasta.

 

At the small dining table, Agatha sat nursing a cup of tea, the ceramic warm against her palms. She leaned back slightly, her gaze following Rio as she moved around the kitchen with practiced ease. The younger woman’s hair was gathered in a loose, slightly messy bun, wisps escaping to frame her face. It wasn’t perfect, and somehow, that made it all the more endearing. She was wearing an oversized shirt with the sleeves rolled up and tucked into a pair of faded jeans that hugged her in all the right places. There was something so effortlessly captivating about the way Rio moved, her focus entirely on plating the meal she had prepared.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a smirk as she tilted her head, watching the way the sunlight caught on Rio’s skin, making it almost glow. “Do you always cook this well, or am I just special?” she teased, her voice laced with playful curiosity.

 

Rio turned to face her, a wooden spoon in one hand as she raised an eyebrow, the corners of her mouth quirking up into a smile. “You’re definitely special,” she quipped, her tone light but her eyes holding a warmth that made Agatha’s chest ache in the best way. She set the plates down on the table, the pasta glistening with a creamy, rich sauce, flanked by perfectly roasted vegetables. “But don’t get too used to it,” Rio added with a sly grin. “I’m not a professional chef or anything. Lilia just taught me the basics, and I wing it from there. Most of the times, it ends up burnt or undercooked, but I made a special effort for you.”

 

“Remind me to thank her,” Agatha said, her smirk deepening as she reached out to gently tug on Rio’s wrist, pulling her closer.

 

“Agatha,” Rio protested, though her laughter betrayed her as Agatha pulled her down into her lap. Rio swatted at her half-heartedly, a bright smile lighting up her face as she relented. “You are so—” She didn’t finish the sentence, cutting herself off with a quick, soft kiss to Agatha’s lips. “Eat your food, woman,” she added with mock sternness, her voice tinged with affection as she tried to wriggle free.

 

“Not until you promise to stay right here,” Agatha countered, her arms wrapping loosely around Rio’s waist, holding her in place.

 

Rio sighed dramatically but couldn’t hide the way her smile softened, her gaze lingering on Agatha’s. “Fine,” she murmured, reaching for her fork and twisting it through the pasta on her plate.

 

They ate like that, Rio perched on Agatha’s lap, the plates balanced between them on the small table. The meal was simple but delicious, and the conversation flowed as naturally as it always did between them. Agatha found herself marveling at how easily Rio fit into her life, how seamlessly their days intertwined despite the risks and secrecy that shadowed their relationship.

 

As Rio twirled another forkful of pasta, she glanced toward the door, her brows knitting together in a flicker of uncertainty. “Did I lock that?” she murmured absently, more to herself than to Agatha.

 

Agatha looked up from her plate, her expression calm but curious. “I didn’t hear the lock turn,” she said.

 

Before Rio could respond, the door swung open with an abruptness that made her jump, and Alice strode in like a whirlwind, a tote bag slung over her shoulder and her face lit with the urgency of a fresh piece of gossip. “Rio, you won’t believe what Jen—”

 

Alice froze mid-sentence, her eyes widening as they landed on Agatha. And then on Rio, who was still perched in Agatha’s lap, their faces far too close to be explained away.

 

Alice’s mouth fell open in a comical expression of shock, quickly morphing into giddy delight. She pointed an accusatory finger at them, her voice breaking the tense silence. “Oh. My. God. What is this?”

 

Panic flared in Rio’s chest as she scrambled off Agatha’s lap so quickly she nearly knocked over the plates. Her face turned a deep, telltale crimson, and she held up her hands as if trying to ward off Alice’s relentless stare. “Alice! Do you ever knock?” she blurted, her voice sharp but laced with the kind of mortification that only Alice could inspire.

 

Alice, unfazed and utterly delighted, dropped her bag onto the floor with a dramatic thud. She pointed between them, her grin widening by the second. “You’re together. You and Dr. Harkness!” Her voice was an octave too loud, filled with uncontainable glee.

 

Agatha, ever composed and unshaken, rose gracefully from her chair, brushing off her slacks as if nothing at all were amiss. She met Alice’s wide-eyed stare with her usual calm demeanor, her lips curving into a polite smile. “Alice,” she said, her tone smooth and controlled. “Lovely to see you again.”

 

Alice’s grin turned downright mischievous. She folded her arms, leaning against the doorframe as if settling in for a long interrogation. “Oh, don’t you ‘lovely to see you’ me,” she shot back, her eyes dancing with amusement. “How long has this been going on? And more importantly, why didn’t I know about it?”

 

Rio groaned, burying her face in her hands. “Alice, I swear—”

 

“No, no, don’t you swear at me, young lady,” Alice interrupted, clearly reveling in the moment. “Do you know how long I’ve been trying to figure out if you were seeing anyone? And now I find out it’s her?” She gestured toward Agatha with exaggerated incredulity, though her tone carried no real judgment.

 

Rio let out an exasperated sigh, dropping her hands and glaring at Alice, though the effect was somewhat ruined by the pink flush still dusting her cheeks. “Fine. Yes. We’re together,” she admitted, her words coming out in a rush. “It’s… new, and we were keeping it quiet. But now, I guess you know.”

 

Alice practically vibrated with excitement, clapping her hands together as though she had just uncovered the greatest secret of the century. “This is amazing. I mean, kind of scandalous, sure, but mostly amazing.” She paused for dramatic effect, her eyes sparkling as she looked between Rio and Agatha. “Rio, I’ve been dying to know what’s been going on with you. And this? This explains everything.”

 

She threw her bag onto the couch with a triumphant flourish and pointed at them, her grin so wide it looked as though it might permanently stretch her face. “I knew it! I knew this was happening!” she practically squealed, bouncing on the balls of her feet like an overexcited puppy. “Oh my God, I can’t believe you thought you could keep this from me. Me!”

 

Rio groaned, her face now a deep crimson as she buried it in her hands. “Alice, please. Can you not make this more humiliating than it already is?”

 

“Humiliating?” Alice gasped as if Rio had personally insulted her. “Humiliating? Are you kidding me, Rio? This is a moment. This is iconic. This is—this is everything I’ve been saying for months.” She threw her hands up, gesturing wildly between Rio and Agatha like an overzealous referee at a particularly dramatic sporting event. “I called this the day you walked into her class. Don’t even try to tell me I’m wrong, because—hello—this right here?” She pointed emphatically at the space between them. “This is all the proof I need.”

 

Agatha, as axlays the picture of composure despite the circus unfolding before her, raised a perfectly arched eyebrow and crossed her arms. Her gaze flicked between Alice and Rio, her tone calm but tinged with amusement. “You’ve been speculating about us?”

 

“Speculating?” Alice snorted, folding her arms as though the mere suggestion was beneath her. “Try betting on it.” She tilted her chin up, feigning offense. “Jen owes me twenty bucks.”

 

Rio let out a long, suffering groan, dragging her hands down her face as though trying to erase herself from existence. “I’m going to kill her,” she muttered, her voice muffled but dripping with exasperation.

 

“Oh, don’t be mad!” Alice flopped onto the couch with a dramatic sigh, throwing one arm over her forehead like a tragic heroine in a melodrama. “You two were so obvious. Like, painfully obvious. The stolen glances? The way you magically loved going to class all of a sudden?” She sat up abruptly, pointing a finger at Rio with mock seriousness. “And let’s not forget the dead giveaway: the moment you stopped talking about her completely a few weeks ago. Textbook denial behavior. Classic move.”

 

Rio groaned again, this time leaning against the edge of the couch as if her knees could no longer support her. “I cannot believe I’m listening to this right now.”

 

Agatha leaned casually against the table, her arms crossed and a small, amused smile playing on her lips. “I suppose Rio underestimated you,” she said, her tone light but with just enough edge to make Alice’s chest puff out proudly.

 

Alice pointed an accusatory finger at her, her grin feral. “Damn right she did. But now that you’ve officially confirmed it—because, oh my god, finally—I need details. When did it happen? Who made the first move? Was it super romantic, or was it one of those tension-filled moments where you just couldn’t resist anymore?”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, though she couldn’t fight the smile creeping onto her face. “Alice, I swear, if you don’t calm down—”

 

“Calm down?” Alice interrupted, leaning forward on the couch as if she were at the edge of her seat in a thriller. “Rio, this is huge. You’re dating Dr. Harkness. The Agatha Harkness! I’m your best friend. You’re supposed to tell me everything.”

 

Rio sighed heavily, shooting Agatha a desperate, pleading look. “This,” she said, gesturing toward Alice without looking at her, “is what I deal with every single day.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her composure unshaken as she reached out and rested a calming hand on Rio’s shoulder. Her thumb moved in small, soothing circles, a subtle gesture of reassurance. “I think she’s happy for us,” she said, her tone teasing.

 

Alice scoffed dramatically, clutching her chest as though Agatha had insulted her honor. “Happy? I’m ecstatic. My girl’s with the hottest, smartest professor on campus. You two are like… like a power couple in the making! Academic royalty! Everyone else can just go home!”

 

“Please stop,” Rio begged, her voice half-laughing, half-dying from secondhand embarrassment. Her cheeks were burning a brilliant shade of crimson, but despite the dramatics, there was a soft smile tugging at her lips. She couldn’t help it—Alice’s enthusiasm was annoyingly infectious.

 

Alice, seeing that she’d successfully chipped away at Rio’s defenses, softened for a moment, leaning forward with an almost maternal air. “Hey, in all seriousness,” she said, her voice losing its playful edge, “I’m really glad. Okay? If she makes you happy—and it’s very clear she does—then I’m all in.” She hesitated for a beat, then grinned wickedly, her mischievous energy flooding back. “But you still owe me every juicy detail. Later, of course.”

 

Rio let out a groan of mock defeat, covering her face with her hands. “She’s going to be unbearable. We’ve created a monster.”

 

Agatha’s lips quirked into a smirk as she glanced at Alice, then back at Rio. “I think the monster was already there, dear,” she said, her voice laced with dry humor. “But I have to admit, she’s a good friend.”

 

Alice threw her arms out dramatically, as though expecting applause. “Damn right I am. The best friend, actually. And don’t you worry, I’ll take this secret to the grave.” She paused, tapping her chin thoughtfully. “Well, for now.”

 

Rio groaned again, this time burying her face in Agatha’s shoulder. “I don’t know why I put up with you,” she muttered, though the fondness in her voice betrayed her words.

 

“Because you love me,” Alice shot back without missing a beat, leaning back against the couch with a triumphant grin. “And because deep down, you know I’m your number-one hype woman.”

 

Agatha chuckled, her hand moving to gently stroke Rio’s back. “She does have a point,” she murmured, her voice warm and amused.

 

Rio pulled back just enough to glare half-heartedly at both of them, her lips twitching upward despite herself. “I can’t believe I’m saying this, but you two together might actually kill me.”

 

Alice grinned, leaning forward and clasping her hands together as if preparing for a toast. “Oh, don’t worry. I’ll behave.” She paused for dramatic effect. “Eventually.”

 

As much as Alice’s excitement was boundless, the moment she realized she was sitting across from an actual professor—Rio’s professor—her energy shifted slightly. She straightened up, suddenly aware of her casual sprawl on Rio’s couch, and brushed her hands down her jeans as if smoothing out invisible wrinkles. Her eyes darted to Agatha, wide and curious but edged with an uncharacteristic self-consciousness.

 

“So…” Alice began, her voice carefully measured, as though she were addressing a head of state. Her gaze flicked between Rio and Agatha, her hands fidgeting with the hem of her shirt. “Dr. Harkness. Or, uh—should I call you Agatha? I mean, you’re, like, not my professor, but still… you’re a professor.”

 

Agatha’s lips quirked into a small, amused smile, her poise utterly unshaken. “Agatha is fine,” she said smoothly. “Outside of the classroom, I assure you, I’m just another person.”

 

“Right. Totally. That makes sense,” Alice said with a quick nod, though her hands continued their nervous dance in her lap. “Agatha. Cool. Nice to, um, officially meet you. I mean, you know, as Agatha—not just ‘the mysterious Dr. Harkness Rio never shut up about.’”

 

Rio groaned audibly, dragging her hands down her face in a fruitless attempt to hide her embarrassment. “Alice,” she muttered, her voice dripping with warning.

 

“What?” Alice said innocently, throwing up her hands. “It’s true! Like, ridiculously true.”

 

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her gaze sliding to Rio with a playful arch of her brow. “Never shut up, you say?”

 

Rio’s blush deepened to the point where it seemed her entire face might catch fire. “Don’t encourage her,” she muttered, her voice muffled as she buried her face in her hands.

 

Alice’s initial awkwardness dissolved into a grin that was all mischief, her energy returning tenfold. “Oh, you have no idea. There was this one time—”

 

“Alice,” Rio interjected sharply, her tone low and laced with thinly veiled menace, though the corners of her mouth twitched as if fighting a reluctant smile.

 

Alice smirked, leaning back against the couch like a cat that had cornered its prey. “Fine, fine. I’ll stop,” she said with exaggerated surrender, holding her hands up as though absolving herself of any guilt.

 

The air between them crackled with unspoken amusement, and Agatha leaned forward sligthtly, resting her hands on her knees. “You two have a… lively dynamic,” she remarked, her voice carrying a warm undercurrent that softened the teasing note.

 

“That’s one way to put it,” Rio muttered, shooting Alice a look that managed to be both exasperated and affectionate.

 

Alice, unfazed, turned her attention back to Agatha. “So, Agatha, tell me—what’s it like being the Dr. Harkness? Do you just go around dazzling people with your intellect and stealing their hearts? Or is that a Rio-only special?”

 

Agatha blinked, clearly surprised by the boldness of the question, though her amusement didn’t waver. “I’m fairly certain it’s just Rio,” she replied with a small, knowing smile, her gaze flicking to the woman in question.

 

Rio groaned again, this time leaning back into the cushions as though wishing they would swallow her whole. “I regret introducing you two.”

 

Alice gasped in mock horror, pressing a hand to her chest. “You regret introducing me to the love of your life?  Wow. Harsh.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened, and she reached over to place a gentle hand on Rio’s knee. “I think she’s just overwhelmed by your enthusiasm,” she said, her tone a perfect balance of humor and reassurance.

 

Alice grinned, clearly pleased with herself. “Oh, trust me, she’s used to it. I’ve been like this since day one. Right, Rio?”

 

Rio opened one eye, glaring half-heartedly at Alice. “Unfortunately, yes. Day one.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her fingers giving Rio’s knee a light squeeze. “Well, I have to admit, I’m starting to see the appeal.”

 

Alice beamed, leaning forward with her hands clasped together. “I like her, Rio. She’s a keeper.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, clearly entertained by their dynamic. “I think I like her too,” she said to Rio, whose exasperated eye-roll did little to hide the small, reluctant smile tugging at her lips.

 

Alice beamed, her chest puffing up slightly at the indirect compliment, though her lingering awkwardness was still evident in the way she fidgeted with her hands. “Thanks. I think you’re… cool, too,” she blurted, before immediately wincing. Her voice dropped to a mortified mumble. “God, why did I say that? She’s literally a professor.”

 

Agatha, as composed as ever, didn’t so much as bat an eyelash at Alice’s outburst. “I appreciate the vote of confidence,” she replied smoothly, her smile kind and warm. “And for the record, I’m glad Rio has someone like you in her life. It’s clear how much she values your friendship.”

 

Alice blinked, visibly taken aback by the sincerity of the statement. Her bravado faltered for just a moment, and she shifted in her seat. “Oh. Uh, thanks. That means a lot, actually.” She scratched the back of her neck, her usual confidence replaced by a faint blush.

 

Rio glanced between the two women, her fondness for both of them unmistakable. “Okay, this is sweet and all, but Alice, if you keep being this awkward, I swear I’m kicking you out.”

 

“I am not awkward!” Alice shot back indignantly, though the flush creeping up her neck betrayed her. “I just—I don’t usually hang out with professors, okay? It’s weird. No offense.”

 

“None taken,” Agatha said lightly, her tone teasing but gentle. “I promise, I’m not nearly as intimidating as I seem. I don’t bite.”

 

“That’s good to know,” Alice replied, managing a nervous laugh. Her expression shifted almost immediately, her grin turning impish as she swiveled toward Rio with a glint of mischief in her eyes. “Except if—”

 

Rio raised a finger, blushing ten shades darker. “Don’t even think about finishing that sentence,” she warned in a half-threatening tone, laced with an edge of mortified panic.

 

Agatha laughed at that, the sound warm and genuine, and Alice seemed to relax a bit more.

 

“You know, Dr. Harkness,” Alice said, her grin softening into something more genuine, “you’re a lot cooler than I expected. No offense again.”

 

“Still none taken,” Agatha replied, her smile unwavering. “And you’re a lot more entertaining than I expected. No offense.”

 

“Touché,” Alice said, raising an imaginary glass in a mock toast.

 

By the end of the visit, while the occasional bout of awkwardness lingered like a shadow, the tension between Alice and Agatha had dissolved into something easier, warmer. Alice cracked jokes with her usual flair, but with a newfound respect for Agatha. Agatha, for her part, offered her own wry observations, matching Alice’s wit with quiet precision.

 

Rio, caught in the crossfire of their budding camaraderie, watched the two women with an expression torn between fondness and exhaustion.

 

As Alice finally stood to leave, she paused at the door, glancing between Rio and Agatha with a sly smile. “You know, I could get used to this. You two are kind of disgustingly cute together. It’s almost tolerable.”

 

“Almost,” Rio echoed dryly, but the warmth in her voice betrayed her.

 

As the door closed behind her, the room fell quiet again. Rio leaned into Agatha’s side, letting out a long sigh. “She’s going to be insufferable, you know.”

 

Agatha chuckled, pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s temple. “She’s a good friend. And I think she’s already quite fond of me.”

 

Rio groaned, but her smile lingered as she leaned into Agatha’s touch. “Yeah, yeah. Just don’t let her corrupt you.”

 

Agatha’s laughter filled the space again, warm and comforting, and for the first time in a while, Rio felt a strange sense of peace in the chaos.

 

*

*

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

I think this is the funniest chapter so far.
and yay!!! First "I love you"s !

The Rio Grande

*

*

*

 

Go, said the bird, for the leaves were full of children,

Hidden excitedly, containing laughter.

Go, go, go, said the bird: human kind

Cannot bear very much reality.

Time past and time future

What might have been and what has been

Point to one end, which is always present.

 

            (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

Saturday mornings at the dance center were always a whirlwind of activity. Little feet pattered across the polished wooden floors, excited voices filled the air, and parents lingered near the studio entrance, sipping coffee or chatting while waiting for the class to begin. Nicky, as usual, arrived with his boundless energy, holding tightly to his mother’s hand.

 

Agatha knelt beside him, adjusting his little dance shoes. “Remember to listen to Miss Rio, okay? And try to keep your arms straight during the jetés this time, like she told you last time.”

 

“I know, Mama!” Nicky said confidently, grinning. “Miss Rio said I’m getting better!”

 

Agatha smiled softly. “I’m sure she’s right.”

 

The two entered the studio, and there she was—Rio, standing in the center of the room with a clipboard in hand, already guiding a few early arrivals through their warm-ups. She looked bright and full of life, her enthusiasm for teaching infectious even to the adults peering through the observation window.

 

As soon as Nicky spotted her, he waved wildly. “Miss Rio!”

 

Rio turned at the sound, her face lighting up when she saw him. “Hey, Nicky!” She crouched down as he ran over, meeting him with an enthusiastic high-five. “Ready to dance today?”

 

“Yeah!” he replied, bouncing on his toes.

 

Agatha observed the exchange from the doorway, her heart swelling at how effortlessly Rio connected with her son. When Rio glanced up and caught her gaze, her expression softened. There was a flicker of something unspoken between them, a quiet acknowledgment of their bond. Agatha’s lips quirked into a small smile, and Rio returned it with a wink before refocusing on the class.

 

The session began in earnest, with Rio leading the children through stretches and basic positions. Agatha took her usual spot near the back of the observation area, watching discreetly. She couldn’t help but marvel at how Rio handled the group—gentle but firm, playful yet professional. It was as if she was made for this.

 

When the kids practiced their routines, Nicky tried extra hard to get everything right, occasionally glancing at his mom for approval. Agatha gave him an encouraging thumbs-up every time, which only fueled his determination.

 

At one point, Rio crouched beside Nicky to adjust his stance, her voice soft but confident. “That’s it! See how strong you look when you hold your arms like this? Perfect.”

 

Nicky beamed, standing even taller.

 

Agatha felt a pang of pride for her son and a rush of affection for the woman guiding him. Watching them like this—a scene so simple yet meaningful—made her feel a sense of peace she hadn’t realized she’d been missing.

 

After class, as the children gathered their things, Nicky ran up to Rio with a wide grin. “Miss Rio! Did I do good today?”

 

“You were awesome,” Rio said, ruffling his hair. “I’m proud of you.”

 

He looked thrilled, but then his gaze shifted to his mother, who had approached to collect him. “Mama, did you see me? Miss Rio said I was awesome!”

 

“I did see,” Agatha replied, crouching to his level. “And I think Miss Rio was absolutely right. You did great.”

 

Nicky turned back to Rio with a triumphant expression. “See? Mama thinks so too!”

 

Rio laughed, her eyes sparkling. “I guess that makes it official.”

 

As Agatha helped Nicky gather his things, Rio lingered for a moment, catching Agatha’s eye. There was a subtle, private warmth in her gaze—a message meant just for her. Agatha smiled back, her heart lighter than it had been all morning.

 

Nicky tugged on her hand, breaking the moment. “Can we make pancakes tomorrow morning, Mama?”

 

“Pancakes sound perfect,” Agatha said, standing. She glanced back at Rio, her voice quieter but no less sincere. “Thank you, as always.”

 

Rio nodded. “Anytime.”

 

As the flurry of children and parents began to disperse after class, Rio stayed behind in the studio, tidying up stray ballet slippers and rearranging the little chairs by the side of the room. She hummed softly to herself, a habit she’d developed over years of teaching, as it helped keep her grounded amidst the chaos of the day.

 

As she was about to leave, she heard the familiar sound of Nicky’s voice echoing down the hallway. He appeared moments later, bounding into the studio with his usual exuberance, his little bag bouncing against his side. Behind him, Agatha followed at a more measured pace, her sharp, poised demeanor a stark contrast to her son’s untamed energy. They both were still here, and it filled Rio with warmth.

 

“Miss Rio!” Nicky called out, skidding to a halt in front of her. “Guess what? Mama said we can have pancakes tomorrow morning because I did so good today!”

 

Rio crouched down to his level, giving him a high-five. “Pancakes? That sounds like a reward fit for a dancing superstar. You deserve it!”

 

Nicky grinned from ear to ear, puffing his chest out with pride.

 

Agatha hesitated for a moment, glancing around the now-empty studio before clearing her throat. “I was wondering…” she began, her voice quieter now. “If you’re free this afternoon, would you like to join us for lunch? Nothing fancy—just something at home.”

 

Rio blinked, caught off guard but undeniably pleased. “Lunch?”

 

“Yes,” Agatha confirmed, smoothing her hands over her coat. “I thought it might be nice. Nicky’s been talking about pancakes, but I was thinking something a bit more balanced today. Maybe sandwiches?”

 

At the mention of food, Nicky perked up. “You should come, Miss Rio! Mama makes the best sandwiches!”

 

Rio chuckled, glancing between the two. “How could I say no to an offer like that?”

 

Agatha’s smile softened, relief flickering across her face. “Great. Then it’s settled.”

 

“Do I get to help make the sandwiches?” Nicky asked eagerly, tugging at his mother’s hand.

 

“Of course,” Agatha said, turning to Rio with a teasing look. “Though I should warn you, his idea of helping usually involves eating half the ingredients.”

 

Rio laughed. “Sounds perfect to me.”

 

As the three of them exited the studio together, Rio couldn’t help but feel a quiet thrill. Sharing lunch with Agatha and Nicky felt like a step forward—a small, significant moment in their delicate balance of secrecy and connection. She didn’t know exactly what to expect, considering Nicky still didn’t know about them, but for now, she was simply happy to be invited into their little world.

 

 

The kitchen was filled with the cozy clatter of plates and the soft hum of conversation. Nicky sat at the table, his legs swinging beneath him as he devoured his sandwich, an impressive tower of bread, turkey, and cheese. Rio and Agatha sat across from him, sharing easy smiles as they assembled their plates.

 

Mid-bite, Nicky looked up at Rio, his eyes sparkling with curiosity. “Miss Rio,” he began, “at school, we learned about big rivers. Like the Rio Grande! Just like your name. Did your parents name you after this river like that?”

 

Rio’s hand stilled for a moment as she set down her glass, Nicky’s innocent question hanging in the air. Across the table, Agatha tensed slightly, her fork halfway to her mouth.

 

Rio glanced at Agatha, whose soft gaze seemed to silently offer support. Turning back to Nicky, she smiled, her voice steady but kind. “That’s a good question, Nicky,” she began gently. “But I don’t actually have parents—I never knew them. So I don’t really know why they named me Rio.”

 

Nicky’s smile faltered as he digested Rio’s words. His brow furrowed, his gaze shifting toward the ground as he asked softly, “But… don’t you wish you had parents? Like mama for me?”

 

Rio’s heart tightened at the concern in his voice. She leaned forward, her eyes warm as she met his gaze. “It’s okay to wonder about things like that,” she said gently. “But I want you to know that even though I didn’t have parents, I have someone who means just as much to me. Her name is Lilia, and she’s the closest thing I have to family.”

 

Nicky looked up at her, still a little confused but listening intently. “So… she takes care of you like a mom does?”

 

Rio smiled softly, her heart swelling at his innocence. “Yes, exactly. Lilia has been there for me for a long time. She didn’t give me my name, nor her last name, but that doesn’t change anything. She’s always treated me like her own. She's my mom and I'm her daughter.”

 

Agatha watched them, her heart full as she saw Rio speak with such tenderness. She had never seen Rio let her guard down so completely with anyone, but with Nicky, there was an ease that Agatha couldn’t help but admire.

 

“Does she come over to visit a lot?” Nicky asked, still processing the idea of Rio’s ‘Lilia’.”

 

“Very often, yeah, and I eat dinner at her house every Sunday,” Rio replied, her voice warm with affection. “She’s just like family, even if we’re not related by blood. Family doesn’t always have to be the people who gave you life. Sometimes, it’s the people who choose to be there for you.”

 

Nicky seemed to consider this for a moment, before his lips curved into a small smile. “That’s cool. I think I’d like Lilia.”

 

Rio smiled back, her eyes soft with gratitude. “I think she’d like you too, Nicky. She’s really special.”

 

Agatha, who had been quietly observing them, reached over to squeeze Rio’s hand under the table, a small gesture of support that Rio returned with a faint smile. Agatha knew Rio had never really spoken about her past like this, and she appreciated the openness. It wasn’t easy, but Rio had managed to share something so important, not just with her but with Nicky as well.

 

“I’m sorry, Miss Rio. But I’m glad you have a Lilia,” Nicky added, smiling widely at his teacher, as if to reassure her.

 

Rio shook her head, her smile never wavering. “You don’t need to be sorry. It’s just the way things are,” she said softly. “But I do know that my name, Rio, means ‘river’ in Spanish.”

 

Nicky perked up at that. “Like the Rio Grande!”

 

“Exactly,” Rio said, her tone lightening. “And my last name, Vidal, means ‘life.’ So my full name basically means ‘river of life.’”

 

Nicky’s face lit up, his enthusiasm bubbling over. “Whoa, that’s so cool! Rivers are so important. They carry water and fish and stuff—and life!”

 

Agatha started to open her mouth, perhaps to steer the conversation elsewhere, but Rio held up a hand, silently reassuring her. She took a slow breath and leaned toward Nicky.

 

“Honestly, Nicky, I don’t really know why my first parents chose it. But I like to think it’s because rivers are strong, and they keep moving no matter what’s in their way.” She paused, her voice softening. “It’s a good name to remind me to keep going, even when things are hard.”

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a quiet smile as she listened, her heart swelling at how Rio managed to answer the question with grace and honesty. She tilted her head slightly, regarding Rio with an affectionate gleam in her eyes.

 

“I think that’s a beautiful name,” Agatha said softly, her voice laced with admiration. “And it suits you perfectly.”

 

Rio glanced at her, their eyes meeting in a moment of unspoken understanding. A hint of warmth crept into her cheeks, and she gave a small, appreciative nod before turning her attention back to Nicky.

 

“You’ve got a pretty cool name too, you know. Nicholas Harkness has a nice ring to it.”

 

Nicky beamed, puffing out his chest with pride as he reached for another bite of his sandwich.

 

As the conversation shifted to lighter topics, Agatha couldn’t help but marvel at Rio’s resilience. River of Life, she thought, the words echoing in her mind. Yes, it was fitting—so fitting. Rio carried strength and vitality with her, moving forward despite the obstacles in her path, just like a river.

 

Watching her laugh with Nicky, Agatha felt her chest tighten with an overwhelming mix of admiration, adoration and tenderness. The connection they shared at this table was something she hadn’t realized she’d been longing for until now.

 

“We can be your family too, Mama and me” Nicky said after a beat, his bright eyes looking at Rio with such earnestness that it took her breath away.

 

Rio blinked rapidly, trying to hold back the tears that suddenly welled up. She hadn’t expected those words to affect her so deeply, but they did. The warmth in Nicky’s offer made her heart ache with a mixture of joy and sorrow.

 

Her voice came out a little shaky when she spoke, “You don’t know how much that means to me, Nicky.”

 

Agatha watched silently, her heart swelling with love for both of them, as Rio struggled to compose herself. She knew how hard it had been for Rio to open up, how much it took to allow herself to be vulnerable. And now, here was Nicky, offering her something she’d never had before Lilia — a sense of belonging, a place to call home.

 

Rio wiped her eyes quickly, trying to smile through the emotion. “I think… I think I might need some time to get used to that,” she said, her voice still thick. “But that’s the nicest thing anyone has said to me in a long time.”

 

Nicky, oblivious to the weight of the moment, smiled brightly. “I mean it. You’re already like family. You’re always here with us.”

 

Agatha, her hand still resting on Rio’s, leaned in and kissed the top of Rio’s head gently, a silent gesture of support. She could see how hard this was for Rio, but also how much it meant to her.

 

“Thank you, Nicky,” Rio said, her voice steadier now. “I’m lucky to have both of you.”

 

As Nicky beamed, clearly pleased with himself, Rio felt a sense of peace settle over her. She had never had the privilege of growing up in a home where she was cherished, where people would offer her love without question. But in this moment, with Agatha and Nicky, she realized that maybe she could have that now.

 

The tears she’d been fighting finally fell, but they were tears of gratitude. She had found a family, and it was right here with her.

 

 

After the emotional moment with Nicky, there was a brief silence that settled in the room, as Agatha and Rio busied themselves in the kitchen, tidying up everything while Nicky played in the living room. Rio, still feeling a mixture of emotions, looked at Agatha with a kind of quiet understanding in her eyes. Agatha met her gaze, her hand still resting gently on Rio’s.

 

“Nicky’s right,” Agatha said softly. “We’re already like family. Maybe it’s time we stop keeping this a secret, at least at home.”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, her mind racing. She had never let anyone this close before, never let herself be vulnerable enough to share her heart, but with Agatha, everything felt different. The way she looked at her, the way she had supported her—it all felt like a promise, one Rio wasn’t ready to break.

 

“You think so?” Rio asked, her voice low.

 

Agatha nodded, her gaze steady. “Yes. We don’t have to hide anymore. And Nicky—he’s to most important person in the world to me. I think it’s only fair we let him know the truth.”

 

Rio took a deep breath. She knew it wouldn’t be easy, but she trusted Agatha, and more importantly, she trusted Nicky. If they were really going to make this work—if they were really going to be a family—there couldn’t be any more secrets.

 

“Okay,” Rio said softly, giving Agatha a small, reassuring smile. “Let’s do it. But we have to make sure it’s the right time.”

 

Agatha squeezed her hand, her eyes full of warmth and affection. “I think now’s perfect.”

 

Rio felt a sense of peace settle over her. This was the right moment. There would never be a perfect time, but this felt right.

 

Agatha moved, smoothing out her shirt, and turned to Nicky with a smile. “Hey, buddy,” she said, her voice soft but filled with warmth. “There’s something we need to tell you.”

 

Nicky stopped, looking up at Agatha with curiosity, his wide eyes attentive.

 

Rio followed Agatha’s lead, standing up beside her. She could feel her heart beat a little faster, but she remained calm, looking at Nicky with the same tenderness. Agatha started, “You know how we’ve been spending a lot of time together?” she asked him gently.

 

Nicky nodded eagerly. “Yeah! You and Miss Rio are always together now. It’s cool.”

 

Rio exchanged a quick glance with Agatha, their silent understanding clear. It was time. Agatha gave her nod, encouraging her to say what came naturally.

 

“Well,” Rio began, her voice warm but a little unsure, “Your Mama and I… we’ve been seeing each other for a while now. We’re not just friends. We’re, uh… together.”

 

Nicky’s face scrunched in confusion, and he tilted his head, clearly trying to process what Rio and Agatha had just told him.

 

“I know you’re together, you’re standing side by side. I know what ‘together’ means silly. I am six, you know!” he said, his voice filled with innocence and confusion.

 

Agatha chuckled at his confusion and exchanged a glance with Rio, and Rio felt her heart race slightly. She smiled at Nicky, realizing this wasn’t just a casual conversation anymore—this was a new chapter for all of them.

 

“Well,” Rio started, taking a seat next to Nicky, her voice gentle, “not exactly. It means that your Mama and I are… more than friends. We care about each other a lot. Like, a lot.”

 

Agatha nodded, sitting down beside them. “We’re a couple, Nicky. That means we’re together in a special way. We love each other.”

 

Nicky blinked a few times, still unsure of the concept. “You… love each other?” he asked slowly, trying to wrap his mind around it.

 

Rio smiled warmly at him. “Yes, Nicky. We love each other. Like how you love your mama or your friends. But it’s a different kind of love. It’s the kind of love that makes us want to be with each other all the time.”

 

Agatha added softly, “When two people love each other, they want to spend time together and help each other. It’s a bond that’s really special.”

 

Nicky thought for a moment, his brows furrowing as he processed the new information. Then his face lit up, and he clapped his hands together.

 

“That’s awesome!” he exclaimed, jumping up in his seat. “You guys are like, two princesses that kiss at the end? It’s so cool!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh at how Nicky had put simple words almost immediately even though they had been trying to explain in over complicated ways, and she felt a weight lift off her chest. “Yeah, I guess we are.”

 

Agatha leaned down to kiss the top of Nicky’s head, her heart full. “We just wanted you to know, because you’re so important to us. You’re part of this too, Nicky. You’re my little prince.”

 

Nicky beamed at both of them, and Rio felt her heart swell with affection. “I’m happy you guys are happy. You make each other smile all the time.”

 

Agatha laughed softly, her eyes sparkling. “You’re right, kiddo. We do.”

 

Rio smiled, a sense of relief washing over her. It had been a big step, but with Nicky’s approval, it felt like a burden had been lifted. No more hiding. Not here, at least.

 

Agatha looked at Nicky, her tone softening as she leaned in slightly. “Nicky, there’s one more thing we need to talk about,” she said, her voice gentle but serious. “This… this thing between Rio and me, it’s something that has to stay a secret for now. We can’t tell anyone else yet, okay?”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened, clearly puzzled by this new instruction. “Why?”

 

Rio was quick to explain, not really wanting to explain the power dynamics at play here. “Well, Nicky, sometimes adults have to keep certain things private, even if they’re really happy about them. It’s just a little secret for now. But we promise you, it’s not because we don’t trust you. It’s just the way things need to be for now.”

 

Agatha nodded, her expression serious but warm. “We’re still figuring some things out. But when the time is right, we’ll tell people, including your friends, okay? But for now, it’s just between us.”

 

Nicky nodded slowly, processing it all. He looked at them both, clearly not fully understanding why it had to be a secret but trusting them. “Okay, I can keep it secret. I won’t tell anyone. But you have to promise me that if I ever have questions, I can ask you.”

 

Agatha smiled, her heart swelling with love and pride. “Of course, Nicky. You can always come to us with questions. And when the time is right, you’ll know all the answers. We just need a little bit of time. Can we count on you to keep our secret for now?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up with a grin, a mix of excitement and pride at being trusted. “I promise! I can keep a secret!”

 

Rio reached out and gave him a hug. “You’re the best, buddy.”

 

Nicky squeezed her back and then looked up at Agatha. “I’m glad you and Rio are happy together, Mama. I think you’re a good team!”

 

Agatha smiled warmly, feeling her heart fill with affection for Nicky. “Thanks, my love. That means more than you know.”

 

With that, the conversation settled into a comfortable, unspoken understanding. The secret was safe with Nicky, and the love they shared, though hidden for now, was strong and real. It felt like a small but significant step in the right direction.

 

*

*

*

You’re Mine

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

At nightfall, in the rigging and the aerial,

Is a voice descanting (though not to the ear,

The murmuring shell of time, and not in any language)

'Fare forward, you who think that you are voyaging;

You are not those who saw the harbour

Receding, or those who will disembark.

 

            (T. S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The quiet hum of the library surrounded Rio and Alice as they sat side by side at a small table near the back, each absorbed in their work. The only sounds were the soft scratch of pens on paper and the occasional turning of pages. Rio’s mind was focused, her eyes scanning over the pages of her thesis once again, the words and concepts starting to blur together in a familiar, comfortable rhythm. She had been working on the same section for hours, the ideas of death and timelessness in modernist poetry coming together more clearly with each revision.

 

Alice, meanwhile, was deep into her own musicology thesis, scribbling notes as she worked through an article on early 20th-century composers. Her brow was furrowed in concentration, but she still managed to throw an occasional glance toward Rio.

 

Rio, however, wasn’t feeling as tense as she had been in the past. Despite the secretive nature of her relationship with Agatha, there wasn’t much to worry about. Things were good. She was happy—so much so that she had almost forgotten how stressed she’d been at the start of the semester. If anything, the secrecy only added to the thrill, and she trusted Agatha completely. It was almost like a game, one where they were in control, and Rio was enjoying every moment of it.

 

Alice’s voice broke through her thoughts. “You’ve been awfully quiet. What’s going on in that head of yours?”

 

Rio glanced up, surprised by the sudden question. “Oh, nothing much,” she said, a smile tugging at her lips. “Just thinking about… stuff.”

 

Alice raised an eyebrow, clearly not buying it. “Come on, spill. I’ve known you for years. What’s on your mind?”

 

Rio hesitated for only a moment before leaning back in her chair. “It’s Agatha,” she admitted, feeling a familiar warmth spread through her chest. “Things are good. Really good, actually. But I’m not stressed about it, if that’s what you’re thinking.”

 

Alice’s expression softened. “You’ve been glowing lately,” she said with a grin. “Something good’s clearly going on. And by the way, I’m not exactly blind to the vibes you two give off when you’re around each other.”

 

Rio laughed softly, her fingers tapping lightly on the table. “Yeah, well, it’s just… it’s nice. I think we’re good at keeping things low-key, you know? We’ve got everything under control.”

 

Alice nodded knowingly. “Good. I just wanted to make sure you weren’t getting too caught up in the secrecy. It’s easy to let that consume you. But you’ve always been good at keeping things balanced.”

 

Rio smiled, reassured by Alice’s words. “I don’t really feel like I’m struggling with anything right now. Honestly, everything’s kind of… perfect. But we’re still keeping it under wraps, just to be safe. You know, with her being my supervisor and all.”

 

Alice raised her hands in mock surrender. “Fair enough. No judgment here. I just hope you know what you’re doing. But you’re not exactly someone who rushes into things, so I trust you.”

 

Rio’s eyes sparkled with amusement. “I’m not rushing. But I’m not worried, either.”

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, clearly satisfied with Rio’s response. “Good. Because, honestly, I’m just waiting for you to tell me about the epic love story that’s unfolding. I can already see the movie in my head. It’s so clear how much she cares about you.”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “Well, don’t get too excited. It’s not like we’re making a grand statement here. But, yeah, she does.” She looked down at her notes, absently tapping her pen against the paper again. “It’s just… I don’t want to mess things up, you know? I don’t want to risk everything.”

 

Alice sighed, shaking her head in disbelief. “Rio, I don’t think you’re going to mess anything up. You’re smart, and Agatha’s smart, and you two are clearly meant to be in each other’s lives. It’s not always going to be easy, but I think it’s worth it.”

 

Rio nodded. “We’re just… happy.”

 

Alice smirked, clearly not convinced, but didn’t press further. “I’ll take your word for it. Now, let’s get back to work. I still need to finish my analysis of Stravinsky’s Rite of Spring, and I’m pretty sure I’m going to lose my mind if I don’t make some progress. And as much as I’d love to keep discussing your love life, I think we’re both here to get some thesis work done. And I want to see you graduate, so… focus!”

 

Rio laughed, turning back to her own work. “Agreed. Let’s make some progress before we both go crazy.”

 

They both returned to their respective theses, the comforting sound of pencils and pens scratching on paper filling the space between them. For the first time in a while, Rio felt completely at ease, her focus sharp, her thoughts clear. Everything felt right.

 

 

As Agatha stood at the front of the classroom, lecturing on the complexities of post-war poetry, her mind wandered just a little. She had been feeling a subtle shift in the air around her and Rio lately. It was only natural — things between them had become more intense, more real. And despite their efforts to keep their relationship under wraps on campus, Agatha couldn’t help but feel a growing sense of pride whenever she saw Rio in class.

 

She glanced toward Rio, who was sitting in the front row, absorbed in the lecture. Her thoughtful gaze was fixed on Agatha, but for a moment, Agatha noticed a subtle interaction at the edge of her attention.

 

A student—one of the quieter ones, who had a tendency to hang around after class asking questions—was leaning a little too close to Rio. Agatha had seen him around before, but today, he seemed to be lingering a bit longer than usual. His smile was easy, almost charming, and he was talking to Rio with an intensity that Agatha could feel even from a distance.

 

Rio, in contrast, was her usual self. Polite, smiling, but distant enough that Agatha could tell she wasn’t engaging in any deeper conversation. And yet, Agatha could see the way the student’s hand brushed the edge of Rio’s desk, the way he leaned closer than was strictly necessary. Agatha couldn’t hear their words, but she could see the look in the student’s eyes, the unspoken intention.

 

A small knot of irritation tightened in Agatha’s chest, something she hadn’t expected to feel. It wasn’t just jealousy—it was a protective instinct, one that took her by surprise. Her mind raced briefly: Why did he feel the need to flirt with her? Doesn’t he know she’s taken? And even if she wasn’t she wouldn’t even be interested anyway.

 

As Agatha continued teaching, she found it difficult to focus. Her gaze kept drifting back to Rio, watching for any signs that she was uncomfortable. And though Rio didn’t appear to be upset, Agatha noticed her posture shift slightly, a subtle defensiveness in the way she crossed her arms, and the slight narrowing of her eyes when the student got too close.

 

It was enough for Agatha to take note, to file away in her mind. After class, she would make sure to check in with Rio, see how she was doing, and maybe even offer some space if she needed it. But she wasn’t going to let this pass by without saying something. Not when she knew the effect it had on her, not when she knew how she felt about Rio.

 

The class ended, but Agatha’s mind kept turning over what had just happened. She felt a slight sense of relief when Rio stood up, but her heart didn’t quite settle until Rio walked toward her after class once all the other students had left, her eyes meeting Agatha’s with that quiet understanding they shared. Agatha closed the door, under the pretense of discussing Rio’s thesis. Agatha’s hand instinctively reached out, grabbing her wrist gently to pull her toward her.

 

Agatha let out a breath she hadn’t realized she’d been holding. “Everything okay?” she asked, keeping her voice neutral but gentle.

 

Rio looked at her with that soft smile of hers, the one that never failed to calm Agatha’s nerves and started very quietly, out of ear of everyone else. “Yeah, just a student asking about the material. I don’t think he was flirting, if that’s what you’re worried about.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, clearly disagreeing, but didn’t miss the way Rio’s lips curled into a small, teasing grin. The tension in her chest slowly loosened.

 

“I guess I was just being a little overprotective,” Agatha admitted with a quiet chuckle, feeling the warmth spread across her cheeks.

 

Rio shrugged, giving her a knowing look. “I can handle myself,” she said softly. “But I appreciate the concern.”

 

They stood there for a moment, the weight of the unspoken between them hanging in the air. It was a mix of relief and the odd, lingering sense of protectiveness that Agatha couldn’t shake. In that moment, though, it felt good to know that Rio was aware of it, that they could talk about it, that it wasn’t something that needed to remain unspoken for long.

 

Agatha smiled at her, that protective feeling now tempered by affection. “I know. But I still like to make sure you’re okay.”

 

Rio’s smile grew a little wider, and for a moment, it felt like the world outside the classroom didn’t matter. It was just the two of them, as it always should be.

 

“I’m fine,” Rio assured her, the warmth in her gaze reassuring Agatha that she wasn’t uncomfortable.

 

Rio looked at her, a slight question in her eyes, but there was warmth in her gaze. “What’s going on, Agatha?”

 

Agatha took a deep breath, trying to steady the rush of emotions that had been swirling inside her all class long. “You’re mine, Rio. And I’m not going to let anyone else try anything with you,” she said, her voice low but steady, laced with that same intensity she hadn’t been able to hide.

 

Rio’s eyes softened, and she tilted her head slightly, a small, teasing smile tugging at the corner of her lips. “Jealous, huh?” she asked, her voice gentle but amused, as if she could read the emotions coursing through Agatha without needing to hear every word.

 

Agatha felt the heat rise to her face, the admission tugging at her chest. She hadn’t realized how much it had affected her, how fiercely she felt about Rio—about keeping her close, keeping her safe, and keeping her to herself. “Maybe,” Agatha murmured, “a little.”

 

Rio’s smile widened as she stepped closer, her presence wrapping around Agatha like a warm embrace. “I like it,” she said softly. “I like that you care. It’s kind of… endearing.”

 

Agatha’s heart fluttered at the softness in Rio’s voice. It was strange to hear her say it like that, to realize that Rio found her jealousy endearing instead of off-putting. It made the whole emotion feel more natural, less of a burden.

 

“I just…” Agatha’s words faltered for a moment, unsure if she should voice the thoughts in her head. But she didn’t need to say much more. The way Rio was looking at her, with that soft, loving gaze, told her everything.

 

Rio reached up, brushing a strand of Agatha’s hair behind her ear. “You don’t have to worry, Agatha,” she said quietly. “I’m here. And I’m not going anywhere.”

 

Agatha couldn’t help but smile at that—at the quiet reassurance Rio always seemed to give her, even when she was being protective, even when she felt insecure. Rio knew exactly what to say to calm her.

 

“You’re mine,” Agatha repeated, her voice a little more confident now, as if she was reminding herself as much as she was reaffirming it to Rio. “And no one else gets to have you.”

 

Rio’s smile grew, her eyes sparkling with something a little mischievous. “Well, that’s a relief,” she teased, “because I’m pretty sure I’m already taken.”

 

Agatha let out a small laugh, the tension in her chest finally easing as Rio’s words wrapped around her like a warm, comforting blanket. “You’re absolutely right,” she replied, her hand sliding to Rio’s waist. “And I’m not letting go.”

 

Rio leaned in, brushing her lips against Agatha’s in a soft, lingering kiss. “Good,” she whispered, pulling back just enough to look Agatha in the eye. “Because I’m not letting go either.”

 

And in that moment, Agatha felt a sense of peace settle over her. It didn’t matter who else might try or what anyone else might think—Rio was hers, and that was all that mattered. And, for the first time in a long time, she felt like she could finally relax into that certainty.

 

 

Later that afternoon, as Rio walked down the hallway between classes, she felt a presence behind her. She turned to see Maya – again -  standing there with an almost casual smile on her face, as though time hadn’t passed and as if things hadn’t ended badly between them years ago, as though she hadn’t been clear enough a few weeks ago when she had asked to stop bothering her.

 

Rio stiffened for a moment, a flicker of discomfort passing through her. It wasn’t the first time Maya had tried to get in touch since their breakup, but it was the first time they’d crossed paths in person since that discussion. Rio had tried to move past the wounds Maya had left, but the way Maya was looking at her now, with that same flirtatious glint in her eye, made her heart twist with a combination of irritation and old scars. Rio’s heart fluttered in an uncomfortable way. Maya had always known how to get under her skin, how to use just the right words to make her second-guess herself. But not anymore. Rio had moved past that version of herself—the one that had fallen for Maya’s charm despite the hurt she’d caused.

 

Maya stepped closer, her voice soft but dripping with an all-too-familiar charm. “Hey, Rio,” she said, “It’s been a while. How’ve you been?”

 

Rio’s first instinct was to walk away. But the conversation, the memories, they had to be addressed, because apparently, Maya had trouble understanding simple requests. She wasn’t going to let Maya make her feel small or like there was something between them again. She took a deep breath, trying to keep her voice steady, trying not to show the mix of emotions that were threatening to surface.

 

“I’ve been good,” Rio replied coolly, her eyes narrowing slightly. “You should go. I’m not interested in talking. I already told you that.”

 

But Maya wasn’t deterred. She leaned against the wall, smirking a little as she gave Rio a sideways glance. “Come on, Rio,” she said, her voice suddenly teasing. “You don’t have to be so cold. I know we ended things badly, but we could have some fun again, don’t you think?”

 

Rio’s stomach twisted with anger and disbelief. The audacity. She clenched her fists at her sides, her expression hardening. “I’m taken,” she said, her voice sharp, her gaze unwavering. “And I’m very not available for you.”

 

Maya’s eyebrows lifted, a glint of surprise in her eyes. “Oh? You’ve moved on that quickly?”

 

Rio nodded. “Yes, I have.” She took a breath, trying to push the nerves away. “And I’m not interested in anything you have to say to me, Maya.”

 

Maya studied her for a moment, her expression unreadable. “So, you’re telling me there’s someone else? That’s… interesting.” She glanced around, almost as if looking for clues, but Rio kept her face neutral, unwilling to give anything more away.

 

“I don’t need to explain myself,” Rio said sharply. “I’m happy with where and who I am, and I’m not looking back. Leave me alone, now.”

 

For a moment, Maya didn’t say anything. She looked as though she was processing Rio’s words, but it was hard to tell what she was really thinking. Finally, she let out a short laugh, shaking her head. “Okay, Rio. I get it. I just thought we might have had something left. But I guess not.”

 

Rio nodded once, firmly, not giving in to the old doubts creeping in. “No. There’s nothing left between us.”

 

With a frustrated sigh, Maya turned and began to walk away, but not without one last comment. “Well, good luck with your… new thing, Rio. Don’t come crawling back when it doesn’t work out.”

 

Rio didn’t reply. She just watched as Maya disappeared down the hallway, feeling a weight lift off her chest as the conversation ended. She felt stronger now, knowing that she had stood her ground.

 

As Rio turned to leave, she spotted Agatha standing just a few steps down the hallway, standing nearby, her arms crossed and her expression unreadable. Her heart skipped a beat. The fact that Agatha hadn’t intervened made Rio’s stomach tighten with guilt, but at the same time, Agatha’s presence—silent and strong—was a reminder that she didn’t need to prove herself to anyone, especially not to Maya. Agatha knew the truth.

 

“I’m sorry you had to hear that,” Rio said quietly, walking toward her, her voice a little shaky but trying to sound steady. “I didn’t think she would show up again. She just doesn’t know when to quit.”

 

Agatha gave her a small, almost imperceptible smile. “You don’t need to say anything, Rio,” she said softly. “You made it clear. I know who you are, and I know what we have.”

 

Rio sighed in relief, her body relaxing a little. “I’m just… glad you’re here. I didn’t want her to make it seem like I was still interested. I’m not.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, her hand gently resting on Rio’s arm. “You don’t have to explain yourself,” she said, her tone warm but firm. “You don’t owe her – or me -  anything. And you don’t have to fight for me, either. I already know.”

 

Rio smiled softly at that, feeling the tension ease away. In that moment, Maya’s attempt to intrude on their world seemed small, insignificant. Agatha’s steady presence made everything feel right again.

 

“Thanks,” Rio whispered, her voice filled with gratitude. “I’m really glad I have you.”

 

Agatha squeezed her arm gently, her gaze filled with warmth and affection. “I’m not going anywhere,” she said, her words soft but full of certainty. Rio’s heart fluttered at the sincerity in Agatha’s voice. She didn’t need to explain anything more to Maya. Agatha already understood her completely. She didn’t need to look back.

 

And with that, Rio knew that no matter who tried to come back into her life—no matter what Maya said—Agatha was the one she was staying with. The only one who mattered. Agatha was her future, and that was exactly what she wanted.

 

 

The rest of the day felt lighter for Rio. After her encounter with Maya and the quiet reassurance from Agatha, she spent her time focusing on her theses and preparing for the week ahead. But her thoughts often drifted back to Agatha’s touch, her calm presence, and the way she made everything seem manageable.

 

Later that evening, as Rio settled into her apartment, she found herself staring at her phone, smiling softly at the last message she’d received from Agatha: “Proud of you. Rest tonight, okay? I’ll call you later. Love you.”

 

The words warmed her. She texted back quickly: “Thank you, love you too.”

 

Just as she put her phone down, a knock sounded at her door. Frowning, she padded over and peeked through the peephole. To her surprise, it was Alice.

 

Rio opened the door, leaning against the frame. “Hey, Al. Didn’t expect to see you tonight.”

 

Alice strolled in without waiting for an invitation, as was her habit. She dropped her bag on the nearest chair and flopped onto Rio’s couch. “I figured you’d need some company after what I saw earlier.”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow as she closed the door. “What do you mean?”

 

Alice turned, sitting up straight. “I saw Maya in the hallway. She looked pissed, which can only mean one thing—you told her off.”

 

Rio smirked. “You’re not wrong. She tried to flirt, but I shut her down.”

 

“Good.” Alice grinned, crossing her arms. “I hope you told her how very unavailable you are now.”

 

“Of course, I did.” Rio sat down next to her, shrugging lightly. “She’s not my problem anymore.”

 

Alice studied her for a moment, her grin softening. “You’ve changed, you know. You’re so much more… sure of yourself these days. Is it because of her?”

 

Rio didn’t need to ask who “her” was. She nodded, her lips curving into a smile. “She helps. A lot. But I think I’ve been learning to stand up for myself for a while now. Agatha just… makes me feel safe being me.”

 

Alice reached over, squeezing Rio’s hand. “Good. You deserve that. And honestly, you two are disgustingly cute together.”

 

Rio laughed, nudging Alice playfully. “Shut up. You don’t even know half of it.”

 

“Don’t need to,” Alice replied smugly. “It’s written all over your face every time you talk about her.”

 

Before Rio could respond, her phone buzzed. She glanced at the screen, her heart skipping a beat when she saw Agatha’s name.

 

“Speak of the devil,” Alice teased, leaning over to peek at the screen. “I’ll leave you two lovebirds to it.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but didn’t stop smiling as she answered the call. Alice waved dramatically on her way out, muttering something about how cute they were.

 

“Hey,” Rio said softly, sinking back into the couch.

 

“Hi,” Agatha’s voice came through warm and familiar. “How are you feeling? I’ve been thinking about you.”

 

“I’m good,” Rio replied. “Better, actually. Today turned out alright.”

 

“I’m glad to hear that,” Agatha said, her tone softening. “I wanted to check in. And to tell you how proud I am of you for standing your ground with Maya.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled. “Thank you. It means a lot, hearing that from you.”

 

They talked for a while longer, their conversation drifting from serious to light and back again. Agatha had a way of making even the most mundane things feel significant, and Rio found herself holding onto every word. Agatha told her everything about Nicky’s project in science class, and Rio promised she would come over soon to help him and explain what photosynthesis was and how it made the plants better.

 

When they finally said goodnight, Rio felt lighter than she had in days. Agatha made everything seem simpler, clearer. And no matter what challenges lay ahead—Maya, their secret, or anything else—Rio knew she wasn’t facing them alone.

 

 

The following day brought a new sense of clarity for Rio. She started her morning early, determined to dive into her work with renewed focus. Between her thesis, her dance classes, and her time with Agatha, she felt like she was juggling a lot—but with Agatha’s steady presence in her life, everything felt manageable.

 

As she arrived on campus, Rio found herself glancing around for any sign of Maya. Though she didn’t regret standing her ground, the encounter had left her a little wary. Maya was unpredictable, and the last thing Rio wanted was for her to stir up any unnecessary drama, especially with Agatha so close to everything.

 

The thought brought a faint smile to Rio’s lips. Agatha. Their relationship, though still a secret to most, had been a constant source of comfort and strength. She loved the quiet moments they shared, the stolen glances and fleeting touches that spoke volumes. It made everything worth it.

 

 

Later that afternoon, Rio was wrapping up her notes in the library when she got a text from Agatha:

 

“Can you stop by my office before you head home? Nothing urgent, just want to see you.”

 

Rio’s lips curved into a smile as she quickly typed back: “On my way.”

 

She packed her things and made her way across campus, her heart beating a little faster with each step. When she reached Agatha’s office, the door was slightly ajar, and she could hear the faint rustle of papers inside.

 

Rio knocked gently before stepping in. Agatha looked up from her desk, her glasses perched on the bridge of her nose. The sight made Rio’s heart flutter—it was such a small, simple detail, but it was so quintessentially Agatha.

 

“Hey,” Rio said softly, closing the door behind her.

 

Agatha’s expression brightened, a smile spreading across her lips. “Hey yourself. How was your day?”

 

Rio shrugged, setting her bag down in the corner. “Productive, I guess. And seeing you makes it better.”

 

Agatha chuckled, standing up and crossing the room to meet her. She wrapped her arms around Rio’s waist, pulling her close. “Flatterer.”

 

“Only for you,” Rio teased, her tone light, though her eyes betrayed the depth of her affection.

 

They stayed like that for a moment, wrapped in each other’s warmth. Then Agatha pulled back slightly, her expression turning more serious.

 

“How are you, really?” she asked, her eyes searching Rio’s.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment before answering. “I’m okay. Better than I was. I think… things are starting to settle again.”

 

Agatha nodded, brushing a strand of hair from Rio’s face. “Good. I’ve been thinking about you a lot since… everything with Maya.”

 

Rio sighed, resting her forehead against Agatha’s shoulder. “It’s fine. I’m fine. She doesn’t matter anymore.”

 

“I know,” Agatha murmured, her hand rubbing soothing circles on Rio’s back. “But you matter to me. And I’ll always make sure you’re okay.”

 

Rio pulled back just enough to look up at her, a soft smile playing on her lips. “You’re too good to me, you know that?”

 

“Not possible,” Agatha replied, her tone warm but firm.

 

They stayed together a little longer, their conversation drifting to lighter topics. Agatha shared a funny story about Nicky’s antics the night before, and Rio laughed until her sides hurt.

 

When it was time for Rio to leave, Agatha kissed her softly before opening the door. “Text me when you get home, okay?”

 

“I will,” Rio promised, her heart full as she stepped back into the hallway.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Not so sure about this chapter, but I really really love the next one, so stay tuned!

The Conference

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

The river is within us, the sea is all about us;

The sea is the land's edge also, the granite

Into which it reaches, the beaches where it tosses

Its hints of earlier and other creation:

The starfish, the horseshoe crab, the whale's backbone;

The pools where it offers to our curiosity

The more delicate algae and the sea anemone.

 

                  (T.S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The letter arrived on a crisp Thursday morning, tucked neatly into Rio’s campus mailbox. She hadn’t expected much—a reminder about library hours or a department circular, maybe—but as she unfolded the thick, cream-colored paper and read the header, her heart skipped a beat.

 

Dear Ms. Vidal,

We are delighted to invite you to present your research at the upcoming Regional Literature Scholars’ Conference, an event dedicated to celebrating and showcasing the groundbreaking work of the most promising doctoral candidates in the field of literary studies. Your research has been recognized for its originality, depth, and significant contribution to a new understanding of Modernist Poetry . It is with great enthusiasm that we extend this invitation, acknowledging your exceptional work and the impact it has on advancing scholarship in the humanities. This is an invaluable opportunity to share your insights with an audience of esteemed academics, fellow researchers, and peers, fostering discussions that may further enrich your work.

 

Her eyes skimmed over the rest, but the words barely registered. She was holding an official invitation to one of the most prestigious academic events for students like her.

 

Rio stared at the letter for a moment, her mind racing. She’d heard about the conference—only a handful of PhD students from each university were invited each year, chosen for the promise their research showed and the impact it could have on the field.

 

Her first instinct was to text Agatha, but the thought of seeing her reaction in person was too enticing. She tucked the letter into her bag, grabbed her books, and made her way to Agatha’s office.

 

 

Agatha looked up as Rio stepped through the door, a soft smile already forming. “To what do I owe this lovely surprise?” she asked, leaning back in her chair.

 

Rio bit her lip, trying and failing to hide her excitement. “I got something today,” she said, pulling the letter from her bag and handing it over.

 

Agatha’s eyes flicked over the paper, her smile growing wider with each sentence she read. By the time she reached the end, she looked up, her expression brimming with pride.

 

“Rio,” she said, her voice soft and full of warmth, “this is incredible.”

 

“It’s just an invitation,” Rio said, brushing a strand of hair behind her ear. “I haven’t even presented yet.”

 

“Just an invitation?” Agatha repeated, shaking her head. She set the letter down carefully on her desk and stood, crossing the room to close the door before pulling Rio into a tight embrace.

 

“This is a big deal,” Agatha said, her voice low as she kissed Rio’s temple. “Only a handful of students get invited each year. It’s an acknowledgment of how brilliant your work is.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed under Agatha’s praise. “You helped a lot, you know,” she murmured. “I wouldn’t have gotten here without you.”

 

Agatha pulled back just enough to look into Rio’s eyes. “Don’t you dare downplay your own hard work. This is yourachievement, Rio.”

 

They spent the rest of the afternoon discussing the conference. Agatha helped Rio brainstorm how to structure her presentation, offering suggestions while giving her space to make the final decisions.

 

“Do you think you’ll attend?” Rio asked as they worked, glancing up at Agatha.

 

Agatha hesitated for a moment before nodding. “I am invited every year to be with the faculty. But I can just opt out this year. If you want me there, I’ll be there. But I don’t want to put any extra pressure on you.”

 

Rio smiled. “I think I’d like it if you were there.”

 

“Then it’s settled,” Agatha said with a grin and a kiss on Rio’s nose.

 

As Rio left Agatha’s office that day, she felt a renewed sense of confidence. The conference wasn’t just an opportunity to share her research—it was a chance to prove to herself that she belonged in the world of academia. And knowing Agatha would be there, quietly cheering her on, made it all the more special.

 

 

The days leading up to the conference felt like an eternity for Rio. The weight of presenting her work, of standing before a room full of scholars and peers, pressed heavily on her chest. Every time she thought about it—what to say, how to say it, the inevitable questions—her stomach twisted into a knot.

 

By Monday, she’d taken over her small apartment with a flurry of notes, drafts, and annotated texts. The sound of her pacing echoed through the space as she rehearsed her presentation out loud, pausing frequently to rewrite entire sections.

 

When Agatha called that evening, Rio barely had the energy to answer.

 

“How’s my favorite future academic star doing?” Agatha asked, her tone light.

 

Rio groaned in response. “A mess. This is going to be a disaster. What if I stumble over my words? What if someone asks a question I can’t answer? What if—”

 

“Rio,” Agatha interrupted gently, her voice steady. “Take a breath. This is not going to be a disaster.”

 

“You don’t know that,” Rio muttered, collapsing onto her couch.

 

“I do,” Agatha replied firmly. “You’re brilliant, and you’ve put so much work into this. You have nothing to prove to anyone but yourself. This isn’t about being perfect—it’s about sharing your perspective. That’s what conferences are for.”

 

Rio let out a small, shaky laugh. “You make it sound so easy.”

 

“It’s not easy,” Agatha said. “But you’re not alone. I’ll be there, remember? And you’ll do beautifully.”

 

 

On Wednesday, Agatha stopped by Rio’s apartment after class with a bag of groceries and a determined glint in her eye.

 

“You’re eating properly, right?” she asked as she set the bag down on the counter.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow. “Define ‘properly.’”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes affectionately. “Sit. I’ll make us dinner. You need a break.”

 

Rio obeyed, slumping into a chair as Agatha moved around the kitchen with practiced ease. The smell of pasta and fresh garlic soon filled the air, and Rio felt some of the tension ease from her shoulders.

 

As they ate, Agatha reached across the table to take Rio’s hand. “I’ve been in your shoes,” she said softly. “And I know how scary it feels. But I also know that you’re ready for this. Trust yourself, love.”

 

Rio squeezed her hand, a flicker of gratitude warming her chest.

 

 

By Friday night, Rio was a bundle of nerves again. She’d gone over her presentation so many times that the words had started to lose meaning, and yet she still felt unprepared.

 

Agatha came over late that evening, armed with her usual calm and a bottle of tea Rio liked. They sat on the couch, Rio curled into Agatha’s side as she vented her worries.

 

“What if I freeze up?” she whispered.

 

“Then take a breath and start again,” Agatha said. “You’re allowed to be human.”

 

“What if they think my research is shallow?”

 

“They won’t,” Agatha said with certainty. “Your work is nuanced and thoughtful. Anyone who hears you speak will see that.”

 

Rio let out a long sigh, leaning further into Agatha’s warmth. “I don’t know what I’d do without you,” she murmured.

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to her temple. “You’d be just as brilliant,” she said softly. “But I’m glad I get to be here for you anyway.”

 

 

On Saturday morning, Rio stood in front of her open closet, staring blankly at the array of clothes. Nothing felt right. Her usual style—casual and slightly eclectic—didn’t exactly scream “serious academic.” But the idea of dressing too formally made her feel like she was wearing someone else’s skin.

 

“Why is this so hard?” she muttered to herself, pulling out a navy blazer and holding it up to the light. “Do I look like a professor? Or like I’m playing dress-up?”

 

She tossed it onto the bed with a sigh, then pulled out a flowy forest green blouse. It was one of her favorites—soft, comfortable, and a little bold. “This says ‘confident,’ right?” she mused, eyeing it critically.

 

Her phone buzzed on the nightstand, and she glanced at the screen: Agatha.

 

“Still staring at your closet?” Agatha’s amused voice greeted her when she picked up.

 

“How did you know?” Rio asked, flopping onto the bed next to her growing pile of discarded options.

 

“Because you’re overthinking,” Agatha said warmly. “And because you told me you were going to pick out your outfit this morning, which means you’ve probably been at it for hours.”

 

Rio groaned. “Nothing feels right. I want to look professional, but not boring. Smart, but not like I’m trying too hard. And also, I need to feel like me. Is that too much to ask?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly. “Not at all. What are you considering?”

 

Rio glanced at the mess of clothing. “Uh, everything I own, apparently. Right now, I’ve got a blazer, a green blouse, and some black pants. But I’m not sure if it’s too…safe?”

 

“That sounds perfect,” Agatha said. “Professional but with a bit of personality. And you’ll feel more confident if you’re comfortable.”

 

Rio hesitated. “You think so?”

 

“I know so,” Agatha assured her. “Besides, the real showstopper isn’t the outfit—it’s you.”

 

Rio felt a smile tug at her lips. “You’re biased.”

 

“Absolutely,” Agatha said without missing a beat. “But I’m also right. Wear the green blouse—it’s one of my favorites on you.”

 

Rio blushed, grateful Agatha couldn’t see her reaction through the phone. “Okay, green blouse it is. Thanks, Agatha.”
