“Anytime,” Agatha said warmly. “Now finish getting ready so you can focus on being brilliant.”

 

Hanging up, Rio stood and held the blouse up again, seeing it in a new light. She paired it with the black blazer and black pants, slipping on her boots for a final touch.

 

Looking in the mirror, she adjusted the collar of the blouse and smoothed down the blazer. It was simple but sharp, and it felt like her.

 

For the first time that day, she smiled. “Okay, can do it.”

 

 

By the time Saturday afternoon arrived, Rio still felt nervous, but Agatha’s steady presence had given her the confidence to face the day. As she stood in front of the mirror, adjusting her blazer, she caught a glimpse of herself—poised and ready.

 

Agatha appeared behind her, circling her arms around her waist and placing her chin on her shoulder. “You’ve got this,” she said simply.

 

And for the first time that week, Rio believed her.

 

 

The conference room buzzed with a low hum of conversations, the air heavy with academic anticipation. Rio adjusted the lanyard around her neck for the hundredth time, her fingers fidgeting with the plastic badge that displayed her name and the title of her thesis. She was nervous, but she reminded herself that she’d prepared for this. She belonged here.

 

Her gaze swept over the growing audience as she stood near the side of the stage, half-hidden by a thick curtain. The conference room was filling quickly, and familiar faces were scattered among the crowd.

 

Her heart skipped when she spotted Lilia sitting toward the middle, her warm, encouraging smile visible even from this distance. Next to her, Alice and Jen waved enthusiastically, clearly more excited than nervous on her behalf. Rio chuckled softly, grateful for their presence.

 

Then her eyes drifted toward the back of the room, where the professors stood in a tight-knit group, chatting amongst themselves. Agatha was there, poised and elegant in a tailored suit, her sharp intellect evident even in her posture. For a moment, Rio felt her nerves spike again. It wasn’t just presenting her work that made her anxious—it was presenting it in front of Agatha.

 

As if sensing her gaze, Agatha looked up and their eyes met. A soft, reassuring smile curved Agatha’s lips, and Rio felt a wave of warmth replace her nerves.

 

Before she could fully process it, Agatha excused herself from the group and began weaving her way toward Rio. Her heart thudded in her chest as she realized Agatha wasn’t stopping at the edge of the stage. Instead, she slipped behind the curtain, finding Rio in the quiet, secluded corner where she stood.

 

“You’re going to be brilliant,” Agatha said softly, her voice filled with conviction.

 

Rio’s breath hitched. “I—thank you. I just—seeing you here, with all of them…it’s intimidating.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, her hands finding Rio’s. “You’ve worked so hard for this. No one in that room knows this material better than you. Trust yourself.”

 

Rio’s eyes darted to the curtain, nerves flaring at the thought of being seen. “We shouldn’t—”

 

“No one can see us,” Agatha murmured, her thumbs gently brushing over Rio’s knuckles. “And I couldn’t let you go up there without telling you how proud I am of you. Not as your professor, but as…me.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled. “Agatha…”

 

Agatha leaned in, her lips brushing Rio’s in a brief but tender kiss. “You’ve got this. And no matter what, I love you.”

 

Rio’s throat tightened with emotion, and she gave a small nod. “I love you, too.”

 

Agatha smiled, her hands lingering for a moment before she stepped back. “Now go out there and show them why you’re one of the most promising minds in the field.”

 

Rio straightened, her nerves momentarily forgotten in the warmth of Agatha’s words. With one last look, Agatha slipped back out toward the professors’ group, leaving Rio alone to take a deep, steadying breath.

 

 

The conference hall hummed with focused energy as Rio took her place at the podium, her notes laid out neatly before her. She gripped the edges of the lectern briefly, grounding herself. The spotlight illuminated her face, and for a moment, she couldn’t see past the bright light and the expectant silence.

 

Then she remembered Agatha’s words—You’ve got this.

 

Her heart steadied. Her voice, though quiet at first, found its rhythm as she began presenting her thesis work on death, mortality, and timelessness in Modernist poetry. Rio’s passion for her topic radiated as she deftly navigated complex theories, weaving in analyses of texts and poignant quotes that painted a vivid picture of her research.

 

From her vantage point among the professors, Agatha watched with a growing sense of pride. Rio had completely captivated the audience. Her confidence built with every word, her explanations clear, thoughtful, and brimming with insight. She moved seamlessly through her presentation, fielding questions from the panel of professors with poise.

 

At one point, a particularly challenging question was posed by a senior professor—an intimidating figure known for cutting remarks. Agatha tensed, but Rio didn’t falter. With a small smile, Rio responded with a nuanced answer that not only addressed the question but reframed it entirely, earning an approving nod from the professor.

 

Agatha’s chest swelled with pride. She couldn’t help the small smile tugging at her lips.

 

Toward the end of the presentation, Rio spoke about how literature reflects humanity’s attempts to reconcile with mortality, her words tinged with both academic rigor and personal resonance. She glanced briefly toward the audience, catching sight of Lilia, Alice, and Jen sitting rapt. Lilia smiled warmly, and Alice gave an encouraging thumbs-up.

 

Then, as Rio’s gaze drifted to the professors’ section, her eyes briefly met Agatha’s. Though it was a fleeting moment, it grounded her even further. The corners of Rio’s mouth lifted slightly before she turned back to her closing remarks.

 

When she finished, the room erupted in applause. Rio stepped away from the podium, a faint blush creeping up her neck as she returned to her seat.

 

Agatha didn’t clap with the same enthusiasm as Lilia or Alice—it wouldn’t have been professional—but her subtle smile and the pride gleaming in her eyes spoke volumes.

 

 

After the conference concluded, Agatha lingered with the other professors as Rio found herself surrounded by her small but dedicated cheering section. Alice practically threw herself at Rio in a hug, squeezing her tightly.

 

“You were brilliant!” Alice exclaimed, pulling back with a huge grin. “I mean, I always knew you were smart, but that? That was a whole other level!”

 

Rio laughed, her cheeks flushed from both the praise and lingering adrenaline. “Thanks, Al.”

 

Lilia stepped closer, her expression soft and proud. She didn’t rush in for a hug but placed a gentle hand on Rio’s arm. “You’ve come so far, my girl. You’ve done something incredible today,” she said. “You held that room in the palm of your hand. I couldn’t be prouder of you.”

 

Rio felt a lump rise in her throat, overwhelmed by the warmth in Lilia’s words. “It means so much to have you here. All of you,” she said, glancing between Lilia, Alice, and Jen, who was giving her a quieter but equally supportive smile.

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed. “Thank you. I—thank you all for coming. It means the world to me.”

 

“Honestly, I don’t know how you didn’t combust,” Alice said, her voice low but teasing. “Having Agatha—sorry, Dr. Harkness—watching you like that? She’s intense. I’d have melted.”

 

Rio bit her lip to suppress a laugh, especially when she caught the pointed look Alice gave her. She knew exactly what Alice was doing, but thankfully, Lilia stepped in.

 

“She’s proud of you too,” Lilia said gently. “She couldn’t stop smiling.”

 

Jen, catching onto the subtle undercurrent, raised an eyebrow but didn’t comment.

 

As if summoned by their conversation, Agatha appeared, walking toward the group with her characteristic grace and authority. Alice straightened immediately, smoothing her shirt like she was trying to make herself more presentable. When Agatha reached them, she placed a hand on Rio’s arm—subtle but grounding.

 

“Dr. Harkness!” Alice said, a little too loudly.

 

“Ms. Vidal,” Agatha said, her gaze sweeping over Rio warmly. “You were exceptional today. I couldn’t be prouder of how you carried yourself, and to be your supervisor.”

 

The gentle emphasis she placed on prouder made Rio’s heart skip a beat. Her smile widened, soft and private, meant just for Agatha even in the presence of others.

 

“Thank you,” Rio replied, her voice soft and full of meaning.

 

Lilia, standing close enough to catch the subtle exchange, hid her smirk. Alice, meanwhile, looked between them with barely concealed curiosity, her lips twitching as if she were holding back a comment.

 

“You should celebrate,” Agatha continued, her tone professional but kind. “This is an important milestone. I’ll leave you to it.”

 

With that, she gave the group a polite nod and stepped away.

 

Alice waited a beat before whispering loudly, “I mean, we know what that look was, right?”

 

Lilia gave her a sharp look. “Alice.”

 

“What?” Alice grinned, turning back to Rio. “Look, I’m just saying—it’s really nice to see someone appreciate you as much as you deserve.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t stop the smile tugging at her lips. “You promised not to say anything.”

 

“I didn’t say anything,” Alice replied, holding up her hands. “Just… implied. Heavily.”

 

Lilia laughed softly, pulling Rio into a brief hug. “Ignore her. You were more than great today, and that’s what matters.”

 

“Thanks, Lilia,” Rio said, her voice quieter now, touched by the support.

 

As they began to make plans for an early celebratory dinner, Rio glanced over to where Agatha stood speaking with some of her colleagues. Though she was keeping her distance, Rio could see the faintest hint of pride still lingering on Agatha’s face.

 

 

After the conference wrapped up, Lilia and Alice insisted on taking Rio out to celebrate. Jen had to leave for a lab commitment, but she’d made Rio promise to meet up later in the week for another toast. Lilia had immediately suggested a cozy little bar nearby that she frequented with some of her fellow book-clubbers.

 

The place had an inviting, laid-back atmosphere—low lighting, dark wood furniture, and the faint hum of jazz in the background. The three of them settled into a corner booth, Alice sliding in first with an exaggerated flourish.

 

“To our resident genius,” Alice declared, lifting her glass of cider after their drinks arrived. “You absolutely crushed it today, Rio.”

 

Rio blushed, fiddling with the rim of her glass. “Thanks, Al. But it wasn’t that big of a deal—”

 

“It was a big deal,” Lilia interjected, her tone firm but warm. “You presented months—no, years—of work to a room full of academics, held your ground during the questions, and left them all impressed. You deserve to celebrate this.”

 

Rio ducked her head, the familiar warmth of Lilia’s unwavering support filling her chest.

 

“Okay, fine,” she said, lifting her drink with a small grin. “To celebrating.”

 

“And to you being brilliant,” Alice added, tapping her glass against theirs.

 

They sipped their drinks, the atmosphere light and easy. Alice kept the mood lively, recounting a story from one of her band’s recent gigs that had gone hilariously wrong.

 

“So then, Jen’s amp just dies in the middle of the set,” Alice said, gesturing animatedly. “She’s standing there like, ‘This is fine,’ while I’m trying not to laugh my ass off because she’s glaring at me like it’s my fault. Meanwhile, Rio’s over there in the corner, completely unfazed, just keeping the rhythm going like a champ. I swear, she’s the only reason we didn’t lose the entire song.”

 

“Someone has to hold it together,” Rio said with a shrug, her lips twitching in amusement.

 

“That’s because you’re secretly the most responsible of all of us,” Alice teased.

 

Lilia chuckled, taking a sip of her drink. “I’ve known that for years.”

 

As the evening wore on, Alice eventually turned the conversation back to the conference.

 

“Okay, but real talk—how did it feel?” she asked, leaning forward on her elbows.

 

“Terrifying at first,” Rio admitted. “But then, once I started talking, it kind of… clicked. Like, I was so focused on explaining everything that I forgot to be nervous.”

 

“You looked completely in control,” Lilia said. “Confident. The room was hanging on your every word.”

 

Alice smirked. “I bet someone was hanging a little harder than the rest.”

 

Rio shot her a look, but the comment made her heart flutter anyway. Agatha’s pride and quiet support had meant the world to her today.

 

Lilia stepped in to redirect the conversation. “So, what’s next for you, Rio? What’s the next step after today?”

 

Rio considered the question, her fingers tracing the condensation on her glass. “More writing, mostly. I got some good feedback during the Q&A that I can work into my next chapter. And now that I’ve presented, I feel like I have a better grasp on how to structure the rest of the dissertation.”

 

Lilia nodded, her gaze steady and encouraging. “You’re on the right track. Just don’t forget to take breaks when you need them. You’ve earned it.”

 

Alice grinned, finishing her drink. “And when you’re done being academic, come jam with us. You know you miss it.”

 

Rio laughed, the tension she’d been carrying all week finally melting away. Sitting there with Alice’s playful energy and Lilia’s steady presence, she felt deeply grateful for the people in her life.

 

From where she was sitting on the right, Alice slung an arm around Rio’s shoulders. “For real, though, I’m so proud of you. I knew you’d kill it today.”

 

“Thanks, Al,” Rio said softly.

 

Lilia smiled, her expression gentle. “I’m proud of you too, my sweet and smart girl.”

 

 

As the evening went on, Rio glanced at the time and realized she’d need to head out soon. She’d promised Agatha they’d celebrate privately, and she was looking forward to winding down the day with her. She set down her glass and cleared her throat.

 

“I should probably get going,” she said.

 

Alice immediately perked up, her curiosity piqued. “Oh? And where’s the genius rushing off to?”

 

Rio hesitated, but she knew there was no point in pretending. Alice already knew, and Lilia wasn’t likely to judge. “I have plans with Agatha,” she admitted, a little sheepishly.

 

Alice’s grin spread wide across her face. “Plans, huh?” she said, with the kind of exaggerated insinuation that made Rio immediately regret saying anything. “Very mysterious. Very adult.”

 

“Alice, don’t start—”

 

But Alice was already on a roll, waggling her eyebrows as she continued. “You gonna bring out the wine and candles? Dim the lights? Ooh, maybe some poetry readings for the occasion?”

 

“Alice,” Rio groaned, burying her face in her hands as her cheeks burned.

 

Lilia, who had been quietly amused up to this point, decided it was time to step in. She set her drink down and leveled Alice with a faux-stern look. “Alice, that’s enough.”

 

Alice threw up her hands in mock surrender but was still grinning.

 

Then Lilia turned to Rio, her expression softening into something more affectionate but no less mischievous. “Rio, my dear, I’m very happy that you’re happy,” she said warmly.

 

Rio started to smile, but then Lilia continued, her tone pointedly maternal, “But I absolutely do not need to hear about your ‘special plans’ with your girlfriend.”

 

“Lilia!” Rio exclaimed, her embarrassment reaching its peak. She felt like her face was on fire.

 

Alice was cackling now, practically falling off her chair. “Oh my god, this is the best thing I’ve heard all week.”

 

“Don’t encourage her!” Rio pleaded, throwing a napkin at Alice in a half-hearted attempt at retaliation.

 

Lilia simply gave Rio a knowing smile, patted her hand, and then stood up to fetch her coat. “You’d better get going,” she said, her tone teasing but kind.

 

“Yeah, yeah,” Rio muttered, trying to gather what was left of her dignity.

 

As they all walked out of the bar together, Alice nudged Rio with her elbow. “Seriously, though, have fun tonight, Miss Genius. You deserve it.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t help the small, grateful smile that crept onto her face. She had to admit, even with the teasing, it felt good to have people who cared about her so much.

 

And when she finally made it to Agatha’s house, where her lover was probably waiting with a bottle of wine and that look in her eyes that made Rio’s heart skip a beat, she knew the teasing had been worth it.

 

 

Rio pulled up to Agatha’s house, her heart already racing at the thought of seeing her. She stepped out of the car, clutching a small bottle of champagne she’d grabbed on her way over, and walked up to the door. Before she could knock, it swung open, and there was Agatha, leaning casually against the doorframe, her lips already curling into a knowing smile.

 

“Right on time,” Agatha teased, stepping aside to let Rio in.

 

Rio couldn’t help but grin back. “You know I wouldn’t miss this.”

 

Agatha closed the door behind her and, without a word, pulled Rio in for a kiss. It was slow and languid, the kind of kiss that made Rio forget everything else—her nerves about the conference, the teasing from Alice, all of it melted away as Agatha’s hands slid around her waist.

 

“Congratulations, my love,” Agatha murmured against her lips.

 

“Thank you,” Rio whispered, her voice catching slightly. The warmth in Agatha’s tone always made her feel like the most important person in the world.

 

They moved to the living room, where Agatha poured them each a glass of champagne in her fancy flutes. They sat close, their knees touching, talking in low, hushed tones about the conference. Agatha listened intently as Rio recounted the highlights, her eyes never leaving Rio’s face.

 

“You were brilliant. Just like I knew you would be,” Agatha said, taking a sip of her wine.

 

Rio chuckled softly, leaning into her. “I still can’t believe it went so well. It’s like… surreal.”

 

“Believe it,” Agatha said, reaching out to tuck a loose strand of hair behind Rio’s ear.

 

After a while, Rio noticed a record player in the corner of the room. “You have a record player?”

 

“Of course. Who do you take me for?” Agatha said with a smirk, already moving to select a record.

 

The soft hum of a jazz tune filled the room, warm and inviting. Agatha turned back to Rio and extended a hand. “Dance with me?”

 

Rio blinked in surprise but smiled, placing her hand in Agatha’s. “Always.”

 

Agatha pulled her to her feet and into her arms. They swayed together, their movements unhurried, as though time had slowed just for them. The music curled around them like a blanket, and Rio let her head rest against Agatha’s shoulder, her eyes fluttering shut.

 

After a moment, Agatha stepped back slightly and spun Rio, making her laugh. When Rio returned to her arms, their foreheads touched, and they both stilled.

 

“You make me so happy,” Rio whispered, her voice soft but certain.

 

Agatha smiled, her thumb brushing lightly over Rio’s cheek. “I didn’t know I could feel like this.”

 

They stood there, swaying gently, foreheads still pressed together, the music playing in the background. The world outside didn’t matter—nothing did except the way they fit together so perfectly in that moment.

 

Rio’s voice was barely above a whisper when she said, “I can’t believe this is real.”

 

Agatha tilted her head, her lips brushing Rio’s. “It is, my love,” she murmured. “It’s as real as it gets.”

 

And as they danced and kissed and held each other close, the only thing they could both feel was the overwhelming, beautiful certainty of being exactly where they were meant to be.

 

As the song shifted to a slower, softer melody, the room seemed to envelop them in its warmth. Rio rested her head against Agatha’s shoulder again, her body swaying in sync with Agatha’s. For a brief moment, the world felt like it had narrowed down to just the two of them—until a small voice broke the peaceful bubble.

 

“Mama?”

 

Both Rio and Agatha froze, pulling apart slightly, and turned toward the doorway. Nicky stood there, his little face sleepily peering around the corner, rubbing his eyes. The sight of him, so unguarded and innocent, tugged at their hearts in the softest way.

 

“Hey, buddy,” Agatha said, her voice filled with affection as she stepped toward him. “Did we wake you up?”

 

Nicky nodded, but a small, sleepy smile tugged at his lips. “I couldn’t sleep.” His eyes wandered between them, still groggy, but there was curiosity and something deeper in his gaze. “Can I dance too?”

 

Rio and Agatha exchanged a look, both of them smiling at the idea. Agatha extended her hand to Nicky, her voice warm and inviting. “Of course you can, sweetheart.”

 

Nicky shuffled forward, his small hand slipping into Agatha’s. Rio bent down to lift him into her arms, his small frame resting against her chest as she joined Agatha. Together, the three of them moved in perfect harmony, Agatha guiding Rio and Nicky as they danced, Rio holding the boy close as they twirled slowly in the soft glow of the room.

 

Nicky giggled, the sound light and carefree, and Rio smiled at how right it felt. There they were, the three of them, dancing together like a little family—together in a way that felt unspoken but undeniably true.

 

“You’re both the best,” Nicky mumbled, his head resting against Rio’s shoulder, eyes fluttering as if he might fall asleep again.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her arm wrapped around both of them. “And you’re our favorite little dancer.”

 

The music swirled around them, gentle and comforting, as they moved in a quiet rhythm, the bond between them growing stronger in that small, precious moment. In the quiet of Agatha’s living room, there was no need for words. 

 

 

Later, after they tucked Nicky back into bed, Rio and Agatha lingered in the hallway for a moment. The soft glow of the lamps in the living room illuminated the space around them, casting long shadows across the walls. They stood there, neither of them quite ready to break the fragile stillness of the evening.

 

Agatha reached for Rio’s hand, intertwining their fingers gently. “You were amazing today, love,” she said, her voice low, filled with the warmth of pride and affection.

 

Rio smiled softly, her heart swelling at Agatha’s words. “I couldn’t have done it without your support. You’re always there for me.”

 

Agatha leaned in, brushing a strand of hair away from Rio’s face, her touch tender. “And I always will be.”

 

They shared a quiet, lingering kiss that quickly deepened, slow and intoxicating, a promise of everything they had both been holding back. By the time they finally broke apart, Rio’s lips were flushed, her breath uneven, her body already attuned to Agatha’s in a way that left her aching.

 

Agatha took her hand, lacing their fingers together as she led Rio toward the bedroom. The air between them crackled with unspoken words, anticipation humming between their bodies like an electric current. When Agatha shut the door behind them, the sound was soft, but final—sealing them away from the outside world, from hesitation, from anything that could pull them apart.

 

Rio’s heart pounded. This was it. The moment she had imagined too many times to count, but none of those thoughts, none of those fantasies, compared to the way Agatha was looking at her now—dark, full of heat and tenderness all at once.

 

“I want this,” Rio whispered, her voice steady despite the tremor in her body, the vulnerability that came with laying herself bare like this. “I want you.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, slow and deliberate, until there was nothing between them but heat and expectation. “Are you sure?” she murmured, one hand lifting to brush her fingers along Rio’s jaw, tilting her face up.

 

Rio swallowed hard, holding Agatha’s gaze. “I’ve never been more sure of anything in my life.”

 

A slow smile curved Agatha’s lips, something wicked and reverent all at once. Then she kissed Rio again, deeper this time, hungrier. A kiss that spoke of restraint finally slipping, of a need that had been simmering for far too long. Rio felt herself melt into it, hands threading into Agatha’s long, dark hair, pulling her impossibly closer.

 

Their bodies pressed flush against each other, warmth spilling between them, and Rio sighed into Agatha’s mouth when deft fingers found the hem of her shirt, pushing it up, up, until Agatha’s hands could splay against bare skin, exploring with deliberate slowness.

 

They undressed each other piece by piece, taking their time, every movement a quiet act of worship. There was no rush—only the burning need to feel, to savor, to take in every inch of each other. 

 

Agatha pulled Rio down on the bed with her, the younger woman falling on top of Agatha, her hands tangled in long brown tresses, before her mouth left Agatha’s mouth to move down her neck. Agatha quickly flipped them over, taking Rio in.

 

Agatha’s lips traced a path down Rio’s neck, slow and teasing, tasting, learning, branding every inch of her skin. Rio’s nails pressed into Agatha’s back as her breath hitched, her body arching instinctively into every touch, every kiss.

 

“God, Agatha,” she breathed, her voice wrecked with longing.

 

Agatha smirked against her throat, her voice a seductive whisper against Rio’s skin. “Patience, love. I want to take my time with you.”

 

And she did. She unraveled Rio with slow, reverent touches, with kisses that lingered too long and not long enough all at once. She traced every inch of her, learning what made her gasp, what made her tremble, what made her whisper Agatha’s name like a prayer.

 

Agatha’s hands were gentle as they explored each other, but there was a sense of purpose in every touch. Rio responded in kind, her fingers tracing the lines of Agatha’s skin, memorizing every inch, every detail.

 

They moved together in sync, bodies pressing, hands gripping, mouths searching. It was overwhelming in the best way—every sigh, every gasp, every whispered name a testament to the depth of what lay between them.

 

When they finally came together, it was as though the world outside had ceased to exist. In the quiet of Agatha’s bedroom, there was only them—two souls finally intertwining, fully and completely. It was soft, intimate, and full of love. The feeling of Agatha’s body against hers, the way their breaths mingled in the space between them, was something Rio had longed for, something she had never thought would be possible.

 

It wasn’t just about the physical connection, though. It was about trust, about love, about finally being able to be completely vulnerable with someone who cherished and accepted her, flaws and all.

 

Agatha held her close through it all, guiding her through wave after wave of sensation, until Rio was clinging to her, her body shuddering with release, her breath stolen. Agatha kissed her through it, swallowed every sound, every plea, every whispered devotion.

 

They collapsed against each other afterward, limbs tangled, bodies damp with sweat and still thrumming from the aftermath. Rio rested her head against Agatha’s chest, listening to the steady rhythm of her heartbeat, grounding herself in the warmth of her lover’s arms.

 

Agatha pressed a slow, lingering kiss to the top of Rio’s head. “You are incredible,” she murmured, voice thick with emotion.

 

Rio smiled against her skin, her fingers tracing lazy circles on Agatha’s side. “I love you,” she whispered, letting the words fall freely, because they felt too big to keep inside any longer.

 

Agatha tightened her hold, pressing their bodies closer together, as if she never wanted to let go. “I love you too. More than you can imagine.”

 

They stayed wrapped up in each other, their bodies a tangle of limbs and heat, the room still heavy with the scent of them, the memory of what they had just shared. There was no need for words now—just quiet touches, lazy kisses, the certainty that this was only the beginning of something neither of them would ever walk away from.

 

By the time sleep claimed them, Rio was still pressed against Agatha, her body utterly spent, her heart impossibly full. And when the morning came, they were still tangled together, as if even sleep hadn’t been strong enough to pull them apart.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

1/ I love this chapter, and I hope you will too hihi

2/ Why do you all want drama?! Don't you want them happy hahahhahah ?

3/ Merry Christmas to those who celebrate! Love you all!

Afterglow and Anticipation

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

Go, said the bird, for the leaves were full of children,

Hidden excitedly, containing laughter.

Go, go, go, said the bird: human kind

Cannot bear very much reality.

 

                  (T.S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The morning light filtered softly through the curtains, casting a warm glow over the room. Agatha woke slowly, her body still tangled with Rio’s. For a moment, she stayed there, just breathing in the familiar scent of Rio’s hair, savoring the feeling of having her so close. The weight of her in her arms, the soft rise and fall of her chest, was a kind of peace Agatha had never fully understood until now.

 

Rio’s hair had fallen across her face, and Agatha gently brushed it away, careful not to disturb the delicate stillness of the moment. Rio’s face was relaxed, her features soft in sleep, the tension of the previous days seeming to melt away. Agatha couldn’t help but smile, her heart swelling with something she couldn’t quite define, but it felt like home.

 

For a long, unbroken moment, Agatha simply held Rio close, her arms wrapped around her like she was something precious, something irreplaceable. Her fingers moved with deliberate tenderness, tracing the soft contours of Rio’s shoulder and the curve of her bare back. It was as though she was committing every inch of her to memory—the warmth of her skin, the way her muscles shifted beneath her touch, the faint rise and fall of her breathing. There was a stillness between them, the kind that only came from being completely in sync, completely safe.

 

Agatha’s hand paused at the small of Rio’s back, her palm resting there as if to anchor her. She pressed a soft kiss to the top of Rio’s head, breathing in the faint trace of her shampoo, mingled with the subtle warmth of her own unique scent. It was intoxicating, grounding, and comforting all at once—a reminder that this moment was real, that Rio was here, with her, now.

 

Rio nestled closer, her head resting against Agatha’s collarbone, her breath a gentle rhythm that Agatha matched without even realizing it. The connection between them felt almost tangible, like a thread weaving their souls together in the quiet of the room. Neither spoke, neither moved to break the spell. Instead, they remained like that, wrapped in a stillness that carried more weight and meaning than any words ever could.

 

Eventually, Rio stirred, a soft sigh escaping her lips. Her eyes fluttered open slowly, the world taking a few moments to come into focus. When her gaze landed on Agatha, a sleepy smile tugged at her lips, and she nuzzled closer, pressing her forehead against Agatha’s chest.

 

“Morning,” Rio mumbled, her voice husky from sleep.

 

“Good morning,” Agatha replied softly, her fingers gently grazing Rio’s arm. “How are you feeling?”

 

“Good,” Rio answered with a contented sigh. “This is… this is nice.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, brushing a light kiss to the top of Rio’s head. “It is, isn’t it?”

 

They stayed like that for a while, not saying much, just enjoying the quiet, the warmth, the connection. Agatha knew it wouldn’t last forever—there were always other things waiting outside this little bubble they’d created—but for now, she wanted nothing more than to stay right where she was, with Rio in her arms, her heart filled with a peace she hadn’t known she was missing.

 

After a while, Rio stretched, her body arching slightly as she woke up fully. Agatha smiled at the sight, a quiet affection in her gaze.

 

“I should get up,” Rio said, yawning as she sat up, her body still a little sleepy.

 

“Only if you want to,” Agatha teased, reaching out to tug her back down. “I’m happy right here.”

 

“Ok, I’ll stay a bit longer,” Rio replied, snuggling closer into Agatha’s chest, before looking at her with a knowing smile. “I’m not going anywhere, Agatha.”

 

And for a moment, as they lay together in bed, the weight of those words settled between them. For the first time in what seemed like forever in her life, Agatha believed it completely.

 

 

The warmth of the bed still clung to their bare skin, the lingering heat of the night before wrapping around them like a second set of sheets. Rio was still sprawled against the pillows, her body deliciously tangled with Agatha’s, her breath slow and steady against Agatha’s neck. Agatha let herself indulge for just a moment longer, running her fingers lazily down Rio’s spine, feeling the way she shivered beneath her touch.

 

But then—

 

A sound.

 

Soft, familiar, but unmistakable.

 

A sleepy murmur, the shifting of small feet against the floor in the next room.

 

Nicky.

 

Agatha froze, her instincts kicking in immediately. She knew Nicky’s routine well; every morning, without fail, he would wander into her room, looking for her in that sleepy, half-awake way.

 

“We should probably get dressed,” Agatha murmured, her voice low as she shifted her gaze to the door. Her words carried a mix of urgency and amusement, knowing it was only a matter of moment before Nicky appeared.

 

A slow, teasing grin spread across Rio’s face as she glanced down at their very, very naked bodies.

 

“I suppose we should,” she admitted, though there was nothing in her voice that suggested urgency. If anything, she was enjoying this just a little too much. “Not sure how we’d explain this to him just yet.”

 

Agatha chuckled, the sound warm and soft, as she reached up to brush a strand of Rio’s dark hair away from her face. “Not today,” she said with a grin. “And hopefully not for at least ten years.” Her tone was joking, but the hint of maternal panic lurking beneath made Rio laugh again.

 

Rio smirked, brushing her lips against Agatha’s jaw, her voice dropping into a sultry murmur. “Ten years? You’re optimistic.”

 

Agatha let out a breathy chuckle, but another noise from Nicky’s room had her snapping back into full Mama mode. She sat up quickly, her movements brisk, reaching for the robe draped over the chair beside the bed.

 

Rio groaned dramatically as Agatha pulled away, flopping back against the pillows. “This is tragic,” she sighed, stretching in a way that was entirely intentional, the sheet slipping just enough to expose the curve of her waist, the swell of her chest. “I had such big plans for this morning.”

 

Agatha shot her a dry look as she tied her robe around her waist. “If those plans involved traumatizing my child, I’m going to have to veto them.”

 

Rio only smirked. “You’re no fun.”

 

“You’re impossible.”

 

Still, Agatha couldn’t resist. She leaned down, capturing Rio’s lips in one last, slow, lingering kiss, savoring the way Rio melted against her, the way she sighed into the kiss as if she wasn’t about to let her go.

 

When Agatha finally pulled back, Rio gave her a wicked little smile. “I’ll be right behind you,” she promised, though the glint in her eye suggested she wasn’t in a hurry.

 

Agatha huffed, shaking her head fondly as she turned toward the dresser, grabbing the first shirt and pair of shorts she could find and tossing them unceremoniously onto the bed. There were some things a six-year-old didn't need to see first thing in the morning. 

 

“Clothes. Now.”

 

Rio grinned, but didn’t argue.

 

As Agatha made her way toward the door, she glanced back one last time—just in time to see Rio stretching again, her hair a wild mess around her face, her skin still flushed from the night before. Even in the hazy morning light, she was effortlessly beautiful.

 

Agatha’s heart gave a traitorous little flutter.

 

She didn’t have time for this.

 

Just as she was about to open the door, she heard Nicky’s soft footsteps getting closer, the unmistakable shuffle of a child who hadn’t fully woken up yet. A second later, she heard the quiet tap on her door. “Mama?” Nicky’s voice was small, muffled from behind the door.

 

“Yeah, sweetie?” Agatha called back, her tone steady, but her heart raced a little.

 

The door creaked open, and Nicky poked his head inside, rubbing his eyes with one hand and holding his stuffed dragon in the other. When his eyes landed on Agatha, he smiled sleepily. “Morning, Mama.”

 

“Morning, sweet boy,” Agatha replied with a smile, moving to kneel in front of him. “How’d you sleep?”

 

Nicky shrugged, still half-asleep. “Okay. I just woke up.”

 

“Well, it’s a good thing you’re awake now, because I think we’ve got a busy day ahead of us,” Agatha said with a playful wink, standing up and pulling him into a quick hug. “How about some breakfast?”

 

He nodded eagerly, his sleepiness fading at the mention of food. “I want pancakes!”

 

“Pancakes it is,” Agatha said, ruffling his hair. “Why don’t you go wash up while I get started?”

 

Nicky bounded off, still clutching his stuffed dragon, and Agatha let out a quiet sigh of relief. She turned back toward Rio, who had now pulled herself into a sitting position on the bed, the sheet drawn up to cover her chest, watching the interaction with a soft smile.

 

“Your turn,” Agatha said with a grin, moving toward the door as she went to join Nicky in the kitchen.

 

Rio smiled at her, her eyes filled with a tenderness that made Agatha’s heart swell. “I’m coming.”

 

As Rio stood up to get dressed, Agatha lingered for a moment, just watching her. They had a moment of peace that she knew wouldn’t last forever, but for now, it felt like they were living in a quiet kind of happiness—small, private moments tucked away from the world, just the two of them.

 

 

Rio stepped into the café, the bell above the door chiming softly as she entered. She spotted Alice immediately, sitting at a corner table with a steaming mug of coffee in front of her. Alice was grinning from ear to ear, and Rio could already tell this was going to be one of those mornings.

 

“Well, well, well,” Alice said, her voice laced with mischief as Rio took a seat across from her. “Look who decided to grace me with her presence. I thought you’d be too busy, you know, celebrating.” She wiggled her eyebrows, teasing Rio mercilessly.

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress the flush that crept up her neck. “Alice, I just spent the night. That’s all,” she said, trying to keep her voice casual as she reached for her own coffee. “It wasn’t a big deal.”

 

Alice smirked, clearly not buying it. “Right, because ‘the night’ at Agatha’s house is totally just a normal thing, right? Are you sure it wasn’t more of a… celebratory night?” She leaned in closer, her tone dropping into a conspiratorial whisper. “You know, I’m just wondering what exactly happened after little Nicky went to bed." She lowered her voice to a conspiratorial whisper, her gaze locking on Rio’s face. “Tell me, how many times did you—”

 

“Alice!” Rio hissed, nearly choking on her coffee, her eyes darting around the café to make sure no one had overheard. Her cheeks flamed as Alice erupted into laughter, clearly enjoying herself far too much.

 

“I’m just saying,” Alice continued, feigning innocence as she stirred her tea, “it’s not every day you get invited to spend the night at Agatha Harkness’s house. And come on, Rio, you look…” She leaned back, studying her with a knowing grin. “Positively radiant this morning. You’re practically glowing. Let me guess—you celebrated with a bang?”

 

Rio groaned, burying her face in her hands as Alice’s laughter grew louder. “You’re impossible,” she muttered, her voice muffled. “Can’t we just have a normal conversation? Like, about the weather or something?”

 

“Oh, come on,” Alice said, almost too eagerly. “Tell me everything. I know you’re dying to share.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat. Alice had been relentless ever since she found out about her and Agatha, but today, it seemed she was really going for it.

 

Rio let out a laugh, her cheeks burning brighter. “I swear, you’re impossible,” she said, shaking her head. “We didn’t—” she stopped, glancing around the café, making sure no one was paying attention, “—we didn’t do anything like that, Alice.”

 

Alice leaned back in her chair, raising her eyebrows and crossing her arms, a playful grin never leaving her face. “Uh-huh. Sure, sure. I can’t imagine what else you two could possibly be doing when you’re alone in her bed. Probably doing origamis, or eating candy, maybe even finger painting…” She paused dramatically, her grin widening, her eyebrows wiggling while Rio’ cheeks and ears took on an alarming crimson color. “But hey, no judgment from me. You deserve it, you know. You’re glowing, Rio.”

 

"Alice, drop it."

Alice wasn’t letting her off the hook that easily. “Oh, no, no, no. You don’t get to waltz in here looking like you’ve just walked out of a romance novel and expect me not to pry.” She leaned in again, lowering her voice for dramatic effect. “So… how was it? Earth-shattering? Life-changing? Were you screaming her name—?”

 

Rio nearly knocked over her coffee cup in her haste to shush Alice. “God, Alice, stop,” she whispered, her mortification reaching new heights. “We didn’t—” She faltered, realizing there was no point in denying it when her flushed face was already giving her away. She sighed deeply, leaning back in defeat.

 

Alice’s smirk widened, her eyes dancing with delight. “Oh, you totally did.”

 

Rio shot her a glare but couldn’t suppress the shy smile tugging at her lips. “Fine. Yes. Happy now? It happened.”

 

Alice gasped theatrically, clutching her chest as though Rio had just confessed to some great scandal. “I knew it! Oh, my god, Rio! You and Agatha—” She broke into a fit of giggles, barely able to contain herself. “You sly thing! So? Details. I want everything. Was it the desk? The kitchen counter? Please tell me it was dramatic and at least a little illegal.”

 

Rio groaned again, this time out of sheer exasperation. “Alice, we’re not talking about this in a café. And it was… it was just good, okay? Really good.” Her voice softened, her embarrassment giving way to genuine warmth. “Better than I ever expected.”

 

Alice rested her chin on her hands again, her grin softening into something more affectionate. “You deserve that, Rio. And I’m glad she’s the one who’s giving it to you.” She wiggled her eyebrows one last time for good measure. “Even if I’m dying to know if it was the desk.”

 

Rio buried her face in her hands, the blush deepening on her cheeks. “I can’t believe we’re talking about this,” she muttered, shaking her head.

 

“Oh, we’re talking about this alright,” Alice teased. “Come on, give me the full scoop! Did you two—” She leaned in closer, clearly relishing the moment. “—did you celebrate the big presentation in style?”

 

Rio shook her head, still trying to calm the embarrassment bubbling up inside her. “It wasn’t some big celebration, Alice. We’re just… really happy. Things are good, alright? I’m not… I wasn’t expecting it to happen, but it just did. And I’m glad it did.”

 

Alice raised her mug, clearly impressed. “I’m happy for you, Rio,” she said, her teasing tone softening for a moment. “You deserve this, all of it. It’s good to see you so… content. Agatha is good for you. And it’s obvious she cares about you. I don’t know, proud of you. You’ve been through a lot, and seeing you this happy? It’s nice.”

 

Rio met Alice’s gaze, a smile tugging at the corners of her lips. “Thanks, Alice,” she said softly, feeling a swell of gratitude toward her friend. “It’s just… nice, you know? Having something that feels right.”

 

Alice nodded, her eyes softening as she gave Rio a knowing look. “Yeah, I can tell. But if you ever need help with… navigating these new levels of domestic bliss,” she said, her teasing tone returning, “I’m your girl.”

 

Rio chuckled, finally able to relax a little in Alice’s presence. “I’ll keep that in mind,” she said, but she knew deep down that this part of her life with Agatha, though complicated and secretive in some ways, was exactly what she needed. And despite the teasing, she was glad to have Alice by her side, supporting her, even if it came with a side of playful sarcasm.

 

Alice looked her over, eyes glinting with amusement. “Okay, good. But for now,” she leaned in, her grin returning with full force, “I want details. How was dessert, and breakfast?”

 

Rio gave her a mock glare, but she couldn’t hide her smile. “Maybe I’ll tell you one day,” she said, sipping her coffee and feeling completely content in this moment of teasing and warmth.

 

The rest of their conversation drifted into lighter territory, but Rio knew that whatever happened, she had the people who cared about her in her corner. Even if that meant dealing with Alice’s teasing for a while.

 

 

Monday morning was unusually quiet in Agatha’s office as she prepared for the day ahead, but the memory of their first night together lingered in both of them. It was hard not to feel the weight of their shared moments, the closeness they had found in each other, the way their bodies and hearts had intertwined so seamlessly. Rio had never felt more seen, more understood, and in Agatha’s presence, it felt as if the rest of the world had faded away.

 

But now, here they were, back in the reality of their professional roles—teacher and student—both struggling to keep the new depth of their connection hidden.

 

A few hours later, Agatha stood at the front of the lecture hall, her authoritative presence filling the space as she began her class. Rio, sitting in the second row as always, couldn’t help but steal glances at her. Every time their eyes met, a small smile would flicker between them, something only they understood. The bond was undeniable, and the air around them was charged with unspoken words and shared memories.

 

They hadn’t yet found the courage to tell anyone outside of their close circle, but the way their gazes lingered, the brush of a hand when Agatha passed a paper to Rio, was enough for both of them to feel the pull of something deeper, something more than just a professional relationship.

 

Throughout the lecture, Rio found herself distracted by the soft, reassuring presence of Agatha at the front. Her mind wandered back to that night—the way they had held each other in the quiet of Agatha’s bed, wrapped in warmth, a tenderness that had seemed so natural. Agatha’s hands on her skin, the way she whispered her name in the dark, telling her she was loved, it all felt so surreal but so real at the same time.

 

But here, in the classroom, they were just two people caught in the delicate balance of their roles. They had to keep it together, keep the secret, even if it was harder than ever. When Agatha would pause to look at her, Rio’s heart would skip a beat, but they kept it contained, the quiet intimacy locked behind their eyes. No one could see it, not yet.

 

It wasn’t just the relative newness of their relationship that made things difficult to hide—it was the strength of their feelings for each other. The passion that had ignited between them was undeniable, and every moment they shared seemed to burn brighter than the last. But for now, they could only hold it close, hidden in the small gestures, in the looks and touches no one else could see.

 

By the time the lecture ended, Rio had to remind herself that they were still in public. The rest of the class trickled out of the room, and Agatha gave a quick nod in Rio’s direction, a silent acknowledgment of their connection. It was enough to keep Rio grounded, even as she fought the urge to rush forward and claim the affection she had been craving all morning.

 

Once the classroom had cleared, Rio lingered for a moment, waiting for the last student to leave, her mind racing. Agatha stood by the door, gathering her things, and as Rio approached her, the weight of the room seemed to shift.

 

“You’re quiet today,” Agatha observed, her voice soft, but with a knowing look that made Rio’s heart flutter.

 

“I’m just… thinking,” Rio murmured, feeling the magnetic pull between them.

 

Agatha smiled gently, leaning in just a little closer, her voice barely above a whisper. “Whatever you’re thinking about, love, it’s worth it.”

 

Rio nodded, feeling a mix of hope and longing. She wanted nothing more than to be able to shout their love from the rooftops, but they both knew it wasn’t the right time yet.

 

“Yeah,” Rio said, her voice low but firm. “It really is.”

 

As they exchanged one last look, Rio left the classroom, her steps a little lighter than before. Though their secret was becoming harder to keep, the love they shared was strong enough to endure whatever they had to face, together.

 

 

The rest of the week seemed to drag on as Rio and Agatha navigated the increasingly difficult task of keeping their relationship hidden. It was clear to both of them that their feelings were growing deeper, the bond between them more undeniable with each passing moment. But the stakes were high, and they couldn’t afford to slip up—not yet.

 

Friday afternoon, Rio found herself staring out the window of Agatha’s office, lost in thought. She hadn’t meant to be so distracted, but the pull of Agatha’s presence in the room was like a constant hum in the back of her mind. She could feel Agatha’s eyes on her, watching her as she worked, but Rio didn’t look up. She wasn’t sure if it was the lingering touches from earlier, the quiet moments they had shared in the hall after class, or the memory of their first night together, but Rio was finding it hard to focus on anything other than Agatha.

 

Agatha, ever perceptive, noticed the slight shift in Rio’s posture. She had been observing her for a while now—watching her become more restless, more distracted. The quiet connection between them was growing more intense by the day, and Agatha knew it was only a matter of time before they had to address it. But she didn’t want to rush Rio. She never wanted to make her feel pressured. Agatha valued the trust they had built over the past few months, and she wasn’t about to risk it by pushing too hard.

 

When the clock struck five, Agatha decided to break the silence. She gathered her things, standing up from her desk and walking over to where Rio was sitting.

 

“Rio,” Agatha began softly, her voice carrying the weight of everything unsaid between them, “are you doing okay?”

 

Rio glanced up at her, a small, guilty smile tugging at the corner of her lips. “Yeah, I’m fine. Just… a little distracted.”

 

Agatha tilted her head, studying Rio with a mixture of affection and concern. “Distracted by what?”

 

Rio hesitated for a moment before responding, her voice barely above a whisper. “You.”

 

Agatha’s heart skipped a beat at the admission, but she kept her expression calm, a small smile curling on her lips. “Me?” she asked, her tone playful yet gentle.

 

Rio nodded, unable to hide the warmth in her eyes. “Yeah. It’s hard to focus on anything else when you’re around.”

 

Agatha’s smile deepened, and she took a step closer, her hand brushing lightly against Rio’s. “I get it,” she said softly. “It’s hard for me, too.”

 

Rio looked up at her, her heart pounding in her chest. For a moment, the room felt too small for the intensity between them. She could feel the heat radiating from Agatha’s body, the pull that was growing stronger with every passing second. But they both knew that they couldn’t give in, not yet.

 

“Can I ask you something?” Rio asked, her voice steady but full of curiosity.

 

“Anything,” Agatha replied, her gaze unwavering.

 

Rio bit her lip nervously. “Do you ever think about… what comes next? After all of this?”

 

Agatha’s brows furrowed slightly, but there was no hesitation in her response. “I think about it all the time, Rio. But we have to be patient. There’s a lot at stake, and we can’t rush it. But I can't wait for it, even if I love what we have now.”

 

Rio nodded, feeling a sense of relief wash over her. It was what she needed to hear. As much as she wanted to be open about their relationship, to shout it from the rooftops, she knew they had to be careful. It wasn’t just about them; it was about their futures, their careers, their lives.

 

“I know,” Rio said quietly. “I just… sometimes it feels like we’re living in two different worlds. You’re a professor, and I’m just… a student.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, her hand brushing against Rio’s cheek. “You’re not just a student, Rio,” she said firmly. “You’re brilliant. And no matter what happens, I’ll always be proud of you, and I'll always be yours. You’re my equal in every way.”

 

Rio felt her heart swell at the sincerity in Agatha’s words. She wanted nothing more than to be with her, to make their relationship public, but Agatha was right—they had to be patient.

 

“Thank you,” Rio whispered, feeling the weight of her words.

 

Agatha smiled, her hand lingering on Rio’s cheek for a moment longer before pulling back. “We’ll get through this. Together. I promise.”

 

Rio smiled back, feeling a sense of peace settle in her chest. They were in this together, and that was all that mattered.

 

As the weekend approached, the two of them found quiet moments to steal away from the world. Their love was a secret, but it was also something they both cherished deeply. And even though they couldn’t yet share it with everyone else, they had each other—and that was enough for now.

 

*

*

*

 

 

 

Chapter End Notes

I can't thank you enough for your comments every day, they were my best Christmas gift today!
I love you all !
see you very soon for next chapter !

Birthday Girl

Chapter Notes

Sorry for not posting yesterday, it was a crazy day! But here it is, I hope you'll enjoy.

And as a belated Christmas gift, I created a Pinterest Board to go with this story. Here is the link if you're interested: https://pin.it/6ttgCLtvB

Love you all, thank you for all your comments, you are all amazing.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

*

*

*

Two and two, necessarye coniunction,

Holding eche other by the hand or the arm

Whiche betokeneth concorde.

Round and round the fire

Leaping through the flames, or joined in circles,

Rustically solemn or in rustic laughter

Lifting heavy feet in clumsy shoes,

Earth feet, loam feet, lifted in country mirth

 

              (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The soft click of a key turning in the lock barely registered to Rio, who was still wrapped in the warmth of her blanket and the haze of sleep. It wasn’t until the familiar sound of footsteps padded into her small flat that she stirred, groggily sitting up and squinting toward the source of the intrusion.

 

“Lilia?” she croaked, her voice thick with sleep.

 

“Happy birthday, my sweet girl!” Lilia’s voice was warm and bright as she appeared in the doorway to Rio’s bedroom, holding a tray with a small plate of toast, a mug of steaming tea, and a single candle flickering cheerfully atop a cupcake.

 

Rio blinked, rubbing the sleep from her eyes. “You let yourself in?”

 

“Of course,” Lilia said, setting the tray on Rio’s bedside table. “I wanted to be the first to wish you a happy birthday. And besides, you gave me a spare key for emergencies. Turning another year older is an emergency, no?”

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound still laced with sleep. “I guess so.”

 

As she sat up further, Lilia perched on the edge of the bed, her dark eyes shimmering with emotion. “Do you know what I was doing this exact time all those years ago?”

 

Rio shook her head, smiling gently. “What?”

 

Lilia reached out, brushing a strand of hair from Rio’s face. “I was sitting in the living room, wondering if I’d done the right thing by taking you in. You were so guarded, Rio. So quiet. But when I walked into your room to check on you, you were already awake, sitting on that bed I’d set up. You looked at me and said, ‘Good morning.’ Just like that. As if you’d been there forever.”

 

Rio’s smile faltered, her chest tightening at the memory. “I don’t remember that.”

 

“Well, I do,” Lilia said, her voice soft but firm. “It was the moment I knew I’d made the right choice. You fit into my life so seamlessly, like you’d always been there. And now, look at you—” her voice broke slightly, and she wiped at her eyes with a quick laugh, “—a brilliant, beautiful young woman. You’ve made me so proud, my love. So, so proud. And I don’t think you will ever stop.”

 

“Lilia,” Rio whispered, her own eyes brimming with tears. “You’re going to make me cry.”

 

“Good,” Lilia teased, though her voice was thick with emotion. “You’ve made me cry plenty over the years, you know.”

 

They both laughed at that, and Lilia leaned forward to pull Rio into a tight hug. Rio melted into the embrace, feeling the unshakable warmth and security that Lilia had given her for so many years.

 

“Thank you,” Rio murmured against her shoulder. “For everything. For always being there.”

 

“Always,” Lilia promised, pulling back to cup Rio’s face in her hands. “You deserve all the happiness in the world, Rio. Today and every day.”

 

Rio smiled, a tear slipping down her cheek as she nodded. “I love you, Lilia.”

 

“I love you too, darling girl,” Lilia said, leaning in to kiss her forehead. Then she straightened, brushing her hands against her jeans. “Now, eat your cupcake before I do. And don’t think I’m leaving until you tell me all about your plans for the day.”

 

Rio laughed, reaching for the tray. “Alright, alright. Let me wake up first.”

 

As Lilia watched her with a fond smile, Rio couldn’t help but think that birthdays like this—waking up to the unwavering love of the person who had given her a home—truly made her feel special.

 

 

As the sun rose over their cozy home, Agatha was already in the kitchen, sipping her morning coffee while Nicky, still in his pajamas, sat at the table munching on a bowl of cereal. She glanced at the calendar pinned to the fridge and smiled. Today was a special day.

 

“Nicky,” she said, setting her mug down and turning to him. “Did you know it’s Rio’s birthday today?”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened, and he looked up from his cereal with excitement. “It is? Is she coming over?”

 

“She is,” Agatha confirmed, her smile growing. “She’ll join us for lunch.”

 

“Can we get her a present?” Nicky asked immediately, his spoon clattering into his bowl. “We have to get her something!”

 

Agatha chuckled at his enthusiasm. “Of course, we can. After breakfast, we’ll go to the store and pick something out.”

 

Nicky practically inhaled the rest of his cereal, his little legs swinging excitedly under the table as Agatha finished her coffee. Soon, they were bundled up and headed to the local shop. The moment they walked in, Nicky began scanning the aisles with a determined expression, his small hand tucked firmly into Agatha’s.

 

As they wandered through the store, Nicky stopped abruptly in front of the toy section. His eyes landed on a colorful box, and his face lit up. “This!” he exclaimed, pointing at a Lego flower set.

 

Agatha tilted her head, inspecting the box. “Lego flowers, huh?”

 

“Yeah!” Nicky nodded eagerly. “Rio likes plants. You told me she had a bunch in her apartment. And we can build it together. She’ll like it, I know she will!”

 

Agatha’s heart warmed at his thoughtfulness, for having picked up on Rio’s likes and dislikes. “Alright, sweetheart, that’s a great idea. Let’s get it.”

 

They picked up the box, and as they headed toward the checkout, Agatha’s mind lingered on the present she already had found, a simple yet personal one. She had already wrapped it up, planning to give it to Rio later, when it was just the two of them.

 

Back at home, Nicky insisted on wrapping the Lego set himself. Agatha handed him some colorful paper and tape, watching with a mixture of amusement and pride as he meticulously folded and taped every corner, his tongue sticking out in concentration. When he was finished, he added a big, uneven bow on top and grinned triumphantly, the gift a little lopsided, but undoubtedly made with love.

 

“Perfect,” Agatha said, ruffling his hair.

 

 

The aroma of roasted vegetables and fresh bread filled Agatha’s home as she set the table for Rio’s birthday lunch. Nicky bounced on his heels beside her, holding his wrapped gift with an eagerness that threatened to burst out of him at any moment.

 

“Remember,” Agatha said with a gentle smile, placing a hand on his shoulder to calm him, “we’ll give Rio her gift after we eat.”

 

“But what if she wants to see it right away?” Nicky asked, his wide eyes darting toward the front door, as if expecting Rio to magically appear any second.

 

“She’ll love it no matter when you give it to her,” Agatha reassured him, pressing a kiss to the top of his head. “And patience, young man.”

 

Before he could argue, the doorbell rang. Nicky bolted to the door with an eager shout, leaving Agatha chuckling softly as she followed at a slower, more composed pace.

 

Rio stood on the porch, her cheeks pink from the cool air outside, holding a small potted plant. “Happy birthday to me,” she teased, lifting the plant like a toast before stepping inside.

 

“Happy birthday to you, indeed,” Agatha murmured, the affection in her voice as warm as the hand she placed on Rio’s arm. She leaned in to press a soft kiss to Rio’s cheek but pulled back quickly as Nicky barreled into Rio’s legs, wrapping his arms around her waist with all the enthusiasm of a child who had been waiting all morning.

 

“Happy birthday, Rio!” he shouted, hugging her tightly. “I made something for you. Well, I picked it out, but you can’t see it yet!”

 

Rio laughed, ruffling his hair as she set the plant down on a side table. “Well, thank you, darling, I’m very intrigued. And hungry. Let’s eat so I can find out what this mystery is.”

 

Agatha led them to the dining table, where a spread of Rio’s favorite dishes was waiting. They ate amidst lively chatter, with Nicky recounting stories from school and Rio sharing snippets of her work at the library and Alice’s latest joke. Agatha mostly listened, her gaze flitting between them as a quiet joy settled in her chest.

 

When the plates were cleared after the cake and Rio had blown her candles under Agatha and Nicky’s cheers and applause, Nicky couldn’t wait any longer. He dashed to the corner where he’d stashed the present and returned, clutching it tightly.

 

“Here,” he said, thrusting it toward Rio. “Open it! Open it now!”

 

Rio grinned as she carefully unwrapped the colorful paper. Her eyes widened as the Lego flower set came into view. “Oh, Nicky, this is perfect! I love it.”

 

“I knew it!” Nicky exclaimed, practically bouncing in place. “And we can build it together. Right now!”

 

Agatha laughed softly, watching the two of them with a mixture of amusement and affection. “Go on, you two. I’ll clean up in here.”

 

Rio followed Nicky to the living room, where they sprawled on the floor and emptied the box of Lego pieces. Nicky began sorting them into piles while explaining his grand vision for how they should build it. Rio nodded along, matching his excitement with her own.

 

“Okay, we start with this one,” Nicky instructed, holding up a piece. His voice was full of authority, his little brow furrowed in concentration.

 

“Got it, boss,” Rio said, her grin widening as she clicked the pieces together. 

 

Agatha, standing in the doorway, leaned against the frame and crossed her arms, a soft smile playing on her lips. The sight before her was almost too much—her son, so animated and joyful, and Rio, whose laughter was bright and unrestrained, fitting into their little world like she’d always been meant to. It made her heart soar - Rio’s laugh, so genuine and free, mingling with Nicky’s happy chatter as they worked together to sort the pieces.

 

Their heads were close together, hands moving in tandem as they constructed the intricate flowers. Occasionally, Nicky would pause to explain a step to Rio, his voice filled with authority and pride. Rio played along, following his instructions to the letter and cheering each time they completed a section.

 

“You’re really good at this,” Rio said, shooting Nicky a playful grin as she clicked another piece into place.

 

“I know,” Nicky replied, completely serious, earning a burst of laughter from Rio that filled the room.

 

Agatha moved to sit on the couch behind them, her presence quiet and steady as she watched them. Her heart swelled with love—love for her son, who had such a kind and vibrant spirit, and love for Rio, who brought a light into their lives that Agatha hadn’t even realized they’d been missing. Her heart felt impossibly full, the love she carried for both of them brimming over. This was her family, her life—and she wouldn’t trade it for anything in the world.

 

When the final flower was placed into its stand, Nicky clapped his hands together in triumph. “We did it!” he declared, beaming up at Rio.

 

“We sure did,” Rio said, pulling him into a hug on top of her. “Thank you, Nicky. This was the best birthday gift ever.”

 

Agatha leaned forward, resting her elbows on her knees as she joined their conversation. “You two make quite the team.”

 

Nicky nodded vigorously from his position, sprawled on Rio’s chest on the floor. “We’re the best team. Right, Rio?”

 

“The absolute best,” Rio agreed, her smile softening as her gaze met Agatha’s.

 

Agatha smiled, reaching over to brush a strand of hair from Rio’s face. “Happy birthday, my love,” she murmured, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

In that moment, surrounded by warmth, laughter, and the quiet hum of happiness, Rio felt a peace she hadn’t known in years. She was home. She was loved. And she was finally, blissfully, where she belonged.

 

 

After lunch, the three of them were lounging in the living room, the finished Lego flowers proudly displayed on the coffee table. Nicky had been carefully rearranging the blossoms into different configurations when Rio glanced at Agatha, a smile tugging at her lips. She nudged her girlfriend lightly with her foot, drawing her attention.

 

“I think it’s time,” Rio said softly, her eyes sparkling with anticipation.

 

Agatha chuckled, setting her mug down on the table. “You’re right.” She turned her gaze toward Nicky, who was now holding one of the Lego flowers up to the light as if inspecting its craftsmanship. “Nicky, sweetheart, can you come here for a second? We have something to tell you.”

 

Nicky immediately perked up, carefully setting the flower back on its stand before bounding over to the couch. He climbed up between them, looking from one to the other with wide, curious eyes. “What is it? Is it a secret?”

 

“Not exactly a secret,” Rio said, laughing softly. “More like exciting news.”

 

Agatha smiled warmly. “You know how Rio is in a band, right?”

 

“Uh-huh,” Nicky said, nodding enthusiastically. “She plays the drums! Like, really, really loud drums.”

 

“Exactly,” Rio said with a grin. “Well, we have a performance this afternoon. It’s part of a big event on campus, and guess what? It’s outside, so you can come this time.”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened with excitement. “Really? I can go?”

 

“Really,” Agatha confirmed, brushing a hand gently through his hair. “It’s a special day, and we thought it would be the perfect chance for you to see Rio play.”

 

“Do I get to sit in the front?” Nicky asked, bouncing on the couch in his enthusiasm.

 

Rio laughed. “You bet. I’ll make sure you have the best seat in the house.”

 

“And can I tell my friends that my mom’s girlfriend is a rock star?” Nicky blurted out, his little face alight with pride.

 

Agatha and Rio both froze for a moment before bursting into laughter. Agatha shook her head fondly. “I think that might give them the wrong idea, sweetheart. I promise soon, you can tell them anything you want about Rio. Just not now, remember ?”

 

“But you are kind of a rock star, right, Rio?” Nicky pressed, tilting his head with an earnest expression.

 

Rio smirked, leaning in conspiratorially. “Oh, definitely.”

 

Satisfied with her answer, Nicky threw his arms around Rio’s neck when she leaned down, squeezing her tightly. “I can’t wait! This is gonna be the best time ever!”

 

Agatha reached over, running a hand soothingly down Nicky’s back. Her eyes met Rio’s over her son’s shoulder, and the two of them shared a soft smile, the warmth of the moment settling over them like a comforting blanket.

 

“Then it’s a date,” Agatha said gently. “We’ll all go together.”

 

Nicky pulled back just enough to look up at them, his grin wide and toothy. “This is the best birthday ever,” he declared, and for a moment, it was impossible to tell whether he was more excited for Rio or for himself.

 

 

The late afternoon sun cast a golden glow over the park as Agatha, Rio, and Nicky strolled toward the makeshift stage set up for the event. A lively hum of activity surrounded them—vendors setting up stalls, families spreading picnic blankets, and students mingling in groups. Rio carried her drumsticks in her hand, tapping them lightly against her thigh in a rhythm only she could hear, and Agatha stood beside her at a respectable distance, holding her son’s hand whose eyes were darting around, clearly very excited by the bustling of everything.

 

As they approached the stage, Alice and Jen appeared, waving enthusiastically. Alice, dressed in her usual vibrant style, bounded over first, throwing her arms around Rio in a tight hug.

 

“Happy birthday, rock star!” she declared, pulling back with a grin.

 

Jen followed, offering Rio a quick hug of her own. “Happy birthday, boss,” she teased, earning a raised eyebrow from her own girlfriend. “Now come on, we’ve got work to do. The stage won’t set itself.”

 

Before Rio could respond, Alice looped her arm through Rio’s and started leading her away. “Come on, birthday girl. We need you backstage!”

 

Rio glanced over her shoulder at Agatha and Nicky with a sheepish smile. “See you in a bit!” she called, holding up her drumsticks as if to say, I’m off to work.

 

Agatha waved her on, her lips curling into a soft smile as she watched Rio disappear into the bustling crowd with her bandmates.

 

“Rio’s friends are so fun,” Nicky said, his eyes wide as he took in the scene, while him mom took the blanket out of her bag to set on the grass.

 

“They are,” Agatha agreed, resting a hand on his shoulder. She glanced around, and her gaze landed on a familiar figure approaching them—a figure she was secretly relieved to see.

 

“Hello there,” Lilia greeted warmly, her eyes flicking to Agatha before landing on Nicky. “And who is this young gentleman?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up as he scrambled to his feet, offering a shy wave. “I’m Nicky!” he announced proudly. “Are you Rio’s mom?”

 

Lilia laughed softly, crouching slightly to meet his gaze. “I am,” she said. “I’m Lilia. I’ve known Rio for a very long time, though. I think she’d say I’m kind of like her mom.”

 

“Oh!” Nicky said, tilting his head in thought and recognition. “You’re Rio’s ‘Lilia’, she told me about you. She also said that you would love me and that I would love you.”

 

Lilia blinked, startled for only a moment before her face softened. “She did, didn’t she? I suppose she was right, then!” she said, her tone carrying a hint of fond amusement.

 

Agatha stifled a chuckle, her hand brushing over Nicky’s head. “I’m sorry about that, Nicky doesn’t waste time,” she murmured, her lips twitching into a smile.

 

“Well, in that case,” Lilia said, straightening up and reaching into her bag, “I can’t meet this new lovable little young man empty-handed, can I?” She pulled out a small box of homemade cookies wrapped in a bright ribbon and handed them to Nicky.

 

His eyes widened as he accepted the gift. “Thank you!” he exclaimed, already trying to open the box.

 

“You’re very welcome, sweetheart, they were supposed to be for Rio, but she had plenty already,” Lilia said, brushing a strand of his hair away from his face with an affectionate touch. “Now, tell me, what’s your favorite kind of cookie? I’ll have to make more next time.”

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled. “I like chocolate chip! But I also like peanut butter. And the ones with sprinkles.”

 

Lilia laughed. “Sounds like I’ve got my work cut out for me,” she said, winking at Agatha, who shook her head with a grin.

“You’re such a sweet boy,” Lilia said, ruffling his hair. “Rio must absolutely adore you.”

 

Nicky beamed, turning to Agatha. “Can Lilia come over for dinner sometime? She’s so nice!”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow at Lilia, her smile growing. “I think that can be arranged,” she said.

 

Lilia settled on the blanket beside them, offering Nicky some of the snacks she’d brought. The way she fussed over him—making sure he had enough to drink, ensuring the sun wasn’t in his eyes—made Agatha’s heart ache in the best way.

 

 

As Rio stepped onto the stage with her band, the crowd gathered in the park cheered enthusiastically. Nicky clapped along with them, his eyes wide and sparkling with awe. He sat on the edge of a blanket, leaning forward as though he couldn’t get close enough.

 

“Isn’t she so cool, Mama?” Nicky whispered, his voice hushed with excitement.

 

Agatha couldn’t help the smile that tugged at her lips. She followed his gaze to the stage, where Rio was adjusting her seat slightly and sharing a laugh with Alice and Jen. The afternoon sun cast a soft glow on her, making her every movement seem effortless, confident, and alive.

 

“She’s the coolest,” Agatha murmured, her voice low enough for only Nicky to hear.

 

The band started their set, and the music filled the air, vibrant and dynamic. Nicky bounced to the rhythm, occasionally turning to Agatha with an expression of pure delight. Every so often, Rio’s eyes scanned the crowd, and when they landed on Agatha and Nicky, her smile brightened just a touch, a momentary sparkle that felt like it was meant only for them.

 

“She’s so good!” Nicky exclaimed as Rio expertly played her part in a high-energy song. “I wish I could play music like that.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly. “You can always learn,” she said, her heart swelling with pride as she watched Rio seamlessly blend into the music, her passion evident in every note.

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically. “Do you think she’d teach me?”

 

“I’m sure she would,” Agatha replied, her gaze never leaving Rio.

 

But while her son was focused on Rio’s musical prowess, Agatha found herself swept up in the sight of the woman she loved so completely. Every move Rio made, every note she played, was a reminder of the brilliant, multifaceted person she was. The fact that she couldn’t openly share this love yet, couldn’t reach out and take Rio’s hand in front of everyone, tugged at her heart.

 

Still, it was enough for now to be there, cheering her on with Nicky, sharing this moment as a little family in the making.

 

As the final song of the set came to a triumphant close, the crowd erupted in applause, Nicky included. He jumped to his feet from his position on his mom's lap, clapping as hard as his small hands could manage.

 

“Rio’s the best!” he declared, his voice loud enough to carry over the cheers.

 

"I couldn't agree more," Lilia said, ruffling his hair before clapping loudly too.

 

Agatha let out a laugh, standing to join him. “She really is,” she said softly, her eyes locked on Rio as she waved to the crowd, her face glowing with joy and exhilaration.

 

In that moment, despite the secrets they still had to keep, Agatha felt a deep, unshakable sense of contentment. Their love might be hidden for now, but it was no less real, no less powerful. And as Nicky leaned against her, his admiration for Rio clear in every word and gesture, Agatha knew they were building something truly beautiful together.
