Nicky had been bouncing in the backseat the whole ride there, still full of energy from the afternoon’s performance, his cheeks still flushed from the excitement of the day and from the anticipation of spending the night with his little friends.

 

“I’ll be good, I promise!” Nicky said as he unbuckled his seatbelt, grabbing the small bag he had packed. “Happy birthday again, Rio!”

 

“You better,” Agatha teased with a wink as she leaned over to kiss his forehead. “Have fun with Billy and Tommy. We’ll see you tomorrow morning.”

 

Nicky nodded, already running toward the door where Wanda was already standing, two little head peeking out from behind her legs, before Agatha and Rio could even fully park the car. He waved enthusiastically as he disappeared inside the house, and Rio and Agatha exchanged a smile.

 

With Nicky settled in for the night, they drove the short distance to Agatha’s house in comfortable silence. The air between them was light and warm, filled with the afterglow of the day’s celebrations. As they pulled into the driveway, Rio turned to Agatha with a soft smile.

 

“Thank you for today,” Rio said quietly, her voice thick with emotion. “It was perfect.”

 

Agatha reached over, taking Rio’s hand in hers. “You deserve perfect, Rio. You deserve everything.”

 

They made their way inside, Agatha locking the door behind them. The house felt so different when it was just the two of them. It was like the world had quieted down, and everything was simply theirs.

 

“I have something for you,” Agatha said, her voice steady but with a hint of excitement. She led Rio to the living room and gestured for her to sit on the couch, the warm glow of the lamps casting a soft light around them.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow. “You didn’t have to get me anything.”

 

Agatha smiled, a little teasing. “Of course I did. It’s your birthday, after all.” She disappeared for a moment, returning with a small, wrapped box in her hands. She sat down next to Rio and handed it to her.

 

Rio took the box, her fingers brushing over the soft, smooth wrapping paper. She glanced up at Agatha, her heart fluttering in her chest. “You’re really spoiling me today,” she said, already feeling a rush of affection.

 

“Open it,” Agatha urged softly, her eyes never leaving Rio’s face.

 

Rio carefully tore the wrapping paper, revealing a small wooden box. She opened it, and inside was a delicate bracelet, silver with four tiny, intricate golden charms that seemed to tell a story all their own. It was simple, yet beautiful, just like the love she shared with Agatha.

 

“It’s stunning,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “But… why this?”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, and she placed a hand on Rio’s. “Each charm represents something about you. The heart is for your kindness, the flower for your strength and growth, and the star for the way you shine in my life. And the wave is my favorite, because it is graceful, strong like a river and with a quiet depth that pulls me in deeper every day.”

 

Tears welled up in Rio’s eyes, and she took the necklace in her hands, holding it to her chest. “I love it, Agatha. I love it so much.”

 

“I’m glad,” Agatha said softly. She kissed Rio’s temple, and they sat in quiet, tender silence for a moment.

 

After a beat, Agatha spoke again, her voice low and full of love. “You deserve to be celebrated, Rio. Not just today, but every day. I don’t think you even realize just how extraordinary you are.”

 

Rio leaned her head on Agatha’s shoulder, feeling her heart swell with love and contentment. “I’m just glad I get to spend this life with you. You make everything feel better, like everything is right.”

 

Agatha kissed her forehead, lingering there for a moment before pulling back slightly to look at Rio with a soft, affectionate gaze. “I love you, Rio. So much.”

 

“I love you too,” Rio replied quietly, her voice thick with sincerity.

 

As Rio held her present in her hands, her heart still racing from the emotion of the gift, Agatha gently cupped her face, brushing her thumb over Rio’s cheek. The quiet between them felt like a soft, sacred space, where nothing could intrude.

It wasn’t rushed, but it was filled with the depth of everything they’d shared. Agatha’s hand slid into Rio’s hair, pulling her just a little closer, as if to remind her this moment was real, that they were real.

 

When they pulled back, both of them breathless and a little flushed, Rio smiled shyly. “You’re full of surprises tonight, aren’t you?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, brushing a strand of hair behind Rio’s ear. “I just wanted to make sure you felt as special as you are.” Her eyes softened as she took in the sight of Rio in front of her, the love and admiration clear in every glance. “You deserve so much more, Rio.”

Agatha’s hand moved to the back of Rio’s neck, holding her gently as their lips danced together in perfect rhythm. It felt like coming home, like every kiss was an echo of everything they’d built together, everything they were becoming.

 

When they finally pulled apart, their foreheads touched, both of them a little breathless. “I think you’ve officially spoiled me,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with affection.

 

Agatha smiled, her eyes sparkling. “Good. I plan on spoiling you more.” She kissed Rio’s lips once more, soft and lingering. « Happy birthday, my love.”

 

The air around them seemed to hum with something unspoken, something shared only between them. Agatha gently guided Rio to rest her head against her shoulder, both of them content to simply be in the moment. There was no rush, no need for words. Just the quiet comfort of being together, of knowing that, whatever came next, they had each other.

 

After a few moments, Rio pulled back slightly, her fingers tracing the collar of Agatha’s shirt, a playful smile tugging at her lips. “You really know how to make a girl feel loved, don’t you?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her heart swelling at the sight of Rio, so beautiful and full of love. “I’m just getting started.”

 

And as they shared one more kiss, it was everything. All of the love, the passion, and the quiet comfort of knowing that they were exactly where they were meant to be.

 

As the evening stretched on, their laughter faded into quiet whispers, and the weight of the world seemed to fall away as they held each other close. Rio leaned against Agatha, her hand tracing the lines of Agatha’s shirt as if committing every detail of the moment to memory. Agatha, too, felt the closeness, the undeniable warmth between them, a love that felt both timeless and new.

 

After a while, they found themselves curled up on the couch, still in the quiet bubble of intimacy they had created. Agatha brushed a stray lock of hair from Rio’s face, her fingers lingering against her skin as she met Rio’s gaze.

 

“You know,” Agatha murmured, her voice soft, “this feels like the perfect way to end the day.”

 

Rio smiled, a playful glint in her eyes. “I think we both know the night’s just getting started.”

 

Agatha’s heart skipped a beat at the confidence in Rio’s voice, at the promise of more shared moments between them. “So it is,” Agatha replied, her lips curving into a slow smile. “But we’ve got all the time in the world.”

 

With that, the air around them seemed to change. The kiss that followed was slow, deeper than any before, filled with a hunger neither of them could quite explain, but one they couldn’t ignore. The air between them was thick with want, the kind that had simmered for so long it was inevitable they would be consumed by it. Their kisses turned hungrier, teeth clashing, tongues tangling, their bodies pressing so close it was impossible to tell where one ended and the other began. The air between them crackled, thick with need, with devotion, with something deeper than just passion. Every whispered word, every stolen glance, every moment spent in quiet intimacy had led them here.

 

 

Agatha’s hands found their way under Rio’s shirt, palms sliding against bare skin, tracing the dips and curves she had memorized in stolen touches with the kind of reckless devotion that left them both trembling. She broke away just long enough to tug Rio’s shirt over her head before her lips found the column of her throat, pressing kisses down, slow, deliberate, savoring the way Rio shuddered beneath her.

 

Agatha’s lips ghosted over Rio’s jaw, down her throat, her breath hot and teasing against the sensitive skin. Rio let out a soft, shuddering sigh as her fingers traced the planes of Agatha’s back, slipping beneath her shirt, nails raking lightly against smooth skin. Agatha groaned at the sensation, tilting her head to claim Rio’s lips again, this time with even more urgency, more fire.

 

Rio felt her knees go weak at the way Agatha looked at her—like she was something precious, something sacred, something to be cherished. And she was.

 

“You drive me mad,” Agatha murmured against Rio’s skin, her voice rough with need, her breath sending a delicious shiver down Rio’s spine.

 

Rio gasped, her fingers curling into Agatha’s long hair, anchoring herself as she felt the world tilt. “Then lose your mind for me.”

 

A growl vibrated against her throat before Agatha’s hands found her hips, gripping tight, guiding her backward until the backs of Rio’s knees hit the bed. She tumbled onto the mattress, pulling Agatha down with her, their laughter mingling with heated breaths before their mouths met again, desperate, open, insatiable.

 

Agatha hovered over her, taking her in, fingers tracing delicate patterns along Rio’s ribs, her touch light but searing, leaving a trail of heat in its wake. “You’re beautiful,” she whispered, not just admiring but worshiping.

 

Rio’s breath hitched, her hands finding purchase in Agatha’s hair, tugging her down for another kiss—deep, slow, claiming. “Show me,” she murmured against Agatha’s lips.

 

And Agatha did.

 

She worshipped her with hands and lips, memorizing every inch, every sigh, every whispered plea. She took her time, never rushing, as though she wanted to etch every sensation into her soul. And Rio, beneath her, undone by every touch, every press of lips, every whispered confession, felt as if she were made of fire and Agatha was the only one who knew how to burn with her without turning to ash.

 

When the last piece of clothing was gone, and they were bare in every sense of the word, Agatha took her time tracing the shape of Rio’s body with her hands, her lips, her tongue, memorizing every inch, every reaction. And Rio, beneath her, met every touch with her own, worship for worship, love for love.

 

Agatha moved with an almost unbearable tenderness, like every touch, every kiss, every whispered word was a vow. It wasn’t just passion; it was love—raw, aching, all-consuming. There was no rush, no frantic desperation—only a deliberate unraveling, a slow-burning fire that built and built until it consumed them both.

 

Rio gasped as Agatha’s lips found the sensitive spot just beneath her ear, her body arching, pressing closer, needing more, needing everything. And Agatha gave it all to her—soft touches, whispered reassurances, devotion woven into every movement, every breath.

 

“I adore you,” Rio whispered between kisses, her voice breathless, her heart pounding against her ribs. It wasn’t just a declaration—it was a confession, a raw, unfiltered truth laid bare between them. “You’re the best thing that’s ever happened to me.”

 

Agatha pulled back slightly, looking into Rio’s eyes with a tenderness that made Rio’s heart race. “And you’re mine,” Agatha replied, her voice steady, but there was something in her eyes—something raw, something powerful—that made Rio’s chest ache in the best way.

 

They moved together like a perfect melody—every touch, every sigh, every whispered name a note in the song they had been composing for as long as they had known each other. There was no rush, no urgency beyond the need to feel, to take, to give, to revel in the sacred intimacy that belonged to them alone.

 

They were there, together, two souls intertwined, sharing more than just a physical connection but something deeper, something that tied them together in a way nothing else could.

 

 “You make me feel so loved,” Rio whispered, eyes half-lidded, body trembling beneath Agatha’s touch.

 

Agatha smiled against her skin, pressing a kiss to the center of her chest before pulling her up into another searing kiss as her fingers slid into Rio’s hair, cradling her gently as she tilted her head back. “You are loved, Rio. So deeply. And I’ll show you every day,” she promised, voice low, reverent, absolute. “Every single day.”

 

And she did. Again and again, until there was nothing left between them but the warmth of their bodies, the soft hum of their breath, and the unshakable certainty that this—this love, this devotion—was the most real thing they had ever known.

 

The night was theirs. There was no rushing, no time constraints—just the two of them, wrapped in each other’s arms, their bodies as close as they could get. 

 

The night passed in a haze of soft whispers, tender touches, quiet gasps that spoke of devotion and cried-out names. They held each other close after, bodies entwined in the comfort of knowing they were exactly where they were meant to be.

 

When they finally settled into the bed, their bodies spent of their energy, chests heaving, the weight of the world seemed to lift, leaving behind only peace. The soft hum of their breath filled the room as they held each other, skin pressed to skin, fingers tracing idle patterns against damp skin, tangled in sheets and love.

 

There, in the quiet, in the stillness of the night, they found their peace.

 

Rio sighed, burrowing deeper into Agatha’s warmth, her head resting against her chest, listening to the steady rhythm of her heartbeat. Agatha pressed a kiss to her forehead, her fingers trailing lazily down Rio’s spine.

 

Their love was quiet in public, but so loud in private—loud in the way they clung to each other, in the way they whispered promises in the dark, in the way they let themselves be completely, utterly bare with one another.

 

They drifted to sleep wrapped in each other’s arms, the promise of tomorrow and every day after that waiting for them. And when the morning light began to seep through the window, they were still together, still holding on to the love they had found.

*

 

 

Chapter End Notes

I died dead writing this chapter.

Institutional Progress

Chapter Notes

Once again, I know it doesn’t work like that in real life and in a real university, but roll with it, it’s for the plot, guy!
Enjoy :)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

*

*

*

 

Dawn points, and another day

Prepares for heat and silence.

Out at sea the dawn wind

Wrinkles and slides. I am here

Or there, or elsewhere. In my beginning.

 

              (T.S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

A week later, the early morning sunlight filtered through the curtains in Rio’s apartment, casting soft, golden light across the room, bathing her numerous plants in a luminous glow. Agatha stirred first, blinking against the warmth of the sun, her arms wrapped securely around Rio. The younger woman’s face was relaxed in sleep, her dark hair a wild mess across the pillow, and Agatha couldn’t help the soft smile that tugged at her lips.

 

For months, they’d been stealing these quiet moments together, hidden away from prying eyes and expectations. It had been thrilling in some ways, but there was also a weight that came with the secrecy—a weight Agatha felt pressing more heavily as time went on.

 

Rio began to stir, her nose crinkling adorably before her eyes fluttered open. She looked up at Agatha with a sleepy smile. “Morning,” she murmured, her voice thick with sleep as she snuggled closer.

 

“Morning, darling,” Agatha replied, pressing a kiss to Rio’s forehead. For a while, they simply lay there, enjoying the comfort of each other’s presence. But as Agatha’s mind wandered, a thought she’d been avoiding began to take shape.

 

“I’ve been thinking,” Agatha started, her voice careful but firm, “about us. About how we’ve been handling things.”

 

Rio tilted her head up, her expression curious but open. “What kind of thinking?”

 

Agatha exhaled, stroking her fingers lightly along Rio’s arm. “I mean… the sneaking around. It’s worked so far, but if we’re serious about this—and I know I am—I wonder if it’s time to be a bit more… transparent.”

 

Rio blinked, sitting up slightly to face Agatha more fully. “You’re talking about telling someone.”

 

“Yes.” Agatha nodded, meeting Rio’s gaze. “The dean, specifically. If we disclosed our relationship, it would make things clean. No whispers, no misunderstandings. Just honesty. It’s not like we’ve done anything wrong, but keeping it quiet does leave room for speculation.”

 

Rio considered this, her brow furrowing as she chewed on her bottom lip. “You’re right,” she said after a pause. “I mean, it’s not like we can keep it a secret forever, not if we’re serious. And I am too, by the way,” she added quickly, reaching to take Agatha’s hand. “Serious, I mean.”

 

Agatha’s heart softened at Rio’s earnestness. “I know you are,” she murmured, squeezing her hand gently.

 

Rio sighed, leaning her head against Agatha’s shoulder. “I guess it does make sense. The dean’s fair, and I don’t think he’d have an issue as long as we’re honest about it. And I’d rather tell him than have someone else find out and try to make it a thing.”

 

“Exactly.” Agatha wrapped an arm around Rio, pulling her closer. “We’ll do it together. When you’re ready.”

 

Rio tilted her head to look at her with a small smile. “What happened to sneaky Professor Harkness who liked stealing kisses in her office and rushing home for secret rendezvous?”

 

Agatha chuckled, playfully tapping her fingers on Rio’s back. “Oh, she’s still here. But I think it’s time for us to move past sneaking around. You deserve more than that.”

 

Rio sighed contentedly, curling back against Agatha. “Okay. Let’s do it. I’m in.”

 

They lay there for a few more moments, basking in the quiet resolution they’d made together. It wasn’t just about telling the dean—it was about taking another step forward, about building something solid together, without fear or hesitation.

 

The day had grown brighter through the window as Rio slid out of Agatha’s embrace, sitting up and stretching. Though they’d just resolved something important, a flicker of stress was still visible in her expression as she toyed with the edge of the blanket.

 

Agatha noticed immediately, propping herself up on one elbow. “What’s wrong, darling?”

 

Rio glanced back at her, offering a small smile that didn’t quite reach her eyes. “Nothing, really. Just… the idea of telling the dean is a lot. Even though I know it’s the right thing, it still feels like a big step.”

 

Agatha reached out, tucking a strand of hair behind Rio’s ear. “It is a big step,” she said softly. “But it’s one we’re taking together, and you’re not doing it alone. I promise you, it’s going to be okay.”

 

Rio nodded, exhaling slowly. “You’re right. I just—maybe I need to take a minute to shake this off.”

 

“I’ve got an idea,” Agatha murmured, her tone shifting to something softer, something coaxing. “Why don’t you take a nice, hot shower? It’ll help you relax.”

 

Rio turned, a glint of mischief sparking in her dark eyes. “A shower, huh?” Her lips curled into a knowing smile as she leaned back on her elbows, stretching languidly, deliberately. “I’ll only do it if you join me.”

 

Agatha’s brow lifted, her gaze sweeping over Rio’s form with lazy appreciation. “Is that so?”

 

“Mhm.” Rio rose to her feet, the blanket slipping off her shoulders and pooling at her feet. She didn’t bother picking it up, instead sauntering toward the bathroom door with an air of pure temptation, glancing back just before disappearing inside. “What do you say, Dr. Harkness? Care to help me unwind?”

 

Agatha was already moving, the corner of her mouth twitching into a smirk as she followed. “Lead the way, Ms. Vidal.”

 

The bathroom quickly filled with the hiss of rushing water and the slow curl of steam, the air turning thick with heat and anticipation.

Water streamed over Rio’s skin, tracing the delicate lines of her body, glistening like dewdrops against golden-hued flesh. Agatha’s hands found their way to Rio’s hips, fingers pressing in just enough to remind her she was there, solid, present, wanting.

 

“See?” Rio murmured, her voice husky as she slid her hands up Agatha’s bare arms, nails dragging lightly in a way that sent a ripple of pleasure down Agatha’s spine. “Told you this was a good idea.”

 

Agatha hummed, her lips ghosting over Rio’s throat, lingering there, teasing. “You’re trouble, you know that?”

 

Rio’s laugh was soft, breathy, her fingers threading through Agatha’s damp hair, tugging lightly until their mouths met. The kiss was slow at first, a languid exploration, but quickly deepened into something more desperate, more consuming. Water drummed against their skin as they lost themselves in each other, hands roaming, bodies molding together like they were made to fit.

 

Agatha’s hands roamed over Rio’s front and down her curves, trailing down the curve of Rio’s back, over the swell of her hips, before pulling her flush against her. Rio gasped into the kiss, her body arching instinctively, pressing into the heat of Agatha’s touch.

 

The tension from their earlier conversation melted away entirely, replaced by the tender, electric connection they shared.

 

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, her voice raw with need.

 

That was all it took.

 

Agatha moved with purpose, her touch reverent and sure, her fingers tracing every dip, every curve, as if committing Rio’s body to memory all over again. Rio melted under her, gasping, grasping, her nails biting into Agatha’s shoulders as she surrendered completely, letting the pleasure consume her.

 

They moved together, finding their rhythm, their breaths mingling and their bodies perfectly in sync, the intimacy between them growing with every passing moment, their whispers and gasps drowned out by the sound of the water around them.

 

As they reached their peak, Rio clung to Agatha, one hand around her neck, her head resting on the older woman’s shoulder as a wave of euphoria washed over her. Agatha held her close, her arms around Rio’s waist, holding her up, her lips brushing over Rio’s temple, her voice a soft murmur of adoration.

 

“You are a goddess,” Agatha whispered against her skin, her voice filled with something deeper than desire—something raw, something devoted.

 

Rio lifted her head, her dark eyes meeting Agatha’s, unguarded and blazing with emotion. “And you’re my queen.”

 

They stood like that for a while, bodies pressed together, chests rising and falling in unison, letting the water wash away the last remnants of tension, leaving only bliss in its wake. Eventually, they cleaned up, their movements slower now, more relaxed.

 

By the time they stepped out of the shower, wrapped in towels and grinning at each other, the stress of the morning was nothing more than a distant memory. They were ready to face whatever came next—together.

 

 

The atmosphere in Dean Montgomery’s office was formal, the air heavy with the weight of the discussion ahead, quiet, save for the ticking of a clock on the wall. Agatha and Rio sat side by side, across from him, their hands clasped tightly under the desk where the dean couldn’t see. Though they’d prepared for this moment, it didn’t make the anticipation any easier.

 

The dean adjusted his glasses, leaning forward slightly.

 

“All right, Dr. Harkness, Ms. Vidal,” he said, his tone expectant. “You requested this meeting. What can I do for you?”

 

Agatha took a breath, her voice steady and professional. “Dean Montgomery, thank you for meeting with us. We’ve come here to disclose something regarding our relationship.”

 

The dean’s brows furrowed slightly, curiosity sharpening his gaze. “Go on.”

 

Rio glanced at Agatha, who gave her a subtle nod of encouragement. “Dr. Harkness and I… are in a personal relationship,” Rio said, her voice firm but respectful. “We felt it was important to be transparent about it.”

 

For a moment, the dean simply regarded them, his expression unreadable. Then he sat back, interlacing his fingers, his eyes sharp. “So, let me get this straight. You’re here to disclose that the two of you are in a romantic relationship?”

 

“Yes,” Agatha said evenly, her voice calm and steady. She had perfected that tone, the one that exuded confidence and competence, but even so, Rio could feel a slight tension in her grip. “We wanted to ensure full transparency. We’re aware of the university’s policies and the ethical expectations in situations like this.”

 

“When did this start?”

 

Agatha answered immediately. “Several months ago, sir. We’ve kept our relationship entirely separate from our professional roles, ensuring there’s no overlap or conflict of interest.”

 

Montgomery nodded, his expression unreadable, his eyes flickering between the two of them, measuring his words. “I appreciate your honesty, but you’re aware that relationships between faculty and students—especially when one is directly supervising the other—can be problematic. There are recommendations in place for this very reason.”

 

Rio took a breath and spoke, her voice unwavering. “We completely understand the concerns, Dean Montgomery. However, we’ve been very careful to keep our personal relationship separate from our professional one. Dr. Harkness has always been—and continues to be—an incredible mentor to me. Dr. Harkness has been nothing but professional. My progress and evaluations have been handled with complete fairness, and she holds me accountable for everything.”

 

Agatha added, “I’ve made certain to maintain professionalism in all matters regarding Rio’s PhD work. Our relationship has not, and will not, affect her progress or compromise the integrity of my supervision. Her outstanding presentation at the latest conference, where she was an invited speaker, serves as evidence of this. The numerous assessments of her work, all aligning with my earlier observations, speak for themselves. »

 

The dean let out a small sigh, tapping his fingers on the desk. “I don’t doubt the quality of Miss Vidal’s work. The concern isn’t just about fairness, though that’s certainly a part of it. It’s also about perception. Others might assume bias, even if there isn’t any.”

 

Rio nodded. “We’ve been discreet precisely because we understand the importance of avoiding even the appearance of impropriety. We’re not trying to flaunt our relationship—we simply want to be upfront about it now to avoid any misunderstandings later. We’ve kept our relationship private, and our priority has always been maintaining the integrity of my work and Dr. Harkness’s role as my supervisor.”

 

Montgomery sighed, his gaze softening slightly as he glanced between them. “You’re both aware this is highly unconventional, but…” He paused, then leaned forward. “It’s clear you’ve thought this through, and I trust Dr. Harkness’s judgment as both a faculty member and a supervisor. However, I’ll have to set some boundaries. Agatha, I expect you to ensure there’s no favoritism. Your role is to provide Miss Vidal with the best supervision possible, as you would for any student.”

 

“Of course,” Agatha said firmly. “We’re bringing this to your attention now because we don’t want there to be any misunderstandings or surprises down the line. We value the trust the university places in us, and we’re committed to upholding it.”

 

Dean Montgomery nodded, before continuing. “And Miss Vidal,” he said, turning to her, “I trust you’ll hold her accountable and not hesitate to speak up if anything feels amiss. If at any point you feel there’s an imbalance or issue, I expect you to bring it to my attention immediately.”

 

“I will,” Rio promised.

 

The dean gave a small nod, his tone softening further. “As long as you maintain professionalism and avoid public displays of your relationship while you’re both at the university, I don’t see a reason to interfere. But I’ll say this: tread carefully. You’re both taking a risk by being in this situation. But you’re both consenting adults, and as long as this doesn’t interfere with the academic or professional standards of the university, I won’t intervene. Just… be careful.”

 

Agatha offered a small, genuine smile. “Thank you, Dean Montgomery. We won’t let you down.”

 

Rio echoed the sentiment. “Thank you for your understanding.”

 

As they left the office, the door clicking shut behind them, Rio let out a deep breath she hadn’t realized she was holding. Agatha reached over, squeezing her hand.

 

“Well, that wasn’t a complete disaster.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, brushing a hand down the sleeve of Rio’s blazer. “That went better than expected,” she murmured, her lips quirking in a small, relieved smile. “He handled it better than I expected. I’m glad we did it.”

 

Rio smirked, her eyes twinkling. “Speak for yourself. My heart was about to leap out of my chest.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her voice warm. “That’s why I did most of the talking.”

 

Rio nodded, her own smile spreading. “Yeah. Now we just have to keep doing what we’ve been doing, but more freely.”

 

Agatha chuckled, her voice warm. “Piece of cake.”

 

Rio nodded, the tension in her chest loosening. “At least now we don’t have to feel like we’re sneaking around completely in the dark.”

 

Agatha gave her a thoughtful look as they walked down the hallway. “We agreed it would stay private, but not a secret anymore.”

 

Rio’s smile widened. “I like the sound of that. I mean, we’re not broadcasting it to the world, but if people notice or ask… we don’t have to lie.”

 

Agatha reached out, briefly brushing Rio’s fingers with her own before pulling her hand back, ever mindful of where they were. “Exactly. It’s about being honest, not flaunting.”

 

Rio chuckled, the sound lighter than before. “Well, I doubt Alice will be able to keep a straight face now. She’s been holding this in like a dam about to burst.”

 

Agatha smirked. “Let’s just hope she doesn’t start telling stories about how she ‘knew it all along.’ I have to admit, I’ll miss the whole sneaking around thing.”

 

“Oh, Dr. Harkness, who said that part was all over? I think I like being the naughty student stealing kisses from her illustrious professor.” Rio teased, her voice low, leaning closer to Agatha, who only responded with a slight pull of Rio’s ponytail, her eyes playful and a tad darker.

 

Rio’s laugh was a quiet, joyous thing, and for the first time in what felt like weeks, she felt truly at ease in this building. They walked side by side down the corridor, their steps in sync, knowing that while the weight of secrecy hadn’t entirely lifted, the burden felt infinitely lighter.

 

 

The moment Agatha, Rio, and Nicky stepped into Lilia’s cozy home that night, the warm, inviting smell of roasted vegetables and herbs greeted them. Nicky eagerly kicked off his sneakers and bounded into the living room where Lilia was waiting with open arms.

 

“There’s my favorite little guy!” Lilia said warmly, leaning down to hug Nicky. “A little birdie told me I made your favorite—mashed potatoes. And there’s dessert after.”

 

“Dessert?” Nicky’s eyes lit up. “What kind?”

 

Lilia winked conspiratorially. “Chocolate cake with extra icing on top. But don’t tell the others I told you before dinner.”

 

Nicky giggled, shooting a gleeful glance back at Rio and Agatha as if he’d just been let in on the world’s greatest secret.

 

Agatha leaned toward Rio, whispering with a chuckle, “It’s like they’ve known each other for years.”

 

“She has that effect,” Rio said, smiling softly. “She’s magic.” Rio then raised her voice, sighing dramatically. “Look, she’s already forgotten all about me”

 

Lilia turned to the two women with a teasing smile. “As if I could. Come here, girl, before you lose all your chocolate privileges in this house,” she said, holding her arms open invitingly.

 

“Yep, wouldn’t risk it,” Rio laughed as she stepped into Lilia’s warm embrace, the older woman pressing a maternal kiss to her forehead. With a playful smile, Lilia freed one arm to gesture toward Agatha, who was watching the scene with fondness in her eyes. “You too, Agatha—this house has standards, you know!”

 

Agatha chuckled and joined in, a little tenser than Rio, but the smile on her face betrayed her true feelings about this new dynamic.

 

During dinner, Nicky sat close to Lilia, chattering away about school and the Lego flower set he’d built with Rio. Lilia listened intently, nodding and laughing in all the right places. She was patient with his every tangent and question, utterly charmed by his endless enthusiasm.

 

Halfway through the meal, Lilia dabbed her mouth with a napkin and leaned in conspiratorially. “Nicky, do you want to know something funny about your Rio when she was your age… well a bit older, but who cares?”

 

Rio groaned softly, already anticipating the stories. “Lilia—”

 

“Oh, hush,” Lilia teased with a playful grin. “It’s nothing too embarrassing, I promise.” Turning back to Nicky, a mischievous glint sparkled in her eye. “When Rio was about twelve—she wasn’t living with me yet, but she’d visit sometimes when her foster family couldn’t keep her—she decided she was going to build a fort in the backyard using sticks and a tarp. She was so determined that she stayed out there in the rain until it was finished.”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened. “Did it work?”

 

“Sort of,” Lilia said with a laugh. “It stayed up long enough for her to sit inside for maybe five minutes before it collapsed completely. She was soaked through, muddy, and grinning ear to ear when she came inside.”

 

Nicky laughed so hard he nearly toppled his glass of water. “That’s so cool! Rio, you were like an adventurer!”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, but a smile tugged at her lips as she reminisced about one of her fondest childhood memories—a rare treasure from a time when such moments were few and far between. “Yeah, an adventurer who caught a cold for two weeks afterward.”

 

“That’s what you get for being stubborn as a mule,” Lilia teased, nudging her affectionately.

 

The stories continued throughout the evening, each one more entertaining than the last. Lilia talked about Rio’s teenage years, her early love for music, and even a story about how Rio once tried to bake cookies and forgot the sugar entirely.

 

By the end of the night, Nicky was firmly attached to Lilia, declaring, “Lilia you’re the best in the world? Rio was right, you’re the coolest.”

 

“Well, sweetheart,” Lilia said, patting his hand, “she was right about you too.”

 

Agatha looked at Rio, her heart swelling at the sight of the family they were creating—one bound not just by blood but by choice, love, and laughter.

 

“She’s amazing,” Agatha said softly.

 

“She’s always been my home,” Rio replied, leaning her head briefly against Agatha’s shoulder.

 

“And now,” Agatha murmured, her voice tender, “she’s part of ours too.”

 

Throughout the evening, Lilia’s affection for Rio shone brighter than ever. She brushed a stray strand of hair from Rio’s face as they sat side by side on the couch after dinner, her gaze warm and maternal.

 

“You’ve come so far, my girl,” Lilia said softly, her voice thick with emotion. “From that stubborn little adventurer building forts in the rain to this incredible woman everyone here is so proud of.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed, and she ducked her head slightly, but the small, vulnerable smile she gave in return said everything.

 

“I wouldn’t be here without you,” Rio said, her voice quiet. “You’re the reason I know what love and home feel like.”

 

“Oh, sweetheart,” Lilia murmured, pulling Rio into a hug. “You’ve always had that light in you. I just gave it a place to shine.”

 

Agatha, watching the exchange, felt her chest tighten with emotion. Seeing Rio so at ease, so cherished, was a rare and beautiful sight.

 

As the night wore on, Lilia’s warmth extended toward Agatha too. While Rio and Nicky were engrossed in building an impromptu card tower on the coffee table, Lilia leaned toward Agatha with a knowing look.

 

“She’s happy,” Lilia said, her tone soft but pointed.

 

Agatha met her gaze, her voice steady. “I’ll do everything I can to keep it that way.”

 

“I believe you,” Lilia replied, her hand reaching out to rest lightly on Agatha’s arm. “I wasn’t sure at first—not because of who you are, but because of what she’s been through. But seeing her like this, seeing the way she lights up when you’re around… I can see she’s safe with you.”

 

Agatha swallowed, feeling a swell of gratitude and responsibility. “She’s changed my life too. I don’t take her—or this—lightly.”

 

Lilia smiled, giving Agatha’s arm a small squeeze. “Good. Because if you ever hurt her, you’ll have to answer to me.” Her voice held a teasing lilt, but her eyes carried a protective gleam.

 

“I wouldn’t expect anything less,” Agatha replied with a chuckle, though she meant every word.

 

Later, as they prepared to leave, Lilia hugged Rio tightly, whispering something in her ear that made Rio smile and nod. To Agatha’s surprise, Lilia then turned to her, pulling her into a hug as well.

 

“You’re family now, too,” Lilia said, her voice warm.

 

Agatha blinked, momentarily speechless. She returned the hug, murmuring a soft, “Thank you.”

 

As they prepared to leave, Nicky tugged gently on Lilia’s sleeve, his wide eyes peering up at her with earnestness. Lilia crouched to meet his gaze, her ever-present warmth radiating in her smile.

 

“What is it, sweetheart?” she asked softly.

 

Nicky glanced toward Rio and Agatha, as though to ensure they were within earshot but not entirely paying attention. “Can I ask you something?”

 

“Of course, you can.”

 

“Well…” He hesitated, fidgeting with his hands. “I don’t have a grandma. But you’re kinda like Rio’s mom, right? And since Rio loves my mom, does that mean you could maybe… be my grandma?”

 

The room fell into a stunned but tender silence. Lilia blinked, her eyes shimmering with unshed tears. Her hands cupped Nicky’s small, eager face as a beaming smile spread across her lips.

 

“Oh, Nicky,” she murmured, her voice thick with emotion. “I would be honored to be your grandma. If that’s okay if your Mama, of course.”

 

“Really?” Nicky asked, his face lighting up with joy.

 

“Really,” she assured him, pulling him into a warm embrace.

 

Nicky turned his small face toward Agatha, his expression still tinged with hesitation but brimming with so much hope that Agatha felt her heart nearly burst. “Of course, my love. Lilia can be whatever you want her to be,” she said, her voice catching slightly in her throat.

 

For so long, it had just been the two of them, and Agatha had always felt a twinge of sadness that she couldn’t give Nicky the kind of big, loving family she had always dreamed of for him. But now, seeing him surrounded by people who cared for him as deeply as she did, she felt an overwhelming gratitude for the life she was building with the woman beside her.

 

As her hand tightened in Rio’s, Agatha’s heart swelled with thankfulness for this unexpected, beautiful love that had brought so much more to her son’s world.

 

Nicky giggled, hugging her tightly. “Thank you, you’re the best! I’ll come up with the very best name for you, I promise!”

 

Beside her, Rio felt her throat tighten, a lump forming as she watched the exchange unfold. Agatha’s hand slid higher up her arm, giving it a gentle squeeze.

 

“You okay?” Agatha asked softly, her voice full of quiet affection.

 

Rio nodded, her voice trembling slightly when she finally answered. “Yeah. More than okay.”

 

Lilia turned toward them, her gaze warm and filled with pride. “That right there—that’s the best gift you could ever give me.”

 

Unable to hold back any longer, Rio surged forward, throwing her arms around Lilia’s neck. “I love you, Lilia. You have no idea how much.”

 

Lilia chuckled, wrapping her arms around Rio in a firm embrace. “Oh, I know, sweetheart. Because I love you just as much. You’re my sweet, kind, brilliant girl, and I couldn’t be prouder of you—for everything you’ve built and everything you’ve become.”

 

When Rio finally pulled back, a single tear had escaped down her cheek, and Lilia brushed it away with her thumb. “Now, go back to your girl and your boy, my love. I’ll always be here for you.”

 

Rio nodded, her chest warm with emotion as she returned to Agatha, who greeted her back with a soft smile and wrapped an arm around her waist, pulling her close. On her other side, a small hand slipped into hers, and Rio looked down to see Nicky leaning against her, his eyes shining with joy as he smiled up at her.

 

In that moment, Rio knew she truly had it all.

 

As they left with more containers of cookies and leftover than they could eat, Nicky waved enthusiastically at Lilia from the car, shouting, “Bye, Lilia! See you soon!”

 

Lilia stood on the porch, waving back with a hand pressed to her heart, her smile soft and full of love. “See you soon, sweetheart. Bye my loves.”

 

For Rio, it was the perfect end to an already perfect evening.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Thank you for your comments, they really make me so happy :)
Also, if any of you have episodes or ideas you’d love to see happen, please don’t hesitate to share them—I’m always open to suggestions!

Protective Fight

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

Here is a place of disaffection

Time before and time after

In a dim light: neither daylight

Investing form with lucid stillness

Turning shadow into transient beauty

With slow rotation suggesting permanence

Nor darkness to purify the soul

Emptying the sensual with deprivation

Cleansing affection from the temporal.

 

              (T.S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

It was a crisp, sunny afternoon, and the park thirty minutes away from campus buzzed with the laughter of children and the hum of life. Rio, Agatha, and Nicky stood in the middle of it all, a little island of happiness. Nicky chased after a kite he’d begged them to help him fly, his shrieks of joy filling the air as it danced in the wind.

 

Maya had been passing by the park on her way to a nearby coffee shop when the scene caught her eye. She stopped short, her heart twisting at the sight. There was Rio, the Rio she once knew—vibrant, alive, and glowing. But it wasn’t for her anymore.

 

Rio stood beside Agatha, leaning into her with a grin as they watched him. Agatha reached for Rio’s hand, their fingers intertwining effortlessly. She turned to press a soft kiss against Rio’s cheek, murmuring something that made Rio laugh, her face lighting up with the kind of unguarded joy Maya hadn’t seen in years.

 

Her gaze darkened as she watched Agatha’s hand linger on Rio’s waist, their bodies naturally leaning into each other. Nicky darted toward them, excitedly holding the kite’s spool, and Rio crouched down to meet him, ruffling his hair as he beamed at her. Agatha smiled at them, her expression so full of love it made Maya’s chest ache.

 

From a distance, Maya’s jaw tightened. How dare Rio move on so completely, so happily, while she was left with nothing but bitterness and regret?

 

Her resentment simmered as she looked away from the idyllic scene. But an idea began to take shape in her mind, fueled by jealousy and an overwhelming need to regain some semblance of control.

 

“If Rio wants to flaunt her perfect little life,” Maya thought bitterly, “then I’ll make sure everyone sees the cracks in her perfect facade.”

 

She didn’t know what she would do just yet, but she was certain of one thing: Rio Vidal’s downfall would be hers to orchestrate.

 

As she looked on a little longer, Maya’s eyes narrowed as the realization dawned. She recognized Agatha—not just as the elegant woman who now had Rio’s heart, but as Dr. Agatha Harkness, a prominent professor at the university.

 

Her mouth fell open slightly in disbelief. She wasn’t just watching Rio with some new lover; she was watching Rio with her professor. The woman who stood at the front of lecture halls, commanding respect and admiration. The woman whose name was spoken with reverence in academic circles.

 

This wasn’t just a relationship—it was scandalous.

 

Maya’s shock deepened as she took in the scene: Agatha casually brushing a lock of Rio’s hair out of her face, Nicky tugging on Rio’s hand to get her attention, the three of them radiating warmth and love like a little family.

 

Her stomach churned.

 

“Unbelievable,” she muttered under her breath.

 

Maya’s mind raced. If this relationship was public knowledge, it would raise questions—serious ones. Rio was a PhD student, after all. Agatha was her supervisor. That kind of relationship was a minefield of ethical complications.

 

And yet, here they were, openly affectionate, completely at ease, as though they hadn’t a care in the world.

 

“They think they’re so untouchable,” Maya thought bitterly, her resentment bubbling to the surface. She felt humiliated all over again—discarded by Rio, who had moved on not just to anyone, but to someone so powerful, someone completely out of Maya’s league.

 

Her hands curled into fists at her sides as she turned away from the idyllic scene. “If Rio wants to play this game, I’ll make sure it doesn’t end well for her—or for her precious professor.”

 

The bitterness swelled as Maya began to walk away, her mind already plotting. This wasn’t just jealousy—it was an opportunity. And Maya was determined to use it.

 

 

Maya knocked sharply on Agatha’s office door the next morning, each rap echoing with her simmering anger and sense of righteous vindication. Her heart pounded in her chest as she prepared for the confrontation, rehearsing her words in her head like a mantra. The brisk, authoritative “Come in” that came from the other side of the door didn’t deter her—it only fueled her determination.

 

Squaring her shoulders, Maya pushed the door open and stepped inside. Agatha was seated at her desk, her long fingers gracefully holding a pen poised over a stack of papers. Her sharp blue eyes lifted from her work, locking onto Maya with a practiced calm that only seemed to intensify Maya’s frustration.

 

“Ms. Reyes,” Agatha greeted evenly, her voice smooth as silk as she set her pen down and folded her hands on the desk. “What can I do for you?” There was no warmth in her tone, but also no hostility—just a measured neutrality that somehow managed to unnerve Maya.

 

The door clicked shut behind her as Maya closed it with a bit more force than necessary. She folded her arms tightly across her chest, her stance confrontational. “We need to talk about Rio,” she began, her voice sharp with accusation.

 

Agatha’s brow arched slightly, her expression unflinching as she leaned back in her chair with the composure of someone who had weathered countless storms. “Alright,” she replied, her tone calm but laced with a quiet steel that warned Maya she was treading on dangerous ground. “Go on.”

 

Maya took a step closer to the desk, her confidence building as her indignation bubbled to the surface. “It’s clear to anyone paying attention that she’s been getting special treatment,” she said, her words pointed, as though each one was meant to pierce Agatha’s calm exterior. “And we both know why. You’re her supervisor—and more. That’s unethical, Dr. Harkness. You’re taking advantage of her position as your student.”

 

Agatha blinked slowly, her expression as calm and unreadable as a still lake, though the faintest flicker of surprise danced in her eyes. She didn’t flinch, didn’t fidget. Instead, she folded her hands neatly on the desk, her posture poised and unshaken. The power in her composure was palpable, and it only made Maya’s anger burn hotter.

 

“Are you implying,” Agatha began, her tone glacially cool, “that Miss Vidal’s success is due to anything other than her brilliance and relentless hard work?” Her voice carried a deliberate calm, but there was an unmistakable edge beneath the surface—a warning, sharp and quiet.

 

Maya’s jaw tightened, her arms crossing defensively over her chest. “I’m saying it’s impossible to know if it’s all fair when you’re clearly involved with her,” she shot back, her voice sharp enough to cut glass.

 

Agatha’s lips twitched ever so slightly, not quite forming a smile. It was the kind of expression that spoke of someone utterly unimpressed by the accusations being hurled at her. She leaned forward slightly, her steely gaze locked on Maya, who suddenly felt very small despite her attempt to project confidence.

 

“Let me be perfectly clear, Ms. Reyes,” Agatha said, her voice dropping to a low, deliberate register that sent a chill down Maya’s spine. “Miss Vidal’s work stands entirely on its own merit. She is one of the most promising students I’ve had the pleasure to supervise, and if you believe otherwise, I would suggest taking that up with your own supervisor. If you’re not performing at the level you’d like, it might be worth examining your own efforts rather than deflecting onto someone else. Redirecting your frustrations onto others will not elevate your own performance.”

 

The words were delivered with surgical precision, each one cutting deeper than the last. Maya’s face flushed crimson, a mix of embarrassment and rage bubbling just beneath the surface.

 

“You’re crossing a line,” Maya snapped, her voice rising slightly. “You’re her professor! Her supervisor! How do I know you’re not—”

 

“Not what?” Agatha interrupted, her tone sharp enough to slice through Maya’s indignation. She rose slowly from her chair, her commanding presence towering over the younger woman even as her movements remained measured and calm. Her dark blue eyes pinned Maya in place, unflinching and unyielding. “Do choose your next words carefully, Ms. Reyes. I’d hate for you to dig yourself into a hole you can’t climb out of.”

 

Maya faltered, her mouth opening and closing as if searching for the right response. The confidence she’d brought into the room was quickly slipping through her fingers, evaporating under Agatha’s unrelenting gaze.

 

“I’m saying,” Maya finally managed, though her voice wavered slightly, “that it’s inappropriate for you to—”

 

Agatha raised a hand, commanding silence with the kind of presence that seemed to freeze the air itself. Her voice, low and sharp, sliced through Maya’s words like a blade. “Stop right there.” The authority in her tone left no room for interruption. “I understand your frustration, but I will not tolerate unfounded accusations. Let me make something abundantly clear—I am acutely aware of my professional responsibilities, and I have upheld them without fault.”

 

She leaned forward slightly, her piercing blue eyes locking onto Maya with an intensity that could shatter stone. “If you feel the need to question my integrity, by all means, take your concerns to the ethics committee. But I strongly advise you to come prepared with more than vague accusations and baseless assumptions, because I assure you, there will be consequences for slander.”

 

Maya’s mouth opened, as if to speak, but Agatha pressed on, her voice now carrying a steely edge. “For your information, Miss Vidal and I disclosed our relationship to the dean from the very beginning. The administration is fully aware, and they are entirely satisfied with our conduct. My professional conduct has been, and will continue to be, beyond reproach. I treat Rio no differently than any other student in the program, except for holding her to the highest academic standards—as I would anyone under my guidance.”

 

Maya faltered, the heat of her indignation cooling for a brief moment as doubt crept into her expression. “So you’re telling me there’s absolutely nothing inappropriate about this?” she asked, her tone laced with skepticism but notably quieter.

 

Agatha tilted her head ever so slightly, her gaze unwavering. “That is precisely what I’m telling you,” she said, her voice even and deliberate, like the strike of a gavel. “And if you still harbor concerns, I encourage you to take them to the dean. However, let me offer you a piece of advice—baseless allegations designed to tarnish reputations often have a way of reflecting poorly on the accuser, not the accused.”

 

Maya’s face flushed with anger and humiliation as Agatha’s sharp words cut through her indignation. She took a step forward, her posture stiff, and spat, “You think she’s so brilliant? So perfect? You don’t know her like I do.”

 

Agatha’s brow arched, her composure unshaken, though the faintest flicker of something dangerous danced in her icy blue eyes. “Enlighten me, then,” she said, her voice calm and clipped, daring Maya to continue.

 

Maya sneered, leaning forward to drive her point home. “Rio’s not as put together as you think. She’s impulsive, reckless. She’ll run herself into the ground chasing something she can’t ever reach. I’ve seen it happen. She’s needy, and when you stop giving her exactly what she wants, she’ll crumble – or worse, she’ll turn on you. Just wait.”

 

Agatha’s jaw tightened ever so slightly, but her expression remained a mask of calm. Her silence only seemed to infuriate Maya further.

 

“You sound bitter, Ms. Reyes,” Agatha finally replied, her words measured and deliberate. “I wonder why that might be.”

 

Maya faltered, but she pushed on, her voice rising. “Bitter? I’m being honest. She’s exhausting, isn’t she? Always needing validation, always pushing too hard. I don’t know what you see in her.”

 

Agatha stood slowly, the air in the room seeming to chill. Her full height towered over Maya, and her presence became a wall of silent authority.

 

“What I see,” Agatha began, her voice soft but as cold and cutting as winter frost, “is someone extraordinary. Someone brilliant, passionate, and resilient. Someone who has faced and overcome more than you could ever begin to comprehend. Whatever bitterness you’re clinging to, Ms. Reyes, I suggest you address it elsewhere. It will find no audience here.”

 

Maya’s mouth opened, a retort clearly forming on her lips, but Agatha pressed on, her voice now carrying the weight of unshakable finality.

 

“Your words,” she continued, “speak volumes—not about Rio, but about you. Your insecurities. Your failures. Your inability to see beyond your own grievances. It’s not Rio who needs validation, Ms. Reyes. It’s you. Perhaps you should take some time to reflect on why that is.”

 

The color drained from Maya’s face, her confidence visibly shaken. Yet, despite her wounded pride, she squared her shoulders, clinging stubbornly to the last shreds of her indignation.

 

“You can’t protect her forever,” Maya hissed, her voice trembling with frustration. “This isn’t over.”

 

Agatha’s gaze never wavered, her expression as cold and impenetrable as stone. “On the contrary, Ms. Reyes,” she said, her tone steady and final. “This conversation is over. You may leave now.”

 

Maya hesitated, her pride warring with the weight of Agatha’s words. Finally, with no retort strong enough to match Agatha’s quiet authority, she turned sharply on her heel and stormed out, the door slamming shut behind her.

 

Agatha remained standing for a moment, her gaze fixed on the closed door, her expression unreadable. Slowly, she exhaled, her body relaxing ever so slightly. Her thoughts drifted to Rio, to the fire and brilliance that Maya had failed to see. A faint smile tugged at the corners of her lips.

 

If Maya thought her words would plant even the smallest seed of doubt, she had clearly underestimated just how deeply Agatha believed in the woman she loved.

 

She allowed herself a small sigh. But it wasn’t frustration—it was determination. She had no doubt Maya would try to stir trouble, but she trusted that she and Rio would handle it, together.

 

Agatha exhaled slowly, her fingers brushing against the edge of her desk as she composed herself. A small, wry smile tugged at the corner of her lips.

 

“Needy and impulsive, of course,” she scoffed, thinking of Rio with nothing but fondness. “As if I’d want her any other way.”

 

The words carried warmth, a private acknowledgment of the quirks and complexities that made Rio who she was. Agatha sat back down, her posture poised yet relaxed, her fingertips tapping a thoughtful rhythm against the armrest of her chair. Her gaze lingered on the closed door for a moment, the remnants of the confrontation replaying in her mind.

 

She had no intention of telling Rio about this. It wasn’t a matter of secrecy but of protection. Agatha knew Rio too well—knew how the words of someone like Maya would land. Rio would bristle with anger, frustration simmering just beneath the surface, but it wouldn’t end there. She’d internalize the venom, letting it gnaw at her confidence even as she outwardly dismissed it.

 

“She doesn’t need this,” Agatha said softly, her voice barely above a whisper. The protectiveness in her tone was unmistakable, a fierce determination hardening her expression. She would not let Maya’s bitterness seep into the vibrant light that was Rio.

 

She gathered her thoughts, already formulating the plan for their next meeting. Instead of burdening Rio with this unnecessary stress, she would channel her energy into supporting her.

 

After all, the best way to silence people like Maya was to ensure that Rio continued to thrive. Her brilliance was undeniable, her determination unmatched—and Agatha was determined to protect her from anything that might dim her light.

 

Later that day, when Rio knocked on her office door, Agatha’s face immediately softened, the sharp professionalism she wore for the world melting into the warmth she reserved for Rio alone.

 

“There’s my favorite PhD student,” Agatha greeted, her tone light but her eyes glowing with unmistakable fondness.

 

Rio stepped inside, her usual energy radiating like sunlight through the room. She arched a brow, a playful grin tugging at her lips. “Favorite? Aren’t you not supposed to have favorites? Sounds like favoritism to me,” she teased, though the faint blush dusting her cheeks betrayed how much the words meant to her.

 

Agatha smirked, rising gracefully from her chair and leaning casually against the edge of her desk. “Ah, that’s something the professor never tells,” she countered with a teasing lilt. “And besides, rules are for those too timid to bend them.”

 

Rio laughed, her voice rich and infectious, and Agatha couldn’t help but let her own smile linger a little longer. The sound seemed to wash away the lingering tension from the morning’s confrontation, replacing it with something lighter, brighter—a reminder of why she fought so fiercely to protect what they had.

 

As Rio settled into the chair across from her, pulling out notes and speaking animatedly about her latest research progress, Agatha found herself watching her with quiet admiration. Rio’s hands moved as she spoke, her passion and enthusiasm evident in every word. It was this fire, this unrelenting drive, that had captivated Agatha from the beginning—not just Rio’s brilliance, but the way she poured her entire being into everything she cared about.

 

Agatha listened intently, offering her thoughts and suggestions where needed, but part of her mind was elsewhere, replaying the bitter accusations Maya had hurled earlier. None of it mattered, not really—not when the truth sat right here in front of her. Rio’s success wasn’t some product of favoritism; it was earned, every single ounce of it, through hard work, talent, and sheer determination.

 

Still, Agatha felt the weight of her own silent promise pressing on her heart. She would shield Rio from the ugliness that others tried to bring into her orbit. Maya’s bitterness, her baseless accusations, were nothing in the face of what Rio deserved.

 

As Rio wrapped up her explanation, looking to Agatha with that familiar mix of excitement and vulnerability, Agatha reached forward, placing a hand lightly over Rio’s. “You’re doing incredible work,” she said, her voice low but steady. “Don’t ever let anyone convince you otherwise.”

 

Rio blinked, momentarily startled by the gravity in Agatha’s tone, but then her expression softened, and she smiled—a quiet, genuine smile that made Agatha’s chest ache with pride. “Thank you,” Rio said softly, her fingers brushing against Agatha’s in a moment that felt too big for words.

 

Agatha straightened, reclaiming her professional air with ease, though the tenderness in her eyes remained. “Now,” she said, her tone lighter, “let’s fine-tune your argument here. It’s good, but you can push it further. And you’re more than capable of it.”

 

Rio grinned, pulling out her pen. “Always pushing me,” she teased. “One of these days, you’ll make me perfect.”

 

Agatha’s smirk returned. “Not perfect, love. Just extraordinary. But you’re already most of the way there.”

 

And as they dove back into their work, the warmth in the room seemed to wrap around them both, a quiet refuge from the world outside. Agatha silently reaffirmed her vow: nothing would dim Rio’s light. Not while she had anything to say about it.

 

 

 

The hallway was eerily quiet as Rio walked toward the library, her thoughts consumed with ideas for her latest thesis revision. Her mind hummed with possibilities, so she didn’t notice Maya standing just around the corner until the words sliced through the air.

 

“Rio.”

 

The voice was sweet, almost too sweet—laced with a bite Rio couldn’t quite ignore. She froze, her spine stiffening at the sound of Maya’s deliberate tone.

 

“What do you want?” Rio’s voice was already thick with irritation, the weariness evident in her words.

 

Maya stepped forward, her smile tight and calculated. She tilted her head in mock curiosity, the innocence in her expression so exaggerated it could have been comical. “Oh, just thought we should talk. I had the most fascinating conversation with your girlfriend, Dr. Harkness.” She let the words hang in the air. “Wow, Rio. You’re really dating up, aren’t you?”

 

Rio’s jaw clenched, the muscles in her neck tightening. She took a slow, steadying breath. “Did you, now?” she replied, her voice tinged with the sharp edge of restraint.

 

Maya’s smile grew, a mix of smugness and satisfaction. “Mm-hmm,” she hummed, the sound so self-satisfied it made Rio’s skin crawl. “She’s really… protective of you. You’d almost think she was your knight in shining armor, wouldn’t you? Always swooping in to save the day.”

 

Rio’s patience thinned by the second, but Maya wasn’t finished. She leaned in closer, her voice lowering, each word dripping with venom. “Or maybe it’s just a savior complex. You always did attract people who wanted to fix you.”

 

A flash of anger ignited in Rio, but she forced herself to stay calm, folding her arms across her chest. “If you’re done wasting my time—”

 

But Maya wasn’t finished. Of course she wasn’t. With an almost gleeful grin, Maya leaned in even closer, her breath cold against Rio’s ear. “You know, it’s funny. Moving from me to your professor?” She let the words roll off her tongue like a deliberate poison. “What’s that, some kind of Freudian thing? Mommy issues, maybe?” She paused, as if savoring the very suggestion, before adding, “What would Lilia think? You should probably look into therapy, Rio. God knows you need it.”

 

The words stung, landing like a slap. Rio’s heart pounded in her chest, but she kept her posture rigid, determined not to let Maya see how deeply those insults cut. Maya’s taunts were meant to provoke, to make her question herself, but Rio knew better than to let them stick.

 

Maya’s smirk grew. “And Dr. Harkness, really? Honestly, she looks like an old, crazy, frigid bitch. You’re kidding yourself if you think this little… fling is going to last. She’ll toss you aside as soon as she’s bored. Maybe that’s what you’re used to, though.”

 

The venom in Maya’s words struck harder than Rio wanted to admit. Her face flushed with a rush of hurt and fury, the familiar sting of past insecurities gnawing at her. But she wouldn’t give Maya the satisfaction of seeing her flinch, of letting her see the cracks that Maya always seemed to find.

 

Taking a slow, steadying breath, Rio straightened her spine, her eyes narrowing. She met Maya’s gaze head-on, her voice cold and unwavering. “You don’t know a damn thing about me or Agatha. Whatever bitterness you’re holding onto from your own pathetic life, keep it to yourself. I’m done with you.”

 

She turned to leave, but Maya still wasn’t done.

 

“Oh, Rio, you’re so predictable,” Maya sneered, taking a step forward. “Always running away. Just like you did with us.”

 

The words hung in the air like a challenge, and Rio whipped around so fast it almost startled herself. Her voice dropped to a deadly whisper, but it was sharp and filled with every ounce of emotion she’d been holding back. “If I ran, it’s because you were toxic and horrible to me. And now you’re just proving it all over again. Stay the hell out of my life, Maya. You’re nothing but a footnote to me.”

 

Without another word, Rio turned on her heel, her footsteps quick and purposeful as she walked away, her heart pounding in her chest. Maya’s insults still lingered, but Rio refused to let them fester.

 

As her anger simmered, another thought began to creep in, its weight sinking deeper into her chest. Why hadn’t Agatha told her about the confrontation with Maya? It wasn’t like her to keep things from her—not with something so… personal. The idea of Agatha withholding something nagged at her, stoking a new fire of uncertainty.

 

By the time Rio reached her apartment, the emotional storm had intensified. Hurt, betrayal, and lingering anger all tangled together, threatening to overwhelm her. She slammed her bag down on the table, the sound of it echoing through the room. Her phone was still clutched in her hand, and her fingers hovered over Agatha’s contact, unsure whether to call or wait.

 

“No,” Rio muttered under her breath, the tightness in her chest making it hard to breathe. She needed to calm down, needed to give herself space before she spoke to Agatha. If she didn’t, she feared she might say something she would regret. Something too sharp, too raw to take back.

 

But one thing was clear, as she stood there, the weight of the day pressing down on her: this wasn’t over. Not with Maya, and not with Agatha.

 

 

The tension in Agatha’s living room was thick enough to cut with a knife. The soft hum of the clock on the wall seemed louder than usual, as if it too could feel the weight of the silence between them. Nicky had gone to bed hours ago, leaving Rio and Agatha alone, but instead of the quiet, loving evening Rio had imagined, her frustration had built to a boiling point.

 

She stood by the window for a moment, her gaze unfocused, fighting the urge to shout, to throw words that were too sharp for the moment. But it didn’t help. The anger simmered, refusing to subside.

 

“You should have told me,” Rio’s voice cracked through the stillness, sharp and unyielding. She began to pace the room, her arms crossed tightly against her chest, as if trying to hold herself together.

 

Agatha, sitting calmly on the couch, exhaled heavily, her posture still relaxed despite the tension. “I didn’t want to upset you unnecessarily,” she said softly, her voice carrying a tired note that didn’t quite mask the weight of her own frustration. “It wasn’t worth stressing you out, Rio.”

 

Rio’s eyes flashed as she stopped pacing abruptly, spinning on her heel to face her. “Not worth it? Agatha, someone—Maya, no less—walked into your office and accused you of being unethical, of taking advantage of me. Then she had the audacity to throw disgusting insults at you and me, and you didn’t think I deserved to know about any of that?” Her breath came fast, anger and hurt lacing each word as it spilled from her lips.

 

Agatha frowned, her fingers steepling in front of her. “It wasn’t your problem to deal with. I handled it.”

 

Rio scoffed, the hurt evident in her voice. “You handled it? Agatha, we’re in this together. When someone says something like that about you—or about us—it’s both of our business.”

 

Agatha rose from her spot on the couch, the sharp edge of her composure still intact despite the weight of the conversation. Her tone was measured, but there was a firmness to it that Rio had come to recognize all too well. “And what would you have done, Rio? March into my office and confronted her yourself? I didn’t want you dragged into her petty games.”

 

“That’s not the point!” Rio snapped, her voice growing higher, her hands gesturing wildly. “The point is, you kept me out. You made the decision for me, like I can’t handle it, like I’m some fragile little thing that needs protecting.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened, but her voice remained steady. “You’re not fragile, Rio. Far from it. But you’re also juggling so much—your thesis, your band, your dance classes, us. I didn’t want to add unnecessary weight to your shoulders.”

 

Rio’s face twisted in disbelief, the words she needed to say tumbling out in a rush. “Do you even hear yourself? You’re coddling me, Agatha.” Her voice cracked as she stepped forward, her eyes filling with unshed tears, a mixture of hurt and frustration. “And it makes me feel… small, like you don’t trust me to handle things. That’s not what I need from you.”

 

Agatha’s shoulders sagged, the weight of Rio’s words settling on her like a heavy burden. Each syllable felt like a stone dropped into her chest, and the guilt lingered, making her feel smaller than she ever wanted to be. She had been trying to protect Rio, to shield her from the chaos of it all, but in the process, she’d failed to see that Rio didn’t need protection—she needed honesty.

 

Stepping closer, Agatha reached out slowly, her hand brushing gently against Rio’s arm as though she were testing the waters. “I’m sorry,” she said softly, her voice raw with emotion. “That wasn’t my intention. I wasn’t trying to make you feel small. I just…” She faltered, the words caught in her throat. “I love you, Rio. And sometimes that love makes me overprotective. I see someone trying to hurt you, and my instinct is to shield you from it. I want to keep you safe from everything, even the things I can’t control.”

 

Rio’s expression softened at Agatha’s confession, but the frustration still lingered. “I get that,” she said, the edge of her anger beginning to dull. “I really do. I know you love me, Agatha. And I know you want to protect me. But I’m not a child. I’m not someone who needs to be sheltered from the hard stuff. I’m your partner, and I need to be in this with you. Not just standing on the sidelines while you fight all the battles for me.”

 

Agatha swallowed, her throat tight. She could feel the truth of Rio’s words digging into her like a splinter. She had always wanted to protect her—had always believed that keeping Rio out of harm’s way was the right thing to do. But Rio was right. She wasn’t fragile, and she wasn’t someone to be hidden away from the world’s cruelties. Rio needed to be seen, needed to stand beside her, not as someone to be shielded but as someone to face the world with.

 

Agatha nodded, her thumb brushing tenderly over Rio’s arm, a silent apology. “You’re right. You’re absolutely right,” she murmured, the weight of the admission settling in. “I should have told you. I should have trusted you with this, and I shouldn’t have made decisions for you. I promise I’ll do better, okay? No more keeping things like this from you. I want you to be a part of it all—good, bad, and everything in between.”

 

Rio took a deep breath, her chest rising and falling as she exhaled slowly, the tension slowly leaving her body. She looked into Agatha’s eyes, searching for sincerity, and found it there—a raw, open truth. The anger she’d felt earlier was fading, replaced by something softer, something more understanding. “Okay,” she said quietly, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

Agatha leaned in, pressing a gentle, lingering kiss to Rio’s forehead, as if trying to impart her apology through the soft touch. “I’m sorry,” she repeated softly.

 

Rio wrapped her arms around Agatha, pulling her into a tight hug. “Just… don’t keep me out again, okay? I want to be here for you, just like you’re here for me.”

 

Agatha nodded against her shoulder, the soft strands of dark hair tickling her cheek. “I won’t. We’re in this together.”

 

Agatha pulled back from the hug slightly, her hands resting lightly on Rio’s arms as she studied her face. She searched for any trace of the anger that had been there earlier, but all she found was a quiet sadness, a weariness in Rio’s eyes that hadn’t been there before. “Are we okay?” Agatha asked, her voice gentle but tinged with a quiet worry, as though afraid the answer might still break the fragile peace they had just begun to rebuild.

 

Rio’s gaze softened as she met Agatha’s eyes, offering a small but reassuring smile that didn’t quite reach the depths of her heart but was enough to settle some of Agatha’s anxieties. “We’re fine,” she said, her voice steady but soft. “I’m not mad anymore. I just… need some time to process, you know?” 

 

Agatha let out a breath she hadn’t realized she’d been holding. “Of course. Take all the time you need.” She hesitated, as if she wanted to say more, but instead leaned in to kiss Rio’s forehead again, the gesture tender and apologetic. “I’ll be in the bathroom if you need me,” she added softly, her voice low, offering a quiet space for Rio to retreat into if she needed it.

 

Rio nodded, pulling away gently. “I think I’m going to work on my thesis for a bit, clear my head. I’ll just be in the living room.”

 

Agatha smiled softly, though there was a trace of concern and uncertainty in her eyes. “Alright. Are you still staying the night?”

 

“Yes, don’t worry, I’m not going to run away.” Rio replied, rolling her eyes slightly.

 

Agatha nodded, her eyes lingering on Rio, searching for any sign that she wasn’t okay, but finding only the calmness of a storm passed. She wanted to reach out, to hold Rio again, to reassure her that everything would be fine, but she knew Rio needed space. Still, her concern made it hard to let go. “Don’t stay up too late, okay?” she said, her voice soft but laced with an undeniable tenderness.

 

“I won’t,” Rio promised as she turned to head into the living room.

 

Once there, she set up her laptop on the coffee table, surrounded by her notes and books. The soft glow of the lamp cast a warm light over the room, but her mind was still swirling. She stared at the blank page of her document for a moment, tapping her pen against her notebook rhythmically.

 

She wasn’t angry anymore—at least not in the way she had been earlier. That sharp, fiery anger had burned out, leaving only the embers of something deeper: hurt. It wasn’t that she doubted Agatha’s love; no, that was as solid and unshakeable as bedrock. What bothered her was the way this entire situation had unfolded, the way it had dredged up old wounds—wounds she had long tried to forget. People, in her past, had always made decisions for her, had always assumed what was best without consulting her. That was what had hurt the most, even now. Not the confrontation with Maya. Not even the way Agatha had handled it, despite her good intentions. It was the echo of something much older, the feeling of being unseen, unheard.

 

She pushed the thoughts aside, trying to refocus on her thesis, diving into the comforting structure of her work.

 

In the quiet, she could hear the water pouring as Agatha was apparently running a bath, and the thought brought a faint smile to her lips. They’d talk more tomorrow, she knew, when emotions weren’t running so high. For now, the rhythmic click of her keyboard and the familiar flow of her thoughts provided solace.

 

Every so often, her gaze flickered toward the hallway leading to the bedroom, and she felt a pang of guilt. Agatha had only been trying to protect her, misguided as it was. She resolved to finish up her work soon—just a little more. Then she would go to Agatha. Because while Rio needed this moment, this time to clear her head, she didn’t want Agatha to feel like she was being shut out. The thought of Agatha alone, waiting for her to come back, made her heart ache. She would finish her work, yes, but she would make sure to be there. The distance between them was temporary—this wasn’t a fight that needed to linger.

 

 

Agatha sank into the warm water of the tub with a deep sigh, letting the lavender-scented steam rise around her. She rested her head against the edge, the tension in her shoulders gradually easing as the heat worked its magic. But her mind was far from quiet.

 

The image of Rio’s frustrated expression lingered, a dull ache in Agatha’s chest. She knew she’d messed up, even if her intentions had been good. “I’m too old for these kinds of mistakes,” she muttered to herself, running a hand through the damp ends of her hair.

 

She was supposed to know better by now. She’d lived through enough, seen enough, to understand that love wasn’t about sheltering the person you cared about from everything that could hurt them—it was about standing beside them, sharing the weight of the world together, even when it wasn’t easy. The thought of Rio feeling betrayed, even in the smallest way, was a heavy burden. Agatha had always promised herself that she would never do that to her, but tonight, it felt like she had broken that vow.

 

The sound of soft footsteps approaching the bathroom broke her train of thought. She glanced toward the door, half-expecting to hear Rio heading to bed, but instead, the door creaked open. Rio stood there, her arms crossed, a hesitant smile tugging at the corners of her lips.

 

“Room for one more?” Rio’s voice was soft, warm, and tentative, as though she wasn’t sure of her own invitation.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a small smile, her heart giving a hopeful flutter. “Always. I really hoped you would join me”

 

Rio’s gaze softened at the sight of Agatha, the vulnerability in her expression melting away some of the walls Rio had unconsciously built between them. She stepped further into the room, the quiet rustling of her clothes the only sound as she began to undress. Each layer of clothing fell to the floor in a soft, fluid motion, revealing the lithe, toned silhouette of her body against the gentle glow of the bathroom light.

 

Rio didn’t say anything, just stepped forward, one foot, then the other, into the tub. The water shifted and rising as she sank down, her knees brushing against Agatha’s thighs. She didn’t stop until she was lying fully against her girlfriend, settled between her legs, her cheek pressed to Agatha’s collarbone, her arms loosely draped around her waist.

 

The water lapped gently at their skin as Agatha wrapped her arms around Rio, pulling her close. For a moment, neither of them spoke. The quiet, the warmth of the water, and the shared intimacy of the moment filled the space between them, making everything else feel far away.
