Agatha signed again, the movement of her chest rippling against Rio’s head, silently thanking her past self for choosing a sizable bathtub. “You know, darling, this bath was supposed to be for one,” she teased, her voice low and affectionate.

 

Rio tilted her head slightly, her lips grazing the skin of Agatha’s chest as she replied, “And now it’s better because it’s for two.” Her voice was muffled but carried a touch of playfulness that melted Agatha’s heart.

 

The water rippled softly around them as they adjusted, Agatha leaning back further to cradle Rio against her. Rio fit perfectly against her, as if she belonged there, her body warm and light in the water. Agatha’s fingers moved to trace lazy patterns along Rio’s back, the gesture as much for her own comfort as for Rio’s.

 

“I wasn’t really mad,” Rio admitted after a moment, her fingers trailing absentmindedly along Agatha’s knee. “Not at you. I just… I don’t like feeling like I need protecting.”

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to the top of Rio’s head. “I know. And I should’ve told you. I just… I wanted to spare you the stress.”

 

Rio tilted her head back slightly to look at her. “We’re a team, remember? If you’re dealing with something, I want to know. I’m stronger than you think, Agatha.”

 

Agatha smiled, her thumb brushing gently against Rio’s shoulder. “I don’t doubt that for a second. You amaze me every day, Rio.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed a little, but she smiled and adjusted herself so her front was flush against Agatha’s and her hands reached up to cup Agatha’s cheeks. “Good. Because you’re stuck with me now.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, leaning down to kiss her, the water sloshing gently around them. The kiss was slow and deep, an unspoken apology and a reaffirmation of their love all in one.

 

When they finally pulled apart, Rio rested her head back against Agatha’s chest, closing her eyes. “This is nice,” she murmured.

 

“It is,” Agatha agreed, her voice low and content. “And I promise, no more secrets. We’ll face things together.”

 

Rio smiled, her fingers playing with Agatha’s hand under the water. “Together.”

 

They lay like that in silence for a while, the warmth of the water cocooning them, the soft rise and fall of their breathing syncing naturally. Agatha could feel the tension in Rio’s frame start to ebb away, the younger woman’s body growing heavier in her arms, a sign that she was finally letting go of the stress that had been weighing on her that day.

 

“You’re warm,” Rio murmured after a while, her voice soft and a little sleepy.

 

“That’s the point of a bath,” Agatha replied with a gentle laugh, her chin resting on Rio’s now damp hair.

 

Rio hummed in response, a contented sound that made Agatha smile. She shifted slightly, just enough to press a kiss to Rio’s temple, her lips lingering for a moment.

 

“Stay as long as you like,” Agatha whispered, her voice barely above a murmur.

 

Rio tilted her head up, her dark eyes meeting Agatha’s, a small smile curving her lips. “I wasn’t planning on going anywhere.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her heart full as she tightened her hold on Rio. The water, the warmth, the intimacy of the moment—it was perfect. And as they lay there, the world outside faded away, leaving only them and the quiet, unwavering love that filled the space between them.

 

The rest of the evening was spent in quiet intimacy, the bathwater cooling but their hearts warm and steady, once again on the same page.

 

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

omg, their first fight!

Of Galas and Flower Crowns

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

Time and the bell have buried the day,

The black cloud carries the sun away.

Will the sunflower turn to us, will the clematis

Stray down, bend to us; tendril and spray

Clutch and cling?

 

              (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

As they sat in Agatha’s office after a meeting, Rio leaned back in her chair, her mind still lingering on the discussion about her thesis. The weight of the conversation had left her feeling energized, yet a little drained, and she glanced over at Agatha, who was organizing a few papers on her desk.

 

Agatha caught her gaze and smiled, a warmth in her expression that made Rio’s heart flutter.

 

“You know,” Agatha began, her tone casual but with a gleam of something in her eyes, “there’s an event coming up that I’ve been invited to. My alma mater is holding a fundraising gala soon, and I thought—” she paused for a beat, her smile turning a little more playful, “—you might want to go with me?”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, intrigued by the suggestion. “A gala? What kind of gala?”

 

“It’s a formal event,” Agatha replied, her voice carrying a note of something special, as if she were offering an opportunity that didn’t come often. “All the alumni come back to raise money for the school and several charities. It’s outdoors, and it has this magical atmosphere, if you can overlook all the pompous big shots who think they’re the main attraction. It’s a big deal, and it would be the perfect chance for us to go out together, without all the complications.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat as she realized what Agatha was suggesting. Their first official date. The thought sent a wave of warmth through her. She hadn’t expected anything like this, especially after keeping their relationship so low-key for so long.

 

“Really?” Rio asked, her voice barely above a whisper as her smile widened. “You want to go with me?”

 

Agatha chuckled, a light, teasing sound. “I mean, I don’t know who else I’d ask,” she said, though there was an undeniable softness to her words. She leaned back in her chair, her eyes locking with Rio’s. “It’ll be far enough from our university that it won’t raise any eyebrows, and we’ll have the chance to be… well, us.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at the thought. It felt like the perfect step, a chance for them to finally share their love with the world—at least a little bit more openly. And to do so at something so elegant and beautiful, it made the idea even more special.

 

“I’d love to,” Rio replied, her voice soft and full of sincerity. “I mean, if it’s not too weird for you, I’m happy to go with you. I can’t believe you want me there.”

 

Agatha leaned forward slightly, her gaze softening as she looked at Rio. “You’re not just a plus-one, Rio,” she said, her voice low and warm. “You’re everything to me. And if this is going to be our first official date, I want it to be perfect. I want everyone to see what we mean to each other.”

 

Rio felt her chest tighten with emotion, her throat going a little dry at Agatha’s words. She’d known, of course, how much Agatha meant to her, but hearing it spoken so openly, so clearly, made everything feel even more real.

 

“I’m really excited,” Rio said, her smile bright and full of affection. “This is going to be amazing.”

 

Agatha’s smile deepened, and she stood up, moving around the desk to stand in front of Rio. She held out her hand, and Rio, without a second thought, took it, her fingers fitting perfectly against Agatha’s.

 

“I’ll make sure it’s perfect,” Agatha promised, her voice soft and serious as she held Rio’s gaze. “This is just the beginning of something beautiful, Rio. I’m so proud of you, of us. And I can’t wait to share all of this with you.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled in her chest, and for a moment, everything else faded away. It was just the two of them, standing together in Agatha’s office, planning their future, their love finally starting to be something they could embrace in the light.

 

“I’m proud of us too,” Rio whispered, squeezing Agatha’s hand gently. “We’re doing this. Together.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened, and she leaned in, pressing a brief but tender kiss to Rio’s forehead. “Always together,” she echoed.

 

And in that moment, Rio couldn’t help but feel like they were finally stepping into something bigger than just the two of them. Something they could share with the world.

 

 

The soft chime of the bell at the door echoed as Agatha and Rio stepped into the boutique, one evening after class. It was the day before the charity gala, and both of them needed outfits. Rio had been particularly excited about the event, not just because it was an occasion to dress up but because it was an opportunity for her to feel a little more at ease in the bustling social academic atmosphere. But more than that, she loved seeing Agatha in her element—her girlfriend, confident, elegant, and commanding, even when they were simply picking out clothes for an evening out.

 

As they entered the boutique, the air smelled faintly of fresh flowers and subtle perfumes. The store was filled with racks of high-end clothing, each piece exuding a sophistication that made Rio feel both a little out of her element and incredibly excited. Her eyes lit up as she caught sight of a display of beautiful silk dresses in shades of deep emerald, sapphire, and ruby.

 

“Agatha, look at this,” Rio said, pulling her Agatha’s arm and directing her toward the dresses.

 

Agatha’s gaze followed Rio’s excitement, a warm smile crossing her lips. She had learned long ago that Rio’s enthusiasm was contagious, and she had grown to appreciate the joy that her lover found in even the simplest things. “I think it’s you who’ll be the one making everyone look twice tomorrow night,” Agatha replied, her eyes already scanning the racks for her own choices. “But go ahead. You’ve earned it.”

 

Rio’s smile stretched across her face, and she picked out a dress with a flowing, almost ethereal feel—a soft lavender number with delicate lacework at the bodice and a flowing skirt that would sway elegantly when she moved. The color reminded her of Agatha. She couldn’t wait to try it on.

 

Meanwhile, Agatha was already moving between the aisles with her usual precision. Her eye quickly found a tailored deep forest green pantsuit that perfectly matched her imposing presence—structured but elegant, with a silky sheen to it that caught the light in the most flattering way. She ran her fingers along the fabric, admiring its smoothness, and then picked it up with a confident, almost possessive gesture.

 

“I’ll be trying this,” Agatha said, her tone leaving little room for debate. Rio chuckled, loving the way Agatha was always sure of her choices.

 

“That’s my favorite color,” Rio said, her eyes soft.

 

Agatha slid her free arm around Rio’s waist and leaned over to kiss her temple. “I know.”

 

As they made their way to the fitting rooms, Rio took one last look at Agatha, who was already scanning the racks for accessories. Even with a simple outfit like a pantsuit, Agatha had a way of making everything look effortlessly chic.

 

In the dressing room, Rio tried on her lavender dress first, stepping into the full-length mirror and turning slowly to admire how it hugged her waist before flaring out in soft waves. The lacework on the bodice felt delicate against her skin, and the soft hue of the dress seemed to make her feel lighter. When she stepped out of the fitting room to show Agatha, she couldn’t help but smile.

 

“Agatha, what do you think?”

 

Agatha’s eyes scanned Rio from head to toe, and she took a moment to appreciate how beautifully the dress fit her. Her smile softened. “You look stunning,” she said, her voice rich with affection. “But you always do.”

 

Rio blushed, looking down for a moment, embarrassed by the praise but also feeling a deep sense of warmth inside. She loved the way Agatha made her feel—like she was always seen, truly seen, even on days when she didn’t feel her best.

 

“Do you think it’s too much?” Rio asked, her fingers fidgeting nervously with the lace, as she looked at herself in the mirror. “I don’t want to look like I’m trying too hard.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, placing her hands on Rio’s shoulders from behind, grounding her with the simple touch. “No,” she said firmly, locking eyes with her. “You’re perfect. You don’t need to try. You shine no matter what you wear.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at the sincerity in Agatha’s voice. The dress, the event, the pressure of it being their first public outing together—it didn’t matter as much as the fact that Agatha made her feel like the most beautiful person in the room, every single day.

 

“Okay,” Rio said, taking a deep breath and smiling brightly. “I’ll get it.”

 

Agatha gave her a satisfied nod and then disappeared into her fitting room to try on her pantsuit. A few minutes later, she emerged, her posture as poised and strong as always, the suit fitting her perfectly, accentuating her tall frame and confident air. Rio looked up, eyes wide with admiration.

 

“You look amazing,” Rio whispered, her gaze lingering on Agatha’s tailored lines and the way the suit made her look both powerful and elegant.

 

Agatha smirked. “I know,” she said with a wink, enjoying the quiet moment of pride.

 

Together, they walked to the counter, their shopping complete. Agatha made a few last-minute adjustments to the outfit in her mind, knowing she would add the right accessories when they got home. Rio, meanwhile, was lost in her excitement about the night ahead—of being with Agatha in a space where they could simply be themselves, no matter how formal the event was.

 

As they paid for their clothes, Agatha wrapped an arm around Rio’s waist. “I think we’ll turn some heads tomorrow,” Agatha said with a playful grin.

 

“You’re definitely going to,” Rio teased back, nudging her shoulder against Agatha’s. “But don’t forget, I’m right there with you, taking the spotlight.”

 

The two shared a quiet laugh, their closeness and the playful banter between them filling the space with a sense of joy and anticipation for the night to come.

 

When they reached Agatha’s house, they spent the evening together, the atmosphere in the house light and filled with love. Rio’s nervousness about the event seemed to disappear under Agatha’s steady and confident presence. The evening ended with Agatha brushing her fingers over Rio’s hair as she was about to leave, a soft moment of connection that grounded both of them in a love that was unconditional, no matter the event or the world around them.

 

 

The night of the charity gala had arrived, and the two women were filled with a mix of excitement and anticipation. The air in Agatha’s home was thick with a sense of warmth, both from the soft golden lighting of their living room and from the intimate atmosphere that had always defined their space together. It was moments like these—quiet, simple, yet deeply significant—that Rio cherished.

 

They had just dropped Nicky off at Lilia’s house, and it was obvious how ecstatic both Lilia and Nicky were about spending the evening together. Agatha had no doubt that Lilia would spoil Nicky endlessly—letting him eat far too many candies and stay up way too late. But she also knew those moments made her son the happiest, so she didn’t mind in the slightest.

 

On her end, Rio couldn’t help but feel a sense of joy in giving Lilia these moments. Sometimes, she felt a twinge of guilt that Lilia hadn’t had experiences like this before with her at this age, but seeing the pure happiness on her face made everything worth it.

 

But for the moment, Rio stood in front of the full-length mirror, watching Agatha prepare everything they would need for the night ahead. Agatha was calm and composed as ever, effortlessly organizing their things with the grace that came so naturally to her. But Rio, as always, had a buzz of energy around her—a nervous kind of excitement as she thought about the evening and the number of eyes that would be on them. She had gotten used to being in the spotlight when it came to Agatha, but tonight felt different. She wanted everything to be perfect for her girlfriend, but mostly, she just wanted to be present and enjoy the night—free of secrecy, free of worries, just existing in the joy of their shared connection.

 

Agatha, noticing Rio’s quiet fidgeting, approached her with a soft smile. “Are you ready for tonight?” Agatha asked, her voice both playful and reassuring.

 

“I think so,” Rio replied, her gaze flickering between Agatha’s reflection and her own. “I’m just… nervous, I guess.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, cupping Rio’s face with her hands, her touch gentle and grounding. “There’s nothing to be nervous about. You’re going to look incredible, and everyone will be in awe of you… just like I always am.”

 

Rio smiled, her heart warmed by the simplicity of Agatha’s words. She wasn’t sure what she would do without the woman in front of her—Agatha always knew exactly how to ground her, to calm her storms.

 

“I want to do your hair and makeup tonight,” Agatha added, a soft twinkle in her eyes. “I want to make you my canvas.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at the thought. They had done this a couple times before—Agatha, with her practiced hands, making Rio feel like royalty with each gentle stroke of makeup, each precise movement of her hand in her hair. But tonight, there was something even more intimate about it. It wasn’t just the makeup and hair—it was the care Agatha always took, the way she made Rio feel like she was the center of the universe, with every touch and word.

 

“Of course,” Rio replied, stepping closer to her. “I’d love that.”

 

Agatha led Rio to her bedroom, where she had a large vanity with soft lighting. The scent of Agatha’s perfume lingered in the air, and the room was filled with an array of beauty products—some Rio’s that she had left there after a few nights spent here, some Agatha’s. Agatha sat Rio down in front of the mirror, her fingers gently brushing through Rio’s hair as she began to work.

 

“Your hair looks beautiful already,” Agatha remarked, running her fingers through the long, dark strands. “But let me add a little something.”

 

Rio closed her eyes, allowing herself to relax into Agatha’s hands as they moved effortlessly through her hair. There was something soothing about the way Agatha worked—her touch was always sure and calming, never rushed.

 

As Agatha carefully curled Rio’s hair, she let the silence linger for a while, both of them lost in the quiet intimacy of the moment. Rio could feel the warmth of Agatha’s presence behind her, could hear the soft murmur of Agatha humming a tune she didn’t recognize. It made her feel safe, at home.

 

In the end, she softly put the flower crown they had agreed on on top of Rio’s head, securing it lightly with a few pins so it wouldn’t slip.

 

After a few minutes, Agatha finished with Rio’s hair and turned her attention to the makeup. “You don’t need much,” Agatha said with a wink. “But let’s highlight your natural beauty.”

 

Agatha’s hands were steady and precise as she applied some blush, blending it seamlessly into Rio’s skin, and then adding just a hint of shimmer to her eyes. She worked with the same careful attention she always did—slow and deliberate, every motion filled with love.

 

As Agatha worked, she picked up a delicate silver necklace from her jewelry box, one that Rio had always adored. It was a simple piece, with a small moon pendant that caught the light beautifully. The necklace had always reminded Rio of Agatha’s unwavering support, a small, unspoken promise of love and presence. Agatha draped it over Rio’s neck, adjusting it gently before kissing her neck and stepping back to admire her work.

 

“There,” Agatha said softly, her eyes scanning Rio’s appearance. “Perfect. You’re perfect.”

 

Rio’s breath caught in her chest, her heart swelling with the depth of emotion she felt. She had always admired Agatha’s beauty—how she exuded confidence, grace, and strength—but tonight, as she looked at her own reflection, she felt like she was seeing herself for the first time. She saw the way Agatha saw her—a beautiful, confident woman who deserved to be loved and cherished. The necklace around her neck felt like a promise, a constant reminder that Agatha was always there, even when she wasn’t physically present. It was Agatha’s silent way of saying, “I’ve got you.”

 

Rio reached up to touch the necklace, her fingers gently tracing the smooth surface of the pendant. “I love this,” she whispered. “It’s so beautiful, just like you.”

 

Agatha smiled warmly, a soft laugh escaping her lips. “It’s nothing compared to how beautiful you are.”

 

Rio chuckled softly, looking at Agatha in the mirror. “You always know how to make me feel special.”

 

Agatha leaned in, placing a kiss on the back of Rio’s neck, her lips warm against her skin. “That’s because you are special. Never forget that.”

 

Rio turned around to face Agatha, before reaching for the dresser, taking the other flower crown and placing it on top of Agatha’s hair, to match her own and the whimsical but classy vibe of the gala.

 

The two women stood together in front of the mirror for a long moment, the weight of their connection grounding them as they admired each other’s reflections. The gala was just around the corner, but in that moment, all that mattered was the quiet love they shared, the comfort they found in each other’s presence.

 

With their preparations complete, the evening awaited. And for once, Rio felt ready—not because of the dress or the makeup, but because she had Agatha by her side. Together, they would face whatever the night brought, and nothing could take away the peace they had found in each other.

 

 

The evening was everything they had hoped for. The air was crisp with the cool night, and the venue was alive with glittering lights and laughter. The charity gala was a lavish affair—an event that brought together the most influential people in the community to raise funds for a cause close to their hearts. But for Agatha and Rio, the night was more than just a social obligation. It was a chance to step out of the everyday hustle of their lives and into a world where they could be together, celebrating the love they shared without the pressure of trying to stay professional for the sake of appearances.

 

When they arrived, the soft glow of the outdoor setting made everything look dreamlike—the flowers arranged in lush arrangements, the candles flickering in delicate glass holders. It felt like something out of a fairy tale. Agatha and Rio stood out, but not in an ostentatious way. There was a quiet elegance about them. Agatha’s green tailored pantsuit, so perfectly fitted to her form, radiated sophistication, and her flower crown nestled in her long brown hair only enhanced her ethereal beauty. Rio, with her flowy violet dress that billowed gently as she moved, wore her own flower crown just as gracefully, her dark hair cascading in soft waves.

 

And it was those small, discreet matching flower crowns they wore that caught the attention of the people around them as soon as they arrived. It wasn’t over the top or too much—it was subtle, an unspoken declaration of their bond, a delicate mix of white, golden, purple and green. A symbol of unity and a quiet nod to the connection they shared. It was their way of honoring each other amidst the glamour of the night.

 

Some of Agatha’s old friends like Wanda had been invited to the event, of course, but seeing the couple together in this setting was something else entirely for them. Wanda had heard so much about Rio in the last months, but tonight, she was in awe of the way they were so in sync with each other. Here, in the glow of the gala, it was as if the world had faded into the background, and the only thing that mattered was the love that seemed to radiate between them.

 

“Look at them,” Wanda whispered to her Vision, her husband, her voice full of awe as she watched Agatha and Rio walk into the venue. “They’re… stunning.”

 

Vision nodded, a little flustered, even if he would never admit it to his wife.

 

As the couple mingled with the guests, Agatha’s calm presence was magnetic, effortlessly drawing people in with her charm and sharp wit, while Rio, a little more reserved, captivated everyone with her intelligent conversations. They moved together like two halves of a whole, almost glowing in the soft lighting of the event.

 

But it wasn’t just their physical presence that amazed the guests—it was the way they communicated, the quiet moments that passed between them, the way they leaned in close to whisper something in each other’s ear, their soft laughs filling the air. It was the way Agatha looked at Rio with such adoration, and the way Rio, in turn, could always make Agatha smile with just a look.

 

“They’re perfect for each other,” Wanda mused, her gaze never leaving her friends as they socialized with other guests.

 

As the night wore on, Wanda and their friends couldn’t help but watch them in awe. Agatha and Rio were a force together—two strong women who had found something rare and beautiful. And as they shared moments with each other, as they laughed, danced, and whispered between conversations, it became clear that their love was as effortlessly beautiful as the night itself.

 

 

The gala was in full swing, the music softly playing in the background as Agatha and Rio made their rounds, exchanging pleasantries with Agatha’s old friends and new faces alike. The evening had been nothing short of perfect, but in the midst of the elegant event, Agatha couldn’t help but notice how utterly stunning Rio looked in her flowy lavender dress.

 

The dress hugged Rio’s figure in all the right ways, catching the light with every graceful movement, the delicate shimmer making her look ethereal. Agatha could barely take her eyes off her. The flower crown nestled atop Rio’s dark waves only added to the effect—like some enchanting forest nymph had wandered into the gala, entirely unaware of the way she captivated everyone around her.

 

But Agatha was very, very aware.

 

She had spent the better part of the evening watching Rio—watching the way she laughed, the way she moved, the way her lips curled into that knowing little smirk whenever she caught Agatha’s gaze lingering a bit too long. And right now, with a glass of wine in one hand and her other subtly trailing down Rio’s arm, Agatha decided she had been patient long enough.

 

They had been talking to a few of Agatha’s old classmates when Agatha leaned in slightly, her voice dropping to a quiet whisper. “I have to say… you look breathtaking tonight.” Her hand brushed lightly against Rio’s arm, a smile tugging at the corner of her lips.

 

Rio, who had been chatting animatedly, looked up, catching Agatha’s gaze. “Thank you,” she replied, her voice warm with affection. She was still caught up in the night, but a subtle blush crept across her cheeks as Agatha’s hand lingered on her arm.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened. “But,” she began, her voice taking on a lower, teasing tone, “I’ll admit I can’t wait to see you out of that dress later.”

 

Rio’s eyes widened for a moment, her cheeks turning a deeper shade of pink as she caught the underlying meaning in Agatha’s words. “Agatha,” she whispered, a mix of laughter and surprise in her voice. She was always so aware of how the night unfolded, always so attuned to the way things felt, but the promise Agatha had just made sent a flutter of anticipation through her chest.

 

“Don’t act so innocent,” Agatha teased, her hand finding Rio’s, giving it a gentle squeeze as she led her further into the crowd. “You know how I feel about you in that dress.”

 

Agatha’s lips curled into a knowing smile. She leaned in again, just enough that her breath fanned over the shell of Rio’s ear, sending goosebumps skittering down her spine. “You’re driving me insane,” she murmured. “That dress, that smile, the way you’ve been teasing me all night without even trying. And when we get home…” She let the words trail off deliberately, her voice thick with promise.

 

Rio swallowed, suddenly hyperaware of the heat pooling low in her stomach, of the way Agatha’s thumb brushed against the inside of her wrist in a way that was entirely too casual for the effect it had on her. “You’re impossible,” she muttered, but the way she squeezed Agatha’s hand betrayed her words.

 

“You love it,” Agatha murmured, her gaze hooded, filled with something sinful. “And later, my love, I’m going to show you just how much I love you in return.”

 

The words sent a shiver through Rio, anticipation curling in her belly, warm and slow and dangerous. She felt herself leaning into Agatha without thinking, as if some magnetic pull had drawn her closer, but before she could respond—before she could let herself fully indulge in the delicious game Agatha was playing—a familiar voice interrupted, pulling her back into the present.

 

“Ah, Agatha! It’s been years!” one of her former classmates called, entirely unaware of the moment he had just shattered.

 

Agatha pulled back smoothly, her expression the picture of calm sophistication, as if she hadn’t just whispered sin into Rio’s ear in the middle of a crowded garden. She turned with an easy smile, greeting the man, slipping back into polite conversation effortlessly.

 

Rio, on the other hand, took a slow sip of her drink, trying to steady her breathing, trying to ignore the way her body still burned from Agatha’s touch. She shot her a glance—one that promised retaliation later—but Agatha only smirked in response, utterly pleased with herself.

 

The night continued, but Agatha’s teasing didn’t let up. Every brush of her fingers, every lingering glance, every low, murmured comment disguised beneath polite conversation kept Rio on edge. The worst of it was when Agatha leaned in close just as they were saying their goodbyes, her lips ghosting over Rio’s ear as she whispered, “And tonight, when we’re alone, I’ll make sure you know exactly how much I’ve been looking forward to that moment all evening.”

 

Rio felt her pulse quicken, the anticipation of the evening ahead making her breath catch in her throat. “You’re incorrigible,” she whispered, but the teasing smile on her lips was just as telling as Agatha’s.

 

Agatha only chuckled, smug and impossibly charming as she slipped her arm around Rio’s waist, guiding her toward the car. “I think that’s the me you fell in love with,” she said, voice full of promise, her fingers brushing just a little too low on Rio’s back.

 

Rio exhaled sharply, her pulse racing as they stepped into the cool night air. If Agatha thought she was going to win this game so easily, she had another thing coming.

 

Because two could play at that game.

 

And by the time the night was over, Rio would make sure Agatha was the one breathless and wrecked beneath her.

 

 

The ride home was quiet, but comfortable, the soft hum of the car engine a gentle backdrop to the weight of the evening fading away. Agatha could feel Rio beside her, a soft smile still playing on her lips as they made their way through the streets. It had been a night full of light and laughter, but Agatha knew that there was something even more intimate and personal waiting for them once they were home.

 

The moment the car rolled to a stop in the driveway, Agatha exhaled slowly, fingers tightening slightly around the steering wheel. She had been patient—so unbearably patient—all night, playing her little game, whispering promises that made Rio flush and shift in her seat, teasing until she could practically feel the anticipation thrumming beneath her skin.

 

But now, with the night stretched out before them and no one around to interrupt, Agatha wasn’t feeling particularly patient anymore.

 

She didn’t rush, though. No, she never did. The best things, after all, were meant to be savored.

 

Rio was already pushing open the door, stepping out with effortless grace despite the lingering effects of champagne and Agatha’s endless teasing. The dress still shimmered in the low porch light, a final taunt, as if it knew just how much it had tortured Agatha all night. She followed, shutting the car door with a little more force than necessary before trailing behind Rio into the house.

 

The moment they stepped inside, the air shifted. The house was dark, quiet—too quiet after the hum of conversation, the music, the lingering heat of the gala. It was just them now, just the slow click of Rio’s heels against the hardwood floor, just the barely-there sound of her breath as she turned to meet Agatha’s gaze.

 

Agatha shut the door with a quiet click, and for a long moment, she simply stared.

 

“Well,” she finally murmured, voice low and almost lazy, but her eyes gleamed with something much sharper. “You were the most beautiful woman in the room tonight…” She stepped forward, slow, deliberate, fingers brushing against Rio’s arm as she reached down. She slipped off one shoe, then the other, taking her time as if undressing her piece by piece. “But now,” she whispered, straightening up, her lips just a breath away from Rio’s, “I get to have you all to myself.”

 

Rio let out a soft laugh, but there was a breathlessness to it, her pulse betraying her. “You’ve had me all night, love.”

 

Agatha hummed, fingertips grazing the soft fabric at Rio’s waist. “Not the way I want.”

 

The words sent a delicious shiver down Rio’s spine.

 

Agatha’s hands moved, slow and reverent, slipping over the smooth fabric, tracing the elegant lines of Rio’s dress. “I’m going to take this off of you, love,” she whispered, eyes locking with Rio’s. “And I want to hear you say you want that too.”

 

Rio swallowed, the intensity of Agatha’s gaze leaving her almost dizzy. “Yes,” she murmured, voice barely above a whisper.

 

That was all Agatha needed.

 

The zipper came undone with agonizing slowness, the sound sharp in the quiet space. Agatha didn’t yank, didn’t rush—she simply let her fingers glide, the fabric giving way beneath her touch, slipping down Rio’s shoulders, sliding over her waist until it pooled at her feet in a silken heap.

 

Rio stood there, in nothing but soft, delicate lace, the flower crown still perched atop her loose waves. The cool air ghosted over her bare skin, making her hyper-aware of just how exposed she was.

 

Agatha took a step back, drinking her in, eyes dark and hungry. “God, you are exquisite.”

 

The words sent heat curling through Rio’s stomach, her breath catching. She had spent all evening reveling in Agatha’s attention, in the way those sharp blue eyes followed her across the room, the way Agatha’s fingers had lingered on the small of her back, the way her teasing whispers had left her warm and aching.

 

But now, with Agatha watching her like this, like she was something sacred and sinful all at once, Rio felt her knees go weak.

 

“Agatha…” she whispered, but she wasn’t sure if it was a plea or a warning.

 

Agatha didn’t let her finish.

 

She closed the distance between them in an instant, hands firm but careful as they found Rio’s waist, pulling her close. Her lips pressed a slow, lingering kiss to Rio’s forehead, then another to her temple, then another just below her jaw—soft, deliberate, maddening.

 

“You know how much I love you,” she murmured against Rio’s skin.

 

Rio melted into the touch, her body relaxing against Agatha’s as she wrapped her arms around her. It wasn’t about the dress anymore, or the teasing that had filled the evening. It was about this—this connection, this love that always found a way to ground them no matter how chaotic the world might feel.

 

Agatha ran her fingers through Rio’s hair, the flower crown gently falling away.

 

Rio barely had time to react before Agatha’s hands slipped lower, fingers grazing the backs of her thighs as she lifted her with ease, earning a quiet gasp as Rio instinctively clung to her.

 

“Let’s get you comfortable,” Agatha murmured, her lips ghosting over Rio’s pulse as she carried her toward the bedroom.

 

Rio had no doubt the night was about to be anything but.

 

The night had been a celebration of them both, of their bond and their love for each other. But now, in the quiet of their own space, Agatha’s every touch felt like a promise. A promise to care for Rio, to love her, and to always be there, in all the ways that truly mattered.

 

“My turn, now,” Rio whispered, her eyes growing darker.

 

Agatha let out a soft hum, her smile laced with anticipation, but she didn’t move. She wanted to see how Rio would unravel her, how she would take her time, how she would turn the simple act of undressing into something far more dangerous—far more delicious.

 

The room was quiet except for the soft rustling of fabric as Rio gently reached for Agatha’s jacket. There was no rush tonight, no need to hurry. Not when she had the pleasure of drawing this out, of making Agatha feel every single touch, every single deliberate movement. Her fingers brushed over the smooth material, skimming Agatha’s shoulders before slipping the jacket down her arms, letting it fall to the floor in a forgotten heap. Every gesture, every touch was deliberate, filled with a deep sense of reverence and love. Agatha’s smile softened as she met Rio’s eyes, a quiet understanding passing between them. It wasn’t just the end of the evening or the removal of clothing—it was something deeper. It was a moment of connection, of intimacy, of honoring one another.

 

Agatha exhaled, steady and patient, but her eyes betrayed her—the flicker of heat, the way she watched Rio like she was trying to burn the sight of her into memory.

 

Rio’s fingers traced over the first button of Agatha’s blouse, and she smirked, playful yet wicked. “You were so patient with me, love. Should I return the favor?”

 

Agatha let out a soft chuckle, the sound low and knowing. “You wouldn’t dare.”

 

“Oh,” Rio breathed, voice teasing, “I think I would.”

 

The first button came undone. Then the next. And the next.

 

Slow. Painfully slow.

 

Rio took her time, unfastening each button as if it were a secret being unraveled, as if she were peeling back every layer of the night itself. Her hands, warm and steady, brushed against the soft skin beneath, her fingers grazing down the line of Agatha’s sternum with excruciating reverence, savoring each movement as though she were handling something fragile, something precious. Agatha stood still under Rio’s touch, feeling the warmth of her adoration in each delicate movement, in each moment of attention. The tension from the evening seemed to melt away, replaced by a soft, steady pulse of affection.

 

The blouse slid from Agatha’s shoulders, slipping down her arms like water, revealing smooth skin, the gentle curves that Rio had memorized a hundred times over.

 

And yet, she still stared.

 

Like she had never seen Agatha before. Like she would never see enough of her.

 

 Every inch of Agatha was beautiful to her—every blemish, every curve, every line. She was the woman she had chosen and who had chosen her in return, the one who knew her like no one else could.

 

“Magnificent,” Rio murmured, her hands trailing over Agatha’s collarbones, lingering just long enough to send a shiver down her spine.

 

Agatha tilted her head, watching her with quiet amusement, though her breathing had grown slightly uneven. “Still teasing, are we?”

 

Rio only smiled.

 

Her hands moved lower, slipping over Agatha’s waist as she worked on the buttons of her trousers, unfastening them with the same unbearable slowness. The quiet pop of each button, the gentle slide of fabric—it was a symphony in the hush of the room, a quiet seduction that left Agatha standing impossibly still, her lips parted ever so slightly, as if she were holding back a sharp inhale.

 

When the trousers pooled at her feet, Rio knelt.

 

Agatha’s breath hitched.

 

The moment stretched, heavy and intoxicating, as Rio’s hands traced the backs of her calves, her fingers ghosting over the delicate skin with infuriating patience. She lifted one of Agatha’s feet, slipping off the last barrier of fabric, then the other. But she didn’t rise right away.

 

Instead, she lingered.

 

Her hands traveled up, slow, deliberate, tracing the smooth length of Agatha’s thighs, the warmth of her palms pressing just firmly enough to send a ripple of heat through Agatha’s core.

 

Still, Rio didn’t look up.

 

She let her fingers skim higher, let them trail, featherlight, up the curve of Agatha’s hips before finally, finally standing, her breath fanning against Agatha’s collarbone, her lips hovering just above her pulse.

 

Agatha shuddered.

 

Rio pulled back just enough to look at her—really look at her.

 

She drank in the sight of Agatha standing before her, bare, exquisite, radiant in the soft glow of the room. Every line, every scar, every inch of her—worshiped with Rio’s gaze alone.

 

There was no teasing now. No playful smirks.

 

Just something raw. Something deeper.

 

Rio reached up, cupping Agatha’s face, her thumb brushing over the soft curve of her lips.

 

“You undo me,” she whispered, and there was nothing but truth in it.

 

Agatha held her gaze, something soft flickering beneath all that intensity. “Then we’re even.”

 

Rio let out a breath of laughter, tilting her head up as her lips finally—finally—met Agatha’s.

 

The kiss wasn’t rushed. It wasn’t desperate.

 

It was slow. Sinfully slow.

 

A deep, lingering pull, a silent vow wrapped in the taste of wine and the echoes of laughter from the night before.

 

When they broke apart, Rio didn’t move far. With a soft sigh, Rio rose on her tiptoes and kissed Agatha’s forehead. She stayed close, her forehead resting against Agatha’s, her fingers trailing through her lover’s long, dark hair before reaching for the flower crown still resting atop her head.

 

She took it off gently, reverently, placing it beside her own on the nightstand, her fingers stroking the delicate petals before returning to Agatha—who hadn’t moved, completely captivated, entirely enthralled.

 

Rio’s voice was barely above a murmur as she traced a slow path down Agatha’s spine, fingers dancing over skin she knew like poetry.

 

“You are everything to me,” she whispered, lips brushing the shell of Agatha’s ear. “Everything.”

 

Agatha’s arms wrapped around Rio then, pulling her in, closer, closer still, until there was no space left between them, until they were breathing the same air, lost in the gravity of each other. The night stretched around them, thick with the weight of anticipation, of everything unspoken and yet utterly understood.

 

Their hearts beat together, a rhythm so in sync it felt fated, as if this was always meant to be—this love, this hunger, this undeniable need. Tonight was just another chapter in the story they were writing together, a story woven with tenderness and fire, devotion and longing, a love that had carried them through every storm and would see them through every one to come.

 

Agatha’s lips found the curve of Rio’s shoulder, pressing a slow, lingering kiss against bare skin, her voice nothing more than a hushed murmur against her lover’s ear. “We’ve had a night full of eyes on us, full of attention,” she whispered, her fingers trailing aimless patterns down Rio’s spine, teasing, promising. “But this? This is just for us.”

 

Rio let out a breath of laughter, low and knowing, before she pushed Agatha back, guiding her until the backs of her knees met the edge of the bed.

 

But Agatha was faster.

 

With a wicked smirk, she caught Rio’s waist, yanking her down with her as she fell back onto the mattress. A soft gasp left Rio’s lips as she landed atop her, her legs settling astride Agatha’s hips, her hair falling forward in a dark cascade, a curtain that shielded them from the rest of the world.

 

Agatha let her fingers slide through the silk of it, twisting a lock around her fingers before tugging gently, just to see Rio’s eyes darken, just to hear the hitch in her breath.

 

Rio leaned down, her mouth hovering just above Agatha’s, teasing, taunting, until Agatha reached up, catching her lips in a kiss that was anything but patient.

 

It was searing, all-consuming, her teeth catching Rio’s lower lip just enough to pull a soft, shuddering sigh from her throat before Rio deepened it, her mouth parting, her tongue brushing against Agatha’s in a slow, languid tease.

 

Hands roamed, nails dragged, lips traced fire along flushed skin. The hunger between them ignited, something frantic and desperate beneath it, something ancient and primal, the way two forces of nature collided, overwhelmed, unable to stop, unwilling to slow.

 

Their touch became more frantic, more searching and exploring and soon, the only thing that could be heard in the room was whispers of each other’s name, cried out gasps and declarations of love.

 

It was never rushed with them, but it was never slow either. It was something else entirely—something sacred, something only they could create, something that burned hot enough to consume and yet never turned to ash.

 

When they came together, when their bodies finally intertwined in the most intimate of ways, it was with a certainty so unshakable that it defied reason, defied anything the world could throw at them and that this, right there was where they could be the purest versions of themselves.

 

Nothing could touch them here.

 

Nothing could tear them apart.

 

They were built for this, for each other.

 

And when the fire subsided into a slow, aching warmth, when the only thing left in its wake was the steady pulse of their heartbeats against sweat-slicked skin, they collapsed together, tangled beneath the sheets, breathless and sated.

 

Agatha shifted, settling her head against Rio’s chest, her fingers tracing lazy, absentminded patterns along her ribcage, savoring the quiet hum of Rio’s heartbeat beneath her fingertips.

 

She sighed, her voice a soft, sleep-drenched whisper.

 

“You really are a river, my love,” she murmured, her lips grazing the skin just above Rio’s heart. “And I think I am drowning in it.”

 

A pause.

 

“And there is nowhere else I’d rather be.”

 

Rio let out a slow breath, her arms tightening around Agatha, pulling her impossibly closer.

 

The world outside no longer existed.

 

There was only this.

 

The warmth of their shared bed, the gentle rise and fall of their breathing in perfect synchrony, and the quiet, immutable certainty that in each other’s arms, they had everything they would ever need.

 

 

The soft light of morning filtered through the curtains, casting a gentle glow across the room. Rio stirred, her body warm and cocooned in the comforting embrace of the sheets. She shifted slightly, her head tucked into the crook of Agatha’s neck, feeling the steady rise and fall of Agatha’s chest beneath her. It was still early—too early to fully be awake, but the world outside was already beginning to hum with the quiet rhythm of the day.

 

Agatha’s hand rested on Rio’s back, her fingers tracing idle circles over the smooth skin as she too began to wake, the softness of the touch grounding Rio even as she drifted between sleep and wakefulness. The night had been a blur of elegance, laughter, and whispered moments. But now, in the quiet of the morning after the gala, it was just the two of them—nothing to do, nowhere to be, no masks to wear.

 

Rio stretched slightly, feeling the warm press of Agatha’s body against her own. The soft scent of their shared perfume still clung to her skin, their clothes everywhere on the floor and the delicate flower crowns they’d both worn still lay discarded on the nightstand, a reminder of the night’s celebration.

 

“Morning,” Rio whispered, her voice still heavy with the remnants of sleep.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a sleepy smile, the softest of chuckles escaping her. She tilted her head slightly, her fingers continuing their slow, comforting movement along Rio’s back. “Morning,” she murmured in return, her voice raspy from the night’s quiet conversations.

 

Rio, feeling the comfort of being held so close, allowed herself to relax further. There was something so serene about the way Agatha held her, as if they were the only two people in the world and the world outside didn’t matter. For a moment, she let the calm wash over her, appreciating the stillness, the peace.

 

“I think we might have scarred Wanda for life,” Rio said with a teasing glint in her eyes, though her words were soft, more like a sleepy murmur. “I think her and Vision are probably gossiping about us as we speak.”

 

Agatha chuckled, her hand coming up to gently brush through Rio’s hair, the dark strands soft under her fingers. “Let them,” she said. “We’ve earned our share of teasing. Besides, it’s not every day we get to show up like that.”

 

Rio laughed softly, her head tilting up so she could look into Agatha’s eyes, the lingering softness of the night still there. “I just love being with you,” she said quietly, the weight of the words settling between them. “Last night, today—everything, really.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, her hand moving to cup Rio’s face. Her thumb traced the curve of Rio’s cheek. “I feel the same,” she whispered. “You and Nicky are everything I could ever wish for.”

 

There was a long, quiet moment between them, both of them lost in the simple, powerful connection they shared. The noise of the world outside faded away as they simply existed in this shared space, this bubble of peace.

 

“Can we stay here for a while?” Rio asked, her voice small, almost vulnerable.

 

Agatha’s eyes met hers, her smile soft but full of understanding. “As long as you want,” she replied. “No rush. We have the whole day ahead of us. I’m sure Lilia won’t mind if she gets Nicky to herself for a little longer.”

 

Rio smiled, her heart swelling with affection. “Nope, she won’t I can assure you that.”

 

The two of them lay there, intertwined under the sheets, the morning light growing stronger as the hours passed. There was no need for conversation, no need for anything other than the quiet, comfortable presence of each other. This was their time—a stolen moment of peace and closeness that they both treasured, away from the demands of the world around them.

 

 

When Agatha and Rio walked into the main library later that day, under the pretense of a meeting and researching new books for Agatha’s upcoming project—nothing unusual, as it wasn’t uncommon for supervisors to involve their mentees in their work—there was an undeniable lightness about them. They moved through the halls with the same composed authority they always carried, but there was something different this time: an air of quiet contentment that didn’t go unnoticed.

 

Alice and Jen exchanged knowing glances as the two passed by their table, their smiles just a little too soft, their hands brushing a little too often for it to be purely accidental.

 

“They’re glowing,” Alice said under her breath, leaning against the counter as she stirred her coffee.

 

“Glowing is an understatement,” Jen replied, smirking. “They look like they’ve just come back from a romantic getaway, not a charity gala.”

 

Alice chuckled, glancing toward the door. “I don’t know what’s more impressive—that they’re so obvious, or that they still manage to pretend they’re just another pair of teacher-student.”

 

A few rows further, towards the back, they could now see Rio perched on the edge of her seat, across for Agatha, chatting quietly but animatedly about something while Agatha listened with that fond, almost amused expression she reserved exclusively for her girlfriend and that Jen and Alice had come to recognize. When Rio gestured dramatically, Agatha reached up without thinking, gently catching Rio’s hand mid-air before placing it back in her lap, whispering they were still in the library—a small gesture that spoke volumes.

 

“Are we just not going to talk about this?” Alice whispered to her own girlfriend, her voice dripping with mock scandal.

 

“We have to talk about this,” Jen said, grinning.

 

Unbeknownst to the two of them, at their table, Rio cast a quick glance toward Jen and Alice, whom she had noticed earlier and could now feel staring at her. She leaned forward, resting her elbows on the table as she spoke softly. “Do you think they can tell?”

 

Agatha glanced up from her book, eyes twinkling with an almost unreadable expression. “They can tell. But it’s no secret, is it?”

 

Rio smiled shyly, her gaze dipping to the table. “No. It’s not.”

 

Jen and Alice waited until the couple had left the library an hour later to make their move. Later in the day, during a break in their own research, they cornered Rio by the entrance of the English department, pushing her into an empty room.

 

“So,” Alice began, her arms crossed but her grin wide but keeping her voice low. “You and Agatha seem… different today.”

 

Rio blinked, her lips parting slightly in surprise. “What do you mean?”

 

“Oh, come on,” Jen chimed in. “You two are practically floating through the halls. Spill. Was it the gala? Or the after the gala?”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed a deep pink as her mind instantly darted back to the intimacy of the night before. “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” she said, though the slight quaver in her voice betrayed her.

 

Alice laughed. “Oh, you absolutely know what we’re talking about.”

 

At that moment, Agatha appeared in the doorway, as though summoned by some unspoken signal. She took one look at Rio’s flustered expression and immediately understood. With her signature smirk, she stepped between Rio and the others, sliding an arm around her waist.

 

“Are we interrogating this lovely girl now?” Agatha asked, her tone teasing but with just enough edge to make the others reconsider their approach.

 

“We’re just making observations,” Alice replied, undeterred.

 

“Observations,” Agatha repeated, raising an eyebrow. “How fascinating. Well, perhaps you should focus your observations on your own lives instead of ours.”

 

Rio hid her face against Agatha’s shoulder, half-laughing and half-mortified. “You’re not helping,” she muttered.

 

“On the contrary,” Agatha said, tilting her head to meet Rio’s gaze. Her voice softened, just enough that only Rio could hear. “I’m always helping, my love.”

 

And with that, she steered Rio away, leaving their two friends laughing behind them.

 

“Still glowing,” Alice noted as they disappeared around the corner.

 

“Absolutely glowing,” Jen agreed.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

I think this chapter made me develop a flower crown kink...

Also, thank you so so much for your comments, they really keep me writing, so keep them coming :)

(Also, no update tomorrow, as I always post around midnight, and I will be at a New Year's Eve party, either celebrating, or crying, depending on my mood!)

Think About It

Chapter Notes

Happy New Year everyone!!!!
May 2025 bring you everything you could wish for :)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

*

*

*

 

Home is where one starts from. As we grow older

The world becomes stranger, the pattern more complicated

Of dead and living. Not the intense moment

Isolated, with no before and after,

But a lifetime burning in every moment

And not the lifetime of one man only

But of old stones that cannot be deciphered.

 

              (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The rain outside painted Rio’s apartment windows in streaks of silver, a soothing backdrop to the cozy scene she’d been meticulously preparing. The small dining table, pushed against the far wall of her studio, was set with mismatched but charmingly eclectic plates. A cluster of candles flickered in the middle, their warm light bouncing off the leaves of the countless plants scattered throughout the space.

 

Nicky stepped through the door first, his eyes immediately going wide. “Whoa!” he exclaimed, his small voice echoing with awe. He darted past Rio, who held the door open for Agatha, and started exploring, taking in all the greenery present in the small apartment. “Are these all yours?”

 

Rio grinned, closing the door behind them. “All of them,” she replied, Taking Nicky’s little rain-soaked jacket and hanging it by the door. “Some of them got names, too, you know. Want to meet them?”

 

Nicky turned to her, eyes sparkling with curiosity. “You named your plants?”

 

“Of course,” Rio said, her tone playfully serious. “They’re family. That one’s Aleafia.” She pointed to a towering fiddle-leaf fig near the window. “And over there is Fernando, my favorite spider plant.”

 

Nicky giggled, reaching out toward a cluster of pothos vines hanging in a macramé holder by the bookshelf. Agatha’s voice drifted in, wry and warm as she slipped off her boots. “Careful, Nicky. You don’t want to make Fernando upset by tugging on his leaves.”

 

Rio laughed, crossing to the kitchen area to check on the pot simmering on the stove. “Don’t worry. Fernado’s tough. He’s survived worse than curious little hands.”

 

Agatha leaned against the doorframe, her long hair falling over her shoulder as she surveyed the room. Plants filled every available surface, spilling from shelves, climbing up trellises, and even perched atop the fridge, mixed with piles of books. The apartment felt alive, vibrant with Rio’s energy, a reflection of the young woman herself.

 

“You really are the queen of the jungle, love,” Agatha teased, earning a quick glance and a soft smile from Rio.

 

“Only if it I am your queen of the jungle, darling,” Rio quipped, turning back to her cooking with a wink. "Lilia used to call me her little green witch."

 

Agatha’s eyes softened at the endearment. "Fitting," she chuckled as Nicky darted to Rio’s side, holding up a small succulent in a painted pot. “What’s this one called?”

 

Rio leaned out towards him, a wooden spoon in hand. “That’s Jack O’Plantern. He’s a survivor.” She winked again. “He almost didn’t make it after I forgot to water him for a month, but now he’s thriving. Just like us, right?”

 

Agatha tilted her head, her gaze lingering on Rio as Nicky excitedly returned the pot to its spot. There was something grounding about being in Rio’s space, surrounded by her vibrant, chaotic life. And for the first time, Agatha felt like they were taking a tangible step toward merging their worlds—her and Nicky’s and Rio’s.

 

“So,” Rio said, clapping her hands as she set the spoon down and gestured toward the table. “Are you two ready for the best dinner you’ve ever had in a jungle?”

 

 

After dinner, the dishes were stacked neatly in the sink, and the scent of the homemade dinner still lingered in the air. Nicky sat cross-legged on the rug by the couch, playing with a set of toy dinosaurs he’d fished out of his backpack, their roars echoing softly as he created an epic jungle battle. Rio, meanwhile, moved around her apartment with a small watering can, her usual post-dinner ritual of checking on her “green babies” well underway.

 

She hummed quietly to herself, crouching to inspect the soil of a fern that had been looking a little droopy earlier that week. With gentle precision, she tilted the watering can, letting a steady trickle dampen the soil. Agatha sat on the couch, legs crossed, observing Rio with a faint smile. There was something endlessly fascinating about the way Rio poured so much care into even the simplest tasks.

 

“You know,” Agatha said casually, her voice smooth and even, “these plants would look amazing in my house.”

 

Rio froze, the watering can suspended mid-air. A single drop of water escaped the spout, landing with an almost imperceptible plink against the ceramic pot. She didn’t turn around, her mind racing at the unexpected weight of the comment. Agatha’s house.

 

Before Rio could muster a response, Nicky perked up from his spot on the floor, looking up with bright eyes. “Do I get to water them too?” he asked excitedly. “Can I take care of Aleafia?”

 

Rio’s lips curved into a soft smile at his enthusiasm, her chest tightening at the earnestness in his voice. Setting the watering can down, she turned to him, crouching to his level. “You’d be a great plant caretaker, Nicky,” she said, ruffling his hair. “Aleafia would love you.”

 

His grin stretched ear to ear, but Rio’s gaze flickered up to Agatha, who was watching her with that same calm, steady expression that betrayed nothing and everything all at once. Agatha’s comment wasn’t just a casual remark about plants. Agatha was asking her to move in, not with words but in the subtle, deliberate way she always had of planting an idea and letting it grow.

 

Rio stood slowly, her heart beating faster than she’d like. She wasn’t sure if it was from the rush of anxiety or the flicker of excitement threatening to bubble to the surface. “Agatha,” she started, her voice quieter than usual, “are you… are you saying—?”

 

Agatha uncrossed her legs, leaning forward with her elbows on her knees. Her expression was soft but unyielding, her lips curving into a knowing smirk. “I’m saying you, Aleafia, Jack, and the rest of the jungle would look good in my house.” she said lightly, though her eyes gleamed with meaning. “But yes, love, I’m asking.”

 

Rio’s throat tightened. She glanced at Nicky, who was now fully immersed in making his dinosaurs roar again, then back at Agatha. The enormity of what was being asked sank in, and while it should have terrified her, the warmth in Agatha’s gaze—and the thought of Nicky’s laughter filling her space every day—made her heart ache in a way that felt startlingly like belonging.

 

Rio picked up the watering can again, though her hands were slower, her movements deliberate as she considered Agatha’s words. She turned toward the towering monstera by the window, tipping the spout just enough to dampen its soil. Her smirk, however, betrayed the tension she was trying to mask.

 

“So, that’s it, huh?” Rio quipped, her voice laced with mock offense. She glanced over her shoulder at Agatha, who was now lounging on the couch with Nicky perched comfortably in her lap. “You’re just after my plants?”

 

Agatha tilted her head, feigning an innocent look. “What can I say?” she replied dryly, her fingers idly brushing through Nicky’s hair. “Your jungle adds charm. But…” She let the sentence dangle for just a beat too long before adding, “Nicky might want you to come, too. Right, kiddo?”

 

Nicky’s head popped up, his wide eyes sparkling with excitement. “Yes!” he declared, his small hands clutching at Agatha’s arms as if to underscore his agreement. “You have to come, Rio! And Aleafia and Jack O’Plantern and—” He paused, his little brow furrowing. “What’s the one hanging by the bookshelf?”

 

“That’s Liliage,” Rio said, biting back a laugh as she turned fully to face them, her arms crossed over her chest, the watering can dangling at her side.

 

Agatha snorted, unable to contain her amusement anymore. “Did you really name a plant after Lilia and made a bad pun about foliage with it?”

 

“Yes, and so what?” Rio replied, raising an eyebrow, before continuing. “And Liliage is very attached to this place. I’m not sure she’d want to leave.”

 

Nicky gasped, clutching his chest in mock concern. “But Liliage has to come, too!”

 

Agatha arched an eyebrow, her lips twitching into a smirk of her own. “Oh, dear,” she drawled. “Sounds like Liliage’s feelings might complicate things. What do you say, Rio? Are you going to let poor Nicky live without his new best friend?”

 

Rio laughed, shaking her head as she leaned back against the counter. “Wow, pulling the kid card already? That’s low, Harkness.” She tilted her head, her smirk softening as she watched the way Nicky’s face lit up at the mere idea of them all being together. “But I see how it is. You just want my plants to do all the decorating for you.”

 

“Obviously,” Agatha said, deadpan, earning a giggle from Nicky. She leaned back against the couch cushions, her eyes never leaving Rio. “Though having their eccentric owner around might not be so bad, either.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, though her cheeks flushed at the casual compliment. She let out an exaggerated sigh, setting the watering can down and walking over to the couch. With a flourish, she dropped onto the armrest beside Agatha, playfully invading her space.

 

“So, if I agree to this—hypothetically, of course—” Rio began, wagging a finger in mock seriousness, “what’s the guarantee that you won’t kill my plants the second I’m not looking?”

 

“Unfair,” Agatha replied with mock indignation. “I’ll have you know I’ve kept Nicky alive for six years. I think I can handle a few leaves.”

 

“Hey!” Nicky piped up, twisting around in Agatha’s lap to face her. “I’m not a plant!”

 

Agatha chuckled, pressing a kiss to the top of his nose. “You are a very pretty plant, my love, the most precious one of all, baby.”

 

Rio crossed her arms, her lips twitching into a smirk as she leaned back against the counter. Her hesitancy melted for a moment, replaced by her usual fiery humor. “I don’t think either of you has the green thumb required for this level of commitment.”

 

Agatha arched a brow, her smirk matching Rio’s. “Give me some credit, love,” she drawled. “I can learn. It’s not rocket science.”

 

Nicky, who had been happily pretending his dinosaur was chomping on the leaves of the monstera next to the couch, perked up immediately. “I can help!” he exclaimed, practically bouncing in place. “I’ll water them every day! Especially Liliage!”

 

Rio’s eyes widened in mock horror. “Every day? Oh no, kiddo. That’s how you drown them,” she said, clutching her heart playfully. “Plants need just the right amount of water, not too much, not too little. You’ve got to read their vibe.”

 

Nicky blinked, his little face scrunching in confusion. “Plants have vibes?”

 

“Totally,” Rio said, crouching down to his level. She picked up a leaf of the pothos trailing nearby. “See this one? Its leaves are perky and green. That’s a happy plant. But if they droop, or get yellow, they’re stressed. You’ve got to know when to give them a drink and when to let them chill.”

 

Nicky nodded solemnly, as if receiving the secrets of the universe. Meanwhile, Agatha rolled her eyes and crossed her arms. “Oh, come on. I could do that,” she said with mock offense. “I know plants need water, sunlight, and… what’s that stuff? Fertilizer?”

 

Rio straightened, raising an eyebrow at her. “Uh-huh. And how much water, exactly?”

 

Agatha didn’t miss a beat. “Enough to keep them alive. Obviously.”

 

“Wow,” Rio said dryly, her smirk widening. “I’m so impressed by your expertise, Dr. Harkness.”

 

“Hold on,” Agatha countered, holding up a finger. “I know more than you think. Like, that one over there—” She pointed to a fiddle leaf fig standing proudly in the corner. “It needs bright, indirect sunlight and hates being moved around. See? I’ve done my homework.”

 

Rio burst out laughing, shaking her head. “Okay, first of all, yes, it does hate being moved. But second, if you overwater it or let it sit in bad drainage, it’s toast. So don’t get too cocky.”

 

Nicky, who had been watching their exchange like it was a tennis match, suddenly chimed in. “But what about Liliage? Does she like bright light too?”

 

“Liliage’s a tough girl,” Rio said with a wink at him. “She’s a Boston fern. Likes indirect light, lots of humidity. She’s a diva, but she’s worth it.”

 

Agatha placed a hand over her heart, feigning offense. “Are you implying I wouldn’t give Liliage the love and care she deserves? I’m hurt, truly.”

 

Rio gave her a sidelong glance, biting back another laugh. “I’m implying you’ve got a lot to learn before I trust you with my jungle.”

 

Nicky grinned, tugging on Agatha’s sleeve. “We can do it, right Mama?”

 

“Of course we can,” Agatha said smoothly, her eyes twinkling as she leaned toward Rio. “You might be the expert, love, but we’re quick learners. And if nothing else, I’ve got a secret weapon.”

 

Rio’s brow furrowed in mock suspicion. “Oh? What’s that?”

 

“Nicky’s enthusiasm,” Agatha said with a smirk. “And my charm. A winning combination, wouldn’t you agree?”

 

Rio shook her head, laughing as she grabbed her watering can again. “You two are a dangerous duo, you know that?” She sighed, glancing at her plants. “Fine. Maybe I’ll consider it. But don’t think for a second that means I’m letting you off the hook. Plant care is serious business, and I’m not lowering my standards.”

 

Nicky beamed, clapping his hands. “We’re gonna have so many plants!” he said, already twisting in Agatha’s lap to inspect the next one.

 

Agatha leaned back, her eyes never leaving Rio’s form, her expression softening as she lowered her voice. “You’ll see, Rio. We would take good care of them—and you.”

 

Rio glanced at her, the teasing banter fading for a moment as the sincerity in Agatha’s voice struck her. She let the weight of those words settle before offering a small, genuine smile. “You better,” she said softly, her tone light but her meaning clear.

 

Rio reached over, ruffling Nicky’s hair before letting her hand rest briefly on Agatha’s shoulder. “I’ll think about it, Dr. Harkness,” she admitted. “But you’re still on probation when it comes to Liliage.”

 

Nicky slid off Agatha’s lap, his little dinosaur clutched in one hand as he wandered over to Rio. His big, curious eyes fixed on her as she crouched down near the monstera, her fingers gently brushing one of its glossy leaves. He tilted his head, his voice soft but serious. “Do plants like moving houses?”

 

Rio paused, a small laugh escaping her lips. She set the watering can aside and turned to look at him. “You know, that’s a really good question,” she said, her tone thoughtful. “Plants can be fussy about moving, but…” She glanced around at the jungle she’d nurtured so carefully, her expression warm and wistful. “They like anywhere they’re loved.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up, his dinosaur momentarily forgotten. “So if we love them, they’ll like our house too?”

 

“Exactly,” Rio replied, her smile widening as she gently tugged on one of his curls. “You’re a smart little guy, you know that?”

 

He giggled, then ran back to the couch, climbing into Agatha’s lap again and resuming his animated one-sided conversation about Jack and Fernando and Aleafia. Rio watched him for a moment, her chest tightening at the sight. When she finally tore her gaze away, she found Agatha watching her—calm, steady, patient, like she always was when something important was brewing under the surface.

 

Rio bit her lip, standing and brushing her hands on her jeans as she leaned against the back of the couch. She spoke softly, almost as if the words weren’t meant to be heard. “I guess people do too.”

 

Agatha tilted her head back slightly, her lips curving into a faint smile, though her eyes softened with understanding. She didn’t push, didn’t press Rio to elaborate. Instead, she shifted Nicky in her lap so he could sit more comfortably, keeping her attention on Rio as if to say, Take your time. I’m here.

 

The weight of it all suddenly felt less heavy, less daunting, as Rio stood in her little jungle, surrounded by the life she’d cultivated and the life waiting for her beyond it. She crossed her arms, taking a few steps back and leaning her head back against the wall, next to the counter, and let out a breathy laugh.

 

“You know, it’s not fair how you both gang up on me,” she teased, her smirk creeping back. “First Nicky charms me with his enthusiasm, and then you hit me with your big soulful eyes.”

 

“Is it working?” Agatha asked, her tone dry but her smirk matching Rio’s.

 

Rio rolled her eyes but didn’t answer. Instead, she turned back to her plants, running her fingers over their leaves like they were old friends. Her heart felt like it was waging a quiet war with itself, but in the background, she could hear Nicky’s soft chatter and Agatha’s low chuckle as they talked about which plant might be their favorite.

 

And at that time, Rio thought that maybe, it wouldn’t be so bad to let her little jungle take root somewhere new.

 

Rio’s fingers brushed over the trailing vines of her pothos, her movements slower now, more deliberate. She glanced over her shoulder at Nicky, who was now crouched by a small succulent on her coffee table, carefully inspecting its tiny, rounded leaves. His soft hums of fascination filled the quiet, a reminder of his boundless curiosity and the innocence that came with it.

 

But for Rio, the simplicity of the moment didn’t ease the knot tightening in her chest. She swallowed hard, her gaze dropping back to the plant in her hands. Her voice, when she finally spoke, was quieter than before. “It’s not just the plants, though.” She paused, her words measured. “Moving in would mean… a lot.”

 

Agatha straightened on the couch, her sharp eyes catching the subtle shift in Rio’s tone, the way her usual fire had dimmed to something more hesitant. She gently shifted Nicky off her lap, giving him a light pat on the back as he scurried back to his dinosaurs on the floor. Then she stood, her long stride effortlessly closing the distance between them.

 

“You’re right,” Agatha said softly, her voice steady but laced with care. “It would mean a lot. For all of us.”

 

Rio glanced at her, her brow furrowing slightly. “Agatha, I…” She hesitated, the words tangling in her throat. The idea of giving up her independence—this space she’d built for herself, where she’d poured so much of her energy and love—felt daunting. And yet, the thought of stepping into something new, something shared, made her heart ache with a mix of fear and longing.

 

Agatha reached out, her hand light on Rio’s arm. “I wouldn’t ask if Nicky and I didn’t want you there,” she said firmly, her gaze unwavering. “Really want you there.”

 

Rio’s breath caught. Agatha’s words were simple, but they carried weight, a promise that steadied the storm brewing in her mind. She looked at Nicky again, who was now carefully poking at a succulent, muttering something under his breath about how “That must be Aleafia’s cousin.” His small presence filled the space with so much light that it was hard to imagine ever being without it.

 

“And I wouldn’t ask if I didn’t think you’d thrive with us,” Agatha added, her voice softening but never losing its conviction. “The way you thrive here, with all this life around you.”

 

Rio’s lips twitched into a faint smile, but it didn’t quite reach her eyes. She let out a slow exhale, shaking her head. “You make it sound so easy.”

 

“It’s not,” Agatha admitted, her hand still resting gently on Rio’s arm. “But nothing worth having ever is. You’re stubborn, and I’m no picnic, either. But if there’s one thing I know, it’s that you’re worth every bit of the challenge.”

 

The words hung between them, heavy but comforting. Rio glanced around her apartment, at the plants she’d cared for, the books she’d collected, the space that had been entirely hers. And then her eyes found Nicky again, his little laugh ringing out as he pretended one of his dinosaurs was climbing the monstera.

 

Her independence had always been her shield, her sanctuary. But now, for the first time, she wondered if it might be okay to share it—not to lose it, but to let it grow alongside something new. She looked back at Agatha, her hesitation still there, but softened by the glimmer of something else: hope.

 

As the conversation wound down, the easy banter between them gave way to a thoughtful quiet. Nicky had climbed back onto the couch, happily reenacting a dinosaur battle with his toys, leaving Rio and Agatha standing by the counter. Rio’s fingers absently traced the rim of the watering can, her eyes distant as she stared at her little jungle of plants.

 

Agatha noticed the shift immediately. The energy that had animated Rio earlier seemed to dim, as doubt began to creep in. Agatha stepped closer, her hand brushing lightly against Rio’s.

 

“Hey,” she said softly, drawing Rio’s gaze. “What’s going on in that beautiful head of yours?”

 

Rio hesitated, biting her lip as she weighed her words. Finally, she sighed, setting the watering can down. “I just… I don’t want to mess anything up,” she admitted, her voice quiet. “You and Nicky—you’ve got your home, your rhythm. What if I disrupt that? What if it’s too soon?”

 

Agatha studied her for a moment, her expression unreadable. Then she reached out, cupping Rio’s cheek gently, her thumb brushing against her skin. “Rio,” she said, her tone steady and reassuring, “you wouldn’t just be moving in. You’d be part of our family. That’s not a disruption—it’s an addition. A beautiful one.”

 

Rio felt her throat tighten at the word family, the sincerity in Agatha’s voice threatening to undo her. She closed her eyes for a moment, leaning into Agatha’s touch as she tried to push back the doubts swirling in her mind.

 

Rio opened her eyes, her gaze meeting Agatha’s. For a moment, the weight of her doubts eased, replaced by the warmth in those words. But still, she wasn’t quite ready to say yes—not yet.

 

“I’ll think about it,” she said finally, her voice tinged with affection and a touch of vulnerability.

 

Agatha nodded, her hand dropping back to her side. “That’s all I’m asking, love,” she said gently.

 

“Mama!” Nicky’s voice broke the moment as he held up one of his toys triumphantly. “Jack O’Plantern won the battle! He’s king of the plants now!”

 

Agatha chuckled, shaking her head. “All hail King Jack,” she said with mock solemnity, earning a giggle from Nicky.

 

It wasn’t long before Agatha gathered Nicky and his things, preparing to head home. Rio stood by the door, watching as Nicky gave her an enthusiastic wave before running to the stairs. Agatha lingered for a moment, her hand brushing Rio’s one last time, pecking her lips several times before taking a step back.

 

“Goodnight, Rio,” she said softly, her smile warm but knowing.

 

“Goodnight,” Rio replied, her own smile faint but genuine.

 

As the door closed behind them, Rio leaned against it, letting out a slow breath. The apartment felt quieter now, her plants casting long shadows in the soft glow of the lamps. She glanced at the monstera, at Liliage, at all the life she’d nurtured in this space.

 

Her thoughts were a tangle of emotions—fear, hope, longing, and uncertainty all woven together. But amidst it all, Agatha’s words echoed in her mind: You’d be part of our family.

 

For the first time tonight, Rio really allowed herself to consider what that might mean. And as the night stretched on, she sat amidst her plants, letting the thought take root.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

As always, let me know what you think, I LOVE hearing your thoughts and comments, and suggestions :)

Aleafia’s New Home

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Love is most nearly itself

When here and now cease to matter.

Old men ought to be explorers

Here or there does not matter

We must be still and still moving

Into another intensity

For a further union, a deeper communion.

 

              (T.S. Eliot. “East Coker.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next day, Rio found herself pacing around her apartment, thoughts swirling in a way that made her restless. The conversation with Agatha the night before had left her both unsettled and intrigued. You’d be part of our family. The words had stuck with her, bouncing around in her head like a melody she couldn’t shake. It had felt so simple when Agatha said it-just move in with them- but for Rio, it was anything but. She loved her independence, her space, the life she had built for herself. And yet… the idea of sharing it with Agatha and Nicky felt both exciting and terrifying.
