With a deep breath, Rio pulled out her phone and dialed the number she knew would offer her some much-needed clarity. The line rang twice before Lilia picked up.

 

“Hey, sweet girl,” Lilia’s warm voice came through the phone. “How are you?”

 

“I’m okay,” Rio replied, her voice sounding more uncertain than she’d intended. “Actually, no, I’m… I’m not. Can I come over for lunch?”

 

There was a pause on the other end, then a soft chuckle. “Of course, sweetheart. You know you don’t have to ask. I’ll make something nice. See you soon.”

 

Rio smiled faintly. “Thanks, Lilia. I’ll be there in an hour.”

 

 

When Rio arrived at Lilia’s apartment, the comforting smells of something warm and savory greeted her at the door. Lilia was already at the kitchen counter, chopping vegetables with her usual grace, her movements steady and deliberate.

 

“Hey, kiddo,” Lilia said warmly, her eyes softening as she looked at Rio. “I’m glad you came. You look like you’ve got a lot on your mind.”

 

Rio laughed lightly but it didn’t reach her eyes. She sat down at the kitchen table, resting her arms on it. “Yeah… I think I do.” Her voice wavered slightly, and she sighed, going for it. “Agatha asked me to move in with her and Nicky. Well, she didn’t exactly ask for it, but she suggested it.”

 

Lilia set down the knife she had been using, her expression turning thoughtful as she joined Rio at the table. “Okay, I see. And you don’t know what to do? You don’t sound convinced.”

 

Rio chuckled bitterly, shaking her head. “It’s not that. I’m just… I don’t know. I love my space, you know? I love having my independence. And I’m not sure if it’s the right time, or if I’d just be… imposing, or disrupting their dynamic. I mean, it’s their home, Lilia, and Nicky. He’s just a kid. What if I mess that up?”

 

Lilia’s face softened, her hands coming to rest on Rio’s. She was quiet for a moment, letting Rio’s words settle in the air between them before responding with the patience she always seemed to offer.

 

“Rio,” Lilia began gently, her voice a grounding force, “I can hear the weight of all your fears in your voice. But this isn’t something you’re doing alone. Agatha asked because she wants you there. She sees you as part of her family, and Nicky—well, that little boy adores you. It sounds like you’re already part of their world. The question is whether you’re ready to make it official.”

 

Rio leaned back in her chair, glancing down at her hands as she let the words sink in. “It’s just… a lot. I’ve been on my own for so long, and the idea of changing everything—sharing a home with them, with a kid… I don’t know if I’m ready to blend my life like that. What if I can’t handle it? What if I’m not a good fit?”

 

Lilia’s gaze softened even further, and she reached out, resting her hand over Rio’s. “You’ve always worried about fitting in, sweet girl. But you already fit with Agatha and Nicky. The question is whether you believe it. Moving in doesn’t mean giving up who you are. It means finding a place where you can all grow together, support each other. If you’re not ready, that’s okay. But I think you’ll know when the time is right.”

 

Rio let out a long, slow breath, trying to absorb the weight of Lilia’s words. “I just don’t want to mess things up,” she murmured, her voice quieter now, filled with vulnerability. “I love them, both of them, and the idea of being part of something like that… It’s scary, you know?”

 

Lilia leaned over, folding her arms on the table, her voice steady and reassuring. “Of course it’s scary. But nothing worth having ever comes without fear. Whatever choice you make, you’ll do it with your heart. And that’s all that matters.”

 

Rio smiled softly, her heart lightened by Lilia’s unwavering support. “Thanks, Lilia. You always know what to say.”

 

Lilia smiled warmly, getting up to stir something on the stove. “You’re welcome, darling. Now, how about we have some lunch and let you think this over a little more? No decisions today, just some good food and conversation.”

 

Rio chuckled and nodded, feeling the tension in her shoulders ease as she watched Lilia move around the kitchen.

 

As they settled down at the table, the warm, comforting food before them seemed to lighten Rio’s mood. She took a bite, but her mind was still busy, turning over the conversation she’d had with Agatha the night before, and the one she just had with Lilia.

Lilia watched her, her eyes sharp but filled with understanding. After a few moments, she set down her fork and leaned forward slightly.

 

“You know,” Lilia said, her tone gentle but direct, “you’ve always had a way of overthinking things when it comes to people you care about. Agatha, Nicky, the idea of moving in… you’re looking for every possible reason to hesitate, to doubt. I get it, sweetheart. It’s a big step. But if your heart is saying yes, maybe you should trust it.”

 

Rio blinked, a little taken aback by the straightforwardness of Lilia’s words. She opened her mouth, but the words didn’t come right away. Lilia was right, of course. Rio had always been quick to question herself, to pick apart the details until they felt too complicated. Her fear of messing things up, of losing herself in the process, often made her second-guess what she truly wanted.

 

“I don’t know if I can trust it,” Rio admitted quietly, her fingers tracing the edge of her plate. “What if I get in too deep and realize it’s not what I want? What if I can’t do it? What if I disappoint them?”

 

Lilia regarded her with a knowing look, her eyes soft but firm. “You’ll never know if you don’t take the step, Rio. Trusting your heart doesn’t mean everything will be perfect. It means you’re willing to embrace the mess and the beauty of it, even when you can’t predict the outcome.”

 

Rio let out a soft sigh, the weight of Lilia’s words pressing down on her. Trust your heart. It seemed so simple when Lilia said it, but for Rio, the concept felt like a leap of faith. She had spent so long protecting herself, keeping her emotions in check, that trusting her heart felt like a risk she wasn’t sure she was ready to take.

 

But there was something about the way Lilia said it, the way she always seemed to know exactly what Rio needed to hear. She wasn’t offering any grand answers, just a simple truth: maybe it was time to stop overthinking and start listening to what her heart had been quietly saying all along.

 

“I think… I think I’m scared,” Rio whispered, her voice small but honest. “Scared of losing myself. Scared of things changing.”

 

Lilia smiled softly, her expression full of empathy. “You’re allowed to be scared, Rio. But remember, the people who love you aren’t asking you to lose yourself. They’re asking you to share yourself and your life with them. And there’s a difference.”

 

Rio slumped a little in her chair, the tension in her chest easing just a little. “I want to. I really do. But it’s a lot to take in.”

 

Lilia nodded. “Of course it is. You don’t have to have all the answers right now. Take your time. But maybe it’s time to listen to what you really want.”

 

Rio let out a long breath, feeling the weight of Lilia’s wisdom settle in her bones. She wasn’t sure where this path would lead, but for the first time in a long while, she felt like maybe it was worth taking a step forward, trusting that the answer wasn’t as complicated as she’d made it out to be.

 

“Thanks, Lilia,” Rio said again, her voice tinged with gratitude. “I’ll think about it. Really think about it.”

 

Lilia smiled, a knowing glint in her eyes. “You’ll figure it out, my love. You always do.”

 

Lilia’s smile grew, and she reached across the table, her hand resting gently over Rio’s. The moment felt warm, as if the weight of the conversation had shifted, and Lilia’s calm presence filled the space between them.

 

“You know,” Lilia began again slowly, her voice takingg on a reflective tone, “when I took you in, I had no idea what I was getting into. It wasn’t a decision that came with a clear plan or certainty. There were a lot of fears—what if I failed you? What if you didn’t feel at home? What if I wasn’t enough?”

 

Rio looked up at Lilia, her eyes wide, hearing her adoptive mother speak about that time with a quiet vulnerability she hadn’t fully noticed before. Lilia had always been so steady, so confident. To hear her admit doubts, even in the face of doing something so incredibly generous, struck Rio deeply.

 

“But sometimes,” Lilia continued, her voice firm but filled with warmth, “it’s about taking that step when it feels right. When your heart tells you it’s worth it, even if the steps ahead are uncertain. I didn’t know if I was ready to be a mother, but I knew I was ready to take care of you. To give you a home. And look at us now.”

 

Rio felt a lump form in her throat, a mixture of gratitude and emotion bubbling up. Lilia had taken her in when she was a scared, lost teenager, providing her with a sense of security she hadn’t known she needed. To think that Lilia, too, had once faced the unknown in a similar way was humbling.

 

Lilia’s hand squeezed hers gently, a proud glint in her eyes. “And now look at you. You’ve found people who care about you so deeply, Rio. Agatha, Nicky—it’s clear they see something in you that’s worth holding on to. You’ve built your own life, but you’ve also made space for them. That’s not easy. And it makes me proud, more than you’ll ever know.”

 

Rio blinked rapidly, a tear slipping down her cheek before she could stop it. She quickly wiped it away, embarrassed, but Lilia just smiled, her eyes soft and full of understanding.

 

“You’ve done something not everyone can do,” Lilia said, her voice quiet but full of emotion. “You’ve opened yourself up to love. And you’re letting it in, even when it scares you. That’s something to be proud of, Rio.”

 

For a moment, the room fell into a comfortable silence. Rio sat back in her chair, the emotions swirling in her chest beginning to settle. It was as if the weight of her decision had lightened, if only a little, by the simple reminder of what she had already accomplished in her life. She had built something on her own, but she had also allowed herself to trust others, to open up and let them care for her. Maybe she really was ready for the next step.

 

Rio’s vice thickened with emotion. “I don’t think I’ve ever really stopped enough to think about it like that.”

 

Lilia smiled warmly, her hand brushing over Rio’s hair. “That’s what I’m here for, sweet girl. To help you see what’s already there. You’re stronger than you think, and you’ve got people who are ready to walk with you, no matter what comes next.”

 

Rio nodded, her heart lighter now, though she still had a lot to think through.

 

She sat back in her chair, her fingers gently tracing the edge of her glass. The conversation with Lilia had eased some of her worries, but there was one thing that still weighed heavily on her mind, a lingering uncertainty she hadn’t yet voiced.

 

“I guess there’s one thing I’m still nervous about,” Rio admitted, her voice quieter now, almost uncertain. She shifted uncomfortably, not quite meeting Lilia’s eyes. “I’m not sure about… about what I’m supposed to do with Nicky. I don’t want to step on any toes. It’s one thing to be there for Agatha, but I don’t know if it’s my place to be that involved with him.”

 

Lilia’s eyes softened with understanding, and she leaned forward slightly, her gaze warm but knowing. “You’re afraid of overstepping, aren’t you?” she asked gently, her tone calm and reassuring.

 

Rio nodded slowly, biting her lip. “Yeah. I know Agatha wants me there. I know she’s inviting me in, but… Nicky’s her son. It’s different. I don’t want to assume anything, or try to be something I’m not supposed to be.”

 

Lilia’s expression never wavered, and after a moment, she reached over, placing a hand on top of Rio’s. Her voice was steady, filled with quiet wisdom. “Rio, you already care about him. I can see it when you’re with him, the way you look out for him. You’re already a part of his life. The rest? That will come naturally, sweetheart. There’s no formula for these things. It’s about showing up, being there, and letting him see that you care. You don’t have to force anything.”

 

Rio let out a slow breath, the tightness in her chest easing just a little. Lilia was right, in a way. She had always been there for Agatha, and in turn, that had meant she was there for Nicky as well. Her love for Agatha extended to him, too, even if it felt like a delicate balancing act. The idea of fully stepping into that role, though, felt like a much bigger step than she had anticipated.

 

“I guess I’m just worried about what kind of role I’m supposed to play,” Rio admitted, her voice quiet now, full of vulnerability. “What if I try to step in too much and confuse things? What if Nicky doesn’t want me in that way, like some… second mom or something?”

 

Lilia smiled softly, a knowing glint in her eyes. “You’re not going to be a second mom, Rio. You’re going to be you. That’s all he needs. Kids are smarter than we give them credit for—they know when someone cares. And they know when that care is real. You’ll figure out what you mean to him later, and it won’t have to fit into some pre-made box.”

 

Rio nodded slowly, the warmth in Lilia’s words sinking in. The fear hadn’t entirely faded, but the tight knot in her chest loosened a little. She knew she wasn’t being asked to replace anything—only to be a part of something bigger. And maybe that was all she needed to do: be herself, show up when it mattered, and let the rest unfold.

 

“Thanks, Mom,” Rio murmured softly, the word rare on her lips as she gently squeezed Lilia’s hand, maybe also to show that she understood that she too, had been in Nicky’s position once. “I just… I don’t want to mess it up.”

 

Lilia gave her a reassuring smile, her eyes full of love and pride. “You won’t. Just trust yourself. And remember, there’s no need to rush. You’ve got time.”

 

Rio leaned back in her chair, feeling the weight of Lilia’s support settle around her. The path ahead wasn’t going to be perfect, and there were bound to be moments of uncertainty. But maybe that was the beauty of it—taking it one step at a time, with an open heart, and trusting that the people who loved her would help her find her way.

 

As the conversation drew to a close, Lilia stood up from the table and walked over to the windowsill, her movements slow and deliberate. Rio watched her fumble with something curiously, unsure of what was happening but sensing that Lilia had something important to share.

 

Lilia turned around, a box in her hand, that Rio couldn’t see yet. She held it out to Rio, her eyes soft and filled with meaning.

 

“Here,” she said, her voice quiet but steady. “I want you to take this with you. Just in case.”

 

Rio frowned slightly as she took the box from her, unsure of what it was. Lilia nodded, urging her to open it.

 

Inside the box was a small, polished stone—smooth and round, a calming shade of deep blue with streaks of white running through it. It wasn’t anything extravagant, but the weight of it in Rio’s hand felt significant, like it held more than just its physical form.

 

She closed her eyes for a moment, feeling the familiar weight of the smooth, cool surface against her fingers.

 

It had been years ago, during her first summer at Lilia’s house, when she’d discovered the stone on the lakeshore, a few miles from the house. She’d been walking alone, her feet dipping into the cool water, feeling lost but comforted by the silence of the lake around her. It was there, nestled among the smooth stones and driftwood, that she had found it—perfectly round, a deep shade of blue with streaks of white running through it. She hadn’t known why, but it had felt significant, like a piece of the world was offering her a reminder of something she needed to hold onto.

 

She’d brought it back to Lilia’s house, unsure of why it mattered, but instinctively knowing it was something special. Lilia had smiled when she handed it over, her eyes lighting up with that same knowing warmth Rio had come to cherish. “We’ll put it right there,” Lilia had said, placing it on the windowsill where it caught the light every morning. “As a reminder that you’re home now. And that this house will always be a place for you.”

 

From then on, the stone had become a small but constant fixture in Lilia’s house, always proudly displayed on the windowsill or on a shelf. It had become a symbol of belonging. A reminder that Rio had found her place, even if it took time to fully undertsand what that place meant.

 

Lilia’s voice was gentle as she spoke. “This stone has been with us for years. It’s a little piece of our home, a reminder that there’s always a place for you, wherever you go. If you decide that moving in with Agatha and Nicky is what you want, take this with you. Let it remind you that you’re not just gaining a new house—you’re gaining a new chapter, one that’s full of love and possibility.”

 

Rio swallowed, feeling a tightness in her throat at Lilia’s words. It was more than just a keepsake; it was a symbol of Lilia’s unwavering support, a physical representation of her belief that this step forward could be a positive, fulfilling one for Rio. It meant that wherever Rio went, there would always be a home for her, even if that home wasn’t the one she had known for so long.

 

Lilia smiled, her eyes soft but full of love. “You don’t have to make any decisions right now. But no matter what, you’ll always have a place with me. And I believe this will be a good step for you, Rio. A very good one.”

 

Rio felt the warmth of the stone in her palm, her heart swelling with emotion. She had always known Lilia had her back, but this gesture—this small, meaningful act—solidified that in a way words couldn’t.

 

Now, as she held it in her hand again, the significance of it was clearer than ever. Lilia’s gesture wasn’t just about giving her something physical—it was about offering her the same comfort and reassurance that stone had provided all those years ago. It was as if Lilia was telling her, once more, that wherever Rio went, whatever step she took, she would always have somewhere to go back to. And that, in itself, was a constant she could hold onto.

 

“I’ll keep it with me,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “Thank you, Lilia. For everything.”

 

Lilia nodded, her smile gentle and knowing. “You don’t need to thank me, my sweet sweet girl. You’ve always had a place in my heart. And now, you’re finding a place in someone else’s, too. I’m proud of you.”

 

As Rio slipped the stone into her pocket, she felt a sense of calm wash over her. No matter where life took her, she would always have Lilia’s love and belief in her. And she hoped that would be enough to help her take the leap forward when the time came.

 

 

Two days later, Rio found herself standing in Agatha’s doorway that evening, her favorite plant cradled carefully in her arms. It was a medium, potted fern with delicate fronds that she had nurtured for years. She wasn’t sure why she felt compelled to bring it with her, but something about it felt like a way of testing the waters, a small but significant gesture that spoke louder than words.

 

Agatha opened the door, her usual confident air softening slightly when she saw the plant in Rio’s hands. For a moment, she raised an eyebrow, her lips curling into a grin she couldn’t hide.

 

“Is this… a housewarming gift?” Agatha teased, her voice light, though there was a flicker of something else in her eyes—a quiet amusement, and hope, as though she knew exactly what this meant.

 

Rio smirked, her lips twitching as she replied, “I thought I’d bring something familiar. You know, to test the waters.” Her words were playful, but she couldn’t entirely mask the vulnerability beneath them. The act of bringing her plant was small, but it felt like a step. She wanted to see if she could envision her life here, if this space—this home—was one she could fit into.

 

Agatha’s grin widened as she stepped aside, letting Rio into the house. She glanced down at the plant with a nod of approval. “I see you’ve decided to bring the plant,” she said, her voice softer now, as though the humor was melting away to something deeper.

 

Rio shrugged, though the movement felt almost shy. “It’s the one I’ve had the longest,” she explained, carefully setting the pot down on a small table near the window. “It’s like a little piece of home for me.”

 

Agatha watched Rio’s movements closely, her smile never quite fading. “Well, it certainly looks like it belongs here already,” she said, a touch of affection in her voice. She stepped closer, her gaze lingering on the plant before circling Rio’s body from behind with her arms and resting her chin on the younger’s woman shoulder.

 

For a moment, neither of them spoke. Agatha’s expression softened, her lips parting slightly as she hugged Rio with something tender—an unspoken understanding. Then she tilted her head, her grin returning, this time with a little more warmth.

 

“You know, I think this is a sign,” Agatha said quietly, her tone almost playful again. “Maybe you’re starting to test more than just the waters.”

 

Rio blinked, a flutter of nervous excitement stirring in her chest. She glanced at the fern, then back at Agatha, her heart beating a little faster. It wasn’t just about the plant. It was about the possibility of moving in, of fitting into Agatha and Nicky’s world in a deeper, more permanent way.

 

“Maybe I am,” Rio admitted, her voice quieter now, almost uncertain.

 

Agatha smiled, tightening her hold, her hands covering Rio’s with a softness that made Rio’s heart skip a beat. “Well, I’m glad you’re testing it here,” she said, her words laced with a subtle warmth. “Because this house? It feels more like homewith you in it.”

 

The weight of Agatha’s words sank in, and Rio felt a wave of emotion rise in her chest. She hadn’t expected the simple act of bringing her plant to be so charged with meaning, but somehow, it was. Maybe it was a small step, but it felt like the beginning of something bigger, something that could grow just as naturally as the plants she tended so carefully.

 

Agatha, sensing the quiet shift in the room, gave her a soft smile, her eyes filled with understanding. “Take your time,” she added, her voice low and reassuring. “But just know, the waters you’re testing don’t have to be cold and stormy. They can be calm and warm too.”

 

Rio swallowed the lump in her throat and nodded, her heart a little lighter. The plant was a small thing—but it felt like a bridge, a way of making the first step without rushing. 

 

As Rio stepped back from the table, admiring her plant in its new spot, Nicky suddenly appeared beside her, eyes wide with excitement. Without hesitation, he planted himself next to the fern, his tiny hands reaching out to gently touch the leaves as if he had been given the most important task in the world.

 

“It can be my job too, right?” he asked eagerly, his voice bright and full of pride. He glanced up at Agatha and Rio for confirmation, clearly eager to prove that he could handle this responsibility.

 

Rio, watching with a knowing smile, nodded. “You’ve got it, kiddo. Liliage is yours to take care of now, when I’m not here.” She ruffled Nicky’s hair, her voice warm and encouraging. “Just remember, you have to water her every day.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but smile at the sight of Nicky’s enthusiasm. There was something about seeing him so excited, so proud of his new “job,” that struck her deeply. She hadn’t expected it, but seeing him this happy with something as simple as taking care of a plant made her heart swell. The idea of this little creature becoming part of her daily life, part of her routine, felt unexpectedly meaningful.

 

Agatha met her gaze, the tenderness in her eyes unmistakable. “I think Nicky’s going to be very good at this,” she said, her voice warm with pride.

 

Rio nodded slowly, a quiet smile tugging at her lips as she looked back at Nicky, who was now chattering away excitedly about all the things he was going to do to take care of the plant. She felt a gentle pull in her chest—something she couldn’t quite explain, but something that made her want to say yes, even if just to this small, simple beginning.

 

“Maybe I’ll bring over a few more,” Rio said softly, more to herself than to anyone else. Maybe this could work. Maybe it was time to let her roots grow somewhere new.

 

Nicky’s excited voice cut through the moment, his face lighting up as he turned to Agatha with wide eyes. “I want a plant in my room, too!” he declared, his enthusiasm contagious. “A big one, like the ones in Rio’s apartment!”

 

Agatha, who had been watching the exchange between Rio and Nicky with a soft smile, chuckled at the request. “Well, if you really think you can take care of it, I suppose we could find room for a plant in your room,” she said, her tone playful, though there was a hint of fondness in her voice. She ruffled his hair again, clearly proud of his newfound sense of responsibility.

 

Nicky bounced on his heels, his hands clasped together in a gesture of excitement. “I can totally take care of it! I’ll water it every day like Liliage!” His face was beaming with determination, and it was clear that the idea of having his very own plant was thrilling to him.

 

Rio watched the exchange with a quiet smile, feeling a warmth spread through her chest. Nicky’s enthusiasm was impossible to resist. She could already imagine him taking care of his own little plant in his room, much like he’d promised to care for the fern. The thought of him growing up with a little green companion to look after made her heart flutter. She could picture Agatha’s house full of life—both from the people who lived there and the plants that would thrive in every room.

 

“That sounds like a great idea,” Rio said, her voice soft but full of affection. “Plants make any room feel more… alive, don’t you think?” Her gaze lingered on Nicky, who was already imagining the perfect spot for his new plant.

 

Agatha nodded, her eyes meeting Rio’s with a quiet smile. “They really do. And I think Nicky would make a great plant parent,” she added, her tone full of pride.

 

Rio’s smile deepened, and for a moment, she let herself imagine it all. Nicky’s plant sitting proudly in his room, thriving under his care, just like the fern under hers. And her plants, scattered around Agatha’s home, growing and changing alongside the little family they were becoming. It felt like a natural progression—a way to blend her life into theirs, piece by piece.

 

“Maybe we should start with a small plant for Nicky’s room first,” Rio said, her smile soft and warm. “To get him used to take care of one. And then he can graduate to a nice big one, just like you said.”

 

Agatha’s smile deepened, and she nodded in agreement. “Sounds perfect.”

 

 

A few days later, Rio found herself standing in the doorway of Agatha’s house, the weight of her decision settling in her chest. Her heart beat a little faster as she looked at Agatha, who was already at the door waiting for her, a soft smile playing at the corners of her lips.

 

Nicky was playing in the living room, humming to himself as he carefully tended to his new own fern, his concentration almost comical for someone so young.

 

Agatha’s eyes immediately flickered to Rio, a question in her gaze, and Rio felt a warmth spread through her as she took a deep breath, stepping across the threshold.

 

“I’ve thought about it,” Rio began, her voice steady, though there was a nervousness bubbling just beneath the surface. “And… I think I’m ready.”

 

Agatha’s eyes widened in surprise and then, before Rio could finish, Agatha was across the room in a heartbeat, her arms wrapping around Rio in a tight embrace. “Really?” Agatha’s voice in her ear was full of disbelief and joy, as though she couldn’t quite believe the words she was hearing.

 

Rio nodded, her lips curving into a small but genuine smile. “I’ve made up my mind. I’ll move in. With you and Nicky.”

 

Agatha let out a soft laugh of relief, her grip tightening around Rio as she pulled her in closer. “I’m so happy,” she murmured against Rio’s hair, her voice full of emotion. “You don’t even know how much this means to me.”

 

Rio could feel the warmth of Agatha’s embrace, the weight of the moment sinking in. She had expected to feel more uncertainty, but instead, she felt a calm certainty that this was the right choice. This was where she was meant to be.

 

Before she could say anything else, Nicky appeared at her side, his small face alight with excitement, as he had apparently heard the whole thing. He looked up at her with wide eyes, his voice filled with enthusiasm.

 

“Does this mean you’re gonna live here for real now?” he asked, his voice almost too big for his little body.

 

Rio leaned down to meet his gaze, her smile widening as she nodded. “Yeah, kiddo. I’m moving in. For real.”

 

Nicky’s face broke into a grin so wide it nearly took over his whole face. He threw his arms around her in a hug, nearly knocking her over with the force of it. “I’m gonna help you move all your stuff! I’m big and strong now, you know!” he said proudly, puffing out his chest in the most endearing way.

 

Rio laughed softly, feeling a warmht she hadn’t expected. “I’m sure you are,” she teased, ruffling his hair affectionately. “I’ll need all the help I can get.”

 

Agatha, who had been watching with a quiet smile, couldn’t help herself anymore. She leaned in and kissed Rio—quick, soft, and full of happiness. Then she kissed her again, this time a little longer, a little more lingering, as if she couldn’t quite believe it was really happening.

 

“I’m so happy,” Agatha whispered, pulling back slightly but still holding Rio close. “You’re going to be such a big part of our world, I can’t wait for everything to change with you here.”

 

Rio felt a smile tug at her lips as she held Agatha’s gaze. “Me too,” she said softly. “I think it’s going to be really good.”

 

As Nicky bounded off to grab a toy truck for their “moving mission,” Agatha held Rio for a moment longer, her arms tight around her. There was no need for words. Both of them felt it—the quiet joy of a new chapter starting, the promise of growth and love, not just for Rio, but for all three of them.

 

“I can’t believe it,” Agatha murmured, more to herself than to Rio. “You’re here. You’re really here.”

 

“And I’m here to stay, my love.”

 

And as Rio stood there, enveloped in Agatha’s warmth and Nicky’s boundless excitement, she realized that she felt like she belonged in a way she hadn’t before. This house, this life—this was where she was meant to be.

 

 

Two weeks later, the house was a whirlwind of boxes, packing tape, and the unmistakable sounds of laughter. Rio stood in the middle of her new home—Agatha’s house—her hands on her hips as she surveyed the chaos with a grin that wouldn’t seem to fade. It was a mess, but it was a happy mess, and every corner of the house buzzed with the energy of change.

 

Jen was busy directing traffic, her voice carrying over the din. “This box says books on it, Rio. It weighs about ten thousand pounds. Where do you want it?” she called, balancing the box precariously in her arms.

 

“Bookshelves in the living room!” Rio replied, her voice bright with excitement.

 

Alice followed closely behind, carrying another box labeled ballet stuff. “I’m just saying, if you don’t put these pointe shoes on display somewhere, I’ll riot,” she teased, setting the box down near the couch.

 

Lilia, the calmest of the group, was in the kitchen unpacking dishes and humming softly. She looked over at Rio and gave her a warm smile. “It’s coming together beautifully,” she said. “Feels like you’ve been here forever already, sweet girl.”

 

Rio chuckled, her heart swelling as she looked at her three helpers. “That’s because you three are working your butts off while I stand here pretending to supervise,” she joked, brushing a stray lock of hair out of her face.

 

Meanwhile, Nicky darted around the house like a whirlwind, proudly carrying one of Rio’s smaller plants to his room. “I’m putting this one right next to my bed!” he announced, his voice full of determination. “So it can grow big and strong like me.”

 

Agatha, leaning against the doorway with her arms crossed, watched the scene unfold with a soft, contented smile. Her house was fuller now—not just with stuff, but with life. She caught Rio’s eye and gave her a look that said everything she couldn’t quite put into words in that moment: Thank you for choosing us.

 

When the last box had been unpacked and the furniture rearranged for the third time, the group gathered in the living room to celebrate. Alice popped open a bottle of sparkling cider while Jen handed out glasses, and Nicky insisted on toasting with everyone, even if his cup was just juice.

 

“To Rio,” Agatha said, raising her glass. Her voice was steady, but there was an unmistakable emotion in her tone. “And to the chaos she brings into our lives—in the best way possible.”

 

Rio laughed, the sound bright and genuine, as everyone clinked their glasses together. “To Agatha,” she replied, glancing at her with a soft smile. “For giving me a home, in every sense of the word.”

 

“And to me,” Nicky added, eagerly, clinking his little plastic glass with everyone’s, making all the women present laugh.

 

As the evening wound down and their friends left, the house grew quieter. Agatha, Rio and Nicky sat together on the couch, their legs tangled, a blanket thrown on them. Around them, the house was a blend of both their lives now—Agatha’s tastefully decorated living room filled with touches of Rio’s personality: plants in every corner, books piled high, and a round smooth blue stone on the windowsill.

 

Agatha reached out, intertwining her fingers with Rio’s over Nicky’s sleeping form. “How does it feel?” she asked softly, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

Rio looked around the room, at Nicky sleeping peacefully with his head on her lap , at their hands clasped together, at the life they were building. “Like I’ve never been happier,” she said simply, leaning her head against Agatha’s shoulder.

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to the top of her head, her heart full. “Good,” she murmured. “Because we couldn’t be happier to have you here.”

 

And in that moment, as the house settled into its new rhythm, Rio knew she was exactly where she belonged.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

As always, comments are my greatest gift!

Teased and Treasured

Chapter Notes

Hello, hello dears, sorry for the lack of chapter yesterday, I fell asleep so early hahah ! but here it is! so enjoy :)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

We are only undeceived

Of that which, deceiving, could no longer harm.

In the middle, not only in the middle of the way

But all the way, in a dark wood, in a bramble,

On the edge of a grimpen, where is no secure foothold,

And menaced by monsters, fancy lights,

Risking enchantment.

 

         (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

It was the middle of a long day when Rio, Agatha, Alice, and Jen gathered at a cozy café just off campus for one of their rare double dates. After Alice had spilled the news about Rio and Agatha’s relationship—and that Jen had even helped Rio move in a week earlier—Jen had been completely on board with the idea. In fact, she’d been the one to suggest a first double date. Rio had hesitated at first, knowing her best friends’ tendency to tease, but eventually, she had agreed. What started as a tentative outing had now become a regular occurrence. Despite the age gap, Agatha had seamlessly integrated into their friend group, much to Rio’s delight.

 

Alice and Jen were already sitting in their usual booth at the end of the café, talking lightly, Alice almost on Jen’s lap, when they spotted Rio entering, Agatha a few steps behind, rummaging in the bag hanging from her shoulder.

 

“Ah, here comes Rio,” Alice said with a smirk, tapping her mug against Jen’s. “Bet she’s fresh from another riveting morning with Dr. Harkness. Care to share, Rio? How’s living in sin with the university's finest intellectual heartthrob treating you?”

 

Rio froze when she reached the table, her eyes wide as a blush crept up her neck. “I—what?” she spluttered, caught completely off guard. “I don’t—”

 

Jen joined in, grinning. “Oh, come on. We all know you two can’t keep your hands off each other. What’s it like being the University’s secret reigning romantic soap opera?”

 

Rio’s face turned a deeper shade of red, her mouth opening and closing like a fish out of water. She turned to Agatha, who was following casually, her hand on Rio’s waist, while the other was still deep in her bag, seemingly unbothered.

 

“Agatha!” Rio hissed, desperate for backup. “Say something!”

 

Agatha finally looked up, raising an eyebrow at the group. For a moment, she seemed ready to offer some diplomatic response, her lips parting with what looked like mild exasperation. But then, Rio saw it—that mischievous glint in her eyes, the slow curve of her lips as a sly smile took over.

 

“Oh, should I?” Agatha drawled, snapping her bag closed with deliberate finality. Her hand slid from Rio’s waist to the small of her back, pulling her just slightly closer. “Well, if you really want to know…”

 

“Agatha, no,” Rio groaned, her hands flying to her cheeks as she realized what was coming.

 

Agatha ignored her entirely, leaning back in her chair with the air of someone settling in for a performance. “This morning was… enchanting, to say the least. Isn’t that right, darling?” She shot Rio a wink that made her want to evaporate on the spot.

 

“Agatha, stop!” Rio squeaked, her voice muffled as she buried her face in her hands.

 

But Agatha was on a roll now, leaning back in her chair with an air of mock pensiveness. “Let’s see. There was the part where she insisted on wearing that silk robe I adore and it has that opening down the front—”

 

Alice’s jaw dropped, and Jen’s laugh turned into a poorly stifled cough as Rio practically shrieked, “Oh my god, don’t!”

 

Agatha didn’t miss a beat, her smirk growing wider. “And then, of course, I had to help her with her hair—she couldn’t decide between a braid or leaving it loose, and, well…” She trailed off, tapping her chin theatrically. “We might have gotten a little distracted. Come to think of it, I don’t think we ever made it to breakfast.”

 

Alice’s jaw dropped as she burst out laughing. “Okay, okay, too much information! I wasn’t ready for that!”

 

Jen was in stitches, clutching her stomach. “You’re killing me! Agatha, I take it back. You win.” She then turned to Rio. “You poor thing. You thought she’d save you? She’s throwing you right under the bus!”

 

Rio, face now a deep crimson, groaned into her hands. “I can’t believe this is my life,” she muttered, her voice muffled by sheer embarrassment.

 

Agatha leaned down, her lips brushing against Rio’s ear as she murmured just loud enough for the table to hear, “Oh, darling, this is just the beginning.”

 

Rio was practically vibrating with embarrassment, her face buried in her hands. “I can’t believe you,” she mumbled, though the corners of her lips twitched despite herself.

 

Agatha leaned over, pulling Rio’s hands gently away from her face and planting a soft kiss on her knuckles. “Oh, come now, darling. You know you love me.”

 

Rio groaned dramatically, but the way she leaned into Agatha’s touch betrayed her true feelings.

 

Alice wiped a tear from her eye, shaking her head. “Remind me never to challenge Agatha again. She’s terrifying when she’s in full unashamed girlfriend mode.”

 

Agatha smirked, her gaze full of mischief. “You should have known better, Alice. No one teases my Rio about this but me.”

 

The room erupted in laughter, and though Rio was still blushing furiously, she couldn’t help but laugh too. She knew what she was signing up for with those people—embarrassment and all.

 

Rio stretched her arms above her head, letting out a soft groan of relief, her head lolling against her partner’s shoulder.

 

“I can’t wait to take a bath tonight after this,” Rio said dreamily, her voice carrying the wistful tone of someone already imagining the warm, relaxing water.

 

The room didn’t just fall silent—it seemed to hold its collective breath. Then, like clockwork, Alice struck.

 

“Alright, that’s enough,” she said with a wicked grin, leaning forward as she tapped her fingers against the table. “We do not need to know what the two of you are planning to do in the bath. Keep it PG, Vidal.” She wiggled her eyebrows for good measure.

 

Rio’s face immediately turned bright red again, her hands flying back to her cheeks as she spluttered, “Come on, not again! That’s not—I didn’t mean— oh my god, Alice, seriously?”

 

Agatha, never one to shy away from another playful challenge, raised an eyebrow and leaned in closer to Rio, her lips brushing the shell of her ear as she whispered, “Well, I know exactly what’s going to happen when we’re alone tonight, darling.” Her voice was low, teasing, and filled with an affectionate warmth.

 

Rio practically choked on her own breath, her face somehow managing to turn an even deeper shade of red as she buried it in Agatha’s shoulder with a mortified groan. “Agatha!”

 

Alice, thoroughly delighted, cackled as she leaned back in her seat, clutching her chest. “Oh my god, Agatha! I was joking, but now you’ve gone and confirmed it!”

 

Jen, thoroughly enjoying the scene, leaned forward with a grin. “Looks like Agatha is in charge of bath time,” she remarked, clearly delighted by Rio’s flustered reaction.

 

Agatha, however, was completely unfazed. A slow, wicked grin spread across her face as she wrapped an arm around Rio’s shoulders, pulling her out from behind her. “Oh, come now, ladies,” she purred, her voice dripping with mock offense. “If we really wanted to scandalize you, we’d give you details about what actually happened this morning.”

 

“Oh, darling,” Agatha teased, her grin downright wicked as her fingers grazed the back of Rio’s neck. “You started this with that little bath comment. I’m just playing along.”

 

Alice laughed so hard she almost knocked over her mug. “This is better than I ever could’ve hoped for!” She turned to Jen, who was barely hiding her smirk. “Agatha’s got no chill whatsoever. Poor Rio doesn’t stand a chance.”

 

Agatha leaned down, her lips brushing against Rio’s temple in a teasingly affectionate gesture. “Oh, but isn’t she adorable when she’s flustered?”

 

Rio muttered something incoherent into her hands, but the telltale twitch of her lips betrayed her amusement despite her embarrassment.

 

Jen, sipping her coffee from the corner, raised an eyebrow and added dryly, “Honestly, I think I preferred it when Rio’s comments didn’t make sense and she was just fawning over you. At least we didn’t have to imagine…” She trailed off, a smirk tugging at the corner of her mouth, letting the implication hang in the air.

 

Agatha chuckled, unfazed, while Rio peeked up just enough to glare halfheartedly at the group. “I hate all of you,” she grumbled, but her tone was more resigned than angry, laced with begrudging fondness.

 

“Oh, maybe,” Alice said with a shrug, raising her coffee like a toast, “but you keep coming back for more, so who’s the real winner here?”

 

Rio sighed dramatically, leaning into Agatha with a defeated groan. “Unfortunately, I’m stuck with you lunatics. But I really hate you all right now,” she added, her voice dripping with mock despair.

 

The group’s laughter filled the café as the conversation shifted. Agatha leaned down, her voice low and meant only for Rio. “Don’t worry, my love,” she whispered, her tone turning from playful to irresistibly soft. “I’ll make sure you get that bath tonight, no interruptions… unless, of course, you want them.”

 

Rio swatted at her lightly, but the smile on her face lingered. Despite the teasing, there was no place she’d rather be than right there with the love of her life and the eccentric group of women they called friends.

 

 

Indeed, the bathroom at Agatha’s house had become one of their sanctuaries—a small space where time seemed to slow down, and the world outside felt distant, once Nicky was in bed, asleep in the world of dreams, probably filled with dragons, princesses and a big river ready to brave every obstacle in its path. It wasn’t uncommon for one of them to take a bath, the warm water soothing her muscles, while the other sat nearby, usually on the edge of the tub, or on the floor, lost in quiet moments of companionship.

 

Agatha, in particular, loved these moments. She’d lean over the side of the tub, her fingers gently swirling in the warm water, creating small ripples as she watched Rio relax. Rio would often close her eyes, leaning back with her head against the edge of the tub, letting the heat of the water melt away the tension of the day.

 

Agatha would talk about anything and everything, sometimes just to fill the space with her voice, sometimes because she loved hearing Rio’s thoughts. She could speak about anything from mundane details—what they’d have for dinner or what had happened in class, or at the faculty meeting that day—to more meaningful reflections about life, about them, or about memories they were starting to share.

 

And Rio would listen, half-distracted but always there, sometimes adding her own thoughts between the bubbles, her voice soft but steady. She’d smile occasionally, her lips curving just a little, or her eyes would open slightly, meeting Agatha’s gaze, the connection deepening with every word.

 

Sometimes Agatha would share her thoughts about the things that mattered most to her—like how much Rio’s smile could light up a room, or how she loved the way Rio’s energy filled her house and drew Nicky’s joy out. And Rio, her eyes half-lidded with the warmth of the water, would nod slowly, as if contemplating Agatha’s words before replying with something equally thoughtful.

 

The conversations would meander like the water itself, flowing gently from one topic to another. Sometimes it would be about books they were reading, or a song that was stuck in Rio’s head. Sometimes, it was quiet and calm, filled with small gestures—Agatha reaching out to brush a strand of hair from Rio’s face, or Rio giving her hand a soft squeeze, reassuring and gentle.

 

Even when their conversations wandered into silence, there was a kind of comfort in just being together—no words necessary, just the shared space and the knowledge that they had each other. And occasionally, Agatha would playfully splash Rio with the water, making her laugh, or she would rest her chin on the edge of the tub, her eyes soft with affection.

 

These moments were precious, intimate, and easy. In these quiet times, they didn’t have to be anything more than simply Agatha and Rio—no masks, no distractions, no role to play, just two people who knew each other more and more deeply every day, with a kind of love that didn’t need to be spoken out loud to be understood. And in those moments, Agatha couldn’t help but think to herself that there was no place she’d rather be than beside Rio, swirling her hand in the water, talking about anything and everything, knowing their boy was safe and sound in his room a few doors over.

 

 

Saturday morning light filtered softly through the curtains, casting a gentle glow over the room. Agatha stirred, slowly waking from a restful sleep, and immediately noticed the warm, familiar weight of Rio beside her. For a moment, she thought it was just the two of them, nestled together, until she felt the small body pressing just below Rio’s head.

 

She turned her head and found Nicky, his small frame tucked between them, his hair messy and his face peaceful in sleep. He must have snuck in during the night, wriggling his way between them, not a sound or movement to disturb them. Agatha smiled softly, her heart swelling with affection as she observed the tender scene.

 

Rio was still deeply asleep, her breath soft and even, her hair fanned out on the pillow like a dark halo, and an arm lightly draped over Nicky’s form. Agatha couldn’t help but feel a wave of love and contentment, watching the two people she adored so much—so completely, so fiercely—so close to her. The soft rhythm of their breathing, the warmth of their bodies, it all felt like the perfect slice of peace.

 

Agatha gently moved her arm, careful not to wake either of them, and brushed a lock of Rio’s hair from her face. She smiled, thinking about how much had changed in the past few months. Their relationship had come with its challenges, its hurdles, but mornings like this made it all feel more than worth it. It was a simple kind of happiness, the three of them tangled together in the warmth of their shared space, of their growing family.

 

She placed a soft kiss on Rio’s temple, then gently leaned over and kissed Nicky’s forehead too. Both of them stirred slightly but remained asleep, and Agatha’s heart swelled with a love she never thought she’d find. This—this soft, ordinary morning—was everything she wanted.

 

As she lay back down, careful not to disturb the peaceful cocoon they had made, Agatha closed her eyes, savoring the quiet moment. She never wanted to let go of it.

 

Nicky shifted slightly, a soft murmur escaping his lips as he slowly woke. He blinked a few times, rubbing his eyes sleepily before he looked up at Agatha, his small face lighting up in a sleepy smile when he realized where he was.

 

“Good morning Mama,” he whispered, his voice still groggy with sleep, but full of warmth.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her heart lifting at the sight of him. “Good morning, sweetheart,” she whispered back, her voice still low to keep from waking Rio.

 

Nicky yawned and stretched, his little arms flailing as he untangled himself from Rio’s arm and  pushed himself up slightly, still nestled between them. His eyes flicked to Rio, still sound asleep beside them, and he smiled. “Rio’s still sleeping?”

 

“She is,” Agatha said, running a gentle hand through Nicky’s messy hair. “But she’ll wake up soon enough.”

 

Nicky gave a nod, clearly content with this arrangement. He nestled back into the warmth between Agatha and Rio, looking up at Agatha with a serious expression. “Can we stay like this forever?”

 

The sweetness of the question caught Agatha off guard for a moment. Her heart clenched in that familiar, protective way it always did when Nicky spoke so openly about his feelings. She kissed the top of his head. “I would love that, Nicky. But for now, let’s just enjoy this moment.”

 

Nicky nodded again, his small smile returning. He reached up, wrapping his arms around Agatha in a gentle hug, his warmth and affection filling the quiet space between them.

 

Agatha sighed contentedly, holding him close for a moment. Agatha couldn’t help but smile softly, feeling her son against her and watching Rio sleep, feeling an overwhelming surge of love for the two people in her life. The bond between them, though simple, was everything Agatha had never realized she needed.

 

As Nicky snuggled closer, still content to be in the peaceful embrace of his makeshift family, Agatha let herself relax, knowing that these moments—these small, soft mornings—were more than enough to make everything feel right.

 

Rio stirred slowly, the warmth of Nicky and Agatha surrounding her making it hard to leave the peaceful bubble of sleep. She blinked a few times, her eyes adjusting to the soft light streaming through the curtains. She felt Nicky’s small body pressed against hers, and Agatha’s presence beside her, their closeness making everything feel so… right.

 

She shifted, trying to stretch, but the moment she moved, Nicky looked up at her with wide, excited eyes.

 

“Rio!” he whispered, a grin spreading across his face. “You’re awake!”

 

Rio blinked a few more times, taking in her surroundings as her mind caught up with the morning. Nicky was nestled between her and Agatha, and it took a few seconds for her to fully register that she had slept through the night with both of them—something so simple, yet so beautiful.

 

“Good morning, little sunshine,” Rio murmured, her voice soft and warm as she reached out to ruffle Nicky’s hair. She was still half-dazed from sleep, but she couldn’t help the smile tugging at her lips.

 

Nicky giggled and wriggled a little closer, clearly thrilled to have both of them awake. “Rio, did you know you were purring?” he asked, trying to hold back laughter.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, a playful glint in her eyes as she shot Agatha a teasing look. “I don’t purr,” she said dramatically, though she knew better.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, looking at both of them with a tenderness that made Rio’s heart swell. “Oh, she definitely does,” Agatha teased gently, giving Rio a knowing smile. “You sounded like a little cat.”

 

Rio let out a mock gasp, dramatically clutching her chest. “A cat? Really?”

 

“Yep.” Agatha nodded, her lips curling into a fond smile as she leaned in to give Rio a soft kiss on the nose. “But don’t worry, it is really cute and I still love you.”

 

Rio’s smile softened, the playfulness fading into something deeper, more sincere. She kissed Agatha back on the cheek, feeling the warmth of her affection fill the space between them.

 

Nicky giggled, clearly pleased with the exchange, before he leaned up and gave Rio a big hug, draping himself over her chest. “And I love you too, Rio.”

 

Rio wrapped her arms around him, her heart swelling as she held him close. “I love you too, Nicky,” she murmured, her voice thick with emotion.

 

Agatha’s gaze lingered on the two of them, a soft, content smile playing on her lips as she watched Rio and Nicky together. It felt like everything was falling into place, the weight of the last few months melting away as she simply basked in this quiet, tender moment with the two people she loved most in the world.

 

 

Later that morning, Rio helped Nicky get dressed for his dance class, carefully pulling on his little sneakers and making sure his dance clothes were all set. He was bouncing around with excitement, his enthusiasm contagious.

 

“Are you ready for class?” Rio asked, smiling down at him as she finished adjusting his sleeves.

 

“Yes! I can’t wait to see my friends!” Nicky replied, practically vibrating with energy.

 

Rio chuckled softly, tying his shoes. “Alright, you go ahead and grab your bag while I get my stuff.” Nicky immediately ran off to grab his dance bag from the corner of the room, but Rio’s gaze lingered on him for a moment. Seeing Nicky so happy, excited for his class, and knowing that he was thriving here made everything feel right.

 

After gathering her own things, she turned to Nicky, who was already bouncing at the door.

 

“Ready to go?” she asked.

 

“Yes!” he squealed, and they both headed out the door, laughing as Nicky tried to race her to the door.

 

Agatha was already seated in the living room, her stack of papers in front of her as she graded, though her mind wandered as she watched Rio and Nicky get ready. She smiled to herself as she listened to Nicky’s excited chatter and Rio’s laughter trailing behind them.

 

Before they left for the dance center, Rio paused by the door, a warm smile spreading across her face as she looked at Agatha. Nicky had already raced off, his excitement palpable, but Rio lingered for a moment.

 

“Hey,” she said, her voice soft but full of sincerity.

 

Agatha glanced up from the papers she was grading, her expression warm. “What’s up?”

 

Rio’s smile widened, and she stepped closer to Agatha. “I just… I just wanted to say thank you for trusting me with Nicky, for letting me take him to class today without hesitation.”

 

Agatha blinked in surprise but then gave a small, knowing smile. “Of course,” she said, her voice steady and full of conviction. “Why wouldn’t I trust you? You’ve always been so good with him and he loves you. You’re family to him already.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at her words. It meant so much to her that Agatha had this unwavering trust in her. It wasn’t just about taking care of Nicky for the day; it was about being part of something bigger, something that felt real and permanent. She knew Agatha’s love for Nicky ran deeper than anything else, and the fact that she could see Rio as a part of that made her feel even more connected to both of them.

 

“That means a lot to me,” Rio said, her voice thick with emotion. She quickly wiped away a small tear that threatened to fall, not wanting to get too sentimental before she had to leave.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, her lips curling into a reassuring smile. “I know you’ll take care of him. You always do.”

 

Rio nodded, feeling the weight of Agatha’s trust settle into her chest. “I won’t let you down, I promise.”

 

Agatha reached over, giving Rio a gentle squeeze on her shoulder. “I know you won’t.” She let out a small laugh. “Now, go on. Get Nicky ad yourself to class, and have a good time.”

 

Rio smiled brightly, nodding. “I will. I’ll see you later.”

 

“Have a good class, my loves!” Agatha called out as Rio opened the door.

 

“Thanks Mama, I’ll see you later!” Nicky smiled, waving before following Rio out.

 

When they arrived at the dance center, Rio walked with Nicky to his class. She could feel the familiar buzz of energy in the air—the hum of feet hitting the floor, the chatter of parents and children, the rush of anticipation as the kids prepared for their lessons. It was a place Rio had always loved, and it felt like home.

 

As they entered the studio, she gave Nicky a gentle nudge. “You go on ahead and find your friends, okay? I need to go to the office real quick, but I’ll be there a three minutes.”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up. “I’ll be the best dancer today, promise, you’ll see!” he called back to her before running off to join his class.

 

Rio smiled as she watched him, her heart swelling with pride. It was clear he was thriving in this world of dance. It had always been a passion for her, and now she got to share it with him in a way that was meaningful.

 

After ensuring Nicky was settled, Rio made her way to the main office to retrieve her roll call papers and the CD she used for her class. With everything in hand, she headed to the studio, where Nicky was already animatedly chatting with his little friends. When he spotted her, he waved excitedly, and Rio returned the gesture with a bright smile.

 

As students began trickling in, Rio moved to the front of the room, radiating energy and ready to teach. The day promised to be a busy one, but this was where Rio thrived—sharing her love of dance with others, the studio alive with movement and music. Having Nicky close by made it all the more meaningful; the way his wide eyes followed her every move filled her heart with joy. Teaching him alongside her other students was a privilege that made her work feel even more special.

 

Meanwhile, at home, Agatha was surrounded by papers, grading the assignments of her students. She sat back for a moment, rubbing her eyes. It was always a lot of work, but she never minded it—especially not when it gave her time to reflect. She smiled to herself, thinking of Rio and Nicky, and the little family they had started to become. It wasn’t always easy, but it was worth it, and that thought kept her going as she dove back into the work ahead of her.

 

Though they were apart for a few hours, each of them, in their own way, cherished the life they had built, and it was moments like these—small, everyday ones—that made it all feel perfect.

 

 

After dance class, Rio and Nicky made their way to the band’s practice space, a cozy room filled with instruments and the hum of excited energy. Rio couldn’t help but smile as Nicky bounced ahead of her, clearly eager to see what the band was up to. She caught up with him quickly and scooped him up onto her lap as they sat down on the big, plush couch near the drum set.

 

“Okay, kiddo,” Rio said with a grin, adjusting him comfortably in her lap, “This is where the magic happens. You’re going to see how we make music.”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up, his face a picture of wonder as he looked around at the instruments. Alice was strumming her guitar, her head bopping to the rhythm as she warmed up, her keyboard already ready next to her, while Jen was adjusting her bass, preparing for their practice. Both of them spotted Nicky and immediately broke into wide grins.

 

“Hey there, Nicky!” Alice called, giving a playful wave. “You ready to see how it all works?”

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically, bouncing on Rio’s lap. “Yeah! I wanna play the drums like Rio!”

 

Jen chuckled from her spot by the bass. “You’re gonna need some serious skills for that, buddy. But you’ve got time.”

 

Rio laughed along with them, her arms around Nicky protectively as she settled into the rhythm of the room. It felt good to be here, to be able to share this part of her life with Nicky, to let him see her world—her music, her friends, her joy. Alice and Jen made it easy, their affection for Nicky clear as they smiled and teased him, calling him their “little band mascot.”

 

“Maybe one day we can teach you some chords on the guitar,” Alice suggested with a wink.

 

“I’ll teach you how to play the bass,” Jen added, making a few exaggerated plucking motions on her instrument for Nicky to imitate.

 

The room was filled with the laughter and lighthearted banter, and Rio was completely in her element. She felt a deep sense of contentment—this was her life now. And Nicky was becoming part of it in such a natural way. She couldn’t have been prouder.

 

It wasn’t long before Agatha arrived to pick up Nicky, her footsteps soft but steady as she approached the door. She paused for a moment in the doorway, watching the scene unfold. Nicky, perched on Rio’s lap behind the drum set, a pair of drumsticks in his little hands, was laughing at one of Alice’s jokes while Rio playfully mimicked drumming movements, and Jen was encouraging him to keep the rhythm. The sight filled Agatha’s heart in a way she hadn’t quite expected.

 

Her son, so happy, so at ease. And Rio… she was so effortlessly in her element with him. Agatha couldn’t help but feel a small flutter in her chest. Rio was becoming such an important part of their lives, and seeing how naturally she fit into Nicky’s world was enough to make her feel both proud and deeply in love with her.

 

Finally, Agatha cleared her throat, making herself known.

 

“Well, I guess I’ve come to steal my favorite little guy,” Agatha said with a soft smile.

 

Nicky looked up at her, his face lighting up. “Mama! Can I stay and watch them practice?”

 

Agatha smiled, though there was a small hint of hesitation in her eyes. “We’ve got to get home and make dinner. You can come back next time, I promise.”

 

Nicky sighed dramatically, but then grinned. “Okay, okay! But I’m coming back next time for sure!”

 

Rio chuckled and ruffled his hair. “You got it, buddy.”

 

As Nicky reluctantly slid off her lap and bounded toward Agatha, Rio caught her gaze, her heart swelling with love and affection. Agatha, standing in the doorway, was watching them with such a fond expression, her lips curving up in a way that spoke volumes.

 

“I’ll see you tonight?” Rio asked softly, though her tone was filled with that quiet certainty they both shared now.

 

“Of course,” Agatha replied, her voice warm and filled with promise. “When do you think you’ll be home?”

 

The word home still sent butterflies fluttering in Rio’s stomach.

 

As Nicky said his goodbyes, Agatha looked back at Rio one last time before leading him out of the room, and Rio felt a deep sense of contentment settle in her chest. She watched them leave, the sound of Nicky’s voice fading as they walked down the hall, and in that moment, Rio realized just how much she had come to love this little, growing family of theirs.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Thank you so much for all of your lovely comments, they really keep me writing and motivated! I love you all and I love hearing your thoughts.
(Currently writing chapter 39 and a bit stuck on something, but I'm sure I'll find a way to make it work really soon!)

Starry Mugs and Not So Starry Encounters

 

*

*

*

 

Lady, whose shrine stands on the promontory, (…)

Repeat a prayer also on behalf of

Women who have seen their sons or husbands

Setting forth, and not returning:

Figlia del tuo figlio,

Queen of Heaven.

 

              (T.S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The classroom buzzed with the low hum of students filing in, shuffling papers, and exchanging murmured conversations as they prepared for the upcoming lecture. Rio sat in her usual spot in the second row, her books neatly stacked, her pen tapping rhythmically against her notebook. She glanced down at her notes, reviewing a passage she’d underlined the night before, her brow furrowing in concentration.

 

Despite the focus on her studies, she couldn’t ignore the familiar anticipation bubbling in her chest. Agatha’s lectures always left her inspired, the brilliance and passion in her teaching reminding Rio why she’d fallen in love—not just with the subject but with the woman who brought it to life.

 

The door at the back of the room creaked open, and the familiar click of heels echoed softly against the tile floor. Rio didn’t need to look up to know it was Agatha; her imperious presence was unmistakable. Still, she glanced up briefly, catching sight of Agatha as she strode confidently toward the podium at the front of the class, a stack of papers tucked under one arm and her dark hair spilling elegantly over her shoulders.

 

Agatha’s gaze swept over the room, landing for the briefest moment on Rio. It was so quick and subtle that no one else would have noticed, but Rio did. A flicker of warmth danced in Agatha’s expression, gone just as quickly as it appeared, replaced by her usual composed demeanor.

 

Rio’s lips curved into a small, private smile as she looked back down at her notes. It felt strange, almost surreal, to be sitting here like this, a student in Agatha’s class, after everything they’d shared. The quiet mornings in their shared home, the way Agatha’s arms felt around her, the late-night conversations in bed that bled into laughter and kisses—it all felt like a secret world they carried with them into this space.

 

As Agatha began setting up for the lecture, Rio couldn’t help but marvel at the ease with which they navigated these two versions of themselves. Here, in this room, Agatha was Dr. Harkness, the brilliant professor who commanded the respect of her students and colleagues alike. But Rio also knew the woman behind that title—the one who teased her in the kitchen, who pressed soft kisses to her forehead before bed, who wrapped her son in her arms every time they hadn’t seen each other for more than a few hours, and who could make her feel like she was the only person in the world.

 

The class settled down as Agatha cleared her throat, her voice cutting through the chatter with practiced authority. “Good morning, everyone. I hope you’ve all had a chance to review the readings for today. We’ll be diving deeper into the themes we’ve been exploring last week. More specifically, we’ll be exploring how Modernist poetry uses allusions, weaving references to classical literature, mythology, and philosophy into new, complex narratives.”

 

Rio straightened in her seat, pen poised over her notebook, ready to absorb every word. But even as she focused on the lecture, there was a quiet thrill in the knowledge that when the class was over, she’d go home—not just to her own space but to the life they were building together. In this moment, sitting among her peers, she felt the weight of her love for Agatha settle in her chest, steady and sure.

 

As the lecture unfolded, Rio’s attention flicked between her notes and Agatha, who was pacing the front of the room with her usual poise. Agatha gestured subtly as she spoke, her words weaving a compelling narrative around the day’s topic. She held a mug in one hand, taking small sips during moments of pause—a common sight during her lectures.

 

But this time, something caught Rio’s eye. The mug.

 

Her mug.

 

The realization settled slowly, the green ceramic adorned with delicate golden stars glinting under the classroom lights. Rio’s heart stuttered in her chest. It was unmistakable—the same mug she’d bought for herself months ago, a little treat to celebrate finishing the first chapter of her thesis. She hadn’t thought much of it at the time, just a pretty, whimsical thing she’d picked up during a walk. At home, she’d noticed Agatha reaching for it more and more often, to the point where it had practically become her favorite.

 

But now, seeing Agatha carrying it here, in the classroom, amidst her strong and authoritative presence, stirred something deep within Rio.

 

It was such a small thing, so subtle that no one else would think twice about it. Yet, to Rio, it was a quiet declaration, a tiny fragment of their shared life that Agatha carried into this separate world. It made her feel… known. Seen. Loved.

 

Her chest swelled with warmth, the kind of glow that started deep in her heart and spread outward, curling into her fingertips and toes. There was something profoundly tender about this small gesture, about Agatha keeping this little piece of their home close to her even while she stood here, embodying the image of professionalism and power.

 

Rio’s lips twitched into a soft, barely-there smile as she watched Agatha set the mug down on the edge of the desk, her voice steady and rich as she fielded a question from a student in the back row.

 

She leaned her chin into her hand, letting her gaze linger for a moment longer. The duality of Agatha never failed to captivate her—the composed professor with sharp wit and imposing presence, and the woman who curled around Rio at night, who teased her with soft kisses and held her so tenderly when the world felt heavy.

 

And now, the woman who carried a little green mug with golden stars, like a secret tether to the life they were building together, a link between the two worlds they still tried to keep separated.

 

Rio’s heart felt impossibly full. She ducked her head, pretending to refocus on her notes, but her pen didn’t move. She was too busy holding onto the quiet, fuzzy warmth that had bloomed inside her, savoring the sweetness of this moment that was theirs alone to understand.

 

As the lecture continued, Rio dutifully kept her eyes on Agatha, though her notes lay forgotten in front of her. Agatha moved seamlessly through her points, the cadence of her voice steady and confident, with only the occasional pause for a sip from her mug.

 

It wasn’t until halfway through the lecture, as a small wave of laughter rippled through the class at one of Agatha’s sharp-witted comments, that Agatha’s gaze flicked up—and it was fixed directly on her.

 

Her heart stuttered.

 

For a moment, Rio thought she was imagining it. Agatha was always composed, always able to divide her personal and professional lives like a master conductor. But the slight curve at the corner of her lips and the way her sharp eyes softened left no doubt.

 

Still watching Rio, Agatha raised her mug slightly, holding it in her hand with an almost imperceptible tilt of her head. Then, with a casual air that no one else would interpret as anything significant, she made a tiny, deliberate toasting gesture in Rio’s direction.

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed instantly, the warmth spreading from her face to her chest. It was playful, teasing—Agatha’s way of letting her know that, even here, surrounded by students and textbooks, she saw her.

 

Rio bit her lip to suppress a grin, her heart doing a little flip as she ducked her head. She could feel Agatha’s eyes lingering for a moment longer before the professor turned her attention back to the rest of the class.

 

The mug. The toast. The secret glance.

 

It was nothing that anyone else would notice, but to Rio, it was everything.

 

She clutched her pen tighter, fighting the urge to glance around the room to see if anyone else had caught the exchange. Of course, they hadn’t. Agatha was far too skilled at keeping things under wraps, her movements subtle enough to be dismissed as coincidence. But to Rio, the moment was as clear as a kiss.

 

Her mind buzzed with affection and something deeper, something that felt almost sacred. Agatha didn’t need to say a word for Rio to know she was cherished, and here, in the middle of this classroom, Agatha had found a way to remind her of that.

 

As the lecture went on, Rio couldn’t stop the tiny smile that played on her lips, her notes remaining untouched as she basked in the quiet thrill of their unspoken connection.

 

As the lecture wrapped up, Agatha closed her book with her signature decisiveness, signaling the end of the session. The students began shuffling their papers and gathering their belongings, murmurs of discussion about the lecture filling the room.

 

Rio, still seated in her spot in the second row, took her time putting away her notes. She knew she had a moment before the room cleared out.

 

Agatha, standing by her desk, glanced toward Rio as the last stragglers filed out. Her calm, professional demeanor remained in place, but there was a flicker of something else in her gaze—something meant only for Rio.

 

Rio stood and slung her bag over her shoulder, approaching the front with an easy stride. She stopped just short of Agatha’s desk, keeping enough distance to maintain appearances. With a small, playful smirk, she tilted her head toward the green mug with the golden stars, now sitting on the edge of the desk.

 

“Nice mug,” Rio said, her tone casual, as though she were commenting on the weather.

 

Agatha’s brow arched just slightly, her lips curving into a knowing smile. She picked up the mug with deliberate care, cradling it in her hand.

 

“It’s a favorite of mine,” Agatha replied, her voice smooth and unbothered, though her eyes twinkled with amusement.

 

Rio couldn’t help the warmth bubbling in her chest. To anyone else, it was a passing exchange about a simple piece of ceramic. But between them, it was a conversation layered with meaning—an acknowledgment of shared moments and quiet intimacies that no one else in the world could understand.

 

“Good choice,” Rio added softly, before turning on her heel and making her way to the door.

 

Agatha watched her go, her smile lingering even as she composed herself for the next class. The green mug stayed firmly in her grasp, a discreet token of their love that felt even more precious now.

 

 

As the evening rolled in, Rio was nestled in a cozy corner of the campus library, the soft glow of her phone screen illuminating her face. She tapped out a quick message to Agatha, her thoughts drifting to their shared home and the little details that made it feel complete.

 

Rio: Hey, heading into town after I’m done here. Going to pick up a few things for the house. Need anything?

 

The message sent, Rio smiled softly to herself. The idea of “their house” still sent a pleasant thrill through her. It wasn’t just a place—it was a symbol of everything they had built together.

 

Agatha’s reply came almost immediately.

 

Agatha: Not that I can think of, love. But thank you for checking. Don’t forget to grab something for yourself, too.

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. Agatha always knew how to slip in that extra bit of care, even in the smallest interactions.

 

Rio: I’ll keep that in mind. See you soon, my starry professor.

 

She added a cheeky emoji—a star surrounded by sparkles—before slipping her phone back into her bag and heading out, her heart light with the thought of coming home to Agatha later.

 

 

As Rio wandered through the aisles of the small grocery store, her basket slowly filling with essentials for the house, she was humming a quiet tune to herself. The day had been pleasant, and the thought of going home to Agatha and Nicky later made her heart feel light.

 

Turning a corner, Rio stopped in her tracks. A group of familiar faces was ahead of her near the produce section. Her stomach dropped when she recognized them—her old foster family.

 

Her chest tightened, a familiar, unwelcome wave of anxiety washing over her. She thought she had left them far behind, buried in the recesses of her memory. But there they were, inescapable and as vivid as ever.

 

The air seemed to shift. They hadn’t noticed her yet, giving Rio a moment to decide whether to quietly retreat or walk past as if she hadn’t seen them. But before she could move, the matriarch of the family, a sharp-eyed woman named Carol, looked up and spotted her.

 

“Well, look who it is,” Carol said, her voice tinged with a forced cheeriness that made Rio’s skin crawl. “Little miss Rio.”

 

Rio’s shoulders stiffened and she forced herself to stand still, every instinct in her body telling her to run. Her grip on her basket tightened, but she forced herself to stand tall, her head held high.

 

Carol tilted her head, her smile not reaching her eyes. “My, you’ve grown up, haven’t you? What are you doing in town? Slumming it?”

 

“I live here,” Rio replied curtly, refusing to elaborate. She wasn’t about to give them any more power over her than they’d already taken in the past.

 

Carol raised an eyebrow. “Really? And what are you doing these days? Still running around with your silly little notebooks and pretending to be smarter than everyone else? Still chasing those silly dreams of yours?”

 

Rio gritted her teeth, keeping her composure. “I’m working on my PhD,” she said simply, hoping to end the conversation quickly, her voice devoid of the pride she usually felt when she said those words. Here, it felt like it would only be twisted into something small.

 

Carol sauntered closer, followed by her husband and one of their now-grown children. The man’s presence made Rio’s skin crawl, memories of his harsh words and the occasional slap across the face flashing unbidden in her mind.

 

“Oh, a PhD,” Carol said, laughing. “Wow, didn’t see that coming. You always did have that ‘head in the clouds’ thing going on. Well… aren’t you just a little genius now. Too bad all those smarts didn’t make you easier to live with.”

 

Rio’s jaw tightened. She could feel her pulse in her ears, the familiar pang of the humiliation they used to make her feel. She knew better than to engage. Their dismissiveness had always been a part of why her time in their house had been so difficult. They never believed in her, never supported her ambitions.

 

“You were always so much trouble,” Carol continued, her voice louder now. “Ungrateful, sneaky… you made it so hard for everyone else… but, good for you,” she said, her tone making it clear she didn’t mean it. “We always did say you were… different.”

 

“You were horrible to me,” Rio said, her voice sharp and clear, cutting through Carol’s tirade.

 

Carol froze, her face stiffening. The husband shifted uncomfortably but said nothing.
