“You pushed me around, yelled at me, made me feel like I was nothing,” Rio continued, her voice shaking now but steady. “You didn’t make it hard for me. You made it impossible.”

 

Carol’s smile faltered, but she quickly recovered. “Oh, don’t be dramatic. You were just a difficult child. You needed discipline.”

 

Rio’s hands curled into fists. She wasn’t a child anymore, wasn’t powerless like she had been back then. “I needed love,” she said firmly. “And you couldn’t give that to me.”

 

“You know, Rio, it’s a shame you didn’t stick with us longer. Maybe you’d have turned out a bit more grounded.”

 

Rio turned back slowly, her eyes sharp. “I think I turned out just fine, actually. Have a good evening.”

 

Without waiting for a response, she walked away, her heart pounding in her chest. She hated how they could still unnerve her, still make her feel small, even after all these years.

 

She stopped a few aisles away, setting her basket on the floor and bracing herself against the nearest shelf, taking a deep breath to steady her nerves. Hearing footsteps drawing closer, she quickened her stride, moving swiftly through the aisles toward the exit, nearly breaking into a run. As she reached the door, she pulled out her phone and sent a quick text to Agatha.

 

Rio: Might be a bit later than I thought. Just ran into some… memories. I’ll tell you about it when I’m home.

 

Agatha’s reply came swiftly, her steady presence already grounding Rio from afar.

 

Agatha: Take your time, love. Whatever it is, we’ll handle it.

 

Rio sighed, the tension in her chest easing slightly. As she left the grocery store, her mind was racing, her pulse still thundering in her ears. The confrontation had reopened wounds she thought had long since healed. She barely registered the sound of the automatic doors swishing shut behind her or the cold air biting at her cheeks.

 

She reached her car, fumbling with her keys, her hands shaking. Her chest felt tight, as though the memories were physically pressing down on her. She slid into the driver’s seat, gripping the steering wheel as she took deep, deliberate breaths.

 

Inhaling. Exhaling.

 

It wasn’t working. The weight of Carol’s words—dismissive, cruel, belittling—still clung to her like a heavy fog.

 

Rio’s phone buzzed in her pocket, snapping her out of her spiraling thoughts. She pulled it out to see another message from Agatha.

 

Agatha: Are you okay, my love? On your way home?

 

The text made her realize something was off. She glanced at the empty passenger seat, her stomach dropping. Her groceries.

 

She’d left them in the store.

 

For a moment, she considered going back, but the idea of potentially seeing them again—Carol, her foster father, that house of horrors personified—made her chest tighten further. No. She couldn’t. Not now.

 

She quickly typed back to Agatha:

 

Rio: I’ll explain everything when I’m home. Might be without groceries, though.

 

Agatha’s response was immediate.

 

Agatha: Don’t worry about groceries. Just come home to me, love.

 

Rio clutched her phone tightly, the familiar warmth of Agatha’s words cutting through the cold knot in her stomach. She started the car, her mind still swirling, but now with a beacon of safety guiding her back.

 

By the time she reached home, she didn’t even notice the absence of bags next to her anymore. All she cared about was the front door opening and Agatha standing there, waiting for her with open arms.

 

As soon as Rio stepped through the door, the weight of the day hit her like a tidal wave. Agatha was already there, her sharp eyes scanning Rio’s face, instantly recognizing that something was deeply wrong.

 

“My love,” Agatha said softly, stepping forward and cupping Rio’s face in her hands.

 

At the gentle touch, Rio crumpled, the tears she had been holding back breaking free. A deep, heart-wrenching sob tore through her, and she collapsed into Agatha’s arms.

 

Agatha caught her effortlessly, pulling her close and holding her tightly. She guided them to the couch, sitting down with Rio practically in her lap, her hands stroking through Rio’s hair as she murmured soothing words.

 

“It’s okay, you’re safe now,” Agatha whispered, over and over.

 

Rio’s fingers clutched at Agatha’s shirt like a lifeline as she wept, the kind of crying that came from somewhere deep and raw, dredging up years of pain.

 

Agatha’s heart ached, but she kept her voice steady. “Nicky’s with Wanda and the boys tonight. It’s just us. Take your time, my love. Let it out.”

 

Rio nodded, her face buried against Agatha’s shoulder, and she cried harder, her body shaking. “I—I ran into them,” she finally managed between sobs.

 

Agatha tensed, but her voice remained calm and steady. “Who, darling?”

 

“One of my old foster families.” Rio replied, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

Rio hung her head, her tears soaking into Agatha’s shirt and continued. “Carol…the mother… she looked at me like I was still nothing. Like I was still… that scared, useless kid. She… she said things…” Her voice broke.

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to the top of Rio’s head, holding her even closer. “You’re not that kid anymore,” she said firmly, her voice filled with conviction. “You are so strong, so brilliant, and so loved. She has no power over you, Rio. None.”

 

“But it still hurts,” Rio whispered, her voice so small it broke Agatha’s heart.

 

“I know,” Agatha said softly, her own throat tightening. “Of course, it does. They don’t deserve another moment of your pain. But you’re here now, with me, and I’ll be damned if I let their shadow linger in our home.”

 

Rio nodded faintly, her breathing starting to even out as Agatha continued to soothe her with soft touches and loving words.

 

“You’re safe,” Agatha whispered again, tilting Rio’s chin up to meet her gaze. Her eyes were gentle but unwavering. “I’ve got you, my love. Always.”

 

Rio managed a weak smile through her tears, and Agatha kissed her forehead. “Let’s just stay here for a bit, okay?”

 

Rio didn’t answer, but she didn’t need to. She simply melted into Agatha’s embrace, finding solace in the steady heartbeat beneath her ear, the warmth of her partner’s arms, and the love that wrapped around her like a shield.

 

Agatha gently brushed the tears from Rio’s cheeks, her own expression filled with quiet determination. “What can I do for you, my love? Tell me, anything.”

 

Rio hesitated, her lips trembling as more tears welled in her eyes. She looked down, shame flickering across her features. “I… I don’t know if I can call her myself,” she whispered, her voice barely audible.

 

“Who, love?” Agatha asked softly, though she already had an idea.

 

Rio hesitated, then finally said, “Lilia. Can you… can you call her for me?”

 

Agatha’s heart ached at the vulnerability in Rio’s voice, but she nodded immediately. “Of course, I can.”

 

She shifted Rio gently onto the couch, tucking a blanket around her lap before grabbing her phone. Agatha kept one hand on Rio’s knee, grounding her, as she dialed Lilia’s number.

 

It rang only twice before Lilia’s warm, familiar voice answered. “Hello, Agatha! What a lovely surprise. Is everything alright?”

 

“Lilia, hi,” Agatha began, her voice calm but serious. “I’m calling because Rio needs you. She had a rough encounter with someone — one of her old foster families?”

 

There was a sharp intake of breath on the other end of the line, “Which one?” Lilia asked, and the fact she needed to ask that question broke something inside of Agatha.

 

“Mmh, I’m not sure, Rio mentioned something about a Carol?” Agatha replied, unsure of what to say. The curse she heard Lilia mutter on the other end of the line did nothing to reassure her. Agatha continued, glancing at Rio as she spoke. “She’s very shaken. I’m with her now, but I think hearing your voice might help.”

 

“Oh, my poor girl,” Lilia said, her voice breaking slightly. “I’ll come over right away.”

 

Agatha smiled faintly, her gratitude clear. “Thank you, Lilia. It means the world to her—and to me.”

 

“Of course,” Lilia said firmly. “I’ll be there in twenty minutes.”

 

Agatha ended the call and turned back to Rio, her touch gentle as she ran a hand through her hair. “She’s on her way, my love. She’ll be here soon.”

 

Rio let out a shaky breath, nodding. “Thank you,” she whispered, her voice thick with emotion.

 

“Always,” Agatha said softly, leaning in to kiss her forehead. She settled back beside Rio, pulling her close again as they waited for Lilia, tears still silently falling from Rio’s eyes into her hair and Agatha’s chest.

 

Lilia arrived quietly, as always, her presence comforting and steady. She stepped into the living room, finding Rio curled up on the couch almost on top of Agatha, her face still damp with tears. The sight of Rio’s vulnerability made Lilia’s heart ache, and she knelt beside her, taking Rio’s hand in hers.

 

“My darling girl,” Lilia murmured softly, brushing Rio’s hair back from her face. “I’m here now.”

 

Rio’s tired eyes met hers, and she managed a weak smile, but it was clear she was still shaken. “I didn’t want to bother you,” she whispered, her voice thick with emotion.

 

Lilia shook her head, her smile warm but firm. “You never bother me, sweet girl. Never.”

 

With a gentle, practiced touch, Lilia helped Rio out of Agatha’s lap and to her feet and guided her to the bedroom, where Rio climbed into bed, still feeling exhausted from the emotional toll of the encounter. Lilia stayed with her for a while, making sure she had everything she needed—water, tissues, the comfort of her presence.

 

After Rio was settled in bed, Lilia stayed for a moment longer, sitting beside her, her hand gently rubbing Rio’s arm as she softly spoke to her.

 

“You don’t need to say anything more right now, sweetheart,” Lilia murmured, her voice soothing. “Just take it easy. Let sleep heal you for now.”

 

Rio nodded, her eyes heavy with exhaustion but still glistening with the remnants of her tears. “I hate that it still affects me,” she whispered, barely audible. “I thought I was over it.”

 

Lilia’s expression softened as she stroked Rio’s hair. “It doesn’t work like that. Sometimes the past has a way of creeping up on us when we least expect it. But you’re not alone anymore, Rio. You have Agatha, and you have me.”

 

Rio gave a quiet, shaky breath, trying to settle her racing mind. “I know,” she whispered, and for the first time in what felt like hours, a small, fragile smile tugged at her lips.

 

“I know you know, sweetheart,” Lilia replied, her voice warm and reassuring. “I’ll be here when you need me.”

 

Rio nodded, her eyes fluttering closed. “Thank you, Lilia… for everything.”

 

Lilia stayed for a few more moments, watching over Rio as she fell into a fitful sleep. She kissed the top of Rio’s head before standing and quietly leaving the room, letting her get some much-needed rest.

 

When she made her way back downstairs, Agatha was waiting in the living room, looking tense, her eyes full of concern. Lilia could see the deep worry etched into Agatha’s features, and she smiled reassuringly.

 

“She’s resting now,” Lilia said softly, sinking into the chair beside Agatha. “She just needed to hear my voice, and a little bit of quiet care. The past caught up with her today.”

 

Agatha’s brows furrowed, her tone low but filled with a quiet intensity. “I hate seeing her like this. What happened?”

 

Lilia sighed, folding her hands in her lap. “This old foster family… they were abusive, Agatha. Not just neglectful, but cruel.”

 

Agatha’s expression hardened, her jaw tightening at the thought. “I had no idea…”

 

“Rio keeps so much of it inside,” Lilia said, her voice gentle but laced with a knowing sadness. “She’s learned to shield herself from it. But sometimes, those walls crack, and the pain comes flooding back.”

 

Agatha was quiet for a moment, taking in Lilia’s words. She could feel the weight of them settling in her chest, the knowledge that Rio had been through so much before they’d even met. The protective instinct she had for Rio flared, but there was something else too—a deep, aching love.

 

“You’re the first person she’s trusted enough to let in like this,” Lilia continued, her gaze soft but knowing. “You should be proud of that, Agatha. She’s finally found a place where she can heal, even if it’s just little by little.”

 

Agatha swallowed, her throat tight. “I just want to help her,” she whispered, her voice raw with emotion. “I want to be the one who makes it all better for her.”

 

“You already are, Agatha,” Lilia said, her voice firm with conviction. “Just by being here, by loving her. That’s the most important thing. She’s been through too much alone. Now she has you.”

 

Agatha nodded slowly, her gaze distant for a moment. “I don’t know how to make it stop hurting.”

 

“You won’t be able to take the hurt away completely,” Lilia replied gently. “But you can be the one who helps her hold on to the good things. The love. The safety. That’s what she needs from you right now.”

 

Agatha nodded, her eyes fixed on the floor. “I hate seeing her like this, Lilia. I just want to take all the pain away for her. I feel so… powerless.”

 

Lilia’s gaze softened, and she placed a comforting hand on Agatha’s arm. “You’re doing so much more than you realize, Agatha.”

 

Agatha met Lilia’s eyes, her expression earnest. “I just want to help her, to be there for her in all the ways she needs.”

 

“You are,” Lilia said with quiet certainty. “She’s been through a lot on her own, but now, she has you. She’s not alone anymore, and that makes all the difference.”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened, emotions she hadn’t realized were sitting heavy in her heart coming to the surface. “But I still feel like I could be doing more. I don’t want her to feel alone again.”

 

Lilia offered Agatha a gentle smile, her eyes full of understanding. “You’re doing more than you realize. A few years ago, something like this would have been impossible for Rio to even discuss. She would have bottled it all up, withdrawn into herself. She never would have let herself rely on anyone like this, let alone lean on someone the way she does with you. And she certainly wouldn’t have come straight home like that.”

 

Agatha blinked, surprised by Lilia’s words. “I never realized she used to be like that,” she said quietly.

 

“She was,” Lilia confirmed, her tone gentle but steady. “All of this, it made her close herself off. It took me so long to get her to open up. She never let anyone get too close, not after everything. But now?” Lilia’s gaze met Agatha’s, full of earnest gratitude. “She trusts you, Agatha. She trusts you with the parts of herself she’s hidden from the world for so long. That’s no small thing. You’ve given her the safety to be vulnerable, and for Rio, that’s a rare and precious gift.”

 

Agatha took a deep breath, wiping away a stray tear that had formed at the corner of her eye. “Thank you, Lilia,” she said softly.

 

Lilia smiled warmly, standing up to leave. “Just keep being there for her, Agatha. That’s all you need to do.”

 

Agatha’s heart swelled with warmth at the thought, though a tinge of worry remained. “I just want to be the person she deserves.”

 

“You are,” Lilia assured her, squeezing Agatha’s shoulder. “You’re already there. Don’t doubt that for a second.”

 

As Lilia made her way to the door, Agatha remained seated, her mind reeling with the weight of everything she had just learned.

 

As the door clicked shut behind Lilia, Agatha turned toward the bedroom, her heart full of quiet resolve. She was never letting that woman go.

 

Once upstairs, Agatha joined Rio in their shared bed. She moved carefully, not wanting to disturb Rio’s rest, but Rio shifted slightly as she sensed Agatha’s presence and pulled her close, wrapping her arms around her. Agatha, always gentle but firm, enveloped her in warmth, holding her close as they lay together in the darkness.

 

For a moment, there was only the soft sound of their breathing, the quiet comfort of being together after such an emotionally draining day. Rio’s voice, barely above a whisper, broke the silence.

 

“I’m sorry,” Rio said, her voice thick with emotion. “For needing Lilia so much.”

 

Agatha felt the tension in Rio’s voice and immediately tightened her hold on her, pressing a kiss to the top of her head. She spoke softly, her tone reassuring and filled with understanding.

 

“You never need to apologize for that,” Agatha replied, her hand gently stroking Rio’s back. “Lilia is family. She’s been there for you, and I’m glad she’s someone you can rely on. You don’t have to carry everything on your own, Rio. Not anymore.”

 

Rio’s body relaxed slightly at Agatha’s words, but there was still an undercurrent of guilt that lingered in her voice. “I just… I hate feeling so weak. It’s like I’m a burden.”

 

Agatha cupped Rio’s cheek, tilting her head so she could look into her eyes. “You’re not a burden. You’re not weak. You’re human. You’ve been through so much, and you’ve come so far. It’s okay to need help. It’s okay to let others in when you’re struggling. And it’s okay to lean on Lilia when you need her.”

 

Rio’s eyes shimmered with unshed tears, and she swallowed hard, trying to hold them back. “I just don’t want to disappoint you.”

 

Agatha’s heart ached at that, and she gently lifted Rio’s chin, forcing her to meet her gaze. “Rio, listen to me,” she said softly but firmly. “You will never disappoint me. I love you, every part of you, and nothing will ever change that. You don’t have to be perfect. You don’t have to be strong all the time. I’m here for you, no matter what.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, and she closed her eyes for a moment, allowing herself to lean into Agatha’s embrace. “Thank you,” she whispered, her voice fragile but full of trust. “I love you, too.”

 

Agatha kissed the top of Rio’s head, her fingers weaving through her hair in slow, comforting strokes. “Get some rest, my love,” she whispered, her voice soothing and warm. “Tomorrow, I promise you hot chocolate in cups of stars.”

 

And with that, Rio let out a little laugh and relaxed fully into Agatha’s arms, letting go of the last of her tension, and for the first time in hours, allowed herself to rest, comforted by the love and security Agatha provided. The night passed quietly, the two of them holding each other, finding peace in the solace of their shared warmth.

 

*

*

*

 

Under the Stars

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

There is a time for the evening under starlight,

A time for the evening under lamplight

(The evening with the photograph album).

 

              (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker. Four Quartets.)

 

 

A week later, the night was crisp and clear, the kind of evening where the stars seemed to stretch endlessly across the sky. Agatha and Rio had agreed it was the perfect moment to escape the weight of their busy lives and share a quiet moment beneath the vastness of the universe. The day had been long and taxing for both of them—Agatha buried under an overwhelming stack of papers to grade and giving lecture after lecture, and Rio locked in the library, struggling to write a new chapter for her thesis.

 

A break was definitely in order, and they both knew that stargazing was just what they needed.

 

Agatha had called the babysitter and put Nicky to bed, and the two had packed a few essentials—blankets, a thermos of hot tea, and a small telescope Agatha had brought home years ago and that she sometimes used with Nicky during summer nights.

 

As they stepped outside into the cool night air, Rio shivered slightly, pulling her green cardigan tighter around her. Agatha immediately draped an arm over her shoulders, her warmth and steady presence making Rio feel warm and grounded.

 

“I know a perfect spot,” Agatha said, her voice low and soft, as though speaking too loudly might disturb the peace of the night. She led Rio through the backyard and up a gentle hill that overlooked the woods, behind her house.

 

When they reached the clearing, Rio gasped softly. It was breathtaking—the stars were brilliant, glowing like diamonds scattered on black velvet. The Milky Way stretched above them in a dazzling arc, and the faint rustling of leaves in the breeze created a soothing soundtrack.

 

“This is perfect,” Rio whispered, her voice filled with wonder.

 

Agatha spread out a thick blanket on the grass and gestured for Rio to sit. They settled side by side, and Rio leaned against Agatha, her head resting on her shoulder.

 

“Look at that,” Rio murmured, pointing toward a particularly bright small cluster of stars. “The Pleiades. It’s always been one of my favorites.”

 

Agatha hummed, turning her head slightly to kiss Rio’s temple. “You’ve told me about them before. Seven sisters, right?”

 

“Yeah,” Rio said with a soft smile. “It’s beautiful. And tragic, in a way. The myth says they were turned into stars to escape Orion’s pursuit.”

 

Agatha tilted her head to study the constellation, her brow furrowing slightly. “I suppose being a star is better than being hunted, though it’s still a bit sad. Always running from the Sun, even in the sky.”

 

Rio nodded, falling silent for a moment as she traced invisible lines between the stars with her finger. “It makes me wonder,” she said softly, “what stories would be told about us if we were up there?”

 

Agatha chuckled, her voice warm and low, like the hum of a distant melody. “Oh, I’m sure the gods would find us endlessly entertaining. But they’d also be terribly jealous of us.”

 

Rio laughed, leaning into Agatha and nudging her playfully. “Jealous? Really? Even with all the great love stories in the cosmos?”

 

“Ours is the most beautiful,” Agatha replied, her voice a blend of tenderness and playful confidence.

 

Rio smiled, her voice barely above a whisper as she answered, “It is.”

 

They lapsed into a comfortable silence, letting the beauty of the night envelop them. Agatha poured them both tea from the thermos, and they sipped it slowly, savoring the warmth. Rio’s gaze flickered between the stars and Agatha’s profile, bathed in moonlight.

 

“You know,” Rio began, her voice barely audible, “I think nights like these are my favorite.”

 

“Why’s that?” Agatha asked, turning to meet Rio’s eyes.

 

“Because it’s just us,” Rio said simply. “No work, no noise, no interruptions. Just you, me, and the stars. It makes everything else seem… small. The only thing missing is Nicky.”

 

Agatha reached over to take Rio’s hand, threading their fingers together. “We’ll bring him with us next time. And you’re right, everything else is small,” she murmured. “At least, compared to this.”

 

Rio leaned into Agatha’s touch, her heart swelling with gratitude. For the first time in days, she felt a sense of calm washing over her. The relentless buzz of her thoughts and memories dulled, replaced by the steady rhythm of Agatha’s presence.

 

Agatha adjusted the telescope and gestured for Rio to take a look. “Here,” she said, her voice soft. “I’ve found Jupiter. Want to see?”

 

Rio leaned over, peering into the lens. Her eyes widened, and a delighted gasp escaped her lips. “Oh, wow. It’s beautiful. You can even see the moons!”

 

Agatha smiled, watching the joy light up Rio’s face. “Four of them,” she said. “Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto. Galileo’s discoveries.”

 

Rio straightened up and turned to Agatha, a playful glint in her eyes. “How do you know so much about astronomy, Dr. Harkness? Secret passion?”

 

Agatha smirked. “Not a secret. Just another way to impress my brilliant girlfriend, and entertain my ever-curious son.”

 

Rio laughed, a sound that echoed in the quiet night, bright and full of life. She leaned in and pressed a soft kiss to Agatha’s cheek. “You don’t need stars to impress me,” she said.

 

Agatha’s smirk softened into a tender smile. “Maybe not. But I like seeing that look on your face when you’re amazed by something.”

 

The stars twinkled softly above, casting their serene glow over them as they sat side by side on the blanket. Rio’s head rested against Agatha’s shoulder, her fingers absently tracing flowers on the fabric of Agatha’s sleeve. They had been talking about constellations, myths, and the quiet beauty of the universe, but Rio’s thoughts had drifted elsewhere.

 

“Agatha,” Rio murmured, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

“Hm?” Agatha hummed in response, her attention still on the telescope she was adjusting.

 

Rio hesitated, biting her lip before continuing. “I’ve been thinking… You know so much about me, about me before you, and I know a lot about your current life—what you’ve done, your accomplishments, your brilliance—but… I don’t know much about your background. Your past. What makes you you.”

 

Agatha froze for a moment, her hands stilling on the telescope. She glanced at Rio, her expression unreadable. “My past?”

 

Rio nodded, her eyes searching Agatha’s face. “Yeah. Where you came from. Your family. Your life before all of this. Before Nicky. Before us.”

 

Agatha sighed softly, leaning back against the blanket and gazing up at the sky. Her features were calm, but Rio could see the faint tension in her jaw, the way her fingers fidgeted slightly.

 

“It’s not a pretty story, love,” Agatha said finally, her voice low and measured.

 

“I’m not asking for pretty,” Rio replied gently. “I’m asking for you. Whatever you’re willing to share.”

 

For a moment, silence stretched between them, the only sound the soft rustling of leaves in the breeze. Finally, Agatha spoke, her voice quiet but steady.

 

“My mother, Evanora… she wasn’t a good mother,” Agatha began, her eyes fixed on the stars above. “She was cold. Strict. Nothing I did was ever good enough for her. She had this… idea of what I should be, and anything that didn’t fit into that mold was unacceptable.”

 

Rio listened intently, her hand finding Agatha’s and giving it a gentle squeeze. Agatha didn’t look at her, but she squeezed back, a small sign of acknowledgment.

 

“I never knew my father,” Agatha continued. “Evanora never talked about him. He wasn’t in the picture, and from what I could gather, she didn’t want him to be. I used to wonder what he was like, whether he was kind or if he would’ve… understood me better than she did. But it’s hard to miss someone you never knew.”

 

Rio’s heart ached at the quiet pain in Agatha’s voice. She reached up to brush a strand of hair away from Agatha’s face, her touch soft and comforting. “I’m sorry, Agatha. That must’ve been so hard.”

 

Agatha shook her head slightly, a wry smile tugging at the corner of her lips. “It was what it was. I learned early on that I couldn’t rely on her—or anyone else, for that matter. So I became self-reliant. Strong. But it left its mark.”

 

Rio shifted closer, wrapping her arms around Agatha and resting her head against her chest. “You don’t have to be strong all the time, you know. Not with me.”

 

Agatha finally looked down at her, her eyes softening. She ran a hand through Rio’s hair, her fingers gentle. “I know, love. You’re the one person I don’t have to be strong with.”

 

They sat like that for a while, the stars above them bearing silent witness to the exchange.

 

“You’ve built such a beautiful life,” Rio said softly. “Despite everything. Despite her.”

 

Agatha nodded, a faint smile gracing her lips. “I have. And Nicky and you are the best part of it.”

 

Rio blushed at the sentiment, her heart swelling. “I’m glad you told me,” she said, her voice barely audible. “I want to know every part of you, Agatha. Even the messy, painful parts. Especially those.”

 

Agatha leaned down, pressing a tender kiss to Rio’s forehead. “You already have all of me, Rio. Every part.”

 

Rio smiled, her eyes glistening with unshed tears. “And I’ll take care of every part, just like you take care of me.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, pulling Rio closer. “I think we take care of each other, love. And that’s all that matters.”

 

As they lay under the starlit sky, the air between them felt lighter, the bond they shared even stronger. In that quiet, sacred moment, it was as if the universe itself held them in its embrace, their love shining as brightly as the stars above.

 

As the quiet of the night enveloped them, Rio nestled closer to Agatha, still processing everything Agatha had shared. The stars above twinkled in their silent dance, offering a semblance of peace to the heaviness of their conversation. Rio’s hand rested over Agatha’s, a steadying gesture as she mulled over her next words.

 

“You’ve done so much to rise above all that,” Rio murmured, her voice barely above a whisper. “And Nicky… he’s so lucky to have you.”

 

A shadow flickered across Agatha’s face, her features tightening slightly. She stared at the sky for a long moment before replying. “I’ve made sure of that, Rio. I swore to myself that Nicky would never know what it was like to feel unloved. To feel… unworthy.”

 

Rio tilted her head to look at Agatha, concern flickering in her eyes. “You’ve done an amazing job with him, Agatha. He’s such a sweet, happy kid.”

 

Agatha exhaled slowly, her fingers entwining with Rio’s. “He is. But I’ve also been… cautious. Protective. Maybe too much sometimes.”

 

“What do you mean?” Rio asked softly.

 

Agatha’s gaze remained fixed on the stars, her voice measured but tinged with emotion. “I’ve refused to let him anywhere near Evanora. I made that decision before he was even born. She didn’t get to see him. Didn’t get to be a part of his life. I would never have given her the chance to hurt him the way she hurt me.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched at the fierceness in Agatha’s tone, but it wasn’t a harshness that frightened her. It was a resolute, protective love that ran deep.

 

“You really think she would have?” Rio asked hesitantly.

 

Agatha turned her head to meet Rio’s gaze, her expression firm. “I know she would have. She was manipulative. Cruel. My mother didn’t know how to love—it was not in her nature. And Nicky… he’s too pure, too kind to be tainted by her bitterness. I would not have allowed it.”

 

Rio reached up to cup Agatha’s face, her thumb brushing gently against her cheek. “You protected him, Agatha. That’s what good mothers do. And you’re the best mother he could ever have.”

 

Agatha’s features softened at Rio’s words, a faint smile playing on her lips. “I hope so. I want him to grow up surrounded by love and kindness. The things I never had.”

 

“He will,” Rio said firmly. “Because of you. Because of us. He has a family who adores him. And he’ll never have to know anything else.”

 

Agatha’s fingers tightened slightly around Rio’s as she continued, her voice taking on a quieter, more vulnerable tone.

 

“When Evanora died three years ago… I was relieved,” she admitted, the words heavy with guilt and finality.

 

Rio’s breath caught, and she turned fully toward Agatha, her brow furrowed with a mix of concern and understanding. “Agatha…”

 

“I know how it sounds,” Agatha said quickly, her voice laced with shame. “She was my mother. I should’ve felt… something else. Grief, maybe. Or sadness. But all I felt was this crushing sense of freedom. Like a weight I’d been carrying my entire life had finally been lifted.”

 

Rio’s heart ached at the pain in Agatha’s voice. She could see how deeply the admission was affecting her, the conflict etched into her features.

 

“Agatha,” Rio began gently, “you don’t have to feel guilty about that. Not after everything she put you through.”

 

Agatha’s lips pressed into a thin line, and she shook her head slowly. “She was cruel, Rio. But she was still my mother. A part of me wonders if I should’ve tried harder to make things right, even if it was hopeless.”

 

Rio scooted closer, wrapping her arms around Agatha in a protective embrace. “Agatha, listen to me. You didn’t owe her anything. Not after the way she treated you. Some people don’t change, no matter how much we wish they would. And it’s okay to feel relief. It doesn’t make you a bad person—it makes you human.”

 

Agatha leaned into Rio’s warmth, her long brown hair cascading over Rio’s shoulder as she let out a shaky breath. “I spent so much of my life trying to survive her, trying to undo the damage she caused. When she was gone, it felt like I could finally breathe. But it also felt… wrong. Like I was betraying her memory.”

 

Rio pulled back slightly to look into Agatha’s eyes, her gaze steady and filled with love. “You’re not betraying anything, Agatha. You’re honoring yourself, your growth, and the life you’ve built. You’ve given so much of yourself to Nicky, to me, to everyone you love. That’s not betrayal—that’s strength.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened, her tension easing ever so slightly. “You always know exactly what to say, don’t you?”

 

Rio offered a small, teasing smile. “It’s one of my many talents.”

 

Agatha leaned into Rio’s touch, her eyes glistening in the dim light. “Thank you, Rio. For saying that. For… understanding. For reminding me that it’s okay to let go of the past. That it’s okay to move forward.”

 

Rio smiled softly, her fingers gently tracing Agatha’s jawline. “It’s more than okay, Agatha. You’ve given Nicky—and me—everything. And I’ll always be here to give that back to you. It’s what you deserve.”

 

Agatha leaned in, pressing a tender kiss to Rio’s forehead. “I don’t know what I’d do without you.”

 

“Hopefully, you’ll never have to find out,” Rio whispered, her voice steady and full of promise.

 

Rio shifted slightly in Agatha’s embrace, her playful smile breaking through the heaviness of the conversation. “You know,” she began, her tone lightening, “I’m head over heels for you, Agatha Harkness. And nothing—nothing—will ever change that.”

 

Agatha tilted her head, a soft smile spreading across her face. “Even with all my baggage?”

 

Rio snorted gently, resting her forehead against Agatha’s. “Especially with all your baggage, God knows mine is heavy too. It just makes you… you. And I wouldn’t have it any other way.”

 

Agatha chuckled, a glimmer of amusement in her eyes. “You’re something else, Rio Vidal.”

 

“And,” Rio added, her grin widening, “if you ever feel like you’re missing out on a family figure, we can always share my Lilia. She’s already been roped into my chaos. She wouldn’t mind a little of yours, too. And she already loves you.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, pretending to consider it. “Your Lilia, huh? That’s a good idea. But don’t think I won’t tease you mercilessly if she starts doting on me more than you.”

 

Rio gasped in mock outrage, her hand over her chest. “How dare you suggest such a thing! Lilia is mine! But, fine, I guess I’ll share her. For you.”

 

Agatha smirked, brushing a strand of hair from Rio’s cheek. “I’ll take it. Besides, I have all I need right here.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed, and she buried her face in Agatha’s shoulder, mumbling, “You’re way too good at this romantic stuff.”

 

Agatha chuckled, pressing a kiss to Rio’s temple. “You inspire me, love.”

 

As they sat under the vast night sky, Rio reached for Agatha’s hand, lacing their fingers together. “For the record, though, if Lilia ends up spoiling you, I demand equal treatment.”

 

Agatha laughed, her voice warm and full of affection. “Noted, my love. Noted.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened as she looked at Rio, her features illuminated by the soft glow of the moonlight. She gently cupped Rio’s face, her thumb brushing over her cheek. “You know,” she began, her voice low and tender, “before you came into my life, everything felt… muted. Controlled. Like I was just going through the motions and the only color was Nicky. But you…”

 

Rio tilted her head, her eyes wide and curious. “Me?”

 

“You brought color back into my world,” Agatha continued, her words filled with emotion. “You made everything so much brighter, so much more alive. And you didn’t just do that for me. You did it for Nicky, too.”

 

Rio’s expression softened, her lips parting slightly in surprise.

 

Agatha smiled, her eyes glistening. “He adores you, you know. The way you light up his world—the way you laugh with him, teach him, love him. You’ve given him something I always feared I couldn’t. A sense of joy, of warmth… of family.”

 

Rio’s eyes filled with tears once again as she reached up to take Agatha’s hand in hers. “Agatha, you didn’t need me to give him that. You’re an incredible mom. Nicky is the amazing little kid he is because of you.”

 

Agatha shook her head slightly, her smile bittersweet. “Maybe. But you’ve made us both better. He needed you, and so did I.”

 

Rio sniffled, laughing softly through her tears. “Well, you’ve got me now. You’re stuck with me, forever and ever, or for as long as you’ll have me.”

 

Agatha chuckled, leaning forward to rest her forehead against Rio’s. “Good. I hope you’re ready for forever, because I don’t ever want to let you go.”

 

Rio wrapped her arms around Agatha’s waist, pulling her closer. “You’re not getting rid of me that easily. And for the record, you’ve changed my life, too. I didn’t think I’d ever feel this loved, this safe. You and Nicky gave me that. You gave me a home. Just like Lilia did.”

 

Agatha’s arms tightened around Rio, her voice barely above a whisper. “You are my home, Rio.”

 

They stayed like that for a while, wrapped in each other’s arms, the stars above bearing witness to their love. Agatha felt a deep sense of gratitude wash over her—gratitude for the little boy who had brought so much light into her life, and for the woman who made their family complete.

 

In that moment, Agatha silently promised herself that she would cherish Rio and protect her with everything she had, for as long as they both lived, and she wished for this to last forever. Unbeknownst to her, Rio had just made the same wish.

 

They fell into a comfortable silence, the weight of their confessions dissipating into the cool night air. As the night stretched on and the stars continued to shine down on them, Agatha felt a sense of peace she hadn’t known in years. With Rio by her side, she knew she could face anything—even the shadows of her past.

 

They stayed out there for hours, pointing out constellations, sharing stories, and occasionally stealing kisses under the blanket of stars. By the time they decided to head back inside, the sky was beginning to lighten with the first hints of dawn.

 

As they walked back hand in hand, Rio looked up at Agatha, her heart full. “Thank you,” she said simply.

 

“For what?” Agatha asked, her brow furrowing slightly.

 

“For sharing yourself and your story with me,” Rio replied. “And for always being my anchor.”

 

Agatha squeezed her hand, her voice soft but steady. “Always, love. Always.”

 

 

When Agatha and Rio reached the house, the warmth of home embraced them. As they entered, Rio quietly slipped her shoes off and followed Agatha down the hall.

 

By the time Rio reached the living room, Agatha had already paid and relieved the babysitter, offering a few warm words of thanks and promising to call her next time they needed help, especially since Nicky seemed to really like her.

 

“I’ll go check on Nicky,” Agatha whispered, her hand grazing Rio’s arm as she started toward the stairs. But just as she reached the first step, she turned and extended her hand toward Rio. “Come with me.”

 

“Are you sure?” Rio asked, knowing that this was usually Agatha’s moment.

 

“I’ve never been surer,” Agatha replied, her voice steady and sure, as Rio took her hand. Together, they moved upstairs, Agatha leading the way with Rio following closely behind.

 

The door creaked open just enough to let them peek inside. Nicky was fast asleep, sprawled out on his little bed, his blankets half-kicked off as usual. His soft brown curls framed his cherubic face, and his tiny hand clutched his stuffed dragon.

 

Rio leaned her head against Agatha’s shoulder, her heart swelling at the sight. “He looks so peaceful,” she murmured.

 

Agatha smiled, her eyes tender as she gazed at her son. “He always does. Like nothing in the world could trouble him.”

 

Rio stepped closer, pulling the blanket gently up to cover Nicky’s small body. Her fingers lingered for a moment, brushing over his hair before she straightened up. “He’s such a good kid. So sweet and kind. Just like his mom,” she whispered, casting a glance at Agatha.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, wrapping an arm around Rio’s waist. “He sees it in you too, you know.”

 

She kissed the top of Rio’s head, her voice warm with affection. “You’ve brought so much love into this house, Rio. It’s in everything you do—even the way you tuck him in.”

 

Rio’s posture opened as she turned to Agatha, resting her head back against her shoulder. “I just want him to always feel safe. Like he belongs. Like he’s loved.”

 

“He does,” Agatha assured her, her voice steady and full of conviction. “And he always will, as long as we’re here.”

 

They stood there for a while, watching over Nicky as he dreamed, the quiet hum of the house enveloping them. The love in the room was tangible—a quiet, unwavering force that bound the three of them together.

 

When they finally left, Agatha softly closed the door behind them, her hand finding Rio’s as they walked down the hallway. “Let’s get some rest, love. Tomorrow is another day, and we’ve got a little boy who will be up bright and early, demanding pancakes.”

 

Rio chuckled, squeezing Agatha’s hand, following her out of Nicky’s bedroom and into their own.

 

As they settled in for the night, the house felt like a sanctuary, as if everything they would ever need was within these walls.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

As always, I love hearing your thoughts!
Also, if you have suggestions, things or scenes you want to see, please don't hesitate !!!

The Choir Show - Part I

Chapter Notes

Yeaah, a Nicky chapter !

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

Or the waterfall, or music heard so deeply

That it is not heard at all, but you are the music

While the music lasts. These are only hints and guesses,

Hints followed by guesses; and the rest

Is prayer, observance, discipline, thought and action.

 

      (T. S. Eliot. « The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The sound of the car’s engine hummed softly as Agatha navigated the familiar streets back to their home, Nicky chattering happily in the backseat. It was a typical afternoon, the sun casting its golden glow through the car windows, and Rio had just texted her saying she was getting started on dinner, and Agatha knew it was going to be an amazing evening, even if she would probably have to tend to the disaster Rio would leave in the kitchen. Rio's cooking skills were... infamous.

 

When they pulled into the driveway, Nicky bounded out of the car and into the house, the usual energy of the little boy filling the space. Agatha couldn’t help but chuckle at his exuberance as she opened the door for him.

 

“Guess what, Rio!” Nicky squealed as he tossed his backpack aside, his eyes lighting up. “The choir show is on Saturday afternoon! I get to sing with my class in front of everyone!”

 

“And that’s wonderful, sweetheart, but Rio is in the kitchen, I’m not sure she can hear you from here, baby” Agatha said, giving him a kiss on top of his head. “I know you’ll be amazing.”

 

Rio stepped out from the kitchen, wiping her hands on a dish towel with way too much stain to be good news and grinning at Nicky’s excitement. “Oh, I heard! You’re going to shine, kiddo,” she said, her heart warming at the sight of him practically bouncing with joy.

 

Nicky’s eyes widened, a mix of eagerness and a bit of nervousness crossing his face. “You both will be there, right? You’re coming to cheer for me?”

 

“Of course we will,” Agatha replied without hesitation. “Wouldn’t miss it for the world.” Her voice was soft, full of warmth, but also a little teasing. “Do you need us to make up a little dance for you?”

 

Nicky chuckled, his face lighting up even more. “No dance, Mama! Just you two watching me sing.”

 

“And maybe your mom’s going to bring the camera, just for memories,” Rio added, giving Agatha a mischievous smile. “You know she’ll want some.”

 

“Oh believe me, I want pictures, lots of them!” Agatha teased, earning a playful scowl from Nicky.

 

“But, wait!” Nicky’s voice suddenly grew serious. He looked at both of them, his face thoughtful. “Can we invite Grandma Lilia too? She always says she wants to see me sing, but she wasn’t sure when. She can come, right?”

 

Rio felt a swell of affection for Nicky and Lilia. She’d always been there for Rio, and Nicky had quickly come to adore her, claiming her as his grandma, just like Rio had claimed her as her mom years ago. There was never any doubt in Rio’s mind that Lilia would be welcomed to any event, but it still made her smile to hear Nicky’s thoughtfulness.

 

“Of course she can come, sweetie,” Rio answered, her tone warm. “I’m sure she’d love to be there.” She turned to Agatha, giving her a subtle, affectionate look. “What do you think?”

 

Agatha smiled at the thought, clearly charmed by the idea of having Lilia join them. “I think it’s a great idea. We’ll get Lilia a seat right next to us. It’ll be a fun family outing.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up like a Christmas tree, his energy now a whirlwind of excitement. “Yes! It’s going to be perfect!” He threw his arms around Agatha’s waist and then Rio’s, his little hands gripping them tightly. “Thanks, both of you!”

 

Rio squeezed him back, feeling a strange mix of joy and something deeper—something she hadn’t quite identified yet. This wasn’t just about a choir show. It was about family, about everyone she loved showing up for each other.

 

“I can’t wait, kiddo,” Rio said softly, giving him one last squeeze before he rushed off to practice his songs in the living room.

 

She turned back to Agatha, her hands finding the collar of her shirt as she gave it a playful tug. “Now come help me, dear. I need more hands to finish dinner before the little singer eats all the bread rolls.”

 

Agatha arched an eyebrow, letting herself be led toward the stove. “Yes, ma’am, but just so you know, that’s no way to talk to your professor.”

 

Rio smirked, leaning closer to whisper in a conspiratorial tone, “Good thing you’re more than that, then.”

 

Agatha chuckled, her hand brushing against Rio’s as she reached for a cutting board. “Cheeky. I like it.”

 

Rio grinned and turned her attention back to the simmering pots and pans. For a few moments, the kitchen filled with the comforting sounds of bubbling sauces and the soft clinks of utensils as they worked together. Agatha passed her ingredients and chopped vegetables with an efficiency that spoke of years of running a household, while Rio expertly handled the stove. They moved in perfect rhythm, exchanging teasing remarks and the occasional touch.

 

 

All week, Nicky’s excitement was absolutely contagious. From the moment he woke up to the minute his head hit the pillow at night, there wasn’t a moment when he wasn’t humming, singing, or dancing around the house. It was as though the entire world was building up to the choir performance, and Nicky was ready to take center stage.

 

On Tuesday morning, Rio walked into the living room to find him standing in the middle of the room with his arms dramatically raised. He was belting out one of his choir songs with all the gusto of a Broadway star, not caring in the least that his audience was just Rio, who had paused mid-step to take in the scene.

 

“Good morning, little star,” Rio said, her tone playful but warm as she leaned against the doorframe, smiling. “You’re ready to take over the world with that voice?”

 

Nicky froze mid-note, eyes wide. He grinned sheepishly and dropped his arms, suddenly self-conscious. “Was I too loud? Did I wake you and Mama?” he asked, wrinkling his nose.

 

“Not at all, we were already awake.” Rio replied, her smile never wavering. “And even if you did, it would have been the best alarm clock we could have asked for.”

 

His face brightened at that, and without missing a beat, he started singing again, his voice softer this time, but no less full of enthusiasm. Rio couldn’t help but chuckle, leaning against the doorframe as she watched him. She’d seen Nicky excited before, but this was a different level of energy—a pure, unbridled joy that made her heart so happy.

 

On Wednesay, the excitement was still growing. Agatha walked into the kitchen after school to find Nicky at the table, a set of papers sprawled out in front of him. His coloring book was open in front of him, but he was busy drawing on the side, what looked like a stage and stick figure children singing on it, his little voice filling the room with one song he was practicing over and over.

 

Rio, who had just come through the front door after a long day in the library couldn’t help but smile when she heard the little voice. She walked over, kissed Agatha sqaurely on the mouth before leaning down to look at the drawing. “You’ve been practicing a lot, huh?” she said gently. “Just make sure to leave a little room for fun. You want to enjoy it too.”

 

“I will! I promise,” Nicky said, his eyes twinkling with determination. “I’m going to do my best, and everyone’s going to cheer for me!”

 

“I think they’ll be cheering so loud, we won’t even hear you sing,” Agatha teased, her voice full of affection.

 

But Nicky didn’t hear that. He was already off, running back to the living room, where he immediately started practicing his moves, twirling in the middle of the space like an over-excited tornado.

 

Throughout the rest of the week, the energy was infectious. Even Rio, who usually preferred quiet moments with her books, found herself humming along to Nicky’s constant rehearsals. By Thursday afternoon, he was beyond ready, practically bouncing with excitement every time someone mentioned the performance. He couldn’t stop talking about it, asking everyone a million questions about what to expect, how they were going to cheer for him, and what he should wear.

 

“I want to wear my special blue shirt,” he said that evening while eating dinner, his fork halfway to his mouth. “You know, the one with the stars on it. It’ll make me look like a rock star, like Rio and her band.”

 

“I think that sounds perfect, but maybe underneath you actual uniform, don't you think?,” Agatha said, a soft smile tugging at her lips as she met Rio’s gaze across the table.

 

 

On Friday night, the house had quieted down after the flurry of activity surrounding dinner and Nicky’s ever-present excitement. Agatha had finally managed to convince Nicky that it was time for bed, even though he was still buzzing with energy, asking her if she’d come to his room to help him pick out the perfect outfit for the next day.

 

Now, in the peaceful silence of the living room, Rio found herself kneeling at the small wooden table in front of the couch, the soft glow of the lamp casting gentle shadows on the walls. She had quietly pulled out a piece of poster board and was carefully decorating it, her focus entirely on the little sign she was making. It wasn’t anything extravagant, just a simple phrase in big, bold letters: Go Nicky! You’re a star!

 

She smirked slightly to herself, feeling a little silly for going all out with a cheer sign for a school choir performance. She wasn’t even sure Nicky would need it, but there was something about the idea of being there with him, fully invested in his moment, that made her feel like she had to do something extra.

 

As she finished, she paused to study the sign, biting her lip in slight hesitation. “Okay, maybe this is a little much,” she murmured to herself.

 

Just then, she heard soft footsteps approaching from behind. She looked over her shoulder to see Agatha standing in the doorway, a knowing smile on her lips.

 

“I should’ve known,” Agatha said with a playful grin, crossing her arms. “You’re making a sign for him?”

 

Rio blushed slightly, trying to hide her unease behind a sheepish smile. “I know, I know. It feels a little silly, but I want to make sure he knows we’re both cheering him on. And… well, I guess I’m just caught up in the excitement.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, her smile warming with genuine affection. She walked over to Rio, gently sitting down behind her on the couch and looking at the sign over her shoulder. “It’s not silly,” she said softly, her voice rich with fondness. “You’re invested in him, in us, and that means everything.”

 

Rio didn’t know why, but hearing Agatha say that made something inside her tighten with emotion. She hadn’t realized how much she’d come to care about Nicky in such a short time—how deeply she wanted to be a part of his world, of their world. The sign, the excitement, even the small things she did to show up for him, felt like more than just little gestures. They felt like they meant something bigger, something deeper.

 

She glanced up at Agatha, unsure of what to say. Agatha smiled softly, her eyes searching Rio’s face.

 

“You’re really doing this, aren’t you?” Agatha asked, her voice low but full of admiration. “You’re fully committed to him, to us.”

 

Rio shrugged, the sudden weight of the question settling in. “I don’t know, it just feels right. I mean, it’s Nicky. I want him to know I care. I guess this is how it’s happening.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened even more, and she reached out, gently brushing her hand against Rio’s. “It’s not just that,” she said, her voice now tinged with warmth. “You’ve only been a part of his life for a little while, and yet… you’re so all in. You’re making a sign, planning to cheer him on. It’s not just about the performance, Rio. It’s about how much you love him. And I think he knows that. He’s going to feel it tomorrow.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered in her chest as she looked at Agtaha, realizing the depth of the bond that was already forming between her and Nicky. It wasn’t just about moving in together, about plants or signs or even a simple school choir show. It was about the way she felt a sense of belonging with them, a new, growing family that felt more like home with each passing day.

 

“I guess I am all in,” Rio admitted softly, the words feeling natural, as if they had always been there. She paused before adding with a teasing smile, “But I still think a sign for a school choir is a little over the top.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her eyes twinkling with affection as she leaned over, pressing a kiss to the side of Rio’s head. “I think it’s perfect. I can’t wait to see Nicky’s face when he sees it.”

 

Rio smiled, feeling a lightness in her chest. “Yeah… me too.”

 

For a moment, there was a comfortable silence between them, the only sound in the room the soft rustle of paper and the distant hum of the house settling. as she leaned back to rest her back on Agatha’s legs, Rio felt the weight of Agatha’s gaze on her from behind, full of love and quiet pride, and something stirred deep within her—something that told her this, right here, right now, was where she was meant to be.

 

“So,” Agatha said after a beat, her voice teasing again. “What do you think—should I make a sign too, or will that be too much?”

 

Rio laughed, her heart full as she shook her head. “We might have to make a whole row of signs at this rate.”

 

Agatha grinned, her eyes sparkling with mischief. “Now that’s an idea. But, for now, let’s just focus on cheering him on. He’s going to be amazing, and we’re going to be there, cheering louder than anyone.”

 

Rio nodded, her heart swelling as she finished the final touches on the sign. She didn’t need a fancy gesture to know she was part of something real. She had everything she needed right here.

 

 

The morning of Nicky’s big performance arrived with the sun shining brightly through the windows, casting a warm golden glow over the house. Rio was bustling around the kitchen, preparing lunch for the small gathering they had planned before heading to the school for the choir show. The excitement in the house was palpable, though Nicky’s nervous energy was just as noticeable as his enthusiasm.

 

“Rio,” Nicky called, his voice a mix of excitement and worry as he sat in the living room, his hands under his legs to keep them from flailing about, “What if I forget the words? What if my voice cracks? What if—”

 

Rio caught him mid-sentence, walking over and kneeling beside him. She gently cupped his face in her hands, forcing him to stop his anxious bouncing. “Nicky, you’ve been practicing all week, right? And you’re going to do amazing. We’re all so proud of you.” She smiled warmly at him, brushing a stray lock of hair from his forehead. “You’ve got this.”

 

He nodded, though his eyes still seemed unsure. “But what if I mess up?”

 

“You won’t, and even if you do, it’s okay” Rio reassured him, giving him a soft squeeze of the shoulders. “We’ll be there cheering you on, no matter what happens, okay?”

 

Nicky nodded again, his small hands fiddling with the hem of his shirt. Just then, there was a knock at the door, and Rio smiled as she opened it to reveal Lilia, standing with a warm smile and a basket of freshly baked bread under her arm.

 

“Hello, my loves!” Lilia greeted, stepping inside with a cheerful air, her presence always bringing a sense of calm with it. “I thought I’d bring something special to keep our energy up before the big performance.”

 

“Lilia!” Nicky shouted excitedly, running over to her and wrapping his arms around her legs. She bent down to hug him tightly, ruffling his hair affectionately.

 

“Hey there, superstar,” Lilia said warmly, standing up and giving Rio a knowing look. “How are you feeling, sweet boy?”

 

“I’m nervous,” Nicky admitted with a small frown, looking down at his shoes. “But also excited. I really want to make you proud, Grandma Lilia.”

 

Lilia smiled gently, bending down to his level. “You don’t need to worry about that. We’re all so proud of you already. Just get up there and have fun. Your voice is beautiful, my sweet sweet boy, just let everybody hear it.”

 

Nicky smiled shyly at her, his nerves slowly melting away under Lilia’s calming words. He seemed to grow just a little more confident at the thought of her support.

 

Agatha appeared in the doorway at that moment, holding Nicky’s neatly folded choir uniform in her hands. The crisp white shirt and deep navy trousers looked freshly pressed, proving the care she’d put into preparing for the afternoon. Her face lit up when she spotted Lilia standing near Rio.

 

“Hello, Lilia,” Agatha said warmly, stepping forward. “I’m so glad you could make it today!”

 

Lilia smiled, her eyes crinkling at the corners as she opened her arms. “Agatha, of course, I wouldn’t miss this for the world.” The two women embraced briefly, the kind of hug that spoke of mutual respect and shared affection.

 

Agatha pulled back, one hand still lightly resting on Lilia’s shoulders, while the other held the little uniform out of the way so it wouldn’t get crinkled. “Nicky’s been so excited to see you. He’s been practicing non-stop,” she said with a fond chuckle, her gaze shifting toward her son.

 

Agatha smiled warmly and turned to her son. “Alright, baby, it’s time to get ready. Let’s make sure everything’s perfect for you,” she said, holding out his uniform.

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically, taking the clothes with care. “Okay, Mama! But don’t forget, you have to sit in the front row with Grandma Lilia and Rio so I can see you when I’m singing!”

 

“I wouldn’t dream of sitting anywhere else,” Agatha promised, smoothing a hand over his hair before guiding him upstairs toward his room to change.

 

Rio moved toward the kitchen, Lilia in tow, to finish the last of the lunch as Agatha and Nicky went upstairs. From the stairs, they could hear the soft sound of Agatha talking to Nicky, probably giving him a pep talk or reminding him to breathe and relax.

 

As she finished putting the final touches on the meal, she could feel her excitement growing as well. Seeing Nicky so nervous yet excited, the palpable tension in the house, made her realize just how much she cared.

 

Nicky came back downstairs a few minutes later, now dressed in his choir uniform. His hair was neatly combed, and he looked a little more at ease, though his nerves still lingered in the air.

 

He looked around at the group, giving Rio and Lilia a quick, shy smile. “I’m ready. I think I’m ready.”

 

Agatha followed closely behind, grinning at how adorable Nicky looked, his uniform a perfect fit. She placed a hand on Nicky’s shoulder, giving him an encouraging squeeze. “You look great, baby. You’re going to rock it out there.”

 

The group gathered around the table, sitting down together for a quick lunch before they would head off to the school. Lilia’s bread was warm and fresh, and Rio had made a light salad with a few sides. The conversation was light, with laughter echoing through the room as they shared stories, teasing Nicky gently, and encouraging him to focus on enjoying the experience. Rio couldn’t help but smile as she watched Agatha and Lilia interact so easily, like they had always been part of the same circle.

 

As lunch came to a close, Nicky was feeling a little more at ease. His nervous energy had shifted into excitement, and he was already talking about the choir performance in detail. But amid the conversation, something seemed to linger in his mind.

 

Lilia had just passed him another piece of bread when Nicky suddenly looked up from his plate, a curious expression on his face. “Hey, Rio,” Nicky asked suddenly, his voice tentative, “You call Lilia ‘mom’ sometimes, but not all the time. Isn’t she your mom all the time?”

 

The question hung in the air, quiet but thoughtful. Rio froze for a moment, her fork hovering just above her plate as she glanced at Lilia. She wasn’t sure how to explain it—how to answer in a way that Nicky would understand. It was true—Rio did call Lilia “Mom” occasionally, but it wasn’t consistent. It was a word that slipped out only in certain moments, when warmth and familiarity welled up so strongly that it felt natural. And Nicky, ever observant, had picked up on that. His gaze flickered between Rio and Lilia now, full of quiet curiosity.

 

Lilia broke the silence first, her voice soft and inviting. “That’s a very good question, Nicky,” she said, her tone carrying no judgment, just patience. She glanced at Rio, offering her the space to respond.

 

Rio exhaled slowly, offering Nicky a small, reassuring smile. “Well, kiddo,” she started, setting her fork down to give him her full attention. “Lilia’s to me kind of like your Mama to you. She didn’t raise me from when I was a baby or even a little girl, but… she’s been there for me in the ways that matter most, just like a mom would be.” She paused, her voice softening. “I guess calling her ‘Mom’ isn’t something I do all the time, but it’s how I feel about her. Does that make sense?”

 

Nicky furrowed his brow, clearly taking her words to heart. He traced the edge of his plate with his fingers, his thoughtful gaze darting between Rio and Lilia as if piecing together a puzzle.

 

“So…” he said slowly, tilting his head, “Lilia’s your mom, but she hasn’t always been?”

 

Lilia’s smile widened, a warm glow in her eyes. “That’s exactly right, darling boy,” she said gently, reaching over to tousle his hair. “You’ve got it.”

 

Nicky’s face brightened a little at the praise, but he wasn’t done thinking. “So… you call her ‘Mom’ when it feels like she’s your mom?” he asked, looking back at Rio for confirmation.

 

Rio nodded, her smile soft and steady. “Exactly. It’s not about how often I say it. It’s about what it means when I do.”

 

Lilia chuckled, her voice light and reassuring. “Sometimes things don’t need a perfect explanation, Nicky. We just do what feels right in the moment, don’t we?”

 

Nicky tilted his head, his small face scrunching up in deep concentration as he worked through everything Rio and Lilia had said. For a moment, the room felt quiet, the soft clinking of plates the only sound as he mulled it over. Then, he gave a little nod, his expression clearing as if a light had just switched on in his mind.

 

His bright eyes settled on Rio, lingering longer than usual, as though trying to piece together something deeper about her. “Okay,” he finally said, his voice carrying the quiet confidence of someone who had cracked an important mystery. “I think I get it now.”

 

He flashed them a small, satisfied smile before his attention turned back to his plate.

 

Rio and Lilia exchanged a quiet, knowing look, as Agatha watched on. They could tell Nicky was processing what they’d said, and though he didn’t press further, it was clear he understood—perhaps not in the way an adult might, but in his own, quiet way.

 

Across the table, Agatha watched the interaction unfold with a quiet smile, her hands wrapped around her glass. She chose not to interject, knowing Nicky needed the space to work it out in his own way. Still, she felt a deep sense of pride in her son’s empathy and thoughtfulness—and in Rio and Lilia’s ability to handle his questions with such grace.

 

As the conversation shifted to lighter topics, Nicky’s excitement returned in full force. He launched into an animated description of his upcoming choir performance, detailing every note, step, and gesture he planned to make on stage.

 

Rio leaned back in her chair, her smile growing as she listened to his exuberant chatter. Lilia joined in, asking him questions and encouraging his enthusiasm, while Agatha observed, her heart swelling. She had decided to not say anything during the conversation, but she knew her son, and she couldn’t help feeling like she knew exactly where this was going.

 

 

As the time for the performance drew nearer, the four of them gathered their things and and piled into Lilia’s car. Nicky’s excitement bubbled over as he chattered about the choir songs, but it was Agatha who seemed to be the most anxious. She had barely stopped moving since they’d finished lunch, fussing over Nicky’s hair, adjusting his clothes, and reminding him to take a deep breath and relax.

 

“Did you have everything you need, baby?” Agatha asked for what felt like the tenth time, smoothing a wrinkle in his shirt that didn’t even exist. “You’re going to do great, sweetheart, but remember—take it easy before the performance, okay?”

 

Nicky, trying to contain his excitement, rolled his eyes playfully but nodded. “Yes, Mama. I have everything. You’ve asked me like a million times.”

 

Agatha smiled, a little sheepishly, but her concern never wavered. She leaned down and kissed Nicky on the top of his head. “I know, I just want you to be ready. You’re going to shine out there, I know it.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but smile at the sight. Agatha’s love for Nicky was undeniable, and it made her heart swell to see how much care she took with every little detail. She couldn’t help but chuckle softly, leaning over to Agatha and teasing, “I think Nicky might just be able to handle this one on his own, love.”

 

Agatha glanced over at Rio, giving her a playful glare, but it was clear she wasn’t offended. “I know, but I’m his mom. Let me have my moment. He’s my little star and my baby, and I just want everything to go perfectly.”

 

Rio smiled, appreciative of Agatha’s devotion. She could see how much Agatha adored her son, how fiercely she wanted to protect him, and how deeply she believed in his potential.

 

Lilia, who was sitting beside Rio in the passenger seat, leaned over and whispered with a smile, “I think Agatha’s going to need a nap after this, don’t you?”

 

Rio laughed softly, glancing back at Agatha in the rearview mirror, who was adjusting Nicky’s collar one last time. “I’m starting to think she might need one right now.”

 

They all arrived at the school shortly after, the air buzzing with excitement. Nicky was practically bouncing in his seat, barely able to keep still as they walked towards the school auditorium. Agatha, still fussing over him, kept a steady hand on his shoulder, making sure he felt secure and ready.

 

As they reached the door to the auditorium, Nicky turned to Rio and Agatha, his face beaming with excitement. “Are you guys ready to see me sing?”

 

Agatha kneeled down to his level and gave him a soft kiss on the cheek. “I was born ready, sweetheart. Just remember to have fun, okay?”

 

Rio smiled and ruffled Nicky’s hair. “You’re going to do amazing, kiddo. We’re so proud of you.”

 

The group moved into the auditorium, finding their seats. Agatha settled in beside Rio, who took her sign out, her mom gaze never straying far from Nicky, who was already making his way backstage with the other choir members. As the lights dimmed, Agatha squeezed Rio’s hand, her excitement palpable.

 

 

As the choir took their places on stage, the atmosphere in the auditorium shifted from nervous energy to real enthusiasm. The lights softened, casting a warm glow on the performers. Nicky was right at the front, his eyes scanning the crowd before settling on Agatha and Rio. A little wave from the front of the stage, and Rio couldn’t help but return it with a wide, encouraging grin. He gave her a thumbs-up, the excitement in his face infectious.

 

The music started, a soft, harmonious hum that filled the room, and Nicky’s voice joined in, clear and bright. As the song continued, Rio’s eyes found him again, his voice standing out with such clarity and confidence. It wasn’t just his tone that caught her attention—it was the effort and heart he poured into every note, reminded her of the dance recital all those months ago. The way he moved with the music, his focus unwavering, made Rio feel as though he was the only one in the room. He wasn’t just singing; he was performing, putting his heart into every lyric, his face lighting up with joy.

 

Next to her, Agatha sat with her gaze fixed on Nicky, her expression a mix of admiration and pride. Rio felt Agatha’s hand gently rest on her knee, a quiet, but intense gesture that spoke volumes. It was a shared moment of pride, a wordless acknowledgment of how far Nicky had come and how proud they both were of him.

 

Rio, unable to hide her smile, felt her heart swell in her chest. She was proud of him too—proud of how much effort he had put into this moment. It made Rio’s heart ache in the best way possible. She didn’t know when it had happened, but somewhere along the way, Nicky had become someone she loved deeply. He was a part of her life now—he was her family, just as much as Agatha was.

 

She glanced at Agatha, who was watching Nicky with a tenderness that made Rio’s chest tighten. There was so much love in Agatha’s gaze, a quiet pride in everything Nicky did, and Rio could see how much this moment meant to her. She gently squeezed Agatha’s hand on her knee, grateful for the way they shared this, how their hearts both swelled for the boy who had brought them all closer together.

 

When the song finally reached its crescendo for the first song and the last note lingered in the air, the audience erupted into applause, and Rio joined in enthusiastically, her hands clapping together with pride. Nicky’s grin was so wide it almost took over his entire face, and Rio couldn’t help but laugh with happiness at the sight, before getting ready for the second song.

 

As the choir’s voices filled the room, Rio’s attention was completely absorbed by Nicky. His face was a picture of pure joy, his eyes sparkling with excitement, and his smile wide and uncontainable as he sang. She couldn’t take her eyes off him.

 

For a brief moment, Rio was overwhelmed. Her chest tightened, and she felt an emotional swell she hadn’t expected. It was as if a dam inside her had broken open, flooding her with the realization of how much Nicky had come to mean to her. It wasn’t just the boy she had come to know and love in bits and pieces; it was the part of him that had woven itself so deeply into the fabric of her own life. He wasn’t just Agatha’s son anymore—he was her family too, and that truth hit her harder than she anticipated.

 

A lump formed in her throat as her eyes filled with tears, the feeling so raw, so beautiful. She hadn’t known how deeply she had already fallen for him. She hadn’t known how much he had changed her life simply by being in it.

 

Rio blinked quickly, trying to regain composure, but the emotion wasn’t going anywhere. She smiled, wiping away the first tear that slid down her cheek, though she didn’t bother to hide the warmth that spread across her face. Her heart ached with love for this young boy who had so easily become a part of her world.

 

It was in that moment that Agatha, sensing the depth of Rio’s feelings, subtly reached for her hand. Rio’s fingers instinctively curled around Agatha’s, and Agatha gave her a gentle, reassuring squeeze.

 

Rio couldn’t stop the smile that crept onto her lips, her heart full, her chest light despite the tears. She squeezed Agatha’s hand back, silently grateful for the understanding between them. Agatha’s touch was grounding, a reminder that she wasn’t alone in this, that they were in this together.

 

Rio’s eyes never left Nicky, but she knew Agatha was watching her, her presence a comforting anchor. The tears that had threatened to overwhelm her settled into a quiet contentment, and she couldn’t help but smile as she saw how much joy Nicky was radiating.

 

The song ended, and the applause erupted. Rio’s hands joined the others once again, clapping with genuine pride and joy. Nicky was grinning, his eyes sparkling as he took in the praise, but Rio saw him looking toward them too, seeking their approval. And when he caught their eyes, his grin widened, and Rio’s heart swelled again.

 

Agatha leaned in, her voice low and filled with emotion. “He’s amazing, isn’t he?”

 

Rio nodded, her voice soft. “He really is.”

 

Agatha smiled, her thumb gently stroking the back of Rio’s hand. “We’re so lucky, all three of us.”

 

Rio nodded, her gaze still on Nicky. She could only agree. Her eyes met Agatha’s for a moment, brown meeting blue in a mix of love and pride, before settling back on Nicky, who was beaming up at the stage.

 

Lilia leaned over Rio, her voice loud enough to cover the applause that kept erupting all over the room. “He was incredible. I think he’s made his own fan club.” She smiled warmly, her heart full of pride. “You’ve done an amazing job, Agatha. And he’s done an amazing job.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened as she watched Nicky, her eyes sparkling. “I think we’ve all done an amazing job.” Her hand gently squeezed Rio’s knee again, this time with a quiet sense of contentment.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Your comments honestly make my day—you have no idea how much they mean to me. (And for those who leave longer ones, please never apologize for their length as some of you do; they almost always bring me to tears, I swear!)

Thank you so much for sharing your ideas—I’m definitely borrowing some of them for the upcoming chapters! And please, feel free to share more anytime. 😊

The Choir Show - Part II

Chapter Notes

NIcky chapter part 2!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

Midwinter spring is its own season

Sempiternal though sodden towards sundown,

Suspended in time, between pole and tropic.

When the short day is brightest, with frost and fire,

The brief sun flames the ice, on pond and ditches,

In windless cold that is the heart's heat,

Reflecting in a watery mirror

A glare that is blindness in the early afternoon.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

As the choir began to file off stage, Nicky’s eyes immediately sought them out. The moment he spotted them, he took off running, his excitement palpable in the way his feet hardly seemed to touch the ground. His face was alight with joy, his eyes wide with pride.

 

“Did you see me? Did you hear me?” he asked eagerly, his voice practically bubbling over with excitement. He barely gave them a chance to respond before Rio was already pulling him into a big, tight hug. She squeezed him close, her heart soaring.

 

“You were incredible, Nicky,” Rio said, her voice full of admiration. “You were the star up there.”

 

Nicky’s arms wrapped around her tightly, soaking in the praise. Agatha stood beside them, a proud smile on her face as she gently ruffled his hair.

 

“You were absolutely amazing,” Agatha added, her voice full of affection, as Nicky turned to her to bury his face in his mother’s stomach. Agatha bent down to pick him up, placing him on her hip, rejoicing in the fact that he wasn’t too big yet for her not to be able to do it anymore. “I’ve never seen anyone shine like you did up there. You’re so special, Nicky. You really are.”

 

Nicky grinned, his face flushed with the joy of their praise. But it was Lilia’s voice that caught his attention next.

 

“You were the best out there, Nicky,” Lilia said, her tone full of warmth and pride. “The best grandson any grandmother could ask for.” She leaned in, her eyes twinkling. “And you’ve got Rio’s talent for music. You’re going places, kid, I can tell.”

 

At the mention of Rio’s talent, Nicky’s eyes lit up even more. He beamed at her from his spot in Agatha’s arms, his heart swelling with pride at the comparison. It was the kind of validation that made everything feel just a little more real. He wasn’t just performing for his own satisfaction anymore; he was doing it for the people who meant the most to him, and hearing their words made him feel on top of the world.

 

Nicky grinned even wider, his chest puffed out a little. “Thanks, everyone!” he said, his voice gleeful, and then he looked back at Rio. “I think I want to sing even more now! And I’ll learn how to play the drums and I’m gonna be like you someday!”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “You’re already a star, Nicky. Keep singing, and you’ll go far.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened as Nicky wiggled to be put down and she took Rio’s hand, her voice tender. “He’s already so much more than I ever imagined.”

 

The group lingered for a moment, all of them basking in the warmth of the day’s accomplishment and the joy of Nicky’s success.

 

 

As they made their way out of the auditorium, Nicky tugged on Rio’s hand, his excitement still bubbling over. “Wait! I want to show you something!” he insisted, his eyes shining with enthusiasm. Rio chuckled, glancing at Agatha, who shrugged with a smile and gestured for Rio to follow. Lilia gently said she was going to wait for them outside, sensing this moment was just for them.

 

Nicky led them through the school hallways, his little feet quick as he nearly skipped with anticipation. Finally, they arrived at his classroom, and he pushed open the door, eager to show Rio everything. The walls were covered with colorful posters and student work, and Nicky immediately started pointing to various drawings he was particularly proud of.

 

“These are my pictures!” he said, practically beaming as he gestured to the collection pinned up on a corkboard. “I did these in art class! Look!” He rushed to a drawing he had made of a giant rocket ship, then moved on to one of a dog with three tails.

 

Rio smiled at each one, admiring his creativity, but it was one particular drawing that made her pause.
