It was a picture of a little boy standing between two women, one with very long brown hair and blue eyes and the other with dark, long hair and brown eyes. The boy in the middle was smiling brightly, his arms outstretched as if he was holding both of their hands. The two adults on either side of him were smiling down at him with as much warmth and affection that stick figures could convey.

 

Nicky watched her reaction closely, his expression hopeful. “I drew this one last week,” he explained, his voice low as he pointed at the image. “It’s… it’s me with you and Mama.” His face was a little shy as he looked between Rio and Agatha, but there was something so tender in the way he had drawn them together—something that spoke volumes about how he saw their place in his life.

 

Rio felt her heart melt at the sight of the drawing. There was something so simple and pure about it, and it took her a moment to collect herself. She crouched down to Nicky’s level, gently placing a hand on his shoulder.

 

“This is beautiful, Nicky,” she said softly, her voice thick with emotion. “You’re so talented.” She smiled warmly, her heart full. “I love it. You’ve captured exactly what it feels like, being with you.”

 

Nicky beamed, clearly pleased with her response, and his eyes sparkled as he said, “I’m glad you like it! I drew it because I want you and Mama to always be with me.” He paused, looking at the picture with a quiet kind of understanding, as if he knew just how special it was to him.

 

Agatha, who had been standing by the door watching with a proud smile, stepped forward. “Nicky, that’s perfect,” she said, her voice filled with emotion. “I think you’ve made a masterpiece.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but feel a lump form in her throat at Nicky’s words, the sincerity in his voice making her chest ache in the best possible way. She hadn’t realized how deeply he too already saw them as a family, how much he wanted them to be together, always.

 

Nicky, completely unaware of the impact his simple drawing had, looked up at them both, eyes full of joy. “You’ll always be with me, right?” he asked, his tone full of trust and certainty.

 

Rio met Agatha’s gaze, and for a moment, everything felt perfect. She smiled, her heart full of love for this little boy who had so easily become such an important part of her life. “Always, Nicky,” she said, her voice steady but full of emotion. “We’re here, and we’re not going anywhere.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up at her words, and he ran over to her, throwing his arms around her in a tight hug. “Thanks, Rio!” he exclaimed, his voice muffled by her shoulder. “I’m so happy!”

 

Agatha stepped forward, placing a gentle hand on Nicky’s back and the other on Rio’s, keeping them close. “We’re all happy, sweetheart,” she said softly, her voice filled with warmth. “You’ve brought so much joy to us today, and everyday.”

 

Rio pulled Nicky back gently and met Agatha’s gaze, a silent understanding passing between them. This—this was their family, right here, in this small classroom, surrounded by Nicky’s drawings and the love that had grown between them all.  Agatha leaned down to kiss Rio with Nicky still sandwiched between them, before they made their way back to the hall where Lilia was waiting for them.

 

 

After Nicky’s excitement had died down, the four of them headed out into the cool afternoon air, their laughter still lingering as they made their way to the small ice cream shop just a few blocks away from the school. Nicky, who was still practically glowing from his performance, bounced along between Agatha and Rio, chattering non-stop about how much fun he’d had and how his friends and him had loved being on stage.

 

Lilia, walking beside Rio, their arms linked together, looked at her pseudo-daughter with a soft smile. “You looked so proud of him, Rio,” she said, her voice warm with affection. “I can tell how much he means to you.”

 

Rio glanced at Lilia, her heart full. “He means the world to me,” she replied quietly. She glanced at Agatha, who had her hand trapped in Nicky’s, her face lit up with pride and love. “I think he’s becoming someone really special.”

 

Agatha, overhearing, smiled and nodded. “He is,” she agreed, her voice full of affection. “And he’s lucky to have you both in his life.” Her eyes softened as she glanced down at Nicky, who was practically bouncing with energy, unable to contain his excitement.

 

When they reached the ice cream shop, the little bell above the door jingled as they entered, and Nicky immediately ran to the counter, his eyes scanning the flavors with intense concentration. “I want the biggest one ever!” he declared, his hands on his hips in a stance that was both determined and adorable.

 

Agatha chuckled, following him up to the counter. “I think you’ll need to pace yourself, sweatheart,” she said with a teasing grin.

 

Nicky pressed his nose against the glass display, his eyes wide as he examined the colorful assortment of flavors. “I want… chocolate!” he announced before immediately changing his mind. “No, wait! Vanilla! Or maybe both?”

 

Agatha chuckled, placing a gentle hand on his shoulder. “How about we get you a scoop of each, hmm? It’s a special day, after all.”

 

Nicky grinned up at her, nodding eagerly. “Okay! And sprinkles, too!”

 

Rio stayed back, watching with a smile as Nicky eagerly pointed to his choice, clearly excited to enjoy a treat after such a big day. Lilia sidled up beside her, nudging her gently with her elbow. “You see how Agatha is proud of Nicky? That’s exactly how I feel about you.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled, and she took a deep breath, glancing over at Agatha and Nicky. “I never thought I’d have this,” she admitted softly. “But now that I do, I can’t imagine my life without them.”

 

Lilia smiled gently, her eyes twinkling. “That’s the way it goes sometimes, sweet girl. You just find where you belong when you least expect it.”

 

Agatha, having ordered for Nicky, walked over to Rio and Lilia. She handed Nicky his ice cream, and the little boy immediately turned to Rio, holding it up to show her his choice with a proud grin.

 

“Look, Rio!” he said eagerly, holding up the massive cone with two scoops of chocolate and vanilla, the ice cream nearly threatening to topple over. “I got the biggest one like I said!”

 

Rio chuckled and bent down to his level, her hands on her knees as she smiled at him. “That’s impressive, Nicky,” she said with a grin. “You’ll have to make sure to share some with me.”

 

Nicky nodded seriously. “Of course! I’ll even save some for you,” he said, his voice full of determination. “But only if you promise to try the chocolate!”

 

Agatha, watching the exchange with a soft smile, leaned in and kissed Rio’s cheek gently. “You’re doing great,” she whispered, her voice low enough that only Rio could hear. “I’m proud of you.”

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat at the tenderness in Agatha’s voice. She looked at her partner, her eyes full of love, and nodded. “I’m proud of us,” she said quietly. “I’m really happy, Agatha. Thank you for giving me this.”

 

Nicky interrupted their moment by tugging on Rio’s arm, eager for them to sit down. “Come on, you need to get your own ice creams now!” he said, his voice full of excitement. “I can’t wait any longer!”

 

The three women chuckled and went back to the counter. Rio studied the options, trying not to laugh at the sheer delight on the boy’s face. Lilia leaned over, nudging her shoulder. “Don’t overthink it, Rio,” she teased. “It’s just ice cream.”

 

Rio grinned back, finally settling on a classic vanilla cone with caramel drizzle. Lilia chose pistachio, and Agatha settled on mint chocolate chip, earning a scoff from Rio.

 

“Don’t even think about kissing me after that,” she teased, eying the green and brown monstrosity in Agatha’s hand.

 

“Not a fan of my choice, love?” Agatha teased back, bringing her ice-cream closer to Rio’s face, almost smearing her cheek with it.

 

“If I wanted to eat toothpaste, I would eat the one in the bathroom, way less expensive.” She replied, taking a step back to avoid the ice cream touching her face.

 

Agatha childishly stuck out her tongue and took Rio’s hand with her unoccupied one, leading her after Nicky and Lilia to a cozy booth by the window. Nicky’s cone was so tall he had to concentrate to keep it balanced, but he attacked it with gusto, managing to get chocolate on his nose within seconds.

 

“Careful, baby,” Agatha warned, laughing as she handed him a napkin. “We don’t want your ice cream wearing you.”

 

Rio couldn’t stop smiling as she watched Nicky happily devour his treat, his chatter filling the air. He was still riding the high of his performance, describing every moment in vivid detail, including how he’d spotted them in the audience cheering him on.

 

“You were the best one on stage, you know,” Rio said, leaning over to tap the tip of his nose with her finger, leaving a little caramel smudge there. “And not just because we’re biased.”

 

Nicky giggled, wiping his nose with his napkin before turning to Lilia. “Did you like my songs, Grandma?”

 

Lilia’s face lit up at the nickname, and she nodded emphatically. “You were amazing, sweetheart,” she said warmly. 

 

The compliment made Nicky beam, and he took another enthusiastic bite of his ice cream before announcing, “I’m gonna sing more songs for you when we get home!”

 

Agatha chuckled, brushing a hand over his hair. “I think we’d all love that.”

 

  

After finishing their ice cream, the four of them stepped out into the crisp evening air. Nicky was still buzzing with energy, skipping along the sidewalk between Agatha and Rio, holding their hands tightly. Lilia walked a few steps behind them, a soft smile on her face as she watched the little family.

 

When they reached the spot where Lilia had parked her car, she turned to Nicky and crouched down to his level. “You did so well today, sweet boy,” she said, brushing a stray curl from his forehead. “I’m so proud of you. Keep practicing those songs, okay?”

 

“I will!” Nicky promised, throwing his arms around her neck in an exuberant hug. “Bye, Lilia! See you soon!”

 

Lilia stood, giving Rio a knowing smile before pulling her into a hug as well. “Take care of them,” she murmured, her voice filled with warmth.

 

“Always,” Rio promised, her voice soft but sure.

 

Lilia gave Agatha a nod, her approval evident, before climbing into her car and waving as she drove away.

 

As they watched her taillights disappear down the street, Nicky tugged on Agatha’s hand. “Can we go home now? I wanna show Rio my other drawings!”

 

Agatha chuckled, wrapping an arm around his shoulders as they started walking again. “Of course, sweetheart. Let’s get you home.”

 

The walk was peaceful, the cool breeze carrying the scent of leaves and rain. Nicky chatted excitedly about the songs he wanted to learn next, his little voice filling the quiet streets. Agatha and Rio exchanged fond glances as they listened, their hands occasionally brushing as they walked side by side.

 

When they finally arrived at the house, Nicky burst through the door, already heading toward his room. “Come on, Rio! You have to see this one!” he called over his shoulder.

 

Rio laughed, slipping off her coat and following him down the hall. Agatha lingered in the entryway for a moment, watching them with a tender smile before locking the door behind her.

 

As Nicky excitedly shuffled through his stack of drawings, Rio knelt beside him on the carpet, giving her full attention to each one he held up. There were rainbows and stick figures, animals and houses. Each one came with an enthusiastic explanation of the story behind it.

 

“This one is a dragon, but he’s a nice dragon and he lives in the river,” Nicky said, holding up a colorful scribble with pride. “He helps the knights instead of fighting them!”

 

Rio grinned. “I like that idea. A dragon with a good heart. And a river is good place to live.”

 

Nicky beamed and quickly grabbed another drawing, this one of a treehouse with three figures beneath it. “This is us,” he explained. “That’s me, and that’s Mama, and that’s you!” He pointed to each stick figure in turn, their smiles clearly drawn in.

 

Rio felt her chest tighten with emotion as she looked at the simple but heartfelt drawing. “You really like drawing us together, don’t you?” she asked softly, her voice catching.

 

Nicky nodded, his curls bouncing. “Because we’re a team now, right?”

 

Before Rio could respond, Agatha appeared in the doorway, leaning against the frame with a soft smile. “That’s right, sweetheart,” she said, her voice full of warmth. “We’re the best team there is.”

 

Nicky turned back to Rio. “Can we put this one in the living room? So everyone can see it when they visit?”

 

Rio glanced at Agatha, who gave a small nod of encouragement. Smiling, Rio said, “Of course, Nicky. I think that’s a great idea.”

 

“Yay!” Nicky bounced to his feet, holding the drawing carefully. “I’m gonna go get some tape!”

 

As he dashed off, Rio rose to her feet, shaking her head fondly. Agatha stepped closer, slipping an arm around her waist. “You’re amazing with him, you know that?” Agatha murmured, her voice low.

 

Rio leaned into her, feeling the warmth of Agatha’s embrace. “He makes it easy,” she admitted.

 

Rio turned to look at her, her heart full. Before Agatha could respond, Nicky’s voice echoed from the other room. “I found the tape! I’m putting it up!”

 

Both women laughed softly and followed the sound of his voice to the living room, where Nicky was carefully sticking his masterpiece to the wall next to the window.

 

“Perfect,” Agatha said, stepping back to admire his work. “Now, I think we should get started on dinner, don’t you think my loves?”

 

“Please, Mama, can I stay here and play with my Legos instead?” Nicky askes, tunring his best puppy eyes to his mother.

 

“Okay, love. You stay here while Rio and I make dinner. But promise you’ll come as soon as we say it’s ready?” Agatha relented, already making her way to the kitchen, Rio in tow.

 

“Promise, Mama, thank you ! »

 

Soon enough, Rio found herself in the kitchen with Agatha, chopping vegetables while Nicky played in the living room. The scent of garlic and rosemary filled the air, mingling with the low hum of their casual conversation.

 

Agatha leaned casually against the counter, her sleeves rolled up, stirring the simmering pot of soup. She stole a glance at Rio, a playful smirk curling at the corners of her lips. “You know,” she said, her voice dripping with mock innocence, “if anyone at the university saw us like this, they’d probably have a heart attack.”

 

Rio snorted, shaking her head as she chopped a carrot with precision. “Oh, absolutely. ‘Dr. Harkness, the brilliant, terrifying genius, cooking dinner with her student? Scandalous!’” She affected a dramatic tone, one eyebrow raised in exaggerated shock.

 

“Not just any student,” Agatha added, her smirk widening, eyes glinting mischievously. “Her PhD student, and the best one, at that.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, though a smile tugged at her lips. “I think you’re a little biased, love.”

 

“Of course, I am,” Agatha teased, her tone light and knowing. Then, her eyes sparkled with playful accusation. “But don’t think for a second I haven’t noticed those lingering glances of yours, Miss Vidal.”

 

“Thanks for the reminder,” Rio shot back, though her cheeks flushed slightly, betraying her mock irritation. She dropped the sliced carrots into a bowl and pointed her knife at Agatha with a smirk. “And let’s not pretend you’re all sunshine and roses either. You’ve scared at least half the department into submission.”

 

Agatha laughed, her eyes flashing with mischief. “Fair point. But they love me for it.” She crossed her arms over her chest, her smirk turning sly, and leaned in slightly, lowering her voice as if sharing a secret. “But you, Rio Vidal, you’re the real scandal. Imagine the looks on your band groupies’ faces—your peers’ faces—if they knew you spent your evenings here, cooking soup with your professor, helping me untangle Nicky’s toy helicopters, and making those little signs for his choir shows. Oh, honey, your reputation would never survive.”

 

Rio couldn’t help herself—she burst out laughing, tilting her head back as the sound filled the kitchen. “Alright, fine, you win,” she said between breaths, her voice light with humor, before she put down the knife and hopped on the counter, sitting down in it gracefully. “But let’s be honest here—your ‘fearsome researcher’ reputation would take just as big a hit if they knew you hum lullabies to Nicky when he’s upset.”

 

Agatha gasped dramatically, one hand flying to her chest as if mortally wounded. “How dare you expose me like this?” she said, her voice full of mock horror.

 

Rio’s voice lowered to a near whisper, ensuring that Nicky couldn’t overhear. “Or if they knew about the nights when you make me your own." Her eyes twinkled with something more intimate as she leaned in closer."Over and over again.”

 

Agatha’s expression shifted in an instant. Her eyes darkened, and she placed the spoon she had been stirring with down on the counter with deliberate slowness. She stepped closer to Rio, closing the distance between them in a single fluid motion, invading her personal space with intent. Standing between Rio’s legs, she placed her arms on either side of her, trapping her in a sensual embrace. “Is that so, Miss Vidal?” she murmured, her voice low, a provocative edge to it. “Is that something you want again? Maybe tonight?”

 

Rio’s breath caught in her throat. Her heart raced as she looked up at Agatha, their faces mere inches apart. “Yes, Dr. Harkness, that’s exactly what I want,” she replied, her voice hushed but full of desire and certainty.

 

“Well, I’ll make sure you have it then”. Agatha replied and without another word, Agatha closed the gap between them, her lips crashing onto Rio’s in a fierce kiss that stole the breath from her lungs. Rio’s hands instantly found their way into Agatha’s long, brown hair, pulling her closer, if that was even possible. The world outside the kitchen ceased to exist, and all that mattered was the fire that flared between them.

 

When they finally pulled apart, both of them breathless, Agatha took a step back, her hands lingering on Rio’s thighs, grounding them both. Her voice softened, the teasing edge replaced by something more genuine, more resolute. “In all seriousness, though,” she said quietly, meeting Rio’s gaze with unwavering intensity, “if anyone judged us for this— for being here, making a life together— well, that’s their problem, not ours.”

 

Rio looked into Agatha’s eyes, the warmth and truth of her words settling into her chest like a comforting weight. Her smile softened, her voice quiet but steady. “Yeah,” she replied, her gaze never leaving Agatha’s. “You’re right. Let them think whatever they want.”

 

Agatha leaned in then, pressing a kiss to Rio’s temple, her lips lingering as she whispered, “That’s my girl.”

 

They turned back to their cooking, the moment hanging between them like a quiet promise. But before they could fully return to the task at hand, Agatha’s fingers brushed lightly along Rio’s waist, slipping beneath her shirt and lingering for just a beat longer than necessary. Rio’s breath hitched at the touch, a small smile tugging at her lips.

 

As dinner came together, Rio set the table while Agatha checked on Nicky in the living room. His giggles carried into the kitchen as Agatha pretended to wrestle one of his action figures away, her playful growl making Rio shake her head fondly.

 

When the table was set and everything was ready, Rio leaned against the doorframe, watching the two of them. Agatha sat cross-legged on the floor, holding up a toy dragon while Nicky explained its magical powers with animated gestures. The sight warmed Rio’s heart in ways she still wasn’t entirely used to.

 

“Alright, you two,” she called, her voice breaking through the moment. “Dinner’s ready. Dragons can wait.”

 

Nicky jumped up, already bounding toward the dining table. “Is it the soup?” he asked excitedly.

 

“Soup and your favorite garlic bread,” Rio confirmed as she ruffled his hair on his way past.

 

Agatha rose more slowly, smoothing down her shirt. “We’re spoiling him, you know,” she said teasingly as she joined Rio.

 

Rio grinned, tilting her head toward the dining room. “And who insists on baking cookies with him every weekend?”

 

“Touché,” Agatha admitted with a smirk, brushing past Rio as they headed to the table. “But if my memory is correct, you’re the one who baked cookies with him the very first time you were in this house babysitting, right?”

 

“Guilty as charged. But look at him! Who could say no to this little face?” Rio said, pointing slightly towards where Nicky was settling in his chair at the table.

 

Over dinner, Nicky’s excitement about his drawings, the choir show, and his new idea for a comic book spilled out in an endless stream of chatter. Rio and Agatha listened attentively, laughing at his wild ideas and encouraging his creativity.

 

At one point, as Rio reached for more bread, Nicky looked at her seriously. “Rio,” he said with his mouth full of soup, “can we do the dragons’ treehouse drawing together tomorrow? You’re really good at drawing trees.”

 

Rio paused mid-reach, glancing at Agatha, whose amused gaze met hers. “Of course, buddy,” Rio replied, her voice warm. “We can do that after breakfast, while I work on my thesis.”

 

“Yay!” Nicky beamed, already launching into detailed plans for their masterpiece.

 

Agatha leaned back in her chair, her gaze soft as it drifted between Rio and her son. Moments like these made her heart swell—this seamless, shared life they were building. She reached under the table, her fingers finding Rio’s and giving them a gentle squeeze.

 

Rio squeezed back without looking, though her small smile betrayed that she’d noticed. Dinner carried on with laughter and warmth, the three of them a perfect little team.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

Honestly guys, you are amazing, your comments always have me kicking my feet.
I love you all

Unwelcomed Judgment

Chapter Notes

Wow, 40 chapters already—and there’s still more to come! When I first started this little story, I had no idea where it was headed, and now look at it—it’s taken on a life of its own, and I wouldn’t have it any other way.

Thank you all so much for your incredible support and for sharing your thoughts with me. You’re truly the best, and honestly, you’re helping me get through life right now.

Love you all! 💜💚

(Oh and on a side note, this chapter is far from being my favorite, but oh well...)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 


*

*

*

 

The backward look behind the assurance

Of recorded history, the backward half-look

Over the shoulder, towards the primitive terror.

Now, we come to discover that the moments of agony

(Whether, or not, due to misunderstanding,

Having hoped for the wrong things or dreaded the wrong things,

Is not in question) are likewise permanent

With such permanence as time has.

 

                  (T.S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The morning at the house was unusually quiet, a rarity that Agatha relished. She had just returned from dropping Nicky off at school and was now savoring the stillness with a steaming cup of tea in the living room. The faint hum of the kettle and the soft rustling of leaves from the numerous houseplants were the only sounds accompanying her as she mentally braced herself for the impending faculty meeting.

 

The tranquility was abruptly interrupted by the chime of the doorbell. Agatha frowned slightly at the unexpected visitor, setting her mug down with deliberate care. She smoothed her cardigan, already summoning the polite demeanor she kept ready for such intrusions, and walked to the door.

 

On the porch stood Professor Eleanor Crenshaw, an elder professor of the English department, cane in hand and an air of undeniable authority about her. Eleanor had a habit of arriving unannounced, as if the world operated on her schedule alone.

 

“Good morning, Agatha,” Eleanor greeted, her voice warm but her eyes sharp, missing nothing. Her cane tapped lightly against the porch as she added, “I thought I’d offer you a ride to the meeting later. You’ve done so much for the department—consider it a small token of appreciation.”

 

Agatha’s irritation was carefully masked behind a practiced smile. “How very thoughtful of you, Eleanor. Please, come in.”

 

Eleanor stepped inside with the measured grace of someone who expected her presence to command the room. Agatha closed the door behind her, already feeling the older woman’s gaze roving over every inch of her home. Eleanor’s sharp eyes lingered on the subtle yet unmistakable changes—a cozier warmth in the decor, the vibrancy brought by the abundance of houseplants, and most tellingly, the additional pair of shoes neatly lined by the door, and the unmistakable signs that a another presence had made its mark.

 

“My, my,” Eleanor said, eyebrows raised. “Your home’s had quite the tranfsormation. It’s looking… different.”

 

Agatha’s smile didn’t waver, though she could feel the weight of Eleanor’s unspoken questions hanging in the air. “Life evolves, Eleanor,” she replied smoothly, her tone light yet firm. “Would you care for some tea?”

 

Eleanor’s lips curved into the faintest of smiles, though it was impossible to tell whether it was one of approval or merely amusement. “That would be lovely, thank you,” she said, her tone suggesting she’d already decided it would be.

 

As Agatha moved to the kitchen, she could feel Eleanor’s gaze lingering, quietly assessing, drawing conclusions she’d never voice outright. Agatha,played the good hostessa dn busied herself with preparing the tea, the clinking of cups and the whistle of the kettle filling the silence.

 

“Your plants are thriving,” Eleanor remarked idly from the living room, her voice carrying just enough weight to suggest she wasn’t simply commenting on the greenery. “I didn’t know you had a green thumb.”

 

Agatha glanced over her shoulder with a serene smile. “Oh I don’t. They do brighten up the space, don’t they? A little bit of care goes a long way.”

 

“And care is something you’ve always excelled at,” Eleanor mused, her tone laced with subtle implication. “Though it seems you’ve found new… inspirations.”

 

Agatha returned to the living room with two cups of tea, her smile unshaken. Handing one to Eleanor, she settled into her seat with an air of calm that matched the quiet strength of her words. “Inspiration comes in many forms, Eleanor. It’s what keeps life interesting, wouldn’t you agree?”

 

Before Eleanor could respond, a voice called down from upstairs—Rio’s, light and casual, completely unaware of the scene unfolding below.

 

“Agatha, have you seen my green notebook? I think I left it in the living room!”

 

The air in the room seemed to shift. Eleanor’s expression froze mid-sip, her sharp gaze snapping to Agatha. For a brief moment, the older woman’s mask of polite curiosity faltered, replaced by an unmistakable flicker of suspicion as she recognized the voice.

 

“Was that Miss Vidal I just heard?” Eleanor’s voice was measured, but the disbelief beneath it was palpable.

 

Agatha, calm as ever, didn’t miss a beat. “Indeed, it was,” she replied smoothly, reaching for the teapot to refill Eleanor’s cup as if this was the most natural thing in the world.

 

Before Eleanor could probe further, Rio appeared at the top of the staircase. She was barefoot, dressed in leggings and an oversized sweater that hung slightly off one shoulder, her hair still damp and curling from a recent shower. She bounded down the stairs with the easy confidence of someone entirely at home, her voice trailing after her.

 

“I swear it was here yesterday—oh.”

 

Rio stopped abruptly mid-step, her gaze landing on Eleanor. A flicker of hesitation crossed her face, a subtle tightening of her posture, though she quickly smoothed it into a polite smile.

 

“Good morning, Professor Crenshaw,” Rio greeted, her voice steady but tinged with a faint awkwardness. Her cheeks, however, betrayed her as a faint pink stain appeared over them.

 

Eleanor blinked, her head tilting slightly, as if trying to fit an unexpected piece into an otherwise orderly puzzle. “Miss Vidal,” she said, her tone polite but laced with pointed curiosity. “I didn’t realize you were… here.”

 

Rio’s eyes darted to Agatha, who was watching her with a soft, steady gaze that carried no apprehension—only quiet reassurance. It was enough to steady Rio, who took a breath and straightened her shoulders.

 

“I just needed to grab my notebook,” Rio said, descending the remaining stairs and crossing the room. Spotting the notebook on the side table, she snatched it up quickly, then, without missing a beat, reached for Agatha’s mug and took a casual sip.

 

The gesture was so natural, so unselfconscious, that it seemed to hang in the air, a silent declaration that no explanation would be offered—or required.

 

Eleanor’s sharp gaze darted between the two women, her sharp mind clearly working to piece together the dynamics at play. The faint tension in the room was almost tangible, yet Agatha remained the picture of composure, her small smile suggesting she was entirely unbothered by the older woman’s scrutiny.

 

Placing her tea down with deliberate care, Agatha straightened in her seat, her tone calm and unyielding.

 

“Miss Vidal and I share this house now,” she said, her tone calm and composed. “We’ve chosen to keep our personal lives private—not secret, but private. The dean is fully aware of our situation, and we’ve taken every necessary measure to ensure professional boundaries remain intact. There is nothing unethical about our relationship.”

 

Eleanor’s eyebrows shot up, clearly caught off guard by Agatha’s directness. “I see,” she said slowly, her tone more judgmental than curious. Her expression shifted as Agatha’s calm explanation settled over the room. Her brow furrowed deeply, and she shook her head, stepping back slightly.

 

“This is not something I expected for you Agatha. This… this is entirely improper, Dr. Harkness,” she said sharply, her voice tight with indignation. “You’re her teacher, her supervisor, for goodness’ sake! Do you have any idea how this looks? It’s unprofessional, unethical, and frankly, it’s disgraceful. What kind of example does this set for your colleagues-or your students?”

 

Agatha’s eyes narrowed slightly, but her voice remained steady. “Eleanor, I assure you, everything has been handled with complete transparency. Dean Montgomery is aware—”

 

“The dean shouldn’t have approved this!” Eleanor snapped, cutting her off. “And what about your boy? How does it feel for him, being part of this… arrangement? Have you considered what kind of confusion this might cause for young Nicholas? Children thrive on stability, not… impropriety.”

 

At the mention of Nicky, Rio’s knuckles whitened as she tightened her grip on her notebook. She stepped forward, her voice calm but edged with steel.

 

“With all due respect, Professor Crenshaw,” Rio said, her tone measured, “you know nothing about how Nicky feels or the kind of family we’ve built together. He’s happy, he’s loved, and he’s thriving.”

 

Eleanor’s sharp gaze snapped to Rio, her lips thinning. “Miss Vidal, this isn’t about your feelings or your defenses. It’s about principles, about maintaining integrity in academia. This is not how things should be done.” She turned back to Agatha, her voice rising with frustration. “Agatha, you’ve always been a pillar of professionalism—a model for this institution. And now? To be entangled in something so… inappropriate. It’s a disappointment, plain and simple.”

 

Agatha’s gaze hardened, her arms crossing over her chest. “Eleanor,” she said, her voice low but imposing, “you’re entitled to your opinions, but you don’t get to define what’s proper or ethical for me or my family. My personal life does not diminish my professional accomplishments, nor does it affect my ability to teach or mentor. And as for my son, Nicky is growing up in a home filled with love, respect, and stability—far more than many can claim. I would caution you against making unfounded assumptions about my life or my choices. I’m afraid you’ve misunderstood the situation entirely. This isn’t a whim or a reckless decision. It’s a relationship built on mutual repsect and care, and we’ve done everything by the book.”

 

Agatha’s voice was calm but unwavering, each word precise and deliberate. She stood tall, her posture radiating quiet authority, her eyes locking onto Eleanor’s with unflinching resolve. Before Eleanor could respond, Agatha pressed on, her tone cutting through the room like a blade.

 

“This isn’t about appearances, Eleanor, or whatever narrative you’ve constructed in your mind. It’s about two adultsnavigating their lives with honesty and integrity, regardless of your discomfort with the concept.”

 

Eleanor’s expression tightened, her lips a thin line of disapproval. “Honesty and integrity?” she repeated, her tone biting. “Agatha, you’re her supervisor. Whether you acknowledge it or not, that position comes with power, influence, and the potential for favoritism. This raises serious ethical concerns—”

 

Agatha raised a hand—not sharply, but with enough purpose to halt Eleanor mid-sentence. Her voice was steady but carried an edge of finality. “Those concerns have been addressed with diligence and transparency,” she said. “If you’d taken a moment to ask instead of rushing to judgment, you’d know that we disclosed our relationship to the dean before making any decisions about living together. I offered to remove myself from any direct involvement in Rio’s academic evaluations. The dean reviewed the situation and determined no such step was necessary.”

 

Rio, who had been standing silently beside Agatha, felt a surge of gratitude as she watched the older woman hold her ground. Straightening, she met Eleanor’s piercing gaze with her own, her voice calm yet resolute. “Professor Crenshaw, I’ve worked hard to ensure my work speaks for itself. If anyone doubts my abilities, they’re free to review my progress. Agatha has never shown me preferential treatment, and I wouldn’t accept it if she tried.”

 

Eleanor scoffed, folding her arms tightly across her chest. “And I suppose you think that’s enough? That we should all just turn a blind eye and pretend this situation doesn’t compromise professional standards?”

 

“No one is asking you to turn a blind eye,” Agatha replied, her tone cooling further, her words deliberate. “We’re asking for respect—for the care we’ve taken to ensure our personal life doesn’t interfere with our professional responsibilities. I refuse to apologize for finding happiness, Eleanor, nor will I allow you to weaponize morality to undermine what we’ve built.”

 

Eleanor’s face darkened further, her frustration battling against Agatha’s steady, unyielding presence. Her lips parted, as if searching for a sharp retort, but the words faltered under the weight of Agatha’s calm resolve. The silence that followed was thick with unspoken judgment, the tension in the room almost tangible.

 

Finally, Eleanor exhaled sharply, shaking her head in a gesture of reluctant defeat. “You’ve changed, Agatha,” she said, her voice tinged with both disapproval and something almost wistful. “I don’t know what’s happened to you, but this… this isn’t the person I used to know.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened just a fraction, her shoulders relaxing slightly, though her eyes remained sharp, unwavering. “People grow, Eleanor,” she replied, her tone steady yet laced with quiet warmth. “We learn, we adapt, and we discover what truly matters. Sometimes that means stepping outside the lines others have drawn for us. I’m sorry if that doesn’t align with your expectations, but I refuse to apologize for living authentically.”

 

Eleanor’s gaze darted between Agatha and Rio, her disapproval as clear as the furrow in her brow, but no further argument seemed to come to her. She raised a hand in a half-hearted gesture of dismissal, shaking her head as though to rid herself of the moment entirely. “I’ve heard enough,” she muttered, her voice clipped.

 

She finally straightened, her expression tight. “I’ve made my stance clear,” she said briskly, reaching for her coat. “What you choose to do with it is up to you. But don’t be surprised when others aren’t as… understanding.”

 

Agatha stood as well, her composure unshaken. “Thank you for sharing your thoughts, Eleanor. I’ll let you see yourself out.”

 

Without another word, Eleanor gathered her things and left, the door clicking shut behind her.

 

A heavy silence settled over the house and the two women still standing in the living room, stretching between them like a thread pulled taut. Rio stood frozen, her chest tight, her mind replaying Eleanor’s words. Agatha, still staring at the door, remained unreadable, her hands loosely clasped in front of her. Finally, Rio broke the stillness, her voice tinged with strained humor.

 

“Well,” she said, her tone light but strained. “That went great.”

 

Agatha turned to her, her sharp gaze softening as it landed on Rio’s troubled face. She closed the distance between them, resting her hands gently on Rio’s shoulders. “Eleanor is entitled to her opinion,” she said evenly. “But that doesn’t make it the truth.”

 

Rio let out a shaky breath. “I know we’re not doing anything wrong, but it still… stings. She didn’t even give us a chance to explain.”

 

Agatha nodded, brushing a stray strand of hair from Rio’s face. “It stings because she doesn’t know us. If she did, she’d see the truth. But what matters is that we know—and the people who care about us know too.”

 

Rio leaned into Agatha’s touch, finding comfort in her unwavering calm. “It just feels so unfair,” she murmured. “Like we’re constantly defending something that’s we shouldn’t even have to hide.”

 

Agatha tilted her head, her lips brushing against Rio’s forehead in a quiet gesture of reassurance. “I know, love,” she said softly. “It’s exhausting. But we’ve stopped hiding, haven’t we? That’s progress. Let Eleanor and others like her think what they will—it doesn’t change the truth of what we have.”

 

Rio exhaled slowly, the tension in her chest loosening under the steady strength of Agatha’s embrace. “Are you okay?” she asked softly, lifting her gaze to meet Agatha’s.

 

Agatha’s shoulders relaxed as she looked at Rio, a small smile breaking through the tension. “I’m fine,” she said. “People like that will always have their opinions. What matters is what we know to be true.”

 

Rio nodded, her hand brushing against Agatha’s in silent support. “And we know we’re doing just fine.”

 

Agatha’s smile widened slightly as she leaned in. “Better than fine, my love. Much better than fine.”

 

Rio wrapped her arms around Agatha, letting herself feel the weight of the moment before slowly letting it go. They might not have convinced Eleanor, but they didn’t need to. They had each other, and that was enough.

 

 

At the faculty meeting later that day, Agatha walked into the conference room with her usual air of quiet authority. Her head was held high, her dark hair falling neatly over her shoulders, and her expression betrayed nothing of the morning’s incident. If anyone noticed the subtle tension in her jaw or the fleeting shadow in her eyes, they were polite enough not to comment.

 

She scanned the room and immediately noticed Eleanor sitting at the far end of the table, chatting animatedly with another professor. Eleanor caught her eye for the briefest moment, then quickly turned away, focusing intently on her conversation as if Agatha weren’t even there. The slight was subtle but deliberate, a clear message that Eleanor wasn’t ready to let their earlier confrontation go.

 

Agatha felt a flicker of irritation but tamped it down. Let her stew, she thought. It’s not my job to manage her discomfort.She moved to her usual seat near the center of the table, nodding cordially to a few colleagues who greeted her on the way.

 

The meeting proceeded as usual, with discussions about upcoming curriculum changes, departmental budgets, and student engagement initiatives. Agatha contributed when necessary, her voice steady and professional, her points concise and well-articulated. She noticed, however, that Eleanor avoided looking in her direction entirely. Even when Agatha presented her input on a key issue, Eleanor directed her responses to another faculty member, blatantly circumventing her.

 

It was childish, Agatha thought, but not entirely surprising. Eleanor was clearly rattled, though she hadn’t said anything to anyone else—at least, not yet. Agatha hoped she’d keep it that way, though the morning’s encounter suggested Eleanor might not let this go without a fight.

 

Across the table, Professor Graham, a senior member of the department and someone Agatha considered a reasonable colleague, leaned over during a lull in the discussion. “Everything alright with Eleanor?” he asked quietly, a note of concern in his voice. “She seems… off today.”

 

Agatha smiled faintly, keeping her tone neutral. “I think she’s just having a tough morning,” she said, deflecting the question. “We all have them from time to time.”

 

Graham nodded, seeming satisfied with the answer, though his gaze lingered on Eleanor for a moment longer. Agatha couldn’t tell whether he was simply curious or already piecing together that something had shifted between them.

 

The meeting finally drew to a close, and as the faculty began filing out, Agatha deliberately lingered, gathering her things with measured precision. She caught snippets of idle chatter as her colleagues exchanged pleasantries and exited the room, but Eleanor’s silence was conspicuous. She brushed past Agatha without a word, her expression set in a mask of stony indifference, and disappeared out the door without even glancing back.

 

Agatha sighed softly, adjusting her bag on her shoulder. Let her sulk, she thought. As long as she keeps her opinions to herself, we’ll be fine.

 

Still, as she walked back to her office, her mind lingered on the interaction. Eleanor’s silence was preferable to open hostility, but it didn’t mean the issue was resolved. Agatha knew better than to underestimate her colleague. Eleanor’s moral indignation might simmer quietly for a while, but it had the potential to boil over if provoked—or if she found an audience willing to listen.

 

When Agatha reached her office, she set her bag down carefully, leaning against her desk for a moment of stillness. The confrontation had been exhausting in a way she hadn’t fully registered until now. She ran a hand through her hair, exhaling deeply.

 

Her phone buzzed softly on the desk, breaking the quiet. A text from lit up the screen.

 

Rio : How’s it going? Hope you’re holding up. Love you.

 

A small smile touched Agatha’s lips as she read the message. Despite everything, Rio’s unwavering support anchored her. She tapped out a quick response.

 

 Agatha: Nothing I can’t handle. Love you too.

 

For now, that was enough. She’d weather Eleanor’s judgment and whatever fallout came next, knowing she and Rio would face it together. Still, a part of her couldn’t shake the nagging feeling that Eleanor’s disapproval would perhaps mean they would need to brace for another storm.

 

 

Eleanor Crenshaw arrived at her book club meeting that evening, her irritation from the morning still bubbling under the surface. The group met in a cozy, well-lit communal space lined with bookshelves, the aroma of freshly brewed tea and coffee filling the room. Lilia was already seated, flipping through the pages of the novel they were set to discuss, a peaceful smile on her face.

 

“Evening, Eleanor,” Lilia greeted warmly as the older woman took a seat next to her.

 

Eleanor nodded stiffly, setting her bag down and smoothing her cardigan. “Evening Lilia. Though I must say, my day has been anything but pleasant.”

 

“What’s the matter?” Lilia asked, sipping her tea, her tone light but genuinely curious, always ready to help.

 

Eleanor huffed, leaning in conspiratorially. “I had quite the shock this morning, Lilia. It turns out one of our esteemed professors is carrying on an inappropriate relationship with her PhD student. And the worst is that they even live together apparently, so it’s happening under her own roof, with her child present! It’s utterly scandalous.”

 

Lilia’s teacup paused midair as recognition flickered across her face. Her usually warm expression grew sharp, though she kept her tone even. “Oh? And what makes you think it’s inappropriate?”

 

“Well, she’s the student’s supervisor! It’s a clear conflict of interest,” Eleanor said, clearly feeling justified. “Not to mention what it must be like for her poor son, witnessing such a thing. And the student—don’t even get me started on her. You should have seen her, acting as if she owned the place when she is nothing but a child biting more than she can chew! It’s just not proper. She’s far too young for Agatha, and—well—it’s just wrong.”

 

Lilia placed her teacup back down on the table with a soft clink, her eyes narrowing slightly. The warmth in her gaze disappeared, replaced by a hard edge, but her tone remained steady and controlled. “Eleanor, I think you’re making quite a lot of assumptions about something you don’t fully understand.”

 

Eleanor bristled. “Excuse me?”

 

“First,” Lilia began, her voice firm but controlled, “there’s nothing inappropriate about two consenting adults being in a relationship—especially when they’ve disclosed it to the proper authorities. Knowing Agatha, I’m confident she’s done exactly that.” She paused, letting the weight of her words settle. “Second, if we’re speaking of Rio Vidal—and I suspect we are—you should know she’s one of the brightest and most hardworking individuals I know, and she’s far from the meek, naïve and overreaching child you’re making her out to be.”

 

Eleanor opened her mouth, but Lilia raised a hand, her gesture both polite and commanding. “And third,” Lilia continued, leaning forward slightly, her tone taking on a razor-sharp edge, “if this relationship bothers you so much, I suggest you take a long, hard look at why that is. Because frankly, dear, this sounds less like concern and more like misplaced judgment.”

 

The words landed like a slap, and for a moment, Eleanor stared, stunned into silence. Her face flushed with a mixture of embarrassment and defensiveness, the kind that often accompanied a jab too close to the bone. She struggled to maintain her composure, opening her mouth to respond but finding that no words would come out.

 

“You… know them?” Eleanor finally managed to croak, her voice now more uncertain than before, the edges of her anger slipping away under the weight of Lilia’s calm authority.

 

Lilia’s lips curved into a small, tight smile, but her eyes remained sharp. “Yes, I do,” she said, her voice firm with a quiet strength. “You see, Rio is my daughter. I raised her when no one else would. And Agatha? She’s practically my daughter-in-law at this point. So, when you speak ill of them, you’re speaking ill of my family. And I won’t stand for it.”

 

Eleanor’s face drained of color. She opened and closed her mouth, trying to formulate some sort of defense, but the words stuck in her throat, caught in the sudden realization that Lilia was not someone she could dismiss or push around. The tables had turned completely, and she was no longer the one in control of the conversation.

 

For several long moments, there was a tense silence between them, the air thick with unspoken truths and lingering tension. Eleanor’s hands twitched in her lap, and her gaze flickered nervously from Lilia to the teacup, as though seeking some escape from the uncomfortable confrontation.

 

Before Eleanor could open her mouth to reply, Lilia continued, her voice unwavering. “Their relationship is built on respect, love, and honesty. It’s not for you—or anyone else—to decide what’s ‘proper.’ They’re not hurting anyone, and they’ve done everything by the book. Agatha is a wonderful mother, and Rio is stronger than you could possibly imagine.”

 

The room was silent, the other book club members listening intently, some nodding in agreement.

 

“I suggest,” Lilia finished, “that instead of fuming over something that doesn’t concern you, you focus on your own life. And perhaps consider an apology to Agatha. She’s a good woman, and you owe her that much.”

 

Eleanor’s cheeks flushed with embarrassment and anger, but she didn’t respond. Instead, she picked up her tea, drinking in silence for the remainder of the meeting.

 

Lilia, for her part, leaned back in her chair, calm and composed. She had defended her family, and she knew she had done so well. She wasn’t a woman who let things slide easily, especially when it came to those she considered family. Agatha and Rio were under her protection, and anyone who dared speak ill of them would feel the weight of her disapproval. But as she looked down at her teacup, she couldn’t help but wonder how many more people would need to be reminded of the boundaries they were crossing, how many more challenges would arise from the ignorance and assumptions of those who thought they knew better.

 

As the tension settled into the room, one of the other book club members, a kind woman named Marjorie, took the opportunity to steer the conversation. “It’s always a pleasure to hear about young Rio. She an amazing young woman.” she said, her voice light but genuine. “How’s she doing these days? I always enjoy hearing about her.”

 

Lilia’s face softened immediately, her warmth returning as she smiled. “Oh, Rio’s doing wonderfully, thank you for asking, Marjorie. She’s in the final stages of her PhD now—writing her thesis. She’s been working so hard, and I couldn’t be prouder of her.”

 

Eleanor’s ears perked up, though she kept her expression carefully neutral, her hands clasped tightly in her lap.

 

“She’s always been such a determined young woman,” Lilia continued, her voice brimming with affection. “Even as a teenager, she was relentless in pursuing her goals. And now, seeing her balance everything—her studies, her passions, even teaching children at the dance center—it’s remarkable. She’s truly blossomed into an incredible person.”

 

Marjorie nodded enthusiastically. “That’s lovely to hear. And she teaches dance too? Such a creative spirit!”

 

“Yes,” Lilia said with a proud chuckle. “She’s been dancing since she was a little girl, and it’s something that’s always brought her joy. She’s also playing with her band in her free time. Music, literature, dance—my Rio’s got a knack for bringing people together through her passions.”

 

Eleanor, still silent, struggled to reconcile the image Lilia was painting of Rio with her own assumptions. The young woman she had seen earlier that day—confident and poised in Agatha’s home—suddenly seemed more layered, more grounded than Eleanor had given her credit for.

 

Marjorie added, “It sounds like you’ve done a wonderful job raising her, Lilia.”

 

Lilia gave a humble shrug, her smile tinged with emotion. “She’s done the hard work herself, really. But I’ll admit, I’m proud to have played a part in shaping the person she’s become. And now, seeing her in a loving relationship with someone who cherishes her—that’s all I’ve ever wanted for her. Agatha is amazing with her, always wanting the best for her, supporting her. And she has the most adorable son ever, if you could see them together, it’s like watching a Christmas movie sometimes. They both make each other better.” Lilia finished, with a pointed look towards Eleanor who was doing her best not to look at her.

 

At this, Eleanor shifted uncomfortably, her earlier indignation crumbling ever so slightly under the weight of Lilia’s words.

 

The conversation shifted naturally to the book they were meant to discuss, leaving Eleanor quiet and reflective. She couldn’t shake Lilia’s words, nor the clear admiration in the room for Rio and her accomplishments.

 

By the end of the meeting, as Eleanor gathered her things, her thoughts were a whirl of confusion and reluctant acknowledgment. Perhaps there was more to Rio Vidal—and to her relationship with Agatha—than she had allowed herself to see.

 

As the members filtered out, Eleanor lingered by the door, adjusting her scarf with a pensive expression. Lilia noticed her hesitation and paused as well, her demeanor calm and open.

 

“Lilia,” Eleanor began hesitantly, her tone softer than before, “I still… I still don’t think it’s entirely appropriate. A professor and a student—it’s unconventional, to say the least. It doesn’t sit well with me.”

 

Lilia nodded slowly, not dismissive but measured. “I understand why it might seem that way, Eleanor. It’s not the usual path people take in relationships, and I can see how it might raise eyebrows, especially within the department. But I’ve seen them together, truly together, and I can tell you—there’s nothing improper or harmful about their relationship.”

 

Eleanor frowned, folding her arms as she mulled this over. “But how can you be sure?  There must be a power imbalance somewhere. In my time…”

 

Lilia’s eyes hardened ever so slightly, her voice steady but firm as she cut Eleanor off. “You’re right—power dynamics can be tricky. But this isn’t a case of manipulation or exploitation. Rio is one of the most fiercely independent and self-aware people I know. She’s no stranger to adversity, and she wouldn’t be with someone who didn’t respect her autonomy. And Agatha… she’s steady, grounding. She supports Rio without ever overshadowing her or demanding anything from her. Their relationship is built on trust, not coercion.”

 

Eleanor’s lips pressed into a thin line, but her posture seemed to relax ever so slightly. “I suppose… I suppose I can see your point. I know you Lilia and it’s clear you care about Rio deeply, and if you trust Agatha with this, that says something. Still, it’s hard for me to let go of my reservations.”

 

Lilia gave her a patient smile. “That’s fair. No one’s asking you to change your mind overnight. Just… give them the benefit of the doubt. Watch how they navigate this, and maybe you’ll see what I see—a partnership between equals, both lifting each other up.”

 

Eleanor sighed, her expression conflicted but not closed off. “I’ll try. That’s the most I can promise right now. But if I ever see anything that makes me question it…”

 

“You’ll bring it up, I’m sure,” Lilia said with a small, knowing smile. “And I wouldn’t expect anything less. Just keep an open mind, Eleanor. You might be surprised.”

 

Eleanor gave a reluctant nod before stepping out into the cool evening. “Goodnight, Lilia.”

 

“Goodnight, Eleanor,” Lilia replied, watching her walk away. As she closed the door behind her, she let out a soft sigh. Despite Eleanor’s lingering reservations, Lilia felt confident that time—and the undeniable bond between Rio and Agatha—would win her over in the end.

 

 

That evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the cozy warmth of their shared home settled around them, Agatha sat at the kitchen table with her laptop open, her glassed perched on top of her nose. The soft glow of the setting sun filtered through the windows, casting a golden hue over the room. She sipped her tea slowly, the warmth of the cup settling her as she scrolled through her inbox. The quiet hum of the house and the soft sounds of Nicky playing upstairs was comforting, a stark contrast to the tension of the earlier faculty meeting.

 

When she saw Eleanor’s name pop up in the subject line, Agatha raised an eyebrow, intrigued. Eleanor had remained silent all afternoon, but Agatha knew better than to think the matter was settled. She clicked on the email, her fingers hovering over the keys as she read it carefully. Her expression shifted from guarded to mildly surprised as she processed the words. Eleanor’s email, though formal, was an unexpected mix of contrition and barely veiled challenge.

 

 

Subject: Apologies

 

      Dr. Harkness,

 

I have had time to reflect on our earlier conversation, and I feel that I may have been too quick to judge your personal life. I want to apologize for how I acted this morning. My reaction was inappropriate, and I didn’t take the time to listen or understand. I won’t interfere in your personal life or bring this up again.

However, I would still like to reiterate that I find your situation unconventional. If I see anything that I find improper or unprofessional, I will report it. I hope this clears the air and that you understand my concerns and that we can move forward with mutual respect.

 

      Best regards

 

      Dr. Eleanor Crenshaw

 

 

Agatha sat back in her chair, a wry smile tugging at her lips. The email was as much a concession as it was a passive-aggressive critique, a classic example of Eleanor’s inability to fully let go of her judgment. She sipped her tea, her eyes narrowing slightly as she processed the words.

 

“Rio, darling,” Agatha called out, her voice calm but tinged with something else.

 

From the living room, Rio looked up from her book, her brow furrowed in a way that always made Agatha smile. “What is it, love?” she asked, her tone light, though there was a trace of concern in her voice.

 

Agatha gestured toward the seat beside her, an invitation that Rio didn’t hesitate to accept. She set her book aside with a soft thud and walked over to the table, the movement fluid and graceful as always, like the dancer she was. Agatha adjusted the laptop slightly, turning it so that Rio could read the email for herself.

 

Rio sat down, leaning in slightly as she read through the message, her expression flickering between amusement and disbelief. When she finished, she raised her eyebrows, her voice laced with a touch of sarcasm. “Well, isn’t that a diplomatic way to say ‘I’m still judging you but I’ll try to be nice about it’?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her eyes gleaming with something akin to amusement. “You’ve got that right. It’s Eleanor’s brand of apology: a mix of begrudging acknowledgment and thinly veiled criticism.”

 

Rio leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms with a smirk. “At least she’s not being completely hostile.”

 

Agatha smirked faintly. “Not exactly an olive branch, but it’s better than nothing.”

 

Rio nodded, her fingers drumming lightly on the table. “She’s clearly still not thrilled about us, but at least she’s not going to be a thorn in our side—unless we give her a reason.”

 

“Not that we would,” Agatha said, her voice steady. She reached out, placing a reassuring hand over Rio’s. “We’ve been careful. Transparent. And frankly, we’ve done nothing wrong.”

 

Rio tilted her head, a small smile creeping onto her face. “I know. But it’s still nice to have this little… resolution, I guess. I wasn’t worried, but it feels better knowing she’s stepping back.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her thumb brushing over Rio’s knuckles. “Exactly my thoughts. It’s not about fear—it’s about peace of mind.”

 

Rio leaned in, resting her arm on Agatha’s shoulder. “You’re good at this, you know. Staying calm under pressure. Talking people down when they’re being ridiculous.”

 

Agatha smiled, pressing a kiss to Rio’s shoulder. “It comes with age and wisdom, my love.”

 

Rio playfully nudged her. “Oh, so now you’re going to pull the age card?”

 

“Always when I need to,” Agatha teased, her voice warm. “But seriously, Eleanor’s email is just noise. What we have is real, and we know we’re doing it the right way. That’s what matters.”

 

Rio nodded, letting herself sink into the comfort of Agatha’s presence. “Yeah. That’s what matters.”

 

Agatha closed the laptop, their spirits lighter, and moved on with their evening, secure in the strength of their love and partnership.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

As always, comments are my greatest gifts !

Rock Star

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

Being between two lives—unflowering, between

The live and the dead nettle. This is the use of memory:

For liberation—not less of love but expanding

Of love beyond desire, and so liberation

From the future as well as the past.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

On Friday night, in their shared bedroom, Rio stood in front of the full-length mirror, adjusting the leather jacket she’d thrown over her outfit. Tonight’s gig was at one of the livelier local bars, and she had dressed to impress—not that she ever needed to try. A green cropped top hugged her torso, exposing a tantalizing sliver of toned stomach, while high-waisted black jeans fit her like a glove, accentuating every curve. Her boots, scuffed but undeniably stylish, added an extra edge to the look, while silver jewelry shimmered with every movement, catching the light like a beacon, with among the many layered necklaces, the moon pendant Agatha has slipped around her neck the night of the gala and that she had worn every day since.

 

Behind her, Agatha leaned against the doorframe, arms folded over her chest in what might have passed for a casual stance—if not for the way her eyes were practically devouring Rio, pupils dark and blown wide, tracking every shift of her body with the kind of unfiltered hunger that sent a delicious thrill down Rio’s spine.

 

Her gaze tracked Rio’s movements with the kind of focus that made her heart race—a mix of adoration, desire, and pure helplessness at how effortlessly Rio attracted attention. Her blue eyes followed Rio’s every movement, from the way she adjusted her hair to the confident sway of her hips. She swallowed hard, her composure slipping just enough for a low hum of appreciation to escape her lips.

 

Rio pretended not to notice at first, continuing to adjust her hair, sliding rings onto her fingers, letting Agatha burn in her own torment for just a little longer. She bit back a smirk, but in the mirror, she caught the way Agatha swallowed hard, shifting on her feet, her knuckles tightening slightly where they pressed against her forearms.

 

Agatha was usually composed. Collected. The controlled and dangerously intelligent Dr.  Harkness, the woman who could reduce grown men to fumbling messes with a single sharp remark.

 

But right now? Right now, she looked wrecked, just standing there watching.

 

Finally, Rio turned—slow, deliberate, torturous. She tilted her head, her smirk deepening, her voice rich with amusement and just a touch of sultry provocation. “Something on your mind, Dr. Harkness?” she teased, her voice playful but sultry, as if daring Agatha to put her thoughts into words.

 

Agatha exhaled, long and measured, but it did nothing to mask the gravel in her voice when she responded. “You.”

 

Just one word, but the weight of it sent heat curling low in Rio’s stomach.

 

Agatha stepped forward, abandoning any pretense of restraint. Her movements were smooth, unhurried, but there was something prowling beneath them—a barely leashed intensity, like she was moments away from doing something reckless.

 

She stopped just short of touching, her breath warm against Rio’s cheek. “Looking like that,” she murmured, voice like silk over steel, “it’s downright criminal. How am I supposed to let you leave the house?”

 

Rio laughed, the sound warm and light as it filled the room. She crossed the distance between them in a few easy steps, her boots clicking softly against the hardwood floor. “You’re not supposed to let me do anything, Agatha. I’m a grown woman, remember?”

 

Agatha’s fingers found her waist, skimming just beneath the hem of her shirt, tracing the bare skin with a touch so light it sent a shiver racing up Rio’s spine. “Oh, I remember,” she murmured, her voice dropping to something darker, something dangerous. Her grip tightened, her other hand coming up to cup the back of Rio’s neck, keeping her close. “But the way you’re testing my patience right now, love—I don’t think you do.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, but she recovered quickly, pressing even closer, their bodies nearly flush. “Mm, is that right?” she mused, lips grazing the corner of Agatha’s mouth but never quite touching.

 

Agatha let out a slow, frustrated exhale. “You’re killing me here.”

 

“I do that a lot, don’t I?” Rio teased, though the slight tremor in her voice betrayed how much Agatha’s proximity was affecting her, too.

 

Agatha’s hands slipped higher, fingers splaying over Rio’s ribcage beneath the thin fabric of her top. “I should just take this off you,” she muttered, her mouth trailing lower, lips grazing the shell of Rio’s ear, then lower still, pressing a slow, deliberate kiss to the sensitive spot beneath her jaw. “Cancel your little gig, keep you here all night. Make you beg for more.”

 

The sharp inhale Rio took was almost embarrassing. Almost. But she wasn’t about to let Agatha win that easily.

 

She placed her hands on her hips, her grin widening. “No, I’ve got a gig to play. The band’s counting on me, and you don’t want to deal with a pissed off Alice if I’m late.”

 

Agatha’s fingers brushed against warm skin as she pulled Rio even closer. “The band might be counting on you,” she murmured, her lips grazing the shell of Rio’s ear, “but they don’t have to deal with the torture of watching you walk out of here like this.” She punctuated her words with a soft kiss just below Rio’s ear, a deliberate, slow kiss that left Rio momentarily breathless.

 

Rio shivered but quickly recovered, placing her hands on Agatha’s chest to push her back gently. “Easy there, Professor. We don’t have time for this right now,” she said, her tone playful but firm. “I’ve got to get to the bar, and so do you. You’re my designated groupie tonight, remember?”

 

Agatha chuckled, though her hands lingered at Rio’s waist, reluctant to let go. “Groupie? Is that what we’re calling it now?” she teased, her smirk sharp but affectionate. “I thought I was your manager.”

 

Rio grinned, leaning up to press a quick, teasing kiss to Agatha’s lips, quickly followed by several other ones punctuating every word. “Manager, groupie, partner, professor, girlfriend, lover—whatever helps you sleep at night. But right now, you need to let me go, or I’m going to be late.”

 

Agatha let out an exaggerated sigh but released her hold, her hands falling to her sides with deliberate slowness. “Fine,” she said, though her tone carried a subtle edge of mischief. “But just so you know, I’ll be counting down the hours until we get back home.”

 

Rio slung her bag over her shoulder and winked. “Good. Because once tonight’s over, I’ll be all yours. Promise.”

 

Agatha’s smirk deepened, her gaze following Rio as she moved toward the door. “You’d better keep that promise, Miss Vidal. Or I might have to think of a way to get back at you for teasing me like this.”

 

Rio turned at the doorway, her eyes sparkling with amusement. “Wouldn’t dream of breaking it, Dr. Harkness.” She shot Agatha one last playful look before disappearing down the hall, the sway of her hips deliberate and maddeningly enticing.

 

Left alone, Agatha exhaled slowly, running a hand through her hair as she tried to steady herself. “How does she manage to do this to me every single time?” she muttered under her breath, her lips quirking in a mix of frustration and adoration. She grabbed her coat, shaking her head as she prepared to support her partner for the evening.

 

As much as she enjoyed watching Rio shine on stage, the thought that Rio would come home with her at the end of the night was enough to make her heart skip a beat.

 

 

The bar was alive with energy, a steady hum of conversation mingling with bursts of laughter and the rhythmic clink of glasses. The warm, golden glow of overhead lights bounced off polished wood surfaces, adding to the cozy, electric atmosphere. As the band began setting up on stage, the room’s energy shifted, the low murmur of voices giving way to eager anticipation.

 

Agatha sat at a small table near the back, cradling a glass of wine between her fingers. She had chosen her spot carefully—close enough to enjoy a perfect view of the stage but far enough to avoid the crush of the crowd gathering near the front. Her eyes, however, never strayed from Rio, who was setting up her drum kit with a fluidity and confidence that betrayed years of practice.

 

Dressed in the effortlessly edgy outfit that drove Agatha crazy, Rio exuded a magnetic presence. The cropped top and leather jacket seemed almost like armor, her confidence shining brighter with every move. As she tightened the snare and adjusted the cymbals, she ran a hand through her hair, causing a few strands to fall casually across her face. Agatha’s gaze lingered on that small, unintentional gesture, her heart fluttering at the sight. The air of focus around Rio made her even more captivating, a quiet intensity that Agatha knew could explode into raw energy the moment the music started.

 

The rest of the band was no less engaging in their own way. Alice had finished setting up her keyboard and was currently adjusting her mic stand, her easy laughter carrying over the noise of the crowd. She exchanged playful banter with a group of regulars at the front, her natural charisma drawing people in like moths to a flame. Agatha couldn’t help but notice how effortlessly Alice owned the room, her warmth a perfect contrast to Jen’s quieter but equally strong presence.

 

Jen stood off to the side, her electric guitar slung low across her hips. She strummed a few experimental chords, each one sending ripples of excitement through the air. The crowd’s attention sharpened, heads turning toward the stage with renewed interest. Jen’s sharp eyes, however, weren’t scanning the crowd—they were stealing glances at Alice, with a subtle, affectionate and loving smile that softened her otherwise cool demeanor.

 

But for Agatha, there was only Rio. Even surrounded by her bandmates, Rio’s presence was magnetic, a force Agatha couldn’t resist. As Rio bent slightly to adjust a pedal, the light caught the silver chains she wore around her neck, the shimmer pulling Agatha’s thoughts into dangerous territory. She took a sip of her wine, as though the cool liquid could temper the warmth blooming in her chest. It didn’t help.

 

The crowd around her grew restless, their excitement building as the band’s setup neared completion. The buzz of anticipation was almost palpable, and Agatha could feel the contagious energy pulling her into the moment. Yet, her focus remained entirely on Rio—on the way her fingers drummed absentmindedly against the edge of her snare, her head nodding slightly to a beat only she could hear. Agatha knew that beat would soon ignite the entire room, but for now, it was a private rhythm, a glimpse into the world Rio carried within her.

 

Rio finally looked up, her gaze sweeping the room as she did a quick mental check of her setup. Her eyes found Agatha almost immediately, as if drawn by some invisible thread. A grin spread across her face, equal parts teasing and affectionate, and she gave a small, subtle wave. Agatha raised her glass in acknowledgment, her lips curving into a smile that was meant only for Rio.

 

It was a small moment, unnoticed by anyone else in the bustling bar, but it was theirs. And in that fleeting connection, Agatha felt the kind of exhilaration that no stage performance could replicate. This was her Rio—bold, talented, and utterly magnetic. And tonight, she would get to watch her shine.

 

When the band finally launched into their first song, the atmosphere in the bar transformed. The low hum of chatter was replaced by an electric current that seemed to ripple through the room as the music took hold. The opening chords of Jen’s guitar rang out, sharp and soulful, cutting through the air like a call for attention. Alice’s voice followed, smooth and rich, wrapping around the audience like a warm embrace, while Rio’s drumming drove the heartbeat of the song—a steady, powerful rhythm that anchored everything together.

 

Agatha could feel the shift as if the room itself was breathing in time with the music. Her wine sat untouched on the table as her attention locked entirely on Rio. It wasn’t just her skill—it was the way she played, the sheer passion radiating from her every movement. Rio’s hands moved with a precision born of years of practice, her drumsticks blurring as they struck the kit with a controlled intensity that seemed effortless.

 

Her whole body was immersed in the performance, from the slight sway of her shoulders to the rhythmic tapping of her boot against the pedal. Rio didn’t just play the drums; she became part of them, her movements fluid and instinctive, her focus absolute. Her cropped top had shifted slightly with the effort, revealing more of her toned stomach, and strands of her dark hair fell over her forehead, framing her flushed face. She looked fierce, untamed, and utterly captivating.

 

Agatha leaned forward, resting her chin in her hand as her gaze followed every motion, utterly mesmerized. The energy Rio poured into her performance was palpable, a force that seemed to draw Agatha in and hold her there. She could feel the bass vibrating through the floorboards, could hear the cheers and whistles from the crowd, but it all seemed distant compared to the hypnotic pull of Rio on stage.

 

Occasionally, Rio would glance up from her drum kit, her eyes scanning the crowd briefly until they found Agatha. The instant their gazes met, Rio’s lips curved into a grin, equal parts playful and affectionate, as if to say, This one’s for you.Agatha felt her heart skip each time, the connection between them cutting through the noise and chaos like a direct line.

 

“You’re incredible,” Agatha murmured, her voice inaudible over the music. She knew Rio couldn’t hear her, but it didn’t matter. She just needed to say it, to let the words escape as her chest swelled with pride and love.

 

The crowd was already caught in the band’s spell, swaying to the rhythm, their cheers growing louder with each transition in the song. Alice commanded the mic, her voice soaring effortlessly as Jen added intricate riffs that seemed to dance around her vocals, and Rio drove the energy, her drumming building in intensity, carrying the band to an electrifying crescendo that left the room breathless.

 

When the final beat of the song hit, the bar erupted in applause and cheers. Rio tossed her hair back, her grin wide and exhilarated as she raised one drumstick in the air in acknowledgment. Agatha couldn’t help but join in the applause, her heart pounding as if she’d been part of the performance herself.

 

As the band launched into their next song, Agatha found herself leaning back in her chair, her smile soft but unshakable. There was something profoundly beautiful about watching Rio in her element, seeing her passion laid bare for everyone to witness. It was raw, unfiltered, and entirely Rio. And for that moment, Agatha felt like the luckiest woman in the world.

 

Before the band began their next song, Alice stepped up to the mic, her signature cheeky grin lighting up her face. The crowd quieted just enough to hear her voice as she addressed them with an easy charm that made it feel like she was speaking directly to each person in the room.

 

“All right, folks,” she began, her fingers lightly tapping the mic stand. “This next one’s a special treat—it’s brand new.” A ripple of excitement passed through the audience, punctuated by cheers and whistles. Alice let the noise build for a moment before continuing, her grin widening. “It’s dedicated to anyone who’s ever looked at someone and thought, ‘Wow, they’re the best thing I’ve ever had.’ You know that feeling, right?”

 

The crowd responded with a chorus of enthusiastic shouts and claps.

 

Alice chuckled, her eyes twinkling as she added, “Now, here’s a little inside scoop for you. All three of us—your beloved ‘Three of Swords’—definitely know this feeling all too well. So, we thought, why not turn it into a song and share it with you?” She threw a playful glance over her shoulder at Jen and Rio, who both laughed along with the crowd.

 

Agatha, sitting at her table near the back, chuckled softly as well. She caught the quick, knowing glance Rio shot her way from behind the drum kit, her dark eyes sparkling with mischief. Agatha’s lips curved into a smile, her heart skipping at the subtle exchange.

 

As Alice stepped back and gave a nod, the music began. Rio’s drums came in first, setting a steady, sultry beat that drew the room’s collective attention like an irresistible force. The rhythm pulsed through the air, a perfect foundation for Jen’s dreamy guitar melody to weave over the top. Alice’s voice soon joined, smooth and evocative, carrying lyrics that felt both deeply personal and universally relatable.

 

As the song built toward its chorus, the energy in the room shifted. The lyrics spoke of love so intense it felt like gravity, a pull so strong it was impossible to resist. Agatha couldn’t help but feel like the words were meant for her. She swayed along with the beat, her smile growing wider with each verse.

 

When the song reached its crescendo, Jen’s guitar soared, Alice’s voice rang out with raw emotion, and Rio’s drumming drove it all home with a fierce, unrelenting energy that brought the audience to their feet. The bar erupted in applause as the final note rang out, and Agatha found herself clapping harder than anyone else.

 

Alice stepped back to the mic, her cheeks flushed from the performance. “Thank you! You guys are amazing!” she called out, earning another wave of cheers. Then, with a sly grin, she added, “And if you felt like that song hit a little too close to home, well… good. That’s the point.”

 

The crowd laughed and cheered again, and Agatha felt a rush of pride as she watched Rio exchange a triumphant high-five with Alice. For a moment, Rio’s eyes found Agatha’s again, and she mouthed something that looked suspiciously like, All for you.

 

Agatha’s heart swelled, and she couldn’t help but smile back. She didn’t need words to respond; the look in her eyes said it all.

 

On stage, Rio stood from behind her drum kit, brushing her hair out of her face with an easy, confident grin. Alongside Alice and Jen, she gave an exaggerated bow, the three of them basking in the adoration of the crowd.

 

As the band began packing up their equipment, Agatha remained at her table, reluctant to disturb the moment. Watching Rio perform had been like witnessing pure magic, and she found herself replaying the set in her mind—the energy, the skill, the way Rio had commanded the stage with every beat of her drums. She couldn’t wait to tell her just how incredible she’d been.

 

Rio stepped off the stage, her presence captivating even in the post-performance chaos. The crowd was still abuzz, and several people gravitated toward her and the other band members almost instantly. Agatha sipped the last of her wine, her gaze following Rio as she was approached by a small group lingering near the stage.
