The group consisted of two women and a man, all of whom seemed utterly enamored with Rio. One of the women, a brunette in a leather jacket, leaned in close, her voice too soft to be heard over the residual noise, but her posture was unmistakably engaging. The man beside her nodded enthusiastically at whatever Rio said, his laughter coming too easily, while the second woman—a striking redhead—hovered just behind them, her eyes never leaving Rio’s face. Their admiration was palpable, their attention bordering on outright flirtation.

 

Agatha remained at her table, swirling the last of her wine with deliberate ease, her outward demeanor a perfect picture of calm. But her sharp eyes betrayed her true feelings, narrowing slightly every time one of the women hovering near Rio leaned in too close or touched her under the pretense of congratulating her. Agatha’s gaze tracked every movement, every overzealous smile, every light touch that lingered just a fraction longer than necessary.

 

The brunette with the saccharine smile and an air of practiced charm, was especially persistent. She laughed at something Rio said, her laugh too loud, too eager, and placed her hand on Rio’s shoulder. It was a casual gesture on the surface, but the way her fingers lingered betrayed her intent. Agatha’s grip tightened slightly on her wine glass as she took a slow, measured sip, her lips twitching downward in the faintest frown.

 

Despite the brunette’s overtures, Rio’s body language was relaxed but firmly neutral. She accepted the congratulations with a polite smile and nodded along as the small group vied for her attention, but there was no real engagement, no reciprocation in her posture. If anything, she seemed mildly amused by the whole interaction, as if humoring a group of overeager fans.

 

What soothed Agatha most, however, were the subtle, searching glances Rio kept sending her way. Every few moments, Rio’s eyes would flicker across the room, scanning the crowd until they found Agatha. And when they did, her expression would shift just slightly—a small quirk of her lips, a barely perceptible lift of her brow that seemed to say, Still with me? It was a quiet reassurance, a tether that connected them despite the noise and chaos around them.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a faint smirk. Oh, she was still with her, all right. And she wasn’t going anywhere.

 

The brunette leaned in again, this time brushing her hair over her shoulder in what was clearly meant to be a coquettish gesture. Agatha’s eyes narrowed further as she leaned back in her chair, her fingers tapping idly against the stem of her glass. She wasn’t the jealous type—she trusted Rio implicitly—but that didn’t mean she had to enjoy watching someone blatantly overstep.

 

Alice, always one to sense the subtle undercurrents in a room, appeared beside Agatha with two drinks in hand, Jen following close behind. She flashed Agatha a knowing grin as she slid one of the glasses toward her, replacing her now empty wine glass. “You good, Agatha?” she asked, her tone teasing but laced with a slight concern.

 

Agatha glanced up at her, one eyebrow arching as she reached for the drink. “Of course. Why wouldn’t I be?” she replied, the words coming out a touch too sharp, a little too quick.

 

Alice smirked knowingly, leaning back slightly in her chair. “Oh, no reason. Just thought I’d check, seeing as how your girlfriend over there is currently being adored by her little fan club.”

 

Agatha’s gaze flicked back to Rio, who was still surrounded by the group of admirers. The sight of the woman leaning in a little too close, laughing a bit too loudly, was enough to make Agatha’s stomach tighten in a way she wasn’t entirely comfortable with. Her fingers curled around the glass in her hand, her grip tightening as she tried to mask her growing discomfort. “She’s hardly encouraging them,” Agatha muttered, her voice betraying a flicker of irritation.

 

“True,” Alice agreed with a nod, settling herself into the chair beside Agatha and crossing her legs. “But still, it’s kind of cute seeing you jealous. Very unflappable Dr. Harkness, rattled by a couple of groupies.”

 

“I’m not jealous,” Agatha said, her tone cool and controlled. But the sharpness of her response and the way she absentmindedly tapped her fingers against the side of her glass said otherwise.

 

“Uh-huh,” Alice said, her grin widening as she leaned back and took a sip of her own drink. “If you say so.”

 

Agatha shot Alice a sidelong glance, her lips pressing into a thin line as she held her gaze for a moment longer than necessary. But before she could come up with a retort—something biting, something that would leave Alice without a comeback—Rio finally managed to escape the small crowd. She waved off the lingering group with a polite but firm smile, her movements graceful and unhurried.

 

As Rio made her way toward the table, Agatha’s heart skipped a beat. The moment their eyes met, Rio’s face lit up, a genuine smile blooming across her features. The light in her eyes seemed to reach Agatha from across the room, making all the noise, all the attention, fade into the background. The way Rio’s entire demeanor shifted when she saw her, how she moved with a quiet confidence, told Agatha everything she needed to know: She’s mine and I’m hers.

 

A small sigh of relief escaped Agatha’s lips before she could stop it. Rio’s presence was like a balm, soothing the tension that had been building since the moment the first admirer had sidled up to her.

 

Rio leaned down to kiss Agatha’s cheek, her lips soft but lingering, in stark contrast to the fiery energy she had just poured into her performance. “Hey, gorgeous,” Rio greeted, her voice a low murmur that somehow cut through the ambient noise of the bar, wrapping Agatha in a cocoon of warmth. She rested her hands on the edge of the table, on either side of Agatha, her gaze lingering on her partner with a quiet intensity. “Enjoy the show?”

 

Agatha couldn’t stop the smile that tugged at her lips, despite herself. “You were incredible,” she said, her voice softer than she had intended, her eyes warm as they followed the movement of Rio’s hands.

 

Rio straightened, her gaze narrowing slightly as she took in the subtle shift in Agatha’s posture, the way her shoulders had tensed ever so slightly. “Everything okay?” she asked, her fingers brushing against Agatha’s as she leaned closer.

 

Agatha quickly masked her emotions, reclaiming her composure like she always did. “Of course,” she said smoothly, her voice as steady as ever. “Just enjoying the atmosphere.” But there was something in her eyes that Rio immediately saw—an unease, a fleeting tension that didn’t belong.

 

Rio tilted her head, studying Agatha for a moment, the wheels in her mind turning. Then, with a knowing glint in her eyes, she smirked. “Did those people bother you?” she asked, the playfulness in her tone softening just enough to show she wasn’t dismissing the subtle undercurrent she had picked up.

 

Agatha huffed lightly, the corners of her lips quirking upward. “Hardly. They were harmless,” she replied, though her words didn’t quite match the slight hardness in her voice. She wasn’t rattled, not exactly, but the way those admirers had hovered around Rio had gnawed at something inside her, an instinct to protect that she couldn’t ignore.

 

Rio’s grin deepened, and she leaned closer, her breath warm against Agatha’s ear, sliding on her lap. “You know you’re the only one I care about, right? Always.” Her voice was low and filled with a quiet promise, as though reminding Agatha that her heart was forever tethered to hers, regardless of how many admirers might surround her.

 

Agatha’s eyes softened, the knot of jealousy unravelling as Rio’s words washed over as she snaked her arms around her waist, her touch gentle, almost reverent. “I know,” she whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “You were phenomenal. I couldn’t take my eyes off you.”

 

Rio’s grin widened, a faint flush creeping up her neck at the unexpected praise. “Careful, Professor Harkness,” she teased, her eyes gleaming with mischief. “Flattery like that might go straight to my head.”

 

Agatha leaned in just a little, her voice dropping into a teasing murmur. “I think you’ve earned it,” she said, her words light but filled with sincerity.

 

“Thanks, love,” Rio replied, her smile turning tender as she planted another quick kiss on Agatha’s cheek. She straightened then, her expression shifting into a more playful one as she backed away slightly. “Now, let me pack up, and we can head home. I believe I made you a promise earlier.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, the last of her earlier irritation fading as Rio’s energy enveloped her once more. “Don’t keep me waiting too long, Miss Vidal,” she said with a raised brow, her voice playful but laced with an undeniable longing.

 

Rio winked, a mischievous sparkle in her eyes, before she turned on her heel and headed back toward the stage. Her presence lingered in the air, leaving Agatha with a smile that seemed to shine brighter with every second. As Rio mingled with the last of the fans and gathered her things, Agatha let herself settle into the quiet contentment that only Rio could bring, her heart still fluttering from the closeness they’d shared in that moment.

 

Even as the noise of the crowd ebbed away, Agatha’s smile stayed with her, a warm reminder that, no matter the noise, no matter the world outside, Rio was always hers. And that was all that mattered.

 

 

As soon as the front door closed behind them, Agatha couldn’t wait another second. The click of the door barely echoed before she had Rio in her arms, her body instinctively pulling Rio close as she turned her around and pressed her gently against the doorframe. Her hands settled on Rio’s waist, the warmth of her touch instantly grounding her. Without a word, Agatha’s lips captured Rio’s in a kiss that was equal parts fiery passion and tender devotion, a perfect reflection of everything Agatha had been holding in.

 

Rio’s soft laugh vibrated through the kiss, her hands lifting to rest on Agatha’s shoulders, her fingers grazing over the fabric of her clothes as if memorizing every curve and line. “Well, hello to you too,” Rio teased breathlessly, her voice a soft tremor against Agatha’s lips, the playful edge in her words belying the heat that simmered between them. “Careful, you’ll wake Nicky up.”

 

“Please, that boy could sleep through a nuclear apocalypse.”

 

Agatha pulled back just enough to look into Rio’s eyes, her own gaze darkened with an intensity that could only come from the depths of the emotions she was feeling. Her breath was steady but low, a hint of vulnerability in the way her lips parted as she searched Rio’s face for any sign of doubt. But there was none. There never was. “You’re mine,” Agatha whispered, her voice steady but laden with a possessiveness that was pure and unapologetic. “You know that, right? I don’t care who looks at you, who flirts with you, who dreams about you—you’re mine, Rio Vidal.” The words hung heavy in the air, a promise and a declaration, a truth Agatha needed to make clear.

 

Rio’s teasing expression melted away in an instant, her features softening, her eyes locking with Agatha’s. She reached up to cup Agatha’s face, her thumb gently sweeping across her cheek in a soothing motion that made Agatha’s heart race. “Always, Agatha,” Rio murmured, her voice low and sincere, as though there was no one else in the world but the two of them. “I’m yours. Completely.”

 

And that was all the invitation Agatha needed. Without another word, she leaned in again, her lips pressing against Rio’s with an urgency that spoke of everything she couldn’t say in that moment. Every ounce of love, of desire, of longing poured into the kiss, a kiss that was both tender and searing in its depth. Rio responded immediately, her hands threading into Agatha’s hair, pulling her closer, their bodies aligning as they deepened the kiss, lost in the heat and passion that swirled around them.

 

The world outside didn’t matter anymore. There was only the feeling of Rio in her arms, the sound of their breath mingling, and the way their hearts beat in perfect sync. Time seemed to stretch out, every second an eternity as they kissed with a hunger that was only ever satisfied when they were together.

 

Agatha’s hands roamed with deliberate slowness over Rio’s body, exploring the feel of her curves, the soft fabric of her outfit—an outfit that had driven her mad all evening. She could still feel the tension that had built up as she watched Rio move on stage, the subtle allure in every motion, the way the crowd had gravitated toward her. And yet, Rio had been hers all along. “This outfit,” Agatha murmured, her voice low and thick with desire as her lips brushed against Rio’s and she slipped her hand underneath the damn crop top to place her hand high in Rio’s torso, “was torture. Watching you all night, knowing they were looking at you, wanting you… all while I had the privilege of knowing exactly who you were going home with.”

 

Rio’s lips curved into a teasing smirk, her fingers sliding down the length of Agatha’s arms as she let her explore her chest, leaving a trail of warmth behind and making Rio moaned slightly, throwing her head back to give her more access. “Well, I wore it for you, you know. Their attention wasn’t exactly my goal, only yours.” Her voice was playful, but Agatha could hear the underlying truth in it—Rio had dressed to captivate only her.

 

Agatha’s growl rumbled low in her throat, dark and possessive, more instinct than thought. Rio barely had time to react before she was swept off her feet, Agatha lifting her with effortless strength. A delighted laugh bubbled from Rio’s lips, breathless and teasing as she clung to Agatha’s shoulders, her legs wrapping naturally around Agatha’s waist.

 

“Someone’s feeling assertive tonight,” Rio teased, her lips brushing against Agatha’s ear, her fingers threading through thick waves of dark hair.

 

Agatha didn’t answer—not with words, at least. She walked them straight to the bedroom, her grip firm but careful, her body radiating heat and intent. The door swung shut behind them with a soft click, sealing them away from the rest of the world. And then, without ceremony, Agatha tossed Rio onto the bed.

 

Rio gasped as she bounced slightly against the mattress, her head tilting up just in time to see Agatha stalking toward her, the flicker of candlelight catching in her dark eyes.

 

“What are you doing?” Rio asked, though her breathlessness betrayed that she already knew the answer.

 

Agatha climbed over her in a fluid motion, caging Rio beneath her, pinning her wrists to the mattress with a grip that sent shivers down her spine. She leaned in, lips hovering just above Rio’s, teasing her with the mere ghost of a touch.

 

“Reminding you,” Agatha answered, her voice soft but carrying a note of command that sent a shiver down Rio’s spine. She hovered above her, her gaze intense, the depth of her love and possessiveness clear in her eyes. “Reminding you that you’re mine. And I’ll never let you forget it.” The words hung in the air, heavy with meaning.

 

Rio’s breath hitched, her pulse pounding in her throat. Agatha’s control, her confidence, the sheer power she exuded—it made Rio dizzy in the best way. She swallowed hard, licking her lips before whispering, “I don’t need reminding.” The tremor in her voice betrayed her, though, and Agatha smirked knowingly. “But I won’t stop you if that’s what you want and need.” The admission was barely audible, but it carried all the weight of Rio’s own desires and understanding.

 

Agatha’s eyes darkened.

 

“Oh, love,” she murmured, pressing her lips just below Rio’s ear, letting the words ghost over her skin. “What I want is to ruin you.”

 

The sound that escaped Rio was somewhere between a sigh and a gasp, her back arching instinctively as Agatha moved lower, her lips curling as she leaned down to kiss the soft skin of Rio’s jaw, trailing her lips down her neck with the utmost care, before moving lower as Rio moaned lowly. She savored each movement, each kiss a promise, each touch a way of marking her in the most intimate of ways. The urgency was there, but it was tempered by the unspoken depth of their bond, the trust between them that allowed them to savor each moment.

 

Rio’s body responded instinctively, her hands threading through Agatha’s hair, pulling her closer as their kisses deepened, more fervent, more passionate with each passing second. The air was thick with desire, the world outside fading into nothingness as they celebrated each other—not just physically, but emotionally, spiritually. There was no room for doubt, no room for insecurity; they were together, completely and utterly. And in that moment, nothing else mattered.

 

Clothes fell away, lost somewhere between sighs and laughter, between teasing bites and desperate hands. There was no distance left between them, no space untouched. Agatha was all over Rio’s body, ravishing it with her with kisses, grazes of her tongue and teeth like she was something to be savored, something exquisite, something worth taking her time with. And Rio—Rio gave back just as fiercely, returning every gesture with an equal intensity.

 

By the time they finally collapsed together, tangled in damp sheets and lingering heat, the air still buzzed with the remnants of their pleasure.

 

Hours later, they lay tangled in each other’s arms, the room bathed in the soft glow of moonlight. Rio lay draped against Agatha’s chest, utterly spent, her body still thrumming with satisfaction. She let out a sigh of contentment, pressing a lazy kiss to the warm skin just beneath Agatha’s collarbone.

 

“I love you,” Rio murmured, her voice a sleepy whisper against the soft rise and fall of Agatha’s chest.

 

Agatha pressed a kiss to the top of her head, her fingers idly tracing small circles on Rio’s back. “I love you too, my Rio,” she replied, her voice thick with affection. Her eyes closed, the sound of Rio’s heartbeat steadying her own.

 

As they drifted into a peaceful sleep, the world outside ceased to exist, leaving only the warmth of their love, their quiet promises, and the unspoken certainty that, come morning, they would do it all over again.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

🔥🔥🔥

Down Memory Lane

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Ash on and old man's sleeve

Is all the ash the burnt roses leave.

Dust in the air suspended

Marks the place where a story ended.

Dust inbreathed was a house—

The walls, the wainscot and the mouse,

The death of hope and despair,

This is the death of air.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

One quiet Saturday afternoon, Rio and Agatha had decided it was finally time to tackle the house’s basement, a task they’d been putting off for weeks. The goal: clear enough space to move the last of Rio’s belongings from Lilia’s house, where they’d been patiently waiting for their owner to retrieve them.

 

Agatha leaned against the doorframe at the top of the stairs, arms crossed as she watched Rio descend first. The wooden steps creaked slightly under her weight, and the faint hum of the flickering basement light added a layer of nostalgia to the otherwise mundane task.

 

“You know,” Rio called back over her shoulder, her voice laced with humor, “if I’m doing this, I think I deserve veto power over anything questionable down here.”

 

Agatha smirked, pushing off the doorframe and following her down. “Questionable? I’ll have you know everything in this basement has been carefully curated. It’s all perfectly respectable. Well,” she paused, a playful glint in her eyes, “except for maybe that one box of old Christmas ornaments. Those might actually be possessed.”

 

Rio chuckled, flipping the light switch and illuminating the organized chaos before them. The basement was a maze of mismatched boxes, old furniture, and forgotten knick-knacks, the kind of space that told the story of a life well-lived. She crouched by a pile of unlabeled boxes, curiosity sparking in her gaze. “All right, let’s see what we’re working with.”

 

They dove into the task with a shared rhythm, sorting items into piles: keep, donate, and discard. Agatha took the opportunity to play the curator, explaining the backstory of certain items, while Rio brought her clever commentary to the process.

 

About twenty minutes in, Rio pulled out a dusty, framed photo from one of the boxes and froze. Her lips quirked into a mischievous grin as she held it up for Agatha to see. “Care to explain this?” she asked, her tone mock-serious.

 

Agatha glanced over and immediately groaned, covering her face with one hand. The photo showed a much younger version of herself – maybe fifteen or sixteen - sporting an absurdly oversized hat, her expression a mix of forced enthusiasm and embarrassment. “That,” she began, her voice heavy with mock exasperation, “was a teenage phase. A short-lived attempt to join a local history reenactment group, just to get away from home for a while. The hat was mandatory, and let me tell you, it weighed a ton.”

 

Rio burst into laughter, holding her sides as she set the photo carefully to the side. “Oh, this is a keeper. Forget the basement—it’s going on the mantle.”

 

“Absolutely not,” Agatha said, narrowing her eyes playfully as she reached for another box. “Over my dead body.”

 

Rio grinned, clearly relishing the banter. “We’ll see about that.”

 

As they continued, Rio unearthed a series of quirky items: an ancient, battered teapot that Agatha claimed once belonged to her grandmother, a set of mismatched candlesticks, and a collection of handwritten letters tied together with a faded ribbon. Each discovery led to a story, a laugh, or a playful jab.

 

An hour in, they’d made significant progress, the basement was looking far less chaotic, and both women were covered in dust and slightly out of breath. Agatha stretched, arching her back with a satisfied sigh. “Not bad, Vidal. We might just make an adult out of you yet.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but smiled, brushing her hands off on her jeans. “You know, this wasn’t half as bad as I thought it’d be. Even if your basement is basically a treasure trove of questionable life choices.”

 

Agatha chuckled, tossing a balled-up piece of newspaper at her. “Keep that up, and I might reconsider letting you move in your own stuff.”

 

Rio dodged the paper, grinning as she stood and offered Agatha a hand to move to the next box. “Come on, let’s finish up. We’ve got space to clear and memories to make.”

 

As they worked through another pile of boxes, Agatha reached for a smaller one tucked neatly into a corner. The handwriting on the label—her own—read: “Nicky - Baby Stuff.” She smiled for a moment before pulling it out and setting it on the floor.

 

Rio, perched nearby and wiping dust off her hands, noticed immediately. Her eyes lit up with curiosity. “Oh, now this I have to see.”

 

Agatha chuckled, shaking her head. “It’s nothing exciting. Just sentimental clutter.”

 

Rio scooted closer, practically bouncing with enthusiasm. “Sentimental clutter is the best kind. Don’t hold out on me.” She reached for the lid, glancing at Agatha for permission. When Agatha nodded, Rio carefully opened the box, and her excitement softened into something warmer. Inside was a collection of tiny folded clothes, soft blankets, and a few well-loved toys.

 

Rio reached for the first item on top, a pale blue onesie with little embroidered clouds. She held it up, her expression a mix of delight and disbelief. “He was this small? I can’t even wrap my head around it!”

 

Agatha smiled, her eyes softening as she traced a finger over the fabric. “He was tiny. He was born a little early, so even this was too big for him at first. I remember rolling up the sleeves so his little hands wouldn’t get lost in them.”

 

Rio’s brows furrowed, her curiosity piqued. “What was he like as a baby? I bet he was adorable.”

 

Settling back onto her heels, Agatha’s gaze turned distant, filled with a tender kind of nostalgia. “Quiet, at first. He had this way of staring at people, like he was trying to figure out the whole world before he even got started. And when he laughed…” Her voice softened further, and a small, wistful smile graced her lips. “That sound could light up a room. I used to do the most ridiculous things just to hear it again.”

 

Rio chuckled, pulling out a pair of impossibly tiny socks. She held them up between her fingers, her eyes wide with amusement. “These are ridiculous. How did you not lose them the second you took them off him?”

 

Agatha laughed, covering her face for a moment. “Oh, I did. Constantly. I can’t even tell you how many lone socks I found in the weirdest places—inside couch cushions, under the car seat, even in the fridge once. Eventually, I gave up and started buying them in bulk.”

 

Rio grinned, shaking her head as she picked up a soft yellow blanket. She held it to her cheek, testing its texture. “This is so soft. Did he have a favorite?”

 

Agatha’s smile grew fond as she reached over and took the blanket from Rio, running her fingers along its frayed edges. “This one, actually. He used to clutch it so tightly in his little fists. It had to go everywhere with him—car rides, naps, you name it. I tried to replace it once, but he wasn’t having it.”

 

Rio laughed, imagining the stubbornness. “That tracks. He’s got your determination.”

 

“Or my stubbornness,” Agatha quipped, shaking her head. “It’s a fine line.”

 

As they continued unpacking the box, Rio unearthed a small stuffed bear with a missing ear. She held it up, her expression half-teasing, half-sentimental. “Please tell me this little guy has a story.”

 

Agatha chuckled, reaching out to take the bear. “Oh, this is Mr. Buttons. He was a gift from a neighbor when Nicky was born. The ear didn’t survive Nicky’s teething phase, but he refused to give it up. Mr. Buttons was his co-pilot through all sorts of toddler adventures.”

 

Rio cradled the bear for a moment before gently setting it back in the box. “This is all so precious, Agatha. I love seeing this side of you—mom mode.”

 

As they packed up the box, Rio paused, her fingers lingering on the tiny, soft onesie. The pale blue fabric felt delicate, almost sacred, in her hands. She looked up at Agatha, her expression thoughtful and a little hesitant. “Will you tell me more about him? Stories from before I knew him?”

 

Agatha’s face softened immediately, her warm smile lighting up the dim basement. “I would love to, my love. And I’m sure he’d love that, too. He’s always asking me about when he was little—as if he’s all grown up now.” She scoffed lightly, shaking her head as a fond image of her little boy filled her mind. “He’s still such a baby in so many ways.”

 

Rio’s lips curved into a gentle smile as she carefully folded the onesie, smoothing out its creases before placing it back in the box. Her movements were deliberate, almost reverent. “Thank you,” she said quietly. Then, with a mischievous glint in her eye, she added, “And I want to know everything. All the accomplishments, all the little moments, the big milestones—and especially the embarrassing stories. You know, so I can really wow him when I bring them up at just the right moment.”

 

Agatha burst into laughter, her head tilting back as she let the sound echo around them. It was a rare, uninhibited kind of laugh that made Rio’s chest swell with affection. “You’re impossible,” Agatha said, wiping at the corner of her eye as her laughter subsided.

 

“Not impossible,” Rio countered, grinning as she set the onesie down and closed the box. “Just thorough.” She winked, her playful energy bouncing off Agatha like sunlight.

 

Agatha shook her head, still smiling. “I can already hear him now: ‘Rio, stop embarrassing me!’ And you’ll just keep going, won’t you?”

 

Rio leaned over, pressing a quick kiss to Agatha’s cheek. “Of course. It’s my duty as his cool Rio.”

 

Agatha’s eyes softened at the wording. It still felt surreal sometimes—how naturally Rio had stepped into their lives, becoming a vital part of her and Nicky’s little world. “You’re way more than just his ‘his cool Rio’,” she said, her voice dipping into something quieter, more serious. “You’re everything he needs. And everything I need, too.”

 

Rio blushed faintly, but she met Agatha’s gaze head-on, her expression full of love. “Well, I learn from the best,” she said, giving Agatha’s hand a squeeze. “You’re a pretty amazing mom yourself, you know.”

 

Agatha let out a soft, almost shy chuckle, brushing off the compliment with a wave of her hand. “I do my best. Now, come on, there’s still plenty of this mess to tackle.” She gestured to the remaining stacks of boxes, her tone light but her smile still lingering.

 

They worked side by side, sorting through the decades of accumulated boxes and forgotten items that had long since claimed the dimly lit basement. The air was thick with dust, the faint scent of old wood and cardboard lingering as they delved into the clutter.

 

Rio hummed softly to herself, her hands busy organizing a pile of books into categories. Every now and then, she glanced over at Agatha, who was kneeling by an older stack of boxes in the corner. Agatha’s brow furrowed as she opened another lid, her movements slower than usual. Rio caught the subtle tension in her posture—the way her shoulders stiffened, the slight downturn of her lips.

 

“What’s in there?” Rio asked gently, her voice cutting through the quiet hum of their work. She dusted off her hands and tilted her head, watching her partner closely.

 

Agatha hesitated, her fingers tracing the edge of the box. Her gaze lingered on it, distant and conflicted, before she finally spoke. “It’s… Evanora’s things. I must’ve shoved this down here after she died. I haven’t touched it since.”

 

Rio’s movements stilled, her playful energy replaced with quiet attentiveness. She moved closer, her presence grounding without being overbearing. “Do you want to go through it?” she asked softly.

 

Agatha gave a small nod, though her hesitation was palpable. She lifted the lid slowly, as if bracing herself for whatever memories might emerge. Inside was an assortment of items that once belonged to her mother: a faded scarf, its fabric worn thin; a set of tarnished hairpins with delicate engravings; a stack of letters, their edges yellowed with age. Beneath these lay photographs, their black-and-white starkness – Evanora hated colored pictures - amplifying the sense of distance and coldness they carried.

 

Agatha reached for the photographs, her fingers trembling slightly as she pulled out a handful. Rio, sensing the weight of the moment, crouched beside her and peered over her shoulder.

 

The images told a story Rio didn’t need Agatha to narrate. A younger Agatha, perhaps no older than eight or nine, stood stiffly beside a woman who exuded an oppressive authority even in the flatness of the photographs. Evanora’s expression was sharp, her features set in a way that seemed designed to intimidate rather than welcome. Her gaze pierced the camera lens with an icy clarity that sent a chill down Rio’s spine.

 

But it wasn’t Evanora who captured Rio’s attention—it was the little girl by her side. Agatha’s small frame seemed dwarfed by her mother’s presence. Her face was carefully blank, her lips pressed into a thin, neutral line. Wide, dark eyes stared back at the camera, not with curiosity or fear, but with a haunting kind of resignation. Her shoulders were drawn inward, as though trying to make herself smaller, to disappear.

 

“Oh, Agatha…” Rio whispered, her voice cracking under the weight of what she saw. She reached out instinctively, her hand brushing Agatha’s arm, searching for the right word. “You look so… melancholy.”

 

Agatha let out a short, humorless laugh, though it lacked any real amusement. Her voice was tight when she finally spoke. “Melancoly would’ve been an improvement. I don’t even remember feeling much of anything back then. Just… numb.”

 

Rio’s chest ached at the admission. She slid closer, her hand moving to rest gently on Agatha’s knee. “I’m so sorry,” she said, her voice barely above a whisper. “No one—especially not a child—should have to feel that way.”

 

Agatha didn’t respond immediately. Instead, she flipped through the photographs, her gaze lingering on each one. “She was cruel, but not in the way you might expect,” she murmured, almost as if trying to convince herself. “She demanded perfection. Anything less was a failure. And failure… wasn’t tolerated.”

 

Rio frowned, anger flashing briefly in her eyes before she tempered it with the understanding Agatha needed in this moment. “You didn’t deserve that. None of it.”

 

Agatha turned her head, meeting Rio’s gaze. The mask she usually wore, the one she used to keep her past at bay, faltered. “I didn’t know how to be anything but what she wanted,” she admitted, her voice trembling. “I didn’t know I could be.”

 

Rio’s hand moved to cup Agatha’s cheek, her touch firm but tender. “You’re so much more than that, Agatha. You always were. And she doesn’t define you—not now, not ever.”

 

Agatha closed her eyes briefly, leaning into Rio’s touch. 

 

Rio’s heart ached as she watched Agatha flip through the photos, her fingers lingering over the edges of each one as if each image carried an unbearable weight. There were more images of a young Agatha, each one like a frozen moment in time, capturing a girl who never quite seemed to belong in the scenes. One showed Agatha seated at a piano in a starched dress, her hands placed stiffly on the keys, while Evanora loomed behind her, her presence almost suffocating. Another showed Agatha standing alone in a garden, her arms at her sides, her gaze distant and directed somewhere just out of frame, as if she were trying to disappear into the background.

 

Agatha’s voice broke the silence, quiet and tinged with a weariness that Rio could feel deep in her chest. “She was… everything a mother shouldn’t be,” Agatha said, her voice hollow, the words heavy with years of unspoken pain. “Cold. Demanding. Unforgiving. Nothing I ever did was enough for her. I wasn’t enough.”

 

Rio’s chest tightened, and she felt a wave of anger rise in her, but she swallowed it down. This wasn’t about her feelings—it was about Agatha’s. She was the one who had lived through it. “You didn’t deserve that,” Rio said softly, her voice steady, though her heart was anything but. She spoke with a conviction that carried through the quiet space, filling the air between them. “Not as a child. Not ever.”

 

Agatha nodded but didn’t respond, her focus remaining fixed on the photographs as if the images held the key to unlocking some long-buried truth. Her hands trembled slightly as she sifted through them, but she didn’t stop until she reached the bottom of the pile. There, she stopped, her breath catching as her fingers brushed against a photo she hadn’t seen in years. It was a rare one—a glimpse of her as a toddler, her small frame sitting on a soft blanket with a book in her lap. Evanora’s hand was visible in the corner of the frame, gripping the edge of the book with a force that made it seem as though even that small moment was not her own.

 

Rio leaned in closer, her heart heavy as she studied the photo. Even at such a young age, Agatha’s body language was telling. The tension was visible in the small curve of her shoulders, the way her tiny hands clutched the book so tightly, as if afraid it might be taken away at any moment. Rio’s voice was soft as she asked, “She never let you just… be a kid, did she?”

 

“No,” Agatha admitted, the word carrying the weight of a lifetime’s worth of unspoken truths. Her gaze stayed fixed on the photo, her fingers tracing the edges of the image as though to ground herself in the present. “She didn’t believe in softness. Or affection. Everything was about control.”

 

Rio’s heart clenched at the rawness in Agatha’s words. She placed a gentle hand over Agatha’s, grounding her in the moment, reminding her that she wasn’t alone. “You’re so much more than what she tried to make you, Agatha,” Rio said, her voice tender yet filled with fierce certainty. “You’re kind. And warm. And strong. You’ve built a life that’s full of love, despite everything she tried to take from you.”

 

Agatha set the photos down carefully, almost reverently, as though they were fragile and could shatter if handled too roughly. She took a deep breath, her hand reaching for Rio’s, her fingers lacing with hers tightly. There was a tremor in her touch, but it wasn’t from weakness. It was from something far deeper—emotion, vulnerability, and a need for contact and connection.

 

“Sometimes,” Agatha began, her voice quiet, almost contemplative, “I wonder how I managed to get here. To have you. To have Nicky.”

 

Rio’s gaze softened, her grip on Agatha’s hand firm as she met her eyes. “You got here because you’re you,” she said, her voice unwavering. “You didn’t let her destroy the best parts of you. And now, you’re giving Nicky everything she never gave you.”

 

A faint smile tugged at Agatha’s lips, though there was a sadness behind her eyes that hadn’t fully lifted. Her expression softened as she squeezed Rio’s hand, her voice cracking just slightly. “You always know what to say, don’t you?”

 

Rio grinned, a lightness returning to her features as she leaned in, pressing a kiss to Agatha’s forehead. “It’s my job, love,” she whispered, her lips lingering for a moment, offering more than just the kiss—an anchor, a promise, a reminder that Agatha was no longer alone in the world.

 

The brush of her lips was gentle, but it carried with it an unspoken promise to be there, to heal the wounds that could never truly disappear, and to create a future built on love and understanding. As Rio pulled back, she kept her hand in Agatha’s, offering the steady comfort that Agatha had always given her.

 

Agatha let out a small, forced chuckle as she placed the photographs back into the box. Her fingers lingered over the edges of the images for a moment, but she quickly closed the lid with a decisive motion, as though the simple act of sealing it away would somehow lessen the weight of the memories inside. “It’s all ancient history,” she said lightly, brushing the dust from her hands, a hollow laugh escaping her lips. “It doesn’t affect me anymore.”

 

The words hung in the air, but Rio didn’t respond right away. She studied Agatha carefully, her gaze tracing the lines of her face, the set of her shoulders. Agatha’s expression was composed, but there was something in the way she avoided eye contact, the deliberate way she kept her gaze fixed on the box, as if the objects inside were more real than the woman sitting beside her. She was trying to seem unaffected, trying to bury the feelings that the photos had stirred up, but Rio knew better. She knew Agatha’s patterns too well by now. The tightness in her jaw, the way her breath came just a little faster than usual, the subtle tremor in her fingers as they brushed against the lid—Agatha was trying to push the emotions away, but they were still there, just beneath the surface.

 

Rio didn’t push right away. She wasn’t foolish enough to believe that Agatha would open up just because she saw through her carefully crafted mask. She knew better than most that Agatha could hide behind walls made of stone if she wanted to. And yet, Rio also knew that Agatha didn’t have to do it alone anymore. That she didn’t have to hide from her.

 

Finally, Rio spoke, her voice soft but unwavering, the sincerity in it as clear as the concern that shadowed her eyes. “You don’t have to pretend with me, you know,” she said, her tone just shy of a plea.

 

Agatha’s eyes flickered toward her, a brief flash of something—vulnerability, perhaps, or a deeper sorrow—but it was gone in an instant. She looked away quickly, and her voice, when she answered, was almost too even. “I’m not pretending,” she said, though the words sounded hollow in the space between them. “It just… doesn’t matter anymore. I’ve moved on.”

 

Rio let the silence settle for a moment, allowing Agatha’s words to linger. She wasn’t buying it—not fully. She knew those things too well herself to believe that everything, especially something as painful as one’s past, could just disappear. But she also understood the importance of giving Agatha the space to navigate the conversation at her own pace. Pushing too hard wouldn’t help anyone. “Okay,” Rio said gently, her voice soft but steady, carrying an unspoken promise of patience. “If that’s how you feel.”

 

For a moment, Agatha seemed to relax, the tension in her shoulders loosening slightly as if the lack of resistance was a relief. She was quick to move on, clearly eager to shift away from the topic, but Rio reached out then, placing her hand over Agatha’s with a quiet tenderness that spoke volumes.

 

“Just… promise me something?” Rio asked, her voice low, almost a whisper, as though the words were something precious.

 

Agatha glanced at her, her brow furrowing in confusion and curiosity. “What?”

 

Rio’s thumb gently stroked the back of Agatha’s hand as she spoke, her gaze unwavering. “Promise me that if you ever do want to talk about it—about her, about anything—you’ll come to me. I’m here for you, always. You don’t have to carry this alone.”

 

The words hung there, raw and honest, vulnerable in a way that Rio rarely allowed herself to be. She held her breath, waiting for Agatha’s response, not wanting to rush her, but needing her to understand just how deeply Rio meant what she was saying.

 

For a long moment, Agatha didn’t respond. Her eyes softened as she looked at Rio, something flickering across her face—something that might have been recognition, or maybe even gratitude, but it was fleeting. Agatha’s lips parted, but the words came slowly, almost as if they were too difficult to say. “I know,” she said finally, her voice barely above a whisper. “I really do.”

 

Rio smiled, the warmth in her eyes deepening. She squeezed Agatha’s hand gently, a quiet reaffirmation of the promise she had just made. “Good,” she said, her voice steady, with no hesitation. “Because you’ve been there for me more times than I can count. Let me return the favor, okay?”

 

A small smile tugged at the corners of Agatha’s lips, faint but real. It wasn’t the big, radiant smile Rio was used to seeing, but it was something. It was a crack in the walls, a crack that, though small, was enough to let in a little bit of light. “Okay,” Agatha replied softly, her voice warm, the promise in her words just as real as Rio’s had been.

 

They didn’t say anything else after that. Rio didn’t push, and Agatha didn’t elaborate further. Instead, they simply sat together, side by side, their hands still joined, the box of Evanora’s things resting quietly between them. It was a silent witness to a painful past that neither of them could erase, but the weight of it felt different now. It wasn’t something Agatha had to carry alone anymore. And that, in itself, was a kind of healing.

 

In the silence, Rio hoped that Agatha could feel the weight of her love, could feel the support that was now hers to lean on. Agatha had given so much to others, had carried so much of the world on her shoulders. And now, Rio was here, ready to carry it with her. To be the shoulder she could lean on, without reservation or fear.

 

As they finished tidying the basement, Rio couldn’t help but steal glances at Agatha as they worked. Her partner moved with her usual grace, every motion fluid and purposeful, but there was something off. A subtle rigidity had crept into her posture, a tightness in her shoulders that spoke volumes, despite the calm expression she wore. The way she lifted the boxes, the way she adjusted her movements, it all felt controlled, as though she was trying to keep herself in check. 

 

When they finally emerged from the basement, the scene that greeted them was a sharp contrast to the quiet tension that had filled the house. Nicky, sprawled out on the living room rug, was so absorbed in a puzzle that he barely registered their presence. The sight of him, so engrossed and innocent, seemed to pull something out of Agatha. A brief flicker of warmth softened her expression, just enough for Rio to catch it.

 

Agatha knelt down beside Nicky, her voice shifting to its usual softness as she asked him about his progress. “How’s it going, sweetheart? Got all the pieces in place?”

 

Rio smiled at the tenderness in Agatha’s voice, even though it was tinged with an undercurrent of something else—something that didn’t belong. Rio moved to sit beside them, crossing her legs on the floor, and offered to help with the puzzle. “Need an extra hand?” she asked, her tone light, trying to fill the space with something easy, something uncomplicated.

 

The next hour was spent in laughter, the three of them working together on the colorful puzzle that spread out before them. The pieces clicked together with satisfying ease, just like the familiar rhythm of their little family. The air was warm, filled with the hum of everyday life. But despite the seemingly calm atmosphere, Rio couldn’t shake the sense of tension that lingered around Agatha. It was subtle, but it was there—an almost imperceptible distance between Agatha and the moment. It was in the way she fidgeted with Nicky’s hair absentmindedly, the way her laugh didn’t reach her eyes, the way her responses seemed just a little too deliberate. Rio knew Agatha wasn’t okay. Not entirely. But for now, she stayed quiet, watching, waiting for the right moment to ask—to offer and reaffirm, if only Agatha would let her in.

 

By the time they had finished dinner and Nicky was tucked into bed, the weight of the evening had settled over Rio like a thick fog. She could feel it, the unspoken tension, hanging in the air between her and Agatha. The dinner had been pleasant enough, Nicky chattering about school and his latest obsession with puzzles, but Agatha had been distant—her laughter a little forced, her responses a little too quick, her attention always just a bit off. When Agatha had read Nicky his bedtime story, her voice was as soothing and melodic as ever, but Rio couldn’t help but notice as she passed by the way her fingers gripped the edges of the book a little too tightly, her knuckles white from the tension. It was subtle, but it was there. Agatha was trying to hold it together, to be present, but it was clearly eating at her.

 

Once Nicky had kissed them both goodnight and was safely in bed, Rio found herself walking beside Agatha in silence, the quiet stretching between them like an unspoken agreement to pretend everything was fine. But Rio knew better—Agatha’s silence was always a signal. She could feel the heaviness that had descended on their home, and though she didn’t want to push, she knew she couldn’t just let it slide. Not tonight.

 

As they made their way to their bedroom, the only sounds in the house were the soft creaks of the floorboards beneath their feet, the faint hum of the evening settling in. Rio could sense Agatha’s internal battle, the way she was holding herself a little too rigidly, as if she were trying to keep a storm inside. When they both climbed into bed, the space between them felt wider than it should have, even though they were side by side.

 

Once they were under the covers, Rio turned towards Agatha, gently tucking a strand of her long, brown hair behind her ear. The soft light from the bedside lamp cast a warm glow across Agatha’s face, but it couldn’t hide the subtle strain in her features. Rio’s voice was low, barely a whisper, but it carried the weight of her concern. “You’ve been tense all night,” she said, her hand resting lightly on Agatha’s arm. “I know you don’t have to tell me what’s on your mind if you’re not ready, but I want you to know I’m here.”

 

Agatha’s eyes met hers, a flicker of something unreadable passing between them. She turned her head slightly, as if deciding how to respond. Her expression softened, but there was still that guarded edge to it, the one that told Rio Agatha was holding back. “I know, darling. I’m sorry. Can we just… can we not talk about it tonight? I swear we’ll talk more, just not right now, if that’s okay.” Agatha’s voice cracked ever so slightly on the last word, and Rio could hear the vulnerability beneath her calm exterior.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, but only for a moment. She understood. Agatha needed time, needed space, and pushing her wouldn’t help. Rio nodded slowly, her thumb gently brushing over the back of Agatha’s hand where it lay beside her on the pillow. “That’s okay. Whatever you want. I’m not going anywhere,” she whispered, her voice steady and sure.

 

Agatha let out a shaky breath, a tremor passing through her as she leaned into Rio’s embrace. The tension that had been so tightly coiled in her body seemed to unravel just a little as she let herself relax against Rio. Her face pressed against Rio’s shoulder, and for a long moment, there was nothing but the sound of Agatha’s slow, steady breathing.

 

“Thank you,” Agatha murmured, her voice muffled against Rio’s skin. “I love you, Rio.”

 

Rio pressed a soft kiss to the top of Agatha’s head, the gesture warm and comforting. “I love you too,” she whispered back, her hand curling around Agatha’s, holding her close.

 

They lay there together, the silence between them no longer awkward but peaceful, the kind of silence that spoke of shared comfort and understanding. Agatha’s breathing grew deeper, slower, and eventually, Rio felt the subtle shift in the weight of her partner’s body. Agatha had fallen asleep, her body relaxed against Rio’s, the weight of the day finally catching up with her.

 

Rio, however, stayed awake for a while longer, watching Agatha’s peaceful expression in the dim light. No matter what came next, no matter how long it took for Agatha to open up, Rio would be there, waiting, ready to catch her when she fell.

 

 

The room was quiet, the soft hum of the night filling the space like a lullaby. Outside, the world had settled into its usual calm, the stars glimmering faintly through the curtains. Rio had drifted into a light sleep, her arm still draped protectively around Agatha, the warmth of their bodies keeping the chill of the night at bay. It was peaceful, serene—the kind of moment that felt suspended in time, untouchable and safe.

 

Until it wasn’t.

 

Agatha shifted beside her, a soft, incoherent mumble escaping her lips. Her body jerked once, a small tremor running through her as if she were trying to shake off some lingering nightmare. Her breathing grew shallow and rapid, each exhale slightly uneven. Then, a soft, anguished sound slipped from her throat—a sound that chilled Rio to the bone. She woke instantly, her mind sharpened with concern.

 

“Agatha?” Rio whispered, her voice thick with sleep but filled with worry, her hand instinctively reaching for Agatha’s trembling body. “Agatha, hey… It’s okay.”

 

Agatha’s eyes shot open with a sharp gasp as she sat up, her chest rising and falling with quick, erratic breaths, as though she’d been running through a nightmare and had just come to a sudden, crashing halt. She muttered something under her breath, a chant of sorts, almost like a prayer to herself. “I can be good. I can be good. I can be good…”

 

Her eyes darted around the room, unfocused, wild, as if she couldn’t quite orient herself to the reality of the room around her. Her breathing was fast and frantic, the edges of her panic creeping through. It took a moment for her gaze to land on Rio, and when it did, there was a brief flash of recognition—a flicker of something resembling clarity before the confusion returned. The mumbled words stopped, but the look in her eyes remained haunted, distant, like something deep inside was still trapped in that nightmare.

 

Rio sat up immediately, her heart twisting at the sight of Agatha so visibly shaken. The serene calm of their night had shattered, leaving only the sharp edges of fear in its place. She reached out, her hand moving to Agatha’s damp forehead, brushing the strands of hair away gently as she spoke in soothing tones. “It’s okay, love. You’re safe here. You’re with me. I’m right here.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard, her breath catching in her throat as she wiped her trembling hands over her face, trying to shake off the remnants of the terror that clung to her. Her voice was a mere whisper when she spoke, raw and fragile. “It was her,” she said, her eyes downcast, avoiding Rio’s gaze as she fought to steady herself. “My mother… she… she was so real. Like she was right here.”

 

The words hit Rio like a punch to the gut. She hadn’t known Agatha’s mother but the venom and fear in Agatha’s voice whenever she spoke about her was enough for Rio to understand. She hated her, too. Hated what that woman had done to Agatha, and how her shadow still seemed to loom over her, even now. Even after all this time.

 

Rio’s voice was gentle, but firm, as she cupped Agatha’s cheek, guiding her to meet her eyes. “It was just a nightmare, my love,” she said softly, her thumb brushing over the damp skin of Agatha’s face. “She’s gone. She can’t hurt you anymore. You’re safe, I promise.”

 

Agatha’s eyes fluttered closed at Rio’s touch, a shudder rippling through her as she leaned into it, her face pressing against Rio’s palm like she was searching for some tether to reality. “I know,” she whispered, her voice breaking with the weight of the admission. “But it felt so real. So real.” Her breath hitched, and her words faltered, as if the memories were clawing their way to the surface. “She was telling me… all the things she used to say. That I wasn’t enough. That I was wrong and evil. That I couldn’t be good. That I didn’t deserve…” She trailed off, her voice cracking, the rest of the sentence left unsaid.

 

The pain in her voice shattered Rio’s heart. She could feel the echo of that trauma in every word Agatha spoke, the poison that Evanora had poured into her years ago still reverberating in Agatha’s soul. Rio wanted to rage, wanted to tear it all apart—wanted to erase every trace of that woman’s cruelty from Agatha’s life. But for now, all she could do was hold her, to remind her that she was loved, that none of those horrible things were true.

 

Rio shifted closer, wrapping her arms around Agatha in a tight, comforting embrace. She pulled her in close, feeling the tremors still running through Agatha’s body. “None of that is true,” Rio said firmly, her voice steady, even though her heart was breaking. “You’re not weak, my love. You’re not evil. You are the strongest person I know, Agatha. And you deserve everything good. Every bit of love, every bit of happiness. Don’t you dare believe anything else. You hear me?”

 

Agatha didn’t respond with words, but her fingers—still trembling—gripped at the fabric of Rio’s shirt, clutching it like a lifeline. She didn’t need to say anything. The silent plea in the way she held on spoke volumes.

 

Rio held her tighter, her voice softer now, more tender. “I’m here, Agatha. You’re not alone in this. You’ll never be alone again.”

 

There was a long moment of silence, the weight of it heavy but comfortable. Rio didn’t push, knowing that sometimes silence was the only space where healing could begin. She held Agatha close, letting her process the words she’d spoken, giving her the time and space she needed to decide how much she wanted to share. Rio wasn’t in a rush. She had learned over time that Agatha would open up when she was ready—when the walls came down, it would be on her terms, and Rio would be there for every moment of it.

 

“Do you want to tell me more about it?” Rio’s voice was quiet, soft, respectful of the vulnerability between them.

 

Agatha’s only response was a slow shake of her head, her face still buried in the warmth of Rio’s shoulder, the movement small and almost imperceptible. She exhaled shakily, the weight of the nightmare still clinging to her, and whispered, “No… I just… Can you just hold me?”

 

Rio didn’t hesitate. Her arms tightened around Agatha instinctively, as if the very act of holding her could shield her from every cruel moment of her past. She tucked Agatha closer to her chest, as if trying to protect her from the weight of the world. “Always,” Rio whispered back, her voice a quiet promise. “You’re good, Agatha. You’re safe now. And you’re loved—so, so loved.”

 

Agatha let out a shuddering breath, and Rio could feel the tension in her body slowly begin to ebb away. It was a long time before Agatha’s shoulders relaxed more, the jagged edge of panic finally slipping away into a fragile stillness. Rio continued to hold her, moving slowly and carefully to lay back down, pulling Agatha with her so she could cradle her against her chest. They settled into the familiar comfort of each other’s embrace, the weight of the world outside their little bubble fading into nothing.

 

For a long while, there were no words between them—just the soft rhythm of their breathing, the steady heartbeat beneath Agatha’s ear, and the quiet hum of their world, completely separated from the chaos of everything else. Rio pressed a soft kiss to the top of Agatha’s head, her lips lingering there, as if to reassure her that she was real, that she was safe, that she was loved. Rio’s fingers traced soothing patterns on Agatha’s back under her shirt, every touch slow and deliberate, a silent offering of comfort and support.

 

The minutes stretched on, and Agatha’s breathing gradually evened out, the quick, shallow inhales replaced with deeper, steadier breaths. The tension that had gripped her so tightly at first began to melt away, and Rio felt it too—their bodies, entwined, finding a peaceful rhythm. Rio stayed there, holding her as if there was nowhere else she could possibly be. She whispered quiet reassurances into Agatha’s hair, her words barely audible in the stillness, but they were enough.

 

Eventually, Rio could feel the moment when Agatha fully relaxed, when her body gave in to the warmth of Rio’s presence and the exhaustion of the night’s emotional toll. Her breathing deepened, slow and even, her body growing heavier on top of the younger woman and Rio knew she had fallen back into sleep, though she didn’t let go. She stayed exactly where she was, holding Agatha close, her heart steady as she offered the same unwavering comfort she had received so many times before.

 

In that quiet, soft moment, Rio stayed awake, her thoughts drifting but never straying too far. She didn’t have all the answers. She couldn’t undo the damage of the past, the pain that still lingered in Agatha’s heart, but she could be here now. She could be the safe harbor Agatha needed.

 

As she lay there, with Agatha curled against her, Rio made a silent vow—a promise to herself, to Agatha, and to the life they were building together. She couldn’t erase the past, couldn’t change the scars that had been left behind. But she could make sure that from this point forward, Agatha’s days would be filled with warmth, safety, and love. Rio would be there to protect her, to hold her through the storms, and to give her a future where light could finally chase away the shadows.

 

 

The morning sunlight filtered softly through the curtains, casting a warm, golden glow across the room. Rio stirred, blinking her eyes open and stretching slightly, careful not to disturb the still form of Agatha still on her chest. Agatha was sound asleep, her face relaxed now, free of the turmoil that had haunted her during the night. But Rio could still see the lingering sadness in her features—the echoes of the nightmare that had disturbed her night.

 

Rio’s heart ached for Agatha, but she knew better than anyone how strong she was. Agatha’s past didn’t define her—it was the love they had now, the life they were building, that mattered. And that was exactly what Rio intended to show her this morning.

 

She carefully slid out of bed, her bare feet brushing the cool floor, and padded quietly to the door. She glanced back at Agatha one last time before closing the door softly behind her.

 

The house was still quiet as she made her way down the hallway, passing Nicky’s room. He was still fast asleep, tucked up in his little bed, his small chest rising and falling gently with each breath. His stuffed dragon had fallen on the floor during the night, so she went in to pick it up and tuck it back in the little boy’s arms. She smiled and exited the room, on a mission.

 

She entered the kitchen, determined to make breakfast that would bring a little comfort to Agatha after her night. She opened the fridge, pulling out eggs, butter, and fresh ingredients. Her movements were quick but deliberate, as if she was crafting something more than just a meal—a small, simple act of love that would hopefully help Agatha feel a little lighter.

 

“Rio?” Nicky’s voice was soft from the doorway, and Rio turned to see him rubbing his eyes, still half-asleep. “Are you making breakfast?”

 

Rio smiled, her heart warming at the sight of him. “I am, little love,” she said gently. “Would you like to help me?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up, and he nodded eagerly, scampering over to the counter where Rio was preparing the ingredients. Rio lifted him up onto a stool, and together, they started cracking eggs and whisking them in a bowl. Nicky’s small hands were clumsy, but Rio didn’t mind. The mess didn’t matter—it was the moment of connection that she cherished.

 

As they worked together, Rio’s mind wandered back to Agatha’s nightmare. She couldn’t help but relate to some of her own experiences. Growing up in foster care in some less than ideal families, she had had her fair share of lack of love, hopelessness and loneliness, but seeing Agatha also struggling with similar problems made her feel terrible. She could deal with the world being unfair towards herself, but she couldn’t stand idea that Agatha had known anything else but love and support.  

 

After a few minutes, Nicky’s giggles pulled her out of her thoughts as he dropped a little bit of egg batter on the counter. Rio laughed softly and wiped it away before turning her attention back to the stove, where the eggs were beginning to sizzle. She hummed a little tune to herself, the warmth of the morning filling her with a sense of peace.

 

Once the breakfast was ready, Rio and Nicky carefully carried everything upstairs, Nicky holding a small bowl of fruit in his hands as if it were the most precious thing in the world, and Rio in charge of the heavier tray. They quietly entered their bedroom and set the tray down on the bedside table, careful not to wake up Agatha, who was still nestled under the covers.

 

“Good morning, Mama,” Nicky whispered, leaning over to kiss her cheek.

 

Agatha stirred at the sound of his voice, her eyelids fluttering open. She looked up at Nicky, her lips curling into a soft, tired smile. “Good morning, my love,” she said, her voice still thick with sleep.

 

Rio sat on the edge of the bed, gently leaning down to kiss Agatha’s sleepy face. “We made you breakfast,” she said quietly, her gaze tender as she met Agatha’s eyes. “I thought it might help.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened, but there was a glint of something else in her eyes—a mix of appreciation and vulnerability. “Thank you,” she murmured, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

Nicky climbed onto the bed beside her, placing the bowl of fruit in her lap with a proud grin. “We made it together, me and Rio!” he said brightly, his little chest puffing up with pride. “I helped!”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her fingers lightly brushing Nicky’s hair. “Rio and I, love,” she corrected gently. “You’re the best, Nicky,” she said, her voice thick with love.

 

As Agatha reached for the tray and began to pick at the breakfast, Rio stayed close by, her heart full as she took a berry from the bowl still on Agatha’s lap.

 

Agatha’s eyes softened as she watched Rio and Nicky, her heart swelling with warmth. She had never imagined that this kind of love and care was something she could have—something that was all hers. The way Rio had thought to make breakfast for her, the way Nicky eagerly helped, and how both of them were so present, so willing to make her feel better, made Agatha feel an overwhelming sense of gratitude.

 

She could feel the lump in her throat as she gazed at the simple, yet deeply meaningful gesture. Her past, the harsh memories of Evanora seemed so distant in that moment, replaced by the love and family she and Nicky had built with Rio.

 

Agatha’s smile widened as she leaned in and kissed Rio gently on the lips. It was a kiss full of gratitude, love, and the quiet promise of forever. When she pulled away, she gave Nicky a tender look. “And you, little one,” she said, grasping an squeezing his chubby cheeks, making his giggle, “you’ve made my life so much brighter. I can’t imagine it without you.”

 

Nicky beamed up at her, his eyes sparkling with pure joy. “I’m happy, too, Mama. I’m glad we’re all together.”

 

Agatha’s heart fluttered at their words, the love between the three of them wrapping around her like a warm blanket. In this moment, the pain of the past seemed to fall away, replaced by the strong, unwavering bond they shared.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

I love hearing your thoughts!

Dance Students

Chapter Notes

I just spent my whole Sunday writing so I have more chapters ready for the days to come hihi (as if I didn't have anythign better to do... I'll regret it later, I just know it)

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

From wrong to wrong the exasperated spirit

Proceeds, unless restored by that refining fire

Where you must move in measure, like a dancer.'

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The rest of breakfast passed in a warm haze of family togetherness. Wrapped in cozy blankets, the three of them stayed in bed longer than they probably should have, Nicky animatedly recounting the latest adventures of his favorite superheroes while Rio and Agatha occasionally exchanged amused glances over his head. Agatha’s nightmare felt like a distant memory now, fading further with every burst of laughter and shared bite of fruit from the tray.The nightmare had left no shadow here.

 

When breakfast was done, Nicky was practically bouncing with excitement, declaring himself ready to help with “important moving stuff.” He stood on the bed and struck a superhero pose, fists on his hips, as if preparing for a mission.

 

Agatha quirked an eyebrow at him, suppressing a smile. “Important, huh? Are you sure you’re up for it? It’s a big job.”

 

“I’m super up for it!” Nicky declared, jumping down from the bed and landing with an exaggerated stomp.

 

Rio laughed, sitting up and ruffling his hair. “Well then, super helper, let’s see what you’ve got.”

 

Once everyone was ready, they gathered what they needed for the trip to Lilia’s house, the last stop in their moving process. A few lingering boxes stored at Lilia’s were finally coming home now that space had been cleared in the basement—a task they’d put off for weeks but had suddenly become urgent with Nicky’s enthusiasm leading the charge.

 

As they piled into the car, Rio reached back to buckle Nicky into his booster seat, her tone playful. “You ready to be our official box carrier, buddy?”

 

Nicky grinned wide, puffing out his chest dramatically. “I’m the strongest! I can carry all the boxes!” He flexed his little arms with great effort, his face scrunching up in mock determination.

 

Agatha chuckled from the driver’s seat, glancing at Rio as she started the car. Her free hand rested briefly over Rio’s on the center console, a silent gesture of affection. “That’s good to know, little man. We’re counting on you to save the day.”

 

The drive to Lilia’s wasn’t long, but it was filled with lighthearted chatter. Nicky bounced in his seat as Rio pointed out landmarks along the way, her voice animated as she wove stories about her past. “See that little park over there?” she said, gesturing out the window. “That’s where Lilia took me for a run when I needed a break from studying. I tripped over that big tree root and swore I’d never run again, but Lilia made me get up and finish a whole lap around it, while she was just sitting on that bench, reading.”

 

Nicky gasped, wide-eyed. “You didn’t just give up?”

 

“Of course not,” Rio said, grinning at him through the rearview mirror. “Lilia said, ‘If you give up, you’ll always trip over the same spot in your mind.’ And she was right. I never tripped over that root again.”

 

Agatha glanced at Rio from the corner of her eye, her lips curving into a fond smile. She loved how Rio could bring even the smallest memories to life, captivating both her and Nicky with her stories. Rio’s voice had a way of weaving warmth into every detail, as if the world itself was softer when seen through her eyes.

 

Rio turned toward Agatha briefly, catching her smile, and gave her a wink. “And that’s why you both should listen to me when I tell you to wear good shoes.”

 

Nicky giggled, but Agatha only laughed softly, her gaze returning to the road. 

 

When they arrived at Lilia’s house, the older woman was already on the porch, her arms folded against the crisp breeze, a fond smile lighting up her face. “There’s my favorite trio,” she called out warmly, her voice carrying the kind of comfort that felt like coming home.

 

Nicky didn’t hesitate, bounding out of the car and up the steps with all the energy of an uncontainable six-year-old. “Hi, Grandma Lilia!” he said brightly, throwing himself into her open arms.

 

“Hello, sweet boy,” Lilia greeted, wrapping him in a hug and pressing a kiss to the top of his head. “I see you’re ready to help today?”

 

Nicky pulled back just enough to beam up at her. “I’m the strongest!” he declared, flexing his tiny arms again for emphasis.

 

Lilia chuckled, brushing a stray curl from his forehead. “I don’t doubt it for a second, sweetheart.”

 

As Rio and Agatha approached, Lilia straightened, her eyes softening even more. Her gaze rested on Rio first. “How are you, sweet girl?”

 

Rio leaned in for a hug, letting out a content sigh as she wrapped her arms around Lilia. “I’m good. Better than good actually.”

 

Agatha followed a step behind, her usual composed demeanor shifting into something gentler in Lilia’s presence, also stepping into Lilia’s embrace. There was always an unspoken respect between the two women, as if they understood the unique role each played in Rio’s life. Agatha offered a small nod, her voice low and sincere as she said, “Thank you for keeping everything safe for us.”

 

“Of course,” Lilia replied, reaching out to pat Agatha’s head affectionately. “You know there’s no need to thank me.”

 

“Let’s get those boxes,” Rio said, smiling at both women before reaching for Nicky’s hand. “We’ve got a helper on the job, after all.”

 

Inside the house, the small stack of Rio’s belongigns was neatly arranged near the door, each box carefully labeled in Lilia’s elegant handwriting. The sight made Rio pause for a moment, a wave of nostalgia washing over her. This house held so many memories—of late-night talks at the kitchen table, Lilia’s calming presence during her most chaotic days, and the quiet reassurance that she always had a place to come back to.

 

“You didn’t have to do all this,” Rio said softly, running her fingers along the edge of a box marked Books.

 

“Of course I did,” Lilia replied with a knowing smile. “I had to make sure everything was ready for the strongest box carrier in the world.” She winked at Nicky, who giggled as he grabbed the smallest box he could find and carried it toward the door.

 

As they worked together to load the car, Lilia stood back, watching the three of them interact. Nicky’s laughter filled the air as Rio pretended to struggle with a box only to let him “help” lift it, while Agatha quietly stepped in to organize the boxes in the trunk with her usual efficiency. Lilia’s heart swelled at the sight.

 

She could see it in the way Agatha’s hand brushed Rio’s back as she passed, in the way Rio’s face lit up every time she looked at her family, and in the way Nicky seemed to radiate pure joy in their presence. There was love here—steady, deep, and boundless.

 

When the last box was carried out, Lilia turned to Rio, her voice soft but thoughtful. “Are you sure you don’t want to leave some of it here, just in case?”

 

Rio paused, her hands resting on the top box still balanced on her hip. She glanced at Agatha, who was leaning against the car, her eyes steady and full of quiet encouragement. Then she looked back at Lilia.

 

“I think… I think it’s time I bring it all home,” Rio said, her voice soft but resolute. “Home with us.”

 

Lilia’s smile widened, her eyes shimmering with pride. She reached out and squeezed Rio’s hand, holding it for a moment longer than usual. “I’m proud of you, sweetheart.”

 

By the time they returned home, Nicky was practically bouncing out of his seat in the back of the car, unable to contain his excitement about helping unpack. As soon as they stepped inside, he darted around the living room, inspecting each box with the enthusiasm of someone who had just discovered a treasure chest.

 

“This can go in your room with Mama, Rio!” Nicky said triumphantly, holding up a book with a big grin on his face.

 

Rio chuckled, ruffling his hair fondly as she took the book from him. “That’s the plan, kiddo,” she said, her voice warm. “You’re really good at this. Maybe you should become an organizer when you grow up.”

 

Nicky puffed out his chest proudly. “I could totally do that! I’m the best at organizing!”

 

Agatha, meanwhile, had begun carefully unwrapping some of Rio’s more fragile keepsakes—photographs, small trinkets, mementos that had gathered over the years. She paused for a moment, her fingers brushing over a small, framed photograph of a younger Rio with Lilia. Her gaze softened, and for a moment, she simply studied the image, tracing it with reverence.

 

Rio noticed her pause and leaned over, her voice gentle. “That was the day Lilia officially adopted me,” she explained, her tone tinged with a mix of nostalgia and quiet affection. “She insisted on taking a picture right after we signed the papers. It meant the world to her.”

 

Agatha turned toward Rio, her gaze lingering on the photo for a moment longer before meeting her eyes. There was something unspoken in her expression—something deep, tender, and full of understanding. “It’s beautiful,” she said quietly, her voice soft but steady. She placed the photo frame on a nearby shelf, making it visible to all, a quiet tribute to the love and history Rio carried with her.

 

As they continued to unpack, the room slowly began to take shape. Boxes were emptied, and last trinkets were unpacked, and the space around them felt a little fuller, a little more complete. Rio stood back for a moment, her arms crossed, taking it all in with a soft, contented sigh.

 

“It feels… good,” she said, her voice low, as if savoring the simple truth of the moment. The walls, the furniture, the memories—they all seemed to settle into place, filling the space with a quiet warmth.

 

Agatha wrapped an arm around Rio’s waist, pulling her close and pressing a kiss to her temple. “It should,” she said, her voice soft, almost like a promise. “This is your home, Rio.”

 

Nicky, who had been darting between the boxes, suddenly appeared in front of them with a big grin on his face. Without missing a beat, he wrapped his small arms around both of them, squeezing tightly. “And you will never leave!” he declared with all the confidence of someone who truly believed that nothing could ever tear them apart.

 

Rio and Agatha exchanged a soft, affectionate glance, a shared moment of silent understanding passing between them. 

 

As they reached the next box, Nicky’s sharp little eyes spotted a photo album resting on top, its cover simple yet well-worn, the corners softened by time and the gentle touch of countless memories revisited. He tilted his head curiously before reaching out to pick it up.

 

“What’s this?” he asked, turning it over in his hands, his small fingers running over the slightly frayed edges.

 

Rio turned at his question, her gaze landing on the familiar album. A soft smile curved her lips, a hint of nostalgia dancing in her eyes. “That’s a photo album Lilia made,” she explained, her voice warm and steady. “It has pictures from when I first came to live with her.”

 

Nicky’s brow furrowed in thought, his curiosity evident as he hugged the album close to his chest. “When did you start living with her again?”

 

Rio took a seat on the couch and patted the cushion beside her, inviting him to join her. “I moved in with Lilia when I was sixteen,” she said, her tone gentle but honest. “Before that… I was with other people in different homes.”

 

Nicky’s gaze softened as he climbed onto the couch, settling himself beside her with the album still clutched in his hands. “Can I look?” he asked hesitantly, glancing up at her.

 

“Of course,” she said, gently taking the album and opening it to the first page.

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up as he leaned closer, his small hands resting lightly on the edges of the pages. The first photograph was of a teenage Rio standing in front of Lilia’s house, her posture slightly stiff, her expression tentative but filled with a flicker of hope. The image seemed to radiate a bittersweet charm.

 

“That’s you?” Nicky asked, his voice laced with wonder, as if he couldn’t quite believe the teenager in the picture was the same Rio he adored.

 

“That’s me,” Rio confirmed with a soft laugh, her cheeks tinged with a faint blush. “I wasn’t very good at smiling for pictures back then. I was still figuring out a lot of things.”

 

Nicky studied the photograph intently before looking back at her. “You look pretty,” he said earnestly, his voice filled with the kind of sincerity that only a child could manage.

 

Rio’s heart melted at his words, her chest tightening with affection. She reached out to gently ruffle his hair. “Thank you, bud. That means a lot.”

 

Agatha, who had been quietly observing the interaction, allowed herself a rare moment of unguarded emotion. Her heart swelled as she watched Rio and Nicky together. She stepped closer, resting a hand on Rio’s shoulder and squeezing it lightly, a silent gesture of support and love.

 

Nicky, oblivious to the tender exchange between the two adults, eagerly turned the page.

 

The next photo showed an almost adult Rio sitting at a cozy kitchen table, a plate of pancakes stacked high in front of her. In this picture, her smile was softer, more genuine, her shoulders beginning to lose the stiffness that marked the earlier photographs.

 

“Lilia made pancakes every Saturday morning, even when I got older,” Rio said, her voice tinged with warmth as she traced a finger over the photo. “She still does when I visit. It was her way of showing me she cared, even when I didn’t know how to accept it.”
