Nicky’s little face lit up. “Pancakes are the best way to show love, I love them!” he declared, clutching the album tighter as though it were a treasure map to Rio’s past.

 

Rio laughed, her hand moving instinctively to tousle his hair. “You’re not wrong, buddy.”

 

As they flipped through more pages, the story of Rio’s journey began to unfold, each photo a testament to the life she’d built after finding Lilia. There was one of Rio and Lilia baking cookies together, flour smudged across both their faces as they grinned for the camera despite the blurry faces of other people around. Another captured now adult Rio in the glow of a Christmas tree, holding a brightly wrapped present.

 

Agatha, who had been watching from the edge of the couch, quietly moved closer and eased onto the seat beside Rio. Her hand found Rio’s knee, giving it a reassuring squeeze as her eyes flicked over the photographs. “It’s incredible,” Agatha murmured, her voice soft yet filled with conviction. “To see how far you’ve come, how much strength you’ve carried with you through it all.”

 

Rio leaned into Agatha’s side, her head tilting slightly to rest against her shoulder. Gratitude surged through her—a deep appreciation for Lilia, for Agatha, for Nicky. For the family she had never thought she would have. “It’s all thanks to Lilia,” she said quietly, her voice steady but filled with emotion. “She showed me what it meant to be safe, to have a home, to feel… loved.”

 

Nicky looked up at her, his small face unusually serious, his brow furrowed in thought. “Do you miss being a kid?” he asked, his voice laced with the kind of innocent curiosity that only a child could muster.

 

Rio’s lips curved into a gentle smile as she considered the question. “Not really,” she admitted. “My childhood wasn’t the easiest. But everything changed when I met Lilia. And now…” She glanced between Nicky and Agatha, her voice softening with affection. “Now I have you and your Mama, which makes it better than I ever thought it could be.”

 

Nicky’s serious expression melted into a radiant grin. Without warning, he flung his arms around Rio, hugging the photo album tightly between them. “You’re part of the best family ever!” he exclaimed, his voice muffled against her shoulder.

 

Rio chuckled, wrapping an arm around the boy and pulling him close. Agatha’s hand slid from Rio’s knee to her back, tracing soothing circles as she looked at both of them with a quiet, unguarded tenderness. Nicky then shuffled off her lap and resumed his careful scrutiny of each of the album pages.

 

As Nicky flipped another page in the photo album, his eyes went wide with astonismhment. “Whoa!” he exclaimed, practically bouncing in his seat. “Is that you, Rio? You’re wearing… a crown!” His finger jabbed at the picture with unbridled enthusiasm.

 

Rio leaned in, her curiosity piqued. The moment her eyes landed on the image, a laugh bubbled up from her chest. “Not a crown, bud,” she corrected, a teasing lilt to her voice. “That’s a tiara.”

 

The photo in question captured a younger Rio standing under a spotlight on a grand stage, poised in an elegant pose. She wore a pale blue tutu, its sequins glinting like tiny stars, and a delicate tiara rested on her head, catching the stage lights just so. Her arms were gracefully arched above her head, and though her expression was serene, there was an intensity in her eyes that hinted at the determination behind the poise.

 

“You look like a princess!” Nicky gasped, his face lighting up with genuine awe. His little hands clutched the album as he brought it closer to his face to see better.

 

Agatha’s smile softened as she glanced over at the photo, her gaze lingering on Rio. “I will have to thank Lilia for that shot,” she murmured, a hint of admiration threading through her tone. “You look so poised, so… ethereal.”

 

A blush crept up Rio’s cheeks as she tucked a strand of hair behind her ear. “Poised? Ethereal? Let’s not get carried away. I was terrified,” she confessed with a sheepish chuckle. “That was my first big recital with a packed audience. I was convinced I’d trip over my own feet or forget the choreography.”

 

Nicky looked up at her, his small face serious. “You don’t look scared. You look amazing! Like a real ballerina, like in the movies!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, reaching out to ruffle his hair. “Thanks, bud. That’s the magic of ballet—making it look effortless even when you’re convinced your legs are about to give out.”

 

Nicky returned his attention to the photo, utterly mesmerized. “Do you still have the crown? And the dress?” he asked, his tone filled with the boundless hope of a child.

 

Agatha smirked, leaning in closer to Rio with a playful glint in her eyes. “The tiara, darling,” she corrected with exaggerated precision, mimicking Rio’s earlier correction.

 

Rio shot her a mock glare, though the smile tugging at her lips gave her away. “No, I don’t have the tiara or the costume anymore. Ballet costumes are rented for recitals, and the tiara was part of the set.”

 

Nicky’s face fell for a moment before he perked up again. “But you still dance, right?” he asked eagerly.

 

Rio nodded. “A little. How else would I keep up with teaching you and your wild little classmates?”

 

Nicky’s grin stretched ear to ear. “I wanna see you dance like that again! Can you wear a crown?” With still absolutely no regards for the correction earlier made.

 

Agatha chuckled, her hand resting gently on Rio’s back. “You know,” she said, her voice warm and teasing, “I wouldn’t mind seeing that myself. It sounds… enchanting.”

 

Rio groaned, though the sparkle in her eyes betrayed her amusement. “You two are incorrigible,” she said, shaking her head. “But maybe I’ll show you a little something later, if you both behave.”

 

“Oh, I know another kind of dancing you can show me later, love”, Agatha whispered, low enough that only Rio’s ear could hear it, making said ear heat up and flush a little.

 

“Promise?” Nicky pressed, oblivious to the exchange, his voice tinged with unshakable excitement.

 

Rio leaned forward, tapping the tip of his nose. “Promise.”

 

Satisfied, Nicky practically bounced with joy, clutching the album to his chest. “You’re the coolest ever, Rio!”

 

Agatha leaned in, pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s temple. “You’re full of surprises, my love.”

 

“And you’re full of flattery,” Rio shot back, though her pink cheeks suggested she didn’t entirely mind.

 

The photo of Rio in her recital costume quickly became Nicky’s favorite. When they were done with the album and set it on the bookshelf, he insisted they leave it open to that page. The rest of the afternoon, he couldn’t stop talking about how amazing it was that Rio used to dance on a stage, asking question after question about her ballerina days, and running to see the picture again.

 

At some point, he decided that if he wanted to dance like Rio one day, he needed to practice. Right now.

 

“Rio, can you show me how to do that spin? You know, the one where it looks like you’re floating?” Nicky asked, pointing at the photo again with an eager bounce in his step.

 

Rio chuckled, reaching out to ruffle his hair. “You mean a pirouette?”

 

“Yeah! That one!” he exclaimed, practically vibrating with excitement. “I wanna get better for ballet class! And you’re my teacher, so you have to help me, right?”

 

From her spot on the couch, Agatha looked up from the stack of papers to grade in her lap, her eyebrow arched in amusement. “He’s got a solid argument, love. Very persuasive,” she teased, her lips curling into a smirk.

 

Rio shot her a mock glare before turning back to Nicky. “Alright, little ballerino. Let’s see what you’ve got.”

 

Nicky let out a delighted squeal and darted to the center of the living room, where there was just enough space to practice. Rio followed, rolling her shoulders like she was about to step onto the stage herself.

 

“Okay,” she said, crouching slightly to meet his eye level. “First things first—show me how you prepare. Remember, a good pirouette starts before you even spin. It’s all about balance and finding your center.”

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically, planting his feet in what he thought was a preparatory stance. His arms wobbled a little, and his focus was completely fixed on Rio.

 

“Not bad for a start,” Rio said, her tone encouraging. “But let’s clean it up a bit. Arms here,” she said, gently repositioning them, “chin up, and remember to breathe. Oh, and don’t forget to smile! Ballet’s all about looking graceful, even when you’re trying really hard.”

 

Nicky tried again, this time with Rio’s adjustments, his face scrunching up in concentration as he lifted his chin and stretched his arms out.

 

“Better!” Rio exclaimed with a grin. “Now let’s work on that spin.” She demonstrated slowly, her movements fluid and deliberate, her years of experience clear in the effortless way she spun on the ball of her foot.

 

“See? You start here, push off from your back foot, and keep your eyes on one spot as you turn. That’s called spotting—it helps you not get dizzy.”

 

“Whoa,” Nicky whispered, his eyes wide with admiration. “How do you not fall over?”

 

“Magic,” Rio teased, winking at him.  

 

Nicky tried to mimic her, spinning with so much enthusiasm that he stumbled and nearly toppled over. Rio caught him with a laugh, steadying him before he hit the floor.

 

“Not bad for your first attempt,” she said, helping him back to his feet. “But maybe a little less zoom and a little more control.”

 

From the couch, Agatha had abandoned all pretense of focusing on her papers. Her gaze was fixed on them, her smile softening as she watched Rio guide Nicky with infinite patience.

 

Rio demonstrated the spin again, this time slower, and Nicky mimicked her movements with growing determination. His little tongue poked out in concentration, and his arms were still a bit wobbly, but his effort was undeniable.

 

“You’re getting there!” Rio cheered, claping lightly. “One more time, and don’t forget to spot.”

 

As Nicky tried again, his laughter echoed through the room, joining Rio’s as she corrected his form or teased him gently about his dramatic attempts. Agatha’s hand drifted to her chin as she leaned forward, her heart swelling at the sight. It wasn’t just the dancing—it was the bond between them, the way Rio’s lightness brought out Nicky’s joy, and the way Nicky’s boundless energy seemed to reflect the love he felt for her.

 

Rio’s voice carried across the room, full of encouragement. “You’ve got this, bud. One day, you’re going to be the star of your own recital.”

 

Nicky spun again, this time a little steadier, and when he stopped, he threw his arms in the air with triumphant flair. “Did you see that? I did it!”

 

“You sure did!” Rio laughed, pulling him into a quick hug. “Keep practicing, and you’ll be spinning like a pro in no time.”

 

Agatha leaned back against the couch, her smile widening as she spoke, her voice warm and teasing. “With a teacher like Rio, how could he not?”

 

Rio looked over her shoulder, catching Agatha’s eye, and winked. “Again, flattery will get you everywhere,” she said, though her cheeks flushed with faint color.

 

Agatha tilted her head, the light catching in her eyes. “It’s not flattery if it’s true, my love.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes playfully but couldn’t quite hide the smile tugging at her lips.

 

Nicky beamed up at both of them, his energy undimmed as he grabbed Rio’s hand. “Can we do it again? I wanna get it perfect!”

 

Rio laughed, letting him pull her back to the center of the room. “Alright, little man, let’s give it another go.”

 

After a few more tries, Nicky managed a decent spin, and Rio cheered, sweeping him into a hug. “That was awesome! You’re going to rock it at your next class.”

 

“Really?” Nicky asked, his cheeks flushed from excitement and effort.

 

“Really,” Rio confirmed, smoothing his hair. “You’ve got natural talent. Just keep practicing.”

 

Agatha finally set the papers aside, her curiosity and amusement winning out. Rising to her feet, she smoothed her jeans and walked over to where Rio and Nicky stood. “Alright, Nureyev,” she said, her voice laced with playful authority. “How about we give your teacher a well-deserved break and let her show us how it’s really done?”

 

Rio’s eyes widened in alarm, her hands immediately going up in protest. “Oh, no. This is Nicky’s moment. I’m just here to guide.”

 

Agatha arched a perfectly shaped brow, her smirk growing. “Oh, come on, love. We both know you’ve got more than a few moves left in you. Don’t make me pull rank.”

 

Before Rio could formulate a response, Nicky bounced on the balls of his feet, clapping his hands together with the enthusiasm only a child could muster. “Yes, yes, yes! Please, Rio! Show us!”

 

Rio sighed, long and dramatic, but the smile tugging at the corners of her lips betrayed her. “Fine,” she relented, shaking her head as if they had both twisted her arm. “But don’t say I didn’t warn you.”

 

Agatha chuckled, stepping aside and gesturing grandly to the open floor. “The stage is yours, my darling.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t help the warmth spreading through her chest. With a small shake of her shoulders, she moved to the center of the room, her posture shifting effortlessly into that of a trained dancer.

 

Nicky watched in wide-eyed anticipation as Rio began. Her movements were fluid and precise, each twirl and leap exuding a quiet grace that spoke to years of practice without overdoing it. She spun on the tips of her toes, her arms extending as though she were carving shapes into the air, and for a moment, the living room seemed to transform into something grander—a stage lit by golden light, where Rio was the star, in a pale blue tutu and a tiara on top of her dark hair.

 

Nicky’s hands flew to his mouth as he watched, utterly enraptured. “You’re amazing!” he burst out as Rio ended with a final twirl, lowering into an elegant bow, one arm close to her chest and the other straight in line with her torso towards her bent knee.

 

The room erupted into applause—well, as much as two people could make. Nicky clapped wildly, jumping up and down with sheer delight, while Agatha’s hands met slowly but with deliberate warmth. Her gaze was steady on Rio, filled with admiration and a hint of something else.

 

Rio straightened, brushing a strand of hair that had escaped her ponytail, her cheeks flushed but her smile genuine. “Alright, alright, that’s enough,” she said, trying to downplay the praise but failing miserably as her grin grew wider.

 

Agatha stepped closer, her voice low and fond as she teased, “I think I just saw the ghost of that tiara.”

 

Nicky was practically bouncing with excitement, his hands clasped together as he looked up at Agatha with his most convincing puppy-dog eyes. “Mama, come on! You have to try, too! Rio can teach both of us!”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, crossing her arms in mock defiance. “Me? Dancing? Oh, I think not, ballerino. I’m much better at cheering from the sidelines.”

 

“Mamaaaa,” Nicky whined, grabbing her hand and tugging with all the determination of a pint-sized persuader. “Please? It’ll be so much fun! And Rio’s the best teacher in the whole world!”

 

Rio chuckled, resting a hand on her hip as she looked at Agatha. “Come on, love. It’s just us. No audience. Besides, don’t you want to show Nicky how it’s done?”

 

Agatha heaved an exaggerated sigh, though the soft smile tugging at her lips betrayed her growing amusement. “Fine,” she relented, unfolding her arms and shaking her head in mock resignation. “But let’s set expectations low, shall we? My last dance lesson was probably before you were born,” she added, pointing at Rio with a playful smirk.

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress her grin. “Well, then, it’s high time you had a refresher, don’t you think?”

 

Nicky cheered in triumph, grabbing Agatha’s hand and practically dragging her toward the open space in the center of the room, which had unofficially been transformed into their makeshift dance studio. 

 

Rio clapped her hands together. “Alright, let’s start simple. Nicky, show your mama the preparation pose we worked on earlier. Remember: strong and steady.”

 

Nicky immediately snapped into position, his arms stretched out like a miniature professional, his chest puffed up with pride. Agatha blinked at him, her expression one of mock trepidation. “Well, look at you, mister professional. Now I have to keep up, huh?”

 

Rio stifled a laugh, gesturing for Agatha to follow. “Your turn, love. Feet like this, arms like that. And… don’t forget to smile!”

 

Agatha sighed dramatically as she attempted to mirror Nicky’s stance. The result was… less than perfect. Her arms were a bit stiff, her posture slightly awkward. Nicky giggled, his laugh high and infectious.

 

“Okay, Mama,” Rio said gently, stepping beside her. She placed her hands lightly on Agatha’s shoulders, guiding her into a more relaxed position. “Drop your shoulders a bit, and keep your head up. There you go.”

 

Agatha glanced at Rio out of the corner of her eye, her expression softening into something more tender. “You’re enjoying this way too much,” she murmured, though her tone carried no edge.

 

Rio grinned, her hand brushing Agatha’s arm as she stepped back. “You bet I am,” she replied, her eyes gleaming with mischief. “Let’s see if you can keep up.”

 

They moved on to basic arm positions and foot placements, with Rio patiently guiding them through each step. Her voice was calm but encouraging, her movements precise as she demonstrated each position. Nicky followed with boundless enthusiasm, his arms and legs a little wobbly but his determination shining through. Agatha, on the other hand… well, she tried.

 

“Alright, now let’s add a spin,” Rio announced, stepping into the center of the room. She demonstrated a slow, elegant pirouette, her movements fluid and controlled. When she stopped, she flashed a smile at her two students. “Your turn. Let’s see what you’ve got.”

 

Nicky didn’t hesitate. He spun on the spot, his arms flailing wildly and his feet stomping more than turning. He stopped abruptly, his eyes wide as he grinned at Rio. “How’d I do?”

 

“Perfect!” Rio declared, giving him a high five. “That was amazing, little man. Now, Mama’s turn.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, her hands resting on her hips. “You’re really enjoying this, aren’t you?” she said again, her voice tinged with mock suspicion.

 

“Yes, I am,” Rio replied with a wink, stepping back to give Agtaha space. “Go on, love. Show us what you’ve got.”

 

With a dramatic sigh, Agatha squared her shoulders and attempted a spin. Her form was stiff, her footing uncertain, and as she completed a rather clumsy turn, she stumbled, reaching out instinctively to grab Rio’s arm for balance.

 

Nicky burst into giggles, clapping his hands. “Mama, that was funny!”

 

Rio steadied Agatha, laughter bubbling up as she gave her an exaggerated look of mock approval. “Not bad for a first try,” she teased. “But I think you might need a little more practice before we book your debut on stage.”

 

Agatha smirked, her tone playful. “Oh, really? Let’s see if you can do better,” she shot back, taking Rio by surprise as she grabbed her hand and spun her into an impromptu twirl.

 

Caught off guard, Rio let out a startled laugh as she stumbled into Agatha’s arms. “Hey! That wasn’t fair,” she said, though the smile on her face said otherwise.

 

Nicky, unwilling to be left out, threw his arms in the air and yelled, “Me too!” He launched himself at them, wrapping his little arms around their legs in a triumphant tackle.

 

What had started as a structured dance lesson dissolved into chaos. Rio shook her head, laughing, and walked over to the speaker. “Alright, you two troublemakers, if we’re going to dance, let’s do it right.”

 

She turned on some music, a lively tune that filled the room with energy. Nicky squealed with excitement, immediately spinning in circles. Agatha joined in, spinning him around with exaggerated, dramatic movements that sent Nicky into fits of laughter. Rio twirled and leaped around them, her genuine grace now mixed with a carefree silliness, her theatrical expressions making Nicky laugh so hard he nearly fell over.

 

By the time the music slowed down, all three of them were sprawled on the living room floor, the once orderly space now littered with scattered cushions and a pair of socks Nicky had flung off mid-action. Their chests rose and fell as they tried to catch their breath, their laughter slowly fading into quiet giggles. Nicky lay nestled between them, his small body warm and snug against Agatha’s side, his cheeks flushed from all the excitement.

 

“See, Mama?” Nicky mumbled, his voice muffled by her shirt. “You’re a great dancer.”

 

Agatha tilted her head to look at him, her lips curving into a soft smile. “Well, I had the best teachers,” she replied, her voice low and full of affection. She leaned over to press a kiss to Nicky’s forehead, lingering just long enough to hear his contented sigh.

 

Rio watched the exchange with a quiet warmth in her eyes. As Agatha turned toward her, Rio shifted closer to rest her head on Agatha’s shoulder. Her free hand found Nicky’s hair, her fingers weaving soothing patterns through his messy curls.

 

“Best dance party ever,” Rio murmured, her voice soft but filled with sincerity.

 

“Agreed,” Agatha said, her tone carrying that rare warmth she reserved for the two people she loved most. Her arm wrapped around Rio, pulling her closer, as her other hand rested protectively on Nicky’s back.

 

For a while, none of them spoke. They simply stayed there, tangled together on the floor as the music faded into silence and the gentle hum of the world outside drifted through the windows. The room, though dimly lit now, seemed to glow with the quiet joy of the moment.

 

Shadows that once lingered in the corners of their lives felt distant, pushed away by the strength of the love they shared. Together, they basked in the simple, perfect peace of their little family, letting the happiness of the present wrap around them like a warm blanket.

 

 

As the quiet of the night wrapped around them, Rio and Agatha lay side by side in their bed, their hands intertwined beneath the covers. The laughter and warmth of the day still lingered in the air, but the room now held a soft, serene stillness.

 

Agatha turned her head to look at Rio, her gaze tender as her fingers brushed a stray curl away from Rio’s face , her fingers lingering just a moment longer than necessary.

 

“You know,” Agatha murmured, her voice barely above a whisper, as though the words were meant only for the two of them and no one else in the world, “one day, I’ll ask you to marry me.”

 

Rio blinked, her eyes widening slightly before a soft, surprised smile spread across her face. Her cheeks flushed with warmth as she shifted to face Agatha fully, her heart thudding in her chest in that way it always did when Agatha surprised her with moments like this.

 

“And I’ll say yes,” she whispered back, her tone sure and steady but carrying an undeniable softness, as though she were sharing a secret too sacred to say aloud.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her thumb brushing over Rio’s knuckles. “But I’ll do it right,” she added, her voice rich with promise, the weight of her words resonating in the stillness of the room.

 

Rio tilted her head, her smile growing as she studied Agatha’s face—the face she had come to know so well, yet one that still managed to captivate her every day. Her eyes shone with affection, with trust, with everything she didn’t need words to express.

 

“Okay,” she said simply, her tone light yet carrying the quiet strength of her unwavering belief in Agatha.

 

For a long moment, neither of them spoke, letting the unspoken depth of their promise fill the space between them. The air felt heavier, but not in a burdensome way—it was heavy with meaning, with a love that needed no further explanation.

 

Agatha leaned forward, pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s forehead. “Good,” she murmured against her skin.

 

Rio smiled as she tucked herself closer to Agatha, resting her back against her front with Agatha's arm curling around her middle, her hand resting in Rio's stomach, her breath falling in time with Agatha’s steady rhythm. Her voice, already heavy with sleep, was a soft murmur when she added, “Just don’t make me wait too long.”

 

Agatha laughed quietly, the sound vibrating through Rio’s frame. “Not too long,” she promised.

 

And with that, the two of them drifted into a peaceful sleep, their fingers still entwined beneath the covers. The quiet promise of their future together wrapped around them, warming the cool night air and settling over their hearts like the softest of skies.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

My heart exploded a little writing this last part, ngl

Hot for Teacher

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

*

*

*

 

This is the use of memory:

For liberation—not less of love but expanding

Of love beyond desire, and so liberation

From the future as well as the past.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

The morning sunlight filtered through the tall windows of the lecture hall on a cool Wednesday morning, casting golden streaks across the polished wooden floors and bathing the room in a gentle glow. Agatha stood at the front, watching over her students like an imperious hawk. Her movements were fluid, every gesture purposeful, and her voice resonated with a smooth confidence that captivated her audience. The lecture hall was packed, but for Rio, it felt like they were the only two people in the room.

 

Seated in her usual spot in the second row, Rio had her notebook open and pen poised, determined to keep her mind on 20th century poetry. She tried to focus on the words flowing from Agatha’s lips—on T.S. Eliot and the way fragmented narrators dismantled the notion of objective truth. But it was proving to be an impossible feat.

 

Agatha was in her element, her sharp blue blazer tailored to perfection, accentuating her statuesque figure. The light glinted off her black-rimmed glasses, framing her piercing blue eyes in a way that seemed almost unfair. Rio could feel a familiar warmth creeping up her neck when Agatha pushed her glasses up the bridge of her nose with a delicate flick of her hand.

 

And then, the pen twirling began.

 

It was effortless, a casual rotation of a sleek black pen between Agatha’s fingers, as if it were merely an extension of her. She continued to lecture, her voice dipping to emphasize a key point about the aesthetic of fragmentation in Eliot’s later works, but Rio barely registered the words. Her focus had shifted entirely to that small, infuriatingly elegant motion. How does she make that look so good?

 

Rio pressed her pen harder against her notebook, scribbling notes that were increasingly illegible in an effort to appear focused. Her mind, however, betrayed her—flashing back to the night before, when Agatha’s hands weren’t preoccupied with pens or chalkboards but with her. The memory of Agatha’s touch, the way she had traced either lazy or frantic patterns across Rio’s skin as they lay tangled together in the soft afterglow of their bedroom, sent a pulse racing through her veins.

 

She glanced up again, her gaze drifting to Agatha’s lips as they formed each word with precise articulation. Body and soul, Rio thought, her pulse quickening at the mere recollection of their whispered conversations and the quiet intimacy they shared when the world was left behind.

 

Agatha leaned slightly against the podium, her fingers brushing the edge as she made a particularly insightful remark about the disjointed narrative structure of some text that Rio hadn’t even picked up on. Her voice dropped lower, and Rio swore she could feel the resonance of it in her chest.

 

Her notebook remained open, the same line of notes untouched for several minutes now. Pull it together, Vidal, she scolded herself, though the thought was half-hearted at best. Even as she tried to redirect her attention to the lecture, her gaze inevitably found its way back to Agatha—the way her hair framed her face just in the way Rio had seen Agatha work on that morning in their bathroom mirror, the faint smile that tugged at her lips when she asked a question and a student fumbled for an answer.

 

“Miss Vidal?”

 

The voice cut through Rio’s haze like a blade. Her head snapped up, heart skipping a beat as she met Agatha’s challenging gaze. “Yes?”

 

The room seemed to still for a moment, the hum of ambient noise fading to a dull background as Agatha regarded her. Though her expression was professionally neutral, the faint quirk of her lips betrayed her amusement. Agatha knew. She always knew. I’m going to kill her… If she doesn’t kill me first…

 

“Your thoughts on how Eliot’s use of the fragmented narrator complicates our understanding of truth?”

 

Rio blinked, her mind scrambling to catch up. She willed herself to appear calm, even as heat crawled up her neck and into her cheeks. Swallowing hard, she nodded. “I—I think it forces the reader to work harder to piece together meaning, and in doing so, it mirrors how truth can be subjective or multifaceted.”

 

A flicker of approval passed through Agatha’s eyes, and her lips curved into the faintest of smiles. “Good,” she replied, her gaze holding Rio’s for a heartbeat longer than necessary before sweeping back to the rest of the class. “Now, does anyone else think this fragmentation alienates the reader, or does it engage them more deeply?”

 

The room stirred as a few students murmured and flipped through their notes. Rio exhaled softly, her shoulders dropping a fraction. She hoped no one had noticed the flush in her cheeks or the way her pulse raced from that fleeting moment of attention.

 

But regaining her focus was easier said than done. Agatha was moving again, pacing slowly in front of the podium, her necklace catching the light with each step towards the window. Rio couldn’t stop her eyes from tracking her every motion—the slight roll of her sleeves over her elbows, revealing elegant forearms, the deliberate way she gestured with her hands, demanding attention with effortless precision.

 

And then there was the pen. That damn pen. Agatha twirled it between her fingers again as she listened to a student’s hesitant answer, her expression thoughtful. The smooth rhythm of the motion was hypnotic, and Rio found herself wondering—absurdly—how many times she’d seen those same fingers trace other kinds of patterns on her own body, only to now watch them absentmindedly twirl a piece of plastic.

 

At one point, Agatha’s gaze flicked to Rio again, and their eyes met briefly. Rio quickly looked down, her heart racing. Stop it, she chastised herself internally. She’s just teaching. You’re supposed to be listening.

 

Rio forced herself to jot down the words, Agatha was saying, hoping the act of writing would steady her. But even the deliberate motion of her pen couldn’t drown out the sound of Agatha’s voice, so rich and deliberate, carrying over the room with an ease that left no question as to who held its attention.

 

She dared another glance, and her heart sank and soared in equal measure when she found Agatha looking at her again. The look was brief, fleeting—just a flicker of something playful—but it sent a shiver down her spine.

 

When the class finally ended, Rio stayed rooted to her seat, her heart still racing from the lingering tension of the past hour. She kept her head down as the other students shuffled out, the low hum of their conversations fading into the hallway. She needed a moment to steady herself, to calm the erratic thrum of her pulse before facing the outside world—or worse, Agatha.

 

At the front of the room, Agatha remained composed, methodically gathering her notes and slipping them into her leather folder. Her movements were unhurried, deliberate, a quiet contrast to the chaos Rio felt within herself.

 

Finally, with a deep breath, Rio stood and slung her bag over her shoulder, willing herself to walk out like a normal person. But as she approached the exit, she felt the weight of a familiar gaze on her. She glanced up—and froze.

 

Agatha’s eyes were on her, sharp yet amused, with a flicker of something else beneath the surface. It wasn’t just amusement. It was knowing. And worse, it was mutual.

 

“Miss Vidal,” Agatha called, her voice smooth and unhurried, stopping Rio in her tracks.

 

Rio turned slowly, trying—and failing—to mask her nervousness. “Yes, Dr. Harkness?”

 

Agatha tilted her head slightly, her lips curving into a faint, knowing smile. Her voice was low, pitched just for Rio. “You seemed… unusually focused today. I’m pleased to see you’re so engaged with the material.”

 

The deliberate weight on the word engaged sent a jolt through Rio, her cheeks flushing. She scrambled to find her voice, her thoughts colliding like mismatched puzzle pieces. “Uh, yes. Very… engaging,” she managed, cursing the way her voice wavered.

 

Agatha’s eyes gleamed with amusement, and Rio swore she saw the faintest twitch of her lips, as though the older woman were savoring the moment.

 

Desperate to regain control of the situation—or at least distract herself—Rio cleared her throat and straightened her shoulders. “Actually, I was hoping we could schedule a quick meeting about my thesis,” she blurted, her words rushing out. “Right now.”

 

Agatha arched an elegant brow, her expression unreadable except for the trace of a smirk at the corner of her mouth. “A quick meeting,” she repeated, her voice smooth as silk. “About your thesis.”

 

“Yes,” Rio replied, her tone too eager, too high-pitched. “Just a short discussion. I’ve been working on some ideas, and I thought it would be a good time to get your feedback.”

 

Agatha closed her folder with deliberate slowness, the soft click reverberating in the quiet room. She stepped around the desk, her heels tapping softly against the floor as she approached Rio. “As it happens,” she said, her voice a study in calm control, “I have half an hour free before my next meeting. Shall we?”

 

Rio nodded quickly, her throat dry as she followed Agatha toward the door. Her footsteps felt clumsy in comparison to Agatha’s confident strides, each one perfectly measured.

 

The hallway stretched out before them, quiet and empty, but the tension between them felt palpable, as though the air itself crackled with unspoken words. Rio’s mind raced, alternating between trying not to fall and avoiding the way Agatha’s blazer accentuated the line of her shoulders and of her….

 

Agatha glanced over her shoulder as they walked, her eyes catching Rio’s briefly, pulling her out of her questionable thoughts. “You seem a bit… preoccupied, Miss Vidal,” she remarked lightly, her tone betraying nothing but professionalism.

 

“I’m fine,” Rio lied, her voice cracking slightly as she hurried to match Agatha’s pace.

 

“Good,” Agatha replied, her lips twitching into that infuriatingly knowing smile again.

 

By the time they reached Agatha’s office, Rio’s nerves were pushed to the breaking point. She hovered awkwardly as Agatha unlocked the door, stepping aside to let her in. The office smelled faintly of cedar and Agatha’s perfume, the neat rows of books and carefully arranged papers reflecting Agatha’s meticulous nature.

 

Rio dropped her bag onto the chair across from Agatha’s desk with a soft thud, then quickly sank into the chair herself. Her hands gripped the armrests, her fingers digging into the plush fabric in an effort to steady herself. The moment Agatha closed the door with a soft click, the weight of the room shifted. It was just the two of them now, and Rio’s heart began to beat faster with every second that passed.

 

Agatha, ever composed, settled into her own chair with deliberate calm, folding her hands neatly on the desk. Her gaze never wavered from Rio as she spoke, the quiet sultry authority in her voice sending a shiver down Rio’s spine. “Now,” she began, her tone cool and collected, “let’s hear these ideas of yours.”

 

Rio shifted in her seat, suddenly feeling every ounce of the tension building between them. Her pulse raced in her ears, drowning out her thoughts. She swallowed hard before blurting out, her voice almost too loud in the quiet room, “You’re doing this on purpose.”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, the hint of amusement tugging at the corner of her lips as she feigned innocence. “Doing what, my darling?”

 

Rio groaned, feeling the heat rise in her cheeks. “You know exactly what! The glasses, the pen, the way you look at me during class—it’s maddening!” She threw her hands up in frustration, her voice cracking with the overwhelming mix of desire and exasperation that had been building since the moment she’d walked into the room.

 

Agatha, effortlessly composed, leaned back in her chair, crossing one leg over the other with an almost casual air of confidence. She looked at Rio as though she were savoring every moment of her discomfort. “You seemed very focused earlier,” Agatha teased, her voice laced with a hint of mischief. “Or was that just a valiant effort to hide your distraction?”

 

Rio’s eyes narrowed, her cheeks burning with the intensity of Agatha’s scrutiny. “You’re impossible,” she muttered under her breath, wishing she could hide from the overwhelming attention.

 

Agatha smiled, slow and knowing. “And yet,” she said, rising from her chair with a fluid grace that made Rio’s stomach tighten, “you’re here, asking for a meeting you don’t need, because you couldn’t wait until we were home to see me.”

 

Rio opened her mouth, ready to protest, but the words caught in her throat as Agatha stepped toward her with predatory ease. Every movement was deliberate, calculated, designed to torment her. She leaned back against the desk just inches away from Rio, their proximity making Rio’s breath hitch.

 

“You’ve been very quiet, Miss Vidal,” Agatha continued, her voice dropping to a lower register, thick with mock professionalism. “Do you need me to prompt you further? Or perhaps you’re distracted again?”

 

Rio swallowed hard, her body suddenly unable to sit still. Every tiny detail about Agatha’s presence—the way she adjusted her glasses, the way her gaze remained fixed on Rio as if she were the only thing in the room—was pushing Rio to the edge. Her thoughts scattered, unable to focus on anything other than Agatha, the intoxicating closeness between them.

 

The silence in the room was thick with tension, suffocating yet magnetic. Rio shifted again, desperate to regain some semblance of control. “I—” she began, but the words caught in her throat as Agatha leaned in just a little closer, the scent of her perfume lingering in the air, sharp and intoxicating.

 

“Perhaps,” Agatha murmured, her voice barely above a whisper, as she sat back down, “you’d prefer if I didn’t make this so… difficult for you?”

 

Rio’s stomach twisted. She was certain Agatha knew exactly what she was doing, knew exactly how much this was getting to her. And yet, it seemed Agatha was savoring every moment, every flicker of discomfort, every unspoken desire that lingered between them.

 

“That’s it,” Rio said suddenly, her voice low and laced with tension. Her breath was uneven as she stood and moved towards the door, locking it with quick, decisive motions. She checked the blinds, ensuring they were drawn tightly, blocking out any possible distractions. The air between them thickened, charged with something undeniable.

 

Agatha’s eyes gleamed with curiosity, though her smile remained unchanged, a knowing tug at the corners of her lips. “Oh? Decided to finally share your thoughts?”

 

Rio didn’t answer immediately. Instead, she turned back, her eyes blazing with a mix of frustration, desire, and something else, something deeper. She crossed the room with a few swift strides, not bothering to conceal the raw urgency in her movements. Before Agatha could react, Rio was on her, gripping the armrests of Agatha’s chair with fierce determination. Their faces were mere inches apart, the heat between them palpable.

 

“You’re insufferable,” Rio growled, her voice thick with emotion. Her breath brushed against Agatha’s lips as she spoke, the words laced with a longing she couldn’t suppress any longer. “Do you have any idea what you’re doing to me?”

 

Agatha’s smirk widened, her gaze never leaving Rio’s face. There was a predatory gleam in her eyes, a quiet confidence that only seemed to make Rio’s pulse race even faster. “Oh, I have some idea,” Agatha purred, her voice dropping to a teasing whisper, a challenge wrapped in velvet.

 

Without another word, Rio’s lips crashed into Agatha’s, fierce and unrelenting. Agatha let out a soft hum of approval, her hands slipping up to grip Rio’s waist, pulling her closer as Rio climbed onto her lap, straddling her with a sense of purpose.

 

“You and those glasses,” Rio murmured against Agatha’s lips, her hands trembling slightly as they moved to remove the glasses from Agatha’s face, tossing them onto the desk with a carelessness that didn’t match the reverence she had shown them earlier. “Do you even know what they do to me? The way you look at me over them, like you own the world—and me?”

 

Agatha chuckled darkly, her hands sliding up Rio’s back, pulling her even closer, their bodies pressed together with a fierce heat. “I do own you,” she said, her voice thick with desire and a smug satisfaction. “You make that quite clear every time you look at me like you’re ready to devour me.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, a growl rumbling low in her chest as her fingers tangled in Agatha’s hair. She kissed her again, deeply, pouring every ounce of frustration, yearning, and heated longing into the kiss. Agatha responded in kind, her usual composed exterior cracking just enough to let the passion slip through, raw and unguarded.

 

As Rio’s lips trailed down Agatha’s neck, she whispered, her voice a hushed reverence, “You drive me crazy, you know that? The way you move, the way you speak—it’s impossible to focus on anything else. It’s like everything else disappears when I’m with you.”

 

“Good,” Agatha breathed, her voice breathless, but still threaded with authority. “That’s exactly the effect I was hoping for.”

 

Rio pulled back just enough to look into Agatha’s eyes, the fire between them intensifying. Her lips curled into a wicked smile, “You’re so smug,” she teased, brushing her thumb over Agatha’s swollen lips, her voice dropping to something teasing and dangerous. “I should make you pay for teasing me like that.”

 

Agatha arched an eyebrow, her smirk returning in full force, every bit as confident and enticing. “Oh, I’d love to see you try, my love,” she said, her voice rich with unspoken promises.

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound low and sultry as she leaned in to kiss Agatha once more. This time, their kiss was slower, more deliberate. Rio took her time, savoring every second of the connection between them. For once, it seemed, she was the one in control—determined to make Agatha feel the same unrelenting desire that had been coursing through her veins all morning.

 

But as the kiss deepened and Agatha’s hands tightened on her hips, pulling her closer still, Rio felt a soft surrender sweep over her. The truth settled in her mind as Agatha’s body pressed against hers, each movement a reminder of who held the power in this dynamic. Agatha pulled back just slightly, her voice a hushed whisper against Rio’s ear. “For the record,” she said with a reverent glint in her eyes, “you own me just as much, my love.”

 

Rio let out a soft sigh, the tension that had once existed between them now a faint memory. As their lips met again, deeper this time, Rio realized something that both thrilled and humbled her—control was never something she would completely have with Agatha. And honestly, she didn’t mind one bit. With Agatha, she was willing to lose herself, to give in to whatever force pulled them together. Because, in this moment, it was clear that they were equals, bound by desire and unspoken promises.

 

The faint sound of footsteps and voices echoed down the hallway, jolting both women back to reality. Rio froze, her fingers still tangled in Agatha’s hair, her breath warm against the curve of Agatha’s neck. Agatha’s body stiffened for a moment, her posture sharpening as she tilted her head slightly, listening for a few seconds, her eyes narrowing with a hint of amusement.

 

“Looks like we’re not as alone as we thought,” Agatha murmured, her voice a cool, controlled whisper, though the amusement lingered in her tone.

 

Rio’s heart skipped a beat, panic flickering through her before she quickly slid off Agatha’s lap. She adjusted her blouse with frantic precision, her cheeks burning with a mixture of embarrassment and lingering desire. Agatha, on the other hand, remained effortlessly composed. She slid her glasses back on, smoothing her hair back as though nothing had happened, her demeanor a perfect portrait of casual poise.

 

“Relax, love,” Agatha said with a soft chuckle, her hands meeting over her chest as she leaned back in her chair, looking up at Rio who as now standing over her. “No one’s going to barge in.”

 

“Still,” Rio muttered, her voice quieter now, a mix of nerves and something else that lingered in her chest like a slow-burning flame. “We probably shouldn’t tempt fate.”

 

Agatha gave a small nod, but her teasing smirk didn’t fade. She leaned over her desk, watching Rio with eyes that burned with unspoken understanding. Rio quickly grabbed her notebook, her hands still a little shaky as she tried to regain her composure, but every movement felt charged with the memory of their shared moment. The sound of the footsteps in the hall seemed to echo louder now as Rio reached for the door, her legs trembling just a little as she closed the distance between herself and the outside world.

 

Before she could turn the doorknob, Agatha’s voice rang out again, calm and casual but with that unmistakable warmth in her eyes.

 

“Before you go,” Agatha began, her tone still light but her presence commanding, “I’ll drop Nicky off at the dance center later for his class. I’ll pick you both up afterward, and we can head home together.”

 

Rio’s hand froze on the doorknob, and she turned back toward Agatha, her lips curving into a small smile. There was something in her voice, something soft and affectionate that made Rio’s heart flutter. “Perfect,” she replied, her voice a little breathless with affection, her smile deepening.

 

Agatha returned the smile, her eyes holding Rio’s with a kind of quiet indulgence. For a brief moment, it felt like everything else faded into the background, leaving just the two of them in that intimate space. But then, with a playful flick of her fingers, Agatha broke the moment.

 

“Go,” she said, her voice teasing but warm. “Before I change my mind and keep you here longer.”

 

Rio laughed softly, shaking her head as the tension between them melted into something lighter, warmer. She opened the door, stepping into the hallway with a reluctant but satisfied sigh, her heart still pounding, her mind still swirling with thoughts of Agatha. She stole one last glance over her shoulder, catching Agatha’s gaze once more before the door clicked shut behind her.

 

 

Rio pushed through the heavy doors of the library, the cool air doing little to dispel the heat still prickling her skin. Her cheeks burned with the memories of what had transpired earlier, and no matter how hard she tried to shake it off, she couldn’t seem to banish the feeling of Agatha’s gaze, the way her touch lingered, the heat of their kiss. The library’s hushed atmosphere, the scent of books and paper, only added to her sense of unease as she made her way toward the back corner, where Alice and Jen were stationed as usual.

 

Alice was leaned back in her chair, her headphones draped carelessly around her neck, eyes fixed on her notebook as she scribbled something down. Jen, on the other hand, was lazily twirling a pen between her fingers – and even the sight of it sent Rio in another spiral, remembering other fingers twirling another pen - her laptop open in front of her to what looked like an unintelligible sea of chemistry diagrams. When they both caught sight of Rio, Alice’s lips curled into a knowing smirk, and Jen paused mid-spin, her eyes narrowing with mischievous intent.

 

“Well, well,” Alice drawled, her voice practically dripping with curiosity and wicked glee. She leaned back in her chair, crossing her arms as her gaze fixed on Rio like a predator stalking its prey. “What’s this? Miss Vidal, why do you look like you just ran a marathon—or something equally… exhausting?”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, but the heat of her cheeks betrayed her. She tossed her bag onto the table with more force than necessary and immediately set to work organizing her laptop and notes, anything to distract herself from Alice’s unrelenting gaze. “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” she muttered, her tone flat, praying the conversation would die a quick death.

 

Jen’s grin widened, her gaze flicking between Alice and Rio, sensing an opening. “Oh no, Alice is right. You’re all flushed, Vidal,” she said, her voice playful but with a sharp edge of curiosity. She put the pen down and leaned forward slightly. “Spill. What’s going on?”

 

“Nothing,” Rio replied, a little too quickly. She pulled her notebook out of her bag, arranging the papers with exaggerated care as if they would somehow shield her from the relentless teasing she knew was coming.

 

Alice leaned forward with a predatory gleam in her eyes, her smile widening to almost impossibly wide proportions. “Oh, come on, Rio. You’ve got that look—the one people get when they’ve been thinking about something very… distracting.”

 

Rio sighed, her fingers slightly trembling as she adjusted her notes, trying to regain control. “I was just in a meeting about my thesis,” she muttered, her voice almost too soft, too flustered. She didn’t dare look up, too afraid of the teasing glint in Alice’s eyes.

 

Jen’s pen stopped mid-twirl, the sudden pause in the air between them a clear sign of her attentiveness. She exchanged a brief, knowing look with Alice before her gaze returned to Rio, her grin widening as if she’d just uncovered some hidden treasure. “A meeting, huh? With Dr. Harkness, I presume,” she drawled, the word stretching out like a tease. “Must’ve been a very stimulating discussion.”

 

“Enough,” Rio groaned, her face now a deep shade of red, almost matching her flustered expression. She dropped her head into her hands for a brief moment, then looked up, trying to muster as much composure as she could. “Can’t a girl just have a normal meeting without you two assuming things?” she asked, though the faint smile tugging at her lips betrayed the struggle to pretend she wasn’t entertained by the relentless teasing.

 

“Normal?” Alice said, feigning shock and pressing a hand to her chest as if Rio had just committed a great sin. “Since when has anything between you and Dr. Harkness been normal? You literally live together, Rio. We know better than that.”

 

Jen chuckled, leaning back in her chair with a smug look on her face as she tapped her pen against her notebook. “Seriously though, you’re flushed, your hair’s all mussed—”

 

“It is not,” Rio interjected immediately, reaching up to pat her hair self-consciously, suddenly aware of every strand that had probably fallen out of place. She sighed in defeat as Jen continued, completely ignoring her protest.

 

“And you’ve got that ridiculous little grin,” Jen finished, her voice full of knowing amusement. “So, spill. What did you do to Agatha? Or should I say, what did Agatha do to you?”

 

Rio groaned, her face burning even more, if that was possible. “I hate you both,” she muttered, half-joking, half-exasperated. Her cheeks were on fire, and no matter how hard she tried to hide it, it was obvious she was fighting a battle she wasn’t going to win.

 

“Oh, come on, Rio! You’re making it too easy!” Alice leaned forward, her grin absolutely wicked. “I’m not saying you have to share everything… but just a little detail wouldn’t hurt.”

 

“Absolutely not,” Rio groaned, shaking her head but unable to keep the corners of her lips from twitching upward.

 

Jen chuckled, raising her water bottle in a mock toast. “To Dr. Harkness,” she said, her voice smooth. “The woman who’s clearly the reason Rio’s looking so—what’s the word—ravished?”

 

“Jen!” Rio practically shrieked, her voice high-pitched as she grabbed one of Jen's discarded pens and threw it at her friend.

 

Alice ducked as the pen flew past her and cackled. “Oh, this is the best entertainment I’ve had all week,” she wheezed. “Agatha’s got you absolutely wrecked, Rio, and I love it.”

 

Rio groaned louder, leaning back in her chair as if she could disappear into it entirely. “You’re both the worst,” she grumbled, though the faint smile on her lips betrayed her affection despite her embarrassment.

 

“Maybe,” Alice said, grinning wide, “but at least we’re honest about it.”

 

"Well, I still hate you both."

 

“No, you don’t,” Alice said, leaning her chin on her hand, her eyes sparkling with mischief. “We’re just trying to keep you grounded. Don’t forget, we’re the ones who knew you before you were the cool professor’s girlfriend. Back when you were just a stressed-out literature nerd.”

 

“I’m still a stressed-out literature nerd,” Rio muttered under her breath, her lips quirking up despite herself.

 

Alice’s grin only widened. “Fair enough. But seriously, you’re giving off some serious ‘just made out with my hot teacher’ vibes,” she teased, her tone dripping with exaggerated sweetness.

 

Rio tried to ignore the comment, her hands shaking slightly as she opened her laptop in an attempt to dive into her work, but the truth was, her flushed cheeks gave her away. “Can we focus on our theses now?” she asked, forcing an air of professionalism, but it was clear the effort was half-hearted. Her fingers danced over the keys as if that would somehow distract from the heat still lingering in her face.

 

Jen leaned closer across the table, her grin wicked, and Rio couldn’t help but notice how she seemed so comfortable with the teasing, as though she’d done it a thousand times before. “You’re so obvious, Rio,” she said, her voice low and almost conspiratorial. “I bet Agatha knows exactly what she’s doing to you, too.”

 

Alice let out a loud laugh at Jen’s comment, then quickly shushed herself as the noise caught the attention of nearby students. “Oops,” she muttered, still grinning like a cat who had caught a mouse. “Sorry, got carried away. Okay then, we’ll let you be. For now. But you have to halp me with these readings, or I’m bringing this up again.”

 

As the conversation shifted back to their academic work, Rio let out a breath of relief, though a smile tugged at her lips despite herself. She couldn’t help but appreciate the bond she shared with Alice and Jen, even if they delighted in making her squirm. Life with them around was never dull, always filled with banter and chaos, and no matter how embarrassing it got, Rio wouldn’t have it any other way.

 

She forced herself to focus on the readings, but even as her friends began discussing the texts, her thoughts kept wandering back to Agatha, to the way her presence still lingered on Rio’s mind like a soft hum, impossible to ignore. No matter how much Rio tried to redirect her attention, the feeling remained—a warm, chaotic, undeniable pull that even her friends couldn’t tease away.

 

And somewhere deep down, Rio was secretly glad that it was a feeling she didn’t want to escape.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

Basically, this chapter was all horny and frustrated Rio hahaha

Also, what a lot of what have been waiting for is coming VERY SOON (like very very soon) if you know what I mean... so stay tuned

A New Title

Chapter Notes

Sorry about yesterday, AO3 was down at the time I usually post, and I just couldn't wait three hours, i really needed to sleep hahahah, so here it is, ENJOY!!!!

I hope you're ready for some feelingssss

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

The moments of happiness—not the sense of well-being,

Fruition, fulfilment, security or affection,

Or even a very good dinner, but the sudden illumination—

We had the experience but missed the meaning,

And approach to the meaning restores the experience

In a different form, beyond any meaning

We can assign to happiness.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The late afternoon sunlight streamed through the tall windows of the university hallways, casting warm, golden streaks across the polished floors of the English Department, almost as if the light itself was welcoming Rio after a long, busy day. Her footsteps echoed softly, the rhythmic sound accompanying the steady pulse of her thoughts as she made her way toward Agatha’s office. Her bag, slightly slung over one shoulder, was a familiar weight, and a faint smile tugged at the corners of her lips. It had been a long day filled with lectures, library sessions, and never-ending deadlines, but the thought of heading home to Agatha and Nicky made everything feel worthwhile.

 

When Rio reached Agatha’s door, she noticed it was slightly ajar, the quiet murmur of Agatha’s voice talking to herself drifting through the crack. With a small smile, she leaned closer, her fingers brushing the cool doorframe. Peering inside, she caught sight of Agatha seated at her desk, her signature dark curls cascading around her face, giving her the kind of sophisticated elegance that Rio found utterly captivating. Agatha was in her usual element—reading glasses perched on her nose as she flipped through a stack of essays, her focused expression radiating effortless authority.

 

Knocking lightly on the doorframe, Rio couldn’t help but tease, “Hey, Professor. Ready to wrap up for the day?”

 

Agatha’s head snapped up, her eyes instantly softening as they met the younger woman’s gaze. “Rio,” she greeted, her voice warm, rich with the kind of tenderness that always made Rio’s heart skip a beat. She set her pen down on the desk and leaned back in her chair, her fingers lightly tracing the edge of the armrest. Agatha took a moment to drink in the sight of Rio—her partner standing there, clad in her certain casual grace, now carrying that slightly rumpled, beautiful tiredness from her day. “Let me guess,” Agatha continued, her lips curling into a playful smirk. “You’re here to rescue me from the mountain of mediocrity I’ve been grading?”

 

Rio laughed, stepping inside and closing the door gently behind her. She leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed, her expression teasing. “That, and to remind you that your adoring son is waiting for us. Well, probably not waiting—he’s probably bossing Wanda’s twins around—but still.”

 

Agatha’s smirk turned into a full-blown grin, as she gracefully rose from her chair and slipped off her glasses. “And what about my adoring partner? Is she waiting too?”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, the playful spark in her eyes matching Agatha’s. “Maybe. But if you’re not careful, I might just leave you here with your essays. Let them be the ones who entertain you for the night.” 

 

Agatha’s laugh was a rich, low sound that always sent a little shiver down Rio’s spine. She walked over to Rio, her steps confident and sure, stopping just a breath away, so close that Rio could feel the warmth of her presence. “You wouldn’t dare,” Agatha teased, her voice quiet but knowing. “Besides, who else would make sure you eat a proper dinner tonight?”

 

Rio rolled her eyes, the smile still on her face despite her best efforts to appear unimpressed. “Touché,” she said softly, reaching out to smooth an imaginary crease on Agatha’s sleeve. “Ready to go?”

 

Agatha glanced at her desk, then back at Rio. “As ready as I’ll ever be. These essays will still be mediocre tomorrow.” She grabbed her coat from the back of her chair and slipped it on, her movements purposeful and deliberate.

 

As they walked out together, side by side, not touching, but nor far away from each other either, Rio felt a deep sense of contentment. The day might have been long, but with Agatha by her side and the promise of Nicky’s cheerful chatter waiting at home, everything felt just right.

 

 

That night, after they had picked up Nicky from Wanda’s house, the little boy seemed different. Normally a bundle of energy and independence, Nicky was unusually clingy with Rio, as though he couldn’t get close enough to her. His small hand remained firmly clasped in hers, and as they moved around the house, he stayed right beside her, his steps quick to match hers.

 

When Rio went to set the table for dinner, Nicky insisted on being by her side the entire time. He even climbed onto the counter to stay as close to her as possible, his tiny body sitting there with an air of quiet determination. Rio glanced at him, a smile tugging at her lips as she tried to balance her task with his insistence on proximity.

 

At dinner, though, Nicky’s behavior only became more noticeable. He barely touched his food, the usual enthusiasm for mealtime nowhere to be found. Instead, he leaned his head against Rio’s arm, his little body curled up next to her as though seeking comfort, his usually bright eyes duller than normal.

 

Agatha, seated across from them, had been watching the exchange with a furrowed brow, her gaze soft but full of concern as she observed the unusual silence from her normally chatty son. She had never seen him like this before—withdrawn, as if carrying a weight he couldn’t quite express.

 

Once Rio had gently coaxed Nicky into eating a few bites, she caught Agatha’s eye across the table. The question was clear in her expression, so she mouthed silently, What’s going on?

 

Agatha gave a small, almost imperceptible shrug, her lips pressed together as her own confusion mirrored Rio’s. Neither of them could figure out what had caused this sudden shift in Nicky’s behavior.

 

After dinner, when the kitchen had quieted and the last dish was washed, the three of them moved into the living room for their usual evening routine. The soft glow of the lamp filled the space, as Agatha settled onto the couch with a content sigh, Rio next to her. But before she could fully relax, Nicky climbed into Rio’s lap with the urgency of someone who needed to be close.

 

Rio welcomed him with open arms, her heart swelling as he snuggled into her chest, his small frame curling into her with a quiet, desperate cling. His hands gripped the fabric of her shirt like it was the only thing tethering him to her, and his head pressed against her, soft and warm.

 

“Sweatheart,” Rio murmured, her fingers gently stroking his hair, trying to soothe the unease she could feel radiating off him. “What’s going on? You’ve been my little shadow all evening.”

 

Nicky didn’t answer immediately. He shifted in her lap, and his face remained pressed to her, as though the mere act of speaking was too much to bear. For a moment, Rio held him tighter, the heaviness in his silence wrapping around her heart like a weight.

 

Finally, after a long pause, his small voice broke through the quiet, muffled by her shirt but trembling with uncertainty. “I don’t know… I just don’t want you to go away.”

 

At his words, both Rio and Agatha froze. They exchanged a glance, their shared understanding pulling at their hearts. The depth of his fear—unspoken, but so raw—was clear now, and it hit both of them in a way that left no room for words.

 

Rio blinked, the tenderness in her eyes deepening as she cradled him even closer. “Why would I go away, Nicky?” she asked, her voice soft and soothing, though her heart ached for him.

 

“I don’t know,” he mumbled, his voice small, like he was afraid to say it too loudly. “But… but you don’t live with us that long yet. What if you leave?”

 

The rawness of his uncertainty hung heavy in the room. Rio’s heart squeezed. She could see it now—the fear of something changing, the worry that their small family wasn’t as permanent as he wanted it to be. And the ache in his voice was too much to ignore.

 

Agathe reached over, brushing Nicky’s hair back with a softness that seemed to calm the air around them. Her hand lingered gently on his head, her voice unwavering as she spoke. “Oh, darling,” she said, her words slow and comforting, “Rio’s not going anywhere. She’s here to stay.”

 

Rio hugged him tighter, pressing a tender kiss to his temple as the weight of her promise settled between them. “Of course I’m staying, little love,” she whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “I love you and your Mama so much. We’re a team, remember? You’re stuck with me, kiddo.”

 

His grip tightened as he looked up at her, his eyes wide and uncertain. “You promise?” His voice was so small, so fragile, as if the question itself held the weight of his greatest fear.

 

Rio felt tears prick at her eyes, but she smiled, her lips trembling with affection. “I promise,” she said, her voice steady, yet full of love. “Cross my heart.”

 

Agatha, feeling the tenderness of the moment, leaned closer, wrapping her arms around both of them. She pulled them into a tight embrace, the warmth of their small family filling the space. “See, Nicky?” she said, her voice warm and soothing. “Rio’s not just part of this house. She’s part of our family.”

 

At last, Nicky’s tense little body began to relax. His tiny arms wrapped around Rio’s neck, and he sighed, the weight of his fear finally lifting. “Okay,” he whispered, his voice small but relieved, his head resting gently on her shoulder.

 

Rio’s heart swelled as she held him, kissing the top of his head. Agatha pressed a gentle kiss to her cheek, her eyes filled with gratitude and love. Together, they settled in, Nicky between them, the three of them wrapped in each other’s warmth for the rest of the evening, playing a game Nicky liked. As they held him close, letting him feel the security of their love, they knew this was exactly what he needed to hear—that they were a family, and nothing would ever take that away.

 

 

As Rio stayed downstairs, tending to her beloved plants and humming softly, a gentle peace settled over the house. She smiled to herself, grateful for the grounding nature of her little sanctuary.

 

Meanwhile, Agatha guided Nicky upstairs for his bedtime routine. The room was dimly lit, the only light coming from the nightlight in the corner casting a gentle starry  glow across the walls and ceiling. Nicky quietly slipped into bed, clutching his stuffed dragon tightly to his chest.

 

Agatha approached him with a tender smile, smoothing his blanket out with practiced hands. She sat down on the edge of the bed, her voice calm and steady as she spoke, knowing that this quiet ritual was one of their favorite parts of the day.

 

“Do you want a story tonight, sweetheart?” she asked, her voice warm and familiar, a question she always asked, but tonight, there was a softness to her tone that lingered just a little longer, as though sensing something different in the air.

 

Nicky, however, shook his head slowly, his little face unusually pensive, eyes downcast, as if deep in thought. Agatha tilted her head slightly, her brow furrowing ever so slightly in concern. She watched him for a moment, taking in the subtle shift in his mood. He usually loved story time, his imagination running wild with the adventures he’d ask for, but tonight, there was something about his quiet demeanor that gave her pause.

 

She leaned in slightly, brushing a stray strand of his hair back from his face, her fingers soft against his skin as she spoke again, her tone gentle and inviting. “What’s on your mind, darling?” she asked, her words barely above a whisper as she studied him with an attentive gaze, hoping to give him the space to open up.

 

Nicky shifted a little under the blanket, a small movement that spoke volumes. He seemed to be thinking deeply, hesitating as if unsure of how to begin. Finally, after what felt like an eternity of silence, he looked up at her with wide, searching eyes, his little face full of questions he wasn’t sure how to ask.

 

“Mama,” he began hesitantly, his voice quieter than usual, as though the weight of what he was about to say had settled heavy on his small shoulders, “can I ask you something?”

 

Agatha’s heart softened at his tone, and she leaned in a little closer, her expression open and reassuring. “Of course,” she said, her voice warm with the promise that there was nothing he couldn’t ask, no question too big or too small. She smiled gently, hoping to make him feel safe enough to share whatever was on his mind.

 

Nicky’s small fingers toyed with the corner of his blanket, twisting it between his hands as though it were the only thing anchoring him in the moment. He seemed lost in thought, his gaze focused on the fabric as if trying to gather the courage to speak. The silence stretched between them, and Agatha could feel the weight of it, the tension building in the air like a soft but steady pressure. Then, finally, he looked up at her, his wide eyes filled with uncertainty.

 

“Would it… would it be okay if I called Rio ‘Mom’?” His voice was soft, almost hesitant, as if the question itself was something that needed careful handling.

 

The words hit Agatha like a wave, unexpected and powerful, and for a brief moment, she was taken aback. She froze, unable to immediately respond, her heart swelling with a mixture of love, pride, and emotion. Her chest tightened, and before she could stop herself, she felt the sting of tears threaten to blur her vision. She blinked quickly, trying to keep her composure, her gaze softening as she placed a hand gently on Nicky’s small, tense shoulder.

 

“Oh, Nicky,” she said, her voice unexpectedly shaky. She took a deep breath, willing herself to steady her racing heart. “That’s such a sweet thing to ask.”

 

Nicky’s small face was filled with vulnerability, his eyes searching hers for a response, for reassurance. He must have felt the weight of his own question too, wondering how it might change things between them, or whether it would make sense to Agatha. But Agatha, though her emotions were stirred, found herself focusing on her son, on his needs, on his sense of belonging and the love that surrounded him. She swallowed the lump in her throat and steadied her breath before continuing.

 

“You know,” she said gently, her fingers brushing his hair back, “that’s really up to Rio. But for me? It wouldn’t bother me at all. Not one bit.”

 

Nicky’s brow furrowed slightly, a flicker of confusion crossing his face. “Really?” he asked, his voice quiet, seeking confirmation, as if the possibility seemed almost too good to be true.

 

Agatha nodded firmly, her smile soft but sure, as she cupped his cheek with one hand. “Really,” she reassured him. “I love Rio so much, and I know she loves you just as much as I do. She wants nothing but the best for you, always. If calling her ‘Mom’ is what feels right to you, then I think you should ask her. It’s your and her choice. It’s about what feels like family to you.”

 

Nicky chewed on his lip, his small face scrunching with thought. He seemed to consider her words, turning them over in his mind, weighing the significance of what it meant to call Rio something so personal, something so tied to the deep affection he felt for her. Agatha’s heart swelled with warmth, knowing just how much Rio had already become a part of their lives, and how much love Nicky had already given her.

 

“Do you think she’d say yes?” Nicky asked finally, his voice small, filled with hope but tinged with a hint of uncertainty, as though he was unsure of how such a change would be received.

 

Agatha smiled, her heart light, and leaned down, brushing a kiss across his forehead. Her lips lingered there for just a moment, as if she could convey all the love and security he needed through that single gesture. “I think she’d be so happy, sweetheart,” she said softly, her voice rich with certainty. “She loves you more than you know.”

 

Nicky relaxed a little, his grip on his stuffed animal loosening as he let out a sigh of relief, as though the weight of the question had lifted off his small shoulders. He settled deeper into his blankets, his expression softening, a small smile tugging at the corners of his lips.

 

“Okay,” he whispered, the word almost imperceptible but filled with the quiet resolve of a child who had found the answers he needed.

 

Agatha lingered a moment, stroking his hair and watching him settle. She leaned in close to whisper, “I’m really proud of you, you know. For being so thoughtful and kind.”

 

A small, shy smile crept onto Nicky’s face. “Thanks, Mama.”

 

Agatha sat back down on the edge of Nicky’s bed, sensing that he wasn’t quite finished with their conversation. His little brows were furrowed, his fingers twisting the edge of his blanket nervously.

 

“Mama,” he began again, his voice small and uncertain. He hesitated, his words coming slower this time, as though he was weighing them carefully before speaking. “Are you really, really sure it wouldn’t bother you? If I called Rio ‘Mom’?”

 

Agatha’s heart melted at his sincerity, and she reached out to cup his cheek gently. “Sweetheart,” she said, her voice warm and steady, “I’m absolutely sure. Do you want to know why?”

 

Nicky’s wide, trusting eyes met hers, and he nodded, eager for the answer. Agatha leaned in a little closer, her voice becoming more confident, as though the words she was about to share held an important truth.

 

“There’s something very special about love,” Agatha explained, her tone filled with quiet conviction. “It’s the only thing in the world that doesn’t run out when you share it. Love isn’t like a cookie or a toy where, if you give it to one person, there’s less for someone else. Love grows. The more you share it, the bigger it gets.”

 

Nicky blinked at her, letting the words sink in. His small hands stopped fidgeting with the blanket as a smile started to form on his face. “Really?”

 

“Really,” Agatha confirmed with a smile. “Loving Rio doesn’t take anything away from me. In fact, it makes my heart even fuller because I love her too. And I know she loves you more than anything.”

 

Nicky grinned now, his happiness evident in the way his eyes sparkled. “So… it makes your heart bigger?”

 

“Exactly,” Agatha said, laughing softly and brushing his hair back. “You’re such a smart boy, you know that?”

 

Nicky beamed, clearly reassured. Then, as if making up his mind, he suddenly sat up straighter. “Mama,” he said, “can you go get Rio now? So I can ask her?”

 

Agatha blinked, taken aback by his eagerness but touched by his determination. “Are you sure you’re ready to ask her tonight?” she asked, her tone soft, but carrying the hint of a smile.

 

“Yes!” Nicky said, nodding so vigorously his hair flopped over his forehead. “I want to tell her now!”

 

Agatha smiled, her heart swelling with pride and affection for her little boy. “Alright,” she said, standing up and kissing his forehead once again. “I’ll go get her. Wait right here.”

 

She left the room and walked downstairs, in search of Rio.

 

Agatha found her in the living room, standing in front of her beloved collection of plants. She was carefully misting the leaves, her posture relaxed, as if the task was her own soothing ritual. The sight was so quintessentially Rio—grounded, calm, and utterly focused— that Agatha almost didn’t want to interrupt. But she knew she had to. And, truthfully, she wanted to.

 

“Hey, love,” Agatha called softly, stepping into the room.

 

Rio turned at the sound of her voice, her expression immediately lighting up. “Hi,” she said, setting the mister down on the table. “What’s up? Is Nicky all tucked in?”

 

Agatha crossed the room to her, reaching out to rest her hands lightly on Rio’s arms, feeling the soft material of her shirt. “He’s not asleep yet,” she admitted, her tone gentle. “He, uh… he wants to talk to you.”

 

Rio tilted her head, her brow furrowing slightly as concern flickered across her face. “Is he okay? Did something happen?”

 

Agatha smiled, shaking her head as she leaned in closer, her hands moving to brush small circles on Rio’s arms. “Everything’s fine,” she reassured her, the words soft but firm. “He’s okay. But… he has a question for you. And it’s—” She paused, looking for the right words to frame what she was about to say. “It’s a big question.”

 

Rio’s frown deepened, her eyes searching Agatha’s face for any sign of what this might be about. She wasn’t used to Agatha being so mysterious. “What kind of big question? Agatha, you’re starting to make me nervous.”

 

Agatha smiled faintly and shook her head. “Don’t be nervous,” she said, her voice warm and reassuring. “I just… I wanted to prepare you. This question is something only you can answer, and there’s no expectation here. Whatever you decide, whatever you say, I’ll support you completely. And Nicky will too.”

 

Rio’s eyes widened slightly, and she studied Agatha’s face carefully, trying to piece together what this was about. But she could see that Agatha wasn’t going to reveal more.

 

“Okay,” Rio said slowly, taking a deep breath. She could sense the seriousness in Agatha’s tone, the quiet gravity of the situation. “Let me go see what this is all about.”

 

Agatha pecked her lips softly before stepping back. “He’s in bed waiting for you,” she said, her voice filled with quiet encouragement.

 

Rio nodded and headed upstairs, followed closely by Agatha, her heart racing slightly from the seriousness of Agatha’s words. Whatever this was, it mattered. And she was determined to handle it with care.

 

Rio’s heart clenched the moment they walked back into Nicky’s room. Tucked under his blankets, his little face peeking out, he looked a mix of determined and nervous. His fingers played with the edge of his blanket as his big, expressive eyes flicked between her and Agatha.

 

Agatha gave Rio a soft, reassuring smile before sitting down on the edge of Nicky’s bed. She rested a gentle hand on Nicky’s shoulder, a silent encouragement for him to find his voice.

 

Rio knelt beside the bed, bringing herself closer to Nicky’s level. She reached out and placed her hand lightly on the bed near his. “What’s up, buddy?” she asked gently, her voice warm and full of care.

 

Nicky hesitated, his small hands gripping the blanket tighter. He looked at Rio, then at Agatha, then back at Rio, as if gathering all his courage. Finally, he took a deep breath and started, “I’ve been… thinking about something. A lot.”

 

Rio tilted her head, her expression soft and open, urging him on. “Okay. Tell me, sweetheart.”

 

Nicky looked at her directly now, his voice a little shaky but earnest. “You told me once that… when you first started living with Grandma Lilia, you didn’t call her ‘Mom’ all the time. Just sometimes. When it felt right. Right?”
