Rio blinked, surprised by the memory he’d held onto, slowly sensing where this was going. She nodded slowly, her voice quiet. “Yeah, that’s right. At first, I didn’t call her ‘Mom’ all the time, and I still don’t. It took a while, but when I felt like I wanted to, I did.”

 

Nicky shifted under his blanket, his small face serious, his eyes locked on hers with a kind of thoughtful intensity. “I was thinking… if it’s okay with you… maybe I could call you ‘Mom.’ Not all the time, but… sometimes. When it feels right. Like you do with  Grandma Lilia.”

 

The room was quiet for a moment, the weight of Nicky’s words hanging in the air. Rio felt her chest tighten with emotion, tears already pricking her eyes as she looked at the boy who had so clearly been carrying this thought for days, maybe weeks.

 

Her eyes instinctively shifted to Agatha, seeking her reassurance in this moment that felt so delicate, so fragile. Agatha met her gaze without hesitation, her own blue eyes shimmering with unshed tears. She gave Rio a soft, trembling smile, one that spoke volumes, a silent reassurance that said more than words ever could. It’s okay. More than okay.

 

“Only if it’s okay,” Nicky added quickly, his words tumbling out. “I don’t want to make you feel weird or—”

 

Rio cut him off gently, reaching out to take one of his little hands in hers. Her voice trembled slightly, but her words were steady. “Oh, Nicky… it’s more than okay. I would be so honored if you wanted to call me ‘Mom.’ Even if it’s just sometimes. You know that, right?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up instantly, relief and happiness flooding his features. He squeezed her hand tightly, as if making sure this wasn’t a dream. “Really?”

 

“Really,” Rio said firmly, her smile breaking through the tears welling in her eyes. She glanced at Agatha, who was watching them with her own teary, radiant smile, before turning back to Nicky. “You’re the most wonderful kid, Nicky. You can call me whatever feels right to you, whenever it feels right. Okay?”

 

“Okay,” Nicky whispered, grinning now, his earlier nerves melting away. He suddenly sat up and threw his arms around Rio, almost suffocating her but she didn’t mind one bit.

 

“Thanks, Mom,” he whispered, his voice muffled against her shoulder.

 

Rio hugged him tightly, her tears finally slipping free. “Thank you, buddy. For trusting me with this. It means the world.”

 

As Nicky pulled back, he looked over at Agatha, who was quietly wiping her own tears with a tissue she’d pulled from her pocket. “Mama, you’re still not mad, right?”

 

Agatha laughed softly, her voice full of affection. “Oh, sweetheart, no. Not even a little. You’re allowed to have as much love in your life as you want, and I know Rio loves you just as much as I do. There’s nothing to be mad about. I’m so proud of you for sharing what was on your mind, sweetheart.”

 

Nicky grinned and and he reached for Agatha’s hand with one of his, his other hand still firmly holding Rio’s. “I’m lucky. I have the best Mama and Mom in the world.”

 

Agatha leaned forward, kissing his forehead again, her heart full to bursting. “And we’re the luckiest to have you.”

 

Rio sat back on her heels, still overwhelmed but filled with warmth. Her hand brushed against Agatha’s, and their fingers intertwined briefly, sharing a silent moment of connection.

 

As Nicky nestled back into his pillows, looking completely at peace now, Agatha and Rio stayed by his bedside a little longer, as they watched him take his dragon that laid forgotten in his bed back in his arms and fall slowly into a peaceful sleep, the three of them basking in the quiet, perfect completeness of their family.

 

 

As the door of their bedroom gently clicked shut behind them, Rio felt the weight of the emotions from the night settle in. She didn’t even make it to their bed before the tears began to fall, spilling down her cheeks uncontrollably. The rush of love, the trust that Nicky had shown her, was overwhelming. The reality of the moment was more than she had ever imagined it would be. She had always known in her heart that she loved Nicky, but hearing him say the words, offering her a place in his heart—it was more than she could have ever prepared for.

 

Agatha, who had been walking quietly behind her, reached out immediately, her arms encircling Rio from behind. She held her tightly, feeling the tremors of emotion in Rio’s body. “Hey, love,” Agatha whispered softly in her hear, her head coming to rest on Rio’s shoulder, her voice breaking with her own tears. “It’s okay. It’s okay to feel everything.”

 

Rio turned in her arms, burying her face in Agatha’s chest, the tears flowing even more freely now. She wasn’t sure why she was crying. Maybe it was because she hadn’t realized just how deeply she had been yearning for this connection, this bond with Nicky, until that moment. Maybe it was the magnitude of the love she felt for both Agatha and Nicky, and the realization that she was truly a part of their family. She didn’t know, but she couldn’t stop.

 

Agatha gently lifted her face with one finger under her chin, wiping away the tears that fell from Rio’s cheeks. “I love you so much, my love. I’m so proud of you. I know Nicky feels the same way.”

 

“I didn’t expect this… I didn’t know I could feel this much love,” Rio choked out, her voice raw. “It’s just so… overwhelming. I love him so much, Agatha. He’s everything to me, just like you are. And to think he trusts me enough to call me that...”

 

Agatha’s heart swelled, tears spilling down her own cheeks now. “He’s your family, Rio. You’ve always been his family, ever since you stepped foot in his life. He just needed to see it too.” She kissed the top of Rio’s head, her voice thick with emotion. “I know you’ve always had a big heart. And now you have him in your arms, too. You’re his mom, Rio. He sees it. I see it. Lilia sees it. We all see it.”

 

Rio took a shaky breath, leaning into Agatha’s embrace, finding the comfort and grounding she needed in her arms. She let herself cry freely, her tears mixing with Agatha’s as they both stood in the middle of their room, overwhelmed by the depth of their love for Nicky and for each other.

 

“I didn’t think I deserved this,” Rio whispered after a long pause. “I didn’t think I could have this kind of family.”

 

Agatha stroked her hair gently, her voice filled with quiet certainty. “You deserve it all, Rio. You’ve always deserved it. You’re a wonderful mom. You’re a wonderful partner. And now, we’re a family. Together. Forever.”

 

Rio nodded, her heart swelling with gratitude for the woman in her arms. “I love you so much, Agatha. And I love Nicky. I never thought I’d have this kind of family, but here we are… and I’m never letting go.”

 

“I wouldn’t let you go either,” Agatha murmured, her hands tightening around Rio, holding her close. “You’re everything to me. To both of us.”

 

They stood there for a long time, wrapped in each other’s arms, the weight of their shared love and happiness filling the room. Slowly, their tears subsided, and they pulled back just enough to link their foreheads. There was no need for words anymore. They had everything they needed. They had each other.

 

Finally, Agatha kissed Rio gently on the lips, her touch tender, as if sealing the promise they’d made to each other — that no matter what, they would be there, loving and supporting one another.

 

And in that moment, Rio knew that everything was exactly as it should be.

 

As they began to settle into their nightly routine, the warmth of the evening still enveloping them, Agatha paused for a moment while adjusting the pillows on their bed. She turned to Rio, a soft smile playing on her lips.

 

“Hey, Mom,” Agatha said casually, as though the word had been part of her vocabulary for years.

 

Rio froze for a moment, her heart skipping in her chest at the sound of it. The way Agatha said it—so natural, so tender—made the word feel like it was just meant to be. She turned to face Agatha, her chest tight with emotions she hadn’t even known she’d been holding onto.

 

“Did you just—” Rio started, her voice a bit unsteady.

 

Agatha’s smile grew, her gaze warm and knowing. “I just wanted to say it out loud.”

 

Rio blinked, feeling a rush of love and tenderness swell inside her. She couldn’t speak for a moment, her throat tightening, trying to process the reality of it all.

 

Rio felt tears welling up again, though this time, they were different. These were tears of gratitude, of recognition. She had always felt like she didn’t truly belong to a family beside Lilia, and yet here she was, being called “Mom,” by a child who had found her way into her heart in a way she never expected.

 

“I… Agatha…” Rio’s voice broke, and she let out a soft, emotional laugh as she wiped away a stray tear. “I don’t know if I can ever get used to that.”

 

Agatha stepped closer, cupping Rio’s face gently in her hands. “You don’t have to get used to it, love. It’s who you are now. It all comes naturally.”

 

Rio’s breath caught in her throat. The weight of Agatha’s words—their truth—settled into her chest, a steady, beautiful reminder of the family they had built together. She leaned into Agatha’s touch, closing her eyes for a moment as she let the emotions wash over her.

 

“Thank you,” Rio whispered, barely able to get the words out through the lump in her throat. “For everything. For helping me understand.”

 

Agatha smiled, her hand reaching for Rio over the bed. “You’ve always known, love. You just had to see it for yourself.”

 

Rio couldn’t stop the smile that tugged at her lips, even as her heart felt full to the point of bursting. She was Nicky’s mom now, truly. And somehow, the word felt as though it belonged to her, in every sense of the word.

 

“I love you,” Rio murmured, her hand reaching out to meet Agatha’s.

 

 “I love you, too, darling.”

 

Rio laughed softly, the word still carrying such a weight with it, but this time it felt like a promise, a new chapter in their lives. It felt like home.

 

 

That night, as Rio lay next to Agatha, her mind began to spiral in a way it hadn’t before that night. The warmth of the bed, the soft breaths of Agatha beside her, and the thought of Nicky peaceful sleeping in the room down the hall were grounding her, but something deep inside kept tugging at her thoughts.

 

The word mom echoed in her mind, still new and unfamiliar, though she’d already heard it a few times out loud. It felt right, but also like a weight she wasn’t sure she was strong enough to carry.

 

She couldn’t help but think: Am I too young for this? Do I have enough experience? She had never imagined herself in this role, never imagined being someone’s mom—not with all the emotional baggage she still carried from her own childhood. And yet, here she was, being called “Mom” by a little boy who had so much love and trust in his eyes, it made her heart ache.

 

But still, the questions lingered. Do I deserve this? Can I be the mother he needs?

 

Agatha must have sensed the shift in her, for she stirred in the bed and turned toward Rio, her voice soft in the quiet of the night.

 

“Hey, you okay?” Agatha asked, her hand reaching out to brush a strand of hair from Rio’s face.

 

Rio blinked, fighting to keep her emotions in check as she turned to face Agatha, her eyes shimmering with uncertainty. “I… I don’t know. It’s just… sometimes I feel like I’m too young for this. Too inexperienced. I’m not like you, Agatha. You’ve raised Nicky, you’ve been through so much. I… I don’t even know if I’m enough for him.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened with understanding, her gaze steady but full of compassion. She shifted closer to Rio, pulling her into an embrace, one hand resting gently on the small of her back.

 

“Rio, listen to me,” Agatha said, her voice quiet but firm. “You don’t need to be like me. You don’t need to have all the answers. You don’t need years of experience to be Nicky’s mom. You’re already exactly what he needs.”

 

Rio swallowed hard, the weight of Agatha’s words sinking in, but still, she wasn’t sure. “But… what if I mess up? What if I don’t know how to help him the way you do? What if I’m not enough?”

 

Agatha pulled back slightly, cupping Rio’s face in her hands, her gaze locking with hers. “You already are enough, Rio. The fact that you care so much, that you’re here, that you’re asking those questions, that you love him the way you do—that’s all he needs. Trust me, love, there’s no perfect parent. There’s only you, doing your best, and that’s all Nicky will ever ask of you.”

 

Rio closed her eyes, the soft pressure of Agatha’s hands comforting her as her thoughts began to quiet.

 

“You don’t have to be perfect,” Agatha continued, her voice gentle but full of conviction. “You just need to be there for him. And you’re already doing that.”

 

“But I’m still learning, Agatha,” Rio said softly, her voice tinged with vulnerability. “I’m still figuring it out.”

 

Agatha smiled, brushing her thumb along Rio’s cheek. “That’s okay. We all are. Parenting isn’t about having it all figured out. It’s about showing up, loving with all you have, and doing the best you can. And that’s exactly what you’re doing. Don’t ever doubt that.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered in her chest as she met Agatha’s eyes, the warmth in her gaze making Rio feel more grounded. Slowly, the knot in her stomach began to loosen thanks to Agatha’s unwavering belief in her.

 

“Thank you,” Rio whispered, her voice barely audible. “Thank you for believing in me.”

 

Agatha leaned in and kissed Rio softly, a kiss full of reassurance and affection. “Don’t ever doubt that, my love I believe in you, Rio. You’re more than enough,” she whispered against Rio’s lips. “Now go to sleep darling, you need it.”

 

Rio chuckled and closed her eyes again, letting Agatha’s words settle deep within her, and for the first time that night she felt the doubts start to fade. Maybe she didn’t have all the answers. Maybe she wouldn’t be the perfect mom. But she was there, and that was enough. She had Agatha by her side, and together, they were more than enough for Nicky.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

So was that what you wanted? did it live up to you expectations? I really hope it did!

I love you all, thank you for all your comments, they make me so warm and happy, please keep them coming!

Of Breakfasts and Pets

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Do not let me hear

Of the wisdom of old men, but rather of their folly,

Their fear of fear and frenzy, their fear of possession,

Of belonging to another, or to others, or to God.

The only wisdom we can hope to acquire

Is the wisdom of humility: humility is endless.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The next morning, the tranquil quiet of their room was abruptly shattered by the unmistakable sound of little feet pattering hurriedly down the hallway. Agatha stirred first, barely registering the commotion before Nicky, with all the energy of a cannonball, launched himself onto their bed. He landed squarely between them with a bounce that sent both adults jolting awake.

 

“Good morning, you two!” he chirped, his grin practically glowing in the soft morning light streaming through the curtains.

 

Rio groaned theatrically, dragging a pillow over her head. “Nicky,” she mumbled, her voice muffled, “do you know what you just committed? An ambush. That’s punishable by law, young man.”

 

Agatha, still wiping the sleep from her eyes, let out a soft laugh. She reached over to ruffle Nicky’s already chaotic bedhead. “Oh, come on, Rio,” she teased, her voice warm and amused. “This wasn’t an ambush. It was a well-executed tactical wake-up call.”

 

Nicky giggled, visibly pleased with his stealthy success. “I wanted to wake you up because it’s pancake day!” he declared, as if it were a universally known holiday.

 

Rio peeked out from beneath her pillow, her hair a mess and her face scrunched in confusion. “Pancake day?” she repeated, squinting at him through sleep-blurred eyes. “I’m pretty sure it’s Thursday. Don’t you have school today?”

 

“Yep!” Nicky said brightly, undeterred. “But last week, you promised we’d make pancakes together, and you said today would be the day! You did, you really did. You promised!” He clasped his hands together for added emphasis, his eyes wide and impossibly convincing.

 

Agatha leaned back against the headboard, a smirk tugging at her lips as she watched Rio grapple with the very awake and very determined six-year-old. “He’s got you there, my love,” she said with mock solemnity. “A promise is a promise.”

 

Rio groaned again, flopping dramatically onto her back and throwing an arm over her face. “You two are ganging up on me,” she grumbled, though a smile was already tugging at the corners of her mouth. She peeked at Nicky, whose hopeful expression was impossible to resist. “Okay, okay, pancake day it is. But you’re in charge of cleanup, little man.”

 

“Yes!” Nicky cheered, throwing his hands in the air. “Best morning ever!” He scrambled to his knees, bouncing on the bed like an overexcited puppy. 

 

Before Rio and Agatha could even think about getting up, the mattress became a battlefield of chaos as Nicky started bouncing up and down with uncontainable energy. It was as if the bed had turned into his personal trampoline, each leap higher than the last.

 

“Come on, come on! Pancake day!” he chanted gleefully, his voice ringing through the room like a celebratory anthem.

 

“Nicky!” Rio groaned, yanking her legs back under the covers just in time to avoid being trampled by his enthusiastic jumps. She grabbed her pillow and plopped it back over her face, letting out a dramatically long sigh. “We already said yes to pancakes but I need more sleep, kiddo. Is that so much to ask?”

 

Agatha, already sitting up and rubbing her temples to shake off the remnants of sleep, laughed softly at the scene. With a well-practiced motion, she reached out mid-jump and caught Nicky, pulling him into her lap. “Alright, young man,” she said, trying to muster some sternness in her voice, but the amusement betrayed her. “If you keep this up, your pancakes are going to be delayed.”

 

Nicky froze in her arms, his small hands flying to her shoulders as his eyes widened in mock horror. “Noooo, Mama! Not delayed! I’ll stop, I promise!” He turned his wide, pleading eyes toward Rio, his voice softening to a dramatic whimper. “Right, Mom? Pancakes need to be on time. Pancakes are important.”

 

Rio’s heart clenched at the word “Mom,” the sound of it slipping so effortlessly from his lips still catching her off guard. She peeked out from under her pillow, trying to suppress the warm smile tugging at her lips. “Alright, little man, you’ve got a deal. No more jumping, and pancakes will be on time.”

 

“Deal!” Nicky exclaimed, wiggling out of Agatha’s lap to plop himself down between them again. He was still buzzing with excitement, but at least the bed had stopped trembling.

 

Rio stretched and let out an exaggerated yawn, glancing over at Agatha. “He’s really taking to that word, huh?” she said, her voice soft and a little hesitant.

 

Agatha reached out, her hand finding Rio’s over the pillow now resting on her chest. Her eyes, still a little sleepy, were warm and full of love. “He is,” she said simply. “And he means it.”

 

Rio nodded, her chest filling with a mix of pride, love, and the weight of her new role in Nicky’s life. “Alright, alright,” she said, swinging her legs over the side of the bed. “Let’s get this pancake party started before he explodes from excitement.”

 

But just as Nicky started to hop off the bed, Rio lunged toward him with a playful grin, wrapping him in her arms and pulling him into a ticklish hug. Her fingers danced over his sides, and he squealed with laughter, squirming in her hold. “Oh no, you don’t!” she teased. “Not without giving me a good morning hug first!”

 

Nicky dissolved into giggles, his small arms wrapping around her neck. “Okay, okay! Good morning, Mom!” he gasped through his laughter.

 

Agatha watched the scene with a soft smile, her heart brimming at the sight of her son and partner so at ease with each other. “Alright, you two,” she said, standing and stretching before putting on her robe over her pajamas. “If we’re doing this, we’re doing it right. Nicky, go wash your hands and grab the mixing bowls. Rio and I will be downstairs in just a minute.”

 

“Yes, Mama!” Nicky chirped, bouncing off the bed.

 

“Come on, let’s go! I’ll get the eggs and the flour and—oh, and the chocolate chips!”

 

“Chocolate chips?” Agatha raised a brow, her tone laced with amusement. “Since when are chocolate chips part of pancake day?”

 

“Since today!” Nicky declared, his confidence unwavering. And without another word, he was out the door, and the sound of his little feet in the stairs could be heard a few seconds later.

 

As the door slammed shut behind him, Rio flopped back onto the mattress with a groan, her limbs heavy with exhaustion from the whirlwind that was Nicky’s morning energy. “How does he have so much energy this early in the morning?” she muttered, eyes half-lidded.

 

Agatha leaned over the bed, her lips pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s forehead, her warmth melting some of the tension in Rio’s body. “Some mysteries of the universe are unsolvable, my love,” she replied with a knowing smile, brushing a lock of hair from Rio’s face. “Besides, he’s a six-year-old with a mission. That’s a powerful combination.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but smile up at her, even though she was still heavy with sleep. “Good luck keeping up with him, Mama,” she teased, mimicking Nicky’s chipper tone.

 

Agatha laughed softly, her gaze full of affection as she ran her fingers through Rio’s hair, tucking it behind her ear. “Come on, Mom,” she said, stretching the word playfully, her eyes twinkling with adoration. “We’ve got pancakes to make.”

 

At the sound of the word, a warm, still unexpected feeling bloomed in Rio’s chest. It was still a little surreal, hearing Nicky call her that, but there was something about it now, something that felt undeniably right. The reality of it settled deeper in her heart. She smiled, a little overwhelmed but full of love, and nodded as she sat up.

 

Agatha squeezed her hand gently before pulling her up to her feet. 

 

 

Downstairs, the kitchen buzzed with the warmth of family. The aroma of freshly brewed coffee mingled with the sweet, comforting scent of pancakes. Nicky sat at the table, his feet swinging beneath his chair as he waited eagerly for pancakes, his bright eyes fixed on the stove as he eagerly awaited his pancakes.

 

Rio was at the stove, her hands expertly flipping the golden discs of batter onto a plate, each one a perfect, fluffy circle. She had long since learned the art of pancake-making, the delicate balance of heat and timing that turned each one into a golden treasure. Agatha, with her usual calm, was at the counter, quietly brewing coffee, the rich aroma swirling around them like a comforting embrace.

 

“You’re the best pancake maker ever,” Nicky declared, his voice muffled between mouthfuls, as Rio set another stack in front of him.

 

“Flattery will get you extra syrup,” Rio declared, reaching for the bottle and drizzling a little more on his plate.

 

“Yayyyy,” Nicky said with a mischievous grin, and Agatha couldn’t help but chuckle from where she sat, cradling her coffee cup in her hands as she joined the easy banter.

 

As they ate, the conversation was light and full of laughter. Nicky chattered non-stop, excited to share everything on his mind, from his plans for the day to the latest happenings in his world. His eyes sparkled as he talked about his art class, about how he’d been working on a drawing he couldn’t wait to show his teacher.

 

“Alright, kiddo, finish up,” Agatha said, glancing at the clock. “We’ve got to get you ready for school.”

 

Nicky nodded, shoveling the last bite of pancake into his mouth. “Done!” he said, wiping his face with his napkin in a somewhat haphazard manner.

 

Rio stood and stretched, a small yawn escaping her. “Alright, let’s get you sorted, mister. Clothes, shoes, and backpack check.”

 

Upstairs, Nicky darted around his room, grabbing his things while Rio helped him pull on his sweater, smoothing it over his head as she tugged it down. Agatha double-checked his backpack, making sure all the essentials were there—his lunch, his homework, his favorite book just in case the day got too long.

 

“Alright,” Agatha said as they all met at the front door. “Shoes on, jacket zipped, and you’re good to go.”

 

“Thanks, Mama,” Nicky said, slipping his hand into hers as they stepped outside into the crisp morning air. The little boy’s hand was warm and small in hers, his other hand already reaching for Rio’s as they stepped outside into the crisp morning air.

 

Rio locked the door behind them, and they walked together toward the car, Nicky sandwiched between them. The little boy hummed a tune as he skipped along, holding hands with his moms.

 

As they reached the car, Rio bent down to buckle Nicky into his seat, her hands moving with practiced ease by now, while Agatha leaned toward her with a smile. Her voice was soft but sure, full of the warmth that had always been present between them. “We make a pretty good team, don’t we?”

 

Rio grinned, her heart full, her hand resting gently on Nicky’s head as he chattered away, oblivious to the exchange. “The best,” she replied, her voice thick with love.

 

With everyone loaded up, they drove off, the morning sun lighting their path as another day began.

 

 

As the car hummed along the road, the soft whir of the engine almost blending with the rhythm of the tires on the pavement, Nicky swung his legs back and forth in his car seat, a thoughtful expression on his face. His fingers drummed lightly against the seatbelt as his mind clearly worked through some monumental thought. 

 

“You know,” he began, his voice taking on a tone that immediately made both Agatha and Rio lean in slightly, “I think it would be really, really cool if we got a pet.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but chuckle softly, her eyes flicking to Agatha, whose lips curled into a knowing smirk. “Oh, really?” Agatha asked, keeping her voice light and playful, though the amusement was clear in her gaze. “And what kind of pet are we talking about here?”

 

Nicky narrowed his eyes with the intensity of a young strategist, clearly savoring the moment. He tapped a pen he’d found abandoned on the seat next to him – the perks of having two scholars for mothers - against his chin thoughtfully, looking very serious. “Hmm… well, I was thinking maybe a dog. But then I remembered dogs are a lot of work, and you’ve got to walk them, and they bark all the time… That could get annoying.” He paused for a moment, rubbing his chin as if weighing the pros and cons in his head. “Then I thought maybe a cat, but cats are kinda picky, and I don’t want it to scratch my toys. Plus, they just sit around and look at you like they are the kings.”

 

Agatha couldn’t suppress a small laugh at that. “A royal cat, huh?” she teased, her eyes twinkling with amusement. “And then what did you think?”

 

Nicky’s face shifted from one of deep contemplation to a sudden burst of excitement, his eyes lighting up as he had his ‘aha’ moment. He sat up straighter, his small shoulders straightening with enthusiam. “A bunny! I think a bunny would be perfect. They’re so soft, and they hop around and have these cute little noses, and they’re small, so they wouldn’t take up much space! And we could build it a little house in the backyard or in the living room!” He was practically bouncing in his seat now, his energy palpable.

 

Rio’s heart melted at the thought, her mind immediately conjuring the image of a fluffy little bunny hopping happily around their home, its soft fur glowing in the sunlight streaming through the windows. “A rabbit, huh?” she mused, her voice soft and affectionate. “That’s… actually kind of adorable. And a lot less demanding than a dog or a cat.” 

 

“Right?” Nicky grinned, his excitement contagious. “It could live in the garden! Or my room! Or—oh, maybe it could share the living room with your plants!”

 

“Share the living room?” Rio laughed. “You know rabbits love eating plants, right? It might end up snacking on all my hard work. Aleafia wouldn’t stand a chance.”

 

Nicky gasped, horrified. “Okay, maybe not the living room. But still! A bunny would be perfect.”

 

Rio chuckled from the passenger seat, her voice light with amusement. “You know, bunnies also need a lot of care. Cleaning, feeding, giving them space to run around… It’s not all cuddles and cute little hops.”

 

“I can help!” Nicky insisted immediately, his voice earnest and full of determination. “I promise I’ll take care of it. I’ll feed it every day and play with it and—” He paused dramatically, as if contemplating the deeper complexities of pet ownership. “And even clean up after it—well, most of the time,” he added with a slight wrinkle of his nose, as if admitting the chore was a bit less glamorous than he’d originally thought.

 

Agatha couldn’t help but laugh, the warmth in her eyes unmistakable as she glanced over at Nicky in the rearview mirror. “It’s a big responsibility, buddy,” she said gently, her tone serious but kind. “A pet isn’t just for fun. It’s like having another family member. You have to make sure they’re well taken care of, not just when it’s easy but all the time.”

 

“Exactly,” Rio chimed in, her voice soft yet firm as she turned slightly in her seat to look at Nicky, the way a parent would when teaching a valuable lesson. “And you’ve got to think about what they need, too. Pets need love, attention, and care just like people. They have their own needs—like space to run and play, and food and water, and a safe, clean home.”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened, as if the weight of the responsibility was just starting to dawn on him. But then, with his characteristic enthusiasm, he threw his arms wide and beamed. “I have so much love to give!” he declared, his face lighting up with the sheer innocence and sincerity only a child could muster. “I’ll love the bunny sooo much!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, the sound full of affection and joy. The car was filled with an easy warmth, the kind that only moments like this could create—moments where the possibilities of a family’s future were still wide open, full of dreams and laughter.

 

Agatha, though, seemed to consider it all for a moment before speaking again. “Well, we’ll think about it,” she said finally, her voice warm but also a bit noncommittal, as if weighing the pros and cons of having a new addition to their little family.

 

“Really?” Nicky’s voice was high with hope, his wide-eyed gaze fixed on the back of Agatha’s seat. “You’re really thinking about it?”

 

Rio shot a playful look at Agatha, her expression full of mischief. “We’ll see,” she said with a grin, making sure Nicky couldn’t interpret it as a definitive answer, though she didn’t want to crush his excitement. “It’s not a no.”

 

“Not a no!” Nicky cheered in pure delight, his energy practically palpable as he bounced in his seat. He was clearly taking it as a win, even though it was still far from a definite “yes.” His joy was infectious, and Rio found herself grinning despite herself.

 

Agatha, shaking her head fondly, glanced over at Nicky in the mirror. “You’re persistent, I’ll give you that,” she said with a chuckle. “I’m not sure if you’re negotiating for a pet or running for office.”

 

Rio laughed at the comparison, her eyes dancing with amusement. “I think he’s got the politician thing down,” she said, raising an eyebrow at Nicky. “We might have a future negotiator on our hands.”

 

Nicky let a few moments of silence pass, his eyes narrowing with determination as he shifted tactics. This time, his approach was far more calculated.

 

“Rio,” he began sweetly, his voice dripping with innocence as he leaned forward from his seat. His wide, round eyes locked onto her, and his voice softened to a near-whisper. “You know how much you love animals, right? And how good you are at taking care of things, like your plants?”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, instantly suspicious of the charm offensive. “Mmhmm,” she replied, trying to suppress the smile tugging at the corners of her lips. She knew exactly where this was headed.

 

“So, don’t you think a pet would be, like, perfect? You’d be such a good… pet mom, just like you are with me,” Nicky continued, laying it on thick with a saccharine sweetness that could melt even the most hardened heart.

 

Agatha snorted from the driver’s seat, unable to hold back her laughter. “Nice try, buddy,” she said, shaking her head. “But Rio isn’t the one you need to convince. And stop comparing yourself to a pet.”

 

“But Mama,” Nicky whined, “you’re harder to convince! Rio’s nicer about these things.”

 

“Hey!” Agatha feigned offense, glancing at Rio with a teasing grin. “I’m nice, too. I just happen to know how to say no.”

 

Rio laughed, holding up her hands as if to ward off the conversation. “Don’t look at me. I haven’t said yes!”

 

“Yet,” Nicky said slyly, his grin wide and mischievous.

 

Agatha chuckled, shaking her head. “Stay strong, Rio. He’s trying to break you down. Resist the puppy-dog eyes.”

 

Rio gasped dramatically. “Puppy-dog eyes? Is that what you think of me, that I would cave at the slightest puppy-dog eyes? I’m hurt, Agatha. Really.”

 

“You’ll recover,” Agatha teased. “But seriously, Nicky, pets are a huge responsibility. It’s not just cuddles and playtime. There’s feeding, cleaning, training, vet visits—”

 

Rio bit her lip, struggling not to laugh at Nicky’s determined, yet endearing, expression. Nicky, however, was not deterred. He turned his full attention to Rio, his eyes growing even wider, his expression so sincere that Rio could almost see the gears turning in his head as he made his final pitch. “Please, Mom? You know how responsible I can be. Didn’t you say I’ve been getting better at taking care of my stuff, and of the plant friends?”

 

Rio glanced sideways at Agatha, the words tugging at her heartstrings. “You have been doing well,” she admitted, her voice soft with affection.

 

Agatha sighed, clearly resigned to the fact that Nicky was playing every card he had. The little rascal was already fully aware that “mom” was his new secret weapon, and it was working.

 

“Don’t you dare,” Agatha said, her voice light but firm, her eyes narrowing playfully. “Stay strong, Rio.”

 

Nicky groaned in frustration. “Mama! I’m talking to Mom! It’s not fair!” he complained, his tone full of exaggerated annoyance.

 

“Exactly,” Agatha replied, smirking. “That’s how this works. You’re my beloved son, and she’s my beloved girlfriend. Neither of you gets to cave on my watch.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes affectionately. “I’m not caving… yet. But don’t think I won’t remember this next time you want something, Agatha.”

 

Agatha laughed, leaning over to kiss Rio’s cheek at a stoplight. “Fair enough. But for now, we’re staying pet-free until further notice. Right, Nicky?”

 

“Right… for now,” Nicky muttered, clearly not pleased with the answer, though his wide grin suggested he wasn’t giving up just yet.

 

As they pulled into the driveway, Agatha shot Rio a knowing look, her eyes sparkling with humor. “Told you he was persistent.”

 

“And I told you I’m not caving,” Rio replied, smiling playfully but her voice not entirely convincing. Her heart softened at Nicky’s antics, but she wasn’t ready to give in.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, a smile tugging at her lips. “We’ll see.”

 

 

After dropping Nicky off at his school—his small hand waving enthusiastically from the school steps until they drove out of sight—Rio leaned back in the passenger seat with a contented sigh.

 

“He’s determined,” she said, grinning.

 

“Please, you want it just as much,” Agatha replied dryly, casting Rio a teasing glance.

 

Rio chuckled, stretching her arms above her head and yawning. “Well, at least I didn’t cave.”

 

Agatha hummed in agreement, pulling into the university parking lot. They stepped out, and the crisp morning air carried the scent of fresh winter wind. The campus buzzed with the energy of students rushing to classes and professors chatting in clusters.

 

“What’s your agenda for the day?” Agatha asked, slinging her bag over her shoulder and walking alongside Rio toward the main building.

 

“Library,” Rio said. “I have to dig up a few more sources on the exploration of mortality—still trying to strengthen that middle chapter.” She glanced at Agatha, her expression brightening. “And you?”

 

“Second-year lecture, fourth-year lecture, then my office for a mountain of papers to grade and, likely, fielding questions from overly eager first-years who think they’ve uncovered some groundbreaking theory on the Lost Generation.” Agatha’s lips curled into a knowing smirk.

 

Rio laughed. “I can’t wait to hear those stories later.”

 

They reached the building, walking through the bustling hallways filled with students, laughter, and the soft hum of academic life. Agatha’s office was on the second floor, while the library, Rio’s second home, was just a short walk away on the ground floor.

 

As they neared the staircase where they would part ways for the day, Rio paused and glanced back at Agatha. “Alright, that’s me,” she said, her tone a little lighter as she turned to head toward the library. “Let me hop right into my world of books. I’m already late for a very important date.”

 

“Come on, Alice in Wonderland? you’re worse than Nicky…” Agatha replied, rolling her eyes with a fondness that betrayed her true feelings.

 

Rio shrugged nonchalantly, her eyes twinkling. With a grin, she leaned in, just enough to let her fingers brush softly against the lapel of Agatha’s blazer. “Have a good morning, Professor Harkness,” she murmured, her voice a little lower, laced with affection.

 

Agatha met her gaze, her eyes softening. “Work hard, Miss Vidal,” she replied, her voice warm as she began her ascent up the stairs.

 

Rio watched her for a moment before heading toward the library, a small smile lingering on her lips.

 

 

In the quiet of her office that afternoon, Agatha sat at her desk, the soft click of her pen punctuating the stillness. Her reading glasses perched on the bridge of her nose, she tried to focus on grading, flipping through the essays in front of her. The papers were as varied as always—some sparkling with insight, others barely worthy of a passing grade—but her thoughts kept straying.

 

She sighed, leaning back in her chair and crossing her arms over her chest, her gaze drifting to the window as her pen tapped rhythmically against the desk. The image of Nicky’s wide, hopeful eyes and Rio’s poorly disguised interest in the idea of a pet played on a loop in her mind.

 

“A rabbit,” Agatha muttered under her breath, her lips curling into a reluctant smile. Of all the pets Nicky could have chosen, something chaotic—like a dog, perhaps, or even a cat—would’ve made more sense. But a rabbit? Quiet, manageable, and surprisingly low-maintenance. Not at all the kind of pet she’d have expected from her spirited, persistent son.

 

But still.

 

Agatha wasn’t entirely convinced. Pets, after all, were a big responsibility. They needed care, attention, and routine—all of which would eventually fall on her shoulders if Nicky’s initial enthusiasm started to wane. She knew all too well how quickly her son’s boundless energy could shift to the next big thing. His love for something new was always fierce but fleeting, and a rabbit, however adorable, would eventually become just another thing to manage. As much as Rio was drawn to the idea, Agatha couldn’t help but worry that her demanding schedule—and her tendency to get completely absorbed in her work—might add an extra layer of complication.

 

And yet…

 

Agatha let out a soft sigh, tapping her fingers absently against her temple as the image of Nicky’s excited face flashed in her mind again. The way his eyes had sparkled when he spoke about the rabbit, as if this were the answer to all of his hopes and dreams. And Rio—sweet, wonderful Rio—hadn’t even tried to hide her amusement, or the faint spark of excitement in her own eyes. She’d tried to remain stoic, to stand firm, but Agatha could tell from the twinkling glint in Rio’s smile that she, too, was already softening under Nicky’s persistence.

 

Even Agatha’s teasing in the car—telling Rio to resist—had been more for show than anything else. A half-hearted effort, a game she wasn’t even sure she wanted to win.

 

Who was she kidding? The moment Nicky had mentioned the bunny, Agatha had known. She had already lost this battle before it had even begun.

 

But Agatha wasn’t ready to surrender just yet. No, she would hold her ground a little longer, just to make sure they understood—really understood—that getting a pet wasn’t something to be taken lightly. It was a responsibility, one that required long-term commitment, and she wasn’t about to let them gloss over that fact.

 

A rabbit, though. She smirked, the image forming in her mind with startling clarity. Nicky crouched on the floor, his little hands gently petting the soft, fluffy fur of some imaginary bunny, while Rio sat beside him, utterly enchanted by the scene. It was such a vivid picture that Agatha could almost hear the soft sound of Nicky’s voice, full of excitement, as he coaxed the rabbit closer. And Rio, her eyes soft with affection, offering gentle words of encouragement. It was a scene that could have been pulled straight from a daydream.

 

Shaking her head, Agatha turned back to the essay in front of her, trying to refocus on her work. “Not today,” she muttered under her breath, though her tone lacked any real conviction.

 

She’d resist for now, that much was certain. But deep down, she knew the truth—this battle had already been lost. And, perhaps more than that, she was powerless to fight it. Because, in the end, she was completely and utterly wrapped around the little fingers of the two people she loved most in the world.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Thank you so so so much for all your very enthusiastic reactions to last chapter, it made me so happy you have no idea!!!
I love you all, you are all the best :)

The Weight of Yesterday

Chapter Notes

This is one beast of a chapter, I hope you're ready!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

It seems, as one becomes older,

That the past has another pattern, and ceases to be a mere sequence—

Or even development: the latter a partial fallacy

Encouraged by superficial notions of evolution,

Which becomes, in the popular mind, a means of disowning the past.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “The Dry Salvages”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

Agatha woke up that morning with a heaviness in her chest that made it hard to breathe, let alone move. The weight was familiar, an old, unwelcome guest that visited like clockwork once a year. No matter how much time passed, it didn’t seem to lose its grip on her.

 

The anniversary. Four years ago today, Evanora had drawn her last damn breath.

 

She turned onto her side, her gaze landing on Rio, who was still fast asleep. She looked peaceful, her face serene in the dim morning light, her breathing steady and calm. Agatha’s heart twisted at the sight. She reached out instinctively, wanting to tuck a stray strand of hair behind Rio’s ear or trace the soft curve of her cheek. But she stopped midway, her hand hovering in the air before she pulled it back. Instead, she let it rest on her own chest, where the ache throbbed.

 

This wasn’t something she wanted to share, not today. It wasn’t because she didn’t trust Rio—Agatha knew better than anyone how deeply Rio cared—but because the memory of Evanora was too sharp, too raw. Her mother’s cruelty lingered like an unhealed wound, and she didn’t want that darkness to touch Rio, didn’t want it to sully the light Rio brought into her life. Some ghosts were best kept buried.

 

Slipping out of bed as carefully as she could to avoid waking her, Agatha padded to the bathroom. The cold tiles beneath her feet sent a shiver up her spine, but she didn’t bother finding her slippers. She flicked on the light, squinting at her reflection in the mirror. Her eyes were tired, the faint lines around them deeper than usual. She placed her hands on the edge of the sink, gripping it tightly as if it could anchor her.

 

“You’re fine,” she whispered to herself, though the words felt hollow.

 

Her routine felt mechanical—quick shower, washing her face, brushing her teeth, tying her hair into a neat bun. She pulled on one of her favorite purple sweaters, the soft knit fabric a small comfort against the cold morning air. When she stepped back into the bedroom, Rio was stirring, stretching languidly under the covers.

 

“Morning, love,” Rio mumbled, her voice warm and thick with sleep. She reached out a hand, her fingers brushing the edge of the blanket as her eyes blinked open. “You’re up early.”

 

“Couldn’t sleep,” Agatha replied, keeping her tone as light as she could manage, as she sat on the edge of the bed on Rio’s side.

 

Rio’s brow furrowed slightly, her sleepy gaze sharpening. “Are you okay?”

 

“I’m fine,” Agatha lied, her smile small but practiced. She leaned in to press a kiss to Rio’s sleepy lips. “Go back to sleep. You’ve got a long day ahead.”

 

Rio didn’t look convinced, but she didn’t push. “Come back to bed for a bit?” she asked softly, her fingers squeezing Agatha’s hand.

 

Agatha shook her head, her smile faltering just enough that Rio noticed. “I’ve got papers to grade and a faculty meeting in two hours,” she said quickly, brushing Rio’s hair back. “You rest.”

 

Rio’s lips parted as if to argue, but she hesitated, her eyes searching Agatha’s face. Whatever she saw there, she decided against pressing further. Instead, she offered a quiet, “Okay. But don’t overdo it, alright?”

 

Agatha nodded, standing and giving Rio’s hand one last squeeze before she stepped out of the room. As she closed the door behind her, the familiar ache in her chest tightened.

 

It was going to be a long day.

 

 

Downstairs, the house was still and quiet, save for the soft hum of the kettle boiling in the kitchen. Agatha leaned against the counter, waiting for the water to heat. Her arms were folded tightly across her chest, her fingers tapping against her bicep in a restless rhythm. When the kettle whistled, she poured the water over a tea bag in her favorite green starry mug, watching as the amber color seeped into the water.

 

She carried the mug to the table, sitting down heavily in one of the chairs. The steam rose in slow curls, fogging her glasses as she stared out the window. The early morning light filtered through the trees that swayed gently in the breeze. Their movement was almost hypnotic, a rhythm she could lose herself in if she let it.

 

But peace was elusive. As she stared into the trees, Evanora’s face flashed in her mind, sharp and uninvited. Her mother’s cutting eyes, the cold, disdainful curl of her lips, and the weight of her words—all of it came rushing back.

 

Why are you so weak? Why can’t you be better?

 

Agatha’s fingers tightened around her mug, her jaw clenching as if she could physically push the memories away. She took a slow sip of her tea, letting the warmth calm her nerves. It didn’t completely work, but it was enough to steady her hands.

 

She didn’t hear Rio until she felt familiar arms wrap around her shoulders from behind. Agatha startled slightly but relaxed the moment Rio’s chin rested on her shoulder.

 

“You okay?” Rio asked softly, her voice still laced with sleep but tinged with concern.

 

Agatha forced a small smile, tilting her head toward Rio’s. “Of course. Just tired.”

 

Rio didn’t move, her arms tightening slightly. “Sure about that?”

 

Agatha hesitated for a fraction of a second, but she nodded. “Mmhmm. Long night, that’s all.”

 

Rio didn’t press, though Agatha could feel her lingering hesitation. Instead, Rio kissed her cheek, her lips soft and warm against Agatha’s cool skin. “Let me make you some breakfast,” she offered, her tone gentle. “You’ll feel better with something in your stomach. Nicky will be up soon anyway.”

 

Before Agatha could protest, Rio was already moving to the stove, pulling out eggs and bread. Agatha watched her, the familiar pang of guilt twisting in her chest.

 

Rio moved with easy efficiency, her bare feet padding softly against the tile and Agatha watched her, a pang of guilt gnawing at her. She hated hiding this from Rio, but she wasn’t ready to unpack it, not yet. For now, she would let Rio’s warmth be enough to carry her through the day, a quiet reminder that she was no longer the scared, hurt child Evanora had tried to break.

 

“You know,” Rio said, glancing over her shoulder, her smile bright despite the early hour. “If you keep staring at me like that, I’m going to think you’re in love with me or something.”

 

Agatha huffed a quiet laugh, the sound more genuine than she’d expected. “Lucky guess,” she murmured, lifting her mug to her lips.

 

Rio grinned, flipping the eggs in the pan. “I’m always lucky when it comes to you.”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened again, but this time it wasn’t entirely unpleasant. It was a bittersweet ache, a reminder of how much Rio had given her—a life filled with warmth and love, something she never thought she’d deserve after Evanora.

 

By the time Rio set a plate of eggs and toast in front of her, the sound of small feet thudding down the stairs echoed through the house. Nicky appeared in the doorway, his hair a messy tangle and his eyes still half-closed.

 

“Morning, Mama. Morning, Rio,” he mumbled, climbing into the chair next to Agatha and leaning against her side.

 

“Morning, kiddo,” Rio said cheerfully, ruffling his hair as she brought his plate to the table.

 

Agatha wrapped an arm around him, pulling him close as she kissed the top of his head. She felt the weight in her chest ease just a little.

 

She wasn’t the broken child Evanora had tried to make her. She was stronger now, even if some days it didn’t feel that way. She had Rio, and she had Nicky—and that made all the difference.

 

 

The sun was high, casting a cold glow over the campus, but Agatha barely noticed it. Her steps were mechanical, her heels clicking rhythmically against the polished floors as she moved between her office, lectures, and meetings. She kept her head high, her demeanor as calm and collected as ever, but beneath the surface, her thoughts were in turmoil.

 

Every corner of her mind felt steeped in the past, as if Evanora’s presence had seeped back into her life, unbidden and suffocating. The anniversary of her mother’s death wasn’t something she celebrated, nor was it something she allowed herself to grieve openly. Instead, she carried the weight of it in silence, locking it away where no one could reach it.

 

The ache in her chest spread like a slow poison, making it harder to focus. By mid-afternoon, her lectures were a blur, her voice moving through the motions while her mind remained elsewhere. Her students didn’t seem to notice anything amiss—Agatha Harkness was as poised as ever—but she could feel the cracks forming, threatening to split her open.

 

Back in her office, she stood behind her desk, her hands hovering over a stack of lecture notes she’d been meaning to work on. Her breathing was uneven, the oppressive silence of the room pressing in on her. She reached up to pinch the bridge of her nose, trying to steady herself, but it was no use.

 

She needed someone.

 

The thought surprised her—Agatha had always prided herself on her independence, on her ability to carry her burdens alone. But today, the weight was too much.

 

The only person who came to mind was Lilia.

 

Lilia wasn’t her mother. She didn’t share Agatha’s history or scars. But she was Rio’s mother, the woman who had loved and cared for the person Agatha adored more than life itself. Somehow, in her desperation, it made sense. Lilia’s presence felt like the kind of safe harbor Agatha had never really experienced.

 

If she couldn’t have had that with her own mother, perhaps she could borrow it here.

 

Her hand shook as she reached for her phone. She stared at the screen for a long moment, hesitating, before dialing Lilia’s number. The ringing seemed to stretch on forever, each second amplifying the lump in her throat, until finally, Lilia’s warm, familiar voice answered.

 

“Agatha, dear? What a pleasure to hear from you. Is everything alright?”

 

Agatha’s lips parted, but no sound came out at first. She swallowed hard, forcing herself to speak. “I… I was wondering if I could come by.” Her voice wavered, betraying her. “Without Rio. I just… I need some time. If it’s alright.”

 

There was a pause on the other end, but it wasn’t uncomfortable. It was the kind of silence that made space for understanding. “Of course, sweetheart. Come whenever you’re ready. I’ll have tea waiting.”

 

Agatha closed her eyes, exhaling deeply. Relief washed over her, loosening the tight knot in her chest just a fraction. “Thank you,” she whispered, her voice barely audible.

 

She ended the call and stood there for a moment, the phone still in her hand. The decision to reach out felt strange, unfamiliar, but not wrong. It was a small step—a quiet acknowledgment that maybe she didn’t have to face this day alone.

 

As she gathered her things to leave, Agatha paused, her hand lingering over her phone on the desk. The weight of the day pressed heavily on her chest, but she knew she needed to send a message to Rio—something simple, something that wouldn’t invite too many questions.

 

After a moment of hesitation, she unlocked her phone again and typed.

 

Agatha: Hey, love. I’ll be home a little later than usual. Just have something I need to take care of first. Don’t wait up for me to eat, okay?

 

She stared at the screen for a beat before hitting send, hoping her words wouldn’t spark worry in Rio. She hated the vague nature of the message, but the alternative—explaining the knot of emotions she was carrying—felt impossible.

 

Finally, she hit send, her chest tightening as the message disappeared into the ether.

 

The reply came quickly, as it always did with Rio.

 

Rio: Okay. Be safe, Nicky and I will be just fine. I’ll make sure there’s food waiting for you when you get back. I love you, Agatha.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a small, grateful smile. Just reading Rio’s reply grounded her. Even without knowing the details, Rio always had her back. It was a reminder of why she needed to make peace with this day, to let herself heal for the sake of the family she had now.

 

Slipping her phone into her bag, she exhaled slowly and glanced around her office. The familiar surroundings—her books, her neatly organized desk, even the faint scent of lavender that usually soothed her felt strangely distant, as though she were looking at her life from the outside in.

 

Shaking off the thought, she grabbed her coat and made her way out of the building, the crisp late afternoon air biting at her cheeks as she stepped outside. The sun was beginning to sink lower in the sky, creating colors and shapes that weren’t there earlier that day. It was beautiful, but Agatha barely registered it, her focus already on the drive ahead.

 

She started the engine, the hum of the car filling the quiet as she pulled out of the parking lot. The roads stretched ahead, familiar yet distant, much like her thoughts.

 

On impulse, she reached over and turned on the radio, letting the soft strains of music fill the space. It was a station Rio always listened to, full of oldies and gentle tunes. The familiarity of it eased the tension in her shoulders, if only slightly.

 

The drive felt longer than it was, every mile stretching out as her mind wandered. Memories of Evanora flickered in and out, her sharp eyes and cutting words as vivid as if they were happening now. Agatha clenched the steering wheel tighter, her knuckles white against the leather.

 

But then she thought of Lilia’s voice, warm and inviting, and the image of Rio’s text lit up in her mind. I’ll make sure there’s food waiting for you when you get back. I love you, Agatha.

 

That was what mattered. That was her reality now.

 

 

By the time she pulled up in front of Lilia’s house, the sun had dipped low, casting long shadows across the quiet street. Agatha sat in the car for a moment, staring at the warm glow spilling from the windows. The house exuded the same welcoming energy its owner did, and for the first time that day, Agatha felt the smallest sliver of relief.

 

She took a deep breath, gathered her things, and stepped out of the car. With each step toward the front door, the knot in her chest loosened ever so slightly.

 

She hadn’t fully decided what she would say—or if she would say anything at all—but the weight on her chest was suffocating. She needed this, even if she didn’t entirely understand why.

 

She climbed on the porch and  knocked lightly on the door, and it opened not even five seconds later, and there stood Lilia, her warm, knowing smile easing some of the tension in Agatha’s chest. “Agatha,” Lilia greeted, stepping aside and gesturing for her to come in. “Just so you know, you never have to knock. My door is always open for you.”

 

Agatha managed a small smile, stepping into the cozy home. It smelled faintly of cinnamon and chamomile, a comforting mix that reminded her why Rio always said Lilia’s house felt like a safe haven.

 

“Thank you,” Agatha said softly, removing her coat and hanging it by the door.

 

“Come on in,” Lilia said, guiding her to the living room, where a pot of tea and two cups waited on the coffee table. “I wasn’t sure what kind of day you’d had,” Lilia said gently, sitting across from her. “But I figured tea couldn’t hurt—or something stronger.”

 

Agatha chuckled quietly, the sound dry and thin. “Tea is fine. Thank you.”

 

As Lilia bustled into the kitchen, Agatha sank into the sofa, her eyes scanning the room. It was a space filled with warmth—photographs of Rio, even one of Nicky and her at his choir show,  bookshelves overflowing with well-loved novels, and a collection of plants also thriving under Lilia’s care, not as much as Rio’s but enough to know who she had gotten that love from.

 

It was a room brimming with life, love, and history—a stark contrast to the cold, sterile environment of Agatha’s childhood home. Sitting here, surrounded by evidence of so much care, Agatha felt almost like an outsider, as though she were intruding on a world she didn’t quite belong to.

 

When Lilia returned, she silently put a plate of little biscuits in front of her, before settling into the chair across from her. Lilia didn’t ask questions or offer platitudes. Instead, she simply waited, her sharp eyes soft with patience and understanding.

 

Agatha wrapped her hands around the mug, its warmth grounding her. She hesitated, the weight of the day pressing heavily on her chest. “I… I didn’t mean to impose,” she began, her voice barely above a whisper. “I wasn’t sure where else to go.”

 

Lilia shook her head, her tone firm but kind. “Impose? Nonsense. You’re family, Agatha. You’re my Rio’s family, and that makes you mine too, dear. Now,” she continued, her gaze unwavering but gentle, “what’s weighing you down?”

 

Agatha’s instinct was to deflect, to claim she was fine and avoid the vulnerability that question demanded. But the steady warmth in Lilia’s voice and the genuine care in her expression unraveled her defenses. Here, in this space, lying felt impossible.

 

“It’s…” Agatha paused, the words catching in her throat. She swallowed hard, her fingers tightening around the mug. “Today is an anniversary,” she admitted, her voice so soft it was almost lost in the quiet room. “Not… a good one.”

 

Lilia nodded slowly, her expression never faltering. “You don’t have to say more if you don’t want to,” she said gently. “But if you do, I’m here. No judgment. No rush.”

 

Agatha’s gaze dropped to her tea, the rising steam swirling in mesmerizing patterns. The silence between them was thick but not oppressive; it was a space Lilia had created for her, free of expectations.

 

“I don’t know how to talk about it,” Agatha confessed after a long pause. “I’m not even sure I know how to feel about it. It’s just… heavy.”

 

Lilia leaned forward slightly, her presence a quiet anchor. “Grief and pain have a way of doing that,” she said softly. “But carrying it alone doesn’t make it any lighter, Agatha. Sometimes, sharing even a small piece of it can help.”

 

Agatha looked up, her chest tightening at the sincerity in Lilia’s words. This kind of gentle, unwavering support was so foreign to her, and yet, she found herself wanting to trust it.

 

“Thank you,” she murmured, her voice tinged with emotion. “Just… being here helps.”

 

Lilia reached out, resting a comforting hand on Agatha’s knee. Her touch was light but steady, grounding. “You’re always welcome here,” she said firmly. “You’ve given Rio so much, and I see how deeply you love her and Nicky. But you need to remember, Agatha—love and care aren’t things you just give. You deserve them too. Always.”

 

Agatha’s throat tightened, and for a moment, she couldn’t speak. The words settled deep in her chest, warm and unfamiliar. It wasn’t the suffocating weight of her memories—it was something else, something softer—an almost maternal comfort she’d never truly experienced before.

 

“Thank you,” Agatha murmured again, her voice thick with emotion. She looked down at her tea, her heart feeling just a little lighter.

 

Agatha’s fingers traced the rim of her tea mug, her eyes locked on the swirling liquid as if its movements might offer some clarity. The room was still, the silence heavy with unsaid words. Lilia didn’t rush her, didn’t ask any questions. Her presence was quiet, but it anchored Agatha, as steady and constant as the earth beneath her feet.

 

The minutes stretched out, a thick web of unspoken emotions, until Agatha finally exhaled a long, shaky breath. Her voice came out softer than she intended, trembling with the weight of years of buried pain. “It’s about my mother.”

 

Lilia didn’t react with surprise or interruption. She simply leaned forward slightly, her hands folded calmly in her lap, her expression one of quiet, nonjudgmental patience. She allowed Agatha to take her time, to speak when she was ready.

 

“Evanora,” Agatha said, the name a sharp bite in her mouth, each syllable like sandpaper. “She… wasn’t a good person. Not to me. Not to anyone.” Her eyes darkened, the pain that had been buried for so long breaking through in waves. “She hurt me in ways I didn’t even understand until I was much older.”

 

Lilia’s brows furrowed slightly, but she remained silent, allowing Agatha to speak at her own pace.

 

“She was controlling, cruel, and manipulative. Nothing I did was ever good enough. If I succeeded, it was because she expected it. If I failed, it was because I wasn’t worthy of her attention. She… she used to tell me I was unlovable, that I was a burden. That everything I touched would wither because that’s who I was—evil, a disappointment.”

 

Her voice cracked, and she clutched the mug in her hands like it was the only thing keeping her tethered to the present. “She passed away four years ago today,” Agatha murmured, her voice cracking. “But sometimes, it feels like she’s still here. Her voice echoes in my head, even when I know it’s not true. Even when I know Rio loves me. Even when I know Nicky adores me. I can still hear her.”

 

Lilia’s expression softened, and without a word, she reached out, her hand warm and steady as it rested over Agatha’s. “Oh, sweetheart,” she said, her voice thick with emotion, a softness Agatha hadn’t expected but desperately needed. “I’m so sorry you went through that. No one—especially not a child—should ever be made to feel like that. No one should have that kind of darkness thrust upon them.”

 

Agatha blinked rapidly, her throat tight as tears welled up in her eyes. The dam she had held together for so long began to crack, and she let out a shaky breath. “I try so hard not to let it affect me, but some days…” She trailed off, her voice faltering. “Some days, it’s like she’s still here, still reminding me of all the ways I’m not enough.”

 

Lilia gave Agatha’s hand a firm squeeze, her voice unwavering as she spoke. “You are enough, Agatha. More than enough. You’ve built a life filled with love—real, genuine love—with Rio, with Nicky. That takes strength. That takes resilience. That takes so much heart. Your mother may have tried to dim your light, but she failed. Look at you now—you’re a wonderful partner. A loving mother. Someone Rio trusts with her whole heart. Someone she loves more than anything.”

 

Agatha’s breath caught, and the tears she had been holding back spilled over, tracing a slow path down her cheeks. She looked up at Lilia, her heart aching with both gratitude and sorrow. “I don’t know how to let it go,” she whispered, her voice cracking under the weight of it all. “I don’t know how to stop hearing her.”

 

Lilia moved to sit beside Agatha on the sofa, her presence steady and grounding as she gently wrapped an arm around Agatha’s shoulders. She pulled her close, enveloping her in the kind of embrace she had offered Rio countless times before—warm, unconditional, filled with the quiet assurance that everything would be okay.

 

“You don’t need to have all the answers right now,” Lilia murmured, her voice soft but firm, carrying the wisdom of someone who had known both love and loss. “Healing isn’t a straight line, Agatha. It’s messy and unpredictable. But you don’t have to carry it alone, either.” Her words wrapped around Agatha like a blanket, soothing the raw, exposed parts of her that had been left too long without comfort. “Rio is with you. I’m with you. You’re a remarkable woman, Agatha, and an extraordinary mother. Don’t you ever forget that.”

 

A quiet sob caught in Agatha’s throat, but she swallowed it down, her eyes closing as she let herself sink deeper into Lilia’s embrace. She had never known this kind of tenderness, the kind that didn’t come with strings attached, the kind that simply existed to offer warmth.

 

“You have a family now, Agatha,” Lilia continued, her words laced with an unwavering conviction. “A real family. One that sees you, that cherishes you for everything you are. One that will remind you every single day that you are so much more than what she made you believe. So much more.”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened, her breath shaky as she let the weight of those words settle into her bones. She had spent so many years trying to convince herself she didn’t need anything more, but here, in this moment, the truth of Lilia’s words began to crack the walls she had built around her heart. For the first time in years, she allowed herself to hope.

 

She rested her head against Lilia’s shoulder, her body trembling slightly as she exhaled a shaky breath. The weight of everything she had been carrying felt a little lighter, just enough to let her breathe.

 

“Thank you,” Agatha whispered, her voice small but thick with emotion, the words barely more than a breath.

 

Lilia pressed a soft kiss to the top of Agatha’s head, her hand stroking the back of her hair in a gesture of quiet affection. “Always, my dear,” she said, her voice thick with emotion, carrying the comfort of someone who truly understood what it meant to offer love without hesitation. “Always.”

 

Agatha pulled away slightly, dabbing at her eyes with the tissue Lilia had handed her, her hands trembling as they held it. Her voice wavered, raw and fragile, as she allowed herself a vulnerability she had long kept hidden.

 

“I don’t know how to tell Rio,” she whispered, her gaze fixed on her lap, as if the weight of the confession were too much to bear. “About everything. About Evanora… about what she did to me. I’ve shared pieces, but not the whole truth. I don’t know if I can bring myself to say it all.”

 

Lilia’s brow furrowed, her hand still resting on Agatha’s shoulder with a quiet steadiness that spoke of years of knowing how to hold space for someone in pain. “Why do you think you can’t?”

 

Agatha swallowed, a sob catching in her throat. She took a shaky breath, her words struggling to surface. “Because… because I’m terrified it’ll scare her away,” she admitted, her voice cracking. “What if it’s too much for her? What if she sees how broken I am and decides I’m not worth it? She doesn’t deserve that. She deserves someone whole, someone… someone who isn’t this mess.” Her hands twisted together in her lap, betraying just how deep the fear ran—fear of rejection, fear of failure.

 

Lilia’s expression softened, her heart aching for Agatha. “Agatha,” she said gently, her tone firm but warm, “Rio loves you. She loves you with a depth that most people spend their entire lives searching for. Nothing about your past will change that.”

 

Agatha shook her head, the words not fully reaching her. “You say that, but—”

 

“No buts,” Lilia interrupted, her voice resolute. “Listen to me. I’ve seen the way Rio looks at you. You’re her person, her heart, her home. She would walk through fire for you, just as you would for her. Sharing your truth won’t scare her away; it’ll only bring you closer. Do you know why?”

 

Agatha shook her head, tears threatening to spill again.

 

“Because Rio doesn’t love you in spite of your struggles,” Lilia continued, her voice soft yet unwavering. “She loves you because of them. All of you. She knows the pain you’ve carried, the weight of the years you’ve spent fighting alone. She admires your strength, even when you don’t see it yourself. And the truth? It’s not a burden to her—it’s an honor to be the person you trust enough to share it with.”

 

Agatha’s lips trembled, her eyes glistening as she whispered, “But what if I’m too much?”

 

Lilia reached out, taking both of Agatha’s hands in hers. “You are not too much, Agatha. You are exactly enough. Rio isn’t going anywhere, no matter what you tell her. And if you need more time to feel ready, that’s okay too. But don’t let fear rob you of the chance to let her love you fully.”

 

Agatha nodded slowly, her chest feeling both heavy and a little lighter at the same time. “You really think she won’t… look at me differently?”

 

“I raised that girl, I know she won’t,” Lilia said confidently. “She looks at you like you hung the moon, Agatha. And that’s not going to change.” She paused, as if weighing something important, before adding, “And you know, if there’s anyone who might understand what it feels like to be an unloved child, it’s Rio. She might know more than you think. Don’t underestimate her.”

 

Agatha let out a shaky breath, a small, tentative smile breaking through her tears. “Thank you, Lilia.”

 

“Sweetheart,” Lilia said, squeezing her hands. “You’re part of this family now, too. And we take care of our own.”

 

As Lilia refilled the cup of tea in front of Agatha, she gently said, “You know, you don’t have to do this alone.  If you’re ready, we could call Rio, have this conversation together. Sometimes, sharing the burden makes it a little lighter.”

 

Agatha hesitated, her fingers tracing the edge of the cup. The thought of opening up to Rio fully was overwhelming, but Lilia’s presence gave her a sense of safety she hadn’t felt in a long time.

 

“Do you think… she’d want to hear all of this now?” Agatha asked, her voice barely above a whisper, tinged with doubt and fear.

 

Lilia smiled warmly. “Agatha, she would drop everything if it meant being there for you. You just need to let her know.”

 

Agatha let out a long breath, her fingers tightening slightly around the cup. “Okay,” she said finally, her voice barely above a whisper. “Let’s call her.”

 

Lilia nodded, giving her shoulder a reassuring squeeze. “Good. I’ll be right here.”

 

With hands that shook despite her best efforts, Agatha reached for her phone. She dialed Rio’s number, the sound of the ring reverberating in her chest. It rang twice before Rio answered, her voice soft and sweet as ever.

 

“Hey, love. Everything okay?”

 

Agatha took a slow, steadying breath, glancing at Lilia, who gave her an encouraging nod. “Rio, I… I need you. Could you come to Lilia’s house? There’s something important I need to talk to you about.”

 

Rio’s tone turned even softer, laced with love and determination. “Of course, Agatha. Let me just drop Nicky off at Wanda’s, and I’ll be right there. Are you okay?”

 

“I’m… trying to be,” Agatha admitted.

 

“That’s all that matters,” Rio said gently. “I’ll be there soon, okay? Just hold on.”

 

“Okay,” Agatha whispered, her voice breaking slightly.

 

After they hung up, Lilia gave her a reassuring smile. “She’s on her way. You’re going to be okay, Agatha. I promise.”

 

Agatha nodded, swallowing hard as she tried to steady herself. The weight of the impending conversation loomed large, but with Lilia’s unwavering support and the knowledge that Rio was coming, she felt just a little less alone.

 

 

When Rio arrived at Lilia’s house, she didn’t even bother knocking. She knew where the spare key was hidden and let herself in, her heart racing with worry. Lilia met her in the entryway, her expression calm but tinged with concern.

 

“She’s in the living room,” Lilia said softly, resting a reassuring hand on Rio’s shoulder. “Take your time with her.”

 

Rio nodded and hurried into the room. She found Agatha sitting on the couch, her posture rigid, as if she were holding herself together by sheer force of will. Her hands gripped the cold, forgotten cup of tea, and her face was drawn, eyes red and tired.

 

The sight of her like that broke something deep inside Rio, and without a word, she crossed the room, kneeling in front of Agatha. She reached for her hands, gently prying them from the mug, holding them with a tenderness that spoke volumes. “Agatha,” Rio murmured, her voice soft yet steady. “I’m here. Whatever it is, talk to me.”

 

Agatha’s lips trembled as she looked down at Rio. “I’m sorry,” she whispered. “I didn’t want to bother you. I didn’t want to… burden you with this.”

 

Rio shook her head, her gaze unwavering as she cupped Agatha’s hands in both of hers, holding them close to her chest. “Love,” she said firmly, her tone soothing yet resolute, “You are never a burden. You never have been, not to me. Whatever this is, we’ll carry it together. Let me in, Agatha. Please.”

 

Agatha hesitated, her gaze flickering to Lilia, who sat quietly in the armchair nearby. Lilia gave her a soft, encouraging nod, her presence a steady reminder that she wasn’t alone. Agatha took a shaky breath, her chest rising and falling as she began to speak.

 

For what felt like an eternity, Agatha shared the depth of her pain—of Evanora’s cruelty, the relentless emotional manipulation, and the scars that had never fully healed. She spoke of the weight of her mother’s expectations, of the fear and pain she had carried for years, of the nights spent in cupboards or the rod that had met her fingers on multiple occasions, and the complicated, tangled emotions she still wrestled with, even after Evanora’s death.

 

Throughout it all, Rio remained silent, her expression a mix of heartbreak and fierce love. She listened with a quiet intensity, her heart aching for the woman in front of her. When Agatha faltered, her voice catching on the words that were too hard to say, Rio reached out to touch her, her fingers soft on Agatha’s arm or cheek, grounding her with every gentle, tender touch.

 

“You don’t have to keep going if it’s too much,” Rio whispered when Agatha paused, her voice full of both compassion and strength. “I’m right here.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard, nodding, and though her pain was raw and heavy, she could feel the weight of it just a little less when Rio’s presence enveloped her. 

 

As the story unfolded, Agatha’s composure began to unravel. Her voice quivered, and then cracked, the weight of the words too much to bear. Tears welled up and spilled over her cheeks as she choked on the confession. “I didn’t want you to know this,” she whispered through sobs, her chest heaving. “I didn’t want you to think less of me… to be afraid of what I come from.”

 

Rio’s heart shattered at the sight, and without hesitation, she surged forward, wrapping her arms around Agatha in a fierce, protective embrace. “Agatha Harkness,” she said, her voice fierce with love, her own tears falling now, “There is nothing in this world that could ever make me think less of you. You are the strongest, most incredible woman I’ve ever known. And I love you—every single part of you.”

 

At the sound of those words, Agatha broke completely, her body shaking as she buried her face in Rio’s shoulder. The flood of emotions she’d kept locked away for so long poured out in a torrent of grief. Rio held her tightly, whispering softly into her hair, over and over, words of reassurance—you’re safe… you’re loved… you don’t have to carry this alone anymore.

 

From her spot in the armchair, Lilia watched them in quiet understanding, her heart aching for Agatha, but swelling with pride for Rio’s unwavering, unconditional support.

 

Time seemed to slow as Agatha’s sobs eventually began to subside. She pulled back slightly, her tear-streaked face lifting to meet Rio’s gaze. A faint, trembling smile played on her lips, and she whispered, “Thank you.”

 

Rio gently brushed a strand of hair from Agatha’s face, her touch soft and tender. She leaned in and kissed Agatha, her lips lingering as if to seal her promise. “My love,” Rio whispered against her lips, her voice steady with conviction. “We’ll get through this together. You, me, Nicky… and Lilia. Forever.”

 

Agatha rested her forehead against Rio’s, a deep, shaky breath escaping her. For the first time in what felt like ages, she allowed herself to simply breathe, to feel the weight lift ever so slightly, knowing that she no longer had to carry it alone.

 

 

As Agatha and Rio prepared to leave Lilia’s house, Lilia walked them to the door, her warm smile chasing away the remnants of the heaviness that had hung in the air earlier. She pulled Agatha into a tight hug first, holding her close.

 

“Agatha,” Lilia said softly, her voice full of warmth and conviction, “I want you to know something. When you made the choice to love my daughter like you do—you became my daughter, too. And I love you and I am so proud of both of you.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched as she returned the embrace, overwhelmed by the sincerity in Lilia’s words. “Thank you,” she managed, her voice thick with emotion. “I… I don’t even know what to say.”

 

“You don’t have to say anything,” Lilia said, pulling back just enough to look Agatha in the eyes. “Just remember that I’m here. For both of you. Always. If you ever need to talk, or even if you just need a mother’s presence, my door is always open.”
