Agatha nodded, her heart full. A quiet tear slid down her cheek, but this time, it was a tear of relief, of love. “I’ll remember,” she promised, her voice filled with the same sincerity that had colored Lilia’s words.

 

Then Lilia turned to Rio, pulling her into a similarly tight hug, her arms wrapping around Rio with the same warmth and protection she’d offered for years. “I love you so much, my sweet girl,” Lilia said softly, her voice tender but unwavering. “You’ve made me so proud every single day since the moment I met you. And seeing the way you love and care for Agatha? That makes me even prouder. You’ve given me more joy than I ever expected.”

 

Rio’s eyes welled with tears, and she sniffled, blinking rapidly to keep them from spilling. She hugged Lilia back just as fiercely, her voice trembling as she whispered, “I love you too, Mom. Thank you for… for everything you’ve done for me. I don’t know how I would have gotten here without you.”

 

Lilia kissed the top of Rio’s head, a gesture of reassurance, before pulling back just enough to gaze into her daughter’s eyes. The sheen of unshed tears reflected the depth of her love and pride. “Take care of each other, okay? Life isn’t always easy, but as long as you have each other, you’ve got everything you need.”

 

Agatha and Rio nodded in unison, their hands automatically finding each other as they stepped out the door.

 

“We will,” Rio said, her fingers intertwining with Agatha’s.

 

“And don’t hesitate to come back,” Lilia added with a light, knowing smile, though her eyes were soft with emotion. “Whether it’s for a talk, a hug, or just a good meal. You’re always welcome here, no matter what.”

 

Agatha turned back for a moment, offering Lilia a small but heartfelt smile. “Thank you, Lilia. For everything.”

 

Lilia waved them off with the same warmth in her smile, a promise lingering in her gaze. “You’re welcome, my dear. You’re always welcome.”

 

As Agatha and Rio stepped out the door and made their way to the car, Rio glanced over at Agatha, still holding her hand firmly. “You okay?” Rio asked gently, her voice low, though her concern was evident.

 

Agatha nodded, her gaze drifting out the window as she gathered herself. She took a steadying breath before answering, her voice calm but sincere. “I think I will be,” she replied, a slight, fragile smile curling at the corners of her lips. She turned her head slightly to look at Rio, a soft warmth in her eyes. “Thanks to you and your… Lilia.”

 

Rio grinned, the expression full of affection. “You can say ‘my mom,’ love,” she teased, her voice light yet meaningful, “especially now that she’s made it crystal clear that she’s yours too.”

 

Rio leaned over to kiss her cheek at a red light, her heart full. They might have a long journey ahead, but they had each other—and that was enough.

 

 

After the emotionally charged conversation with Lilia, Agatha and Rio made their way to Wanda’s house, the weight of the day lingering between them. The quiet was comfortable, though, a soft hum of shared understanding in the air. When they arrived, they found Nicky already dozing off in Wanda’s arms, his small face relaxed in peaceful slumber, his head nestled gently against her shoulder.

 

Agatha’s heart softened at the sight, and without a word, she crossed the room, her arms already open. With a quiet, grateful smile, Wanda carefully passed Nicky into Agatha’s embrace. Agatha cradled him with the tenderness of a mother, her heart swelling as she held him close. His tiny breaths were slow and steady, warm against her neck, as if in his sleep, he was offering her the comfort she’d been yearning for all day.

 

The drive back home was silent but serene, the gentle hum of the car and the soft murmur of the world outside filling the space. Rio’s left hand was on the wheel and the right rested on Agatha’s thigh, warm and steady, offering a silent reassurance that no words could match. They didn’t need to speak; the quiet comfort of their presence was enough. Agatha kept her gaze on the road, her mind wandering through the conversation with Lilia and the overwhelming kindness Rio had shown her.

 

For the first time in a long while, Agatha felt like she was slowly coming to terms with the weight of her past. The way Rio had supported her—no questions asked, no hesitation—was a balm to her soul. She could feel herself beginning to breathe again, a deep, cleansing breath that came from a place of acceptance. Rio understood her in ways that no one else ever had. She wasn’t just her girlfriend; she was her partner in every sense, carrying the burden of Agatha’s pain with grace and love.

 

Once at home, Agatha gently carried Nicky inside and into his room. She placed him carefully in his bed, tucking him in with the same tenderness that had become second nature to her. As she stood there for a moment, watching him sleep.

 

It wasn’t long before Rio entered the room, her presence as comforting as always. She stood quietly by the doorway, watching Agatha with a knowing smile, her gentle energy filling the space between them.

 

Agatha turned to her, her heart full, her voice soft in the stillness of the night. “We’re getting the bunny.”

 

Rio blinked, a look of surprise quickly spreading across her face. “What? Really?” Her eyes shone with excitement, and Agatha couldn’t help but smile at the unexpected joy that lit up Rio’s face.

 

Agatha leaned against the doorframe, arms crossed, savoring the moment. “Yes. I know it’s something you and Nicky have both wanted for a while, and… after everything today, I think it’s time. We’ll get the bunny.”

 

Rio’s face lit up like a child on Christmas morning, her excitement bubbling over as she rushed to Agatha and enveloped her in a tight hug. “Thank you, Agatha. Seriously, thank you. Nicky’s going to be over the moon when he hears this!”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, squeezing Rio back with equal affection. “I know he will. But don’t forget—we’re the ones who’ll be taking care of it, not just Nicky. And no turning our house into a zoo. And please, no names like ‘Fluffykins’ or ‘Bubbles,’ alright?”

 

Rio pulled back slightly, her grin widening. “I promise, no ‘Fluffykins,’ I swear. But this is going to be so much fun! I can already picture how the house is going to feel with a new little furry friend running around.”

 

Agatha smiled, her eyes twinkling with warmth as she watched Rio’s excitement. “I’m glad you’re excited. We’ll tell Nicky tomorrow, but tonight, I think we should focus on getting some rest. It’s been an emotional day for all of us, and we all need a good night’s sleep.”

 

Rio nodded, a content smile on her face. “You’re right. But this… it feels like a good start to a new chapter, doesn’t it?”

 

Agatha nodded, her heart lighter than it had been all day. “It really does. We’re building something special. For all of us.”

 

With that, they both stood for a moment, gazing at Nicky, who was peacefully asleep in his bed. And even though there was still healing to be done, Agatha felt a sense of peace wash over her, knowing they were all moving forward, together.

 

Once they settled into bed, the room dim and quiet, a gentle calm settled over them. Agatha nestled into Rio’s side, her body instinctively seeking the comfort of the woman who had become her safe harbor. The familiar warmth of Rio enveloped her, and Agatha let out a soft sigh of relief as she felt the weight of the day begin to lift. Rio wrapped her arm around Agatha, pulling her closer, their bodies aligned as their faces drew near, their breathing in sync, slow and steady, filling the quiet of the night with a peaceful rhythm.

 

Agatha, her voice soft but filled with emotion, whispered, “Thank you, Rio. For being here… for everything. I don’t know what I’d do without you.”

 

Rio smiled, her hand gently trailing across Agatha’s back. “There’s no need to thank me. I’m right here, Agatha. Always will be. This… us… it’s what we do. We’re in this together.”

 

The simplicity of Rio’s words, the certainty and unconditional love that filled them, made Agatha’s heart swell with emotion. “I’m just… so grateful. You make everything feel right, even on the hardest days. I don’t know how you do it, but you do. You just make everything feel like it’s going to be okay.”

 

Rio pressed a soft kiss to Agatha’s forehead, holding her a little tighter. “I’m yours, Agatha. You don’t ever have to carry anything alone, not with me by your side. You’re my heart, and my home.”

 

Agatha let out a contented sigh, burying her face into the crook of Rio’s neck, feeling the steady rhythm of her pulse beneath her cheek. “I love you so much. I don’t say it enough, but I do. More than I can express.”

 

Rio chuckled softly, the sound low and comforting, and Agatha’s heart melted at the sound of it. “You don’t have to say it every second, love. I know. And I love you too, more than anything, just as much as that boy in the other room. More than you could ever know.”

 

They held each other quietly for a while, the weight of their shared love making everything feel right in the world. It was in these moments, in the stillness of their connection, that Agatha found a kind of peace she had never known before.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

So, more angst for our girls I'm sorry... but of course, they make it through because they're queens and i love them.
Thank you for all the love, seriously you are so amazing!

Señor Scratchy

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

The knowledge imposes a pattern, and falsifies,

For the pattern is new in every moment

And every moment is a new and shocking

Valuation of all we have been.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

Saturday morning dawned bright and clear, the perfect day for an outing. Agatha and Rio moved through the kitchen with practiced ease, each of them immersed in the rhythm of preparing breakfast. The sound of eggs sizzling in the pan and the soft clink of utensils filled the air, creating a cozy, familiar atmosphere. Nicky, in his usual lively manner, chattered away, completely oblivious to the plan that had been set into motion for the day. He eagerly described his imagined adventures, his excitement building as he spoke.

 

Agatha glanced over at Rio, a small, amused smile tugging at her lips. Their eyes met across the counter, a shared understanding passing between them—a silent acknowledgment of the surprise they were about to spring on Nicky. They had this little secret, this small act of joy they were about to share, and it felt like the perfect way to end a week that had been full of emotion and healing.

 

Once breakfast was ready, they bundled up in coats and scarves, the crisp air outside beckoning them. Nicky, in his usual excitement, practically bounced around the kitchen as they finished tidying up, still blissfully unaware of what was coming. Agatha couldn’t help but smile as she watched him, her heart full. There was something about Nicky’s boundless energy, his unfiltered joy, that made everything feel a little brighter.

 

They made their way to the car, and today, it was Rio who took the wheel. Agatha slid into the passenger seat, a contented sigh escaping her as she settled in, the comfort of their shared space still fresh in her mind. Nicky climbed into the backseat, his little legs swinging as he buckled up, still talking nonstop about what he imagined they were going to do. But what he didn’t know was that today, he was in for a surprise.

 

“Where are we going?” Nicky asked, his bright eyes shifting between Agatha and Rio, his curiosity piqued. He was always full of questions, his mind racing with possibilities.

 

Rio shot a playful glance at Agatha, her smile wide and conspiratorial. “We’re taking a little detour today, buddy. But I think you’re going to like it,” she said, her voice light but with a hint of excitement in it.

 

Nicky tilted his head, his brow furrowing in confusion. “A detour? What’s that?”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, reaching back to ruffle his hair. “You’ll see soon enough,” she said, her tone warm, but there was a playful edge to it that made Nicky squirm with anticipation.

 

The car hummed along the road, the familiar scenery of their town giving way to something a little more out of the ordinary. Rio’s hands on the steering wheel were steady, her gaze flicking back and forth between the road and Agatha, whose eyes sparkled with the quiet joy of sharing this moment with her. For a moment, there was nothing but the peaceful hum of the car and the shared excitement between the three of them.

 

Nicky’s eyes darted back and forth between them, clearly trying to piece together what was going on. “Okay, you two are being sneaky. Tell me, tell me!” he demanded, a giggle bubbling up in his chest as he glanced between his moms.

 

Agatha exchanged a quick, knowing glance with Rio, the playful tension making the moment feel like a secret between them all.

 

“We’ll tell you when we get there,” Agatha said, her voice low and teasing, enjoying the suspense. Nicky groaned, clearly desperate for the reveal, but Agatha could tell it was only making him more excited.

 

Rio’s gaze flicked to the rearview mirror, her excitement practically bubbling over, though she kept her eyes on the road. Her smile was wide, and she couldn’t contain the thrill in her voice. “We thought it was time to add a new member to our family,” she said, her tone playful yet filled with an underlying warmth.

 

For a brief moment, Nicky furrowed his brow, trying to make sense of the hint in her words. His little mind was racing, connecting dots in his own way. Then, with a sudden gasp, his eyes widened in surprise, his voice tinged with innocent hope. “Am I getting a little sister?”

 

Rio’s eyes snapped wide, her grip tightening on the wheel as she nearly swerved, and Agatha let out a strangled breath at the question. The unexpected thought had caught them both off guard. Agatha cleared her throat, still recovering from the shock, her voice soft but firm. She sneaked a glace towards Rio, who was staring straight ahead, and Agatha couldn’t tell if she had paled or blushed. Probably both.

 

“No, sweetheart. No little sister,” she said, her tone weak from the surprise. “We were thinking more in terms of… a little furry friend.”

 

Nicky’s eyes widened. “Are we getting my bunny? Really? A bunny?!” he exclaimed, his voice a mix of disbelief and pure joy, the panic his innocent earlier question has caused completely overlooked.

 

Agatha couldn’t help but laugh softly at the sheer joy lighting up his face, deciding to table the little sister conversation for later. Much later. She turned in her seat, her heart warmed by his excitement. “We’re going to the pet shelter to look for one,” she confirmed, her voice calm but with an edge of amusement at his reaction. “But only if we find the right one,” she added, a small smile curving her lips as she glanced at Rio.

 

Nicky’s excitement was almost too much to contain, his body practically vibrating with enthusiasm. “Oh, I promise, Mama, I’ll find the best bunny ever!” he declared with such earnestness that it was impossible not to laugh. “And I’ll take care of it, and—” He paused, as if the excitement was too big for words to hold, and then finally burst out, “Thank you, thank you, thank you!”

 

Rio’s laughter joined his, now that she had recovered, a rich, soothing sound that filled the car with a sense of shared joy. Without taking her eyes off the road, she reached her hand back and patted Nicky’s knees gently. “Don’t thank us yet,” she teased, her tone lighthearted but sincere. “You’ll have a lot of responsibility with a bunny, mister.”

 

“I will!” Nicky responded with all the seriousness of a child making a grand promise. His nod was so earnest, his face so full of determination, that even Agatha couldn’t hold back a smile.

 

“We’ll see if we find the right one,” Agatha added softly, her eyes meeting Rio’s briefly, her heart full as she took in the moment. “But I think we’ll be okay. We’ll find the perfect bunny for our perfect family.”

 

As the car continued down the road, Nicky’s excited chatter filled the air, a perfect soundtrack to the journey ahead. He talked about all the ways he would take care of the bunny, from giving it food and water to making sure it had the comfiest little bed. His words spilled out so fast, full of plans and promises that were as big as his heart. And for a moment, Agatha and Rio could only listen, their hearts full of love and anticipation for the new chapter they were about to open together.

 

 

The pet shelter was a lively, bustling place, filled with the soft sounds of animals moving in their enclosures and the gentle hum of conversations. Volunteers moved about, tending to the animals and assisting families, while the air was thick with the warmth of both the shelter and the sense of purpose that came with the mission of helping these animals find homes. Nicky’s grip on Rio’s hand was firm, his small fingers wrapped around hers as they walked down the rows of enclosures. His eyes were wide with wonder, taking in every sight, every sound, and every excited animal that caught his attention.

 

The sight of so many animals, their little faces filled with longing and curiosity, tugged at Rio’s heart. She could already feel the connection forming, knowing this trip was going to mean so much more than simply getting a pet for Nicky. It was a step forward in their journey as a family, and it felt like an opportunity to share a deeper bond, one that transcended just adopting an animal.

 

The shelter was teeming with life. The soft rustle of hay in some of the cages mixed with some soft barks and purring and the faint sound of families chatting excitedly about their future pets. Nicky’s excitement was palpable, and he tugged at Rio’s hand with each step, practically bouncing with joy. He had his eyes trained on every animal they passed, and though they hadn’t even reached the rabbit section yet, his energy was like a live wire, ready to explode at any moment. Agatha, walking beside them, followed with a calm but affectionate gaze. She watched the way Nicky’s eyes lit up, her heart softened by his enthusiasm.

 

As they continued, a cheerful woman with a clipboard approached them, her warm smile instantly reassuring. She knelt slightly to meet Nicky at his level, her eyes twinkling with kindness. “Hi there! What brings you to the shelter today, little guy?” she asked, her tone friendly and welcoming.

 

Nicky beamed up at her, the excitement practically vibrating through him. “I’m getting a bunny!” he declared loudly, his voice filled with pure joy.

 

The woman laughed softly, her smile widening. “That’s so exciting! And who are you here with today?” she asked, clearly charmed by Nicky’s enthusiasm.

 

Without a moment’s hesitation, Nicky looked over at Rio and Agatha with a proud grin, his voice loud and clear. “I’m here with my moms!” he said, his words ringing out with confidence and an innocent joy that made Rio’s heart skip a beat.

 

The words hit Rio like a wave, and for a split second, the world seemed to fade away. My moms. She barely caught herself from gasping, her breath hitching in her chest as the weight of those words settled inside her. It felt new, like something raw and beautiful, the kind of moment that took your breath away. To hear Nicky say it out loud, in front of another person, filled her with an overwhelming warmth. She had always known that this was her family, that they had found something special together, but hearing it spoken so plainly felt like a seal on the bond they were all building.

 

Her heart fluttered, full of a tender love that still caught her off guard. The feeling was both powerful and overwhelming, yet it felt so undeniably right. It was the first time Nicky had said it so openly, and in the presence of strangers, no less. The joy that radiated from him made everything feel like it was falling into place.

 

The woman stood up, her smile widening even more as she looked up at Rio and Agatha. “That’s wonderful,” she said warmly. “Welcome, all of you! Let’s see if we can find the perfect bunny for your family.”

 

As the shelter manager led them deeper into the rows of animals, Agatha glanced over at Rio. She noticed the faint pink tint coloring her cheeks, and the corner of her mouth curved upward in a knowing smirk. She leaned in slightly, her voice soft but teasing. “You okay, Mom?”

 

Rio’s eyes widened for a moment, caught off guard by Agatha’s teasing. She shot her a flustered look, the heat in her cheeks deepening as she whispered back, “Stop it.” But despite the fluster, the soft, glowing smile that followed couldn’t hide the warmth she was feeling inside.

 

Hand in hand with Nicky, Rio squeezed his fingers gently, marveling at how something so small could feel so big, the butterflies still fluttering as she silently marveled at how a single word could feel like the greatest honor in the world.

 

Agatha trailed behind, her arms crossed loosely as she walked, but her eyes never left the two of them. Her gaze was warm and affectionate, a soft smile tugging at her lips as she watched Nicky’s boundless enthusiasm. The way his energy could make even the smallest thing seem like an adventure was contagious. Rio, beside him, mirrored his excitement as they ventured deeper into the shelter, each new animal discovery sparking a fresh wave of joy.

 

“Look at this one!” Nicky exclaimed, his small hands pressing eagerly against the glass of a guinea pig enclosure. The little creature inside, with its round, fuzzy body, blinked up at him, oblivious to the adoration being poured upon it.

 

Rio leaned closer, her smile widening at the sight. “It’s adorable, Nicky. You think they’re all this fuzzy?” she asked, genuinely intrigued by the tiny creature’s charm.

 

“Probably!” Nicky answered, turning back to her with his face aglow, his eyes brighter than ever. His enthusiasm was a breath of fresh air, so pure and filled with excitement.

 

They moved on, their footsteps echoing softly in the shelter, until they reached the kitten enclosures. The moment Nicky saw a tiny gray tabby pawing eagerly at the glass, his eyes went wide, and he squealed in delight. “Mom! Look!” he exclaimed, tugging at Rio’s sleeve urgently, as though he were trying to share the joy of the moment with her.

 

Rio’s heart swelled, and a gentle laugh escaped her as she looked at the little kitten. “She likes you already, doesn’t she?” Rio said softly, tapping the glass in sync with the kitten’s pawing. Her heart melted as the small creature seemed to reach out for Nicky, creating a moment of quiet, sweet connection.

 

Nicky’s eyes filled with longing as he looked up at Rio. “Can we—” he began, his voice hopeful, his fingers still pressed to the glass.

 

But Agatha, who had been watching the exchange with a fond but knowing smile, stepped forward with a raised brow. Her voice was light but carried the weight of a gentle reminder. “One pet, remember?” she said, her tone playful yet firm.

 

Nicky, momentarily caught in his excitement, glanced at Agatha and nodded, his face reddening a little with a sheepish smile. “Right. Just one.” His voice had a hint of both reluctance and understanding, realizing the importance of the decision. Though his heart still ached for that adorable kitten, he respected the rule Agatha had set.

 

Rio chuckled, giving Nicky a reassuring squeeze. “We’ll find the perfect one, don’t worry,” she said, her voice soft and encouraging. 

 

They moved through the shelter at a leisurely pace, pausing by each enclosure as they explored. Rio gasped in delight over the kittens, her voice soft and full of admiration, her hands pressed to the glass as she cooed at the tiny furballs. She smiled at the puppies, too, her heart melting at their puppy-dog eyes and clumsy, playful antics. Even the birds caught her attention, their vibrant colors and fluttering wings captivating her for a moment. Nicky being the the enthusiastic mimic he was, mirrored her gestures, exaggerating her expressions, which had Agatha stifling a laugh. His energy was infectious, and Rio couldn’t help but share in his joy.

 

By the time they reached the rabbit section, their excitement was palpable. Rio practically bounced on her feet, eyes wide with wonder as she pointed at a small grey bunny with perky ears. “Oh, look at this one!” she exclaimed, her voice filled with awe.

 

Nicky, unable to contain himself, leaned forward, his face pressed against the glass. “It’s so cute!” he whispered, his voice barely audible but full of affection.

 

Agatha stood beside them, hands on her hips as she watched her two favorite people fawn over the animals. “You two are going to fall for every single rabbit, aren’t you?”

 

Rio turned her face up to her, eyes sparkling. “Can you blame us?” she teased.

 

Agatha let out a soft sigh, but the smile tugging at her lips betrayed her true feelings. She crouched down beside them, her gaze softening as she took in the sight of the grey bunny. “It is cute,” she admitted begrudgingly, her words filled with reluctant affection, which made Nicky gasp dramatically.

 

“You like it too, Mama?” Nicky asked, his eyes widening with a mixture of surprise and excitement as he turned to look up at Agatha, his voice a pitch higher with the thrill of the moment.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, her hand brushing against his back. “I like seeing you happy,” she said simply.

 

Rio’s heart swelled, and she couldn’t resist leaning into Agatha. “You’re softening,” she teased.

 

“Don’t push your luck,” Agatha replied with a mock glare, but her tone was warm.

 

As Nicky continued to press his nose to the glass, Rio and Agatha exchanged a glance, their silent conversation clear: this was going to be a moment to remember.

 

Agatha straightened up from where she had been leaning against the enclosure, her hands clasped firmly behind her back as she surveyed the scene before her. Rio and Nicky were darting between rabbit pens with the energy of two people who had never seen a more adorable creature in their lives, their enthusiasm practically vibrating the air around them. Their joy was palpable, infectious—and admittedly, completely adorable. But as they bounced from one enclosure to the next, it was also starting to feel a little like chaos.

 

She watched them with a mixture of affection and bemusement. She couldn’t help but marvel at how much energy they both had, how their shared excitement lit up the room, but it was quickly getting out of hand. Clearing her throat dramatically, she took a step forward, her voice carrying with teasing authority.

 

“Alright, you two,” Agatha called, raising an eyebrow in mock seriousness. “Let me remind you that we are here for one rabbit. One. Not a rabbit, two kittens, and a guinea pig. I’m talking to you, Rio.”

 

Rio turned from where she had been crouched by one of the pens, her face the picture of exaggerated innocence. “I wasn’t saying we should get the guinea pig,” she said, her voice light and airy. “I was just—”

 

“—getting carried away,” Agatha finished for her, folding her arms and tilting her head slightly, her gaze pointed but affectionate. “You do realize you’re supposed to be the adult in this equation, don’t you, dear?”

 

Rio’s mouth fell open, a theatrical gasp escaping her as she pointed an accusing finger at Nicky, who was still hopping eagerly between the enclosures. “He started it!” she protested, a playful grin tugging at her lips.

 

“Did not!” Nicky interjected with a giggle, running over to another pen with a bounce in his step. “Mom! Come look at this one!” he called, his eyes wide with wonder.

 

Rio gave Agatha a look of mock exasperation, holding her hands up. “See? It’s not just me.”

 

Agatha sighed, though a smile tugged at her lips despite her best effort to remain firm. Pinching the bridge of her nose in mock frustration, she muttered loud enough for Rio to hear, “This is why I’m the voice of reason in this family.”

 

“And we love you for it,” Rio said brightly, flashing her a grin before turning back to Nicky, her excitement undeterred.

 

Shaking her head but unable to suppress a smile, Agatha trailed after them. She wasn’t even sure if they were picking a rabbit anymore or just admiring each and every one they passed. And yet, the sight of their excitement and shared joy filled her chest with warmth.

 

Even if they were terrible at sticking to plans.

 

As they moved through the rows of rabbit enclosures, Nicky and Rio’s chatter filled the air, their excitement bubbling over. Agatha trailed behind, content to watch them bond as they cooed at the animals. She was ready to step in when needed—whether to reel them in or facilitate their inevitable decision-making struggles.

 

But then, as they neared a corner pen, something unexpected happened. A small, fluffy bunny with velvety white fur and beige spots hopped forward with surprising enthusiasm. It paused right at the edge of its enclosure, its floppy ears twitching as it tilted its head up, seemingly studying them—or rather, studying Agatha.

 

Agatha blinked, surprised by the bunny’s sudden approach. “Well, hello there,” she murmured, crouching down without thinking.

 

Rio and Nicky turned at the sound of Agatha’s voice, their attention immediately drawn to the little bunny. Nicky’s eyes widened in astonishment. “Mama, it likes you!” he gasped, his voice filled with wonder.

 

The bunny twitched its nose, then stretched up on its hind legs, as though it was trying to reach out to her. Agatha slowly extended her hand, and the bunny nuzzled her fingers gently through the bars of the pen, its soft fur brushing against her skin.

 

Rio chuckled, kneeling beside Agatha. “Well, isn’t this a twist? Looks like the bunny picked you.”

 

Agatha shot her a dry look, though it was softened by a small smile as she turned back to the bunny, whose calm gaze seemed to hold a kind of quiet understanding. She couldn’t deny the strange, unexpected sense of connection she felt with the little creature. “I suppose we don’t have much of a choice now, do we?”

 

Nicky, clearly delighted, knelt on Agatha’s other side, his eyes wide and sparkling with hope. “Can we get this one? Please? I think it’s perfect!” he pleaded, his voice practically dancing with excitement.

 

Agatha sighed, but there was no real exasperation in it—just a quiet acceptance of the inevitable. “I have a feeling saying no would make me the villain in this story,” she said, raising an eyebrow.

 

“Absolutely,” Rio teased, nudging Agatha’s shoulder with a grin.

 

Agatha stroked the bunny gently through the bars, her expression softening as she watched it nuzzle her hand again. “Alright then,” she said, her voice quiet and almost affectionate. “It looks like we’ve found our bunny.”

 

Nicky threw his arms around her in delight, and Rio leaned into her with a radiant grin. Even as Agatha straightened up to speak with the shelter staff about finalizing the adoption, she could feel the bunny’s calm, curious gaze following her every move, as if silently acknowledging the new bond they had formed. The moment felt significant, a quiet affirmation that sometimes, the perfect connection came when least expected.

 

At the counter, the shelter manager crouched down to Nicky’s level, her warm smile radiating kindness as she spoke. “Alright, young man,” she said, gesturing toward the bunny now nestled comfortably in a carrier. “This little one’s going to need a few things to settle into his new home.”

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled with eager curiosity, and he leaned forward, gripping the edge of the counter with both hands. “What does the bunny need?” he asked, his voice filled with a seriousness that made both Agatha and Rio exchange amused but proud glances.

 

“First,” the manager said, holding up a checklist, “you’ll need a cozy enclosure—something safe and secure where your bunny can sleep and relax. It should be big enough for her to hop around comfortably. And bedding, of course! Soft bedding will make him feel at ease.”

 

Nicky nodded again, his brow furrowing in concentration as if committing the list to memory. “Okay, a big home and soft stuff,” he echoed.

 

Rio grinned, leaning over the counter. “Don’t worry, bud. We’ll make sure it’s the comfiest bunny palace ever,” she teased, ruffling Nicky’s hair.

 

The manager chuckled and continued, “Next, your bunny will need fresh hay every day. It’s the main part of its diet, along with some leafy greens and special pellets. Oh, and always fresh water—very important.”

 

Nicky glanced back at the carrier. “I’ll make sure you have lots of yummy food, bunny,” he whispered.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, chiming in with mock seriousness, “And who’s going to make sure you remember all this, hm?”

 

Nicky grinned sheepishly. “You and Rio will help, right?”

 

Rio put a hand to her chest in mock offense. “Look at you, already delegating responsibility.”

 

The manager smiled, clearly charmed by the dynamic. “There’s also grooming to think about—bunnies like to keep clean, but brushing them occasionally helps. And toys! They love to chew and play, so toys are great for keeping them entertained.”

 

Nicky was wide-eyed. “Toys? Like mine but for bunnies? That’s so cool!”

 

“Very cool,” Rio agreed, nudging Nicky with her elbow. “I think we should pick some out together, huh?”

 

As they moved toward the shelves to gather the supplies, Agatha lingered behind for a moment with the manager. “Thank you for taking the time to explain all this,” she said, her voice soft but sincere.

 

The manager waved a hand. “Of course. It’s clear you all care a lot about this bunny—and about each other. It’s going to be a very lucky rabbit.”

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a small, genuine smile. “Thank you. That means a lot.”

 

By the time they left the store, their car was loaded with a new enclosure, bedding, hay, pellets, toys, and a few extra treats. Nicky was practically vibrating with excitement, and even Rio looked as giddy as a child. The carrier was safely put in the backseat, next to Nicky and he couldn’t stop leaning over to look at it.

 

Agatha, watching them from the driver’s seat as they discussed names for their new family member, felt a warmth bloom in her chest. Maybe she hadn’t been completely sold on the idea at first, but seeing the joy it brought to her family, she knew they had made the right decision.

 

 

At home, the three of them set to work creating a cozy space for their newest family member. The enclosure was assembled in a sunny corner of the living room, complete with fresh bedding, a little hideaway house, and a bowl of water and pellets. Nicky carefully scattered hay in the enclosure as Rio adjusted the placement of a chew toy shaped like a carrot.

 

“Okay, bunny,” Rio said as she placed the carrier on the floor and gently opened it, “welcome to your new palace.”

 

The bunny hopped out slowly, twitching its nose as it took in the surroundings. Its soft fur practically shimmered in the light, and it moved with a curious grace. Nicky clapped his hands in delight, sitting cross-legged on the floor to watch. “He’s exploring!” he whispered.

 

As the bunny ventured further into its new home, Rio glanced nervously at her array of plants scattered throughout the room. She leaned toward Agatha and muttered, “What if he decides my plants are his new snack bar?”

 

Agatha, already amused, raised an eyebrow. “You’ll just have to share custody of your precious greenery.”

 

Rio shot her a faux-glare, but her attention quickly shifted when the bunny sniffed at the base of Fernando, the potted fern. She held her breath, watching as the little creature gave a twitch of its nose and then, almost dismissively, hopped in the opposite direction.

 

“Hah!” Agatha smirked, folding her arms. “Clearly, we’ve adopted a very intelligent bunny. He already knows what’s off-limits.”

 

Rio let out a relieved laugh. “Smart and polite. We really hit the jackpot.”

 

Nicky giggled. “He’s the best bunny ever!”

 

They spent the next hour watching the bunny get comfortable in its new environment. It hopped in and out of its little hideaway, nibbled contentedly on a piece of hay, and even flopped onto its side in a gesture of complete relaxation. Nicky was fascinated by every movement, his laughter bubbling up every time the bunny twitched its ears or wiggled its nose.

 

Agatha, sitting on the couch with a cup of tea, observed the scene with quiet contentment. She watched as Rio joined Nicky on the floor, showing him how to gently pet the bunny. The sight of her partner and son bonding with their new pet filled her heart with a warmth she hadn’t expected.

 

When the bunny eventually curled up in its hideaway for a nap, Nicky sat back with a satisfied sigh. “I think he likes it here.”

 

Agatha reached over to ruffle his hair. “I think you’re right.”

 

Rio glanced at her plants one more time, then at the peacefully sleeping bunny. She shook her head with a grin. “Alright, and I guess I don’t need to worry about bunny teeth in my monstera after all.”

 

Agatha smirked. “Told you he’s smart.”

 

Rio leaned back against the couch, her hands settling on Agatha’s shoulders from behind as she leaned over to look at Agatha upside down. “Yeah, well, he’s part of the family now. Of course, he’s smart.”

 

 

An hour later, the three of them sat around the living room, brainstorming names for the bunny as it snoozed peacefully in its new hideaway. Nicky was brimming with ideas, his excitement bubbling over as he rattled off suggestions.

 

“How about Mr. Fluffytail?” Nicky suggested, his eyes wide with anticipation.

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, her lips curling into an amused smirk. “A bit on the nose, don’t you think?”

 

“Okay, okay, what about… Sir Hopsalot?”

 

Agatha let out a soft laugh, shaking her head. “I’m not addressing a rabbit as ‘Sir’ every time we call for him.”

 

Rio, watching the back-and-forth with a grin, decided to jump in. “Hey, I think it’s cute. Sir Hopsalot sounds like he has class.”

 

Nicky beamed. “Right? Classy bunny!”

 

Agatha groaned dramatically, placing a hand on her forehead. “I cannot believe I’m outnumbered on this.”

 

“Alright, fine, what about… Captain Nibbles?” Nicky offered next, practically bouncing in place.

 

“Absolutely not,” Agatha deadpanned, but her lips twitched, betraying her amusement. “We’re not giving him a title of command.”

 

Rio chuckled, nudging Agatha lightly with her elbow. “Oh, come on, Agatha. Let the kid have fun. Captain Nibbles is… imaginative.”

 

“Ridiculous, you mean,” Agatha replied, her tone teasing.

 

Nicky leaned over, now completely invested in winning this game. “Okay, what if we call him… Carrot Crusher?”

 

Agatha blinked at him, then turned to Rio, exasperation in her expression but a twinkle in her eye. “Please tell me you’re not endorsing this.”

 

Rio, trying and failing to stifle a laugh, shrugged. “I mean, he does eat carrots. It’s accurate.”

 

Nicky’s laughter echoed through the room, and Agatha let out a sigh of mock defeat. “You two are going to name this bunny something absurd, aren’t you?”

 

“Maybe,” Rio said with a mischievous smile. “But only because you’re making it so fun to tease you about it.”

 

“Fine,” Agatha said, folding her arms but unable to suppress her own laughter. “But if we’re going to be absurd, I demand veto power. There’s no way I’m calling him ‘Carrot Crusher’.”

 

Nicky, now giggling uncontrollably, threw his arms up before reaching for his little white board that had been set in the living room for the occasion. “Okay, back to the drawing board!”

 

As the banter continued, the bunny remained blissfully unaware, now curled up in its hideaway, scratching the walls of his little bunny hut, already loved beyond measure.

 

After what felt like an eternity of playful debates and increasingly silly suggestions, Nicky suddenly gasped, his face lighting up as if struck by a brilliant idea. He leaned over to Rio, cupping his hands around his mouth to whisper, his tone conspiratorial.

 

“Rio, how do you say ‘Sir’ in Spanish?”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, amused by his secretive demeanor. “We say ‘Señor,’” she whispered back with a grin.

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled with excitement. “Perfect,” he declared, before straightening up and announcing proudly, “I think we should call the bunny ‘Señor Scratchy!’”

 

Rio tilted her head, pretending to give the suggestion serious thought. “Señor Scratchy?” she repeated. “That’s… actually kind of adorable. But why ‘Señor Scratchy’?”

 

Nicky grinned, his pride evident. “Well, your name is Spanish, right, Rio? So ‘Señor’ makes sense!” He paused, leaning closer to whisper again, “And this way, Mama won’t know that we’re still calling him ‘sir.’”

 

Rio burst out laughing, shaking her head. “Alright, kiddo, that can be our little secret,” she said, her tone just as low. But she was perfectly aware that Agatha, sitting just a few feet away, could hear every word—and knew enough Spanish to understand the joke.

 

Nicky continued his explanation. “And… and Mama said that when I was little, I loved scratchy sounds from my sneakers! Remember, Mama? You said it was my nickname!”

 

Agatha froze for a moment, her face softening as she smiled, the memory washing over her. “I did call you Scratchy,” she said, her voice laced with warmth. “You were obsessed with the velcro on your shoes. You’d sit for hours opening and closing it, just to hear the sound.”

 

Nicky grinned proudly and turned back to the bunny. “And look! He is already scratching his house! So it’s perfect! Señor Scratchy!”

 

Rio laughed, her heart melting. “That’s honestly so clever, Nicky. I love it.”

 

Agatha nodded, her smirk giving way to a genuine smile. “Alright, I admit it. That’s a great name. Good job, buddy.”

 

Nicky clapped his hands together, thrilled at the unanimous approval. “Yay! Señor Scratchy it is!”

 

Rio crouched down to gently pet the bunny, who twitched his nose in response. “Welcome home, Señor Scratchy. You’ve officially joined the family.”

 

Agatha leaned back into the couch, watching her partner and son with a quiet sense of pride and contentment. “Well, Señor Scratchy,” she said dryly, “I hope you know you’ve got some very persistent people looking out for you.”

 

Nicky giggled and snuggled into Agatha’s side. “And the best moms ever.”

 

At that, Rio felt a familiar flutter in her chest. Their little family—and their new furry addition—felt just right.

 

 

As the hours passed, Señor Scratchy settled into his new home. His little bunny house was in a cozy corner of the living room, but wherever Agatha went, he was sure to follow. He’d hop up to her feet, nudge at her legs with his tiny nose, or even curl up on the couch beside her if she was sitting down.

 

At first, Agatha tried to maintain an air of indifference about all the attention she was getting from the bunny. She’d playfully push him away, making exaggerated noises about how he was a “spoiled little bunny” and “way too demanding.” But despite her attempts at feigned annoyance, it didn’t take long for her to fall completely under his spell. He had a way of looking at her with those big, innocent eyes, tilting his head as if he was the most endearing creature on the planet. 

Soon enough though, she was petting him and giving him soft belly rubs, allowing him to settle comfortably in her lap as she read or worked on her papers.

 

Rio, who had been watching all of this from the doorway with a teasing grin, couldn’t resist making a comment. “Uh-oh, darling,” she said, her voice full of playful mischief, “I think Señor Scratchy’s going to replace me.”

 

Agatha shot Rio a sly look, one eyebrow cocked, as she gently scratched the bunny’s head. “Oh yes, darling, you’ll have to fight for your spot in my bed now,” she teased, her fingers tracing patterns in the soft fur. “I didn’t realize he was so needy.”

 

Nicky, who had been gleefully observing the exchange, jumped in with a dramatic gasp. “Are you jealous, Mom? Señor Scratchy loves Mama more than you and me!” He giggled at his own playful accusation, his eyes shining with amusement.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, gently nudging the bunny away to give Nicky a hug. “Don’t be silly. You’re my number one,” she said, pulling him close. But as she glanced down at the bunny, she couldn’t suppress a smile. “But it looks like we’ve got competition for my attention now, huh?”

 

Rio raised an eyebrow and grinned. “Oh I’m definitely jealous. I can already see it. Señor Scratchy’s stealing your heart.”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes, but the warmth in her expression was undeniable. “Fine. Maybe just a little. He’s awfully cute,” she admitted, glancing down at the bunny, who was now nestled comfortably in her lap again. “But you,” she added with a teasing wink towards Rio, “are still my favorite.”

 

Rio smiled and leaned in to kiss Agatha’s cheek, her heart swelling. “I’m glad I’m not being replaced.”

 

Agatha’s heart fluttered, and she pulled Rio closer for a soft kiss. “You’re the love of my life,” she whispered. “No bunny could ever replace you.”

 

“Eww, you’re gross” They heard from the side, where Nicky was scrunching his little nose, in a very good imitation of the bunny now curled up on his lap. But, still beaming with joy from the whole situation, he added, “I’m just glad I have the best moms, and Señor Scratchy too!”

 

It felt like the perfect moment—quiet, content, and full of love. The trio—along with their new bunny companion—had officially become a little family. And even though it might get a bit chaotic with their new furry friend, Agatha knew, deep down, that nothing could change the bond they shared.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

The king has arrived.

Also, writing the tilde on Señor every time is such a pain haha. I’m not sure if it’s just an issue with AZERTY keyboards, but oh well—small price to pay!

As always, comments are my greatest gift!

Date Night

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Sudden in a shaft of sunlight

Even while the dust moves

There rises the hidden laughter

Of children in the foliage

Quick now, here, now, always—

Ridiculous the waste sad time

Stretching before and after.

 

                  (T.S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

Friday arrived with a buzz of anticipation that seemed to ripple through the house. Agatha and Rio had been looking forward to their first proper date night since bringing Señor Scratchy home for days now. Between work, Nicky’s endless energy, and the process of settling into their dynamic as a family, moments just for the two of them had become rare. Tonight, though, was theirs, and both were determined to make it special.

 

Agatha, ever meticulous, had claimed the bathroom first, locking the door with a determined air. She took her time, savoring the quiet. The mirror fogged slightly as she carefully applied her makeup—subtle yet refined, with smoky eyes that added a touch of drama. She spent extra minutes taming her long, dark brown hair, sweeping it into a sleek low bun that accentuated her sharp cheekbones. Sliding into a fitted black dress that clung perfectly to her elegant figure, she added gold jewelry: a simple necklace, a delicate bracelet, and earrings that shimmered faintly under the light. The final touch was her favorite pair of black heels, polished to perfection. Giving herself one last appraising glance in the mirror, she allowed a small, confident smile. “Good enough to make her jaw drop,” she murmured to herself with a chuckle.

 

Meanwhile, Rio was in the bedroom, a storm of movement and energy as she rifled through her side of the closet. Clothes were draped across the bed, each rejected outfit a step closer to the perfect one. Finally, her fingers landed on a classy emerald green jumpsuit with a cinched waist and a high neckline that elegantly bared her shoulders. “Perfect,” she whispered, holding it up. The color brought out the warmth of her skin and the dark shiny undertones in her hair.

 

Her hair was styled loosely, soft waves falling to frame her face, and her makeup was bolder than usual—winged eyeliner, a touch of gold shimmer on her lids, and a deep berry lip color that added just the right amount of flair. She finished the look with statement earrings, geometric and gold, that swung gently as she moved. A pair of sleek black heels completed the ensemble, and as Rio caught her reflection in the full-length mirror, she struck a pose. “Looking sharp, Vidal,” she quipped to herself, satisfied with how her outfit accentuated her figure.

 

Just as Rio was spritzing on a light floral perfume, the soft scent filling the room, Agatha emerged from the bathroom and stepped into the bedroom. The moment her eyes landed on Rio, she froze, caught in the breathtaking sight of her. Rio was now adjusting one of her earrings in front of the mirror, her movements graceful, but it was the way the light caught the soft contours of her figure that took Agatha’s breath away. The reflection in the mirror barely registered—what mattered was the woman in front of her.

 

“Wow,” Agatha murmured, her voice quiet but thick with admiration, as though she couldn’t quite grasp the words to describe the feeling surging inside her.

 

Rio, hearing the soft exhale of wonder in Agatha’s voice, turned toward her. Her eyes widened, her mouth parting slightly in surprise. Her gaze softened as it met Agatha’s, a swell of emotion rising in her chest. “You look…” Rio trailed off, unable to find the right words at first. She swallowed hard, her voice steadying as she continued, “You’re breathtaking.”

 

The raw sincerity in Rio’s voice tugged at Agatha’s heart, and she took a small step forward, her usual confidence replaced with something warmer, more vulnerable. A smirk tugged at the corner of her lips. “You’re one to talk,” she said, her eyes raking over Rio’s ensemble. “That outfit… My God, Rio. You’re going to make it impossible to focus on anything else tonight.”

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound a little nervous, a little shy under the intensity of Agatha’s gaze. She glanced down at herself, her cheeks flushing ever so slightly. “You’re going to make me blush before we even leave the house,” she said, her voice carrying the quiet thrill of being so thoroughly admired.

 

Agatha’s expression softened, the teasing smirk fading into something more tender as she closed the distance between them. Her hands found Rio’s waist, the touch light but firm, grounding them in the moment. Her voice dropped into a low, husky whisper. “Good,” she murmured, leaning in just a fraction closer. “I like when you blush.”

 

Rio’s breath caught in her chest, her heart fluttering. She leaned into Agatha’s touch, her arms slipping up to rest loosely around Agatha’s neck, as though drawn to her gravity. “How do you do this to me every time?” she asked, her voice soft but full of wonder. “Every time I see you, it’s like falling all over again.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, her lips parting slightly as the weight of Rio’s words sank in. She closed the remaining gap between them, her forehead pressing gently against Rio’s, her hands drifting up to cup Rio’s face. “Maybe because I feel the same way,” Agatha confessed, her voice trembling ever so slightly with the depth of the emotion she was letting out. “Every time, Rio. It’s always like falling in love all over again.”

 

For a long moment, neither of them spoke. The world outside their little bubble seemed to pause, leaving only the sound of their breathing and the steady thrum of their hearts. In that stillness, Agatha saw Rio, truly saw her—the woman who had become her home, her heartbeat. And Rio saw the same in Agatha. The quiet acknowledgment that tonight, and every night, they were always falling deeper into each other.

 

The sound of Nicky’s laughter drifted up from downstairs, a sound that pulled Agatha and Rio back to reality. They had set up a cartoon for him to enjoy while they finished getting ready for their much-needed night out, and now, hearing his joy-filled giggles, it was a reminder of the world they had temporarily set aside for a little while.

 

Rio pulled back slightly, her smile widening as she caught Agatha’s gaze. “We should probably go before I decide I don’t want to share you with the world tonight,” she said, her voice teasing but soft.

 

Agatha chuckled, her expression softening with affection as she stepped back reluctantly, her fingers lingering on Rio’s for just a moment longer. “Good idea. Let’s go before I change my mind about leaving the house at all,” she agreed, her voice tinged with humor but also a bit of that all-consuming warmth she felt whenever she was with Rio.

 

Hand in hand, they descended the stairs, their footsteps light as they found Nicky sprawled out on the couch, his wide-eyed attention fixed on the cartoon playing before him. Señor Scratchy was curled up contentedly on Nicky’s chest, his little nose twitching in his sleep.

 

The sight of the two of them together—Nicky and the bunny, so peaceful in their little bubble—stirred something soft and tender in Agatha’s chest.

 

As they made their way into the living room, Rio couldn’t help but smile at the picture they made, before leaning down to give Nicky a quick kiss on the forehead. “Having fun, kiddo?” she asked gently.

 

Nicky’s eyes flickered up from the TV, his face lighting up instantly. “I’m having the best time!” he declared with the enthusiasm only a child could muster. “And Señor Scratchy’s so comfy. He likes cartoons, too!” He gave the bunny a little pat, causing the small creature to stir but not quite wake up.

 

Agatha and Rio exchanged a quiet, knowing glance. They had arranged for Alice and Jen to babysit Nicky, a decision that had thrilled him to no end. He’d been counting down the minutes all day, eager for the promise of fun with the two women who had a special way of making every moment feel like an adventure.

 

“They’re so much fun!” Nicky had squealed earlier that day when Rio told him about the babysitting plan. “They play all the games!”

 

Agatha had arched a brow at that, her lips quirking into a playful smirk. “Don’t get too excited, little man. Remember, they’re in charge tonight,” she had warned, the words light-hearted but with a knowing edge.

 

But Nicky hadn’t even blinked at the reminder. He had practically vibrated with excitement at the idea of Alice and Jen’s babysitting skills. In the end, nothing could dampen his enthusiasm. And when the doorbell rang, signaling their arrival, Nicky practically exploded from the couch.

 

“It’s Alice and Jen!” he squealed, his small frame shooting up from the couch like a rocket. He bolted toward the door, throwing it open with the energy of a child on Christmas morning.

 

Alice was the first to step through the door, her energy immediately filling the space as she carried a well-packed backpack brimming with games, snacks, and the promise of fun. “Wow, you two look amazing,” she said, her eyes taking in Rio and Agatha’s polished appearances. She turned to Nicky with a grin. “Ready for an epic night, kiddo?” she asked, crouching down to meet his eye level.

 

“Yeah!” Nicky cheered enthusiastically, throwing his arms around Alice’s neck in a spontaneous hug, the sheer joy on his face contagious.

 

Jen followed right behind Alice, effortlessly balancing a guitar case in one hand and a tray of freshly baked cookies in the other. She made a grand show of presenting the tray, holding it out with a flourish. “We come bearing gifts,” she said dramatically, eyes twinkling with mischief.

 

“Cookies?” Rio asked, raising a brow.

 

“For after dinner,” Jen said, giving her a pointed look. “We’re fun, but we’re responsible fun.”

 

“Debatable,” Agatha muttered, though her lips twitched into a smile.

 

Jen paid her no mind and continued. “Thought I might play a song or two if that’s cool with you, boss.” She winked at Nicky, who beamed at being called “boss.”

 

Agatha and Rio exchanged a look—half amused, half resigned.

 

“You two realize you’re supposed to babysit, not throw a party, right?” Agatha teased, folding her arms but unable to suppress a smile.

 

“Define ‘party,’” Jen shot back, grinning.

 

“Alright, alright,” Rio interjected, placing a hand on Agatha’s shoulder to steer her toward the door. “Nicky’s in good hands. Let’s go before they recruit him into the band or something.”

 

As Agatha slipped on her coat, Nicky ran up and hugged both his moms tightly. “Have fun on your date!” he chirped.

 

“We will,” Rio promised, bending down to kiss his cheek. “You be good, okay?”

 

“I’m always good,” Nicky said with a cheeky grin, making them laugh.

 

“Alright, Alice, Jen,” Agatha said, her voice playful but carrying an unmistakable edge of mock sternness as they stepped out the door. “Don’t let him stay up too late, and absolutely no drumming on the walls this time. I mean it.”

 

“No promises!” Alice replied with a mischievous grin, already rubbing her hands together in glee as if plotting some future chaos.

 

Rio stepped a little closer to Alice, lowering her voice just enough for the moment to feel more intimate. “Thanks again for doing this. He’s been looking forward to it all week, you know?”

 

“No problem at all,” Alice said, waving her off as though it was no big deal. “You two deserve a break, seriously. And Nicky’s a blast—he’s the best.” She gave Nicky a quick wave, and he grinned back at her, already pulling out a board game from his pile of toys.

 

Agatha shot the duo a mock-stern look, her arms crossed, her expression balancing somewhere between warning and fondness. “I can’t stress this enough: no drumming on the furniture, no teaching him any questionable song lyrics, and bedtime is eight-thirty. Got it?”

 

“Got it,” Alice said with a wink, clearly unconcerned about the strict bedtime rule.

 

“Totally,” Jen added with a smirk that suggested some of those rules might get bent, or at the very least, creatively interpreted.

 

Agatha sighed with mock exasperation but couldn’t suppress a smile. “Alright, let’s go before I change my mind and decide to stay home to supervise instead.”

 

Rio chuckled softly, gently nudging Agatha toward the door. “I’m sure Nicky will be just fine. Now let’s go or we’ll be late.”

 

“Bye, Nicky!” Rio called as they moved toward the door, blowing him an exaggerated kiss.

 

“Bye, Moms!” Nicky shouted back, his attention already fully absorbed in whatever game he was setting up with Alice, his excitement bubbling over.

 

As Agatha closed the door behind them, she paused for a moment, glancing back at the house. “We’re definitely coming back to chaos, aren’t we?” she said, the affectionate humor in her voice unmistakable.

 

Rio looped her arm through Agatha’s, her playful grin matching the spark in her eyes. “Probably. But at least he’ll have a great time. And so will we.”

 

As they walked out the door, the cool night air wrapping around them, Agatha tightened her grip on Rio’s hand. “Ready for a night of making everyone else jealous of us?” she teased.

 

Rio laughed, leaning closer to Agatha, her own voice full of anticipation. “Always. No one else stands a chance tonight,” she said with a wink.

 

 

The restaurant was dimly lit and intimate, the perfect setting for Rio and Agatha to reconnect away from the bustle of their daily lives. They sat at a secluded corner table by the window, where snowflakes floated lazily down outside, blanketing the world in a soft, quiet glow that mirrored the peacefulness inside. The world beyond felt distant, leaving only the two of them in this moment.

Candles flickered between them, casting a soft glow on their faces.

 

“This place is beautiful,” Rio said, looking around. “You always pick the best spots.”

 

“I like to keep you impressed,” Agatha replied with a wink, earning a laugh from Rio.

 

Rio chuckled softly, the sound full of affection. “You succeed,” she said, her gaze lingering on Agatha, who could never be anything but captivating in every way.

 

The evening unfolded like a slow dance—perfectly paced and comfortably familiar. They started with appetizers, their plates arriving like small works of art: delicate seared scallops nestled beside small portions of artisanal bread and creamy whipped butter, and the conversation flowed just as easily, moving from lighthearted chatter about Nicky’s latest antics to deeper musings on how much their lives had changed since their paths first crossed.

 

“You know,” Rio began, her voice thoughtful as she swirled the wine in her glass, “do you ever think about how different everything could’ve been?”

 

Agatha’s expression softened, and for a brief moment, she considered the weight of the question. “Sometimes,” she admitted, her voice gentle, almost nostalgic. “But then I look at you, and I know this is exactly where I’m supposed to be. Right here. With you. With us.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled, and she reached for Agatha’s hand across the table. “Me too. Every day.”

 

Their main courses arrived, and the rhythm of the evening continued effortlessly. Rio’s mushroom risotto was creamy and rich, while Agatha’s white fish, delicate and perfectly cooked, was accompanied by roasted vegetables that melted in the mouth. They traded bites, savoring each other’s choices with smiles that spoke volumes. 

 

When dessert came—a molten chocolate cake with vanilla ice cream—they shared that too, Rio feeding Agatha a spoonful. Agatha caught her wrist playfully, kissing the back of her hand.

 

“You’re being awfully charming tonight,” Rio teased, though her cheeks were flushed.

 

“Can you blame me?” Agatha countered, her smirk warm. “You’re stunning.”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at the genuine admiration in Agatha’s eyes, the sincerity of her words. She smiled softly, feeling more in love than ever before. 

 

They sipped on more wine, sharing stories, laughter, and occasional quiet moments where they simply gazed at one another.

 

“So, Señor Scratchy,” Rio started with a smirk, her eyes sparkling, “think he’s going to learn to open cabinets soon?”

 

Agatha rolled her eyes with exaggerated exasperation, though the corner of her lips betrayed her amusement. “If he does, he can start paying rent,” she said, her voice dripping with mock seriousness.

 

Rio laughed, her warm, melodic tone filling the small space. “Don’t act like you don’t already adore him.”

 

“Maybe I do,” Agatha admitted, her voice softening. “But only because he reminds me of a certain someone who made herself at home in my life and refused to leave.”

 

Rio tilted her head, her smile turning tender. “I’ll take that as a compliment.”

 

“It was meant as one,” Agatha said, reaching across the table to take her hand.

 

After dinner, they decided to take a walk despite the cold. The streets were quiet, save for the soft crunch of snow under their shoes. The trees along the sidewalk were adorned with delicate fairy lights, casting a soft, magical glow that seemed to turn the night into something out of a dream.

 

Rio looped her arm through Agatha’s, leaning in just a little closer. “This feels like one of those cheesy holiday movies,” she said with a playful grin, her breath visible in the crisp air.

 

“Except this isn’t scripted,” Agatha murmured, looking down at her with a fond smile. “This is real.” She squeezed Rio’s arm gently, as though to remind her that the magic of the moment was something they had created together, without the need for any camera or director.

 

They walked hand in hand, their laughter mingling with the crisp winter air, until the cold became too much. Rio shivered, and Agatha immediately wrapped her scarf around Rio’s neck, tucking it in securely.

 

“Agatha, you’ll freeze,” Rio protested.

 

“I’ll be fine,” Agatha said, brushing off her concern.

 

Rio didn’t let it go, though. She tucked both of Agatha’s hands into her own coat pockets, pulling her close for warmth. “Let’s get to the car,” she said with a laugh, pressing a kiss to Agatha’s cheek. “Before we both turn into popsicles.”

 

Once inside, the car’s heater hummed to life, and they sat for a moment, soaking in the warmth. Agatha glanced at Rio, her gaze lingering a little longer than usual. There was something in the softness of her expression that made Rio pause, her heart skipping a beat at the intensity of the look.

 

“What?” Rio asked, noticing the way Agatha was staring at her with that quiet affection that always made her feel like the center of Agatha’s universe.

 

Agatha smiled, a little shy now, though the tenderness in her eyes remained. “Nothing,” she said softly, her voice almost a whisper. “Just… I love you.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled at the simplicity and depth of those words. She leaned over, cupping Agatha’s cheek with gentle hands, her thumb brushing over her skin as she looked into her eyes. “I love you too,” she whispered back, her voice thick with emotion.

 

As they drove home, their hearts were full, the memory of the night already etched deeply in their minds—a reminder of the unshakeable bond they shared.

 

 

When Agatha and Rio walked into the house, the first thing they noticed was the warm glow of the living room light spilling into the entryway. They could hear the faint sound of a children’s cartoon, and as they stepped closer, the sight that greeted them made them both smile.

 

Nicky was sprawled out on the couch, fast asleep, his little chest rising and falling steadily. Alice and Jen sat on either side of him, their eyes glued to the colorful cartoon playing on the TV. Alice was munching on popcorn, and Jen was sipping from a mug, both looking surprisingly invested in the antics of the animated characters.

 

Agatha folded her arms, leaning against the doorway with an amused smirk. “Comfortable, are we?”

 

Alice looked up, her face lighting up with a grin. “Oh, hey! Welcome back. We thought you’d be later.”

 

“We could’ve been,” Rio teased, her voice soft as her eyes lingered on Nicky. “But this little scene is too good to miss.”

 

Jen gestured to the TV with her mug. “Okay, but have you seen this show? It’s weirdly compelling.”

 

Alice nodded. “And Nicky made us promise to finish the episode for him when he passed out. We couldn’t let the kid down.”

 

Rio chuckled and stepped over to the couch, gently brushing Nicky’s hair out of his face. “Thank you both for keeping him company.”

 

“Anytime,” Alice said, her tone genuine. She leaned closer to Nicky, lowering her voice dramatically. “He’s a riot. You two are raising a very cool kid.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened as she watched Rio bend down to stroke Nicky’s cheek. The boy didn’t even stir. “He’s got good role models,” Agatha said quietly, her gaze flickering between Rio and the two women.

 

Alice leaned against the wall, grinning. “Before we go, we need to debrief you two on our night of adventures with Nicky.”

 

“Oh?” Rio raised an eyebrow, settling on the armrest of the couch while Agatha leaned casually against the wall.

 

Jen laughed, holding up a hand. “First off, Nicky decided we were officially Auntie Alice and Auntie Jen. He insisted. So, you’re looking at two very proud honorary aunts.”

 

Agatha smirked. “He promoted you already, huh? That’s quick work.”

 

Alice nodded enthusiastically. “We earned it! We built a fort out of cushions and blankets, had a battle of who could make the silliest face, and we may or may not have eaten ice cream after dinner.”

 

“After dinner?” Agatha’s eyebrow arched, her tone teasingly stern.

 

“Don’t worry!” Alice waved her hands. “We also made him eat his broccoli, which he grudgingly did because I told him superheroes eat their greens.”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “Clever.”

 

“Very clever,” Jen said, mockingly impressed. “But then Señor Scratchy decided he didn’t like me, and poof, he disappeared. Gone without a trace.”

 

Alice burst out laughing, clutching her stomach. “You should’ve seen her face. She tried to win him over with a carrot, and the bunny just turned his back and hopped away. Cold-blooded.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but giggle, while Agatha chuckled, trying to keep her usual composure. “Well, he has his preferences,” Agatha said.

 

As if on cue, a soft rustling sound came from the corner of the room. Señor Scratchy emerged, hopping toward them with a slow, deliberate gait. His little nose twitched as he approached Agatha, who crouched down to scoop him up.

 

“Of course,” Alice said, throwing her hands up in mock defeat. “The bunny likes you best.”

 

“He has good taste,” Agatha said smugly, scratching behind Señor Scratchy’s ears.

 

Jen crossed her arms, grinning. “You’re his favorite, no question. But I’ll have you know, I was very charming.”

 

“Uh-huh,” Alice teased, slinging her bag over her shoulder. “He’s a tough crowd, but maybe you’ll win him over next time.”

 

Rio stood, still laughing. “Thank you both for tonight. Nicky clearly had the best time—and so did we.”

 

Jen and Alice hugged them both, still laughing about the bunny debacle.

 

“We should get going,” Jen said, setting her mug down. She stood and stretched, glancing at the empty popcorn bowl on the coffee table. “Thanks for the snacks, by the way.”

 

“Yeah, and for trusting us with your little dude,” Alice added. “We had a blast.”

 

Rio smiled. “We’ll have to do this again sometime—maybe when we need another date night.”

 

Alice grinned. “You know where to find us.”

 

As they both stood to leave, Alice grinned widely. “Remember, anytime you need Auntie Alice and Auntie Jen, just call. We’ve got this babysitting thing down.”

 

“Oh we know, don’t worry we really like not having to pay you guys!” Rio replied, patting Alice on the head.

 

As Alice and Jen grabbed their coats and bags, Alice stopped at the door and turned back with a mischievous grin.

 

“Before we go,” she began, eyes glinting with mischief, “please, for the love of all things sacred, wait until we’re gone before you two get all steamy and scandalous.”

 

Jen, catching on, immediately doubled over laughing. “Yeah, seriously. We do not need any mental images of…that. Spare us.”

 

Rio’s eyes widened in mortification, her cheeks flushing a deep crimson. “Alice!”

 

Alice simply smirked, clearly unfazed by Rio’s reaction. “What? Am I wrong?” she said innocently, batting her lashes. “It’s a valid request. You two are practically radiating ‘we just came back from a romantic date and couldn't wait to get home’ energy. Honestly, I’m just trying to protect myself from needing therapy.”

 

Agatha, on the other hand, remained perfectly composed, a mischievous glint in her eyes. She raised an eyebrow and leaned against the doorframe with a smirk. “Oh, don’t worry, Alice. I am planning to wait until at least the door clicked shut to take her clothes off. I do have manners. Though, I can’t promise anything beyond that.”

 

Rio’s jaw dropped. “Agatha!”

en doubled over again, gasping for air between her fits of laughter. “I knew it. I knew you’d say something even worse!”

 

Alice, pretending to be horrified, clapped both hands over her ears. “Nope! Nope! I am DONE. Forget I said anything. I’ll be in therapy for years because of this.”

 

She made a show of stumbling backward toward the door, still covering her ears. “Bye, Nicky’s moms! May your night be as sinful as I’m trying very hard NOT to picture it.”

 

Jen barely managed to drag herself out behind Alice, still wheezing from laughter. She yanked the door shut, leaving only the sound of their fading giggles and Rio’s deep, exasperated groan in their wake.

 

As soon as the door clicked shut, Rio turned to Agatha, still red-faced but unable to hide the smile tugging at her lips. “You’re terrible, you know that?” she said, trying to sound stern but failing miserably.

 

Agatha, ever smug, shrugged nonchalantly, a playful smirk tugging at her lips. “You love it,” she teased, her eyes twinkling with mischief.

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress the smile that followed. She leaned in, cupping Agatha’s face and planting a gentle kiss on her lips. “Unfortunately for me,” Rio murmured, her voice softening with affection, “yes, I do.”

 

“Good, because I’m not planning on changing anytime soon.”

 

When they separated, Rio knelt beside Nixky, her fingertips brushing a stray lock of hair from his forehead. Her eyes softened as she looked at him, the affection in her gaze palpable. “He had so much fun,” she murmured, her voice tender, as though speaking too loudly might disturb the fragile tranquility of the moment.

 

Agatha nodded in agreement, a small smile tugging at her lips. “He deserves it,” she said quietly, her gaze lingering on the peaceful little boy before meeting Rio’s eyes. “Come on, let’s get him to bed.”

 

With practiced ease, Agatha bent down and gently scooped Nicky into her arms, her movements slow and deliberate, mindful of his weight and the way his small body remained heavy with sleep. He stirred only slightly, his little fingers curling into the fabric of her dress before he nuzzled into her shoulder with a soft sigh, melting back into his dreams.

 

Rio followed closely behind, her gaze lingering on Agatha—not just as a mother, but as something else entirely. There was something breathtaking about the way Agatha held their boy, something that sent warmth curling in Rio’s chest and, admittedly, a different kind of heat spreading lower. It was the tenderness, the quiet protectiveness, the ease with which Agatha carried the weight of their world in her arms.

 

By the time they reached Nicky’s room, Rio was half-dazed, lost in the quiet intimacy of the moment. Agatha lowered him onto the bed with the same steady, unshakable care, tucking the blankets around him like a practiced ritual. She lingered, pressing a gentle kiss to his forehead, her lips barely ghosting over his skin before she straightened.

 

Rio, leaning against the doorway, smiled warmly, though there was an undeniable flicker of something else beneath it. Watching Agatha like this—soft, affectionate, endlessly strong—made her heart clench in a way she wasn’t sure she’d ever get used to.

 

Agatha turned off the light, stepping back into the dim glow of the hallway. As she quietly closed the door behind them, her posture shifted, that playful glint creeping back into her eyes. “One down,” she murmured, voice low, teasing.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow, amused but wary. “One what?”

 

Agatha didn’t answer immediately. Instead, she tilted her head, letting her gaze flicker down, lingering on Rio’s lips before dragging back up to her eyes. A smirk curled at the edges of her mouth, slow and deliberate. “One person I need to carry to bed tonight.”

 

Rio barely had time to react before she was suddenly lifted off her feet, her breath catching in a startled squeal. “Agatha—!” she gasped, instinctively clutching at Agatha’s shoulders, her fingers digging into firm muscle as laughter bubbled out of her.

 

Agatha’s grip was sure, her steps steady as she carried Rio down the hallway as if she weighed nothing at all. “What?” she purred, voice thick with amusement and something else entirely. “I’m just being thorough.”

 

Rio’s laughter faltered, replaced by a quick intake of breath when Agatha shifted her grip just enough to let one hand slip down, fingers pressing dangerously close to the hem of her shorts.

 

“Careful,” Rio murmured, her voice dipping into something dangerously close to a challenge. “You keep that up, and I might start thinking you have ulterior motives.”

 

Agatha hummed, her lips brushing just beneath Rio’s ear as she whispered, “Oh, darling… I don’t think I’ve ever been subtle about my motives.”

 

Rio shivered. “Not fair.”

 

“Never claimed to play fair.”

 

When they reached their bedroom, Agatha kicked the door shut behind them with a deliberate flick of her foot, the soft click of the lock sealing them in their own private world. The air inside was different—thicker, charged, humming with anticipation.

 

With effortless grace, Agatha carried Rio to the bed, her touch both reverent and possessive as she lowered her onto the plush mattress. But she didn’t step away—her hands remained, fingertips grazing the soft fabric of Rio’s jumpsuit, skimming over the curves they concealed as if memorizing the feeling through the layers. Her thumbs stroked lazy circles at Rio’s hips, grounding, teasing.

 

Rio looked up at her, breath already coming a little faster, and met the intensity of Agatha’s gaze. It was searing, unyielding, and yet so full of something deeper—something that made Rio’s stomach flip in a way that had nothing to do with nerves.

 

The playful energy that had filled the night twisted into something else, something heavier, richer, something that had been building since the moment they’d stepped through the door.

 

Agatha leaned down, her lips brushing the shell of Rio’s ear, her breath warm against her skin as she murmured, low and full of promise, “Now, it’s time to celebrate us properly.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, her fingers tightening where they rested against Agatha’s forearms. A slow, delicious heat coiled in her belly, spreading outward, making her pulse hammer against her ribs. A rosy flush crept up her neck, but it wasn’t from shyness—it was from the way Agatha’s voice alone could undo her, from the way every syllable felt like a deliberate caress.

 

Her arms wound around Agatha’s neck, pulling her closer, eliminating what little space remained between them. “Then stop talking,” she whispered, her voice dipping into something softer, needier. “And kiss me already.”

 

Agatha smirked—lazy, knowing—but obeyed.

 

Her response was immediate, the playful smirk on her face replaced by a look of deep affection and desire. She leaned down, capturing Rio’s lips in a slow, passionate kiss that seemed to stretch time itself. The kiss deepened, soft at first, then more urgent, as if their lips had been craving the connection for far longer than either of them had realized.

 

Rio sighed into it, her fingers threading into Agatha’s thick, brown hair, tugging just enough to earn a quiet groan from Rio’s lips. The sound sent a shiver racing down Rio’s spine, pooling heat in places she was quickly becoming desperate to soothe. It was a kiss that spoke of shared love, of desire, devotion, of quiet moments like this, of all the things they didn’t need to say because they had already said them in every glance, every touch, every soft word.

 

Agatha’s hands moved to the back of Rio’s jumpsuit, blindly finding the zip and pulling it down, without breaking the kiss. Her fingers caressed the naked skin it uncovered, the fabric sliding against her fingertips, the tension between them growing stronger with every passing second. Their connection, so real and raw, filled the room with an undeniable heat that had little to do with their physical closeness, but everything to do with the love they shared.

 

As the kiss finally broke, both of them were left breathless, foreheads resting against each other, their eyes closed for a moment as they simply breathed in the shared intimacy of the night.
