It was a moment just for them—away from the chaos of the world, away from everything that wasn’t theirs.

 

“I love you,” Agatha murmured, her voice thick with emotion as she brushed a strand of hair from Rio’s face.

 

“I love you too.” Rio smiled, her heart full as she leaned in again, this time for a gentle, lingering kiss. “Now get the rest of that off me, so I can reciprocate.” She said, shimmying her shoulder to let the top of her green suit fall down to her waist.

 

Agatha obliged, her eyes a shade darker as she took in the newly exposed skin and soon the jumpsuit was nothing but a green silky pool on the floor of their bedroom, promptly followed by the black sleek material that used to be Agatha’s dress.

 

In no time, Rio found herself pressed against the pillows, her hair all over them as Agatha’s brown mane joined it as she leaned in for another searing kiss, her hands travelling further and further, making Rio’s head fall back, giving Agatha perfect access to her neck and everything that came below.

 

Rio arched into her, fingers skating down Agatha’s back, tracing the ridges of her spine, nails biting just enough to make Agatha feel it.

 

Agatha responded in kind, her hands wandering lower, bolder, pressing into soft curves, coaxing gasps and sighs and desperate little sounds from Rio’s lips—sounds that made Agatha feel drunk with need, with love, with the sheer rightness of it all.

 

The night unfolded as a testament to their love, their connection deepening with every touch, every whispered word, every moan and meeting of naked skins. Names were murmured, chanted and welcomed, accompanying declarations of desire, worship and devotion. They didn’t just take from each other; they gave—love, pleasure, adoration. They offered themselves, wholly, completely, with nothing held back.

 

By the time the heat finally ebbed into something slower, softer, and limbs tangled beneath the sheets, they lay in the dimly lit hush of their bedroom, skin still warm, hearts still pounding, bodies still pressed close.

 

Agatha traced idle patterns along Rio’s bare shoulder, her fingers featherlight, absentminded. Her other hand rested over Rio’s heart, feeling the steady beat beneath her palm, as if grounding herself in the reality of it.

 

“I love you,” she murmured, her voice quieter now, but no less intense.

 

Rio turned her head just enough to meet Agatha’s gaze, a lazy, satisfied smile curving her lips. “I love you too,” she murmured, her fingers brushing over Agatha’s cheek before tangling in her hair, pulling her in for another slow, lingering kiss.

 

And then, voice teasing but heavy with affection, she whispered, “Now, go get me some water before I die of dehydration.”

 

Agatha chuckled, rolling onto her back, one arm still draped over Rio’s waist. “You really know how to kill a moment, love.”

 

Rio grinned, stretching like a satisfied cat, unbothered. “You’ll recover.”

 

Agatha sighed, dramatic but indulgent, and with one last lingering kiss to Rio’s shoulder, she finally rolled out of bed, muttering something about how this was the price of dating an insatiable little menace.

 

Rio only laughed, watching her go, knowing full well they both wouldn’t be getting much sleep tonight.

 

 

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

Hello, hello!

I have huge exams all week, so I might not reply to all comments right away, but i'm still reading them and I love them so much, thank you so so much for all your heartfelt words!
Don't worry, I'll still post as I have several chapters ready.

Thank you thank you, I hope you enjoyed this chapter !!

Dinner Party - Part I

Chapter Notes

Part 1

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

To arrive where you are, to get from where you are not,

You must go by a way wherein there is no ecstasy.

In order to arrive at what you do not know

You must go by a way which is the way of ignorance.

In order to possess what you do not possess

You must go by the way of dispossession.

In order to arrive at what you are not

You must go through the way in which you are not.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. « East Coker.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

Agatha sat at the kitchen table, her fingers drumming a soft, rhythmic beat against the smooth surface. The invitation lay in front of her, a sleek, expensive card that practically screamed pretension. It was the kind of invite that belonged in the world of the wealthy, polished, and well-connected—a world she’d once inhabited with a sense of purpose but now viewed with a mix of disdain and obligation. The dinner party was being hosted by one of her college friends—or, rather, the people she had once called friends—an event she had been dreading since it arrived.

 

She stared at the card, her lips pressed into a thin line, the weight of its significance settling heavily in her chest. It wasn’t just an invitation; it was a reminder of a world she had distanced herself from, a world she no longer belonged to, and a part of herself that she didn’t want to revisit. But in her current position—still navigating the politics of academia, still protecting her reputation—it felt impossible to ignore.

 

Rio walked in, a mug of tea in her hands. She paused when she saw Agatha’s expression. “What’s got you looking like that? Did Señor Scratchy eat one of your books?”

 

Agatha glanced up at her, her smirk tugging at the corners of her mouth despite the tension knotting her insides. “No, though that would be a more pleasant situation than this,” she replied dryly, pushing the invitation toward Rio with an exaggerated sigh.

 

Rio raised an eyebrow but set her tea down before picking up the card, her fingers brushing over the elegant lettering with a soft curiosity. “Oh. Fancy dinner party with some old friends, huh?” She scanned the details, her expression unreadable.

 

“Not friends,” Agatha corrected, her voice cool and steady as she leaned back in her chair. “Acquaintances. Connections. People I tolerated because it was beneficial back then. Now? I’d rather spend an evening cleaning out the garage.” Her voice softened as she leaned forward again, her fingers tapping out a nervous rhythm on the table. “The last time I saw them was… years ago. And even then, I only tolerated them because they were useful.”

 

Rio tilted her head slightly, watching Agatha with a blend of amusement and understanding. “So don’t go. You’re not obligated to spend time with people you don’t like.”

 

Agatha’s eyes fluttered shut for a moment as she let out a long, frustrated sigh. “I know, but they’re… valuable. They’re well-connected, Rio. They can open doors, get me in the rooms where decisions are made, introduce me to the right people. It’s not just about liking them. It’s about keeping those doors open, making sure I’m not forgotten when it matters most.” She pressed her fingers to her temples, as if massaging away the headache forming behind her eyes. “Especially when I’m finishing build a name for myself in academia and publishing. I can’t afford to cut myself off from opportunities like this. It’s a game, and if I don’t play, I risk losing everything.”

 

Rio leaned forward, her brows furrowed in thought, her hands folded in front of her as she met Agatha’s gaze. “But at what cost, Agatha? If being around them makes you miserable, is it really worth it? You’re not a pawn to be moved around for someone else’s benefit. You don’t have to sacrifice your happiness for a seat at their table.”

 

Agatha was quiet for a long moment, her fingers now tracing the rim of her coffee mug. She studied the swirling dark liquid, as if searching for an answer in its depths. The warmth of Rio’s words—their gentle insistence—settled over her like a soft blanket, and for a second, she allowed herself to relax in the comfort of Rio’s unwavering support.

 

She looked up then, her expression softening. “It’s not that simple, my love,” Agatha said quietly, her voice barely above a whisper. “Sometimes, you have to play the game. It’s not about liking them or even being true to yourself all the time. It’s about surviving in a world that demands you adapt, to fit into a mold that isn’t always comfortable.” She shook her head slightly, as if the words didn’t sit well with her, but they were the reality of her circumstances. “It’s not a matter of principle—it’s about staying in the game long enough to make your own rules.”

 

Rio’s eyes softened, her heart aching for the woman she loved. She could see the conflict warring inside Agatha, the part of her that resented the need for these pretentious gatherings and shallow connections, and the part that knew they were necessary if Agatha wanted to protect her career, her reputation.

 

Agatha let out a long, slow breath, her fingers resting lightly on the edge of the table as she looked down at her hands. For a moment, she seemed lost in thought, her brow furrowing slightly as she weighed her words carefully. Finally, she met Ria’s eyes, her gaze soft but resolute.

 

“I was thinking… maybe you could come with me,” Agatha began, her voice calm but filled with an undertone of something deeper, something she couldn’t quite put into words just yet. “As my date.”

 

Rio blinked, clearly caught off guard by the request. Her brow furrowed in confusion. “Your… date?” she asked, her voice a mixture of surprise and curiosity.

 

Agatha nodded, taking a small step closer to Rio, her voice steady and deliberate as she explained. “Yes. I know these kinds of events can be overwhelming, and I don’t blame you if you’d rather not. But the truth is, I don’t want to go alone. I thought… I thought it might be a good opportunity to introduce you to them.” She hesitated for a brief moment, her fingers gently brushing over the surface of the invitation she had discarded on the counter. “To show you off, honestly. You’re such an incredible part of my life, Rio. And I want them to see that. To know that.”

 

Agatha paused, her heart fluttering with a mixture of excitement and uncertainty. She wasn’t sure why it had taken her this long to ask, but she knew, deep down, that the thought of having Rio by her side—of showing the world who she truly loved—was something she had to do. It was time to stop hiding the woman who meant everything to her.

 

Rio, however, didn’t respond immediately. Instead, she paced across the living room, her arms crossed tightly over her chest, her lips moving soundlessly as she processed Agatha’s words. The tension in the room thickened, and Agatha could feel it, could feel the whirl of thoughts running through Rio’s mind as she muttered to herself.

 

“I just don’t think this is a good idea,” Rio finally said, her voice tight, and she spun on her heel, meeting Agatha’s gaze with a mix of concern and hesitation. “These people… they’re not your friends. You said it yourself. What if they’re judgmental or rude? What if—”

 

Agatha stepped forward, closing the distance between them with a gentle but firm motion. She reached out, her hands settling on Rio’s shoulders, grounding her in the moment. “Love,” Agatha said softly, her voice warm and steady. “Breathe.”

 

Rio froze, her wide, uncertain eyes locking onto Agatha’s. For a moment, the room fell silent, save for the soft hum of the air conditioning and the distant sound of the city outside. Rio’s lips parted, her chest rising and falling with the weight of her emotions. “I’m serious, Agatha. What if I embarrass you?”

 

A tender smile touched Agatha’s lips as she stepped closer, her hands now cupping Rio’s face. “You could never embarrass me,” she replied firmly, her words quenching Rio’s worries. “Rio, you’re brilliant, funny, and breathtakingly beautiful. If anyone has a problem with you, that says far more about them than it does about you.”

 

Rio’s tense shoulders relaxed under Agatha’s touch, but the apprehension still lingered in her eyes. “But what if—”

 

“No ‘what ifs,’” Agatha interrupted, her tone gentle but firm. “I’ve been thinking about it for a while now, and I don’t want to keep you hidden anymore. I want to introduce you as my girlfriend, my partner, my love. You’re such an important part of my life, and if I’m going to spend an evening with these people, I want you there with me. By my side.” Her voice softened, the vulnerability in her words clear as she gazed into Rio’s eyes, searching for understanding.

 

Rio stood still for a moment, her expression conflicted as she considered Agatha’s plea. The uncertainty clouded her face, but there was something else there too—a flicker of hope, of wanting to believe in the possibility of acceptance. “Agatha, I don’t know… What if I don’t fit in? What if they don’t like me?”

 

Agatha’s heart ached at the vulnerability in Rio’s voice. She stepped even closer, her fingers brushing softly against Rio’s arms as she gently took her hands in her own, squeezing them with reassuring tenderness. “Rio, listen to me,” Agatha said, her voice dropping to a more intimate, gentle tone. “I’m not worried about them liking you. I’m not worried about you fitting in, because, sweetheart, you’re not the one who has to fit in. They do. You’re smart, you’re radiant, and you’re mine. That’s all that matters. They can take it or leave it, but they’ll see you for exactly who you are.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed, the hint of a smile tugging at the corners of her lips, but it was uncertain, as though she wasn’t quite ready to let go of her doubt. “You make it sound so simple,” she said, her voice laced with a mixture of awe and hesitation.

 

“It is simple,” Agatha replied softly, her eyes full of affection. “You’re my love. And I want to share that with the world, not hide it away. If you’re not comfortable with it, I’ll go alone, no problem. But if you come, I’ll be with you every step of the way. We’ll face this together. As a team.”

 

Rio bit her lip, her mind still turning over the possibility of stepping into that world, but the weight of Agatha’s words began to settle in her heart. “You really want me there?” she asked quietly, her voice soft and vulnerable.

 

Agatha’s eyes softened even further, her thumbs gently tracing the backs of Rio’s hands as she looked at her with unmasked affection. “More than anything,” she said, her voice full of sincerity, her heart laid bare before Rio.

 

Rio sighed, the sound a mixture of resignation and acceptance as she leaned forward, pressing her forehead gently against Agatha’s. “Okay,” she murmured after a long pause, her voice barely above a whisper. “I’ll go. But don’t be mad if I cling to you like a koala all night.”

 

Agatha chuckled, the sound rich and full of warmth, and she pressed a soft kiss to Rio’s temple, her hands caressing her back in a comforting gesture. “I wouldn’t have it any other way,” she replied, her smile genuine and loving.

 

“And if I do end up embarrassing myself, it’s on you,” Rio added, her voice laced with a teasing edge as her lips curled into a small but mischievous grin.

 

“Deal,” Agatha said with a laugh, leaning in to kiss Rio gently, sealing the promise between them. 

 

 

The evening of the dinner arrived, and Rio stood frozen in front of her closet, her mind whirling as she stared blankly at the rows of hanging clothes. She was surrounded by her usual wardrobe—comfortable, practical, and undeniably her—but tonight, none of it felt right. Her eyes flicked from one piece to another, her brain refusing to settle on anything. Nothing seemed to fit the occasion, and the pressure to look a certain way only made the task feel more daunting.

 

With a frustrated sigh, she dropped her shoulders and groaned softly, burying her face in her hands.

 

“Why is it so hard to dress for a bunch of people I don’t even want to meet?” she muttered to herself, her voice muffled.

 

From across the room, Agatha, seated on the edge of their bed, delicately fastened the last earring in place. She glanced up, her lips curling into a knowing smile as she observed her turmoil.

 

“Because you care more than you’re willing to admit,” Agatha teased lightly, her tone playful yet filled with affection.

 

Rio huffed in response, turning to face Agatha with a frown tugging at her lips. “It’s not that I care what they think,” she said, her voice tinged with frustration. “I just… I want to look good. Like, I want them to see me and know I’m with you for a reason. I don’t want them to think I’m out of place, or that I don’t belong in that world.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened at the vulnerability in Rio’s voice. She stood up and crossed the room with a graceful ease, her presence filling the space with a quiet strength. She reached Rio’s side, gently placing her hands on her shoulders. Her touch was warm, grounding, and Rio couldn’t help but relax under it.

 

“You could wear sweatpants and a t-shirt,” Agatha said earnestly, her voice low and comforting, “and you’d still look better than anyone else in that room.”

 

Rio gave her a doubtful look, arching an eyebrow. “Flattery won’t help you every time, you know?” she replied, though a small smile tugged at her lips despite herself.

 

Agatha chuckled “Maybe not, but it is working right now.” She stepped back slightly, her eyes scanning the array of clothes before turning back to Rio. “Now, what’s the issue? Too many choices or not enough?”

 

Rio’s hands gestured helplessly at the closet, as if the answer was tangled in the fabric of the clothes themselves. “I don’t know how to dress for something like this,” she admitted, her voice quieter now, more vulnerable. “My usual stuff feels too casual, but anything fancier feels… like I’m pretending to be someone I’m not.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, her thumb gently brushing the back of Rio’s neck in a quiet act of comfort. She understood the struggle, the inner conflict Rio was facing. Agatha knew how much Rio valued authenticity—how uncomfortable it felt to wear a persona that didn’t fit, to try and blend into spaces where she didn’t feel she belonged.

 

“I get it,” Agatha said quietly, her voice steady. “But you don’t have to change who you are to make a statement. You’re already perfect as you are.”

 

Rio’s lips parted, as if about to protest, but Agatha continued before she could speak.

 

“You’re not pretending to be someone you’re not,” Agatha said, her voice gentle but firm. “You’re showing them who you are. Who we are. You don’t have to look like them to impress them. You’re already impressive. Just by being you.”

 

There was a long silence as Rio processed Agatha’s words, her gaze softening. A warmth spread in her chest, and for the first time in the past hour, she felt the tight knot of anxiety loosen, even if just a little.

 

Agatha tilted her head thoughtfully, her fingers tapping against her chin as if pondering a solution. “But if it bothers you that much,” she said, her voice soft with understanding, “why don’t you borrow something of mine?”

 

Rio blinked, her confusion evident. “Really?”

 

“Of course,” Agatha replied with a playful smile, already moving toward her wardrobe with a sense of purpose. “You’d look stunning in half my clothes anyway. Let’s see…”

 

She began thumbing through her well-organized collection, pulling out items one by one. Each piece was carefully examined against Rio’s frame, Agatha holding them up with an expert eye, as if imagining them already on her. She was thorough, deliberate, searching for something that would give Rio the confidence she needed while still allowing her to stay true to herself.

 

After a few moments of this, Agatha’s fingers stopped on a sleek, burgundy blouse with a delicate gold accent along the collar. She held it up with a satisfied nod. “This,” she declared with a confident smile. “This will bring out your eyes. It’s classy without being too over the top. And most importantly, it’s comfortable. You’ll still feel like yourself in it.”

 

She reached back into the closet, pulling out a pair of black slacks and a belt that would complement the blouse perfectly. She handed them to Rio, who was still inspecting the blouse in her hands.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, running her fingers over the soft fabric of the blouse. “Are you sure? This looks… expensive.”

 

Agatha’s smirk was mischievous, but her eyes softened with affection. “It is. But it’s worth every penny if it means you’ll feel good tonight. Trust me, you deserve to feel stunning.”

 

Rio looked uncertain for just a moment longer but nodded, surrendering to Agatha’s insistent confidence. She carefully slipped out of her current outfit, unbuttoning her shirt and replacing it with Agatha’s blouse. When she turned to face the mirror, she couldn’t help but smile.

 

The blouse fit perfectly, hugging her curves in all the right places without being constricting. It had an effortless elegance, and the deep burgundy color made her eyes sparkle in a way she hadn’t expected. The gold accents at the collar added a touch of warmth that made her skin glow.

 

Agatha stepped up behind her, resting her hands lightly on Rio’s waist as she gazed at her reflection in the mirror. “See?” she said, her voice full of admiration. “You look amazing.”

 

Rio met Agatha’s gaze in the mirror, her cheeks flushing at the compliment. She smiled softly, her heart warming at the sincerity in Agatha’s eyes. “You really think so?”

 

“I know so,” Agatha replied, her voice steady and unwavering. There was no doubt in her tone, no hesitation. “And just so you know, they’re going to be more intimidated by how gorgeous and confident you look than you could ever be of them.”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, a soft sound that filled the room with warmth. She leaned back into Agatha’s embrace, allowing herself to relax against her steady presence. “You’re too good to me, you know that?”

 

“I know,” Agatha said with a smirk, brushing a kiss on Rio’s lips. “But you’re worth it.”

 

 

Agatha and Rio stood at the ornate front door of Agatha’s old friend’s grand house, the soft hum of lively conversation and laughter drifting through the cracks in the wood. The house, towering and grand, seemed to gleam in the soft light of the evening. Rio felt a twinge of nervousness ripple through her as she adjusted the hem of the borrowed blouse, tugging at it in a subconscious attempt to make it feel more like her own.

 

She glanced up at Agatha, her gaze momentarily betraying her unease.

 

“Relax, love,” Agatha murmured with a soothing smile, gently taking Rio’s hand in hers. Her thumb traced tender, slow circles over Rio’s knuckles, grounding her in the moment. “We’re just here for dinner, not a trial.”

 

Rio let out a quiet, nervous breath, but the tension in her shoulders didn’t ease. “You say that now,” she replied, her voice tinged with a mix of humor and apprehension, “but you haven’t seen the way I spill wine under pressure. It’s like an art form.”

 

Agatha chuckled softly, the sound rich and warm against the cool air. She leaned in close, her lips brushing Rio’s temple in a fleeting kiss. “If you spill, I’ll spill too. Solidarity.”

 

The absurdity of the idea broke through Rio’s anxiety, and she couldn’t help but laugh—a soft, genuine laugh that echoed between them. 

 

Rio squeezed Agatha’s hand in gratitude, the comfort of that simple gesture settling her nerves. “I’m glad you’re here,” she admitted quietly, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

“I wouldn’t be anywhere else,” Agatha responded, her tone filled with quiet assurance. She leaned back slightly to look at Rio, her smile soft but confident. “Besides, I’m the one who’s supposed to be intimidating. You’re just here to look beautiful and make them jealous.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress the smile that tugged at her lips. “You’re a little too good at that whole ‘confidence thing.’”

 

Agatha’s smirk was teasing, but her eyes sparkled with warmth. “It’s not confidence, love. It’s just knowing you’re with the most captivating woman in the room.”

 

Rio’s cheeks flushed at the compliment, her nerves temporarily forgotten in the face of Agatha’s adoration. She gave Agatha a playful push, then turned to face the door, taking a deep breath. The laughter and chatter inside sounded inviting now—less intimidating and more like the beginning of an adventure with Agatha by her side.

 

Agatha gave her hand one last reassuring squeeze before she reached for the doorbell. “Ready?”

 

Rio nodded, her heart still fluttering, but more steady than it had been moments before. “Let’s go show them just how amazing we are.”

 

When they stepped through the threshold, the room seemed to quiet for a brief moment, as if the atmosphere itself had shifted. The guests, men and women in finely tailored outfits, their drinks sparkling like jewels under the soft glow of the chandelier, sized them up with practiced ease. The laughter and murmur of conversation tapered off just enough to signal the entrance of the newcomers, making the couple’s arrival feel like a side spectacle.

 

Agatha, as always, was unruffled. With a calm grace that made it look effortless, she guided Rio forward, her hand settling lightly on the small of her back, a reassuring touch that grounded Rio even as the eyes of the room lingered a fraction too long on them.

 

“Everyone,” Agatha’s voice rang out, smooth and commanding, but not loud—just the right tone to capture attention without effort. “I’d like you to meet Rio, my better half.”

 

The polite chorus of “Oh, how lovely,” and “Nice to meet you” followed, as Agatha’s friends stepped forward to greet them with the cool politeness of people who had been trained in the art of social graces. Yet, despite the cordial responses, Rio could feel the subtle shift in energy—the flicker of surprise, the barely perceptible exchanges of glances, the slightest hesitations before each person spoke, as if they were reassessing Agatha’s choices through the lens of her younger, less traditionally polished partner.

 

She wasn’t imagining it. The judgments were there, sharp and almost imperceptible, like cold fingers brushing against her skin. It was as though, in their eyes, she didn’t belong in this world of tailored suits and cocktail conversations, and in turn, she was forcing them to reconsider Agatha’s stature. They were measuring her against expectations she couldn’t meet, and for a fleeting moment, it felt as though they were questioning her worthiness, not just as a partner to Agatha but as a person.

 

Agatha seemed to sense it, too. Her touch on Rio’s back grew firmer, more protective, a silent promise that nothing would come between them. Agatha leaned in slightly, her voice low and steady as she murmured, “Ignore them. They’re irrelevant.”

 

The quiet conviction in Agatha’s words steadied Rio. She swallowed her discomfort, finding strength in the unwavering support Agatha offered. This was Agatha’s world, and Rio was her equal in it. They were a team, no matter what anyone else thought. With that thought anchoring her, Rio straightened her posture and faced the room, her smile turning from polite to genuine, grounded by Agatha’s presence.

 

Mark, the host, a tall man in his early fifties with a salt-and-pepper beard that was meticulously groomed, stepped forward with the air of someone accustomed to being in charge. His wife, Madeline, followed close behind, her platinum blonde hair gleaming like a halo against the soft lighting of the room. She had the air of someone who rarely left the spotlight, her smile practiced but warm, as though she was sizing up everyone in the room to ensure they fit her vision of perfection.

 

“Agatha,” Mark said warmly, his voice rich with the sound of familiarity. His eyes briefly flicked to Rio, as if assessing her, before settling back on Agatha with a slight but unmistakable arch of his brow. “It’s been far too long.”

 

“It has,” Agatha replied smoothly, her voice cordial but distant, the right mix of politeness and control. “Thank you for having us, Mark. I trust you and Madeline have been well.”

 

Madeline nodded, giving them a graceful smile, but Rio caught the way her eyes lingered for just a moment too long—her curiosity veiled behind the practiced smile of a woman who had seen it all. Agatha continued, her tone steady and unbothered, gesturing toward Rio with an air of quiet pride. “This is Rio, my partner.”

 

Mark’s smile widened fractionally, but Rio could sense the way his expression shifted slightly, as if the introduction had triggered some recalculation in his mind. “Ah,” he said, his voice dipping with a trace of new interest. “Rio. Welcome.”

 

“Thank you,” Rio replied, meeting his handshake with practiced poise. Despite his neutral expression, Rio could feel the weight of his scrutiny, the subtle dissection of her worth beneath the veneer of civility. But she didn’t flinch. Instead, she held his gaze, steady and unfazed, the warmth of Agatha’s touch anchoring her as they moved on.

 

As they moved deeper into the room, the gentle hum of small talk resumed, wrapping itself around them like a soft, impenetrable veil. Agatha’s friends, or the epitome of politeness, exchanged pleasantries with the couple, but there was a distinct air of reservation—an undercurrent of something that Rio couldn’t quite place but was all too aware of. She caught snippets of conversations about travel, art, and politics, but it was the subtle glances and half-formed questions that drew her attention more. The way they looked at her when they thought she wasn’t looking. The subtle judgment that lingered in the air, quiet but unmistakable.

 

Rio couldn’t shake the feeling that, to them, she was an anomaly—someone who didn’t quite belong in the world they had created with their tailored suits, elegant cocktails, and casual airs of superiority. She tried to breathe through it, but it wasn’t easy.

 

The sound of champagne flutes clinking filled the air, and a woman in a navy cocktail dress—a striking figure with an air of practiced curiosity—leaned forward. Rio recalled her name as Julia, though she couldn’t be sure. Julia’s glass hovered just below her lips, her eyes gleaming with the kind of politeness that was just sharp enough to cut.

 

“So,” Julia began, her tone light but edged with something Rio could not quite name, “how exactly did the two of you meet? It’s always fascinating to hear these stories.”

 

The question, as seemingly innocent as it was, felt like a trap, and Rio’s body stiffened before she could stop herself. Agatha, ever poised, met Rio’s gaze with a silent reassurance before reaching for her own glass, her posture as unflappable as always.

 

“Rio is a PhD student,” Agatha replied smoothly, her voice carrying effortlessly over the murmurs of the room.

 

The response hung in the air for a moment, the room stilling just slightly, as if a collective breath had been held. The woman’s eyebrows lifted just a fraction, a sharp gleam in her eyes as she processed the words.

 

“Your student?” another voice, a man’s, chimed in, his tone laced with disbelief, though he kept it under the surface just enough to maintain a façade of civility.

 

“Indeed,” Agatha answered without missing a beat, her confidence unwavering. “She is pursuing her doctorate in English literature, and I have the privilege of supervising her thesis. It didn’t take long for me to recognize her brilliance, both academically and personally.”

 

Rio felt a flush creeping up her neck, the heat of the room suddenly more intense. Was it the champagne? The weight of their eyes on her? Or just the sudden spotlight that made her feel like she was standing on display? She swallowed hard, but before she could shrink back, Agatha’s steady presence beside her grounded her, offering a silent anchor.

 

“Our relationship is not a secret,” Rio said softly but firmly, her voice calm and even despite the racing of her heart. “It has been disclosed to all relevant authorities.” Her words were measured, but there was a small hitch in her throat. “It’s not—”

 

“Improper,” Agatha interjected smoothly, her voice slipping into that familiar, gentle authority that made everything sound so natural, so effortless. Her hand settled on Rio’s back, warm and comforting. “It was entirely above board. Rio’s brilliance was always professional first. The rest, well…” She let her voice trail off, a faint smile tugging at her lips. “The rest came after.”

 

The woman in the navy dress nodded slowly, her smile faltering just slightly, as if she wasn’t quite sure how to navigate this new territory. “Well, that’s… unique,” she said, her tone soft but with a trace of doubt lingering in her words, as if she had tasted something unfamiliar and hadn’t quite decided whether she liked it.

 

“It is,” Agatha agreed, her smile sharpening just a little. She tilted her head slightly, an almost imperceptible challenge flashing in her eyes. “Unique and perfect for us.”

 

Rio took in the room, her eyes scanning the faces of the other guests as they exchanged quick, sidelong glances. Their expressions were a mix of surprise, mild discomfort, and something else—something more insidious, like the cold sweep of judgment masked beneath thin layers of forced politeness. The heat in Rio’s chest seemed to spread outward, but just as quickly, Agatha leaned in closer, her lips brushing the shell of Rio’s ear as she whispered, her voice a soft balm to Rio’s nerves.

 

“Breathe, love,” Agatha murmured. “You’re dazzling them. They’re just too boring to admit it.”

 

A soft laugh slipped past Rio’s lips, and she gave Agatha a grateful, if somewhat shaky, glance. It was the kind of reassurance Rio needed—the gentle reminder that, in this world of sharp-edged opinions and veiled judgments, Agatha would always be there, unwavering and untouchable.

 

Before the tension could stretch any further, Mark, the host, sensing the growing discomfort in the air, chimed in with a good-natured laugh, trying to diffuse the tension. “Well, I must say,” he said, his voice carrying a touch of amusement, “it sounds like the beginning of a very compelling story. An academic romance! You should write a book about it, Agatha.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened at the comment, her eyes flicking to Rio with a warmth that made Rio’s heart skip a beat. There was a depth in Agatha’s gaze, a shared secret that made everything else feel inconsequential.

 

“If I did,” Agatha said, her tone laced with affection and a touch of mischief, “it’d be the only thing I’ve ever written that doesn’t need a single embellishment.”

 

The guests laughed lightly at the quip, the tension in the room beginning to ease just slightly, though the lingering glances didn’t entirely fade.

 

As the conversation flowed and glasses were refilled, Agatha’s old friends began catching up with her, exchanging updates on their careers, families, and travels. The tone was light, filled with polite laughter and occasional jabs about how much time had passed. Eventually, the topic turned back to Rio.

 

“So, Rio,” one guest, a middle-aged man in a tweed blazer, leaned forward, offering her an encouraging smile. “We’ve heard so much about Agatha over the years, but tell us more about you. Where are you from?”

 

The question came out with the kind of ease that Rio knew she had to answer. She hesitated for only the briefest of seconds, her practiced polite smile never wavering as she thought through her response.

 

“Oh, I grew up in a lot of places,” Rio said casually, waving a hand as though the specifics were too trivial to concern herself with. She could feel the weight of the moment, but she tried to brush it off, deflecting attention from anything too personal.

 

“Really?” Another woman, her voice laced with genuine curiosity, leaned in. “That sounds fascinating. Were your parents in the military or something?”

 

The question, well-meaning as it was, made Rio pause for a moment longer. It was an easy assumption for someone like her—someone who had moved from place to place as a child—but it wasn’t quite right. Rio’s expression flickered, just for an instant, as she considered how to respond without getting too personal.

 

“Not exactly,” she replied, her voice still smooth but a little more guarded, the walls going up just a fraction. “I spent a lot of time moving around before I finally settled with Lilia—my adoptive mom.”

 

At the mention of Lilia, a softening seemed to come over Rio. The name brought a warmth that contrasted sharply with the cool, measured tones she’d adopted. She smiled more genuinely now, her voice carrying a tenderness that was hard to hide. “She’s been everything to me,” she said, a note of true affection slipping into her words.

 

The man in the blazer blinked, his attention sharpening, clearly intrigued. “Adoptive mom?” His tone was curious, but something in his eyes betrayed a lack of tact. “So what about before that?”

 

The question hung in the air, heavier than she anticipated. Rio felt her pulse quicken, the air around her seeming to grow thicker. For a split second, she froze, the weight of the moment pressing down on her. Her grip tightened around her flute of champagne as she sought to compose herself, her pulse quickening at the question she’d known might come up. Agatha’s hand subtly came to rest on her elbow, a silent gesture of support.

 

Rio’s breath caught in her chest. She didn’t want to answer that question. Not here. Not now. But she forced herself to speak, to push through the discomfort.

 

“Oh, you know,” she said with a small, dismissive laugh, trying to play it off as if it were no big deal. “I was in the foster care system. Moved around a lot, met a lot of interesting people.” She glanced down at her drink for a moment, then back up at Agatha, who gave her a reassuring nod—silent, but full of understanding.

 

Rio took a deep breath, her gaze softening as she continued. “But Lilia took me in when I was a teenager, and she’s been the closest thing to home I’ve ever had.” Her voice grew quieter, more sincere, as the depth of the truth settled in her words.

 

For a moment, the room was silent. The guests, caught off guard, didn’t quite know how to respond. Rio could feel the shift in the air, the discomfort hanging like a thick fog that threatened to obscure the easy-flowing conversation from before. The man in the blazer seemed at a loss for words, his mouth opening as if he might say something—anything—but he quickly closed it again, unsure of what was appropriate.

 

Before the moment could stretch into something awkward, Agatha smoothly interjected, her voice as warm and composed as ever. “Lilia is wonderful,” she said, her tone light yet firm, guiding the conversation away from any lingering discomfort. “She’s not only been a mother to Rio but to me as well. I think we both hit the jackpot with her.”

 

Agatha’s words, as always, were impeccably timed, and the conversation effortlessly shifted back to lighter topics. The tension in the room began to ease as the guests seemed to absorb the redirection, though the eyes still lingered on Rio for a beat longer than she would have liked.

 

Rio, feeling the weight lift just slightly, relaxed marginally. Her posture softened, and though her smile returned, it wasn’t quite as guarded as it had been moments before. She glanced at Agatha, whose hand remained steady on her arm, offering a silent, unwavering support. Rio’s pulse steadied as she let herself settle into the moment, finding comfort in the familiar warmth of Agatha’s touch. 

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

TBC - Part 2 next chapter

Dinner Party - Part II

Chapter Notes

Part II

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

O dark dark dark. They all go into the dark,

The vacant interstellar spaces, the vacant into the vacant,

The captains, merchant bankers, eminent men of letters,

The generous patrons of art, the statesmen and the rulers,

Distinguished civil servants, chairmen of many committees,

Industrial lords and petty contractors, all go into the dark.

 

                  (T. S Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

 

Just before dinner was served, Rio found herself wandering through the grand hallways of the house. She had slipped away from the lively crowd of guests under the pretense of needing something from her coat pocket, but in truth, she just needed a moment to breathe and escape the evening’s stress.

 

Rio walked slowly down a hallway, the soft click of her heels muffled by the thick Persian rug beneath her feet. The hallway was adorned with an array of ornate paintings, each frame capturing moments of history and beauty that contrasted sharply with the unsettling turbulence stirring within her. As she paused before each painting, her gaze lingered for a moment, drawing strength from their silent elegance. It was a brief respite, an attempt to steady herself before she rejoined the gathering in the dining room.

 

But as she neared the kitchen, the faint sounds of voices—low and hushed—drifted out through the slightly ajar door. Rio froze in her tracks, her curiosity piqued by the mention of her name. She hadn’t intended to overhear anything, but the words reached her all the same, slipping through the crack in the door like an unwelcome whisper.

 

“I just don’t get it,” a woman said, her tone biting and dismissive. “Agatha is brilliant—brilliant. She could have anyone, but instead, she’s… what? Dating her student? It’s not just inappropriate. It’s unprofessional. It’s pathetic.”

 

The words cut through the air like a blade, and Rio felt her chest tighten. Her pulse quickened, her heart already racing in the thick silence of the hallway.

 

“And not just any student,” a man’s voice chimed in, mocking and disdainful. “Look at her. She’s a kid, for god’s sake. Barely out of whatever system she came from. A foster kid who’s probably been scrapping her way through life since she could walk. She sees someone like Agatha and thinks, ‘Here’s my ticket out.’ It’s not hard to figure out what’s going on here. Nothing but a broken past to fall back on.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, her hands trembling at her sides. She could feel the sting of their words all over again. The years of rejection, the countless times she’d been told by a family they couldn’t keep her, none of that was new, but hearing it now, about her relationship with Agatha, hit like a fist to the gut. A foster kid with nothing to offer. That was all they saw. A foster kid. They didn’t even say it with pity—just contempt, as if her childhood, her entire life before now, was some shameful blemish she’d never escape.

 

Rio’s stomach twisted in a painful knot, her breath catching in her throat. The words felt like a slap—each one leaving a bruise, even though she wasn’t sure why she let them hurt so much. But they did. The sting was real, sharper than she expected. She wasn’t some innocent, naïve girl. She was used to rejection, to being looked down on—but this felt like a fresh wound.

 

“And Agatha?” the woman continued, her voice low but filled with a bitter edge. “She’s smart, sure, but this is reckless. She’s a strong, independent woman who could have anyone, but instead she’s with some poor, confused little orphan who also happens to be her student. It’s honestly embarrassing, it looks like a charity case. And what kind of example is she setting for her son? Dating someone like that.”

 

The man’s voice chimed in again, the disgust almost palpable. “Exactly. It’s wrong,” he said with a mocking laugh. “You’d think she’d know better. She’s too good for this kind of mess. Can you imagine what people would say if this got out? ‘Oh, look, Dr. Harkness, brilliant scholar, seduces her poor, vulnerable student.’ That’s what everyone will think. It’s gross. It’s unprofessional. It’s… trashy.”

 

Rio’s breath quickened, her vision blurring with tears she refused to let fall. She couldn’t decide what hurt more—the way they spoke about Agatha, as though their relationship was some kind of sordid scandal, or the way they dismissed her, reducing her entire existence to her past.

 

Her body tensed as the words rattled around in her mind like poison. She stood frozen in place, every part of her wanting to push open the door, to confront them, to demand they take their words back. To tell them they didn’t know her, didn’t understand Agatha, didn’t understand the kind of bond they shared.

 

But then, she could picture Agatha’s voice in her mind, soft but firm, urging her to stay calm. “Take a breath, love. Let them talk. They don’t know us. It’s only two people’s opinion. They don’t understand what we have, and they never will.”

 

A slow, shaky breath escaped her lips. Rio closed her eyes for a moment, her pulse thudding in her ears as she fought to steady herself. It wasn’t worth the confrontation. Not now. Not when the evening was already so delicate.

 

With a deep, deliberate breath, Rio took a step back, her heels barely making a sound on the polished wooden floor as she turned away from the kitchen. She moved quietly down the hallway, her face composed, but the storm in her chest still raging. Each step felt heavier than the last, her heart pounding in her chest like a drumbeat of defiance and hurt, but she held her head high.

 

By the time she reached the dining room, the smile on her face was in place—calm, measured, carefully crafted—but her thoughts churned restlessly beneath the surface. The voices that had spoken so cruelly still echoed in her mind, and for a brief moment, she wondered if she was enough. If she truly belonged in Agatha’s world.

 

But then, as she entered the room and saw Agatha across the space, her warm gaze instantly locking with hers, something shifted. Agatha’s quiet strength, her unwavering support, wrapped around Rio like a protective cloak, steadying her in ways that words never could.

 

“Hey, love,” Agatha murmured softly as Rio sat down beside her, the warmth in her voice pulling Rio’s focus back to the present.

 

“Hi,” Rio replied, her voice smooth and controlled, a stark contrast to the storm churning beneath the surface. She leaned in closer, as though sharing a secret, seeking the calm that always seemed to radiate from Agatha. The quiet strength in her touch, the unwavering certainty in her gaze, was enough to steady her for a moment.

 

“Everything okay?” Agatha asked, her eyes narrowing slightly with concern, reading Rio like an open book despite the practiced calm Rio wore on her face.

 

Rio’s chest tightened, but she gave a quick nod, a smile tugging at the corner of her lips, though it didn’t quite reach her eyes. “Of course. Just needed a little breather,” she said, the words flowing easily despite the weight behind them.

 

Agatha didn’t press. She knew Rio well enough by now to understand that sometimes, space was what was needed most. But that didn’t stop her from reaching out under the table, her hand finding Rio’s with quiet urgency. Her fingers interlaced with Rio’s in a gesture so simple yet profound—an unspoken promise of solidarity.

 

As the conversation flowed around them, Rio did her best to engage, her smile polite, her responses well-rehearsed. She nodded when appropriate, offering the occasional laugh, but her thoughts remained anchored elsewhere. The voices in the kitchen, sharp and cutting, continued to echo in her mind like a relentless drumbeat. The words stung, each one sharper than the last, swirling and twisting in her chest. They didn’t know her. They didn’t understand her, or Agatha, or the depth of what they shared. But still, the hurt lingered, like a shadow that wouldn’t quite lift.

 

She gripped Agatha’s hand under the table a little tighter, grounding herself in the feel of her touch. She didn’t owe anyone here an explanation—she knew that, and yet, the weight of their stares, the quiet judgment hanging in the air, made her wonder if it was a truth they would ever accept.

 

The room hummed with the sounds of a well-to-do gathering: the soft clink of silverware against fine china, the quiet murmur of polite conversation, the flicker of candlelight casting dancing shadows over the immaculate table. The centerpiece of fresh flowers, their vibrant colors almost mocking in their innocence, stood proudly in the middle. The scent of roasted meats and delicate sauces filled the air, but it might as well have been distant, as if Rio were looking through a pane of glass at the whole scene, disconnected from it all.

 

Agatha, however, couldn’t seem to focus on any of it.

 

Her gaze was locked on Rio, unwavering, as though trying to decipher the distance between them that had grown in the span of a few minutes. Rio, her back straight, her posture impeccable, moved through the motions of the dinner with practiced ease. She answered questions with the precision Agatha had come to expect from her—sharp, intelligent, thoughtful. But there was something in the air around her that Agatha couldn’t ignore, a shift, a subtle weight pulling her down.

 

Agatha watched as Rio cut into her food, her movements almost too careful, as though each action was deliberate, controlled, as though she were trying to hold herself together piece by piece. Her gaze was often trained on her plate, her focus drifting inward, away from the conversation, away from the room. Agatha’s brow furrowed slightly as she watched Rio glance up, offering the polite smile she always wore in these situations, but it was a mask, and Agatha knew it. The smile didn’t reach her eyes; those eyes, usually so bright, were clouded with something Agatha couldn’t name but felt deeply.

 

It pained her to see it. To see the woman she loved, so vibrant, so full of life, retreating into herself in a room full of people who could never understand.

 

Under the table, Agatha gave her hand another squeeze, a quiet gesture meant to remind Rio that she was there, that she always would be, even when the weight of the world felt too heavy. Even when the judgment of others felt unbearable.

 

Rio’s fingers twitched in response, a small but telling sign that she was still tethered to Agatha, still holding on. But Agatha knew her well enough to recognize the strain in Rio’s movements. Rio was a fighter, a survivor, but tonight, the fight felt like it had been taken out of her, like she was simply enduring the evening, one moment at a time.

 

Then she saw it.

 

A single tear, almost imperceptible, traced down the curve of Rio’s cheek, catching the candlelight before it fell silently to her chin. Her hand shot up in reflex, swiping it away quickly, as though trying to erase any evidence that it had ever been there. But the damage had been done. Agatha’s stomach tightened, an icy chill sweeping through her. The suddenness of it left her breathless. What had caused that?

 

Agatha’s pulse quickened. She reached for her glass, her fingers shaking ever so slightly, the cool touch of the crystal against her skin doing nothing to quench that moment of panic. But she couldn’t let it take over. Not yet. Not in front of everyone.

 

She leaned in closer, her body shifting toward Rio. Her voice was a soft murmur, meant only for Rio’s ears, her concern wrapped in gentle words. “Are you okay, my love?”

 

Rio blinked rapidly, the faintest glimmer of surprise in her eyes before the practiced smile appeared on her lips, a mask so familiar it almost fooled Agatha. “I’m fine,” she murmured, her voice just a little too steady, a little too rehearsed.

 

Agatha’s heart clenched. She knew better than to believe it. She saw past the words, the smile, the careful composure. Without missing a beat, she let her gaze sweep around the table. Most of the guests were caught up in a heated discussion about the merits of various wine pairings—thankfully, a topic so banal that no one seemed to notice the shift in the air. Lowering her voice further, Agatha pressed again, her tone gentle but unyielding. “Did something happen, darling?”

 

Rio’s hand, cool and hesitant, brushed against Agatha’s under the table. It was the smallest of gestures, but to Agatha, it spoke volumes. Rio shook her head, a subtle movement, her eyes cast downward as if the simple act of meeting Agatha’s gaze might reveal too much. “Not here,” she whispered, her voice tight with a barely concealed plea for patience. “Please.”

 

Agatha’s eyes softened, her pulse thudding in her ears, but she nodded without hesitation, biting back the instinct to push further. She could feel the weight of the room pressing in on them, but more than that, she could feel the weight of Rio’s discomfort, heavy and unspoken. It threatened to suffocate them both, but Agatha would hold it together. She would wait until they were alone, where Rio could unravel without anyone watching.

 

For now, she could do something else.

 

Her fingers found Rio’s thigh beneath the table, a quiet promise that she wouldn’t let go. She let her hand rest there, not too tight but not too light, a steadying presence in the midst of everything that felt off-balance. It wasn’t much, but it was enough for the moment. Every time Rio shifted in her seat, Agatha’s hand subtly adjusted to keep contact, a silent anchor in the storm swirling inside Rio.

 

The rest of the meal passed in a blur, the voices around them fading into a distant hum. Agatha kept her focus on Rio, her attention razor-sharp, the quiet tension in her body palpable. Each time Rio responded to a question, her voice was perfectly controlled, but Agatha could see the cracks—the small, unspoken things that flickered in her eyes, the stiffness in her movements. She was here physically, but her heart was somewhere far away, locked up in a place Agatha couldn’t reach… yet.

 

Agatha’s gaze never wavered, and though no one mentioned it, she could feel the others beginning to notice. Her intensity was unmistakable, her focus on Rio sharper than anything else in the room. But she didn’t care. She couldn’t afford to care. Not when she could feel the pain radiating off Rio in waves. Whatever had happened to cause that tear, whatever had triggered that raw vulnerability, Agatha would not allow her to face it alone. Not tonight. Not ever.

 

The evening dragged on, the noise of the room a distant echo in Agatha’s ears as she tried to piece together what was going on behind Rio’s walls. What had she seen? What had she heard? Why had it shaken her so deeply? There were too many unanswered questions, but Agatha knew one thing for sure: Rio wasn’t just sitting beside her—she was holding herself together with the same quiet strength she always did, but it was fraying at the edges.

 

As the dessert plates were cleared and the wine glasses refilled, Agatha’s concern for Rio deepened. The younger woman’s subdued demeanor hadn’t lifted, and though Rio kept up her polite facade, Agatha could see the tension in her shoulders and the way her hands fidgeted with the hem of her napkin. Rio was barely holding it together.

 

Agatha’s chest tightened with an instinctual need to protect her, to get her out of this suffocating space. She didn’t know what had happened, what words or looks had pushed Rio to retreat into herself, but the evening had gone on long enough.

 

She glanced at Rio again, her heart aching with every subtle shift in her posture, before Agatha made her decision. She couldn’t let this continue.

 

Raising a hand to her temple, Agatha feigned a wince, her fingers pressing lightly against the side of her head. She let out a soft, exaggerated groan that caught the attention of several guests. The room fell into a momentary silence, heads turning in concern.

 

“Agatha, are you alright?” One of her old friends, a woman who had been too busy discussing her latest trip to Italy only moments before, now leaned forward with furrowed brows, concern etched across her face.

 

“I think I’ve overdone it tonight,” Agatha replied, her voice laced with a balance of apology and resolve. She maintained an air of practiced grace even as her mind raced. “It’s been a long day, and I feel a migraine coming on. I’m so sorry to cut the evening short, but I don’t want to risk making it worse.”

 

She offered a weary smile, a touch of vulnerability seeping through despite her careful control. Then, under the table, her fingers found Rio’s hand, squeezing it gently but firmly. “We should head home.”

 

The response was immediate, and Madeline – the good perfect hostesss - quickly stood and made her way over to them. “Of course, Agatha,” she said with a soft nod, her voice symapathetic. “Don’t worry about it. You’ve had a lot on your plate lately, I’m sure. Take care of yourself.”

 

The words were kind, but they felt far too superficial for Agatha’s taste. She didn’t need their sympathy. What she needed was to get Rio out of here, away from all of this.

 

As they moved to gather their things and say their goodbyes, Agatha’s eyes remained focused on Rio, scanning her face for any signs of relief. The younger woman’s brow furrowed slightly at the sudden change in course, confusion flashing across her features. But Agatha didn’t give her the chance to question it. She caught her gaze and gave a subtle, reassuring look—just go with it.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment. The politeness was still there, of course, and Rio offered the expected smiles to those around them, but Agatha could feel the weight of her silence, her body language still tightly coiled, as though she was bracing herself against something she couldn’t control.

 

Once outside, the cold night air hit them like a wave, the sudden contrast between the warmth of the house and the crisp night drawing a small breath from Agatha. She waited until they reached the car, then stopped, her movements deliberate as she turned toward Rio.

 

Gently, Agatha cupped Rio’s cheek with one hand, her thumb brushing the soft skin beneath her eye. “Let’s get you home, okay?” she murmured, her voice a soothing whisper, meant only for Rio.

 

For a moment, Rio just stood there, her eyes a little too wide, as though she was unsure of how to respond to the tenderness in Agatha’s touch. Then, Rio leaned into the palm resting against her cheek. It was a subtle movement, but to Agatha, it spoke volumes.

 

When Rio finally nodded, it was almost imperceptible, but it was enough. 

 

Agatha started the engine, the silence in the car feeling heavy but not uncomfortable. She reached over, resting a hand on Rio’s thigh as she drove. She didn’t want to push, not now—not when Rio was so clearly carrying something heavy, something that hadn’t yet found its way into words.

 

Rio turned her head slightly, her gaze meeting Agatha’s, and Agatha saw the shimmer in her eyes—the silent turmoil she was fighting to keep hidden. Her lips parted, but for a moment, no sound came. Agatha knew that Rio didn’t need to say anything just yet.

 

“Thank you,” Rio’s voice came, small and fragile, barely above a whisper. The words hung in the air between them, a soft thread of gratitude that didn’t need to be said but was anyway. It was all Agatha needed to hear to understand that Rio was holding onto something, something difficult, something painful, but that Rio knew, without a doubt, she didn’t have to face it alone.

 

Her eyes never left the road, but her focus was on Rio, on the unspoken, the things that couldn’t be voiced just yet. Agatha didn’t need Rio to speak now; she needed to get her home, to a place where Rio could breathe again, where the weight of the world didn’t press so hard against her chest. A place where she could be herself, without fear of judgment, without any expectation but the comfort of Agatha’s presence.

 

They drove in silence for a few more miles, the rhythm of the road beneath the tires soothing in its predictability. It was a kind of peace, the kind that came with knowing they were heading home. Agatha pulled the car into a quiet spot by the side of the road, away from the noise and lights of the city, and she let the engine die down. The sudden hush left the air thick with anticipation.

 

She was still, watching Rio’s profile, waiting. Her gaze softened, no longer the commanding force she often wore in public, but something gentler, a quiet insistence, laced with concern. Her fingers gripped the steering wheel tightly, but she didn’t reach for Rio just yet. Not until Rio was ready.

 

“Rio,” Agatha said, her voice soft, but steady. It was more of an invitation than a demand. “What happened back there? Talk to me.”

 

For a long moment, Rio didn’t respond. Her eyes remained fixed on the dashboard, staring ahead into nothingness. Her fingers dug into the fabric of the seat as if grounding herself against something she couldn’t escape. Her lips were pressed tightly together, a small, almost imperceptible tremor passing through her.

 

Agatha waited, patient, never pushing, but never looking away. She wanted to give Rio the time she needed to process, but she also wanted to make it clear that Agatha wouldn’t leave her alone in this. Not now. Not ever.

 

Minutes passed, and the silence in the car stretched between them, but Agatha’s hand remained on the wheel, steady, ready to move, ready to reach out when Rio was ready. She didn’t rush it. She couldn’t rush it. This wasn’t a battle for time; it was a battle for trust.

 

Finally, Rio let out a breath, deep and shaky, her hand leaving the seat as it slowly moved to her lap. She still didn’t meet Agatha’s gaze, but the tension in her body shifted, just a little. Agatha could feel it, that small change, the subtle relaxation that told her Rio was starting to let go. Slowly, cautiously, Rio finally spoke.

 

“I—I overheard some of your friends,” Rio began, her voice trembling as the words started to come out. She pulled her knees up to her chest, hugging them tightly as though trying to make herself smaller, to disappear into the comfort of her own body. Her forehead rested against her knees, and the first tear slid down her cheek, the silent weight of it breaking through her composure. “In the kitchen… they were talking about us.” She paused, her breath shallow and jagged, struggling to find the right words, but they came too quickly, too harshly. “They were saying things about us… about me.”

 

Agatha’s heart lurched painfully in her chest. Every instinct in her wanted to pull Rio close, shield her from this hurt. But she stayed still, her grip on the steering wheel tightening, trying to keep her own composure so she could be the calm one, the steady one. Her heart was a whirlwind of protective fury, but she focused on Rio’s words.

 

“What kind of things, love?” Agatha asked, her voice now firm, a gentle edge of protectiveness creeping in. She couldn’t hide the concern that threaded through her tone—this was more than just overheard gossip. Rio was hurting, and that was something Agatha couldn’t stand.

 

“They… they said it was inappropriate,” Rio continued, the words coming out slower now, as though they were fighting their way through the rising tide of emotion. Her eyes, once so vibrant and full of life, were now glassy with tears, her voice barely above a whisper. “They… they said I’m just some street kid,” Rio continued, her voice cracking slightly. She didn’t meet Agatha’s eyes, staring instead at her own hands twisted together in her lap. “That I’m nothing. That I’m using you to… to climb out of where I came from. Like I’m some charity case you decided to take in. They said I’m… not good enough for you.”

 

Her words came faster now, tumbling out as if she could outrun the weight of them. “And that you’re… ruining your reputation. That you should be embarrassed. That I’m… trashy. That you’re setting a bad example for Nicky by being with me. Because I’m your student. Because I’m…”

 

Her voice broke, and she sucked in a trembling breath, blinking back the tears that threatened to spill. “Because I’m nothing but some desperate, broken foster kid who doesn’t deserve to be here. That’s what they think, Agatha.”

 

Finally, Rio looked up, her dark eyes brimming with unshed tears. “Is that what people are always going to think about me? About us?”

 

Agatha’s heart dropped into her stomach, the protective surge of anger rising up like a tidal wave. She could feel the heat in her chest, her hand clenching around the wheel so tightly her knuckles turned white. But she forced herself to take a deep breath, to hold back the flood of emotion threatening to spill over. She had to stay calm for Rio, for this moment. The last thing Rio needed was more anger, more tension. But inside, Agatha’s emotions were a tornado—rage, frustration, and an intense desire to lash out, to shield Rio from this cruel judgment.

 

How dare they? How could they say these things? How could they make Rio feel this way? Her mind screamed in disbelief, the injustice of it all burning inside her.

 

But as she glanced over at Rio, her love—so small, so vulnerable in that moment, her face still trembling with uncertainty—Agatha’s fury started to dissipate, replaced by an overwhelming urge to comfort her. Rio’s body language screamed of the doubt and the pain that had been thrust upon her, and it crushed Agatha to see it. She knew Rio carried so much weight, so much of herself wrapped up in the opinions of others, and the last thing Agatha would ever allow was for those words to fester in her heart.

 

She didn’t want Rio to see her angry, didn’t want her to think it was her fault, but the protective instinct in Agatha was like a fire raging inside her. She wanted to tear down anyone who made Rio feel small, who made her question herself.

 

But Agatha knew better than to let the anger take over. This wasn’t about fighting Rio’s battles for her; this was about reassuring Rio, showing her that she was not alone, that she was not defined by the cruel words of others.

 

Rio’s voice was quieter now, almost fragile, as if the weight of her own thoughts were threatening to crush her. “I know I’m young,” she murmured, her words trembling. “I know I’m not… I’m not like you. I’m not as experienced, or mature, or… anything.” Her eyes flickered to Agatha, the vulnerability in them raw and open, as though she was standing on the edge of a cliff, unsure whether to jump or step back. “What if they’re right, Agatha? What if I’m not the right person for you? What if you need someone more than me?”

 

The words hit Agatha like a physical blow, and her chest tightened painfully, the very thought of Rio doubting herself so deeply stirring a fierce protectiveness in her heart. She couldn’t stand it, couldn’t bear the sight of Rio questioning her worth when Agatha knew, deep in her soul, just how much she meant to her. Rio was everything to Agatha, more than enough in ways she couldn’t even put into words.

 

Seeing the anguish on Rio’s face, Agatha’s heart raced. She refused to let Rio spiral into this doubt, refused to let her carry the weight of those insecurities alone.

 

Without a word, Agatha shifted in her seat, moving closer to Rio. She didn’t wait for permission, didn’t hesitate. She gently pulled Rio into her lap, cradling her with the kind of tenderness that only she could offer.

 

“Hey, look at me,” Agatha said, her voice steady but filled with all the conviction in the world. She tilted Rio’s chin up, forcing her to meet her gaze. “What they said, it’s not true. Not a word of it.”

 

Rio looked at her, still vulnerable, but Agatha could see her searching her face for truth, for reassurance. Agatha leaned in close, her forehead gently resting against Rio’s as she spoke, her words full of force and determination.

 

“Those people, my so-called ‘friends,’ they couldn’t be more wrong. You’re not just good enough for me, Rio. You are everything I need. You are more than enough—more than I ever could have dreamed of.”

 

She tightened her hold, her voice lowering, but no less intense. “And if they can’t see that, then they’re not the kind of people I want in my life anyway.”

 

“But I’m not…” Rio started, her voice still trembling.

 

“Shh,” Agatha interrupted, her thumb brushing the back of Rio’s hand in a calming motion. “I don’t care what they think, or what they say. You are everything to me. Don’t you dare believe anyone who tells you otherwise.”

 

She paused, allowing the weight of her words to settle between them. “As for being young…” Agatha trailed off, giving Rio a pointed look. “I don’t need someone with more experience, Rio. I don’t need someone older, or more ‘mature.’ I need you. I’ve never needed anyone more in my life than I need you.”

 

Rio’s eyes welled up, her lips quivering. “I don’t want to hurt you or your life, Agatha,” she whispered, her voice breaking. “Sometimes, I just feel like I don’t fit in, like I don’t belong anywhere or with anyone,” she whispered, her voice barely audible. “Like I’m always going to be the one who doesn’t belong.”

 

Agatha pulled her even closer, her hands gently cupping Rio’s face to lift it so they were eye to eye. “Listen to me,” she said softly but firmly. “You belong with me, Rio. You belong in my life, in our life. I’m not going anywhere. I’m here. I’m not just your professor, I’m your partner, your family, whatever you want me to be. And no one—no one—can take that from us. Not them, not anyone. You belong here. Not because of where you came from or what you’ve been through, but because of who you are. You fought to get here. You earned every piece of the life you’re building. And you are more than enough.”

 

Rio clung to her, her body shaking with the release of every insecurity, every fear she had been carrying, and Agatha held her tighter, wrapping her arms around her with a fierce tenderness.

 

“I’m sorry,” Rio whispered, her voice breaking with the weight of her own vulnerability. “I’m sorry I’m so… insecure.”

 

Agatha’s heart twisted with affection and protectiveness as she gently brushed the hair from Rio’s face, her fingers trailing softly down her skin. “You’re mine,” Agatha whispered, her lips brushing lightly against Rio’s forehead, the tenderness of the gesture deepening the sincerity of her words. “And I’m yours. That’s all that matters. Don’t you dare apologize for being you.”

 

Rio’s chest hitched in a breath, the sobs coming more freely now, but Agatha didn’t flinch. She held her close, letting Rio cry, letting her release all the pain and doubt she had been carrying. It wasn’t sadness—Agatha knew that. It was a mixture of relief and love, of finally being able to lean on someone who was strong enough to carry the weight, even for a little while.

 

Agatha kissed her forehead again, slowly rocking her in her lap. “You’re perfect, Rio. You’ve always been perfect. And you don’t need to change a thing for anyone—least of all me.”

 

Rio wrapped her arms tight around her, the distress in her expression slowly melting away, replaced by a peace that could only come from knowing she was truly loved, truly seen.

 

“I love you too, Agatha,” she murmured, her voice steady but filled with emotion. “I’m sorry I doubted us.”

 

Agatha smiled softly, her heart full. “Don’t apologize, love. We’re in this together.”

 

The silence settled over them, a quiet comfort in the wake of all that had been said. Agatha felt her protective instincts flare once more, the image of anyone making Rio feel less than she was igniting a fire deep within her. The thought of those people who had dared to make Rio question her worth made Agatha’s blood boil with a fierce protectiveness. “We can go back,” she offered, the anger evident in her voice. “I’ll set them straight—let them know what kind of person you are.”

 

But Rio shook her head, her voice steady but with a touch of vulnerability that tugged at Agatha’s heart. “No,” Rio said softly. “I’ve been humiliated enough for one night. I don’t want to go back there. Not tonight.”

 

Agatha immediately softened, her anger melting away at Rio’s words. She knew her love was strong, but she also knew when Rio needed to be protected from more than just the harsh words of others. “Of course,” Agatha said gently, her hand brushing over Rio’s cheek in a comforting gesture. “You’re right. We don’t need to go back. Let’s just go home. Just you, me, and Nicky.”

 

Rio let out a breath, as if a weight had been lifted. “Thank you,” she whispered, her voice a little lighter now. “I just want to be with you, Agatha. I don’t need anything else.”

 

Agatha’s heart swelled with tenderness, a wave of love crashing over her as she gazed at Rio. “And you will be with me, love,” she said softly, her words rich with promise. “ Let’s go home, get some rest, and just be together. You deserve it.”

 

With that, Agatha started the car again, the warmth of her presence and her love enveloping them both. The night had been difficult, but as they headed toward home, the promise of peace and comfort at the end of the day was all that mattered. They had each other—and nothing would change that.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

Back to fluff next chapter, I promise !

I’ll reply to your comments very soon—I’ve read them, and I absolutely love them! This week has been brutal, and I haven’t had a chance to write a single word for this story. Instead, I’ve been stuck writing endless, massive dissertations during in-person exams that last six or seven hours each—and I still have two more to go before the week is over. Thankfully, I’ve got a few chapters ready to go!

LOVE YOU ALL

A Mystery

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Words, after speech, reach

Into the silence. Only by the form, the pattern,

Can words or music reach

The stillness. (…)

                 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

Agatha sat at her desk in the quiet solitude of her university office, the faint yellow glow of a single desk lamp illuminating the scattered papers before her. Outside the window, the campus lay draped in darkness, the occasional flicker of streetlights casting long, shifting shadows. The hum of the building’s heating system filled the stillness, a low, constant reminder of the late hour. She adjusted her glasses, her fingers absently brushing a loose strand of hair from her face as her sharp eyes scanned the finalized program for the poetry reading night—an annual tradition that had become a cornerstone of the English department’s culture.

 

The event, steeped in decades of tradition, was a celebration of creativity and vulnerability. It had been designed to foster camaraderie between students and faculty, giving them a rare opportunity to connect through the raw power of verse. Agatha had inherited the responsibility of organizing it around five years ago, and despite the logistical hurdles, it remained a task she took pride in. There was something magical about witnessing hesitant students find their voices, their emotions spilling out into words that filled the room with a quiet intensity. She always left the event feeling humbled and inspired.

 

Her red pen hovered over the program’s schedule as she made a final note, double-checking the lineup to ensure no one had been inadvertently left out. The faculty readings were strategically placed between student performances, a decision she had learned over the years helped ease nerves and keep the energy steady. 

 

She tucked the program into her worn leather briefcase, its edges softened from years of use, and leaned back in her chair, the tension in her shoulders easing for the first time all day. She exhaled deeply, letting her head rest against the high back of the chair as her thoughts drifted from the intricacies of the event to the warm haven that awaited her at home. Tomorrow would be a long day of coordinating sound checks, arranging seating, and managing last-minute adjustments, but tonight, she had something far more precious waiting for her—a quiet evening with Nicky and Rio.

 

Her lips softened into a smile at the thought. Nicky would likely be sprawled out on the living room floor petting Señor Scratchy, his smile soft in adoration for his new best friend. And Rio—her vibrant, unpredictable Rio—would probably be experimenting with a new recipe in the kitchen, or floating around her plants, tending to them - her movements a dance of energy and grace. The image filled Agatha with a warmth that no event, no matter how prestigious, could replicate.

 

The days following the debacle of the dinner party had been a whirlwind of emotions. Agatha had been left reeling, quietly devising ways to make them pay, while Rio had grown slightly more clingy than usual, seeking reassurance more frequently than before, and Agatha had been happy to provide. Now that things had gone back to normal, all Agatha could think of as she was about to make her way home was reuniting with her son and her lover—the only two anchors in her chaotic world.

 

As Agatha gathered her belongings, her eyes landed on a small, framed photograph tucked neatly in the corner of her desk. It was a snapshot from last month, a moment she treasured more than she could put into words. The image showed Nicky perched securely on Rio’s hip, his little legs wrapped snugly around her waist. His head rested on her shoulder, the angle of his face soft and relaxed, exuding the quiet trust only a child could have. In one small hand, he clutched a juice box, the straw askew, adding a charming imperfection to the scene.

 

Rio’s face wasn’t visible; the photo had been taken from behind by Agatha herself. But even so, she was unmistakable—the cascade of dark hair tumbling down her back, the way her posture effortlessly radiated strength and care. It perfectly captured who Rio was: someone who could carry the weight of the world on her shoulders—and her whole world in her arms at the same time, all with effortless grace. Agatha couldn’t help the small, tender smile that tugged at her lips as she looked at it.

 

Standing, she slung her coat over her arm and grabbed her briefcase, her movements purposeful yet unhurried. The long day behind her dissolved into the promise of the evening ahead. As she flicked off the lamp and locked her office door, the quiet click echoed in the now empty hallway. She stepped out into the crisp night air, the campus quiet except for the distant rustle of leaves in the wind.

 

The poetry reading could wait until tomorrow. Tonight, the real poetry was waiting for her at home—in the laughter of her son, the steady love of her girlfriend, and the simple, quiet joy of being together.

 

 

The warm, inviting aroma of garlic and rosemary greeted Agatha the moment she stepped through the door, making her stomach rumble. She shrugged off her coat, hanging it on the rack near the entryway, and followed the source of the heavenly smell into the kitchen. There stood Rio, stirring a pot on the stove, her back turned but radiating the returned easy confidence that always made Agatha’s heart ache in the best way.

 

Rio’s dark hair was tied back in a loose bun, stray wisps framing her face, and she wore Agatha’s favorite apron —the one Nicky had made in school for Mother’s Day years ago. Its faded fabric, speckled with stains, told the story of countless shared meals and quick snacks. The sight of her, bathed in the golden light of their kitchen, made the stresses of Agatha’s long day melt away.

 

“You’re late,” Rio said, her voice teasing as she stirred the pot, not bothering to glance up. “Let me guess—you fell into another black hole of grading?”
