Agatha smirked, setting her leather bag on the counter with a soft thud. “Not grading, for once. I was finalizing the program for next week’s poetry reading night. It’s practically a second job at this point.”

 

Rio turned off the burner, reaching for plates to dish up their meal. “Ah, yes. The esteemed poetry night,” she said, her tone laced with playful sarcasm. “A time-honored tradition. Let me guess—endless enthusiasm from the undergrads and last-minute chaos from everyone else?”

 

Agatha chuckled, reaching for two glasses and filling them with the leftover wine they had opened two days earlier to celebrate Agatha’s new grant approval. “You’re not entirely wrong. Though, surprisingly, even a few of the PhD students are stepping up this year.” She handed one of the glasses to Rio, who finally turned to face her with a smirk that softened into something fond.

 

“Where’s Nicky?” Agatha asked, leaning against the counter as Rio set the plates on the table.

 

“He begged to go to Wanda’s,” Rio said with an affectionate roll of her eyes. “You know how Billy and Tommy are his new best friends. Wanda promised to drop him off later, so it’s just us for dinner.” She leaned down and kissed the top of Agatha’s head before settling into her chair. “What’s the lineup for the poetry night looking like?”

 

Agatha sat across from her, swirling the wine in her glass before taking a sip. “Surprisingly good. Some raw talent, some overconfidence, the usual mix. But you know,” she said, fixing Rio with a pointed look, “PhD students are encouraged to participate, you could always join in. I’ve read your work. You’d blow them all away.”

 

Rio froze for half a second, her back to Agatha, before recovering smoothly. “I don’t know,” she said, turning around with a careful shrug. “Maybe. Depends on how busy I am. I’ll see if I’m in the mood.”

 

Agatha narrowed her eyes slightly, taking a sip of her wine. “You’re usually full of opinions about the department’s events. I expected either an immediate yes or a dramatic refusal.”

 

Rio gave a small, nonchalant wave of her hand, as if brushing away Agatha’s scrutiny. “Well, it’s not like I have to, right? It’s optional for us PhD students.” She kept her voice breezy, but she could feel Agatha’s gaze linger, weighing her words.

 

“True,” Agatha replied slowly, leaning forward and resting her chin on her hand. “But you do like poetry, and I’d think you’d enjoy the chance to show off your brilliance in front of the department.”

 

Rio smirked, stabbing at her food. “Who says I need a stage for that? You already know how brilliant I am.”

 

Agatha chuckled, shaking her head. “I do, indeed. But you’re avoiding the question.”

 

Rio laughed, setting the plates on the table. “Maybe I’m trying something new. Keeping you on your toes.”

 

“Hmm,” Agatha hummed, her suspicion piqued. But she didn’t press the matter, instead taking her seat at the table.

 

Agatha studied her for a moment longer, clearly unconvinced but not willing to press further—for now. Instead, she gave a little shrug of her own, returning her attention to her plate. “Suit yourself,” she said. “But you’ll miss out on the fun.”

 

“We’ll see,” Rio replied, her tone playful, though her heart raced a little under Agatha’s scrutiny. She quickly took another bite to avoid saying too much.

 

As they ate, Rio steered the conversation toward safer territory—her dance classes, a funny story about a fellow student, and their plans for the weekend. But as the evening wore on, Agatha couldn’t shake the sense that Rio was hiding something.

 

By the time they cleared the table and settled onto the couch with tea, Rio had already disappeared into the study with a small notebook tucked under her arm. Agatha’s curiosity simmered beneath the surface, but she knew better than to pry. Whatever Rio was working on, she’d reveal it when she was ready.

 

 

Agatha leaned against the doorframe of their shared study one evening, her arms crossed as she watched Rio hunched over the desk. The soft glow of the desk lamp illuminated her tousled hair and the steady motion of her pen across the page.

 

“Burning the midnight oil again, are we?” Agatha teased, her voice light.

 

Rio jumped slightly, her hand instinctively snapping the notebook shut before turning to face her. “Oh, you know how it is,” she replied with a casual shrug. “Thesis ideas. They come at the strangest times.”

 

“Do they?” Agatha asked, arching an eyebrow. She stepped into the room, her gaze flicking to the notebook Rio had just hidden beneath her hand. “Because your actual thesis notebook is still sitting on the kitchen counter, exactly where you left it two days ago.”

 

Rio blinked, momentarily caught off guard, before letting out a soft laugh. “Okay, so maybe I’m brainstorming. Not everything has to go into that notebook, you know.”

 

Agatha hummed thoughtfully, her lips quirking into a smirk. “Hmm. Brainstorming, you say. And yet, so secretive about it.” She leaned a little closer, her fingers brushing over the notebook’s cover, but Rio pulled it protectively closer to her chest.

 

“It’s nothing exciting,” Rio insisted, her tone light but firm. “Just… preliminary notes. A mess, really. Not ready to share.”

 

Agatha straightened, her curiosity piqued further. She wasn’t used to Rio being this evasive—not with her, at least. But she also knew better than to push. Rio was stubborn, and when she was ready, she’d share.

 

“Fine,” Agatha said, stepping back with a playful sigh. “Keep your secrets. But you’re making me curious.”

 

“Curiosity killed the cat,” Rio shot back with a grin, and Agatha laughed softly.

 

“Good thing I’m a not a cat, then,” she replied, tapping her temple knowingly before turning toward the door.

 

As she left the study, Agatha couldn’t help but glance back, catching Rio reopening the notebook and scribbling again with intense focus. Whatever Rio was working on, it wasn’t her thesis—that much was certain.

 

And whatever it was, it had to be something important.

 

 

Agatha sat at the kitchen table the next morning, her coffee steaming beside her as she flipped absentmindedly through a stack of papers. Her thoughts, however, weren’t on work—they kept drifting back to Rio’s mysterious behavior over the past few days.

 

She replayed the scene from the previous evening in her mind: Rio hunched over her notebook, that protective flash in her eyes when Agatha had tried to peek at it. It wasn’t like Rio to be so secretive, especially about her writing.

 

Agatha sipped her coffee, staring at the untouched notebook still lying on the counter—Rio’s actual thesis notebook. It confirmed what she already knew: whatever Rio was working on had nothing to do with her research.

 

“Could it be for the poetry night?” she wondered aloud, setting her mug down with a soft clink. The thought lingered for a moment, filling her with a spark of intrigue. Rio was certainly capable of it—she had a poetic soul, after all. And Agatha could imagine Rio wanting to surprise her with something special.

 

But as quickly as the idea formed, Agatha dismissed it with a shake of her head.

 

“No,” she muttered. “If she were planning to read at the event, she would have told me by now.” Rio wasn’t shy about her talents, and she had never been one to keep something like that under wraps—at least not from Agatha.

 

And yet… Agatha couldn’t entirely shake the feeling that the answer was right in front of her, just out of reach.

 

Her thoughts were interrupted by the sound of Rio’s footsteps padding into the kitchen. She looked up to find her partner rubbing sleep from her eyes, her hair a wild mess that Agatha found endearing.

 

“Good morning,” Rio mumbled, reaching for the coffee pot.

 

“Morning,” Agatha replied, watching her closely. She decided to test the waters again. “So, still hard at work on those ‘thesis notes’ of yours?”

 

Rio hesitated for just a fraction of a second—so brief that most people wouldn’t have noticed. But Agatha did.

 

“Yep,” Rio said breezily, pouring herself a cup of coffee. “It’s been a productive week.”

 

 

Over the next week, Rio’s behavior grew increasingly elusive, her every move laced with a secrecy that was both frustrating and endearing. She spent countless hours in their shared study, the door often left slightly ajar, as if daring Agatha to investigate. Yet every time Agatha ventured too close, Rio would snap her notebook shut with lightning speed, diverting her attention to something inconsequential—a stray pen, the edge of the desk, or her phone, which she tapped on with exaggerated concentration.

 

It was a dance of distraction that Agatha found both amusing and exasperating. “I swear, love, it’s like living with a secret agent,” she remarked one evening, leaning casually against the doorway with her arms crossed. Her tone was light, but her curiosity had been piqued beyond reason.

 

Rio didn’t look up, her pencil moving swiftly across the page of a notebook that was unmistakably new. She had started carrying it everywhere, tucking it under her arm like a prized possession.

 

“Top-secret thesis work,” Rio replied, her voice as airy as her demeanor.

 

Agatha arched a skeptical brow. “Is it? Because unless your thesis has suddenly veered into espionage, I’m finding that hard to believe. And may I remind you, Ms. Vidal, that I’m your supervisor? You’re contractually obligated to show me your work.”

 

Rio finally glanced up, flashing her a mischievous grin. “Contractually obligated? That’s rich, Professor Harkness,” she said, her tone dripping with mock formality. “Patience is a virtue, you know.”

 

Agatha let out a long, exaggerated sigh, pushing off the doorway and stepping further into the room. “You know I hate when you’re this evasive. It’s maddening.” She gestured toward the notebook, now strategically tucked beneath a neat stack of blank paper. “Are you hiding a manifesto under there? Perhaps some groundbreaking theory you’re withholding from me? Are you going to change the literary field forever and not share your discovery with me?”

 

Rio laughed, a sound that was warm and teasing. She stood, crossing the room to where Agatha lingered, and planted a quick kiss on her cheek. “You’ll survive,” she said lightly, the corners of her lips quirking into a smirk.

 

Agatha tilted her head, narrowing her eyes as if trying to read the secrets hidden behind Rio’s calm demeanor. “Oh, I’ll survive. But will you, when I inevitably find out what you’re up to?”

 

Rio only winked, slipping past her and heading toward the kitchen with a casual wave of her hand. “Tea, Professor? Maybe some chamomile to help with all that pent-up curiosity?”

 

Agatha stood in the study for a moment, staring at the abandoned desk and the neatly stacked papers. Her gaze lingered on the edge of the notebook peeking out, just enough to taunt her.

 

“Oh, you’re enjoying this far too much,” she muttered, shaking her head as she followed Rio to the kitchen, her curiosity now firmly at war with her self-restraint.

 

 

Late that night, Agatha stirred from sleep to the soft, persistent sound of a pen gliding across paper. She blinked into the dim room, her eyes adjusting to the faint golden glow of the bedside lamp. Turning her head, she found Rio sitting upright in bed, her back pressed against the headboard, knees drawn up to support a notebook. Her dark hair spilled over one shoulder, slightly disheveled from sleep, though it was clear she hadn’t done much of that tonight.

 

Rio was completely absorbed, her pen moving furiously across the page as though the words might slip away if she didn’t capture them quickly enough. Her brow was furrowed in concentration, her lips slightly parted, occasionally murmuring inaudible fragments of thought to herself.

 

For a fleeting moment, Agatha considered confronting her. She could demand to know what had consumed Rio’s attention so entirely, what had dragged her from sleep to work in the middle of the night with such obsessive focus. But as she lay there, watching Rio, listening to the rhythmic scratching of her pen, the thought dissolved.

 

There was something almost sacred about the scene. The energy Rio exuded was electric, raw, and deeply personal. It reminded Agatha of when they had first met—Rio had spoken with the same fiery intensity about her thesis topic, her fascination with the interplay of death, mortality, and timelessness in poetry. That passion had drawn Agatha in like a moth to a flame, leaving her captivated by the way Rio seemed to live and breathe her work.

 

Rio didn’t seem to notice that Agatha had woken. Her pen continued its steady rhythm, her focus unbroken. Agatha watched her for a few moments longer, marveling at how beautiful Rio looked in the soft light, utterly consumed by her work.

 

Agatha sighed quietly, sinking back into her pillow. She would let Rio have her secret, for now. The air in the room felt charged, as though disturbing Rio in this moment might shatter something fragile and profound. Agatha told herself she would wait. Rio would share her project when she was ready.

 

Still, as she closed her eyes, Agatha couldn’t quite banish the spark of curiosity flickering at the edges of her mind. The secrecy had gone on for almost a week now, and while she admired Rio’s dedication, a small part of her was beginning to feel left out of whatever had taken hold of her partner so completely.

 

Whatever you’re up to, Rio Vidal, Agatha thought as she pulled the blankets higher, it had better be worth all this suspense.

 

Eventually, Agatha drifted back into an uneasy sleep, her dreams peppered with flashes of Rio’s mysterious notebook and the tantalizing enigma of what it contained.

 

 

Agatha stood in kitchen one lazy morning before her afternoon classes, arms loosely crossed, her posture relaxed but her gaze sharp. Rio bustled around the counter with a focused energy, her movements fluid yet purposeful. A soft hum escaped her lips, punctuated by barely audible murmurs that seemed to rise and fall with a rhythm only she understood.

 

Agatha tilted her head, straining to make out the words, but all she caught were fragmented phrases—snatches of sentences that didn’t make sense on their own. Her curiosity piqued, she lingered silently, letting Rio’s unguarded moment unfold before her.

 

The rhythm of Rio’s murmurs abruptly stopped as she reached for a notebook tucked haphazardly beside the toaster. She flipped it open with practiced ease, jotted something down in hurried strokes, and snapped it shut again, tucking it back into its hiding spot before returning to the vegetables on the cutting board.

 

“Caught in the act,” Agatha quipped, her voice lilting with amusement, though her eyes gleamed with mischief.

 

Rio startled, the knife she held clattering against the cutting board. She spun around, her hand instinctively sliding over the counter to shield the notebook from view, as though Agatha hadn’t already seen it.

 

“What act?” Rio asked, her voice pitched higher than usual, her attempt at innocence betrayed by the faint flush creeping up her neck.

 

“Oh, you know,” Agatha replied with an exaggerated wave of her hand as she stepped into the kitchen, closing the distance between them. “The one where you mutter things like a poet in a trance, then scribble furiously in your little notebook and act like it’s nothing.”

 

Rio’s eyes widened slightly, but she quickly recovered, flashing a grin that didn’t quite meet her eyes. “You’re imagining things, Professor. It’s just… a habit.”

 

“Habit?” Agatha echoed, leaning casually against the counter, one brow arched in skepticism. “Funny, I don’t recall you having this habit until recently. And that notebook… it seems to have become your constant companion. I’m starting to feel a little jealous.”

 

Rio’s grin turned sheepish, and she ducked her head, focusing intently on the zucchini she was chopping. “It’s nothing serious,” she mumbled, her tone unconvincing. “Just… creative thoughts. Helps me clear my head.”

 

Agatha studied her closely, her sharp eyes catching the faint blush rising on Rio’s cheeks and the nervous way her hands moved as she resumed chopping, her rhythm slightly off. This wasn’t just playful evasion—there was something deeper at work here, something personal.

 

For the first time, Agatha found herself wondering if Rio’s secretive behavior was more than just a distraction or a quirky side project. There was a vulnerability in the way Rio guarded her notebook, an almost childlike protectiveness that softened Agatha’s initial frustration into something gentler.

 

“I see,” Agatha said softly, her voice losing its teasing edge. She reached for a glass of water on the counter and leaned against the sink, her gaze never leaving Rio.

 

For a moment, the kitchen was filled with the quiet sounds of the knife against the cutting board and the faint murmurs Rio let slip as she worked.

 

Agatha felt a tug in her chest—a strange mixture of curiosity, tenderness, and pride. Whatever Rio was working on, it clearly mattered to her deeply. And though Agatha’s natural instinct was to uncover every mystery, she knew this wasn’t the time to unravel this one.

 

She set her glass down and stepped closer, pressing a soft kiss to the crown of Rio’s head. “Whatever it is you’re working on, love, I hope it’s making you happy.”

 

Rio froze for half a beat, then leaned into the gesture, her shoulders relaxing. “It is,” she murmured, her voice quieter now, almost reverent. “Thanks for… letting me have this.”

 

Agatha smiled, her heart warming at the sincerity in Rio’s tone. “Of course,” she said simply, brushing a strand of hair from Rio’s face.

 

As she stepped back, Agatha resolved to be patient. Whatever secret Rio was guarding, she would share it when she was ready. For now, Agatha would content herself with the mystery, savoring the glimpse of Rio’s passion and the quiet beauty of this moment in their kitchen.

 

 

But her resolve was hard to hold on to. That evening, Agatha arrived home to the comforting hum of domestic chaos. The scent of basil and cooked tomatoes wafted from the kitchen, mingling with the soft rhythm of Rio’s humming. In the living room, Nicky was sprawled on the carpet, surrounded by a colorful sea of building blocks. Señor Scratchy hopped lazily around him, occasionally nudging a stray block with his nose.

 

Agatha set her bag down by the door and leaned against the living room entryway, her lips curling into a fond smile as she watched her son’s tiny fingers carefully construct what looked like an intricate tower. The focus on his face was adorable—his tongue poked out slightly, his brow furrowed in concentration. Agatha saw it as an opportunity.

 

“Hello, my little architect,” Agatha called softly, a mischievous glint in her eyes.

 

Nicky didn’t look up, too engrossed in balancing a precariously placed block at the top of his tower. “Hi, Mama,” he mumbled, his tone distracted.

 

Agatha crouched down beside him, her presence finally breaking his concentration. “That’s quite the masterpiece,” she said, running her fingers lightly over Señor Scratchy’s soft fur, who had naturally drifted towards her.

 

“It’s a castle,” Nicky explained proudly. “For Señor Scratchy to live in.”

 

“Well, Scratchy is a very lucky bunny,” Agatha replied with a smirk, her tone teasing. She picked up a stray block and added it to the base of the structure, earning an approving nod from Nicky.

 

After a moment, she leaned closer, her voice dropping into a conspiratorial whisper. “I need your help with something important.”

 

That got his attention. He turned his wide, curious eyes up to her, clutching a bright red block tightly in his small hands. “What kind of help?”

 

Agatha feigned seriousness, lowering her voice further. “It’s about Mom. She’s been acting… mysterious lately. Working on something she won’t tell me about. I thought maybe you’d know what it is.”

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled with intrigue, but the moment Agatha’s words sank in, he shook his head vigorously, his small hands now gripping two blocks as if to shield himself. “Nope! I don’t know any secrets.”

 

“Oh, come on,” Agatha said, her tone mock pleading. “You’re six and almost seven! You must know something.”

 

Nicky tilted his head in thought, his expression caught between wanting to help and fiercely guarding his loyalty. Then, as if remembering an unspoken oath, he glanced toward the kitchen, where Rio’s voice still hummed softly in the background, and set his jaw with a determination that made Agatha chuckle.

 

“Even if I knew,” he said firmly, puffing out his little chest like a knight defending a treasure, “I wouldn’t tell you.”

 

Agatha placed a hand over her heart in an exaggerated show of betrayal. “You wound me, Nicholas,” she said dramatically. “I thought we were a team!”

 

Nicky grinned, clearly pleased with himself for holding his ground. “Mom says secrets are for keeping, but only the good kind of secrets,” he said, returning to his tower. “It’s a good secret, I promise.”

 

Agatha ruffled his hair with a laugh, shaking her head at his stubbornness. “Well, it seems I’ve been outmaneuvered. I guess you’ll keep your secrets, but don’t get too comfortable—I’ll figure it out eventually.”

 

“I’m not telling!” he insisted, his voice as serious as a six-year-old’s could be.

 

Shaking her head, Agatha rose and made her way to the kitchen. She leaned against the doorframe, watching Rio stir something on the stove, her body moving in time with the tune she was humming.

 

“Well,” Agatha said with an exaggerated sigh, “it seems I won’t be getting any answers from the little spy.”

 

Rio glanced up, her eyebrow arched in amusement. “Spy?” she asked, her voice laced with curiosity.

 

“Your son,” Agatha replied, walking over to stand beside her. “I tried to extract some information about whatever secret project you’re working on, but he’s like a vault. Loyal to the end.”

 

Rio smirked, her eyes gleaming with mischief. “Good boy. He’s learning well.”

 

Agatha leaned closer, her voice softening. “Come on, love. Can’t you give me just a hint? A tiny clue?”

 

Rio turned off the burner and faced her, a playful smile curving her lips. She reached out, put both hands on Agatha's cheeks and planted a kiss right on he lips. “Some secrets are meant to stay that way,” she murmured, her voice warm and teasing.

 

Agatha groaned, throwing her head back in mock exasperation. “You’re no fun.”

 

Rio chuckled, planting her hands on her hips. “You’ll live.”

 

As Rio turned back to the stove, Agatha wrapped her arms loosely around her waist from behind, resting her chin on Rio’s shoulder. “You know,” she said softly, “whatever you’re working on—it had better be worth all this suspense.”

 

Rio glanced back at her, her smile softening. “It will be,” she promised, her tone so certain it made Agatha’s curiosity burn even brighter.

 

Agatha sighed, releasing her and stepping back to grab three glasses from the cabinet to start setting the table. For now, she’d let it go. But she couldn’t help but wonder—what was Rio planning, and why was she going to such lengths to keep it hidden?

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Tomorrow night, I’ll finally be free from exams, and I promise I’ll take the time to reply to your comments! In the meantime, let me know what you think. 😉

Seriously, I’m barely surviving over here, but those email notifications are my little pockets of joy throughout the chaos. You’re all amazing, and I love you so much!

💜💚

Poetry Night

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

That was a way of putting it—not very satisfactory:

A periphrastic study in a worn-out poetical fashion,

Leaving one still with the intolerable wrestle

With words and meanings. The poetry does not matter.

It was not (to start again) what one had expected.

What was to be the value of the long looked forward to,

Long hoped for calm, the autumnal serenity

And the wisdom of age?

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

The night of the poetry reading arrived with the usual bustle Agatha had come to associate with these events, a mixture of nervous energy and artistic anticipation. She strode briskly through the university halls, her heeled boots clicking against the polished floors, a clipboard in one hand and a stack of papers tucked securely under her arm. As she neared the English department’s main hall, the hum of activity greeted her like a familiar rhythm.

 

Students darted about, their voices rising in a symphony of preparation. A group was adjusting the chairs and aligning them with laser precision, while another fussed over the microphone stand on the small, makeshift stage. Others huddled together, whispering snippets of poetry or rehearsing their introductions with nervous energy. The air buzzed with an electric mix of nerves and excitement.

 

Agatha entered the hall with her usual imposing presence, immediately drawing the room’s attention. She scanned the space with her sharp, discerning eyes, mentally noting what still needed adjusting. As she set down her stack of papers on the registration table, she rolled up her sleeves, ready to dive into the organizational chaos.

 

“Who’s on lights?” she called, her voice carrying easily over the din.

 

“James is!” a voice piped up from the corner.

 

“Good. Make sure the dimmer’s ready for transitions between readers,” she instructed, already moving toward the stage to inspect the microphone. She crouched slightly to test it herself, her voice reverberating through the room. “Check, one, two… Perfect.”

 

She moved with purpose, offering a quick word of encouragement here, a slight adjustment to the seating arrangement there. Her presence seemed to calm the more jittery students, her confidence anchoring them. But no matter how much she immersed herself in these preparations, Agatha couldn’t shake the gnawing feeling that had settled in her chest.

 

Every few minutes, her eyes flicked toward the door. She wasn’t sure how conspicuous it was, but the compulsion was undeniable. She was waiting, hoping for a familiar figure to step through.

 

“She’ll come,” Agatha muttered under her breath, as if saying it aloud would solidify the belief.

 

Rio had mentioned she might not be able to attend. Between her demanding thesis schedule and the last-minute band rehearsal that might run late she had mentioned the night before, Agatha had tried to temper her expectations. Still, she’d seen the flicker of excitement in Rio’s eyes when Agatha first brought up the event weeks ago. She’d heard the warmth in her voice when she talked about poetry readings being a rare space where vulnerability and performance collided so beautifully. And she had the unshakable feeling that what Rio has been working on so furiously for the whole week was intimately tied to tonight.

 

It matters to her. I know it does, Agatha thought, clutching the clipboard a little tighter as she walked over to the refreshment table.

 

The minutes ticked by, and the hall began to fill with attendees. Students, professors, and a smattering of literary enthusiasts from outside the university claimed seats, creating a growing hum of anticipation. Agatha greeted them warmly, though her eyes still strayed to the entrance with every passing moment.

 

“Dr. Harkness, do you have a moment?” a student asked, pulling her back to the task at hand.

 

“Of course,” Agatha replied smoothly, forcing her focus onto the nervous young woman clutching a folded sheet of paper. She listened patiently, offering reassurance and advice, but even as she spoke, the door remained in the corner of her vision, achingly empty of Rio’s presence.

 

Agatha found herself standing at the podium, shuffling through the program – without ever taking the time or fucus to properly review anything that was in it - with a calm professionalism that belied the storm brewing inside her. The soft murmur of the gathering audience filled the room, a hum of excitement and pre-performance nerves. She adjusted the microphone, fiddled unnecessarily with her clipboard, and scanned the crowd, her eyes darting toward the entrance for what felt like the hundredth time.

 

Her attention was pulled back by a gentle tap on her shoulder. She turned to find Lily, one of her quieter students, standing there with her poem clutched tightly in trembling hands. Lily’s tall and lanky frame seemed to fold inward, her nervousness all but radiating off her.

 

“Dr. Harkness,” Lily said softly, her voice almost drowned out by the background noise. “Do you think we’ll have enough time for everyone to read? I—I don’t want to take up too much space.”

 

Agatha’s expression softened instantly. She placed a reassuring hand on Lily’s shoulder and gave her a small, encouraging smile. “Lily, this is your space as much as anyone else’s. Don’t worry about the time—we’ll make it work. Just focus on your words. They’re why we’re here.”

 

Lily nodded hesitantly, her grip on her poem relaxing just a little. “Thank you,” she murmured before retreating toward the front row, where she took a seat among a cluster of other students.

 

Agatha watched her go, her heart warmed by the student’s bravery but still weighed down by the gnawing absence she couldn’t shake. Her gaze flicked back to the door, her chest tightening at the emptiness beyond it.

 

Where is she?

 

Agatha couldn’t help but wonder, her thoughts momentarily distracted as she looked at the clock. It was nearly time for the event to begin. She checked her notes, adjusted her glasses, and tried to steady her nerves. But nothing could shake the tight feeling in her chest.

 

She made another round through the room, checking in with more students and making sure everyone was prepared. Still, no Rio.

 

She still has time.

 

Just before stepping up to the podium to start the evening, Agatha lingered at the back of the room, scanning the sea of eager faces and the entrance beyond them. The program was in her hands, but her thoughts were elsewhere, her heart pulling in two directions—toward her students and toward the empty space Rio should have occupied.

 

The hum of voices quieted as Agatha made her way to the front. She adjusted the microphone again, her fingers brushing over the cool metal as she began her opening remarks, the script she had prepared flowing smoothly from her lips.

 

And then, just as she was preparing to introduce the first reader, she heard it—a soft rustling and the quiet creak of the door opening.

 

Agatha’s words faltered for the briefest moment as her eyes darted to the back of the room.

 

There, standing in the doorway, was Rio.

 

The moment Agatha’s eyes landed on her, everything else in the room seemed to blur, like the world had shifted into slow motion. Rio was wearing a deep purple dress—that dress. Agatha knew that Rio knew purple was Agatha’s color, and seeing her in it now sent a jolt of warmth straight to Agatha’s chest. The rich hue was doing wonders for her complexion, the flowing light skirt brushing her calves with every moves, and she had paired it with boots and a jacket.

 

Her hair, styled just the way Agatha adored it, fell in soft waves down her back, the ends brushing against her shoulder blades. A few strands framed her face, giving her an effortless, ethereal quality, held back behind one of her ears by a single very small flower – an Aster, if Agatha was not mistaken. There was nothing extravagant about her look, but it was perfect—simple, graceful, stunning, exactly the way Agatha loved it. It wasn’t about the dress or the hair, though. It was about Rio, the way she carried herself, with a calm confidence that made every room feel like it was meant for her.

 

Rio’s eyes scanned the room, a quiet assessment, and when her gaze finally met Agatha’s, something in Agatha’s chest tightened. The smile that tugged at Rio’s lips was soft, tender—a silent acknowledgement that she was here, for Agatha, even if only in this fleeting moment. The warmth in her expression made Agatha’s heart flutter in a way she could never quite predict. It was like Rio had the ability to calm the storm inside Agatha with just a look.

 

Rio didn’t make a grand entrance. She wasn’t one for theatrics, never one to demand attention, that was more Agatha’s territory. Instead, she moved with a kind of quiet assurance, walking with purpose toward an empty seat near the back. Her movements were graceful, almost as though she was dancing between the spaces, her presence made more significant by its subtlety. Agatha couldn’t help but be mesmerized, her gaze tracking Rio’s every step, even as the noise of the event hummed around her.

 

When Rio settled into her seat, Agatha felt the subtle but undeniable shift. Her chest loosened, and a quiet joy filled the space left in her heart by the absence of her worry. The evening would go on. It had to. But there was something different now. The chaos of the event didn’t seem nearly as overwhelming. Agatha could breathe a little easier. Rio was here, and in her stillness, Rio offered Agatha a silent support that couldn’t be put into words.

 

She’s here, Agatha thought, a gentle smile tugging at her lips. She’s really here.

 

Agatha’s gaze swept over the crowd once more before settling on the first reader, standing off to the side of the stage. He looked poised and ready, likely eager to present what he had undoubtedly poured time and effort into creating. She gave him a brief nod, signaling it was his time to take the stage. But even as she did, her mind kept returning to Rio, seated in the audience, her presence a comfort to Agatha, a reminder that no matter how hectic the world around her seemed, Rio would always be there, quietly supporting her.

 

And now, with Rio seated comfortably in the crowd, there was a new sense of anticipation in the air, a shift in the atmosphere. The evening, which had started with uncertainty, suddenly seemed full of possibility. A spark of curiosity danced in Agatha’s chest—what would Rio surprise her with this time?

 

Maybe this evening would unfold in ways Agatha hadn’t expected, with more than just poetry filling the room. But one thing was sure, Rio’s presence was already the most beautiful poem of all.

 

 

The evening flowed seamlessly as Agatha moved through the program, her voice calm and assured as she introduced each student in turn. The soft hum of anticipation in the air mirrored her own excitement as the students took their turns at the podium, reading poems that varied in theme and style—some earnest, others abstract, but all heartfelt. Each performance was met with polite applause, the audience leaning in, captivated by the raw emotion and creativity spilling from the students’ words.

 

Agatha’s voice never wavered as she announced the names and managed the flow of the event. There was no hint of the nerves or anxiety that had plagued her earlier; she was in her element, doing what she did best. And yet, beneath the composed surface, something inside her stirred. Despite her attention being drawn to the students, there was a quiet, insistent tug on her focus that pulled her toward the back of the room. Rio.

 

Why would she come if she’s not going to read? Agatha couldn’t help but ask herself. She had known Rio long enough to recognize the signs. Rio was a perfectionist in everything she did, especially when it came to her writing. Agatha had seen her labor over words for hours, meticulously crafting each sentence, striving for the elusive perfect expression of thought. So why was she sitting there, silent and still, instead of sharing what she had undoubtedly written? Agatha had anticipated, hoped even, that Rio would step up to the podium at some point, like she always did in their private moments, sharing her thoughts with a quiet strength that always left Agatha in awe. But tonight, Rio was content to watch, her presence in the audience an enigma that made Agatha’s thoughts swirl.

 

She’s always a mystery, Agatha thought with a soft smile tugging at the corner of her lips. It was a fondness mixed with a touch of frustration, that paradox of knowing and not knowing Rio all at once. But that was part of why Agatha loved her so fiercely—the way she could surprise Agatha, challenge her understanding, and still remain a puzzle.

 

Agatha stole another glance at Rio, seated in the audience, her posture perfectly poised, her gaze steady as she took in the event unfolding before her. There was an air of quiet calm about her, a tranquility that seemed almost too serene for a poetry reading. The way Rio’s eyes swept across the room—focused, but distant, like she was taking in the moment without fully engaging—only deepened the sense of mystery that surrounded her.

 

As each student took their turn at the podium, Agatha tried to focus. She reminded herself that the evening was about them, the students, the poetry they had worked so hard to prepare. The applause was polite but sincere, and Agatha offered words of encouragement with a practiced smile, her voice steady, even as her thoughts kept drifting back to Rio. Why was she here if she wasn’t going to share her work? Agatha wondered, her heart tightening. Was there something wrong?

 

Agatha shook her head, silently chastising herself for worrying. She knew perfectly well that Rio wasn’t scheduled to read tonight—she had made the program herself, for heaven’s sake. And yet, despite knowing better, a part of her couldn’t help but hope for something unexpected to happen.

 

She glanced again at Rio, who seemed at ease, almost too calm. Rio wasn’t one for idle chatter, and her silences often spoke volumes, but this was different. Agatha couldn’t pinpoint why, but there was a strange stillness about her tonight. It wasn’t like Rio to simply observe without participating or at least engaging. Her absence from the stage felt like something missing that Agatha couldn’t quite explain.

 

“Next, we have Lily Harper, second-year literature student” Agatha announced, her voice carrying through the room, pulling her attention back to the task at hand.

 

Lily, her shy and soft-spoken student, made her way to the podium. Her poem was introspective, a quiet rumination on love and loss, but as she read, Agatha’s mind inevitably drifted back to Rio again.

 

Come on, Rio, just get up there, Agatha thought impatiently. I know you’ve been writing. You can’t just be here to watch. There’s something more… I know it. I can feel it.

 

She cleared her throat and refocused on Lily, applauding her when the poem came to an end.

 

The event continued like this for a while, Agatha introducing one student after another, a part of her slowly becoming aware that she was awaiting something—something that hadn’t yet come to pass, and that might never come. Every time another student took their turn, Agatha would catch herself glancing at Rio, almost subconsciously.

 

She’s not just going to sit there, is she? Agatha’s thoughts were becoming more frantic, though her outward composure remained intact. She didn’t want to jump to conclusions, but it was becoming harder not to wonder what was going on. Was Rio upset with her? Was it a way to silently give her a message? Or was it something else entirely—something Agatha couldn’t yet understand?

 

But there was no room for these questions in the moment. Not here, not in front of everyone. Not when she was meant to be focused on the students, their work, and the event they had all worked so hard to put together. Agatha steeled herself, forcing the doubts back down as she called out the name of the next reader, her voice a little less certain this time, betraying the tightness she felt in her chest.

 

As she spoke, a voice in the back of her mind whispered softly, She’s going to surprise you.

 

It was the only explanation Agatha could come up with.

 

Her eyes lingered on Rio just a moment longer before she turned her attention back to the program. Each moment that passed seemed to stretch on longer than the last, Agatha now feeling as if the event was crawling by. Come on, Rio, she thought, squeezing the edge of the podium. I know you’re going to do it. Just get up there.

 

And then—

 

The next reader finished, and Agatha, without thinking, glanced once more toward the back of the room. Her gaze immediately fixed on Rio, who had quietly stood up. It wasn’t the dramatic rise Agatha had imagined, no bold moment to announce her presence. Instead, Rio’s movements were fluid, effortless, her silhouette as sure and graceful as always. But it was the quiet intensity of her gaze that stopped Agatha in her tracks. Their eyes met across the room, and in that instant, an unspoken communication passed between them—a silent exchange that made Agatha’s heart skip a beat. There was no need for words. Rio was ready.

 

And indeed, as Agatha turned the page to her program, her fingers brushing the list of names, one jumped out at her. Rio Vidal, PhD candidate. She froze for a moment, her brow furrowing slightly in confusion. She could have sworn that name hadn’t been there when she had printed the program yesterday. The thought struck her with a smile that bordered on exasperated affection. Sneaky, she thought with a quiet chuckle to herself. She must have swapped it this morning.

 

Rio had always been full of surprises.

 

Rio moved toward the stage with a slow, deliberate confidence that Agatha couldn’t help but admire. There was nothing ostentatious about the way she walked, no exaggerated gesture. It was simply the certainty in each step, a quiet power in the way she carried herself. Every inch of her, from the way her deep purple dress swayed to the rhythm of her movement to the focused expression on her face, exuded a calm, unwavering confidence that Agatha found deeply compelling.

 

She’s really doing it.

 

As Rio reached the podium, she stood for a moment, her eyes scanning the room briefly before landing on Agatha. It was only a brief glance, but it felt like a conversation in itself. There was a question in the way Rio looked at her, a quiet invitation. The room seemed to hold its breath, waiting for the next moment to unfold. Agatha’s pulse quickened, anticipation building in her chest. She knew Rio well—there was no turning back now. Agatha fought to steady her voice, trying to conceal the slight tremor as she announced the one name that had been lingering in her thoughts all evening.

 

Rio took the microphone in hand, her fingers gripping it gently, and then, after a long pause, she cleared her throat. It was a subtle sound, but it was enough to quiet the room, every person present holding their breath. Agatha couldn’t help but be drawn to Rio, her eyes locked on her as if nothing else in the world mattered. She felt a soft stirring inside her, a mix of pride, love, and the deepest admiration.

 

Rio’s voice broke the silence, soft yet steady, with a warmth that filled the room like honey. As the words flowed from her lips, they seemed to vibrate in the air, weaving through the space between them, pulling at the hearts of everyone listening. Agatha’s breath hitched, and she found herself unable to tear her eyes away.

 

“I’ve found the one who carries truth like flame,

She moves through the world unburdened by shame.

She steps into rooms with a quiet might,

Not out of pride, but from owning her light.”

 

The words came like a river, flowing with such ease and grace that Agatha felt as though she was drowning in them. Each line Rio spoke was an echo of Agatha’s very essence. The words, carefully crafted, felt as though they had been pulled directly from her heart—descriptions of the very person Agatha had worked so hard to become. She tried to steady her breathing, to hold herself together, but Rio’s voice, her unwavering confidence, was shaking Agatha’s resolve.

 

“With fire in her voice and stars in her gaze,

A depth that draws those who dare to appraise.

She challenges all, yet never must shout,

Her presence alone leaves the world no doubt.”

 

Agatha felt the warmth in her chest, the unspoken truth she had never said aloud, unfolding in the rhythm of Rio’s voice. The woman in the poem was her—every word, every line. The fire in Agatha’s spirit, the quiet authority she wielded, and the way Rio saw her—not just as a partner, but as someone worthy of admiration and love.

 

“A circle of fate, our hearts entwine,

Unlocking gates, hidden and divine.

Like constellations that paint the night so wide,

Our hearts are woven, with spirit as our guide.”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened, and her vision blurred for a moment. She could feel the weight of Rio’s gaze, even though their eyes hadn’t yet met. It was as though Rio’s words were directed at her very soul, unraveling all the walls she’d carefully built around her heart.

 

“She’s the northern star in my endless skies,

Her glow unyielding, where uncertainty lies.

She asks for nothing, yet gives me it all,

A love so deep, it catches my fall.”

 

She could feel the tears welling up in her eyes, but she blinked them away, unwilling to let them fall. Rio’s love was so loud in this room, soothing her wounds, filling the spaces where doubt used to linger. She could barely comprehend the depth of the love Rio was laying bare for her, the promises woven into every line of the poem. Rio was giving her a part of herself—one Agatha would carry with her always.

 

“She feels what I cannot feel,

And in her eyes, I find what makes me real.

Primal nights, where whispers shine,

I hold Love’s hand in mine.”

 

The entire room seemed to vanish in that moment. It was just Agatha and Rio, the quiet intensity between them undeniable. Agatha could barely hold herself together, every word pulling her closer to the truth Rio had been holding for so long. Rio hadn’t just written this poem—she had poured her heart into it, for Agatha, and Agatha could feel it with every beat of her heart.

 

“Through many miles of trials and fears,

I wander high and low, but love perseveres.

When shadows fall, her light will show,

The time has come for us to grow.”

 

Agatha’s chest swelled with pride, and for the first time in so long, she felt truly seen. Rio’s love was not just a fleeting thing—it was a steady, unbreakable force, something that had the power to carry them both through anything.

 

« One day, I’ll marry her, not because I’m told,

But because with her, I’ve found a home to hold.

She makes me whole, with fire shining bright,

Her love, a galaxy, setting the stars alight.”

 

Agatha could hardly breathe. Rio was giving her the world in this poem—the truth, the depth of their bond, the promise of forever. Agatha felt a tear escape, tracing a path down her cheek. She couldn’t stop it, not now, so she silently blessed her position in the dark of the stage.

 

“In the strength of standing beside one so true,

I find my purpose, my meaning, my view.

There’s promise in her soul, certain as the sun,

That one day I’ll be hers, as we become one. »

 

And then, as Rio finished, their eyes met across the stage. Agatha’s heart leapt, her chest swelling with emotions she couldn’t quite name. The applause erupted around them, but Agatha’s hands didn’t join the others; instead, they remained pressed firmly against her chest, where her heart was still racing. Her gaze was fixed entirely on Rio, whose eyes had never left her. The look in them told Agatha everything—This is all for you.

 

Rio gave a small, graceful bow, acknowledging the audience with a quiet, humbled smile before returning to her seat. Agatha’s eyes followed her every movement, but it was when Rio met her gaze again, briefly but intensely, that her heart skipped a beat. It was a silent exchange, one so filled with meaning that Agatha couldn’t put it into words. Rio didn’t need to say anything more, she had already said it all. Agatha gave a slight nod in Rio’s direction—a simple, almost imperceptible gesture, but it meant everything. I see you. I feel you. I love you.

 

For a moment, the applause, the noise of the event, everything else seemed to fade away. There was only Rio, sitting there, her heart bared for Agatha to see. Agatha could feel the weight of it, a warmth spreading through her chest, as though the entire room had suddenly shrunk, leaving only the two of them. She didn’t care about the rest of the program. All she could think about was Rio and the profound intimacy that had just been shared between them.

 

She tore her eyes away only when she realized the next student was ready, waiting by the stage, but her thoughts were still with Rio. She couldn’t help but feel a deep, quiet pride swelling inside her. Rio had done something so bold, so beautiful. And despite the vulnerability of it, Rio hadn’t flinched. She had stood there, so completely herself, and Agatha admired her even more for it.

 

Agatha stole another glance at Rio, who was now sitting back in her seat, her posture relaxed, a quiet air of contentment radiating from her. Her gaze was no longer focused on the stage but was now somewhere else, lost in her own thoughts, perhaps reflecting on what she had just shared. Agatha couldn’t help but smile softly to herself, a warmth spreading through her chest as she watched Rio. There was something so breathtakingly honest about her, so effortlessly beautiful, and in that moment, Agatha felt like the luckiest woman in the world.

 

As the next student prepared onstage, arranging an impressive array of instruments to accompany his poem, Agatha’s mind began to wander. Lost in thought, she was jolted back to the present when Dr. Graham, one of her colleagues, approached her with a thoughtful expression.

 

“That was a stunning poem,” he remarked, his voice filled with genuine admiration. “I didn’t know Miss Vidal had such a gift. She’s yours, right?”

 

The question caught Agatha off guard. Her heart stuttered for a beat, and she nearly choked on her own breath. She quickly regained her composure, forcing a neutral smile as her mind raced. Mine? The word felt too personal, too loaded, especially after what she had just witnessed.

 

“Mine?” Agatha repeated, her voice a little too sharp, though she quickly masked her surprise.

 

Dr. Graham blinked, apparently unaware of Agatha’s internal turmoil. “Yes, she’s one of your students, isn’t she?”

 

“Ah, yes. She is,” Agatha replied, gathering herself as she stood tall, her professional mask slipping back into place.

 

Dr. Graham’s eyebrows raised slightly in appreciation. “Lucky you. Had I known, I would’ve fought harder to get her when her old supervisor left.”

 

Agatha’s heart gave an involuntary leap at the words, but her face remained calm. She gave a subtle nod, a careful, measured response. “She’s a talented student,” she said, her voice steady, betraying none of the pride that had nearly overwhelmed her. “I’m glad she shared her work tonight.”

 

Dr. Graham studied her for a moment longer, his gaze lingering as though trying to peel back the layers of Agatha’s composed exterior. There was a flicker of something in his eyes—perhaps curiosity, perhaps an inkling of something more—but it was gone before Agatha could analyze it too closely.

 

“You must be proud,” he said, his tone light, but there was something soft beneath it, an understanding that Agatha couldn’t quite place. It felt almost like a quiet acknowledgment, a recognition of the bond he suspected existed between them, even if neither of them spoke it aloud.

 

Agatha forced a smile, the edges of her lips tugging up in a way that almost felt automatic. “Of course. She’s a brilliant individual.”

 

Inside, however, the words brilliant individual didn’t feel like enough. Rio’s poem had been so much more than brilliance. It had been raw, unguarded, a vulnerable offering of herself in front of an entire room full of strangers. Agatha hadn’t expected that—didn’t know Rio had been capable of exposing that much of herself so openly. But Rio had stood tall, her voice steady, open for the world to see, and Agatha’s heart had swelled with admiration. It had been a declaration, a love letter wrapped in verse.

 

As Dr. Graham moved away to engage with his another colleague standing in the wings, Agatha felt her gaze drifting back toward the audience, toward Rio. There she was, sitting quietly, her posture relaxed, yet there was a glow about her that radiated quiet confidence—a confidence Agatha knew had been hard-earned. She was done for tonight.

 

 

As the last student finished reading and the applause began to die down, Agatha’s gaze swept over the room one more time. She spotted Rio standing near the exit, lingering in the crowd as people began to slowly make their way out. She knew she couldn’t embrace her or speak openly, not with all the eyes in the room, but the pull between them was undeniable.

 

Agatha moved through the dispersing crowd, her heart racing with a sense of urgency, eager to meet Rio. The moment their eyes met, a silent understanding passed between them, but Agatha knew the boundaries of the situation. Not here, not with everyone watching. The public persona they both maintained at school was still in place. But even so, the need to be near her, to close that distance, was overwhelming.

 

Every step she took brought her closer, her pulse loud in her ears. She wasn’t sure what she felt more—anticipation or the desire to be near Rio, to be alone with her, away from the eyes of the world. It didn’t matter. All that mattered was the space between them closing.

 

Finally, she reached Rio, who was still standing there, her back slightly turned but her body language open, waiting. Agatha stood close, but not too close—just enough to maintain the pretense of normalcy, the illusion of distance. They both understood the rules, and yet, in the quiet hum of the room, it felt as though the world outside them had faded completely.

 

Agatha leaned in, her breath warm against Rio’s ear, her voice soft and intimate, reiterating the promise she had already made. “I’ll marry you,” she whispered, the quiet intensity in her voice burning brighter than ever, a surge of emotion rising within her. “I’ll marry you, one day.”

 

Rio’s smile was slow but warm, her cheeks flushing as she met Agatha’s gaze. The joy in Rio’s gaze was undeniable, and Agatha felt her own heart swell with something akin to reverence. 

 

Rio nodded, her voice barely audible. “I know,” she simply whispered back, as though the words didn’t need to be said aloud for either of them to believe them.

 

Rio’s smile was the answer Agatha had longed for, the unspoken promise between them shining brighter than the stars that had inspired Rio’s words. They didn’t need to say anything else. In that moment, they both knew. Their love was already written in the stars.

 

 

Later that night, after the event had ended and they had retreated to the privacy of their home, Agatha lingered in the doorway of their bedroom, her thoughts still swirling around Rio’s poem.

 

As Rio entered the room, still wearing the purple dress she had chosen for the occasion, Agatha couldn’t stop herself. She crossed the space between them in a few quick strides, her arms reaching out to pull Rio into her embrace. The moment their bodies met, Agatha’s chest tightened in a mixture of relief and affection, the weight of the night lifting as she felt the familiar warmth of Rio against her. Rio’s soft exhale brushed against her ear, the sound grounding Agatha in a way nothing else could. She couldn’t help but smile, feeling an overwhelming sense of safety in the privacy of their shared space.

 

“You,” Agatha began, her voice light with teasing, though there was a deep affection woven into every word, “are such a mystery sometimes. You spend days hiding your notebook, sneaking off to write… and then you go and share something like that with an entire room full of people.”

 

Rio, still wrapped in the afterglow of the evening, felt her cheeks flush. She pulled back slightly, trying to hide the small smile that threatened to spread across her face, her eyes bright and a little embarrassed. “I didn’t want to say anything until it was ready,” she explained softly, her voice quieter now, edged with a nervousness that only made Agatha want to pull her closer. “I was… unsure about sharing something so personal. But… I couldn’t keep it to myself any longer.”

 

Agatha’s heart softened at Rio’s words, and she pulled her in closer, her hand gently cupping the back of Rio’s head. “You were incredible tonight. The poem—” She paused, searching for the right words. “It was beautiful. I don’t think I’ve ever been moved by anything the way I was by what you shared. You captured something in it that… that I can’t even put into words. It was so much more than just words on a page.”

 

Rio’s eyes fluttered closed, the heat of Agatha’s praise making her heart race in the best way. She hadn’t expected Agatha to respond like this, so fully, so deeply. She’d been nervous about her vulnerability, about the way the words would be received in such a public setting. But hearing Agatha’s praise made all the uncertainty worthwhile.

 

“I wanted you to know,” Rio admitted, her voice barely above a whisper as she looked up at Agatha, “how much you mean to me. I wanted you to know that I’m not afraid of… of us, and that I see a future with you. I’m not just writing about someone. I’m writing about you—about us.”

 

Agatha’s heart skipped a beat. She kissed Rio’s forehead gently, her lips lingering for a moment, her hands brushing tenderly over Rio’s back. “I know, my love,” Agatha murmured, her voice thick with emotion. “I know. You don’t have to tell me for me to feel it. But hearing you say it… it means more than you could ever know.”

 

 

As the night deepened, Agatha and Rio laid together in their bed, the soft glow of the bedside lamp casting a gentle light across the room. The events of the evening had left them both feeling a quiet euphoria, a feeling of connection that lingered in the air between them. The poem, the words that Rio had shared so bravely, rested between them on the covers, the open notebook lying on the bed, the pages soft under Agatha’s touch, as if it held a part of Rio’s soul within it.

 

Agatha took the notebook into her hands again, her fingers tracing the edges of the pages as if she couldn’t quite get enough of the poem. Her gaze shifted to Rio, lying on her stomach beside her, propped up on her elbows, still flushedwith the joy and nervousness of the evening.

 

“Let me read it again,” Agatha murmured softly, her voice steady and warm, as she flipped to the page where Rio had written the poem. Rio nodded, her eyes soft, the kind of look that only Agatha could ever bring out in her.

 

Agatha cleared her throat softly, the words already familiar but no less beautiful. As she read, her voice low and full of emotion, she let each line sink in, savoring the meaning behind every word.

 

As Agatha read, Rio’s gaze never wavered from her, her eyes locked on Agatha’s face.

 

As Agatha finished the last line, she found herself silent for a moment, her voice thick with emotion that she hadn’t quite been able to express before. The words were so powerful, so raw, and hearing them out loud again even if in her own voice, from Rio’s own heart, felt like a gift—one she would cherish forever.

 

Rio, watching Agatha’s reaction, felt a twinge of vulnerability, but the warmth in Agatha’s eyes soothed her, calming her fears.

 

With a small, shy smile, Rio reached over, her fingers trembling ever so slightly as she gently took the page from her notebook. She handled it with care, as if it were a delicate treasure, something too precious to rush. Slowly, deliberately, she tore it out, the sound of the paper releasing from the binding almost too loud in the quiet room. She folded it gently, her gaze never leaving Agatha’s, before extending it to her, the original handwritten version of the poem.

 

“I want you to have it,” Rio said softly, her voice barely above a whisper, the words rich with meaning. “I want you to keepit.”

 

Agatha’s eyes widened slightly, her heart swelling as she took the page from Rio’s hands. The weight of the gesture was not lost on her—it was more than just words on paper. It was a piece of Rio’s heart, and now, Agatha was entrusted with it, to keep it forever.

 

Agatha kissed Rio’s forehead, her voice barely above a whisper. “Thank you,” Agatha whispered, her voice thick with emotion, barely above a breath. “I’ll keep this forever, Rio. I promise.”

 

For a moment, they simply held each other, the world outside completely irrelevant in the presence of their shared warmth. Agatha’s hands rested over the page, still held close to her heart, as she let the quiet settle between them.

 

Rio lifted her head slightly to meet Agatha’s gaze, her expression soft but intense. “Do you think we’re ready? Ready to make all of this real? I mean, we’re already real—this, us—but… I guess I’m asking if you think we can make this permanent.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened even more, her fingers gently cupping Rio’s face as she looked at her with absolute certainty. “We already are real, Rio. In every possible way. And yes, I think we’re ready. I think we’ve been ready for a long time.”

 

Rio’s eyes shimmered as she leaned into Agatha’s touch, her lips parting just slightly. “I love you,” she whispered, the words feeling like the most natural thing in the world.

 

Agatha’s response was immediate, her voice warm, steady, and full of affection. “I love you too, Rio.” She ran her thumb gently over Rio’s cheek, her gaze softening with the unspoken understanding that this was real, this was them—unshakable, undeniable.

 

“You know what to do then,” Rio said, her voice dropping lower, playful and teasing. The cheeky grin tugging at her lips only deepened the affectionate warmth that swelled between them.

 

Agatha couldn’t help the small chuckle that escaped her, the sound filled with tenderness and a knowing fondness. She leaned in just a little closer, her lips hovering near Rio’s ear as her fingers continued to gently trace the curve of Rio’s jaw. “Oh, I do, love,” Agatha said softly, her breath warm against Rio’s skin. “I’m just waiting for the right time.” Her voice held a hint of mischief, a gentle promise of things to come. “Those things take time, you know. If you want them to be perfect.”

 

Rio shivered slightly at the closeness, the weight of Agatha’s words settling comfortably in her chest. The teasing, the playful push and pull, only made her want Agatha more. But she also understood the weight behind Agatha’s words—the idea that some moments, the most important ones, deserved to be savored, to be nurtured until they were as flawless as their love.

 

“Perfect, huh?” Rio murmured, her voice low but full of longing. “Well, I guess we do deserve the perfect moment, don’t we?”

 

Agatha’s eyes softened at Rio’s words, her heart fluttering with affection. “We deserve all of it, Rio. All the time, all the moments… all the perfection in the world. But what we have right now? This is already more than I ever dreamed of.”

 

With that, the two of them settled back into the soft covers of the bed, the poem now resting safely between them. Rio nestled close, her head on Agatha’s chest as the room grew darker, the only sound the quiet rhythm of their breathing. Agatha held the page close to her, childishly putting it under her pillow for now, knowing that it wasn’t just the poem that made this moment so precious—it was the love between them, something that could never be captured in words alone, but something she would treasure forever, just like the woman falling asleep in her arms.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

Guys, I’ve got so much to say:

1/ My exams are officially doooone for now!!!

2/ In case anyone’s wondering, asters symbolize patience, love, wisdom, and admiration (just to name a few)—I thought it fit perfectly in this context.

3/ I literally wrote the poem at the end of my exam on Monday on draft paper and my brain was fried after 6 hours... (I finished early and didn’t want to leave since no one else had moved yet.) Also, I’m not a poet at all, so please don’t be too harsh, but I do love studying poetry!

4/ I know you all were hoping for a proposal, and honestly, I’m with you on that. But I think I know when I want it to happen now, so bear with me. And by now, they both made it quite clear that they wanted it so...

5/ This story will eventually have to come to an end, (I'm thinking 60 chapters), but DO NOT WORRY—there will be a sequel, and I’ve already got ideas. It won’t be the end, I promise!

6/ Love you all!

Nicky at Uni

 

*

*

*

 

At the source of the longest river

The voice of the hidden waterfall

And the children in the apple-tree

Not known, because not looked for

But heard, half-heard, in the stillness

Between two waves of the sea.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

The sound of Agatha’s heels was sharp and deliberate, echoing through the tiled corridor as she exited the lecture theater. The hum of her second-year students’ chatter faded into the distance, and she allowed herself a brief moment to feel satisfied. The lecture had gone well, her thoughts were still on their evolving grasp of literary theory, and she was already mentally cataloging how she’d tweak certain sections for the next class. But as she reached for her phone in the inner pocket of her blazer, she noticed the missed call notification flashing ominously.

 

Her brow furrowed. Missed calls in the middle of the day were never a good sign. She tapped the voicemail icon, pausing in a quiet alcove by the window. The recorded message was short but effective at spiking her stress.

 

“This is Westview Elementary calling to inform you that there’s been an electricity issue, and we’re asking all parents to come and pick up their children as soon as possible. We apologize for the inconvenience.”

 

Agatha let out a long, slow breath, pinching the bridge of her nose. “Perfect,” she muttered, sarcasm dripping from the word. It wasn’t as if she had an entire afternoon of lectures to manage, or meetings to attend, or office hours to be present for. But, of course, parenting didn’t wait for convenient moments.

 

Sliding her phone back into her pocket, she adjusted the strap of her leather bag and set off for the parking lot. Her footsteps quickened as she walked, the familiar rhythm of her heels on tile helping her focus. She tried to work out the logistics in her head: pick Nicky up, keep him entertained in her office until her next class, and then…

 

Her thoughts faltered as she realized there was no ideal solution. Normally, Rio would step in, but Rio was one of her students today. And there was no way she was leaving Nicky unsupervised in her office for an hour-long lecture. That only left one option, and it wasn’t one she was thrilled about.

 

Agatha climbed into her car, the cool leather seat creaking as she settled in and buckled up. Her hands tightened on the steering wheel as she started the engine, her mind still ticking through potential complications. Bringing Nicky to class meant keeping him occupied and making sure he didn’t accidentally reveal their carefully guarded “secret”. It wasn’t that Agatha didn’t trust him—he was a remarkably clever six-year-old—but six-year-olds weren’t exactly renowned for their subtlety.

 

Her lips quirked into a reluctant smile as she imagined the look on Rio’s face when she would see Nicky in class. The two of them adored each other, but keeping up the pretense of a casual babysitter relationship in front of the other students would be… interesting.

 

 

When Agatha arrived at Westview Elementary, the parking lot was already bustling with parents picking up their children. Agatha stepped out of her car, her gaze immediately sweeping the scene, her sharp eyes scanning the crowd until they landed on her son.

 

Nicky was perched on a bench near the school entrance, his small backpack resting next to him, the fabric worn in the corners from weeks of use. He was swinging his legs with abandon, the lightness of his mood contagious even from a distance. The moment his eyes found her, his face broke into an enormous grin, and without a second of hesitation, he jumped up from the bench, waving both arms above his head as though he feared she might not see him.

 

“Mama!” His voice rang out, a bright, clear call that cut through the busy hum of the crowd.

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a smile despite the mild chaos around her. She made her way over to him, her pace quick but steady. “Hello, sweetheart,” she greeted, as he came barreling into her legs. “Were you waiting long?”

 

Nicky shook his head, his curls bouncing with the motion. “Nope! Mrs. Clarke let us color while we waited. But she said we have to go home ‘cause the lights don’t work anymore.” He grabbed his backpack and slung it over one shoulder, clearly unbothered by the unexpected schedule change.

 

“Well, lucky for you, you’re coming to the university with me today,” Agatha said, brushing a stray curl out of his face.

 

His eyes widened with excitement. “Really? I get to spend the day at your work?”

 

“That’s right,” she confirmed, straightening up and holding out her hand for him to take. “But remember, you’ll need to be on your best behavior. I still have a class to teach.”

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically, his small hand slipping into hers. “Can I sit in the big chairs in your office?”

 

“You can, but only for a little while. I have to take you to class with me later,” she explained as they walked toward the car.

 

“To your class?” Nicky asked, his voice tinged with curiosity and excitement.

 

“Yes,” Agatha replied, glancing down at him as they walked. “Promise you’ll be a big boy today?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up with pride at the question, and he puffed out his chest dramatically, making a show of being as serious as a six-year-old could be. “I’ll be the best boy!” he declared, his voice high with the excitement of the adventure ahead. “I can’t wait to tell Señor Scratchy all about my day!”

 

Agatha couldn’t suppress a soft laugh as she helped him into his car seat, her fingers brushing through his unruly curls. “I’m sure Señor Scratchy will be thrilled to hear all about it.” She fastened the straps securely, her eyes soft with affection as she lingered for a moment, looking at her son.

 

As they drove back to the university, Nicky chattered excitedly about all the things he’d seen on his previous visits to the campus. Agatha listened with half an ear, her focus split between the road and mentally preparing for the balancing act of bringing her son into a lecture with a room full of students—one of whom happened to be his other mother.

 

“Today’s going to be interesting,” she muttered under her breath, glancing at Nicky in the rearview mirror. He was practically vibrating with excitement, his cheeks flushed and his eyes bright.

 

When Agatha pulled into the faculty parking lot, she could clearly see Nicky’s grin getting wider and wider. He was craning his neck toward the window, his wide eyes fixed on the campus in front of them. His excitement was almost palpable, and Agatha smiled softly as she parked the car, hearing him let out an excited giggle as she shifted the gear into park.

 

The moment the car came to a stop, Nicky was practically bouncing in his seat, his small hands grasping the seatbelt as he unbuckled himself with a burst of energy.

 

“Mama, can I carry my own backpack?” he asked, his voice full of anticipation. His tiny fingers fumbled at the straps, gripping them tightly with an eagerness that made Agatha’s heart warm.

 

“Of course, you can,” Agatha replied with a small smile, helping him out of the car and smoothing down his hair. “But remember, stay close to me, alright? Campus isn’t like your school.”

 

“I’ll stay right by you, Mama!” Nicky chirped, his eyes shining with a mixture of excitement and determination. With an exaggerated flourish, he swung his backpack over his shoulders like a tiny explorer ready for an adventure, the straps barely fitting over his small frame.

 

Together, they made their way toward the entrance of the building. The hustle of campus life surrounded them—students chatting, professors carrying stacks of papers, and the sound of footsteps echoing on the paved paths. Agatha kept a protective hand on Nicky’s shoulder, guiding him through the crowd with practiced ease.

 

As they approached the main entrance, a familiar voice called out, “Agatha!”

 

Turning with a smile, Agatha saw Dr. Juliet Price, a youngish professor in the English department, walking toward them. Dr. Price was a woman of precise movements and sharp intellect, always with a stack of papers in her hands and her ever-present reading glasses perched just so on the bridge of her nose.

 

“Good afternoon, Juliet,” Agatha greeted, her tone polite but brisk, her posture shifting slightly to create a protective barrier around Nicky. It wasn’t out of distrust— Juliet was nice - it was more a reflexive instinct to protect her son in unfamiliar surroundings.

 

“And who is this little gentleman?” Juliet asked, raising an eyebrow as her sharp eyes moved from Agatha to Nicky, who was standing a bit shyly beside her.

 

“This is my son, Nicky,” Agatha replied smoothly, placing a hand on his shoulder.

 

Nicky, raised to be a very polite child, tilted his head up at the sound of his name and waved shyly. “Hi.”

 

“Well, aren’t you charming?” Juliet said, her tone softening as she looked at Nicky with a smile that showed her usual no-nonsense exterior was momentarily melted by the sight of the little boy. “What brings you to campus today, young man?”

 

Nicky glanced up at Agatha, his eyes wide, suddenly shy.

 

“There was an issue at his school,” Agatha explained, stepping in with ease. “They had to send the kids home early, so he’ll be spending the day with me.”

 

“How delightful,” Juliet said with a warm chuckle, clearly taken by the idea of a child spending a day on campus. “I’m sure he’ll be the most popular guest we’ve had on campus in a while.” She turned her gaze back to Agatha. “Well, I won’t keep you. Good luck juggling your responsibilities today. And, Nicky, it was a pleasure meeting you.”

 

“Thank you,” Nicky said politely, flashing her a shy, but genuine smile.

 

As Juliet walked away, Agatha gave Nicky an approving look, her voice filled with quiet pride. “Good job, sweetheart. You were very polite.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up at the praise, and he beamed up at her. “I’m always polite, Mama,” he said, a confident glint in his eyes. He slipped his hand back into hers, his grip tight and trusting as they continued into the building.

 

“Is she your friend, Mama?” Nicky asked, his voice full of curiosity as he looked up at her with wide, innocent eyes.

 

Agatha’s lips twitched with amusement, as she held the building’s door open for Nicky to walk through. “She’s my colleague, Nicky,” she replied, the smile softening her features. “That’s a little different from being friends.”

 

“Oh,” Nicky said, his expression one of understanding. He nodded as though the distinction made perfect sense, clearly satisfied with the answer, even if the difference was still a little fuzzy to him. “So she’s like a teacher?”

 

“Yes, just like me,” Agatha said, chuckling softly at his thoughtful expression. “And we work together. We help each other out.”

 

Nicky nodded sagely, the seriousness of his nod disproportionate to his tiny size. “I think I could be a teacher too,” he said matter-of-factly. “I could teach about dragons and superheroes.”

 

Agatha laughedl. “I think you’d make a wonderful teacher, sweetheart. I’m sure the students would learn a lot from you.”

 

With that, they continued down the corridor, Nicky’s small feet tapping lightly against the floor, his enthusiasm infectious. Agatha smiled, feeling the warmth of his little presence at her side. Despite the rush of responsibilities awaiting her, this moment—this quiet, tender exchange between them—felt like a perfect little bubble of peace in the chaos of the day.

 

Once back in her office, Agatha guided Nicky to the small seating area near her desk. She pulled out his favorite dinosaur-themed coloring book and a neatly packed bag of snacks and placed them on the table in front of him.

 

“Here you go, sweetheart,” she said, kneeling down to his eye level and meeting his gaze with a soft smile. “I’ve got some notes to prepare for my next lecture, so I’ll need you to keep busy for a little while, alright?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up with eager enthusiasm as he nodded, already reaching for his crayons with both hands. “Okay, Mama!” he chirped, his voice filled with excitement.

 

She ruffled his hair affectionately before standing and returning to her desk. As she opened her notebook and flipped through the pages, the sound of crayons scratching against paper filled the room. Nicky hummed quietly to himself as he worked, occasionally pausing to sip his juice or inspect his progress.

 

Agatha glanced up every so often, her gaze softening at the sight of her son happily coloring. She couldn’t help but marvel at how easily he adapted to new situations. Even in a university office surrounded by towering shelves of books and stacks of academic papers, Nicky seemed perfectly content.

 

A few minutes passed before Nicky’s voice broke the silence. “Look, Mama!” he exclaimed, his voice full of pride. He held up his latest masterpiece, the crayon strokes bright and bold on the page—a vivid green dinosaur surrounded by a swirling rainbow sky. “He’s happy because he has so many friends!”

 

Agatha’s eyes softened at the sight of the drawing. The rainbow sky, the exuberant dinosaur, the wild creativity—there was something so pure in it. She leaned forward, examining the page with a genuine smile that reached her eyes. “That’s wonderful, darling. You’re so creative. I love it.”

 

Nicky beamed, his chest puffing out just a little at the praise. “Do you think Mom would like it?” His voice was hopeful, filled with the kind of innocence that only a child could have when it came to showing off their work.

 

Agatha’s heart skipped a beat at the mention of Rio. It was such a casual comment, one that felt as natural as any other, but it still hit her in a way she hadn’t anticipated. Rio—her love, her partner, the other half of their little family. The way Nicky mentioned her so freely was both a comfort and a reminder of their carefully guarded secret, at least in this environment.

 

“She would love it, baby,” Agatha replied softly, her voice thick with affection. She walked over and crouched down next to him, her hand resting on his tiny shoulder, her tone becoming gentle but firm. “But remember, sweetheart, we have to keep our secret while we’re here. You can’t talk about Rio being anything more than a friend who babysits sometimes, okay?”

 

Nicky’s expression faltered slightly, his brow furrowing in confusion, but he nodded obediently, his small face falling just a little. “Okay, Mama. I won’t tell.”
