Agatha kissed his forehead, her lips lingering for a moment, feeling the warmth of his skin against hers. “Thank you. You’re being very brave,” she said quietly, a wave of tenderness washing over her. She held him for a moment, her heart swelling with love and a quiet pride.

 

Satisfied that Nicky was settled, Agatha returned to her desk to finalize her lecture notes. As she wrote, the faint sound of Nicky humming filled the room, a comforting background melody to her thoughts.

 

After a while, Agatha glanced at the clock on her desk and realized with a start that it was almost time for her next class. She closed her notebook with a soft snap, her fingers briefly brushing her desk as she stood. Straightening her pants with a smooth motion, she turned to Nicky, who had been busy flipping through his coloring book, completely absorbed in his own world.

 

“Alright, Nicky,” she said, her voice soft yet purposeful, “we’ve got to head to my lecture now.”

 

Nicky’s head shot up at the sound of her voice, and his eyes widened in excitement, his face lighting up as though he had forgotten their earlier conversation. “I get to go to your class?” he asked, his voice brimming with wonder.

 

Agatha smiled, her heart warming at his enthusiasm. “Yes, you’ll be my student today,” she said, crouching down to his level and helping him gather his things. She took extra care as she slid his dinosaur-themed coloring book back into his bag.

 

Nicky nodded solemnly, his small face set in the serious expression he always wore when he was determined to follow through on something. “I’ll be good, Mama. Promise.”

 

Agatha gave him a soft pat on the head, then glanced around to make sure she had everything she needed. She grabbed her bag and Nicky’s belongings, her movements swift and practiced. She paused for a moment, the mischievous spark in her eye giving her away as she reached for her phone. Her fingers hovered over the screen as she typed a quick message to Rio, savoring the anticipation of what she knew would be a fun little surprise.

 

Agatha: Heads up, there will be a surprise guest in today’s class.

 

She didn’t add any more details, letting the mystery of the message linger for a moment. A playful grin tugged at her lips as she imagined Rio trying to decipher the cryptic message, the curiosity already likely gnawing at her. The reply came swiftly, as expected.

 

Rio: What kind of surprise? Should I be nervous?

 

Agatha chuckled softly, pocketing her phone without replying. Let her wonder, she thought.

 

Turning back to Nicky, Agatha knelt down to adjust the straps on his backpack, making sure they sat just right on his small shoulders. She met his gaze and smiled, her voice soft but firm. “Alright, little one, remember what we talked about?”

 

Nicky nodded enthusiastically but then paused, his brow furrowing slightly as he seemed to think for a moment. “No talking about Mom, even if she’s here. It’s our secret,” he recited, his little voice serious but filled with pride.

 

Agatha gave him an approving smile. “Exactly. And what else?”

 

He counted off the points on his small fingers, his face scrunching in concentration as he made sure to cover every rule. “Be quiet, sit still, and don’t interrupt,” he said, his tone matching hers in seriousness, as if he were preparing for a big mission.

 

“Good boy,” Agatha said with a soft kiss to his forehead, the tenderness in her gesture contrasting with the playful light in her eyes. She straightened up, smoothing out her skirt once more and taking his hand in hers. “Now let’s go impress a room full of college students, shall we?”

 

Nicky’s face broke into a wide, gleeful grin. His excitement bubbled over, and he nearly skipped in place as they headed for the door. “I can’t wait, Mama! I’m going to be the best student ever!”

 

Agatha couldn’t help but chuckle at his enthusiasm. The idea of Nicky, small and wide-eyed, walking into a lecture hall full of college students, was a source of quiet amusement for her. But more than that, it was a reminder of how special these little moments with him were—how even in the midst of her busy academic life, she could share a piece of her world with him. Nicky was thrilled, and so was she, in her own way.

 

As Agatha and Nicky made their way through the university hallways, the bustle of student life seemed to slow around them. Colleagues and students alike couldn’t help but cast curious glances in their direction. Some wore expressions of surprise, others amusement, but most simply smiled warmly, offering friendly waves to Nicky as he walked alongside his mother. Nicky, a little shy in this new environment, returned the gestures with small, hesitant waves, his cheeks flushed with the attention but clearly enjoying the moment.

 

As they neared the lecture hall, Nicky tugged gently on Agatha’s hand, his voice soft and full of curiosity. “Mama, do you think Rio will like my surprise?”

 

Agatha glanced down at him, her lips curving into a secretive smile that only Nicky could see. She took a moment before responding, savoring the playful tension in the air. “Oh, I think she’ll be very surprised,” she said, her voice low and teasing.

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled with excitement at the thought of his surprise reaching his mom, a mixture of anticipation and eagerness settling on his small face. He bounced slightly on his toes, the energy from being in such a new and exciting place still evident in his every movement. “I can’t wait for her to see me, Mama,” he said, his tone almost conspiratorial as though sharing a secret mission.

 

Agatha pushed open the door to the lecture hall, her hand gently guiding Nicky into the room. The moment the door swung wide, a wave of murmurs rippled through the students who were already seated. Eyes flicked toward the entrance, some surprised, others curious. The sight of their usually composed professor—calm, controlled, and unfailingly professional—now accompanied by a small child in tow, was an unexpected sight. Some students exchanged amused glances, eyebrows raised in silent questions, while others couldn’t help but break into broad grins, clearly intrigued by the sudden change in their typical classroom dynamic.

 

Agatha, ever poised, strode confidently to the front of the room, the rhythmic clicking of her heels punctuating the otherwise hushed atmosphere. Her posture was as impeccable as ever, exuding an air of authority that seemed to say, This is still my classroom, and nothing has changed, even with the new addition at her side. Once at the podium, she turned to face the class, her hand still resting lightly but protectively on Nicky’s small shoulder.

 

She cleared her throat, a small smile playing at the corner of her lips, before speaking with her usual steady, commanding voice. “Class,” she began, the words clear and confident, but there was a faint undertone of dry humor in her tone. “This is Nicholas, our very special helper for the day. Due to unforeseen circumstances, he’ll be joining us for today’s lecture.” She paused for effect, letting the class’s curiosity simmer. “So, I expect you all to be on your best behavior. Be nice to him, or he’ll have no trouble telling me all your secrets.”

 

A ripple of laughter swept through the room as the students caught the humor in Agatha’s words, the tension of surprise easing into a more relaxed atmosphere. Even Agatha allowed herself a small smirk, a rare moment of lightness amidst the usual academic rigor. Nicky, standing proudly beside her, surveyed the room full of adults with wide, unblinking eyes, clearly basking in the attention, and looking for one specific pair of dark eyes. His chest puffed out slightly, as if he, too, was suddenly aware of how important this moment was.

 

As the room settled, Rio, seated a few rows back, had frozen for just a split second. The words had registered, and in that brief pause, her eyes widened ever so slightly. Nicky. She blinked in surprise, her mind quickly processing the unexpected revelation. A smile tugged at the corners of her lips, a soft, knowing curve that spoke volumes of her quiet amusement. So, this was the surprise guest Agatha had been teasing her with. Nicky, their son, was here—right here—in the middle of a university lecture.

 

Without missing a beat, Rio subtly switched her seat, moving to an open spot near the aisle with an empty chair beside her. She knew Agatha well enough to anticipate where she would want Nicky to sit.

 

Agatha’s eyes flickered briefly to Rio, her expression unreadable but her gaze lingering just long enough to confirm Rio’s silent gesture. She turned to Nicky, bending slightly to murmur something to him.

 

“Alright, buddy. You’re going to sit right over there, next to…” She hesitated for just a fraction of a second before saying, “Miss Vidal. She’ll help you out if you need anything.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up with excitement at the mention of her name. “Okay, Mama!” His enthusiasm was palpable, and before Agatha could even offer a reply, Nicky was already darting toward Rio with an energy that almost made him seem too small for his own eagerness. Agatha watched him go, her eyes rolling in mild exasperation at his uninhibited joy. It was both endearing and a little overwhelming at times, but Agatha wouldn’t have it any other way.

 

As expected, Nicky slid into the seat next to Rio, his movements quick but carefully measured. He immediately leaned in toward her, his small hand brushing against hers with a sense of quiet familiarity, as though the touch was a shared secret between them. A sly, conspiratorial smile curled on his mouths as he brought a finger to his lips, the universal gesture for silence, but in their shared language, it meant so much more. It wasn’t just about keeping quiet in class—it was a promise. A promise to guard what mattered most, to hold tightly to their little world, and, more than anything, to protect her. To keep Rio safe, in his own small but fierce way.

 

Rio chuckled softly, the sound a mix of amusement and tenderness. To anyone else, it might have seemed like an innocent gesture, a playful nod to the need for silence. But she knew better. That finger to his lips wasn’t just about quieting a classroom or respecting the moment. It was his promise to keep them—to keep her—their bond, their love, their family, safe and sacred.

 

She leaned in just enough to brush her lips against his temple, her voice low and warm. “Our secret,” she murmured, matching his smile. 

 

“Hi, Miss Rio,” Nicky said, his voice a hushed whisper, almost as if speaking too loudly might break the magic of the moment.

 

“Hi, Nicky,” Rio replied, her tone equally soft, but there was no hiding the affection that colored her words. She resisted the strong urge to ruffle his hair or scoop him up into a hug, instead, she turned her attention to the front of the room, giving Agatha the space to begin the lecture.

 

The murmurs had died down, but a few students still cast curious glances at Nicky, clearly charmed by his presence. Agatha ignored them entirely and launched seamlessly into the day’s material.

 

As the lecture began, Nicky stayed remarkably well-behaved.  Every so often, he would glance up at Rio, his face breaking into a shy grin as if to check in, just for reassurance, or he would quietly whisper a question about what Agatha was saying. To the casual observer, it seemed entirely normal for a child to gravitate toward a kind, familiar face, even if said familiar was in fact his other mom - the one person they had to keep hidden, the one person who was more than just a name, a whisper in the background.

 

Agatha stood tall behind the podium, her gaze sweeping over the class before she began her lecture. She could see Nicky sitting quietly next to Rio, his legs swinging under his chair, watching his Mama with wide-eyed curiosity. Every now and then, his attention would flicker to the students around him, who offered small smiles and amused glances.

 

“Now,” Agatha said, her voice steady, yet strangely gentle, “before we dive into today’s topic, I think it’s time we put our special helper to good use.” She turned to Nicky with a smile that softened her usual sharp expression, the motherly affection in her eyes only visible to those who knew her best. “Mr. Harkness, would you be so kind as to help me out for a moment?”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up at the sound of his name, and he sat up straighter in his chair, excitement palpable. “What do you need, Mama?” he asked, his voice full of eager enthusiasm.

 

Agatha’s smile widened just slightly as she handed him a small stack of papers. “Take these,” she instructed, “and pass them down each row, okay? Start over here.” She gestured to the row nearest her, where students were already leaning forward in anticipation of the unexpected spectacle.

 

“Got it!” Nicky said confidently, hopping down from his seat with an unrestrained bounce. He carried the papers with the careful attention of someone who took his new responsibility seriously, moving down the first row and handing them out one by one. 

 

“You’re doing great, Nicky,” Rio whispered as he passed her. Her voice was warm, full of affection, and Nicky flashed her a grin, the same lighthearted joy radiating from him. He handed her a paper with a quiet “Thanks” before continuing on his way.

 

Agatha watched from the podium, her professional mask slipping just enough to reveal a flicker of pride in her son. As Nicky finished his task and returned to his seat beside Rio, she gave him a small nod of approval.

 

As Nicky returned to his seat, his eyes bright with accomplishment, Agatha gave him a small, approving nod. “Excellent work,” she said, her tone returning to its usual authority, though there was a hint of warmth beneath it. “Now, let’s get back to business.”

 

She turned her attention back to the class, and with a deep breath, she seamlessly dove into the day’s material. 

 

As Agatha continued her lecture, the students remained engaged with her words, but it was clear that the presence of her son added a new, unexpected layer to the classroom dynamic. Agatha was really professional, but she couldn’t resist involving Nicky in small, playful ways to keep him engaged and make him feel included in the learning environment.

 

At one point, her voice broke the steady rhythm of the lecture with a warm but purposeful command. “Nicholas,” she called, turning her gaze toward him, “can you help me count how many students are in each row? Start from the back and work your way forward.”

 

Without hesitation, Nicky sprang into action, his small legs carrying him energetically through the aisles between desks. His eyes narrowed in concentration as he wove through the rows, counting heads with the meticulous care of a little professional. His brows furrowed, his tiny lips murmuring numbers under his breath as he worked. The students, already charmed by his presence, couldn’t help but chuckle softly at his earnest expression. Even Agatha’s usually sharp, commanding demeanor seemed softened in the face of her son’s unwavering determination.

 

When he finally returned to the front, his little chest puffed with pride, Nicky looked up at Agatha, his voice bright with accomplishment. “There are eleven rows, Mama!”

 

Agatha’s smile was faint but genuine as she gave him a nod of approval. “Excellent observation,” she praised, her tone affectionate yet measured. “See? You’ve just demonstrated the importance of precision and attention to detail. A lesson for all of you,” she added, her voice shifting back to its usual authoritative cadence as she swept her gaze across the room, her eyes sharp with that familiar intensity.

 

The students couldn’t help but chuckle at the way Agatha had seamlessly tied a child’s simple task into an academic point. For a moment, the room felt lighter, the heavy atmosphere of academic seriousness momentarily tempered by the warmth of motherly pride.

 

From her seat, Rio couldn’t suppress a small smile as she watched Nicky bask in the praise. His face glowed with the satisfaction of being seen and heard by his mother, and it was clear that every bit of recognition made him feel more important in this world of academia. Though the room buzzed with quiet curiosity about the dynamic between Dr. Harkness, her son, and the oddly familiar way he interacted with Rio, no one dared to question it outright.

 

Except one student, sensing the opportunity for more, who leaned forward and asked, “He seems really comfortable with you, Rio. How come you know him so well?”

 

Rio, who had now been quietly guiding Nicky through a maze of intricate coloring pages, heard the question out of the corner of her ear and stiffened just for a second. The casual nature of the inquiry masked a more probing curiosity, and she knew she had to handle it with care. She kept her focus on Nicky for a moment longer, then turned her head slightly to meet the student’s gaze with a calm, composed expression.

 

With a soft chuckle, she replied, “Oh, I babysit for them sometimes. You know, just helping out when they need a hand.” Her smile was warm, even if a little forced, as she hoped the casual tone would be enough to quell any further digging into their personal lives. She leaned closer to Nicky, redirecting her focus back to him, hoping the student would let the matter rest.

 

Thankfully, Nicky, in his innocent world, seemed oblivious to the subtle tension in the air. His attention was entirely consumed by his coloring book as he worked diligently, shading in an image with quiet concentration. Rio silently sent a prayer into the air, hoping he wouldn’t say anything else that could expose more than what was necessary.

 

As if on cue, Nicky glanced up at Rio, offering a bright, conspiratorial smile. “I’m doing good, right, Mo… Miss Rio?” he asked, his voice a little too loud in the quiet room.

 

Rio chuckled softly, offering a quick, subtle pat to his head as she whispered, “You’re doing great, buddy.” She shot a quick glance at the students around them, relieved to see no one else seemed to have caught the slight slip.

 

Nicky returned to his quiet work, occasionally flashing Rio a smile as she leaned over to help him with a particularly tricky part of his picture. Her gentle touch on his head and the occasional whisper of encouragement made it clear how much care and affection they shared, but the other students only saw what they wanted to see—a friendly, slightly protective relationship between the two.

 

As the final minutes of the lecture ticked away, Agatha watched from the podium, her professional demeanor never faltering, even though a part of her was deeply content with how well everything was going. Rio’s ability to keep Nicky engaged while maintaining her composure in such a public space and still taking her own notes only deepened Agatha’s admiration for her.

 

When the bell rang, signaling the end of the class, the students began to pack up their things, their eyes occasionally drifting toward Nicky as he sat quietly by Rio’s side.

 

“Well, that was a nice change,” one of the students remarked, packing away her notebook. “Dr. Harkness’s son is adorable. Looks like Rio is really good with kids.”

 

Another student, nodding thoughtfully as he adjusted his bag, added, “Yeah, she’s so chill. It’s kind of cute, actually. I mean, seeing Rio like that… you wouldn’t expect it, you know?” His eyes softened as he glanced at Nicky and then back at Rio, clearly noting the calm and almost maternal energy she exuded around the child.

 

Rio, hearing the comments but choosing to stay silent, smiled warmly at Nicky, her heart swelling with an unspoken affection. 

 

Once the last student had filed out of the classroom, Agatha called for Nicky and Rio to follow her back to her office. As the door clicked shut behind them, Nicky wasted no time—his little feet thudding against the floor as he bolted toward Rio. His face was alight with excitement, and there was a glimmer of mischief in his eyes, as if he couldn’t wait any longer for the moment he had been holding in all through the class.

 

Without hesitation, he threw his arms around her, practically jumping into her embrace. His smile was wide and uncontainable, and he whispered in a conspiratorial tone, “Do I have to keep pretending now?”

 

Rio let out a soft laugh, her heart swelling at the sight of him so eager. “Not here, buddy,” she whispered back, lifting him effortlessly onto her hip. “Here, we’re safe.”

 

Agatha, leaning against her desk, couldn’t help but smile at the moment. The office was quieter now, the usual buzz of papers and lectures replaced by the warmth of this small, private exchange. Rio was gentle with Nicky, her hand resting on his back as she steadied him on her hip, and Agatha couldn’t quite hide the pride that swelled in her chest at the sight. It was a rare privilege, these small windows into their life together.

 

Nicky, still nestled in the comfort of Rio’s embrace, seemed content with the arrangement. He nuzzled into her shoulder, his tiny hands curling around the fabric of her shirt. “I was really good in class, huh?” he asked, his voice muffled against her skin, a hint of childlike pride in his words.

 

Rio smiled down at him, her gaze soft and full of affection. “You were perfect, sweetheart,” she replied, her voice a quiet, loving reassurance. “Best little helper ever.” Nicky beamed up at her, his trust in her as evident as his joy.

 

Agatha, still standing by her desk, glanced over at the two of them with a knowing smile. She walked over, her gaze softening. “He was, wasn’t he?” she said, leaning over to give Nicky a quick kiss on the top of his head.

 

 “Alright, you two,” she said, her voice light but firm. “We’ll be picking up your things and heading out to the dance center soon. But first, I need a little bit of quiet to get my work done.”

 

Rio, still holding Nicky, raised an eyebrow with a playful smile. “We’ll give you all the quiet you need, love. Don’t worry,” she said, giving Agatha a wink. “We’ll be out of your hair soon enough.”

 

Turning to Nicky, Rio continued with a grin, “What do you say we go get a snack while Mama’s working?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up immediately, his eyes sparkling with excitement. “I want a chocolate bar, you know the kind I like!” he cheered, his little hands clasped together in enthusiasm.

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound a musical and full expression of her amusement. “You got it, dude. Maybe we’ll even bring something back for Mama!” she teased, her voice warm with affection. Nicky bounced in her arms, his small legs kicking with barely contained excitement, and Rio couldn’t help but feel a rush of tenderness toward him. This was the simple joy she had come to cherish—these moments of unspoken happiness, shared between the three of them.

 

As Rio adjusted Nicky on her hip and turned toward the door, Agatha couldn’t resist teasing them both. She smirked and gave them a sideways glance. “Well, I must say, you both did an excellent job today. I might even hire Rio as a permanent babysitter at this rate,” she said with a raised eyebrow.

 

Nicky, who had been happily resting his head on Rio’s shoulder, immediately shot back, as if he’d been affronted. “Rio’s not a babysitter!” he declared, his little face scrunching up in determination a small puff of air escaping from his mouth as though the idea was absolutely absurd. “She’s my mom!”

 

Agatha’s smirk deepened, and her heart softened at the sound of Nicky’s voice. It was so sincere, so matter-of-fact, that it struck her straight in the chest. She chuckled, the sound warm and affectionate. “Right, right,” she agreed, raising her hands in mock surrender. “Rio’s your mom, not a babysitter. My mistake.”

 

Rio, still holding Nicky with ease, shot Agatha a playful look over her shoulder. Her lips curled into a soft, knowing smile, one that was full of affection. “Careful, love,” she teased, her voice light and teasing. “You wouldn’t want to upset the little guy. He’s got a very clear opinion on the matter.” She gently adjusted Nicky, her touch as tender as ever, making sure he was comfortable on her hip.

 

Nicky, clearly pleased with the attention he was receiving, puffed out his chest proudly, as if the declaration of his status as Rio’s son was the most important thing in the world. His eyes sparkled with certainty as he flashed a wide, proud grin. “I do!” he said emphatically, his voice filled with such joy. 

 

Agatha laughed, the sound full of warmth, echoing around the room and making the air feel lighter than it had all day. It was a beautiful sound—one that always seemed to come more easily when Rio and Nicky were around. “Well, we all love her, don’t we?” Agatha said, her voice softening as she gazed at Rio. Her gaze lingered for just a moment longer than usual, the quiet intensity of her love for the woman standing before her coming through clearly in the silence that followed.

 

Rio winked at Agatha, her smile tender and affectionate as she shifted Nicky in her arms. “Of course, you do,” Rio said, her voice playful but filled with warmth. “Good thing she loves you too, then!”

 

Nicky, in the meantime, was practically bursting with excitement, his small frame bouncing with energy at the thought of their upcoming snack break. “Chocolate bar!” he cheered, his words full of pure, unrestrained joy. His little legs kicked in the air, and his grin could have lit up the room.

 

Agatha smiled, though she tried to mask the fondness she felt for the little scene unfolding before her. “Go now,” she said with a smile, trying to refocus on the work scattered in front of her. “I’ll be fine here. Take your time.”

 

Rio shot Agatha a wink before putting Nicky down, who bounced eagerly at the idea of a little treat. “We’ll be back before you know it,” Rio said, her voice light as she led Nicky down the hall.

 

Once they were outside the office, Rio leaned down and whispered to Nicky, “What should we get Mama? Something sweet, right?”

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled as he grinned. “Something chocolate! Mama loves chocolate.”

 

Rio chuckled at his enthusiasm, her heart full. “Chocolate it is, then.” They made their way to a small café in the building where Rio had seen Agatha grab coffee before.

 

The café was quiet, almost serene, tucked away in a corner of the building with soft lighting and a few small tables scattered around. It was the kind of place that felt like an oasis in the middle of a busy day. Rio and Nicky made their way to the counter, where they picked out a selection of pastries—some filled with rich, dark chocolate, others drizzled with melted chocolate or dusted with powdered sugar. They couldn’t go wrong with a mix of treats, and Rio could already imagine Agatha’s smile when she’d see them.

 

With their pastries carefully put in a small box, Rio and Nicky sat down at a cozy table in the corner, the aroma of chocolate and coffee hanging in the air. Nicky practically bounced in his seat, eager to dive into his treat, and Rio couldn’t help but laugh at his infectious energy.

 

Nicky, already halfway through his chocolate croissant, looked up at Rio with wide eyes of delight. “This is so good, Mom! You have to try one!” he exclaimed, his words muffled by the flaky pastry in his mouth.

 

Rio smiled. She took a sip of her coffee, then reached for one of the pastries she’d picked out for herself. “It’s pretty good, huh?” she said, watching Nicky’s face light up with each bite.

 

“Yeah! It’s the best! Can we get some more next time?” Nicky asked, his face lighting up with joy.

 

Rio chuckled, nodding. “Of course, sweetheart. We can get more whenever you want.” She watched him devour the last bite of his pastry, crumbs dotting his face, and her heart swelled with affection.

 

After maybe half an hour, they returned to Agatha’s office with the box of pastries, the smell of chocolate filling the air.

 

When they reached Agatha’s office, Nicky couldn’t contain his excitement. He knocked once on the door, then swung it open, his small voice ringing out with glee. “Mama!” he called, his face glowing with pride. “We got you something!”

 

Agatha looked up from her papers, smiling softly at the sight of them. “You did? What did you bring me?”

 

Nicky hopped over to Agatha’s desk, eagerly placing the box of chocolate pastries in front of her. “Here! It’s for you!” he said proudly, then glanced at Rio, his face lighting up with a mixture of mischief and affection. “Mom says chocolate makes everything better.”

 

Agatha laughed, her heart lightening at the sight of Nicky’s excitement. She reached for one of the pastries, breaking it into pieces before taking a small bite. “Well, I can’t argue with that,” she said, savoring the sweet treat. “Thank you both. This is exactly what I needed.”

 

Rio stood back and watched the two of them for a moment, her eyes softening with affection. “Thought you could use a little break. You’ve been working hard.”

 

“I’ve got the best team,” Agatha said, reaching for Nicky’s hand and pulling him gently into her lap, brushing his hair back from his face. “I’m lucky to have both of you.”

 

But Nicky couldn’t sit still any longer. His energy seemed to be bubbling over as he bounced on his heels, his wide eyes filled with eager anticipation. “Is it time to go to dance class yet?” he asked, his voice nearly vibrating with excitement.

 

Rio, who had just settled back into her seat, smiled at his uncontainable enthusiasm. She’d always admired Nicky’s zest for life. “Not yet, buddy. We’ve still got a little time before class starts,” she said, her voice soft and reassuring. “But don’t worry, we’ll be there soon enough.”

 

Nicky stared up at Rio, clearly unwilling to wait any longer. “Are you teaching today?” he asked, his eyes wide with hopeful expectation, as if the entire class hinged on her presence.

 

“Yep, I’ll be teaching your class today,” Rio replied, her voice full of warmth. She glanced down at him with affection. “You know I’m always happy to teach you and your friends.”

 

Nicky beamed up at her, his smile wide and proud. “You’re the best teacher ever, Rio!”

 

Rio felt her heart swell at the praise, but she kept her voice light and teasing. “Thank you, little man. I’m glad you think so.”

 

As Nicky continued to fidget in his chair, Rio took a deep breath, savoring the small moments before they headed to the dance center.

 

Her gaze drifted across the room to Agatha, who was seated at her desk, her focus completely absorbed in the glow of her laptop screen. The faint clicking of keys was a soothing counterpoint to Nicky’s energetic bouncing. Rio studied her for a moment, noting the faint crease of concentration between her brows and the way her lips pressed together ever so slightly as she typed. She looked beautiful, as she always did, but there was something extra endearing about her intensity when she was lost in her work.

 

Unable to resist, Rio leaned over, catching Agatha’s attention with the lightest brush of her fingers on her arm. Before Agatha could fully look up, Rio closed the gap between them and kissed her squarely on the lips. The kiss was soft but deliberate, quick but filled with affection and mischief. Agatha blinked in surprise, her eyes wide for just a heartbeat before they softened, a smile tugging at the corners of her mouth.

 

“Well, hello,” Agatha murmured, her voice tinged with amusement as she tilted her head to look at Rio more closely. “What was that for?”

 

Rio grinned, her eyes sparkling with playful warmth. “Just reminding you how much I love you,” she said lightly, but her voice held an unmistakable depth of sincerity.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, shaking her head as she returned her attention to her work, though the smile lingered on her lips. Rio leaned back in her seat, her heart lighter than it had been all day, when—

 

“Moooom, can we go now? I’m ready to dance!” Nicky’s voice rang out, cutting through the moment with all the subtlety of a firecracker. He was practically bouncing out of his chair, his excitement impossible to contain.

 

Rio laughed, the sound warm and affectionate. She reached out to ruffle Nicky’s hair, her smile widening at his eagerness. “Alright, alright, hold your horses, little man,” she teased. “Let me grab our stuff, and we’ll head out.”

 

Nicky didn’t wait for further confirmation. He jumped out of his chair, his small fists pumping in the air as he exclaimed, “Yes! It’s time to dance!”

 

Rio finally stood up, holding her hand out to him. “Alright, sweet boy. Let’s go. It’s time for you to show off those dance moves.”

 

Nicky jumped out of his chair, his energy practically radiating from him. “Yay!” he shouted, before running over to kiss his Mama good bye.

 

As Nicky and Rio were about to head out the door, Agatha looked up from her desk and caught their attention. With a warm smile, she reminded them, “I’ll pick you both up later to go home, okay?”

 

Nicky gave a thumbs-up, his face lighting up with the excitement of his upcoming class. “Okay, Mama! See you later!”

 

Rio smiled at Agatha, grateful for the small but meaningful gesture. “Thanks, love,” she said softly, her voice filled with affection. “We’ll see you soon.”

 

Agatha nodded, her expression tender. “You two have fun. I’ll be waiting to take you home.”

 

With that, Rio and Nicky waved as they left the office, the door snapping shut behind them.

 

*

*

*

Dance Mom

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

I said: 'The wonder that I feel is easy,

Yet ease is cause of wonder. Therefore speak:

I may not comprehend, may not remember.'

And he: 'I am not eager to rehearse

My thoughts and theory which you have forgotten.

These things have served their purpose: let them be.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

Rio parked the car outside the dance center, glancing in the rearview mirror at Nicky, who was practically bouncing in his seat. His little sneakers tapped against the floor as he swung his legs, his energy spilling over after a day full of adventure.

 

“And did you see how Mama asked me to hand out the papers, and everyone was looking at me like I was so important?” Nicky beamed, his small hands gesturing wildly. “I think they thought I was a professor too!”

 

Rio laughed, unbuckling her seatbelt. “I’m sure they did, Professor Nicholas. You certainly looked the part.” She winked at him before stepping out and opening the car door for him.

 

As they walked into the dance center, Nicky clutched his little bag with his dance shoes, still chattering away. “Do you think I could teach a class someday? Like you with dance and Mama with books?”

 

Rio glanced down at him with a warm smile. “I think you’d be a natural. But first, you’ve got to master those moves in your own class. Deal?”

 

“Deal!” Nicky exclaimed enthusiastically, his energy never waning as he skipped a few steps ahead of her, the small bag swinging from his hand. He paused just before the glass doors of the dance center, turning to look back at her with a wide grin on his face. “I’m gonna be the best dancer ever, just wait!”

 

The hum of activity greeted them as they stepped inside, the sound of kids laughing and feet tapping on the hardwood floors filling the air. Parents lingered near the reception desk, exchanging pleasantries with instructors, while groups of children darted through the space, their energy and excitement palpable. 

 

“Miss Rio!” one of the older kids called, waving enthusiastically from across the room. Rio waved back, her presence immediately commanding attention in the bustling space.

 

As they reached the little changing room tucked away in the back, Rio knelt down beside Nicky, who was practically bursting with excitement. He hopped from one foot to the other, barely able to contain himself as Rio carefully helped him slip into his tiny dance shoes. His feet wiggled impatiently as she tied the laces, her nimble fingers moving with practiced ease.

 

“Okay, champ,” she said, tightening the last bow. “You’re all set. Go show them what you’ve got.”

 

Nicky grinned, his cheeks flushed with excitement. “Do you think I can do the spin thing today?”

 

Rio’s smile widened. “I know you can. Just remember what we practiced—stay balanced, and don’t forget to have fun.”

 

Nicky tugged on her hand. “Can we go to my studio now? I want to show you my new moves before class starts!”

 

Rio knelt beside him, adjusting his bag strap. “How about you get warmed up with your friends first? I’ll be there in a few minutes.”

 

He nodded, practically vibrating with anticipation. “Okay, but only if you promise to watch me!”

 

“I’ll always watch you,” Rio said with a laugh, ruffling his hair as she stood.

 

As he bounded toward his group, Rio couldn’t help but feel a wave of pride wash over her. She had a front-row seat to his growth, both as a dancer and as a little human discovering the world with a fierce enthusiasm. This was their little world, this space filled with music, laughter, and the energy of children finding their rhythm. It was where they both found joy, where Nicky was given the freedom to explore and grow, and where Rio could witness his progress in real-time.

 

Rio took a moment to glance at the clock, noting that the class would begin soon. With a soft exhale, she turned toward the staff room, her mind already beginning to focus on the lesson plan she’d prepared earlier that morning. As she made her way down the hallway, her thoughts shifted toward the choreography and movements she’d designed to challenge her students that day, but even as she mentally slipped into instructor mode, she couldn’t help but carry that warmth with her. 

 

Rio grabbed her CD and made her way back to the studio, where the energy inside was already buzzing. The children were scattered throughout the space—some leaning against the barre, others sitting cross-legged on the floor, and a few already animatedly chatting amongst themselves, their voices high-pitched with excitement.

 

As soon as one of the kids spotted her, they jumped up, unable to contain their enthusiasm. “Miss Rio!” she called out, her voice filled with an eagerness that made Rio’s heart warm. “Are you teaching us today?”

 

Rio’s face lit up with a bright smile. “I sure am!” she called back, her voice carrying across the room with the promise of something exciting. She clapped her hands lightly, an attention-grabbing gesture that immediately silenced the room. “So you’d better get ready, because we’ve got some fun stuff planned!”

 

At her words, the kids erupted into cheers, their energy practically vibrating through the floor as their little slippers squeaked on the polished wood. The room filled with a palpable excitement, each child eager for the class to begin.

 

“Miss Rio, are we doing leaps today?” one of the boys asked, practically bouncing on his toes, his eyes wide with anticipation.

 

“Can we practice the recital dance?” another voice piped up from across the room, its owner clutching a dance shoe like it was a prized possession.

 

Rio chuckled softly, holding up her hands to bring the room back to order. “One thing at a time, everyone!” she said, her tone light but firm, as she enjoyed the collective energy that filled the space. “First, we’ll warm up, and then we’ll see how much energy you’ve got left for some leaps and recital practice.”

 

A collective groan of playful disappointment rose from the group, but it was all in good fun. The kids knew that Rio would make every minute worth their while. Without further prompting, they all scrambled into their usual positions, eager to get started. Rio noticed that Nicky had taken his spot front and center, his posture already straight, and a grin plastered across his face.

 

As Rio began to organize them, she heard a few hushed whispers coming from the group. One of the other kids leaned toward Nicky, his voice just loud enough for Rio to hear. “We’re so lucky Miss Rio’s our teacher,” he said, not even trying to lower his voice. “She’s so fun and so pretty.”

 

Nicky’s chest puffed up with pride at the compliment, and he shot a quick, conspiratorial glance toward Rio. His smile was a mixture of sweetness and a little bit of mischief, a sign of the deep connection the two shared. “She’s the best,” Nicky responded matter-of-factly, his eyes sparkling with admiration.

 

Rio’s heart swelled at the simple honesty in his voice. She shook her head with a fond smile, her eyes softening as she took in the group. “Alright, enough flattery, everyone,” she said, her voice teasing but warm. “Let’s get moving before you all talk your way out of warm-ups!”

 

The kids erupted into laughter, some of them playfully groaning as they knew all too well that Rio’s warm-up sessions were no joke.

 

“Alright, dancers,” she called out, clapping her hands to grab their attention. “Let’s get started! Everyone spread out—remember, no bumping into your neighbors unless you want to owe me ten jumping jacks!”

 

The kids giggled as they scrambled into their spots, a few glancing nervously at their spacing to avoid the dreaded penalty.

 

Rio took her place at the front of the room, her presence attracting attention without a single word of force. The kids quieted down instantly, their eyes focused on her as she exuded an energy that was both authoritative and playful. It was a balance she had perfected over the years—able to encourage, inspire, and make her students feel like they were capable of achieving more than they ever thought possible.

 

She led them through their stretches with a light-hearted ease, cracking jokes and offering little bursts of encouragement along the way, and guiding them through each movement with clear, gentle instructions. “Reach for the sky! Higher! Pretend you’re grabbing the biggest star you can find!” She exaggerated the motion, her arms sweeping upward, and the kids mimicked her with giggles and determination.

 

As they stretched, she gave praise to their form, her eyes catching each of them in turn as she moved through the room, making sure no one was left out or overlooked.

 

“Great job, Sarah,” she called out, her voice warm. “That’s the kind of reach we need. Keep that energy up, team!”

 

When it came time to work on splits, Rio noticed little Sophie scooting closer, her face scrunched up in determination. “Miss Rio,” she said, her voice tinged with a mix of frustration and persistence, “can you help me? I’m almost there, but it feels stuck!”

 

As Rio helped Sophie, a few of the other kids leaned forward, their eyes bright with curiosity. “Miss Rio, can you check mine next?” one of them asked eagerly, a grin already forming on his face.

 

“Mine too!” another child chimed in, practically bouncing on the spot.

 

Rio chuckled, raising a hand for attention. “One at a time, everyone!” she called, her voice playful yet firm. Turning back to Sophie, she gave the little girl a gentle pat on the shoulder. “You’re all set, Sophie. Keep practicing, and you’ll get there.”

 

Sophie beamed at her, a quiet sense of accomplishment blooming on her face. Rio moved on to the next child with a seamless flow, checking postures, adjusting stances, and offering words of encouragement that made the process feel less like work and more like a collaborative effort. The kids hung on every word, watching intently as she moved from one to the next.

 

With each adjustment, Rio continued to weave through the room, a dynamic presence—part instructor, part cheerleader, and always ready with a teasing remark to keep the mood light.

 

When the time came to move on to footwork drills, Rio demonstrated each step with exaggerated flair, drawing delighted giggles from the kids as she danced across the floor with exaggerated precision.

 

“Now, watch closely,” Rio said, her tone playful as she skipped through the sequence. “It’s toe-heel-toe-heel, not stomp-stomp-stomp-stomp.”

 

She paused dramatically mid-step, her feet stomping with such exaggerated force that the sound echoed through the room, sending the children into peals of laughter.

 

“You mean like this?” Nicky teased, taking a few stomping steps of his own, the sound of his tiny feet against the floor filling the air.

 

Rio shot him a mock stern look, one eyebrow raised in playful disapproval. “Exactly like that, troublemaker. And if you keep it up, I’ll make you do it as a solo in the recital!”

 

The room erupted into laughter, the kids’ excitement ringing through the space as Nicky flashed a grin, clearly delighted to be at the center of attention.

 

As they worked through the steps, Rio’s balance between fun and structure became more apparent. She had a knack for knowing when to let the kids be silly and when to pull them back on track. Her instructions were firm but never harsh, her playful demeanor making even corrections feel like encouragement.

 

“Remember, it’s not about being perfect,” Rio said, addressing the group as they practiced the steps. “It’s about trying your best and having fun. If you mess up, just keep going! Dancing is about movement, not about nailing every single step. Got it?”

 

“Yes, Miss Rio!” they chorused, their enthusiasm palpable.

 

Nicky, as usual, gravitated toward her throughout the class, looking to her for reassurance or a quick thumbs-up. Rio always responded, whether it was a whispered “Good job” or a brief touch on his shoulder.

 

By the time they moved on to leaps, the atmosphere in the room was electric. The kids were fully immersed in the lesson, their faces flushed with concentration and excitement. The air buzzed with energy as they cheered each other on, their small voices a chorus of encouragement. Rio, standing at the side of the room, clapped her hands enthusiastically after each successful jump, offering tips and words of praise that made every child feel like a star in their own right.

 

She moved with effortless grace as she demonstrated a perfect grand jeté, her body soaring through the air in a smooth, controlled arc. The kids watched, captivated by the fluidity of the movement, eyes wide with admiration. Rio landed with precision, the soft sound of her feet connecting with the floor barely breaking the silence as she smiled at the class, waiting for the next attempt.

 

Just as she prepared to give her next instruction, a loud, clear voice rang out, cutting through the murmur of the class.

 

“Wow, Mom! That’s so cool!”

 

The room fell silent as if someone had pressed pause on a movie. All the kids froze in place, their wide eyes darting between Nicky and Rio, trying to process what they’d just heard.

 

Rio paused slightly, a flicker of surprise crossing her face. Quickly, she replaced it with a warm, reassuring smile, locking eyes with Nicky. “Thank you, bud. You’re cool too,” she said calmly, her voice steady and encouraging.

 

The quiet didn’t last long. A hand shot up from the back of the room. “Miss Rio, is Nicky really your son?”

 

Rio chuckled softly. She took a moment to brush her hands down her leggings as she straightened, looking out over the sea of inquisitive faces. The tension melted away, replaced by curiosity, and she offered them all a smile that was equal parts sincere and playful.

 

“Yes, he is,” Rio said, her tone light and casual, as though it were the most natural thing in the world. “But today, he’s just another one of my amazing students, just like all of you!” She gave them a wink, making the whole room feel like part of the secret.

 

Her easy, open response worked like magic. The children’s expressions shifted from surprise to awe, their initial shock transforming into fascination. They leaned in closer to one another, eager to hear more.

 

“That’s so cool!” one of the older girls exclaimed, bouncing slightly on the balls of her feet, her eyes sparkling with excitement.

 

“You’re so lucky, Nicky,” another child said, her voice full of admiration. “Miss Rio is the best!”

 

Nicky’s chest puffed out with pride, his cheeks pink from the attention, but his smile only widened. “I know!” he said, his voice full of joy and mischief, earning a chorus of giggles from his classmates. His innocence, his absolute pride in his mom, was contagious, and Rio couldn’t help but smile at how effortlessly he stole the spotlight.

 

“Okay, everyone, let’s get back to practicing,” Rio said, clapping her hands to refocus the group. “And if anyone has any questions, save them for after class. For now, let’s see those leaps!”

 

The class quickly resumed its lively energy, the kids pouring their excitement into their dancing. Despite the unexpected moment, Rio maintained her composure, her effortless blend of warmth and authority guiding them back to the lesson.

 

As the children practiced, Nicky caught Rio’s eye from across the room, giving her a toothy grin that made her heart swell. She smiled back, a silent reassurance that everything was just as it should be.

 

The rest of the class flowed with a new, almost electric energy. The kids, already fond of Rio, seemed even more determined to impress her now. They lined up eagerly for their turns to try new moves, their faces glowing with excitement whenever Rio offered praise or corrections.

 

“You’re all doing amazing today,” Rio said, her voice full of warmth as she clapped for a particularly well-executed plié. “I can see so much improvement already!”

 

Nicky, of course, thrived under the spotlight. Every time it was his turn, he looked up at Rio for approval, his grin widening when she gave him a thumbs-up or a proud, “That’s it, Nicky!” The other kids didn’t seem to mind; if anything, they admired him more now, whispering amongst themselves about how cool it must be to have Miss Rio as his mom.

 

As Rio moved through the class, demonstrating steps and offering guidance, her mind occasionally drifted to Nicky’s slip-up earlier. The way he’d called her “Mom” in front of everyone had been so casual, so effortless. For a moment, she’d felt the air leave the room, but as soon as she’d seen his beaming face, everything had fallen into place.

 

It felt natural, she realized, right. Being his mom wasn’t just a role she’d stepped into; it was who she was now. Nicky didn’t hesitate to claim her as his, even if he hadn’t meant to share that part of their lives so openly. And the way the kids had reacted—with awe, admiration, and not a hint of judgment—made her heart swell.

 

“Miss Rio, am I doing this right?” one of the kids called, breaking her train of thought.

 

“You’re so close!” Rio said, immediately refocusing. She stepped closer to demonstrate, adjusting the child’s posture with a gentle hand. “Try bending your knees just a little more. Perfect—there you go!”

 

As she moved to help another student, her gaze flicked to Nicky, who was busy showing a friend his version of the steps. His joy was infectious, and Rio found herself smiling again.

 

By the time the class ended, the kids were buzzing with excitement, chattering about their progress and eagerly planning to practice at home. Rio gathered them in a circle for their usual closing routine, clapping for their hard work and reminding them to stretch.

 

“You all did fantastic today,” she said, her voice full of genuine pride. “I can’t wait to see what you’ll show me next time.”

 

Nicky hung back as the other kids filtered out, bouncing on his toes as he waited for Rio to gather her things. She glanced at him, her heart swelling with affection. Being his mom wasn’t just a title. It was the most natural thing in the world.

 

After class, the studio buzzed with the usual post-lesson chaos—kids chatting excitedly, stuffing their shoes into their bags, and comparing notes on the day’s moves. Nicky stood by the cubbies, carefully tucking his dance shoes into his bag, his face still glowing from the class.

 

As Rio moved around the studio, carefully collecting the scattered water bottles and stray shoes, a small voice called out from the side of the room. She turned to find one of her younger students, a little girl with curly pigtails and a curious gleam in her eyes, lingering by the doorway. Rio’s gaze softened as she noticed the child hesitating, her small fingers nervously twisting the hem of her shirt.

 

“Everything okay, sweetheart?” Rio asked, her tone gentle.

 

The girl bit her lower lip, her cheeks flushing pink as she shifted her weight from one foot to the other, unsure of how to ask what was clearly on her mind. Finally, with a small but determined breath, she clasped her hands behind her back and looked up at Rio, her eyes wide and full of innocent curiosity. “Miss Rio… does Nicky call you Mom at home too?”

 

Rio’s heart skipped at the question, but she smiled softly, keeping her voice calm and warm. ““He sure does,” Rio replied, her tone light, but there was an undeniable tenderness behind the words. She paused for a second, her smile widening. “But you know what? That’s our little secret, okay? Can you keep it safe?”

 

The girl’s eyes widened in surprise, and for a moment, Rio saw that quiet spark of mischief, that same curiosity that often led the little one to ask questions no one else would think of. A soft giggle escaped her lips, and she nodded enthusiastically, her face lighting up as if she had just been entrusted with the most important of secrets. “I promise! But… can I tell my mom?” she asked, her voice lowering to a conspiratorial whisper, as if they were about to share something thrilling and significant.

 

Rio winked at her, giving her shoulder a gentle pat. “You can tell your mom. You’re officially part of the secret club now.”

 

The girl beamed, her shyness melting away, and skipped off to rejoin the other kids. Rio straightened, watching her go with a small chuckle.

 

Nearby, Nicky was waiting patiently, his backpack slung over one shoulder. When Rio caught his eye, he gave her a knowing smile.

 

“All set, buddy?”

 

“Yep!” Nicky chirped, taking her hand as they walked toward the door of the studio.

 

Outside, the evening air felt cool and crisp, a stark contrast to the warmth of the studio. The sound of children’s laughter and the low murmur of parents’ conversations filled the air, creating a cozy, bustling atmosphere as the little ones ran to greet their families. Rio and Nicky stood near the curb, waiting for the familiar sight of Agatha’s car to appear.

 

And then, it did.

 

A sleek black car pulled up smoothly to the lot, its polished surface gleaming under the fading light of day. Rio’s eyes caught the movement as Agatha stepped out, looking effortlessly composed in a tailored coat that draped perfectly over her frame, her heels clicking softly on the pavement. She carried herself with a quiet elegance, her presence alone commanding attention, yet there was a softness to her expression when she spotted Nicky.

 

“Mama!” Nicky shouted, his face lighting up with pure joy. Without missing a beat, he bolted toward her, arms outstretched, his little legs moving quickly in his excitement.

 

Agatha crouched just in time to catch him, her lips curving into a warm smile as she scooped him up. “There’s my little star! Did you have fun in class?”

 

Before Nicky could respond, one of the other children, still lingering nearby with their parents, tilted their head curiously at the sight of the trio. “Is that your other mom?” the child asked, their tone innocent yet tinged with wonder as they stared at Agatha and Nicky.

 

Agatha froze for a brief moment, her gaze flickering between the child and Rio, uncertainty flickering in her eyes. It was just a split second, but Rio caught it and was already stepping forward, her expression light and relaxed, her demeanor as easygoing as always.

 

“Yes, that’s Nicky’s Mama,” Rio said with a breezy smile, her tone cheerful and casual. “And she’s here to take us all home. Isn’t that sweet of her?” Her words flowed smoothly, putting everyone at ease.

 

Nicky, still cradled in Agatha’s arms, blinked curiously at the child who had asked the question, and then glanced up at Agatha. In that moment, Agatha’s understanding kicked in, and she gave him a knowing smile, her eyes softening as she held him closer.

 

“Yeah, that’s Mama,” Nicky said with complete innocence, snuggling deeper into Agatha’s arms. “And she loves my Mom.” His voice was light, matter-of-fact, as though this was the most natural thing in the world.

 

The child seemed satisfied with this simple explanation, nodding with a casual shrug before scampering back to their parent.

 

Rio let out a quiet breath of relief as she approached Agatha, who had a mischievous glint in her eye. “New official title?” Agatha asked softly, her lips twitching with amusement.

 

Rio rolled her eyes good-naturedly, a smile tugging at the corners of her lips. “Nicky thought it was time to make it official.”

 

Agatha chuckled. “And wasn’t he so right!.”

 

“He was,” Rio said, shooting her a knowing grin.

 

As they made their way through the parking lot, Nicky perched on Agatha’s hip, the evening air was filled with the excited chatter of kids recounting their class to their parents. Rio walked slightly ahead, carrying her dance bag and Nicky’s belongings.

 

Just as they neared Agatha’s car, the sound of footsteps behind them caught Rio’s attention. She turned to see Sophie’s mom, the ever-friendly and bubbly woman, walking toward them with Sophie at her side, her curly hair bouncing as she skipped along, her face flushed with the energy of the class.

 

“Miss Rio,” Sophie’s mom called out, her voice warm and inviting, “I just wanted to say how wonderful you are with the kids.” She beamed at Rio, her smile sincere and appreciative. “My daughter absolutely adores your class. She’s been practicing her moves all week, and I think it’s because of how encouraging you are.”

 

Rio blinked in pleasant surprise, a rush of warmth flooding her chest at the compliment. Her cheeks colored just a hint, and she smiled widely, grateful for the kind words. “Oh, thank you so much! That really means a lot to hear,” she replied, her tone sincere and touched. “Sophie’s a joy to teach—she’s always so eager to learn, and she brings such a positive energy to the class.” Her eyes softened as she glanced over at the little girl, who was now standing quietly by her mother’s side, eyes wide with admiration.

 

The parent beamed, clearly pleased. “Well, it shows how much she looks up to you. Honestly, it’s rare to see someone handle a group of kids so well—firm but fun. You’ve got a real gift.”

 

Rio chuckled softly, glancing back at Agatha, who was observing the interaction with a quiet, proud smile. “I try my best. They make it easy, though—they’re such a great group.”

 

Before Sophie’s mom could respond, Nicky piped up from Agatha’s arms, “She is the best teacher ever!”

 

Rio shot him a playful look, though her eyes sparkled. “Thank you, little love,” she said with a laugh, ruffling his hair. “I’m lucky to have such a sweet assistant.”

 

Sophie’s mom smiled warmly at the exchange. She observed the subtle but undeniable connection they shared, the effortless camaraderie between the three. After a moment, she hesitated, her tone shifting to one of curiosity, though still friendly. “Sorry to ask, but—” she began, her words measured but not unkind, “I couldn’t help but notice how close you all seem. Are you… related in some way?”

 

Rio felt the question linger in the air, and for a brief second, she glanced at Agatha, the quiet understanding between them palpable. She met Sophie’s mom’s gaze with a calm, open expression. “We’re all family,” she said, her voice steady yet full of affection. “Nicky’s Agatha’s son, and now he is mine too.”

 

Sophie’s mom blinked, taken aback by the unexpected honesty, her eyes widening for a fraction of a second. She quickly masked her surprise with a soft, approving smile, clearly warmed by the revelation. “Ah, I see,” she said, nodding thoughtfully. “That’s wonderful! It’s so nice to see a family like this. You all seem very close-knit.”

 

Agatha, still holding Nicky securely in her arms, nodded in agreement. Her gaze softened as she tightened her grip on her son, pulling him closer. There was something unspoken in that moment, a sense of deep, unwavering connection that spoke volumes. “We are,” Agatha replied, her voice rich with quiet love. “Nicky is everything to us.”

 

The warmth in Sophie’s mom’s smile deepened, her eyes reflecting a genuine appreciation. “That’s lovely,” she said, her voice filled with admiration. “It’s nice to see kids surrounded by so much love. You’re doing a great job with him. You’re a lucky woman, Miss Rio.”

 

Rio felt a surge of emotion swell in her chest at the kind words, but she held her composure with ease, a soft smile playing on her lips. “We’re just trying to make sure he knows he’s always loved,” she replied, her voice steady but tinged with gratitude.

 

Sophie’s mom gave one last smile, a warm, heartfelt expression of support, before turning to walk away, Sophie skipping happily by her side. As they headed toward their car, Rio, Agatha, and Nicky stood together for a moment, basking in the peaceful, almost sacred atmosphere that enveloped them.

 

As they climbed into the car, Agatha gave Rio a knowing look. “Not exactly the most subtle way to reveal our family dynamic, huh?”

 

Rio laughed lightly, her tone playful but full of affection. “After today, I think we’re well past subtle, Agatha.”

 

Nicky grinned up at them both from the backseat. “I like it when people know we’re a family.”

 

“We do, too, buddy,” Agatha said softly, pressing a gentle kiss to his forehead.

 

As Rio settled into her seat and buckled her seatbelt, Agatha turned to her, her smirk resurfacing. “Firm but fun, huh? I think they’ve nailed your teaching style.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes in mock exasperation, laughing as she did so. “Oh, hush. You’re just jealous you didn’t get a compliment too,” she teased, her tone light but affectionate.

 

Agatha chuckled as she slid into the driver’s seat, her hands gripping the steering wheel with practiced ease. “Touché,” she said, glancing at Rio with a sly smile before starting the car.

 

The car pulled smoothly out of the parking lot, and as the evening sky deepened, Nicky leaned forward in his seat, his curiosity piqued by the conversation. “Mama, did you hear what the lady said about Mom?” he asked, his voice filled with excitement as he bounced slightly in his seat.

 

“I did,” Agatha replied with a grin, her eyes twinkling as she glanced at Rio, who was smiling softly, gazing out the window at the dimming sky. “And you know what? She were absolutely right.”

 

Rio shook her head gently, her smile softening. She gazed out at the world passing by, her thoughts turning inward. It had been a good day.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

Guys, I've just started writing the very last chapter of this story, and I can't wait to share it with you, i already like it a lit hihi!

As always, comments are my greatest gifts!

Love you all

Three Drunk Swords

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

Round and round the fire

Leaping through the flames, or joined in circles,

Rustically solemn or in rustic laughter

Lifting heavy feet in clumsy shoes,

Earth feet, loam feet, lifted in country mirth.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

The air was still thick with the energy of their performance as Rio, Alice, and Jen made their way out of the venue. The applause still echoed in their minds, a sweet reverberation that made their hearts race with adrenaline. Rio could feel the buzz from the crowd, the rush of every beat she’d hit on her drum set, every chord Alice and Jen had strummed. It had been a perfect night.

 

“Did you see their faces when I hit that solo?” Alice grinned, still riding the high of the performance. “They were loving it!”

 

Jen chuckled, her guitar case slung over her shoulder and her hand firmly clasped in Alice’s. “They couldn’t get enough. It’s like we became the show instead of providing it.” Her wide smile spoke to the pride she felt.

 

Rio, walking a few paces ahead, turned back to them with a satisfied grin, walking backwards. “The crowd was on firetonight. We were unstoppable. I swear, every time I looked up, it was like the entire room was vibrating with the music.”

 

Their footsteps echoed on the sidewalk as they headed for a small bar around the corner, their favorite place to unwind after a show. The neon lights of the bar flickered in the distance, a familiar beacon calling them to relax, celebrate, and maybe do a little bragging, too.

 

“Drinks on me,” Rio declared, throwing a playful glance over her shoulder. She could already taste the sweet relief of a cold drink, something to quiet the buzz of the stage and soothe the energy that had been running through her veins.

 

Alice and Jen cheered in agreement, their laughter filling the night air. Rio wasn’t sure how many drinks it would take before they were all so tipsy they could barely stand, but tonight, she wasn’t thinking about limits. She was thinking about fun.

 

As they stepped inside the bar, the low murmur of conversation and clinking glasses welcomed them. The cozy, dimly lit space was already buzzing with energy. There was something comforting about the familiar scent of spilled beer and the hum of conversation after a night of giving everything on stage. Rio slid onto a stool at the bar, the others quickly following suit.

 

“Three beers, please,” Rio said with a grin, waving a hand. “Actually, make it four. I’m celebrating.”

 

The bartender shot them a curious look, but didn’t question it. He set four bottles in front of them, and Rio grabbed hers with a flourish. She toasted with Alice and Jen, the three of them clinking bottles together.

 

“To being unstoppable,” Rio said, her grin wide and wild.

 

“To Three of Swords,” Alice added, tapping her bottle against Rio’s.

 

Jen raised her bottle last. “To the best damn band in the world.”

 

They all took a long, satisfying sip. The night was just beginning, and as Rio leaned back in her seat, the weight of the performance still thrumming in her chest, she knew this was exactly where she was meant to be.

 

The conversation flowed easily, like the music they’d just played, smooth and in sync. Rio leaned back, feeling the warmth of the alcohol spreading through her, and exchanged playful glances with Alice and Jen.

 

Alice took the first shot. “Alright, seriously—I think we need to talk about how Rio basically owned the drums tonight. You were a beast up there.”

 

Rio smirked and took another sip of her drink, pretending to be modest. “I’m just doing my part, y’know? Someone’s gotta keep the tempo, and it’s clearly a tough job.”

 

Alice shot Jen a teasing glance. “Yeah, someone’s gotta keep us all on time since someone can’t seem to make it through a set without almost missing their cue.” She burst into laughter. “I still can’t believe you almost missed your cue on the last song. The entire crowd was waiting for you to play that solo!”

 

Jen, traying to be a good sport, simply raised her glass. “Hey, in my defense, Rio was so distracting with her insane drumming, I got a little lost in the rhythm. But don’t worry, I made up for it.”

 

Alice teased her, tapping Jen’s shoulder with a playful look. “Made up for it? You barely caught the cue at all, babe.”

 

Jen smiled, clearly unbothered by Alice’s playful teasing. “It was theatrics, alright? A bit of suspense before the big finale.”

 

Rio chuckled at the banter between them, a warmth spreading in her chest. The two had always been a couple of banter queens, but tonight, their dynamic felt even more infectious. The energy in the room mirrored the chemistry on stage—effortless, playful, and totally in sync. Rio felt herself drawn into their easy camaraderie, her laughter spilling out.

 

“Oh, Jen,” Rio said, wiping a tear from her eye after laughing so hard. “You just barely made it, but we all know you were just giving the crowd the drama they didn’t know they needed.”

 

“Drama’s my middle name,” Jen quipped, grinning and clinking her bottle with Rio’s. “But seriously—did you see the way the crowd went wild after Rio’s solo?”

 

Rio grinned, enjoying the praise. “Well, I do aim to please.”

 

“Please? Honey, you wrecked the drums,” Alice said with mock seriousness. “It was like the entire room was vibrating with every beat you hit. You could’ve set the stage on fire, and the crowd would’ve been too busy cheering to notice.”

 

Jen raised an eyebrow, a teasing smirk playing on her lips. “Let’s be real, though. There’s one thing we need to talk about.”

 

“What’s that?” Rio asked, leaning forward.

 

“The fact that you literally stole the spotlight tonight,” Jen said with a wink, as if Rio hadn’t already noticed. “I think you’re the reason half the people in the crowd didn’t even notice Alice and I out there. I’m starting to think we’re just the side act, huh?”

 

Alice joined in, nodding dramatically. “You know, Rio, you’ve got to start sharing the stage a little. It’s only fair. I’m starting to think you’re jealous because your girlfriend is at home while mine is right here.” Alice continued, draping an arm around Jen and pulling her closer to kiss her square on the lips.

 

Rio grinned, pretending to look scandalized. “Oh, I’m sorry. Should I step back and let you have your moment? And my girlfriend and I are doing very well, thank you very much.”

 

Jen and Alice erupted into giggles at Rio’s mock-serious tone. It was moments like this that made everything feel so easy. The drinks flowed, the conversation flowed, and there was no pressure, no stress—just the shared joy of their friendship and the excitement of the night they’d just had.

 

The laughter grew louder, a few drinks too many fueling their carefree antics. Rio felt the warmth of the alcohol spread through her limbs, her laughter coming a little too easily. Normally, she prided herself on being able to handle her liquor, but tonight, it felt like her head was spinning just a little more than usual.

 

Jen, with her usual mischievous grin, raised her glass. “Come on, you two. One more round for the road. It’s celebration time, remember?”

 

Alice laughed, her cheeks flushed. “Oh, I’m in. Let’s go! We’re unstoppable tonight, what’s one more drink between friends?”

 

Rio, still smiling, was tempted by the suggestion, the fun of the night bubbling up inside her. She didn’t even need much encouragement—she was already feeling loose, the buzz settling into a pleasant, fuzzy warmth. “Alright, alright, one more,” she said, lifting her glass to meet theirs.

 

They clinked their glasses together, and the trio downed their drinks almost in unison, each of them feeling the effects in their own way. Jen, as usual, was the first to giggle, leaning into Alice as if they were sharing an inside joke. Alice wasn’t far behind, the tipsiness turning her teasing into something more affectionate. “I swear this night is way too much fun.”

 

Rio grinned, nodding in agreement but finding that the room had started to feel just a little… wobbly. She shook her head, trying to shake off the dizziness, but the world still spun slightly around her. “Okay, okay, we’re done now, right? I’m feeling like the floor’s moving under me.”

 

Alice, her tipsy energy magnified by the alcohol, suddenly stood up on her chair with a dramatic flourish. Her eyes sparkled with mischievous excitement as she raised her glass high above her head.

 

“Ladies and gentlemen!” Alice announced, her voice a little louder than necessary. “I’d like to make a speech! About something important!”

 

Jen, already swaying slightly in her seat, raised an eyebrow but smiled. “Oh no,” she muttered, as she watched her girlfriend make a spectacle of herself with fondness in her eye.

 

Rio, equally tipsy, grinned and leaned back in her seat. “Here we go,” she laughed, her words a little slurred but no less amused.

 

The few patrons still in the bar turned toward Alice, their curiosity piqued. Alice, completely undeterred by the attention, began to speak with a dramatic, theatrical flair.

 

“We are Three of Swords,” she declared, holding her glass up like a trophy, “and we are undefeated! The best band to ever grace this town! You’ve seen our gigs, you know the magic we create when we get on stage! We—”

 

“We are legends in the making!” Jen added from her seat, slurring slightly but grinning wide.

 

Alice shot her a playful look before continuing. “Exactly! The best! We’re unstoppable, and no one can ever forget what they saw when we took the stage tonight! Because let’s face it, we’re freaking awesome!”

 

The bar patrons, a few of whom had been watching the band earlier that night, couldn’t help but laugh and cheer. A few claps started, then more followed, until the entire bar was giving Alice a round of applause, some even cheering. Rio, thoroughly amused, clapped along with them, her laughter bubbling up with the crowd’s infectious energy.

 

“Thank you! Thank you!” Alice called, taking a dramatic bow. “We’ll be here all week! No, really, we will. But seriously, keep an eye on us, because we’re just getting started!”

 

Jen stood up, leaning into Alice as if ready to join her in some impromptu victory dance, though she wasn’t quite steady on her feet. “We might be legends already, but you all haven’t seen anything yet,” she said with a grin.

 

The trio’s carefree joy only grew as the night wore on. The atmosphere in the bar shifted from a laid-back post-gig vibe to a full-blown party, with Rio, Alice, and Jen at the center of it all. The music pulsed through the speakers, and without any hesitation, they all found themselves on the dance floor, moving in time with the rhythm, their laughter and shouts blending with the beat.

 

Rio spun in circles, her body moving more freely than it ever did on the stage. She was completely caught up in the moment, her hair flying around her as she giggled and twirled, her hands raised high in the air. “This is the best night ever!” she shouted, her words slurring just a bit as she tried to catch her breath between bursts of laughter.

 

Jen, slightly less coordinated but no less enthusiastic, grabbed Alice’s hand and pulled her toward the center of the floor. The two of them giggled and stumbled around, their laughter contagious as they bumped into other patrons. It wasn’t long before their playful energy turned into something more affectionate, as they began making out right there on the dance floor. The crowd cheered them on, egging them on with cheers and whistles.

 

Rio watched them for a moment, her face a mix of amusement and excitement. She stumbled toward them, her own giggles spilling out.  “I want Agatha to come here and make out with me, too! Right now!” she slurred, flailing her arms dramatically. Jen and Alice, equally intoxicated, laughed at Rio’s outburst, spurring her on with more ridiculous comments of their own.

 

Rio laughed even harder at their antics, not quite able to form coherent sentences, but clearly having the time of her life. “Agatha will have a heart attack when she finds out about this!” she shouted, raising her glass for a toast she couldn’t quite finish. Drinks splashed over the edge, spilling onto the floor, adding to the growing mess around them.

 

 

At home, Agatha stood by the vanity, slipping into her silk robe as the quiet of the house settled around her. Nicky was with Lilia for the weekend, leaving the house eerily peaceful. The soft ticking of the clock filled the silence as Agatha brushed out her long hair, a small smile playing at her lips. It had been a good day—just the kind of quit evening she had been looking forward to.

 

She glanced at the clock, her fingers pausing mid-stroke as she noticed the time. Rio was still not home.

 

A wave of concern washed over her. She knew how easily time could slip away when Rio got caught up in things, but it was already late. Too late for Rio to still be out.

 

Agatha set down her brush and reached for her phone, her fingers hovering over the screen for a moment before she dialed Rio’s number. She needed to check in, just in case.

 

The phone rang twice before Rio picked up. Agatha could hear the muffled sounds of music and laughter in the background—an indication that Rio was at least in good company, but the slurring in her voice made her frown instantly.

 

“Hey, love,” Rio greeted, her tone a little too loud, the words tumbling out in a slurred, uneven rhythm. “You wouldn’t believe what just happened!” She broke into a fit of giggles, the sound bubbling through the phone like champagne poured too fast.

 

Agatha’s frown deepened, the corners of her mouth tightening as she listened. Rio’s voice carried the unmistakable telltale signs of intoxication—the exaggerated pitch, the disjointed cadence, the way her laughter seemed to tumble into itself like she couldn’t keep her balance even in conversation. Agatha’s sharp intuition filled in the rest of the picture: the sway in Rio’s movements, the glass in her hand, the unsteady steps.

 

“Oh, is that so?” Agatha said, her voice carefully even, though there was no hiding the edge of concern beneath her words. “How are you, darling?”

 

“I’m fine!” Rio replied, dragging out the word as though it was a definitive statement. “I’m more than fine, actually!” She punctuated the declaration with another bout of laughter, the sound spilling through the phone like a too-bright neon sign flashing everything’s fine when it clearly wasn’t.

 

Agatha pinched the bridge of her nose, inhaling deeply to steady herself before responding. “You’re not fine,” she said, her voice a blend of firmness and gentle insistence. “Where are you, love?”

 

“I’m…” Rio hesitated, giggling softly, the pause long enough for Agatha’s concern to deepen. “I’m still at the bar! We were… dancing, having fun, and then I—oh, I’m fine, really!” The hiccup that followed only added to the unraveling picture. “Just having a blast.”

 

“Rio,” Agatha said, her tone softening but no less resolute. “I’m glad you’re having fun, but I need you to tell me exactly where you are. Can you do that for me?”

 

There was a long pause on the other end, the music and chatter in the background suddenly feeling louder as Rio’s drunken mind tried to process the request. “It’s, uh… that place, you know, the one with the… lights? And the… music?” She giggled again, clearly struggling to focus. “Oh, come on, you know it!”

 

Agatha closed her eyes for a moment, exhaling slowly. She recognized the bar Rio was describing—it was one Rio had mentioned before, a favorite spot among her friends. The mental image of Rio, likely unsteady on her feet and surrounded by chaos, made Agatha’s chest tighten further.

 

“Stay right where you are,” Agatha said, her voice calm but carrying an undeniable sense of authority. “I’m coming to get you.”

 

“What? Nooo, you don’t have to do that!” Rio protested, though the slurring in her words dulled any sense of conviction. “I’m good, I promise! I can—”

 

“You’re not fine, Rio,” Agatha interrupted gently, her tone unwavering. “And I’m not letting you stumble home alone or stay there like this. Just stay put, love. I’ll be there soon.”
