Agatha nodded, her gaze fixed on Rio with an intensity that was soft but unwavering. “It wasn’t anything extreme, but you started mumbling in your sleep… about needing to work on your thesis again. You sounded so panicked, like you were ready to get out of bed and start working right then and there, as if everything else just faded away.”

 

Rio’s brow furrowed, and a slight blush crept into her cheeks, the embarrassment rising up like a wave she didn’t know how to avoid. “I… don’t remember that at all,” she admitted, her voice small and vulnerable, as if admitting that she didn’t recall it somehow made the whole situation worse.

 

Agatha gave a soft, understanding smile, her fingers still brushing the blanket, the fabric offering her some kind of comfort. “You wouldn’t, ”Agatha said, her voice soft but firm. ““You were so exhausted you could barely keep your eyes open. I wasn’t going to let you get up and push yourself any further. I just got you to lie back down, and you were out again in seconds.”

 

Rio swallowed hard, the shame and vulnerability she’d felt the day before bubbling back up. She set the water glass down on the bedside table, her fingers trembling slightly, feeling suddenly exposed.

 

“I didn’t even realize I was that far gone,” Rio muttered, the words thick with guilt. Her voice was small, the shame rising in her like an uninvited guest that she couldn’t shake. The idea of having let herself reach that point, of letting her exhaustion spill over into something as fragile as a nightmare, made her heart ache.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened even further, her heart aching for the woman beside her. She reached out, her hand finding Rio’s with a tenderness that was both grounding and reassuring. She squeezed gently, offering comfort that Rio so desperately needed but couldn’t seem to ask for. “Love,” Agatha said, her voice warm and steady, “you’ve been running on empty for too long, it’s no wonder your body started pushing back. You’ve been carrying so much, not just physically but mentally and emotionally. Last night wasn’t your fault—it was your exhaustion talking, not you.”

 

Rio looked down at their joined hands, her chest tightening. “I didn’t mean to make you worry,” she murmured.

 

Agatha tilted her head, her expression soft as she brushed her thumb across Rio’s knuckles. “I’m not worried because of you, Rio. I’m worried because I see how much you’re shouldering, and I just want you to be okay. That’s what I’m here for. And Nicky, too.”

 

Rio swallowed hard, the words settling in her chest like a stone. She felt a wave of guilt wash over her, pressing down so heavily she could barely catch her breath. She hadn’t realized how much of herself she’d been keeping locked away, how much of her burden she’d been silently carrying, shutting out the very people who loved her. The memory of Nicky’s concerned face flashed in her mind—his small, earnest eyes, the way he would check in with her, always so aware of her moods. Her heart ached, the guilt sinking deeper.

 

“I’ve been shutting you both out, haven’t I?” she asked quietly, her voice rough with emotion. The words felt like a confession, like something that had been building for so long it could no longer be contained. It stung to admit it, but in a way, it was also a release.

 

Agatha’s smile was sad but understanding. “A little, but we know you didn’t mean to. You’ve been running on fumes for too long, Rio. We get it. It’s just time to let us in now, okay?”

 

Rio exhaled shakily, her fingers tightening around Agatha’s. “Okay.”

 

Before Rio could say another word, the soft creak of the bedroom door echoed through the quiet space, and Nicky’s small figure appeared in the doorway. Tucked securely under one arm was his blue dragon, its bright colors almost glowing in the morning light. His eyes, the same shade of blue as Agatha’s, immediately brightened when he saw Rio awake. The corners of his mouth curled into a wide grin, and without hesitation, he scrambled onto the bed, making a beeline for her side.

 

“Mom!” Nicky exclaimed, his voice filled with a mix of excitement and gentleness, as if instinctively knowing that she needed peace more than anything. His words were light but soft, his small feet barely making a sound on the floor. “You’re awake! I told Mama you’d feel better after a good sleep.”

 

Rio smiled warmly, her arms opening to him. “Hey, little love. Come here.”

 

Without hesitation, Nicky bounded into her embrace in her lap, dragging his dragon with him. He tucked himself close, squeezing into her chest, the stuffed animal squeezed awkwardly between them. Rio felt a warm rush of love as he nestled against her, his small arms wrapping around her waist.

 

“Me and Dragon protected you all night,” he announced proudly, his little voice carrying a sense of duty far beyond his years. He tilted his head back to meet her eyes, his face alight with determination. “We kept watch, just like we always do, even when we fell asleep.”

 

Rio laughed softly, the sound lighter than it had been in days. She pressed a kiss to the top of his head, feeling the softness of his hair under her lips. “You’re the best little protector I could ever ask for. Thank you, my brave little hero.”

 

Nicky beamed at her words, his chest puffing up with pride. “It’s our job to keep you safe,” he said matter-of-factly, nodding seriously. “Right, Dragon?” He glanced at the stuffed toy, holding it up with a little flourish as if expecting an answer.

 

Rio reached over and ran her hand across the dragon’s soft, plush head, giving it a tender pat. “Right, Dragon,” she agreed with a grin, her voice soft with love. “I’m so lucky to have both of you on my team.”

 

Agatha, watching the tender scene from the side of the bed, smiled softly. She sipped her tea, letting the moment unfold between Rio and Nicky, her heart swelling at the sight of her family coming back together, piece by piece.

 

Agatha set her tea down on the bedside table, the sound a quiet but definite declaration that she was putting everything aside. Her tone was firm yet warm as she said, “Alright, love, here’s what’s going to happen today: no work, no stress. Just rest. Your thesis can wait another day.”

 

Rio opened her mouth to protest, but Agatha raised a hand to cut her off. “This isn’t negotiable—And I’m talking as you girlfriend and your supervisor.”

 

Rio groaned softly, sinking back into her pillows. “She shot Agatha a look of mock exasperation. “You’re pulling rank on me now?” she mumbled, her voice thick with fatigue, though there was no true resistance in her words.

 

Agatha leaned in close, brushing a strand of hair out of Rio’s face with a tenderness that made Rio’s heart flutter. “Absolutely,” she said, her voice softening just a touch, her hand lingering at the side of Rio’s face. “You need to take it easy, love. Let me take care of you, hmm?” There was a quiet certainty in her words, an understanding that Rio needed this—needed to be taken care of—for once.

 

Before Rio could respond, Nicky piped up from her side. “Yeah, Mom! You’re not allowed to do anything but rest today,” he said with a firm nod, his face scrunched up in earnest determination. “Mama’s the boss,” he added, lifting his chin in a way that was meant to emphasize the point, as though he were presenting the most indisputable of facts.

 

Rio blinked, surprised at the sudden burst of authority coming from her young son. Her lips quirked into a smile, and she couldn’t resist reaching over to ruffle his soft hair. “Guess I’m outnumbered, huh?” she asked, her tone teasing but warm, as if she were accepting defeat with grace.

 

Agatha smirked. “You are, indeed. Don’t worry, I’ll make sure the world doesn’t fall apart without you for one day.”

 

Rio gave a small nod, rubbing her eyes as she tried to shake off the remnants of sleep. “Okay then,” she said, her voice still tinged with the haze of exhaustion, but she pushed herself to her feet. She swayed slightly, her balance not quite steady yet, the residual weakness from the previous day still lingering in her body.

 

Agatha’s eyes sharpened with concern, but before she could reach out, Nicky’s small hand was already gripping Rio’s tightly. “Even if you’re a little wobbly,” he said earnestly, his tone serious but his face full of a determined little smile. His grip was firm, a tiny but resolute anchor against Rio’s unsteady steps.

 

“Especially if you’re a little wobbly,” Agatha added with a wink, her voice light but full of affection as she made her way to Rio’s other side, offering her a steadying arm.

 

With a little help, Rio made her way to the kitchen and Agatha pulled out a chair for her, and Nicky climbed into the chair beside her, his blue dragon clutched in his small hands, its soft fabric draped over his lap like a comforting companion.

 

The table was set with a plate of toast, some fruit, and a mug of tea.

 

Rio sighed, her heart swelling at their quiet care. “Thanks, you two. I don’t know what I’d do without you.”

 

“You mean you three, don’t forget Dragon!” Nicky piped up from beside her, holding his dragon up, before putting it down on the table, between Rio and him, as though the soft toy was an important part of their breakfast ritual.

 

“Oh yes, sorry, you three, how could I forget Dragon”, Rio said, teasingly apologizing.

 

Agatha leaned against the counter, her arms crossed on it as she watched them with a fond smile. “You’re definitely outnumbered,” she teased, her voice light but filled with love. “It’s us three now. No escaping.”

 

 

After breakfast, Rio attempted to rise from the table, the steadying warmth of the food already beginning to wear off. She wobbled slightly as she grabbed her empty plate, her movements slow but determined. “Let me at least help with the dishes,” she said, reaching for Nicky’s plate as well.

 

Agatha arched an eyebrow, her expression both amused and firm. “No, love. You’re not doing anything today but resting.” Her tone was calm but unwavering as she moved swiftly to take the plates from Rio’s hands, gently placing them back on the table.

 

Rio’s lips curled into a faint pout, her stubbornness surfacing. “I’m fine. I feel better now. I can at least—”

 

“Rio,” Agatha interrupted, her voice soft but firm, a quiet authority that Rio knew she couldn’t easily dismiss. “You’re still swaying. You need to sit down and recover, not overdo it again.”

 

“But—”

 

“No buts,” Agatha said, cutting her off gently but decisively. She guided Rio back toward the couch with a steady hand on her back. “Sit. Rest. Read a book. Snuggle with Nicky. Whatever you want, but no chores, no work, and no meal prep. Doctor’s orders.”

 

Rio huffed lightly, sinking back onto the couch, her arms crossed in quiet defiance. “You’re not a doctor.”

 

Agatha smirked, her gaze playful yet authoritative. “Technically, I am,” she quipped, draping a soft blanket over Rio’s lap as she settled beside her. “No, but I am the one who’s not letting you collapse again. So, I’m calling the shots.”

 

“Oh right, Dr. Harkness, silly me,” Rio mocked, though the amusement in her voice was clear as she settled deeper into the cushions.

 

From his spot on the living room rug, Nicky looked up. “Yeah, Mom, you have to listen to Mama. She’s always right.”

 

Rio chuckled despite herself, ruffling his hair. “You’re teaming up on me, huh?”

 

“Someone has to keep you in line,” Agatha quipped, pressing a kiss to the top of Rio’s head.

 

Rio sighed, leaning back into the cushions as she finally relented. “Fine. But only because I’m too tired to argue.”

 

“Good choice,” Agatha replied with a grin, heading back to the kitchen.

 

Nicky scooted closer to Rio on the couch, holding his dragon out to her. “Wanna hold him again? He’s really good at making people feel better.”

 

Rio smiled warmly, pulling Nicky into a hug. “I think I’ll take you up on that.” She took the dragon gave her, holding it close as Nicky snuggled against her side.

 

As Rio settled into the couch, Nicky’s energy shifted into full cheerleader mode. “Hold on, Mom! I’ve got something to show you!” He scurried over to the coffee table, rummaging through a colorful pile of papers. His little hands shuffled through the drawings until he triumphantly returned with a crayon masterpiece.

 

“Look, Mom!” Nicky said, climbing back onto the couch and nearly shoving the paper in front of her face, his voice filled with excitement. “It’s you, me, and Mama! See? You’re holding a dragon too!”

 

Rio’s heart melted as she gazed at the drawing. It was bright and full of chaos—wobbly stick figures, jagged lines, and a large green dragon filling the space. It wasn’t the most precise work of art, but the love and joy in it were unmistakable. “Wow, buddy,” she said softly, running a finger over the paper. “This is amazing. You’re a real artist.”

 

“You think so?” Nicky’s eyes sparkled with hope, his grin widening.

 

“I know so,” Rio assured him, leaning down to give him a playful nudge. “You’ve got talent.”

 

Encouraged by her praise, Nicky bounced off the couch again, this time grabbing a larger pile of drawings from the coffee table. With a flair for the dramatic, he spread them out like a miniature art gallery before Rio. “Okay, this one is a dragon flying over a castle!” He pointed to the first picture with enthusiasm, clearly proud of his work. “And this one is a dragon fighting a knight—don’t worry, the dragon wins. And this one—”

 

Rio laughed softly, her exhaustion momentarily forgotten as she watched Nicky talk animatedly about his drawings. His small hands flitted over each page, pointing out details she could barely keep up with. “Wow, so many dragons,” Rio teased, her voice light with affection, perfectly knowing Nicky was in his dragons and dinosaurs phase.

 

“They’re the best!” Nicky responded immediately, puffing out his chest as though defending his beloved dragons from any naysayers. “I wish I could have one,” he added wistfully, his little face full of longing. “And guess what!” he exclaimed suddenly, his eyes lighting up with excitement. “I made up a story about dragons too. Want to hear it?”

 

“Of course I do,” Rio said, her heart a little lighter with each passing moment, the stuffed dragon still nestled comfortably in her lap. She leaned back, settling into the couch as Nicky prepared to tell his story.

 

Nicky climbed back onto the couch, positioning himself next to her and holding up his blue dragon like a storyteller’s prop. “Okay, so one day, there was a dragon named Fluffy—he’s really brave and really nice, like you, Mom—and he had to save his friend Sparkle from an evil wizard!”

 

As Nicky continued, weaving a tale of daring rescues and magical battles, Rio felt her heart lighten. His innocent enthusiasm and the way he looked at her, so full of love and admiration, made her realize how much she’d missed moments like these.

 

“And then,” Nicky said, eyes wide with excitement, “Fluffy and Sparkle were best friends forever, and they made sure no one could ever hurt anyone again. The end!”

 

Rio smiled, a soft laugh escaping her lips as she hugged him closer. “That was the best story, buddy. You’re a fantastic storyteller.”

 

Nicky beamed, basking in her praise. “Thanks, Mom! I can make up more stories whenever you want,” he said eagerly, his face glowing with joy at her approval.

 

Agatha peeked out from the kitchen, watching the two of them with a smile. Seeing Nicky’s unrelenting efforts to cheer Rio up reassured her that, even in the middle of everything, they were still a team.

 

 

In the soft glow of the afternoon, Rio and Agatha sat side by side on the couch, their legs stretched out comfortably. Rio rested her head on Agatha’s shoulder, the warm weight of her body pressing gently against her. Agatha’s hand was resting lightly on Rio’s knee, the subtle connection grounding them both in this moment of stillness.

 

Nicky the small whirlwind of imagination, was nearby on the living room rug, completely engrossed in a tiny world of his own making. He had scattered his toys around him, and the small scene he’d constructed was a flurry of action and excitement, even if only he could truly see it. Among the scattered figurines and toy animals, Señor Scratchy, their family bunny, sat as the unsuspecting center of Nicky’s latest tale.

 

The rabbit, oblivious to the world of dragons and knights that Nicky had spun around him, sat lazily in the middle of the rug, munching on a leaf of lettuce. His long ears twitched every now and then, but his disinterest in the unfolding drama was clear. Undeterred, Nicky carefully placed a tiny knight figurine next to the rabbit, holding it out as though it were a life-or-death offering. He leaned in close, his voice a mix of excitement and seriousness as he announced, “Señor Scratchy, the bravest bunny of them all, prepare for battle against Fluffy, king of Dragonland!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh softly at the sight. The absurdity of it was endearing—Nicky, fully committed to his little world, with Señor Scratchy, who was definitely not about to slay any dragons or defend any kingdoms, as his unlikely hero. Agatha gave her a sideways glance, a small smile tugging at her lips as she watched Nicky’s animated antics.

 

Rio chuckled. “I think Señor Scratchy would rather nap through the whole battle. But I have to admit, Nicky’s commitment to his characters is impressive.”

 

As if on cue, Nicky stood up suddenly, his arms raised dramatically, holding the knight and bunny figurines aloft like they were the stars of an epic showdown. “The battle is fierce!” he declared loudly, causing both Rio and Agatha to laugh. “Fluffy, king of Dragonland, breathes fire—rawr!” He growled, making an exaggerated noise as he moved the knight closer to the disinterested bunny. “But Señor Scratchy, the brave bunny, doesn’t back down! He charges with his sword!”

 

Nicky made a series of very serious swishing motions with the knight, his face scrunched in concentration. The tiny bunny, still largely oblivious, blinked slowly, his only action being the gentle twitching of his nose.

 

Agatha sat quietly, the weight of the book in her lap seemingly insignificant compared to the pull of Rio’s presence beside her. Her eyes flickered between the open pages and the woman resting next to her, noting how Rio’s posture remained slouched, her shoulders heavy with the exhaustion that had lingered for days. The stuffed dragon, Nicky’s most beloved companion, was still tucked under her arm like a lifeline.

 

Agatha’s gaze softened, and with a gentle sigh, she closed the book, setting it aside. She turned her attention fully to Rio, her voice quiet and tender. “You’re still tired, aren’t you?” she asked, her fingers brushing lightly against Rio’s hair, tucking a stray strand behind her ear. The question wasn’t so much an inquiry as it was an acknowledgment of the exhaustion she could see etched on Rio’s face.

 

Rio nodded, stifling a yawn. “A little,” she admitted, though the truth was written all over her face.

 

Agatha’s touch remained gentle, brushing over Rio’s hair with a soothing rhythm. “Why don’t you take a nap? Just a quick one, love,” she suggested softly, her voice warm with concern. There was no hurry in her words, only a strong invitation to rest.

 

Rio started to protest, but Agatha cut her off with a small smile. “It’s actually not up for debate. You need rest, love. I’ll be right here.”

 

Her resistance crumbled almost immediately. The comfort of Agatha’s presence and the quiet atmosphere made it too easy to agree. “Okay,” Rio murmured, shifting slightly to get more comfortable.

 

Agatha shifted with her, ensuring that Rio was settled against her shoulder, her body curling slightly to support her head. The moment Rio’s head found its resting place, something in her body seemed to give way—like a dam breaking, the exhaustion that had been slowly building up over the past few days flooding through her in waves. With a soft exhale, Rio’s body melted into the warmth of Agatha’s side, the tension draining from her muscles.

 

Agatha’s arm naturally draped around Rio, steady and warm, holding her close as she succumbed to the comfort of the space they shared. Within minutes, Rio’s breathing deepened, slow and steady, her body surrendering completely to sleep. Agatha watched her, a small smile tugging at her lips. She absently ran her hand through Rio’s hair, her touch tender and familiar. It was a quiet moment, a rare moment of stillness, and Agatha held onto it with everything she had.

 

From across the room, Nicky paused in his epic knight-and-bunny quest, eyes wide and curious as he looked up at his moms. His small face wrinkled with concern, clutching Señor Scratchy close to his chest as he asked softly, “Is Mom okay?” His voice was a whisper, as though even speaking too loudly might disturb the peace of the moment. “She’s sleeping again.”

 

“She’s just tired, sweetheart,” Agatha replied, her voice low and soothing. “She needs lots of rest to feel better.”

 

Nicky nodded solemnly and looked at Señor Scratchy. “We can be extra quiet, right, Señor Scratchy?” he whispered, stroking the bunny’s soft fur. The rabbit twitched its nose in what Nicky decided was agreement.

 

The room settled back into a peaceful rhythm, the quiet broken only by the soft sound of Nicky’s whispered storytelling as he returned to his toy figures. Agatha stayed exactly where she was, her arm still wrapped around Rio, her gaze soft and watchful. Nicky, content in his own little world, continued his imaginative quest. Occasionally, Señor Scratchy would hop closer to one of the figurines, sniffing at them before hopping away again in search of more important things, like another leaf of lettuce or a cozy corner of the rug.

 

As Rio dozed peacefully against Agatha, her breathing soft and steady, Nicky climbed up onto the couch beside them. His eyes flickered over to Rio, checking that she was still sound asleep before his small fingers reached out, tugging gently at Agatha’s hand.

 

“Mama,” he whispered, his voice barely more than a breath, his gaze drifting between Agatha and Rio.

 

Agatha leaned down slightly, her face softening at the sight of her son. Her voice matched the softness of the room, a quiet murmur only for him. “What is it, sweetheart?”

 

Nicky’s brow furrowed in earnestness, and he shifted closer to Agatha, lowering his voice even further. “I need to go to the store,” he said seriously, his tiny hand gripping Agatha’s with surprising firmness.

 

Agatha blinked in surprise, her eyebrows arching as she processed his words. “The store? Right now?” Her tone carried a mix of curiosity and gentle amusement.

 

Nicky nodded firmly, his grip on her hand tightening, his determination shining in his eyes. “It’s a surprise for Mom. I need to get it myself.”

 

Agatha studied him for a moment, her heart warmed by his determination. “What kind of surprise?”

 

Nicky shook his head, his brown curls bouncing. “I can’t tell you. It’s secret. But it’s really important.”

 

Agatha paused for a moment, her mind momentarily torn. She glanced down at Rio, still nestled against her, lost in her peaceful slumber. The thought of leaving her alone, even for just a short time, caused a knot of unease to twist in Agatha’s stomach. But then she looked at Nicky—his wide eyes full of hope and excitement—and her heart softened. His earnestness was impossible to resist.

 

“Okay,” Agatha relented with a small smile. “But we have to be quick. And quiet, so we don’t wake Mom, alright?”

 

Nicky grinned, his excitement bubbling over. “I’ll be super quick, Mama. Promise!”

 

Agatha carefully shifted Rio’s weight, settling her more comfortably against the couch and draping the blanket over her. She placed a kiss on Rio’s forehead before standing, making sure she was still sound asleep.

 

“Let me grab my keys, and we’ll go,” Agatha whispered to Nicky, who nodded enthusiastically, already bounding toward the door to put on his little sneakers.

 

With one last glance at Rio, Agatha followed Nicky out, her curiosity growing as she wondered what he had planned.

 

 

At the store, Nicky’s small hand clasped tightly in Agatha’s, he marched through the aisles with a determined look on his face. Agatha followed silently, her heart warmed by the little boy’s sense of purpose. “We have to hurry, Mama,” he said, glancing back at her with urgency in his big blue eyes.

 

“I’m right behind you, sweetheart,” Agatha assured, her tone gentle yet amused. She couldn’t help but feel warmth blossom in her chest at his earnestness.

 

Finally, they reached the stuffed animal section, shelves overflowing with plush creatures in every size and color. Nicky’s eyes widened as he took in the rainbow of soft textures and shapes. He released Agatha’s hand and darted toward the shelf like a tiny knight on a mission.

 

“This one!” he declared, his voice bursting with excitement as he tugged a green and purple dragon from the display. Its soft wings fluttered slightly as he held it up, the stitched smile giving it a friendly, comforting expression.

 

Agatha crouched down to his level, her fingers brushing over the plush fabric. “That’s a wonderful choice,” she said, smiling at him. “Why this one, love?”

 

Nicky hugged the dragon tightly to his chest, his curls bobbing as he nodded with certainty. “Because it matches mine! See, mine is blue, and this one is green and purple. Now Mom can have one too, for when she’s sad or tired—like now.”

 

Agatha felt a lump rise in her throat, her chest tightening with emotion. She reached out, brushing a hand over Nicky’s curls. “That’s so thoughtful of you, baby. Mom’s going to love it.”

 

Nicky beamed at her praise and clutched the dragon tighter. “I think it’ll help her. Dragons are really good at protecting and making you feel better.”

 

Agatha leaned forward to kiss his forehead, her voice soft with emotion. “You’re absolutely right, sweetheart. Mom’s going to feel so much better when she sees this.”

 

Nicky grinned, hugging the dragon closer as if it already carried the magic to heal. Agatha stood and offered him her hand, which he took eagerly. “Let’s get it wrapped up so we can take it home to her.”

 

At the register, Nicky insisted on carrying the dragon himself, placing it carefully on the counter with both hands. “It’s for my mom,” he told the cashier earnestly, his little voice solemn. “She’s not feeling good, but this dragon will help her.”

 

The cashier, a kind-looking older woman, smiled warmly at Nicky. “That’s a very thoughtful gift. Your mom is lucky to have such a sweet boy.”

 

Nicky beamed under the praise, glancing at Agatha to make sure she’d heard too. She reached down to ruffle his hair, her heart swelling with pride.

 

Once the dragon was paid for and carefully wrapped in bright tissue paper, they headed back to the car, Nicky clutching the package tightly as if it were the most precious treasure in the world. Agatha glanced down at him as they walked, the corners of her mouth lifting in a smile.

 

“You’re something special, you know that?” she said softly.

 

Nicky looked up at her, his grin widening. “Like a dragon?”

 

Agatha laughed, a quiet, affectionate sound. “Exactly like a dragon—brave, kind, and always protecting the ones you love.”

 

Back in the car, Nicky sat cradling the gift in his lap the entire way home, his eyes shining with anticipation. Agatha couldn’t wait to see Rio’s face when Nicky presented her with his perfect, thoughtful surprise.

 

 

When Agatha and Nicky returned home, the house was wrapped in a tranquil stillness. The warm light of the setting sun filtered through the curtains, casting a soft glow over the living room. On the couch, Rio remained curled up, her body tucked under the cozy blanket Agatha had draped over her earlier. Her breathing was steady and rhythmic, the kind of deep sleep that spoke of much-needed rest. Agatha paused in the doorway, her gaze softening as she took in the peaceful scene.

 

Her lips curled into a gentle smile, relief washing over her at the sight of Rio finally relaxing. She glanced down at Nicky, who clutched the gift bag tightly against his chest, his expression a mix of pride and purpose.

 

Agatha crouched to meet his eye level, her voice quiet to avoid disturbing Rio. “Hey, sweetheart,” she said softly. “I need to step out again for a little while. Can I count on you to stay here and keep an eye on Mom?”

 

Nicky nodded seriously, his little face set with determination as he looked at Rio. “I’ll take care of her, Mama, I promise.  She’s gonna be okay.”

 

Agatha’s heart swelled with love for him. “I know you will, love. Just keep your dragon with her, alright? That way she’ll have some extra protection while she’s sleeping. You can give her the new one later tonight.”

 

Nicky smiled brightly and hugged the bag to his chest. “I’ll make sure she feels better,” he promised.

 

Satisfied, Agatha rose to her feet, casting one last fond glance at Rio. She leaned over, brushing a feather-light kiss against her lover's forehead, her voice barely above a whisper. “Rest well, my love.”

 

As Agatha slipped out the door, careful not to make a sound, Nicky climbed onto the couch beside Rio. He sat cross-legged, his small form barely taking up space, but his presence radiated purpose. He adjusted the blue dragon with careful precision, tucking it snugly beside her under the blanket, planning to give her the new one when Agatha came back.

 

“Don’t worry, Mom,” he whispered, his tone conspiratorial as if sharing a secret with the sleeping Rio. “This dragon’s really strong. It’s gonna make sure you feel better.”

 

Rio stirred slightly, her hand unconsciously brushing against the soft fabric of the plush toy. Nicky watched her closely, his brow furrowing in concentration. He stayed quiet, glancing between her and the door as if ensuring the house remained a sanctuary for her rest.

 

When Señor Scratchy hopped into the room, Nicky gestured for him to come closer. “Hey, Señor Scratchy,” he whispered. “You can help too. You’re really brave, remember? Just stay right here with Mom.”

 

The bunny, as if understanding the gravity of the moment, twitched his nose and settled on the rug near the couch. Nicky smiled to himself, reassured by his growing team of protectors. He leaned back against the couch cushions, one hand resting lightly on the blanket covering Rio, and the other reaching for his picture book.

 

“I got this,” he murmured quietly, his voice filled with a determination far beyond his years. “You don’t have to worry, Mom. You’re safe.”

 

 

Agatha arrived at Lilia’s house as the evening sky deepened into shades of amber and indigo. A swirl of emotions churned within her—concern for Rio, guilt for leaving her behind, and a deep-seated need for answers. She trusted Nicky to keep watch over his mom, but the weight of responsibility lingered, as did the nagging thought that she hadn’t done enough to prevent Rio’s exhaustion from spiraling this far.

 

The porch light cast a warm glow over the doorway as Lilia opened the door, her smile radiating the kind of maternal comfort Agatha had come to rely on. She was dressed in a soft cardigan and linen pants, her posture as open and welcoming as ever, but her sharp, perceptive eyes quickly picked up on Agatha’s unease.

 

“Come in, dear,” Lilia said, stepping aside to let Agatha enter. Her voice was calm, steady—an anchor. “I can see something’s weighing on you. Let’s talk.”

 

Agatha stepped inside, the familiar scent of lavender and freshly baked bread wrapping around her like a comforting blanket. The house was warm, cozy, filled with signs of Lilia’s life—a basket of yarn by the armchair, a few novels scattered on the coffee table, and a framed picture of Rio from her early twenties smiling on the mantle. Agatha’s gaze lingered on it for a moment, her chest tightening with emotion.

 

Lilia guided her to the kitchen, where a kettle was already steaming on the stove. She gestured for Agatha to sit at the table, setting out two mugs as if sensing they’d need the warmth of tea for this conversation. 

 

Agatha hesitated for a moment, then took the seat Lilia had gestured to. She clasped her hands together on the table, her fingers twisting nervously as she tried to put her swirling thoughts into words. “It’s about Rio,” she began, her voice quieter now, tinged with guilt. “She… she collapsed. Well, not exactly collapsed, but she broke down, really. She hasn’t been taking care of herself—working late into the night, not eating, barely sleeping. I should have noticed sooner, but I didn’t. And now I’m terrified that I didn’t intervene in time to stop it from getting this bad.”

 

Lilia listened intently, her steady presence a stark contrast to the whirlwind of emotions Agatha felt. She nodded slowly, her face calm but thoughtful. “Start from the beginning,” she said gently. “What led up to it? Were there signs you missed, or was it sudden?”

 

Agatha ran a hand through her hair, struggling to find the right words. “Her nose started bleeding, which is something I had never seen, really. She’s been jittery, too, like she’s running on fumes. I thought maybe it was just stress at first, but it became so much more.”

 

She paused, her voice catching. “I tried to tell her to take a break, but she got defensive. Angry, even. And then… it spiraled. She lashed out, said something about her age, and it turned into a full-blown argument. And then it was like everything just collapsed. She went quiet, and all that fight drained out of her and she started sobbing. It broke my heart, Lilia.”

 

Lilia’s face softened with sympathy, but her eyes remained sharp as she processed Agatha’s words. “I see,” she said after a moment, leaning back in her chair. “That sounds like my Rio. She’s always been stubborn about pushing through her limits. She doesn’t want to show weakness, especially not to the people she loves. But you’re not to blame for missing the signs, Agatha. She’s been hiding them from herself as much as from you.”

 

Agatha felt a sharp pang of guilt twist in her chest, but before she could say anything, Lilia continued, her tone gentle but probing.

 

“Tell me—did she show any signs of being physically unwell? Fainting, dizziness, or anything more serious?” Lilia asked, her concern for her daughter evident as her brows knit together.

 

Agatha shook her head, but the weight of her words made it clear how deep Rio’s exhaustion ran. “Not really. She didn’t faint, but she was definitely weaker. Her movements were sluggish and slow. She barely responded to Nicky when he tried to show her something, and that’s never like her. She was so… distant. Like she wasn’t even there. It really scared me, Lilia.”

 

Lilia reached across the table, her hand resting gently over Agatha’s, her touch warm and grounding. “You’re scared because you care. And that’s good, Agatha—it means you’re paying attention now. Rio is still Rio, but she might need your help to recognize her own limits, even when she fights you on it. That doesn’t mean you failed her before.”

 

Her words were calm yet firm, a mix of understanding and quiet strength. She leaned back slightly, her hands folding in her lap as she processed everything Agatha had shared. When she spoke again, her voice softened with a maternal warmth that Agatha had come to rely on. “You did the right thing by getting her to rest. And don’t blame yourself. It’s not easy to step in when someone is determined to push themselves to the edge, especially someone as stubborn as Rio. But this is why you’re here now. You’re doing everything you can, and she’s in good hands with you.”

 

Agatha let out a breath she didn’t realize she was holding. The weight of Lilia’s reassurance was a relief, though it didn’t completely erase her guilt. “But what if it happens again?” Agatha’s voice wavered, her hands tightening into fists in her lap. “What if I miss the signs next time? I don’t want to be the one who lets her slip through the cracks again, Lilia. And what if she doesn’t listen? She’s so good at shutting people out when she’s overwhelmed.”

 

Lilia leaned forward, her expression steady but compassionate as she met Agatha’s troubled gaze. “You’re not alone in this, Agatha. You have Nicky, and you have me. We’re both here for her—and for you. Rio trusts you, even when she fights you. She may resist, but she needs to hear that she can’t keep going at this pace. Start small. Help her balance her workload, you’re her supervisor after all. Keep reminding her to eat, to rest. Don’t let her bury herself under everything. She needs those reminders more than she’ll admit.”

 

Agatha nodded slowly, her fingers unclenching as Lilia’s words settled into her mind like a roadmap. “I’ll do that. I just… I don’t want her to feel like I’m taking away her autonomy. She’s always been so fiercely independent, and I don’t want to make her feel like I’m trying to control her.”

 

“You’re not taking anything away from her, Agatha. You’re helping her recognize her limits—helping her see that it’s okay to lean on you when she needs to. There’s a difference.” Lilia paused, her gaze thoughtful. “Independence doesn’t mean she has to carry everything on her own. She just hasn’t quite learned that yet.”

 

As the conversation continued, Lilia leaned back in her chair, her expression distant yet thoughtful. Her fingers idly traced the edge of her mug as if grounding herself in the present while revisiting the past. “You know,” she began softly, her voice tinged with both fondness and melancholy, “Rio learned early on that nothing in life was handed to her. With the way she was bounced around when she was young, she figured out quickly that if she didn’t work hard, if she didn’t make herself stand out, she’d be overlooked.”

 

Lilia paused, her gaze shifting toward the window. For a moment, she seemed lost in memories, her eyes reflecting both pride and sorrow. “She had this fire in her even as a child—a drive to prove herself. She’d push beyond her limits, desperate to show that she wasn’t just another forgotten kid in the system. That she was worth something.”

 

Agatha’s heart ached as she listened, her chest tightening with every word. It explained so much—the relentless drive Rio carried, the way she pushed herself even when it hurt, and how she so often dismissed her own needs. It wasn’t just ambition—it was survival.

 

Lilia’s voice softened further, her tone carrying the weight of someone who had seen the depths of Rio’s struggles. “I noticed it the moment she came to me. She was barely more than a teenager, but she was already so exhausted—physically, emotionally. She didn’t want to admit it, of course. She was so used to taking care of herself, to doing everything alone, that asking for help felt like weakness. She didn’t know how to let someone else carry even a fraction of her burdens.”

 

Agatha swallowed hard, her hands gripping her own mug as if it could steady the whirlwind of emotions stirring within her. “That sounds exactly like her,” she murmured. “She still does it sometimes—works late into the night, skips meals, barely sleeps. And if I try to step in, she just brushes it off like she’s fine. But she’s not fine.”

 

“No,” Lilia agreed with a small, knowing nod. “She’s not. And she hasn’t been for a long time.” Her voice softened, and she met Agatha’s gaze with a mixture of sadness and warmth. “But you have to understand—it’s not just about the work. It’s deeper than that. It’s her way of proving, even to herself, that she’s capable. That she’s enough.”

 

Agatha’s brows furrowed as she let the words sink in. “She’s always so hard on herself,” she said quietly. “I’ve seen it. If something isn’t perfect, or if she feels like she’s falling short, she gets frustrated. Almost like she’s afraid of failing—or of letting people down.”

 

Lilia offered a sad smile, her eyes glimmering with empathy. “That’s exactly it. It’s not just about achieving. It’s about proving her worth—to everyone, and to herself. She spent so many years feeling like she had to earn her place in the world. She never had anyone, not until me, to tell her that she was loved and valued just as she was—not for what she could do, but for who she is. And even now, I don’t think she fully believes it. It’s hard to unlearn that kind of thinking when it’s been a part of you for so long.”

 

Agatha felt a wave of understanding wash over her, tinged with guilt for not recognizing the depth of Rio’s struggles sooner. “I see it now,” she said softly, her voice laced with a mixture of regret and determination. “I always thought it was just her passion for her work, her drive to succeed. I didn’t realize it was… this.”

 

Lilia’s expression remained gentle, but there was a firmness in her tone as she replied, “Rio might not say it outright, but she needs people to remind her that it’s okay to rest. That she doesn’t have to carry the weight of the world on her shoulders all the time. She’s spent so long equating rest with failure, but it’s not. She just needs someone who can help her see that.”

 

Agatha nodded, her grip on her mug loosening as a sense of clarity began to settle over her. “I want to be that for her, Lilia,” she said with quiet resolve. “I want her to know she doesn’t have to do everything alone, but I don’t know how to make her see it. She’s so stubborn. She’ll fight me every step of the way.”

 

Lilia leaned forward, her warm, knowing smile radiating reassurance. “She’ll fight, yes. That’s who Rio is. She’s fiercely independent like you said, always has been. But that’s also what makes her so incredible. And deep down, Agatha, she knows you’re there for her. You just need to meet her where she is—be patient, even when it’s hard. Gently remind her to slow down, to breathe, to take care of herself. She might resist at first, but you have to hold your ground. Let her know she’s worth more than her accomplishments. She’s not a thesis, a deadline, or a goal to be checked off. She’s Rio. And that’s enough.”

 

Agatha thought about Rio’s breakdown, the way she had collapsed into her arms, exhausted and vulnerable. It broke her heart, but it also made her more determined than ever to help Rio see that she didn’t have to do it all alone.

 

“I’ll do whatever it takes,” Agatha said, her voice steady. “I won’t let her burn out. I just need to know how to approach it the right way, without pushing her too far.”

 

Lilia nodded, her expression thoughtful. “You’re right to be mindful of that. She needs to feel like she’s still in control, even when she’s struggling. It’s a delicate balance, but you’re more than capable of handling it. The most important thing you can do is remind her—through your actions and your words—that she doesn’t have to prove anything to you. That you see her and love her, even when she’s not at her best. Even when she’s vulnerable or not able to do everything she wants to. She needs to hear that, Agatha, over and over again.”

 

Agatha’s chest tightened with emotion. “I’ve tried to tell her, but sometimes it feels like it doesn’t sink in. Like she doesn’t believe me.”

 

“She might not believe it right away,” Lilia said gently, “but keep telling her. Keep showing her. It’s not about convincing her in one big moment. It’s about the little things—checking in with her, noticing when she’s pushing herself too far, and being there when she finally lets herself rest. You’re already doing so much, Agatha. Don’t underestimate the power of just being consistent.”

 

Agatha nodded, her mind already racing with ways she could support Rio better. “You’re right. I see how hard she tries, even when she doesn’t have to. She’s been fighting her whole life, and I want her to know she doesn’t have to fight so hard anymore. Not with me.”

 

Lilia’s eyes softened with affection. “And that’s exactly why she’s lucky to have you. You’re not just her companion—you’re her safe place, her anchor. She may not always show it, but she trusts you more than anyone. That trust is your biggest strength in helping her through this. And don’t be afraid to ask for help, either. I’m always here if you need me. Sometimes, even the strongest people need a village.”

 

The weight of Lilia’s words settled over Agatha, grounding her in a sense of purpose. “Thank you,” she said quietly, her voice filled with gratitude. “You’ve given me so much to think about.”

 

Lilia stood, placing a firm yet comforting hand on Agatha’s shoulder. “You’re doing a great job, Agatha. Don’t doubt yourself. You know Rio better than anyone else—her rhythms, her quirks, her strengths and weaknesses. Trust your instincts, and trust her too. She’ll get there.”

 

Agatha left Lilia’s house feeling a little lighter, knowing that with time, patience, and unwavering love, Rio would learn to rest and recover. It wasn’t going to be easy, but Agatha was determined to help Rio find balance—whatever it took.

 

 

When Agatha stepped through the door, the familiar hum of their home wrapped around her, and her heart lifted at the sight before her. Rio was awake, sitting on the couch with Nicky nestled close by her side. The two of them were absorbed in a colorful cartoon playing on the TV, Nicky’s animated chatter filling the room as he pointed excitedly at the screen. His laughter rang out like a bell, light and carefree, while Rio smiled softly at his enthusiasm. Though a touch of weariness lingered in her posture, there was a peacefulness about her that made Agatha’s chest tighten with affection.

 

Agatha’s heart swelled, seeing them together, so normal and peaceful after the chaos of the past few days. She made her way over to them, settling on the couch beside Rio.

 

Nicky turned to her with a big grin, his eyes sparkling with excitement. “Can I give my gift to Mom, now that she is awake?”

 

Agatha smiled, her voice warm. “Of course, sweetheart. Go ahead.”

 

Without hesitation, Nicky sprang off the couch and darted toward the kitchen, his little feet padding quickly across the floor. Agatha couldn’t help but chuckle softly, watching him disappear through the doorway. Rio glanced at her with a curious tilt of her head, her brows knitting slightly in question, but Agatha simply gave her a knowing smile.

 

Moments later, Nicky returned, clutching a brightly colored gift bag in his hands. His excitement was palpable as he hurried back to the couch and held it out to Rio. “This is for you, Mom!” he said, practically bouncing on his toes.

 

Rio blinked in surprise, her lips parting as she took the bag from him. She reached inside and pulled out the plush stuffed dragon, its soft fabric a vibrant purple with scales and accents of green.

 

“She’s for you,” Nicky said with absolute certainty, his small hands holding up his own blue dragon for emphasis. “Now we both have dragons, so we can feel better when we’re sad. She’s green because it’s your favorite color, and purple because it’s Mama’s favorite color.”

 

Rio’s breath caught, her fingers curling around the dragon’s plush body as her gaze flicked between it and Nicky. Her lips trembled slightly, and Agatha noticed the way her eyes shimmered with unshed tears. The weight of Nicky’s thoughtfulness was overwhelming in the most beautiful way.

 

For a moment, Rio seemed unable to speak. Then she hugged the dragon tightly to her chest, cradling it as though it were something fragile and precious. Her voice, when she finally spoke, was thick with emotion. “Thank you, Nicky,” she whispered, her words trembling with sincerity. “This is… this is the best gift I’ve ever gotten.” Her lips curved into a watery smile. “Nobody’s ever given me a stuffed animal before.”

 

She reached out and pulled Nicky into her arms, holding him close as tears slid quietly down her cheeks. “You’re my little hero,” she murmured, pressing her cheek to his soft hair.

 

Nicky grinned, clearly pleased with himself, and held up his blue dragon, making it ‘wave’ at Rio’s new purple one. “Now they’re friends, too! They can help each other when they’re feeling lonely.”

 

Rio laughed softly, wiping at her eyes with the back of her hand. “They’re already the best of friends, just like us,” she said, her voice still tinged with emotion.

 

Agatha watched the exchange, her own heart heavy with love for both of them. She reached out, her fingers brushing gently through Rio’s hair, a silent gesture of comfort and connection. When Rio looked up at her, her eyes were still glistening, but there was a warmth in them that seemed to make the entire room glow.

 

“Thank you,” Rio said softly, her gaze locked with Agatha’s. “I don’t know what I’d do without you two.”

 

Agatha smiled, leaning in to press a kiss to Rio’s forehead, her lips lingering there for a moment. “Well,” she teased gently, “for starters, you wouldn’t have your very own stuffed dragon…”

 

Rio chuckled, her laugh soft but genuine, and she held the dragon up to inspect it. “True. And honestly, I can’t believe I ever lived without one.”

 

Nicky beamed, satisfied with his gift’s success, and snuggled back between them on the couch. Together, the three of them settled into the quiet comfort of the moment, the cartoon continuing to play in the background. For Agatha, there was no greater happiness than this—a home filled with love, laughter, and the promise of brighter days ahead.

 

 

That night, as the quiet of the house settled around them, Agatha and Rio lay side by side in bed, the dim light from the lamp casting soft shadows across the room. Nicky was already sound asleep down the hall, tucked snugly under his blankets with his stuffed dragon resting beside him. Across the room, Rio’s new green-and-purple dragon sat proudly on the dresser, its round eyes seemingly fixed on them, a silent guardian of their peace.

 

Rio shifted beneath the covers, her movements still a little slow, but there was a softness to her, a calmness that hadn’t been there in days. Agatha turned toward her, propping herself up on one elbow to take her in fully—the soft slope of her shoulders, the relaxed curve of her lips, the subtle flicker of thought behind her eyes.

 

“How are you feeling?” Agatha asked softly, her voice a gentle murmur in the quiet room. She reached out, tracing the curve of Rio’s arm with the lightest touch, offering a silent reassurance.

 

Rio let out a deep breath, her chest rising and falling as though she were still exhaling the tension of the past days. She turned her head to meet Agatha’s gaze, her expression open but vulnerable. “I’m better,” she admitted, though her voice carried the weight of lingering uncertainty. “I just… I think I’m scared of slipping again.” She paused, her fingers absently plucking at the edge of the blanket. “It feels like I’ve got this endless list of things to do. And if I don’t do them perfectly, it’s like I’m failing—not just myself, but everyone else, too.”

 

Agatha’s heart ached hearing the familiar insecurity in Rio’s voice. She reached out, cupping Rio’s face in her hands and making sure their gazes met. “You don’t have to be perfect, love,” Agatha said, her voice steady and filled with warmth. “You never have to be perfect. Not for me, not for Nicky, not for anyone.” Her lips curved into a tender smile. “Even though, for what it’s worth, you already are perfect to me.”

 

Rio’s lips quirked upward in a faint, almost reluctant smile. She leaned into Agatha’s touch, her tension melting under the warmth of her girlfriend’s palms. “You always know exactly what to say,” she murmured, her voice barely above a whisper.

 

“That’s because I mean every word,” Agatha replied, pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s forehead. She lingered there for a moment, letting the silence speak for her. When she pulled back, her hand slid down to rest against Rio’s chest, feeling the steady beat of her heart beneath her palm.

 

Rio let her eyes drift closed for a moment, breathing in the comfort of the moment. “I just… I don’t want to let you down. Or Nicky. You both deserve more than someone who’s constantly teetering on the edge of burnout.”

 

Agatha shook her head gently, her expression firm but kind. “You’re not letting anyone down, Rio. And you never will. You’ve already given us everything—your love, your care, your strength. Nicky adores you. I adore you. All we need is you, exactly as you are. Even on the hard days.”

 

Rio opened her eyes, and they shimmered with a mixture of unshed tears and gratitude. “I’m trying,” she said softly. “I really am.”

 

“And that’s more than enough,” Agatha assured her, her voice a soothing balm. She kissed the tip of Rio’s nose, earning a soft laugh that warmed the space between them. “You’re enough, love. Always.”

 

Rio let out a shaky breath, her chest rising and falling as if the weight of her thoughts was too much to bear. She glanced away for a moment, staring at the wall as if searching for answers in the empty space, before finally meeting Agatha’s eyes again. The vulnerability in her gaze was almost palpable. “I don’t know how to balance it. Everything just feels so overwhelming, and if I stop for even a second, I feel like I’m falling behind. Like if I don’t keep moving, I’ll lose everything I’ve worked for.”

 

Agatha’s heart clenched with empathy, the familiar weight of Rio’s words sinking into her own chest. She understood it now—the way Rio threw herself into her work, her relentless drive to be the best at everything, as if stopping meant failing. Agatha had witnessed it from the beginning, but hearing Rio say it out loud made her realize just how deeply it had rooted itself in Rio’s heart. Her conversation with Lilia only reinforced it all.

 

“I get it,” Agatha said softly, her voice steady but filled with the weight of understanding. “You want to give everything your best, I see that every day. But you also have to listen to your body, Rio. You can’t pour from an empty cup, no matter how much you want to give. It’s not sustainable.”

 

Rio’s eyes dropped to the covers, her fingers nervously tugging at the hem of her shirt as she processed Agatha’s words. She nodded slowly, but there was a distant look in her eyes, as if she were trapped in a cycle that had become too familiar to escape. “I know,” she murmured. “I’ve always been like this… pushing myself to the edge, never stopping. I guess I never really learned how to rest, or even want to. It feels like if I do, everything will fall apart.”

 

“We’ll figure it out together,” Agatha said softly, her tone reassuring. “It’s about finding the balance. You can still be passionate and driven without losing yourself in it. And I’m right here. We can set some small changes, baby steps.”

 

Rio looked up, her eyes searching Agatha’s. “Like what?”

 

Agatha thought for a moment, her voice firm but caring. “Well, for one, let’s set some specific work hours, so you don’t feel like it’s never-ending. You need breaks, regular ones, and no skipping meals or water.

 

Rio nodded, a faint smile tugging at her lips. “That sounds doable.”

 

“We also need to work on setting boundaries with your thesis and any other commitments,” Agatha continued, her voice gentle but firm. “If something’s too much, you need to speak up. Don’t try to handle everything on your own, especially when it’s overwhelming. If you’re struggling, you don’t have to keep it to yourself. It’s okay to ask for help.”

 

Rio buried her face in Agatha’s chest, as she continued.  “I’m here. Nicky’s here. Lilia’s here. We’re all in this together. You’re loved. You’re supported. And you will always be enough.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched, and her arms tightened around Agatha, clinging to her as if she were afraid of letting go. The tightness in her chest loosened just a fraction as Agatha’s words sank in, settling like a weight lifting off her heart.

 

“I don’t know how I’m supposed to let go of all of that,” Rio murmured, her voice barely above a whisper. “But I’ll try. For us.”

 

Agatha pressed a soft kiss to the top of her head, her arms tightening around her. “That’s all I’m asking you to do.” She tucked Rio back into her side, letting the silence settle between them, the comforting weight of their presence enough for now.

 

And as Rio drifted off to sleep in Agatha’s arms, she felt a small weight lift from her chest. Maybe she didn’t have to be perfect. Maybe, with Agatha by her side, she could learn to be enough just as she was.

 

*

*

*

Chapter End Notes

The fluff is back, and here to stay!

Three more chapters, I'm gonna cry, I'm so attached to those characters, but they'll be back for more!!! and very soon at that!

As always your comments and thoughts make me the happiest!

Weekend Getaway

Chapter Notes

I just got back from a concert and I had such a great time! I’m not sure if any of you are into French music, but if you are, I highly recommend checking out Zaho de Sagazan (if you don't know her already)—she’s incredible!

My top two song picks: "La Symphonie des éclairs" and "Old Friend".

Anyway, enjoy this chapter, the fluff is baaaack!!!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

Wait without thought, for you are not ready for thought:

So the darkness shall be the light, and the stillness the dancing.

Whisper of running streams, and winter lightning.

The wild thyme unseen and the wild strawberry,

The laughter in the garden, echoed ecstasy

Not lost, but requiring, pointing to the agony

Of death and birth.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “East Coker.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

The late afternoon sun streamed through the study window, creating golden patches of light across the dark wood desk where Rio sat. Her laptop screen glowed with the email draft containing what she had been agonizing over for days. The subject line read: Submission of Fourth Chapter – Rio Vidal: “The Timeless Abyss of Death in Modernist Poetry.”

 

Rio’s heart pounded as her fingers hovered over the trackpad. Her breath felt shallow, as if the weight of the entire document rested not on the hard drive but on her chest. After a deep inhale, she pressed send.

 

A soft whoosh sound confirmed the email’s departure. Rio stared at the screen for a moment longer, as though waiting for some immediate response that she knew wouldn’t come. Relief crashed over her in a wave, but it was accompanied by the familiar undercurrent of doubt. Was it good enough? Would the board tear it apart?

 

The sound of approaching footsteps snapped her from her thoughts. Agatha appeared in the doorway, her presence magnificent as always but softened by the warmth in her gaze.

 

“You did it, love,” Agatha said with a knowing smile. She crossed the room, her heels clicking softly against the floor, and stopped behind Rio. Her hands, always so steady, settled gently on Rio’s tense shoulders.

 

“I did,” Rio murmured, her voice tinged with disbelief.

 

Agatha leaned down, her long hair brushing against Rio’s cheek, and pressed a kiss to the top of her head. “And I couldn’t be prouder.” Her voice was quiet but firm, full of sincerity.

 

Rio tilted her head back to look up at her, her brown eyes searching Agatha’s face for reassurance. “You think it’s good enough?”

 

“Good enough?” Agatha echoed, a playful glint in her eyes as she arched an eyebrow. “Darling, it’s brilliant. You poured your heart – and your health - into this chapter, and it shows.” She moved around to the side of the desk, perching gracefully on its edge so she could face Rio.

 

“As your supervisor,” Agatha continued, slipping into a slightly teasing tone, “I can say with absolute confidence that the board is going to love it. But as your partner…” Her expression softened, and she reached out to brush a stray curl from Rio’s face. “I’m so proud of you—not just for this, but for how hard you’ve worked, how much you’ve pushed through, even if a little too much. It’s remarkable.”

 

Rio’s throat tightened, and she felt a surge of emotion rise in her chest. “You’re biased,” she whispered, though her lips curved into a small smile.

 

“Maybe,” Agatha admitted, her own smile widening. “But that doesn’t make me wrong.”

 

Rio let out a breathy laugh, leaning forward to rest her head against Agatha’s stomach. Agatha’s hand came to rest on the back of Rio’s head, her fingers threading gently through her hair.

 

“Thank you,” Rio murmured, her voice muffled.

 

“For what?”

 

“For believing in me,” Rio said, sitting up to meet Agatha’s gaze again. “And for being… you.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened, and she tilted her head. “Always, my love. Now,” she said, standing up and offering her hand, “let’s go pack. Nicky will never let us hear the end of it if we’re late getting on the road.”

 

Rio chuckled, her shoulders feeling lighter than they had in weeks. She took Agatha’s hand, letting herself be pulled to her feet. As they left the study together, the faintest trace of doubt lingered in Rio’s mind, but it was quickly overshadowed by something far stronger: a quiet sense of accomplishment and the unwavering support of the woman by her side.

 

 

As Rio and Agatha stepped out onto the porch, locking the door behind them, the sound of Nicky’s excited chatter filled the air. He bounced around the driveway, his little backpack jostling on his shoulders and his beloved stuffed dragon’s hand peeking out of his little bapack. “Mama! Mom! Do you think there’s gonna be a lake? Can we go swimming? What if there’s a bear? Do you think I’ll see a deer?!”

 

Rio chuckled, watching their son dart from one side of the car to the other like a whirlwind of energy. “Nicky, you’re going to tire yourself out before we even leave,” she teased, though the corners of her lips tugged upward in a fond smile.

 

“Impossible!” Nicky declared, grinning wide. “I’ve got my dragon for energy!”

 

Agatha, standing beside Rio with the house key in hand, shook her head with an amused sigh. “He’s going to talk the entire drive, isn’t he?”

 

Rio grinned at her. “Oh, absolutely. Better brace yourself.”

 

Just then, a familiar car pulled into the driveway, and Lilia stepped out, waving warmly. She looked relaxed and radiant, as always, her presence instantly grounding. “Sorry I’m late, loves! Got caught in traffic,” she called out, her voice carrying easily over the sound of Nicky’s excited squeals.

 

“Grandma!” Nicky shouted, running to her with open arms.

 

Lilia crouched down just in time to catch him, laughing as he threw himself at her. “There’s my favorite little adventurer!” she said, planting a kiss on the top of his head. “Are you ready for our big weekend?”

 

“Yes!” Nicky practically vibrated with excitement, pulling back to look up at her. “There’s gonna be a lake and woods, and Mom said maybe we can see deer! Do you think there’s gonna be a bear, Grandma?”

 

Lilia shot Rio a raised eyebrow as she straightened up, her hands still resting on Nicky’s shoulders. “A bear? Really?”

 

Rio held up her hands defensively. “I never said there’d be a bear. That’s all him.”

 

Agatha stepped in smoothly, slipping the key into her bag. “Don’t worry, Lilia. If there is a bear, I’m sure Nicky and his dragon will handle it.”

 

Lilia laughed, ruffling Nicky’s hair. “Well, I feel safer already.” She glanced toward the packed car and nodded approvingly. “Looks like we’re ready to go.”

 

“Let’s get this show on the road,” Rio said, opening the passenger door for Lilia as Agatha started guiding Nicky toward the back seat.

 

Agatha slid into the driver’s seat and glanced over her shoulder at her family, her smile softening. “Everyone buckled in?”

 

“Ready!” Nicky declared, pumping his fist in the air.

 

“All set,” Lilia confirmed, glancing at Agatha.

 

“Then let’s go,” Agatha said, starting the car. As they pulled out of the driveway, Nicky immediately launched into an animated story about what his dragon would do if it saw a bear, and Rio leaned back against her seat next to Nicky, soaking in the laughter and warmth that filled the car.

 

 

The car ride was filled with a steady hum of chatter and laughter, the kind of warmth only a true family could create. Nicky, strapped into his booster seat, bounced along to the beat of the pop song playing on the radio, his high-pitched voice belting out lyrics he only half-knew. Rio smiled, her head resting against the cool glass of the window, the tension in her shoulders melting away as she listened to the lively conversation swirling around her.

 

Lilia, seated comfortably in the passenger seat, was in the middle of recounting an embarrassing story from Rio’s teenage years. “And then,” she said, barely able to keep her laughter in check, “this one decided to sneak into the kitchen in the middle of the night to get to the cookie jar, only for the jar to come crashing down—cookies and all!”

 

“Lilia!” Rio groaned from the backseat, her cheeks flushing pink. “You promised we weren’t bringing that one up again.”

 

“Oh, I never promised,” Lilia teased, her eyes twinkling with mischief as she glanced over her shoulder at Rio, musing over the moments Rio had finally felt safe enough in her house to disobey. “Besides, Nicky deserves to know what his mom was like as a teenager.”

 

Nicky’s face lit up as he turned to Rio. “Mom, you sneaked into the kitchen at night for cookies? That’s so cool! Did you get in trouble?”

 

Rio buried her face in her hands, laughing despite herself. “Let’s just say there were no cookies after dinner in my future for a while after that.”

 

“Good,” Agatha chimed in from the driver’s seat, her voice smooth and playful. “I need to remind you to stop raiding the pantry sometimes, too.”

 

Rio shot her a mock glare, but her smile betrayed her. “You too, Agatha?”

 

Nicky giggled uncontrollably, clutching his dragon to his chest. “Grandma, tell another story!”

 

“I’ve got plenty,” Lilia said with a grin, earning an exaggerated groan from Rio.

 

As the miles rolled by, Nicky shifted gears, asking, “How much longer until we’re there?”

 

Agatha glanced at the GPS. “About forty-five minutes, love.”

 

“Forty-five minutes?” Nicky cried, his jaw dropping in exaggerated disbelief. “That’s, like, forever!”

 

Rio chuckled, nudging him gently. “You said that fifteen minutes ago when it was an hour. We’re getting closer, I promise.”

 

“Maybe I should teach you patience this weekend, Nicky,” Lilia suggested with a mock-serious expression, turning in her seat to face him.

 

Nicky’s eyes narrowed suspiciously. “How do you teach patience?”

 

“Well,” Lilia began, her tone thoughtful, “first, you have to sit very still and—”

 

“Nope!” Nicky interrupted, throwing his hands up in mock horror. “Nope, nope, nope! I’m not doing it!”

 

The car burst into laughter, even Agatha letting out a rare snicker.

 

The lighthearted banter carried them through the rest of the drive, Nicky peppering everyone with random questions about the cottage, what kind of wildlife they might see, and whether dragons could survive in the woods. By the time they turned onto the gravel road leading to the cottage, Rio felt lighter than she had in weeks, the weight of her thesis temporarily forgotten amidst the love and chaos of her family.

 

 

The car rolled to a stop in front of the charming, rustic cottage, its silhouette bathed in soft moonlight. The structure was quaint, with ivy creeping up one side and a weathered wooden porch that creaked as the wind passed through. Nicky pressed his face to the car window, his eyes wide with wonder.

 

“Whoa,” he whispered, his voice full of awe. “It looks so cool and spooky! Like a haunted house!”

 

Agatha chuckled as she turned off the engine. “It’s not spooky, love. It’s just old,” she said, stepping out of the car. “And trust me, when you see it in the daylight, you’ll think it’s more enchanting than eerie.”

 

Nicky didn’t look convinced, clutching his stuffed dragon tightly as he hopped out of the car. Lilia was already at the trunk, pulling out bags, while Rio stretched, her muscles stiff from the long drive.

 

As they made their way inside, the front door gave a low groan, as if greeting them. The cottage was cozy, the kind of place that invited you to curl up under a blanket with a good book. A stone fireplace dominated one wall, and the wooden beams overhead added a rustic charm. But the floorboards creaked with every step, and shadows danced oddly in the corners, thanks to the flickering light of the old sconces.

 

“It smells like firewood,” Nicky remarked, wrinkling his nose but staying close to Rio’s side.

 

“That’s because of the fireplace,” Agatha said, setting their overnight bags on the floor. “And see? Not so spooky once you’re inside.”

 

Rio grinned and leaned down to Nicky’s level. “She’s right, kiddo. It’s just a cozy old house that creaks a little. Nothing scary here.”

 

Nicky didn’t look entirely convinced but nodded anyway. “I guess it’s kinda cool. Like an adventure house!”

 

“Exactly,” Rio agreed, ruffling his hair.

 

The family spent a few minutes exploring the small cottage, peeking into its various nooks and crannies. The kitchen was quaint, with antique cabinets and a checkered tablecloth on a tiny dining table. The bedrooms were simple but inviting, with warm quilts draped over the beds.

 

When they reached the room meant for Nicky, he paused at the doorway. It was a little smaller than he expected, with a single twin bed tucked into the corner and a wooden rocking chair near the window.

 

“This is your room, bud,” Rio said, placing his bag on the bed.

 

Nicky hesitated, clutching his dragon even tighter. “I don’t know… It’s kinda far from your room.”

 

Agatha knelt beside him, her hands resting gently on his small shoulders. “It’s just down the hall, love. And you have your dragon to protect you. Plus, your grandma and us are just a shout away if you need anything.”

 

Nicky frowned, his lips pressing into a thin line. “Promise?”

 

“Promise,” Agatha said firmly.

 

Rio gave him an encouraging smile. “And if it’s too scary, you can always come snuggle with us. But I bet you’ll love having your own space by tomorrow morning.”

 

“Okay,” Nicky said reluctantly, climbing onto the bed to test it out. The springs squeaked, and he giggled nervously. “It’s kinda bouncy.”

 

“It’s perfect for you,” Lilia teased, stepping into the room. “A bouncy bed for a bouncy boy.”

 

Nicky smiled at that, his nervousness easing a little as the adults worked to make him feel at home.

 

Soon, they were all settled, their belongings tucked away, and the night beckoned them to rest after the long drive. But as Rio climbed into bed with Agatha, she couldn’t shake the feeling that Nicky might end up joining them before morning.

 

 

The night was still and quiet, save for the occasional creak of the old cottage settling into itself. Agatha stirred slightly, half-asleep, as the muffled sound of soft footsteps padded down the hall.

 

Just as Rio had predicted, Nicky appeared in the doorway, clutching his blue dragon tightly to his chest. The dim moonlight streaming through the window illuminated his nervous face, his wide eyes scanning the unfamiliar shadows in the room.

 

“Mom? Mama?” he whispered, his voice trembling just enough to tug at Agatha’s heart.

 

Agatha blinked awake, her gaze shifting to the small figure standing hesitantly in the doorway. She nudged Rio gently, but Rio only shifted in her sleep, still lost in her dreams. Agatha smiled faintly, shaking her head before sitting up.

 

“What’s wrong, love?” Agatha asked softly, her voice soothing.

 

“The house makes weird noises,” Nicky said, his bottom lip quivering. “And… and my room feels really far away.”

 

Agatha’s heart squeezed. “Come here,” she said, holding out her hand.

 

Nicky hesitated for only a moment before scurrying over, his dragon dragging slightly along the floor behind him. Agatha scooted to the edge of the bed and pulled him up into her lap. His small arms immediately wrapped around her neck as he buried his face in her shoulder.

 

“Can I stay with you and Mom?” he mumbled into her shirt, his voice barely audible.

 

“Of course, you can,” Agatha whispered, pressing a kiss to his temple. “There’s plenty of room for all of us.”

 

With practiced care, Agatha gently untangled herself from Rio, who barely stirred, and scooted over to make room. She helped Nicky climb onto the bed and settle between her and Rio.

 

As soon as he nestled in, his little body relaxed, the tension from his fear melting away. He clutched his dragon tightly with one arm and reached out with the other to grab a handful of Rio’s shirt.

 

“Mom’s warm,” Nicky murmured sleepily, his eyes already drifting shut.

 

Agatha chuckled softly, brushing a hand through his hair. “She is. And so are you, my little furnace.”

 

Nicky let out a small giggle, his voice fading into a yawn as his breathing evened out, slipping into peaceful sleep.

 

Rio shifted slightly, her arm draping over both Nicky and Agatha in her sleep, as if instinctively pulling them closer. Agatha’s heart swelled at the sight of her little family, cocooned together in the quiet of the night.

 

The cottage still creaked and groaned in the background, but to Agatha, it sounded almost comforting now, like a lullaby cradling her family in its arms. She rested her head against the pillow, one hand resting protectively on Nicky’s back, the other brushing against Rio’s.

 

“Sweet dreams, love,” she whispered, her words meant for both of them.

 

 

The next morning, the weather announced itself to be perfect, and its light bathed the living room as everyone began to stir. Rio sat on the couch, cradling her morning coffee, still a bit groggy from the late-night cuddle session with Nicky. She watched as Agatha moved around the small kitchen, humming softly as she prepared tea, her movements as graceful as ever.

 

Nicky bounded in, already full of energy. “Good morning, Mama! Morning, Mom!” he chirped, climbing onto Rio’s lap and snuggling against her.

 

“Good morning, my little chef,” Lilia called from the kitchen doorway, a mischievous grin lighting her face. “Speaking of chefs, I’ve decided that today we’re having a very special cooking lesson.”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up instantly. “A cooking lesson? What are we making?”

 

“Something delicious,” Lilia replied with a wink, holding up a bag of ingredients she’d brought along. “But first, every chef needs the right equipment.” She pulled out a small, white chef’s hat from the bag and plopped it on Nicky’s head. It was a little too big and tilted to the side, but he beamed with pride anyway.

 

“I’m the boss!” Nicky declared, puffing out his chest and adjusting the hat.

 

Lilia turned her teasing smile on Rio. “And I suppose the boss might need an assistant. Rio, what do you say? Ready to redeem yourself for all those kitchen disasters from back in the day?”

 

Rio groaned, sinking back into the couch. “Oh, come on, Lilia! That was ages ago. I’ve gotten so much better.”

 

“Better?” Lilia arched an eyebrow, her grin widening. “You mean like that time you tried to make brownies and accidentally used salt instead of sugar?”

 

Rio’s face flushed. “I was sixteen!”

 

“That’s already too old for that! And the lasagna that turned into soup?”

 

“Okay, that was one time!”

 

Agatha, who had been quietly sipping her tea, finally spoke up, her voice laced with amusement. “You have to admit, my love, you do have a bit of a history with… creative culinary experiments.”

 

Rio shot her a mock glare, though her lips twitched with the threat of a smile. “You’re supposed to be on my side.”

 

“I am,” Agatha replied, setting her cup down and leaning against the counter. “But I also think you should join. For Nicky’s sake, of course.”

 

“Fine,” Rio said with a dramatic sigh, setting her coffee down and standing. “But if anything goes wrong, it’s not my fault.”

 

“Famous last words,” Lilia teased, ushering them all into the kitchen.

 

The tiny cottage kitchen quickly became a flurry of activity. Nicky stood on a step stool at the counter, his makeshift chef’s hat slightly askew, as he handed out tasks. “Mom, you chop the vegetables. Mama, you stir the sauce. Grandma, you… um…”

 

“Supervise?” Lilia suggested with a grin.

 

“Yes! Supervise!” Nicky agreed enthusiastically.

 

Rio glanced over at Agatha, who was standing at the stove with a wooden spoon in hand, her expression one of pure amusement. “You’re enjoying this, aren’t you?”

 

“Immensely,” Agatha replied, her lips curling into a smirk.

 

As they worked, the kitchen filled with laughter and the sound of Nicky’s cheerful instructions. Lilia kept up a steady stream of commentary, offering tips and occasionally throwing playful jabs at Rio’s expense.

 

“Rio, that’s too much salt!”

 

“Lilia, it’s a pinch!”

 

“A pinch for who, a giant?”

 

Even Agatha couldn’t hold back her laughter, and Rio eventually gave up trying to defend herself, focusing instead on not letting Nicky spill flour all over the floor.

 

Of course, chaos ensued anyway. At one point, Nicky accidentally knocked over a bowl of chopped vegetables, sending them scattering across the counter. Rio, in her attempt to catch it, knocked over a jar of tomato sauce, which splattered across her shirt.

 

Agatha covered her mouth, trying - and failing - to suppress her laughter. “You really do make cooking an adventure, love.”

 

Rio shot her a look, though she couldn’t help but laugh too as Nicky giggled uncontrollably.

 

Agatha was now sitting at the table, observing fondly, her mug of tea cradled in her hands, as she watched the chaos unfold in the tiny cottage kitchen. Nicky was still proudly wearing his chef’s hat, issuing dramatic orders, while Rio was frantically wiping up the trail of spilled sauce that had somehow ended up on the counter, the floor, and her shirt. Lilia, for oncethe instigator, was tossing playful jabs at both of them, her laughter ringing warmly through the room.

 

Agatha couldn’t help but smile fondly at the scene. Her family, chaotic as ever, brought a kind of joy that filled her chest and made her heart ache in the best way. She sipped her tea, savoring the warmth of the moment before setting her cup down with purpose.

 

“Alright,” she said, stepping into the fray and clapping her hands lightly. “That’s enough kitchen carnage for one morning.”

 

Rio turned, a streak of flour somehow smeared across her cheek, and gave Agatha a mock-offended look. “Kitchen carnage? I’ll have you know, we’re creating culinary magic here!”

 

Agatha raised an eyebrow, gesturing at the mess around them. “If this is magic, love, I’d hate to see what a disaster looks like.”

 

“Rude,” Rio muttered, though the smile on her face gave her away.

 

“Come on, Mom,” Nicky chimed in, grabbing Rio’s hand and tugging her toward the door. “Mama’s right—let her and Grandma fix it! We can go play while they finish lunch!”

 

Rio threw her hands up in defeat, allowing Nicky to drag her out of the kitchen. “Fine, but when this meal is amazing, remember who the real chefs were.”

 

“I’ll be sure to give you full credit for spilling half the ingredients,” Agatha teased, her tone light and affectionate.

 

Once they were gone, Agatha turned to Lilia, who was already wiping down the counter with a practiced efficiency.
