“Well, that was… spirited,” Agatha remarked, picking up the only jar of tomato sauce that had miraculously survived the chaos.

 

“Spirited is a generous word,” Lilia replied with a grin, her tone warm as she began chopping the remaining scattered vegetables. “You’ve got your hands full with those two, you know.”

 

“Oh, believe me, I know,” Agatha said with a laugh, rolling up her sleeves. “Now, what’s the plan? Let’s salvage this meal before we’re subjected to Rio’s cooking experiments again.”

 

The two of them worked seamlessly, Lilia offering tips and sharing stories about her own adventures in the kitchen, many of which involved a younger, clumsier Rio. Agatha listened intently, enjoying the way Lilia’s love for her daughter shone through in every word.

 

By the time they finished, the kitchen was spotless, the food was plated, and the smell of something delicious filled the cottage. Agatha took a step back, wiping her hands on a towel and surveying their work with satisfaction.

 

“See? Peaceful, productive, and no sauce explosions,” she said with a smirk.

 

“Maybe I should give you the real chef’s hat,” Lilia teased, nudging Agatha playfully.

 

Agatha chuckled, picking up a plate to bring to the table. “No need. I’ll let Nicky keep that title—for now.”

 

As they called Rio and Nicky back to the kitchen, Agatha couldn’t help but feel a deep sense of contentment. These moments—messy, chaotic, and full of love—were what made life so beautifully worth it.

 

 

The afternoon air was nice, the clear light filtered through the dense canopy of trees, lightening the forest floor. The crisp, cool air was filled with the earthy scent of leaves and moss, and the sound of crunching footsteps echoed as the family ventured deeper into the woods. Nicky skipped ahead with a small bag slung over his shoulder, his eyes scanning the ground for anything that might qualify as a “treasure.”

 

“Look, Mama!” he called out, holding up a particularly shiny acorn as though he’d just found a precious gem.

 

Agatha smiled, her hands tucked in her coat pockets. “A fine find, little explorer. Keep it safe—it might be magic.”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up at the word magic, and he carefully placed the acorn into his bag, zipping it up with a dramatic flair. “I’m going to find even cooler stuff! You’ll see!”

 

Rio, walking a few paces behind, raised an eyebrow at the challenge. “Oh, you think you’re the only treasure hunter here, kid? I’ve got skills, you know.”

 

“Skills?” Agatha teased, glancing over her shoulder at her partner. “I seem to remember someone getting lost in the woods for hours during our last hike because they followed a squirrel.”

 

“Again, that was one time,” Rio defended, pointing a finger at Agatha. “And I found the coolest rock ever, thank you very much.”

 

“Coolest rock, huh?” Nicky giggled, clearly enjoying his moms’ banter. “Bet you can’t find a cooler one than me today!”

 

“Oh, it’s on,” Rio declared, crouching slightly as though ready to sprint off into the trees. “Prepare to be amazed, young one.”

 

With that, the treasure hunt officially turned into a competition. Nicky darted from tree to tree, picking up feathers, oddly shaped sticks, and colorful leaves, while Rio focused her efforts on finding something truly extraordinary. Every so often, she’d hold up a rock or a piece of bark, only for Nicky to shake his head dramatically and proclaim it “not cool enough.”

 

Agatha trailed behind them, content to watch the adventure  unfold with Lilia at her side.

 

“Should we tell them that this forest probably doesn’t have any buried treasure?” Agatha asked dryly, her lips quirking into a small smile.

 

“Where’s the fun in that?” Lilia replied, slipping her arm through Agatha’s as they walked. “Besides, I’m enjoying seeing Rio get so competitive with a six-year-old. It’s good for her.”

 

“She’s going to end up climbing a tree, isn’t she?” Agatha muttered, shaking her head fondly.

 

Meanwhile, Rio had indeed spotted something shiny in a nearby bush and was half-kneeling, half-crawling to retrieve it. “What do we have here?” she murmured, emerging triumphantly with a smooth, round stone that glinted faintly in the sunlight.

 

“Okay, kid,” she announced, holding it up for Nicky to see. “Top this.”

 

Nicky inspected the stone carefully, his face serious as he considered. “It’s shiny,” he admitted, “but look at this!” He reached into his bag and pulled out a feather, its deep blue hue catching the light.

 

Rio’s jaw dropped in mock disbelief. “A feather? That’s cheating! You didn’t even find that on the ground!”

 

“Yes, I did!” Nicky insisted, clutching the feather protectively. “It was on the trail! Right, Mama?”

 

Agatha chuckled, her arms crossed as she leaned casually against a tree. “I did see him pick it up. I’d say it’s fair game.”

 

Rio threw her hands up in exaggerated defeat. “Fine. You win this round, kid. But I’m still the reigning champion of coolest rocks.”

 

As the competition wound down, they continued their walk deeper into the woods. The towering trees seemed to stretch endlessly into the sky, their branches swaying gently in the breeze. Nicky’s curiosity was boundless, and every few steps, he’d pause to ask questions about the plants, the animals, and the strange sounds they occasionally heard in the distance.

 

“Mom, what kind of flower is this?” he asked, pointing to a small patch of purple blossoms.

 

Rio leaned down beside him, inspecting the plant closely. “That’s wild violet,” she explained, brushing her fingers gently over the petals. “They grow in shady spots like this. See the heart-shaped leaves? That’s how you can tell.”

 

Nicky tilted his head, his little brows furrowing in concentration. “Can we touch them?”

 

“Wild violets are safe,” Lilia chimed in, crouching next to them. “But you should always ask first because some plants aren’t friendly to touch. Like poison ivy.”

 

“What’s poison ivy look like?” Nicky asked, wide-eyed.

 

“Three leaves,” Rio replied, holding up three fingers for emphasis. “And if you see it, don’t touch it. Trust me on that one.”

 

Lilia chuckled softly. “She learned that the hard way a few years back. Came running home with her hands covered in rashes.”

 

“Not my fault I fell into them, but, thanks for bringing that up, Lilia,” Rio said dryly, though her lips twitched with a faint smile.

 

As they continued walking, Nicky’s questions poured out like water from a faucet. “Why are the leaves green? How do mushrooms grow? What’s moss for? Do animals live in that hole in the tree?”

 

Rio and Lilia answered as best they could, their explanations a mix of science and playful storytelling that kept Nicky enthralled. Agatha hung back slightly, content to watch her girlfriend and mother-in-law field the rapid-fire inquiries. She sipped from her thermos of tea, her gaze soft as she observed the natural ease between the three of them.

 

“How do you two know all this?” Nicky finally asked, glancing up at Rio and Lilia with a mixture of awe and suspicion.

 

Lilia placed a hand on her hip and gave him a mock-serious look. “How do you think your mom knows all this stuff? I taught her everything she knows.”

 

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t suppress the small, grateful smile that crept across her face. “Well, maybe not everything, but close enough.”

 

Nicky grinned. “Grandma, you’re like a plant professor!”

 

“I like the sound of that,” Lilia said, pretending to straighten an imaginary tie. “Professor Lilia, at your service.”

 

Rio, who was now poking at a pile of moss with a stick, looked up and smirked. “Yeah, yeah. You’re a walking encyclopedia. Don’t let it go to your head.”

 

As they ventured deeper into the woods, the rustling of the trees and the soft crunch of leaves beneath their feet were the only sounds filling the air. Nicky’s eyes were wide with wonder, scanning every nook and cranny for something new to explore.

 

And then, they all froze.

 

In the distance, just beyond a cluster of trees, a small family of deer appeared—two adults and a fawn grazing peacefully in the clearing. Nicky gasped, his small voice dropping to an excited whisper.

 

“Mama Deer, Mom Deer, and Baby Deer!” he exclaimed, pointing eagerly at the trio. His voice was barely a breath, but it held the purest joy.

 

Rio smiled at Nicky’s enthusiasm, her heart swelling with affection as she watched him try to take in every detail of the scene. Agatha looked over at her with a soft, knowing smile.

 

Nicky continued to watch the family of deer, his eyes wide with awe. Then, after a few seconds, he paused, a small furrow appearing on his brow.

 

“But where’s Grandma Deer?” he asked, his voice suddenly serious as he turned his gaze toward Lilia, who was walking beside him.

 

Lilia laughed, her eyes twinkling with mischief. She placed a hand on Nicky’s head, ruffling his hair playfully. “Well, she’s just too cool to be spotted with other deers. She prefers to remain mysterious and elusive.”

 

Rio snorted softly at the unexpected answer, and even Agatha couldn’t help but chuckle, her arms crossed as she leaned against a nearby tree, enjoying the moment.

 

“I see, Grandma’s a celebrity now,” Rio teased, her eyes sparkling with affection.

 

Lilia winked at her. “That’s right, darling. You can’t expect her to be out there with the common deer.”

 

Nicky laughed, clearly satisfied with the explanation. “Okay! But when we see Grandma Deer, I’ll say hi for you!”

 

“Deal,” Lilia said with a grin, her voice filled with playfulness.

 

As the family of deer continued to graze in the distance, the moment held a quiet sense of connection. The gentle breeze rustled the leaves above them, and for a brief moment, it felt like everything was exactly as it should be.

 

“Look at them,” Rio murmured, gazing at the deer as they moved gracefully through the clearing. “They’re so peaceful. It’s like they belong here.”

 

“They do,” Agatha replied softly, her voice full of warmth. “Just like us.”

 

Nicky, still mesmerized by the deer, nodded solemnly, as though he fully understood the sentiment.

 

As the deer eventually disappeared into the trees, Nicky waved after them, his face glowing with excitement. “This is the best treasure ever,” he declared.

 

Rio wrapped an arm around him as they continued their walk. “I think you might be right, kid.”

 

And for a moment, it truly felt like they all belonged to this quiet, beautiful world in the woods—a world where the magic of nature and family blended together in perfect harmony.

 

 

Back at the cottage, the cozy warmth of the living room filled the space as the afternoon settled out. The smell of Lilia’s cooking drifted from the kitchen, mingling with the crisp scent of wood burning in the nearby fireplace. The day had been full of adventure and laughter, and now, as the sun began to dip below the horizon, the house seemed to take on a soft, gentle hush.

 

Agatha settled into the worn but comfortable couch, adjusting the cushions behind her to make herself more at ease. She had been looking forward to this moment all day—some quiet time with Nicky, something familiar and grounding amidst the whirlwind of activities.

 

Nicky was a little worn out from the day’s exploration, his wide eyes now calm with the soft promise of a story to accompany nap time. He climbed up beside Agatha, clutching his beloved dragon tightly in one hand, curling into her side.

 

“Can we read the dinosaur story again, Mama?” he asked, his voice small and sweet, his little fingers tracing the dragon’s wings absentmindedly.

 

Agatha smiled down at him, a soft warmth spreading through her chest. She knew which story he meant—it was one of their favorites, a tale of a brave dinosaur who protected a peaceful village. “Of course, sweetheart,” she replied, smoothing his hair back gently. “The dino’s ready for another adventure, huh?”

 

“Yeah! He’s gonna fight the bad guys and save everyone!” Nicky said, his eyes lighting up as he leaned in closer, eager to hear the familiar tale.

 

Agatha opened the book and began to read, her voice gentle and soothing, making sure to add emphasis on the most exciting parts of the story. Nicky snuggled in closer, his small body pressing against her as he listened intently, his dragon forgotten for the moment, the safety of his Mama’s side all he needed.

 

As Agatha read, she felt a rare moment of peace—a quiet, grounding presence that she cherished deeply. The crackling of the fire, the soft rustle of the pages turning, and Nicky’s steady breathing as he settled into the rhythm of the story all seemed to align in perfect harmony. This was their space, their time together.

 

Agatha glanced down at Nicky, seeing the way his eyelids were fluttering, heavy with sleep as he sank further into her side, sliding onto her lap. Her heart swelled with affection as she slowed her pace, not wanting to finish just yet.

 

When the story finally came to its conclusion, Agatha closed the book softly, her voice lowering to a whisper. “And the brave dinosaur lived happily ever after, surrounded by all of his friends, safe and sound.”

 

Nicky, barely awake now, nodded sleepily. “He was the best dino, wasn’t he?”

 

“The best,” Agatha agreed, brushing a kiss to the top of his head. She gently shifted, adjusting his position so he could rest more comfortably, the soft sound of his breathing filling the quiet room.

 

 

While Agatha and Nicky were on the couch, having their quiet time, in the kitchen, the soft hum of conversation blended with the rhythmic sound of knives chopping and pans sizzling. The air was warm and fragrant with the aromas of dinner cooking, filling the cozy space with comfort. Rio stood at the counter, carefully slicing vegetables for the stew Lilia was preparing, the rhythm of the task grounding her.

 

Lilia, standing at the stove, turned toward her with a teasing grin. “I couldn’t help but notice,” she said, her voice light with playful amusement, “you were quite the competitor during the treasure hunt this afternoon. I mean, did you really need to bring back an entire tree branch?”

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head. “I can’t help it! When I’m in the zone, I’m in the zone.” She smirked. “Nicky doesn’t know what hit him. I am the queen of treasure hunting.”

 

Lilia raised an eyebrow, a smile tugging at the corner of her lips. “I know. I’ve never seen you so determined to win over something so… well, small and shiny.”

 

Rio laughed again, the sound easy and light. “I guess I just get into it. Plus, I was kind of hoping to show Nicky that I’m still ‘cool,’ you know?”

 

“Oh, sweet girl,” Lilia said, her voice softening as she met Rio’s gaze. “You’ll always be cool in Nicky’s eyes. He already looks at you like you’re the world.”

 

Rio’s hands stilled for a moment, a lump rising in her throat at the unexpected tenderness in Lilia’s words. She turned her attention back to the vegetables she was slicing, hiding the way her chest tightened. The words lingered in her mind as she cut through the carrots with a little more force than necessary, trying to distract herself from the sudden vulnerability that crept up on her.

 

Lilia noticed the subtle change in Rio’s demeanor and, after a pause, she gently added, “You’ve come so far, you know. It brings me so much joy to see you so… happy, thriving with your little family.”

 

Rio’s breath caught in her throat, the weight of Lilia’s statement settling over her like a soft blanket, but in the most unexpected way. She looked over at Lilia, meeting her mother’s knowing, warm gaze.

 

“Thrive?” Rio echoed, almost in disbelief. “I—” She trailed off, not sure how to put into words what she was feeling. Her hands began to move again, but slower now, as if she needed to take a moment to process Lilia’s words. She paused, realizing that the woman who had taken her in, loved her without question, had seen something in her that Rio often struggled to see in herself and had known so for even longer.

 

“I never really thought I’d get here, you know?” Rio admitted, her voice quieter, almost vulnerable. “I mean, from where I started, I didn’t think I would… be enough for anyone, except for you, let alone have a family. I was just… a kid in the system. Lost and forgotten. And now here I am, with Nicky, with Agatha.”

 

Her chest tightened at the thought of Agatha, and she allowed herself a small, fond smile. “I don’t even know how I got so lucky.”

 

Lilia’s expression softened even further, her hands stilling on the stove as she regarded Rio with a knowing look. “It’s not luck, darling,” she said gently. “You’ve worked so hard. And it’s because of that—because of who you are—that you’ve built a life with Agatha and Nicky. You’ve become the woman you are now, the woman I always knew you could be.”

 

Rio felt a warmth spreading through her chest, her heart fluttering with the unexpected weight of Lilia’s words. She was quiet for a moment, taking in the comforting presence of the woman who had been both her mother and her rock.

 

“You have no idea how much I needed to hear that now,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with emotion. “Thank you, Mom.”

 

Lilia smiled, her eyes softening with a deep, unconditional love. “I’ll always be here, Rio. You’re not alone ever, okay?”

 

Rio nodded, feeling the tightness in her chest ease just a little, the overwhelming gratitude for everything she had built and overcome flowing through her in a quiet rush. She thought about Agatha, about Nicky, about this life they had created together—and she couldn’t help but feel a quiet sense of pride.

 

She was a daughter. A lover. A mother.

 

 

The evening had settled in with a peaceful stillness, the last remnants of the sunset fading into the deep blue of the night sky. The cottage was quiet, the only sounds the occasional rustle of the leaves in the trees and the gentle hum of nature. They had all gathered outside after dinner, wrapped in blankets, the cool air pressing against their skin, but not in an uncomfortable way—more like a gentle embrace, comforting and familiar.

 

Nicky, his eyes wide with wonder, sat nestled between Lilia and Agatha, looking up at the stars like they were treasures just waiting to be discovered. Rio leaned into Agatha, their bodies naturally aligning as they sat back against the porch railing, their warmth a soft contrast to the cool night. The moment felt still, timeless even, as if the world had paused for just a little while to let them breathe and exist in this space together.

 

Nicky was the first to break the silence, his voice full of curiosity. “Mom, what’s that one?” He pointed up toward the sky, his small finger aimed at a bright cluster of stars.

 

Agatha smiled softly, adjusting her position so she could better see what he was pointing at. “That’s Orion’s Belt,” she explained, her voice steady but full of a quiet excitement. “It’s a group of three stars that look like a belt. The whole constellation is shaped like a hunter with a bow, but those three stars are the most noticeable.”

 

“Like a hunter?” Nicky asked, his eyes lighting up. “What does he hunt?”

 

“Well,” Agatha started, her voice low as she leaned in closer to Nicky, “he’s a symbol of strength, so in stories, he hunts big animals. But in the sky, he’s hunting the monster called Scorpion, which is another constellation.”

 

Rio, nestled against Agatha, couldn’t help but smile at how patiently she answered Nicky’s endless questions. It was one of the things she loved about Agatha—the way she always seemed to have an answer, the way she didn’t rush or brush Nicky off, no matter how many questions he asked.

 

“What about that one?” Nicky pointed again, this time toward a distant, hazy patch of sky.

 

Lilia, who was lying back on her blanket, turned her head to look. “Ah, that’s the Milky Way,” she said with a twinkle in her eye. “It’s the galaxy we live in. It’s so big we can’t even see all of it from here.”

 

“How big is it?” Nicky asked, his voice hushed as if the enormity of it all was almost too much to fathom.

 

Agatha gave him a soft, patient smile. “Well, it’s so big that it’s hard to even say. It’s made up of billions of stars, just like the ones we see in the sky, but there are so many more out there we can’t see with our eyes.”

 

“Wow,” Nicky whispered, clearly in awe. His voice held a note of wonder that made Rio’s heart swell, remembering how curious and bright he was, always wanting to learn, always asking questions. “What’s beyond the Milky Way? Is there another galaxy?”

 

Lilia chuckled, her hand resting on Nicky’s head, gently ruffling his hair. “Yes, sweetheart, there are billions of other galaxies. Just like how our stars are all part of the Milky Way, the galaxies are part of the universe, and that’s even bigger than we can imagine.”

 

“Like… a never-ending space?” Nicky’s face scrunched up, trying to understand.

 

“Exactly,” Agatha said softly. “It’s like an infinite ocean of stars and galaxies. We’ve only just begun to explore it, and there’s so much we still don’t know.”

 

Rio felt a gentle squeeze of Agatha’s hand as she shifted slightly to get more comfortable, and she leaned her head against Agatha’s shoulder. The world felt so vast in this moment, and yet, sitting there, wrapped in warmth with her family, everything felt exactly right. It was a peaceful, quiet kind of awe—one that didn’t require answers, just presence.

 

Rio smiled softly, her heart full of contentment as she watched her family. Agatha was answering Nicky’s questions with such care, and even though they were talking about far-off galaxies, black holes, and stars, Rio couldn’t help but feel like she was in the middle of her own little universe—a universe that was exactly where she wanted to be, right here with the people she loved.

 

As Nicky’s questions slowed down and his eyelids grew heavier, Lilia watched him with a soft smile, the evening’s magic lulling him into a drowsy state. His head began to tilt toward her shoulder, his small body sinking deeper into the blanket beneath him. The stars above seemed to dim, the world quieter now, as if the universe itself were waiting for Nicky to fall asleep.

 

Lilia exchanged a glance with Agatha and Rio, her gaze filled with warmth. “I think he’s ready for bed,” she said, her voice low and gentle, not wanting to disturb the peaceful atmosphere.

 

Nicky blinked a few times, then yawned widely. “I’m sleepy, Grandma.”

 

Lilia chuckled softly, her heart swelling with affection as she gently stroked his hair. “I know, sweetheart. Let’s get you settled in for the night, hmm?” She carefully sat up and moved to gather him in her arms.

 

Agatha and Rio, still sitting close together, exchanged a quiet, knowing glance. It wasn’t often that they had moments alone—moments where the world felt just a little bit smaller, where the busyness of their lives could pause, if only for a while.

 

“Thanks, Lilia,” Agatha said quietly, her voice filled with gratitude. “We’ll be here when you’re done.”

 

Lilia nodded with a smile, cradling Nicky in her arms as she stood up. “I’ll make sure he gets to sleep. You two enjoy some quiet time.”

 

As Lilia carried Nicky toward the cottage, Agatha leaned back against the railing, stretching out her legs in front of her. She sighed contentedly, the soft rustling of the trees the only sound for a few moments.

 

Rio shifted beside her to lie down and rest her head on Agatha’s lap and her lover’s hand immediately found its place in Rio’s hair. There was a sense of calm settling between them, a rare kind of stillness that felt almost sacred. They both allowed themselves to sit in silence for a few minutes, soaking in the beauty of the night, the quiet comfort of each other’s presence.

 

“I love this,” Rio murmured, her voice quiet but full of feeling. “It’s like… everything is exactly as it should be. Perfect.”

 

Agatha smiled softly, her other hand finding Rio’s and squeezing it gently. “I feel that too,” she said, her voice just as soft. “Sometimes, it’s hard to believe we’ve made it here… all of us, together.”

 

Rio closed her eyes, the gentle warmth of Agatha’s hand grounding her. “I don’t think I’ve ever felt this… at peace. I mean, I’ve had moments before, but this is different. Being here, with you, with Nicky… with Lilia. It’s like… like this is what life’s meant to be.”

 

Agatha’s breath hitched softly, the weight of Rio’s words landing deep within her. “I couldn’t agree more,” she whispered. “There’s nowhere else I’d rather be. Nothing else I want more than this. Our little family.”

 

Rio tilted her head up just enough to catch Agatha’s gaze. Her eyes were soft, vulnerable, the weight of the world seemingly lifted just for the moment. “I want everything with you, Agatha. Every day, every step… even the hard ones. I want them all with you.”

 

Agatha’s heart swelled in her chest, and she leaned down, pressing a soft kiss to Rio’s forehead. “You have me, love,” she whispered. “Always.”

 

They sat there, in the deepening night, the quiet of the world around them the perfect backdrop for their shared moment. The stars above seemed to shine a little brighter, as if affirming the truth of their words. In each other’s arms, they had found a home—something deeper than just a place to live. It was a love that wrapped itself around them, a quiet, unwavering presence in the vast, never-ending universe.

 

After a few moments, Agatha stretched, a quiet groan escaping her as she stood. “I think we should get some rest. It’s been a long day, and I don’t think I can stay awake much longer without risking falling asleep right here.”

 

Rio chuckled softly and nodded, standing as well. “Yeah, I don’t think I’m far behind you. Let’s go.”

 

The two of them moved inside, the warmth of the cottage greeting them as they stepped through the door. The quiet creaks of the old wood and the soft crackling of the fireplace welcomed them in, and Rio felt her body relax in the familiar comfort of their little getaway.

 

They made their way to their bedroom, the coolness of the night air still lingering on their skin. Agatha slid into bed first, holding the covers open for Rio, who slipped in beside her. The bed was warm, a safe haven after the events of the day, and Rio let out a contented sigh as she settled against Agatha’s body.

 

Agatha wrapped her arm around Rio, pulling her close, and Rio rested her head on her shoulder. She felt the weight of the day’s adventures slowly slip away, leaving only the soft sound of Agatha’s breathing and the faint rustling of the trees outside.

 

“You okay?” Agatha asked softly, her fingers brushing through Rio’s hair in a comforting motion.

 

Rio nodded, a small smile tugging at her lips. “Yeah, I’m perfect. Just… really glad to be here with you.”

 

Agatha smiled, pressing a gentle kiss to Rio’s forehead. “Me too, love. Me too.”

 

The two of them drifted into a peaceful sleep, the stars outside still watching over them, a quiet promise that they would never be alone in the vastness of the world.

 

 

The soft light of dawn was beginning to seep through the window when Rio stirred in the bed, her eyelids fluttering open, but something felt… off. The space beside her was empty. Agatha was gone.

 

For a moment, a flutter of worry stirred in Rio’s chest, but she shook it off, knowing that Agatha was probably just up early, enjoying the quiet morning. She quietly slipped out of bed, careful not to disturb Nicky or Lilia, who were still sound asleep in their rooms.

 

The cool air greeted her as she stepped out into the hallway, barefoot, her hair messy from sleep, carrying a blanket like a cape. She checked the kitchen and living room, but Agatha wasn’t there. A soft sigh escaped Rio’s lips, and she moved toward the porch, drawn by the peace of the morning.

 

There, just outside, Agatha sat on a bench on the small wooden porch, her back to Rio. The early morning sunlight bathed her in a soft golden hue, the world around her still quiet, except for the gentle chirp of birds and the rustling of the trees. Agatha’s gaze was fixed on the horizon, her face calm and serene, as if lost in the beauty of the moment.

 

Rio hesitated for a moment, unsure whether to interrupt the peaceful silence, but the sight of Agatha, so relaxed and at ease, made her heart swell with warmth. She stepped outside, her feet padding lightly on the wooden floor as she approached.

 

Agatha didn’t seem to notice her at first, so Rio stopped just behind her, watching her for a moment. There was something undeniably calming about the way Agatha sat, her posture perfect, her expression thoughtful but unburdened. It was a rare moment for Agatha, who always seemed to be moving or planning or thinking about the next thing.

 

“Morning,” Rio whispered, her voice soft, not wanting to disturb the tranquility of the moment.

 

Agatha turned slightly, her eyes brightening when she saw Rio standing there. A smile curved on her lips. “Morning, love. I didn’t want to wake you. I thought I’d catch the sunrise while it was still quiet.”

 

Rio stepped forward, her gaze softening as she sat down next to Agatha on the porch, wrapping the blanket around them both. She didn’t speak for a moment, just taking in the view of the sunrise, the soft colors beginning to stretch across the sky. The world felt still, like everything was holding its breath for just a moment longer.

 

Agatha stretched out her legs, leaning back with a contented sigh. “It’s nice to just… breathe sometimes, you know? No deadlines, no responsibilities… just the quiet of the morning.”

 

Rio nodded, her own shoulders loosening as she sank into the calmness of the scene. “Yeah, I know exactly what you mean. It’s hard to find these moments when everything else is so… loud.”

 

They sat in silence for a little while longer, just watching the sky as it shifted from deep purples to soft pinks and oranges. The world around them seemed to come alive slowly, like a slow-moving wave of energy.

 

Finally, Agatha broke the silence, her voice gentle but full of meaning. “I’ve been thinking… about everything. About us, about Nicky. This weekend has been perfect, just… perfect. It reminds me that I want to make more time for this. For us. To just be… here. Together.”

 

Rio turned her head to look at Agatha, her heart swelling with emotion at the words. There was a depth to Agatha’s voice, a sincerity that made Rio feel both incredibly loved and incredibly lucky.

 

“I feel the same way,” Rio said softly, her eyes locking with Agatha’s. “I don’t want to rush through life anymore. I want to be here, in the moments that matter. With you. With Nicky.”

 

Agatha’s hand reached out, brushing gently against Rio’s, fingers intertwining as if sealing the promise between them. “We’ll make it happen. All of it. Every step of the way. Together.”

 

Rio leaned in, pressing her forehead to Agatha’s, a small, contented sigh escaping her lips. “Together,” she whispered, the word feeling more right than anything else.

 

“You know, I was thinking,” Rio continued, her voice quiet but firm as she gazed at the horizon, “about everything we’ve built so far. About this little life we’ve created… It feels like we’re just getting started, you know? Like we still have so much more to experience.”

 

Agatha shifted slightly, her hand finding Rio’s, their fingers naturally intertwining as if it were the most natural thing in the world. The connection between them was always present, a bond forged through shared experiences, challenges, and joys. She squeezed Rio’s hand gently, offering her a sense of reassurance even before she spoke.

 

“I know exactly what you mean,” Agatha replied, her voice low, full of warmth and certainty. “And that’s because we arejust getting started. There’s so much more waiting for us out there. We’ve already made something beautiful together, but the journey isn’t over. It’s only just beginning.”

 

Rio sighed softly, her chest lifting with a contented breath as she closed her eyes for a moment. Her mind wandered to all the things they had yet to do, all the moments they’d share, the lessons they’d teach Nicky, and the places they’d see. It was like standing on the edge of a cliff, looking out at a vast, unknown landscape. The future was uncertain, but with Agatha by her side, Rio knew she could face whatever came next.

 

“I want to experience everything with you,” Rio said, her voice soft but steady. “Every single thing. I don’t want to miss a moment of it. I want to see the world, make memories with you and Nicky, and… just be present for all of it.”

 

Agatha smiled, her thumb tracing the back of Rio’s hand with a gentle, reassuring motion. “We will, my love. All of it. There’s nothing we can’t do together. Whatever life throws at us, we’ll face it as a family. I believe in us. I believe in this… in you. And I know we’ve built something solid here. Something worth protecting.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled with emotion, and she felt a lump form in her throat. Agatha’s words always had a way of soothing her anxieties, grounding her when her mind threatened to race. She had always been the rock in their relationship, the steady force that kept Rio from spiraling. And in return, Rio was the spark—fiery, passionate, and full of life. Together, they were a perfect balance, a perfect order.

 

“I don’t know what I’d do without you,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with the depth of her feelings.

 

Agatha turned her head slightly, her lips brushing softly against Rio’s hair. “You don’t have to worry about that, love. You’ll never be without me. I’m here, always. And we’re building a life together—a good one. A strong one.”

 

Rio leaned in, her cheek pressing against Agatha’s, and they sat there together, wrapped in the blanket, watching the sun climb higher in the sky. The world seemed to expand around them, offering endless possibilities, but in this moment, all that mattered was the quiet promise they had made to each other—to live fully, to face the future hand in hand, and to cherish every step of the journey they would take together.

 

 

The morning sun rose quickly, illuminating the cottage with a soft golden light streaming through the windows. It was a peaceful start to the day, but there was a sense of inevitability in the air as they began packing up. The weekend had been everything they had hoped for—relaxing, fun, and full of memories—but it was time to head back home.

 

Nicky darted around excitedly, his little hands busy gathering his treasures from the weekend: a few leaves he had pressed between the pages of a notebook, a pinecone he had found on their walk, and of course, his ever-present dragon. His dragon had been his comfort throughout the trip—his little guardian through the unfamiliar woods and the adventures of the weekend. He was determined to make sure it was in the picture, too.

 

“Moms, you have to get in! It’s the last picture of our family at the cottage!” Nicky said, his voice full of enthusiasm as he clutched the camera. “Dragon gets in, too!”

 

Agatha and Rio exchanged a smile, amused by Nicky’s determination. Rio was the first to comply, squatting down to make sure the dragon was carefully placed in the frame beside Nicky. She looked up at Agatha with a quiet affection in her eyes, her hand reaching out to intertwine with hers. Agatha smiled back, her expression soft, and nodded in agreement. They were going to make this moment last, just like every other moment they’d shared during the weekend.

 

“Alright, we’re all set,” Rio said, standing next to Nicky, who was now bouncing excitedly on his feet, holding up the camera.

 

Lilia, who had been organizing the last of their things inside, stepped out onto the porch, wiping her hands on her apron. “Do I get to be in this family picture, too?” she asked with a playful smile, clearly enjoying the family dynamic she was witnessing.

 

“Of course, Grandma!” Nicky said enthusiastically, grabbing Lilia’s hand and pulling her into position. “You’re part of the family!”

 

Agatha chuckled softly at the sight of Nicky taking charge, and Rio laughed, shaking her head. “Alright, Lilia, come on over here. You’re part of the team now.”

 

Lilia joined them, giving Rio a soft glance, proud of the family they had all become. Nicky placed his dragon on the grass in front of them, making sure it had the perfect spot in the frame.

 

“Okay, on three,” Rio said, leaning down to make sure they were all in the shot, just as the timer on the camera clicked on.

 

“Cheese!” Nicky grinned, his face alight with excitement, while Lilia smiled warmly, her hand resting on Nicky’s shoulder. Agatha and Rio exchanged a quiet, knowing look, one that spoke volumes about the love and strength they had built together.

 

As the camera clicked, capturing the moment forever, the four of them sat there for a few seconds longer, taking it all in. The cottage, the memories, the quiet affection they shared—it was more than just a snapshot.

 

“Thank you, Nicky,” Agatha said, her voice full of affection as she ruffled his hair. “This picture will be a treasure.”

 

“It will go straight to the mantle,” Lilia said, already planning to print and frame the picture when she got home.

 

Nicky beamed up at her, his eyes shining with pride. “I’m going to show my friends when we get home! And I’m going to tell them about the deer and the dragon that I’m sure I saw in the woods!”

 

“You’ve certainly earned your title as the family photographer,” Rio added with a grin, her voice warm.

 

As they packed the last of their things into the car, the cottage looked a little emptier, the energy of their presence already starting to fade. But the memories they had created here would stay with them forever, woven into the fabric of their family.

 

“Do we really have to leave already?” Nicky asked, his voice quieter now.

 

“We’ll come back, I promise,” Rio said, her voice soft but filled with certainty. She turned to Agatha, their gazes meeting for a brief moment before they both smiled. “There’s always next time.”

 

Lilia, who had been watching them closely, added her own quiet, comforting voice to the moment. “And I’m sure we’ll also find other places just as special,” she said, her smile warm and knowing.

 

As they made their way to the car, ready to drive back to their life at home, Rio felt a sense of contentment settle over her. 

 

As the car rumbled down the winding road back home, the landscape shifting from the peaceful woods to the familiar stretch of highways, Rio sank into the seat, feeling a quiet sense of peace wash over her. The trip had been exactly what she needed: a break from the weight of her thesis, from the endless deadlines, from the stress of her day-to-day routine. But more than that, it had been a reminder of the simple joys of life—the kind she had sometimes forgotten to savor.

 

She glanced out the window at the changing scenery, the familiar landmarks blurring by. But as the moments passed, she found herself feeling more and more at ease, the knots in her stomach loosening. The weekend had given her a fresh perspective, a calm clarity that she hadn’t realized she needed.

 

Her fingers found Agatha’s hand resting on the console between them, their palms briefly touching before Rio entwined her fingers with Agatha’s. She squeezed lightly, drawing Agatha’s attention.

 

Agatha quickly looked over at her with a soft smile before refocusing on the road. “What’s on your mind, love?”

 

Rio paused for a moment, her thoughts catching up with her. Then she finally spoke, her voice quiet but full of sincerity. “I just… I just wanted to thank you. For pushing me to celebrate my achievements. I’ve been so focused on always moving forward, on the next thing I have to do, the next hurdle I have to jump. But I’ve forgotten how to stop and appreciate how far I’ve come.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened as she squeezed Rio’s hand gently in return. “You’ve worked so hard, Rio. I’ve always admired your determination, but you deserve to take a breath and celebrate yourself, too. You’ve earned it.”

 

Rio let the words settle in her heart, feeling a mix of gratitude and warmth. She had always been so driven, always thinking about the future, about what was next. But this weekend, she had allowed herself to be present, to enjoy the little moments with her family, to celebrate the work she had already done instead of worrying about what was still to come. It was something Agatha had encouraged her to do, and it felt like a small but significant shift in her mindset.

 

Agatha’s expression softened even further, her gaze filled with the depth of her affection. “You should be proud, love. Look at everything you’ve done. You’re a brilliant, strong woman—and you’ve surrounded yourself with a beautiful family who loves and supports you. You don’t need to chase after perfection. You’re already enough, exactly as you are.”

 

Rio felt a lump form in her throat, a wave of emotion threatening to overwhelm her. She had always been her own harshest critic, but hearing Agatha’s words, feeling the warmth of her love and support, made her realize how much she had to be grateful for. Her life was filled with so much—so much love, so much support, so much strength—and for the first time in a while, she felt a sense of peace in that.

 

As the car continued its journey back to their home, Rio felt the weight on her shoulders lift, replaced by a sense of warmth and belonging. She had always known she was loved by Agatha, by Nicky, by Lilia, but in this moment, she truly felt the depth of that love. It was a quiet, comforting certainty, one that filled her up from the inside out.

 

She leaned back against the seat, content and at ease, ready to face whatever came next—with the people she loved, and with the knowledge that she was enough, just as she was.

 

And for what felt like the millionth time over the weekend only, Rio allowed herself to simply be present, basking in the love that surrounded her. It was enough. It was more than enough. With Agatha, with Nicky, with this life they were building… the future felt bright and full of hope. And for the first time, Rio didn’t fear it.

 

She was ready.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

I already told you—the last chapters are massive!

Only two chapters left for this story, but don’t worry, there’s more to come soon, I promise!

Love you all, and as always, don’t hesitate to leave a comment! 💜

Graduation Day - Part I

Chapter Notes

Welcome to the final two-part segment of this story.

If you’ve made it this far, first of all—thank you so much. By now, you know this is not just a love story but also an academic journey, and like all journeys, it must come to an end. This is where this one does.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

 

*

*

*

 

What we call the beginning is often the end

And to make and end is to make a beginning.

The end is where we start from. And every phrase

And sentence that is right (where every word is at home,

Taking its place to support the others.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Little Gidding.” Four Quartets.)

 

 

 

A few months later, the day dawned bright and warm, a late-May morning carrying the unmistakable promise of summer in the air. Rio woke up early, her heart fluttering with a mix of nerves and excitement. The soft morning light poured through the curtains, painting the room with a warm glow. 

 

She blinked a few times, her eyes adjusting to the softness of the morning, and turned to find Agatha still asleep beside her. Agatha’s peaceful expression made her smile, the soft rise and fall of her chest as she slept, a calming presence beside Rio. In the quiet of the room, Agatha looked so serene, as though the world outside hadn’t yet begun its day.

 

Rio stayed still for a moment, savoring the tranquility. The weight of the day ahead hung around her like a soft, comforting blanket, familiar but full of promise. She could already feel the rush of anticipation tightening in her chest, a mixture of excitement and nerves. This was the day, after years of hard work, when everything she had sacrificed and poured her heart into would come together.

 

She had spent countless hours hunched over textbooks, in libraries, and in lecture halls. Long nights writing papers, revising drafts, and questioning everything she thought she knew. It had been grueling at times, but it had also been a journey that shaped her in ways she could never have anticipated.

 

But today wasn’t just about her graduation, or the culmination of her academic achievements. It wasn’t just about the recognition she would receive for all of her hard work. Today was about everything that had come before it—the journey that had led her here. The late nights with Agatha by her side, the quiet moments spent in the warmth of their shared space, the words of encouragement and love that had kept her going when self-doubt crept in. Agatha had always been there, a constant source of strength and tenderness, even in moments when Rio thought she couldn’t go any further. Their shared dreams for the future, the ones they spoke of in the early mornings or late at night, when they let their hearts wander beyond the here and now. The vision of what they wanted to build together, side by side, was right there, within her reach.

 

And it was more than that. It was the family they had begun to build—a family that was made of love, of choice, of the spaces they carved out for each other in their lives. There was a quiet joy in knowing that, no matter what this day brought, it would be shared with Agatha. With the person who had seen her at her best and her worst, and loved her all the same. This moment was as much about them as it was about Rio herself. Every triumph, every milestone, every step forward had been something they had walked through together.

 

Rio turned her gaze back to Agatha, her heart swelling with affection. The future they had dreamed about, the future that was beginning to unfold, was right here, right beside her. The weight of everything—the accomplishments, the sacrifices, the love—settled into her chest as she gently brushed a strand of hair from Agatha’s face. She smiled, taking in the comfort of this moment. No matter what came next, she had already built something worth cherishing. Something that would carry her through whatever challenges lay ahead.

 

With a deep breath, Rio slid out of bed, careful not to disturb the peace around her. She glanced at Agatha, still nestled beneath the covers, her breathing even and calm, a small smile playing at the corners of her lips as if she were still lost in a good dream. Rio tiptoed to the bathroom, taking a moment to wash away the remnants of sleep and the buzzing anticipation building within her. The water was refreshing, like a reset, a small ritual to help clear her mind. She stepped out of the shower, toweling off quickly, the cool air of the morning brushing against her skin.

 

When she returned to the bedroom, only clad in the towel, she paused in the doorway. Agatha had woken up in her absence and was sitting up in bed, her expression soft, still half-lost in the gentle haze of sleep. Their eyes met across the room, and an unspoken understanding passed between them. Twin smiles blossomed on their faces—small, intimate, as though the world outside didn’t matter right now. There was only this moment, this shared space of quiet joy and nerves.

 

“Good morning, future graduate,” Agatha said, her voice warm and tender, filled with that same affection that always seemed to wrap around Rio like a protective embrace. She stood up and moved toward her, reaching out to take Rio’s face in her hands, her thumbs brushing softly against Rio’s skin before she kissed her, gentle and lingering. It was a kiss that said everything Rio didn’t have the words to express right now—how grateful she was, how full her heart was, how much she loved Agatha.

 

“Good morning, Dr. Harkness,” Rio replied, her voice thick with the warmth of affection and nervousness. She closed her eyes, savoring the aftertaste of Agatha’s kiss, the reassurance that everything was unfolding just as it should. For a moment, it felt like time had slowed down, just enough for them to savor the quiet before the excitement of the day ahead.

 

“Ready for today?” Agatha asked, her voice a gentle challenge, but with an underlying tenderness that reminded Rio just how far she had come.

 

“As ready as I’ll ever be,” Rio replied, her heart pounding with a mix of excitement and nerves. There was no way to fully prepare for a day like today, but she had walked this path for so long that she could almost feel the weight of every step that had brought her to this point. She had earned this.

 

“You deserve it all, my love. Enjoy it,” Agatha said, her eyes full of pride. Her hand brushed against Rio’s arm, the touch grounding, reminding Rio that the moment was hers to live, to embrace.

 

Rio took a breath, glancing down at herself. “I should get dressed,” she said softly, the hum of the day calling her to move forward.

 

“Let me help.” Agatha’s voice was low, filled with the kind of quiet affection that only deepened Rio’s appreciation for her. She reached over to the closet, where Rio’s outfit had been carefully laid out the night before, waiting for this very moment, and returned to her side, dress in hand, her movements unhurried and intentional. With a deft hand, she untied the towel wrapped around Rio, letting it slip at her foot to the floor, and Rio couldn’t help but blush. Agatha’s gaze lingered, her eyes soft and appreciative, her smile a mix of adoration and tenderness.

 

“As much as I adore you like this,” Agatha said, her tone teasing but warm, her words heavy with affection, “in all your naked, glorious perfection, I think this might be a better fit for the day.” She held out the dress, the fabric draping gracefully over her arm like a quiet offering.

 

Rio reached out to take it, her fingertips brushing against Agatha’s in a fleeting touch that sent a grounding warmth through her. The simple contact felt intimate, grounding—an anchor in a moment that could have easily swept her away in its magnitude.

 

Without a word, Rio slipped the dress on. She stood before the mirror in their bedroom, smoothing a hand over the soft fabric. The dress was simple but perfect—a soft green linen that reached gracefully to her mid-calf. The material moved with her, light and comfortable, and would flare around if she twirled. Two delicate bows sat undone at her shoulders, thick enough to make the dress feel like it was meant for a day like today.

 

It had been a gift from Agatha, one Rio had hesitated to accept at first. Agatha had picked it out weeks ago, knowing Rio’s preference for simplicity and comfort, yet choosing something just a little more special than she would have picked herself. She remembered Agatha’s soft smile as she handed it to her, the quiet confidence in her eyes. “You could wear this when you walk across that stage. I think it would suit you perfectly.” At the time, Rio had been unsure, but now, as she looked at herself in the mirror, feeling the fabric against her skin, she understood why Agatha had chosen it. It felt perfect. It felt like her.

 

Agatha stepped forward, reverently sliding her hands along Rio’s arms, her fingers brushing the fabric as she carefully tied the bows at her shoulders. The soft cotton slipped through Agatha’s fingers, the gesture intimate, small, yet significant, as if she way tying the loose ends of the journey that was coming to an end today.

 

Today, Rio would take another leap—into the future, into the recognition of all the hard work and sacrifice. Today, she would become Dr. Vidal.

 

She took a deep breath and smiled, the nerves still there but tempered by something deeper—a sense of gratitude, love, and achievement. Today, she would celebrate not only her academic journey but the incredible support system that had carried her through it all.

 

“Let me help you with your hair,” Agatha offered, her fingers gently running through the dark strands.

 

The gesture was simple, but Rio felt it deeply. Agatha’s hands were always gentle with her, always a reminder that no matter what was happening around them, she was loved and cared for. Agatha’s touch was a reminder of how far Rio had come—from the girl who once felt lost to this moment, standing before the world with so much more than just a degree.

 

Rio’s heart swelled with pride as she watched Agatha work in the mirror, her steady hands pulling her hair back into a neat style that felt like the perfect balance of elegance and ease. “You look stunning,” Agatha said softly, her hands lingering for a moment on Rio’s shoulders.

 

Rio met Agatha’s gaze in the mirror, her breath catching as she saw the look of love and pride in her eyes. “Thank you,” she said, her voice barely a whisper.

 

“You’ve worked so hard for this, Rio,” Agatha said, her voice thick with emotion. “I’m so proud of you. So incredibly proud.”

 

Rio swallowed the lump in her throat, her eyes glistening. It was hard to put into words how much this moment meant—how much Agatha’s unwavering belief in her had shaped who she was today.

 

“I couldn’t have done it without you,” Rio whispered, her voice cracking just slightly. “You’ve been my strength through all of this. I couldn’t have made it here without you.”

 

Agatha smiled softly, leaning forward to press a kiss to Rio’s temple. “And you’re going to keep going,” she said, her voice filled with quiet determination. “Because you’re amazing. You’ve always been.”

 

Rio took a deep breath, steadying herself. She could feel her nerves settling, the weight of the day’s significance pressing against her chest. But with Agatha’s touch, with the love and support that had always been there, Rio knew she was ready. She was ready to stand before the world and claim the title she had worked so hard to earn.

 

Just as Agatha finished placing the last pin in Rio’s hair, securing the delicate twists and curls with a small white flower, the door to their bedroom flew open with a burst of energy. Nicky, his small feet pattering against the floor with unrestrained excitement, dashed into the room. His eyes were wide, full of wonder and curiosity, and his smile was as bright as the sun spilling through the windows.

 

“Mom, you look so pretty!” Nicky exclaimed, his wide eyes shining with awe as he took in Rio’s appearance. His small hands clasped together in front of him, and for a moment, he looked like he could hardly believe his mom was standing right there, all dressed up and radiant.

 

Rio turned to him, her smile warm and filled with love. “Thank you, sweetheart,” she said, bending down slightly to meet his gaze. “You like it?”

 

“I love it!” Nicky nodded enthusiastically, his curls bouncing as he did. He looked up at her with sparkling eyes, brimming with excitement. “Will I get to see you walk across the stage? Will you wave to me? Promise you’ll wave!”

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, a sound light and genuine that filled the room and chased away the nerves that had been tightly wound inside her moments before. She bent down with practiced ease, scooping Nicky into her arms, his little hands reaching for her neck as she pulled him close, wrapping him in a tight, comforting hug. His small body felt warm against her chest, and the simple joy of being his mother made her heart swell with a love so pure it took her breath away.

 

“Of course, you’ll see me walk across the stage, sweetheart,” she said, her voice soft and reassuring, as though she could calm all of his boundless energy with a few simple words. “And I’ll definitely wave to you,” she added with a smile, her heart fluttering at the thought of Nicky cheering her on.

 

Nicky clung to her, his tiny arms wrapped around her neck, his face pressed against hers as he whispered conspiratorially, “I’m gonna be so loud, Mom. I’ll cheer louder than anyone else!”

 

Rio’s heart melted at his declaration, her smile growing even wider as she pressed a kiss to the top of his head. “I know you will, my loud little champion,” she said, her voice full of warmth. She pulled back slightly, holding him out just enough to look him in the eyes, her affection for him almost overwhelming.

 

From the corner of the room, Agatha watched this tender moment unfold with a soft smile, her heart swelling with pride. She had always known Rio to be the chaotic, unpredictable force in their family, but seeing her like this—so full of love for Nicky, so full of life, so completely immersed in the joy of this morning—was a reminder of just how much she had grown. The transformation was both beautiful and humbling. Rio wasn’t just a partner; she was a mother, a daughter, a force of nature with so much to give.

 

Rio gently set Nicky down, her fingers brushing through his hair in a playful ruffle, her face lit with affection. “You know what?” Rio said, looking into his bright, eager eyes. “Hearing you cheer is going to be my favorite part of the day.”

 

Nicky’s grin stretched from ear to ear. “Really?”

 

“Really,” Rio confirmed, her voice soft but full of love. She leaned down and kissed his forehead. “You’re my good luck charm, you know.”

 

Nicky giggled, wrapping his small arms around her waist in a quick but tight hug. “I love you, Mom.”

 

“I love you, too,” Rio whispered, her voice catching just slightly as the moment settled in her heart, filling it to the brim.

 

Nicky’s eyes sparkled with determination. “I’m gonna make sure everyone knows you’re my mom!” he announced with a beaming grin, his little chest puffing out with pride.

 

The simple words struck Rio like a gentle wave, washing over her with an unexpected flood of warmth. Her heart, already full from the love she felt for Nicky, expanded even further as she looked at him—her son, her family. She caught a glimpse of Agatha, who had been watching them both with an almost imperceptible softness in her eyes. There was so much love between them, so much shared history, so much to be grateful for. In this moment, Rio could hardly believe how far she had come—from the girl who had once been unsure, lost in her own struggles, to this confident, whole woman, surrounded by the people who made her life everything she’d ever dreamed of.

 

As if reading her thoughts, Agatha met Rio’s gaze across the room. A small, knowing smile played at the corners of her lips. It was a smile that spoke volumes—of pride, of deep affection, of a love that needed no words to be understood. In that moment, Rio knew exactly what Agatha was thinking. She knew how proud she was of her, how much she loved her. It was a silent exchange, but it was louder than anything either of them could have said.

 

“Alright, kiddo,” Agatha said, her voice light but firm, as she stepped toward Nicky to coax him toward the door. “Let’s let Mom finish getting ready and get you dressed. We don’t want to miss the ceremony. And remember—you’re the loudest cheerer in the room, okay?”

 

Nicky’s face lit up even more, his eyes practically sparkling with mischief. “You got it, Mama!” he said, already bouncing on his heels in anticipation.

 

As Agatha led Nicky toward the door, Rio watched them, a soft smile on her lips. But just before they left the room, Agatha turned back, her eyes twinkling with love. She blew Rio a playful kiss, her gesture light and filled with affection. It was the perfect little moment—one that Rio would carry with her throughout the day.

 

Today wasn’t just another milestone in Rio’s life—it was a new chapter. Today, she would step into the next phase of her journey, both as a graduate and as a mother, partner, and woman. It was a day that Agatha had stood by her for from the very beginning, and in her heart, Rio knew that Agatha would always be there, supporting her every step of the way.

 

Today, Rio would cross that stage with the people she loved cheering her on, and nothing felt more perfect than that.

 

 

Rio, Agatha, Lilia, and Nicky arrived at the graduation venue, stepping into the vast, grand hall that seemed to stretch endlessly before them. The soaring ceiling, adorned with elegant chandeliers, arched high above, as if reaching for the heavens themselves. The rows of seats below were already filling with proud families, eager faculty, and excited students—each person buzzing with anticipation as they waited for the ceremony to begin. Rio felt a flutter of nerves mixed with excitement as they entered, the weight of the moment settling over her.

 

As they moved through the crowded room, Agatha squeezed Rio’s hand one last time, offering her a look of quiet reassurance. With her characteristic poise, Agatha released her hand and moved gracefully toward the stage, her steps deliberate and confident as she took her place among the faculty. There was something powerful in the way Agatha held herself, a subtle shift in her posture that made it clear she was no ordinary professor. She belonged here, standing among the distinguished educators who had helped shape the future of so many. As Rio watched her from across the room, their eyes met for a brief, intimate moment, that was enough to calm the last of her nerves.

 

Meanwhile, in the front row, Lilia sat with Nicky, who was practically vibrating with excitement. The sheer joy radiating from him was contagious, and Rio’s heart skipped a beat as she took in the sight of her little boy. Nicky’s energy was palpable; he was bouncing in his seat, practically bursting with pride as he waited to see his mom walk across that stage. He was dressed to the nines, a small bowtie neatly tied around his neck, his outfit crisp and polished for the occasion. His eyes were fixed on Rio with an intensity that made her heart swell. It wasn’t just admiration in his gaze—it was pure, unfiltered love, the kind that only a child could offer. His face glowed with a smile that could light up the entire room, and it struck Rio how deeply he had changed her life. He had taught her what it meant to love unconditionally.

 

She took a deep breath, her nerves calm now that she was surrounded by her family. They were all there for her, each one a pillar of unwavering support. Lilia, her mother, who had been there for so long, providing love, stability, and wisdom when Rio needed it the most. Agatha, her partner, the woman who was her everything, the woman who had stood by her side through thick and thin, who had believed in her even when Rio doubted herself. And Nicky, their son, the one who had brought a whole new dimension of meaning to her life—a little boy who, with his infectious joy and love, had given Rio one more reason to dream, to push forward.

 

Pulling herself from the comforting thoughts that had briefly carried her away, Rio made her way through the bustling hall, her eyes scanning the crowd in search of her two best friends. The air was thick with excitement, filled with the buzz of conversations and the sound of heels clicking against the polished floors, but Rio’s heart lightened when she spotted Alice first. Her vibrant black and red hair was unmistakable, even from a distance, a striking contrast to the sea of black graduation gowns. Beside Alice stood Jen, her calm yet radiant presence adding a quiet balance to the scene. The two women were standing together, their matching gowns flowing around them as they laughed, their hands clasped into each other’s, their joy unmistakable. Their faces lit up with that infectious energy that had carried them all through their academic journey.

 

Rio couldn’t help but feel a surge of gratitude for the shared experiences, for the late nights and long hours spent in libraries, the endless conversations about everything and nothing, the way the three of them had always had each other’s backs. They had been through it all, and now here they were, standing together at the finish line, ready to take on whatever came next.

 

“Hey, you two!” Rio called out, her voice carrying across the crowded hall. As soon as the words left her lips, the last of her anxiety vanished away, replaced by the comfort of their familiar faces.

 

Alice’s eyes flicked up, and when she saw Rio, a wide grin spread across her face. “There she is!” Alice teased, her tone playful, her eyes sparkling with excitement. “How does it feel to be one of the stars of the show?”

 

Jen, always a little more reserved but just as enthusiastic, gave Rio a knowing smile. “It’s surreal, huh? We’ve all worked so hard for this moment.”

 

Rio chuckled softly. “Surreal doesn’t even begin to describe it. I feel like I’ve been waiting for this day forever, but now that it’s here, it feels like it’s happening too fast. Like I’m not even sure how I got here.”

 

“Yeah, we know that feeling,” Alice said, bumping her shoulder against Rio’s playfully. “But we made it!” She paused for a moment, her expression softening.

 

Rio smiled at the bond the three of them shared—three women who had supported each other through so much, and now, here they were, on the verge of a new chapter in their lives.

 

Alice’s expression softened slightly, her voice quieter but full of meaning. “We’re here. We did it. Together, like we always said we would.”

 

“And someone is graduating with high honors, no less!” Jen added, her pride evident in her voice. “You’ve earned this, Rio. You’re incredible.”

 

“Thanks,” Rio said quietly, feeling a rush of emotion. “But I couldn’t have done it without both of you.”

 

“Stop it,” Alice laughed. “We were all in this together. No one did it alone.”

 

They exchanged a moment of knowing glances, a shared understanding between them. They had all started this journey as individuals, but they had grown together, each of them leaning on the others when things got tough.

 

With the ceremony about to begin, the trio moved toward their assigned seats with the other graduates, their black gowns swishing as they walked in sync.

 

As they sat down, Rio glanced over at Alice and Jen, both of them looking as proud as she felt. There was a calmness in the air now, an understanding that this was the final step in a long, challenging journey. The nerves that had once been so strong inside Rio began to settle, replaced by a sense of anticipation.

 

It was time to graduate—not just as a student, but as a new version of herself, one who had found her place in the world.

 

 

The ceremony began with the soft hum of excited whispers that gradually fell into a respectful silence as the dean stepped up to the podium, a commanding presence in the center of the grand hall.

 

His tall, imposing figure paused for a brief moment, surveying the sea of graduates, family members, and faculty gathered before him. The smile that tugged at the corners of his lips was warm, prideful, and full of acknowledgment—recognizing the hard work and sacrifice that had led to this moment. With a sweeping glance over the crowd, the dean cleared his throat, and the room fell into an expectant hush.

 

“Today, we gather to celebrate the achievements of a remarkable group of students,” the dean began, his voice steady and full of pride. “A group of individuals who, through determination, discipline, and unwavering commitment, have proven that there is no challenge too great for those who set their minds to it. These graduates have poured hours of work, countless nights of study, and heart and soul into their fields of study. They have overcome obstacles, faced the unexpected, and persevered in the pursuit of knowledge, excellence, and truth.”

 

The words carried through the hall, reverberating off the high ceilings, each syllable imbued with the weight of their meaning. The graduates in the audience sat straighter, their hearts swelling with pride as the dean spoke of the passion and effort they had invested in their journey. There was something about hearing it said aloud—something about the recognition that made their years of hard work feel tangible, real, like a building that had been meticulously crafted brick by brick, each experience adding another layer of accomplishment.

 

“Today is not just about degrees or honors,” the dean continued, his voice deepening with emotion. “It is about the culmination of a journey, a journey that has shaped you, tested you, and most importantly, helped you grow. You have all arrived here not only with knowledge but with a sense of purpose, a drive that will carry you forward into the next chapter of your lives. This is the moment where we pause to reflect on everything you have achieved—both the challenges overcome and the triumphs celebrated. But it is also the moment where we acknowledge the path ahead, the unknowns and the opportunities that await you.”

 

A soft murmur rippled through the crowd, the dean’s words striking a chord with the students. Some smiled, others were lost in thought, but all of them shared the same sense of reverence. It wasn’t just about the degree—it was the people they had become through the process. It was the late nights studying together, the support of friends, the professors who pushed them to be their best, and the sense of community that had guided them to this pivotal point.

 

“As we call each of your names today,” the dean continued, his tone shifting to one of quiet reverence, “we honor not just the knowledge you have acquired, but the growth that has occurred within you. You have learned not only from books and lectures but from one another. From your experiences. From the moments of failure that taught you resilience, and from the moments of success that proved you could rise to any challenge.”

 

The air felt charged now, the words stirring something in the hearts of the graduates, making them feel both reflective and hopeful. Rio’s gaze wandered briefly to her friends, Alice and Jen, and then to Agatha, sitting among the faculty. The pride in Agatha’s eyes made Rio’s heart swell. She had come so far, and now, it was finally here—the moment of recognition.

 

“The world is waiting for you,” the dean said, his voice filled with a sense of responsibility and promise. “Your education has equipped you with tools—tools to build, to innovate, to create, to question. But above all, it has equipped you with the ability to make an impact. Whether in science, in art, in business, or any other field, you are the architects of the future. And the future, as we know, will not wait for you to catch up. It will be built by your hands, shaped by your decisions, and driven by your vision.”

 

The graduates sat still, absorbing the weight of the dean’s words, their eyes reflecting a mixture of awe, excitement, and even a hint of uncertainty. What lay ahead was unknown, but the dean had just reminded them of their power to shape it.

 

“Today is not an end,” the dean concluded, a sense of finality settling in his voice. “It is a beginning. The beginning of your journey beyond these halls. As you step out into the world, remember the lessons you’ve learned, the bonds you’ve formed, and the dreams you’ve dared to chase. Know that you are prepared for whatever comes next, and that you are never alone. You carry the legacy of this institution with you, and more importantly, you carry the promise of your own potential. We are proud of you all, and we look forward to the incredible things you will accomplish.”

 

A wave of applause filled the hall as the dean quieted for a moment, the room buzzing with the energy of accomplishment and anticipation. The air, once thick with nerves and anxiety, now felt light, full of possibility. The graduates looked at each other, some wiping away tears, others grinning widely, all standing together in the shared experience of the moment. 

 

“We’ll proceed alphabetically” the dean announced, his voice carrying across the hall, full of warmth and pride. He smiled down at the row of students seated in front of them, each one preparing to step forward in a momentous rite of passage. The air was thick with anticipation, the collective buzz of excitement palpable.

 

“When I call your name,” the dean continued, his tone infused with gravitas, “please step forward and claim what is now rightfully yours—a testament to your hard work, perseverance, and dedication.”

 

Rio’s heart picked up its rhythm as the dean’s gaze swept over the graduates, and she couldn’t help but feel a surge of energy. This was the moment. Her friends had worked so hard to get here, and now, they were about to cross the finish line.

 

The dean’s voice echoed through the hall as the first names were called, and Rio watched as one by one, students rose to their feet. Their movements were measured but full of meaning, their faces illuminated by a mixture of pride, relief, and excitement. The steady rhythm of applause filled the space as each name was announced, and Rio couldn’t help but smile, her own sense of accomplishment intertwined with theirs.

 

“Jennifer Kale,” the dean announced suddenly, his voice ringing clear and sure.

 

Jen stood up immediately, her tall frame standing out among the sea of graduates. She looked back at Rio and Alice, giving them a small, excited wave before making her way to the stage.

 

“Go, Jen!” Rio cheered, the words tumbling out of her with enthusiasm she couldn’t hold back. Her voice rang loud and clear, cutting through the room as if propelled by sheer joy. She saw Jen’s face light up, her lips parting into a bright, wide grin as she looked back at Rio, their eyes meeting for a split second before Jen turned her attention to the stage.

 

Alice, who was sitting just behind Rio, leaned in with a soft smile. “That’s my girl,” she whispered, her voice full of pride and love, as they both watched Jen make her way down the aisle. “God, I love her so much.”

 

The dean handed Jen her diploma, and the moment seemed to stretch in Rio’s mind, as if the world paused to honor her friend’s accomplishment. Jen’s smile was radiant, a mixture of relief and excitement as she turned to face the audience, beaming with pride. The dean placed the doctoral hood over her head, and Jen straightened up with a sense of dignity that left Rio in awe.

 

When Jen made her way back to her seat, Rio could hardly contain herself. She clapped enthusiastically, her hands vibrating with energy, feeling every bit of the pride she had for Jen’s success.

 

The ceremony continued, the names of graduates being called one by one. Rio clapped along with the rest of the audience, her heart swelling with pride for each of her peers as they crossed the stage to receive their diplomas. The atmosphere was electric, filled with an overwhelming sense of accomplishment that vibrated in the air.

 

And then, the dean’s voice rang out again, cutting through the murmur of the crowd with authority and warmth.

 

“Rio Vidal.”

 

The room seemed to hold its breath, and for a moment, Rio felt as though the entire world had slowed down. Her heart thudded in her chest as she stood, her green dress swaying softly underneath her gown with each step she took toward the stage. The soft linen fabric brushed against her legs, grounding her in the moment as she walked up the aisles towards the stage.

 

She met Agatha’s gaze as she reached the front, and the world seemed to narrow until it was just the two of them. Agatha’s smile was warm, but the depth of emotion in her eyes took Rio by surprise—there was a fierceness, a pride that transcended words. It wasn’t just a smile; it was a look that made Rio feel seen, loved, and understood in a way that no one else could.

 

Rio walked up the few steps that led to the stage and, to her surprise, she saw Agatha stand up from her seat among the faculty, her eyes never leaving Rio as she crossed the stage with purpose.

 

There was a pause, a collective inhale from the audience. Traditionally, it was the dean who placed the doctoral hood over the graduate’s shoulders, but Agatha’s confident stride toward Rio was a clear signal that this moment meant more than tradition. The dean, after a brief glance, nodded approvingly, as if he knew what was about to happen, understanding the significance of this personal gesture between them.

 

Agatha took the hood from the dean’s hands with a grace that was almost reverential, her fingers brushing against the soft fabric, her touch lingering as if savoring the moment. She turned to face Rio, and the entire room seemed to hold its breath. The quiet tension in the air made it feel as though time had slowed, allowing them to stretch this second into eternity. Rio’s pulse quickened, but she held still, her heart swelling with emotion. She couldn’t tear her gaze away from Agatha, who approached her with a quiet confidence, each step bringing them closer to this pinnacle moment.

 

In one fluid motion, Agatha ceremoniously draped the hood over Rio’s shoulders, her touch gentle but deliberate. The weight of the moment seemed to settle on Rio’s shoulders along with the hood, a symbol of her years of hard work, her growth, and everything she had achieved.

 

Agatha leaned in slightly, her voice low and intimate, though clear enough for Rio to hear. “Congratulations, Dr. Vidal,” she murmured, the words rich with emotion, each syllable carrying a depth of pride and love that only Agatha could convey. There was something in the way Agatha spoke that made Rio’s chest tighten—a promise, a recognition of all they had gone through together, and a celebration of everything Rio had become.

 

Rio’s smile widened as she looked into Agatha’s eyes, the emotion and history between them evident in the way they shared this quiet exchange. “Thank you, Dr. Harkness,” she replied, her voice steady but rich with warmth. Her words carried a teasing lilt, a playful edge that was uniquely theirs. It was an inside joke, a reminder of the playful, ever-present chemistry that ran between them—of the late nights spent together, the laughter, the tears, and the quiet moments of understanding. This was more than just a formal exchange—it was a reflection of their entire relationship, the highs and lows, the shared triumphs, and the deep emotional connection that had gotten them to this point.

 

They now stood as equals in every sense of the word.

 

Agatha’s lips curled into a soft smile, her eyes glimmering with pride and affection. For a brief moment, the noise of the audience faded away, leaving just the two of them standing together in that precious instant. They shared a glance that said everything—love, partnership, mutual respect, and the quiet understanding that this was just one of many milestones they would reach together. Then, with a simple movement of her hand, Agatha invited Rio to face the crowd, and present herself in her new light.

 

Rio turned back to face the audience, her heart full, her hand brushing against the hood resting on her shoulders. She was no longer just Rio Vidal; she was Dr. Rio Vidal. 

 

The applause filled the room, and Rio stood on the stage, momentarily lost in the sea of sound. She felt the weight of the moment settle on her shoulders, but it wasn’t a burden—it was a celebration. The overwhelming sense of accomplishment and pride was almost too much to contain, and she smiled, her heart soaring with every clap and cheer.
