Then, through the applause, she heard a voice that cut through the noise—small, excited, and full of joy. “Mommy! Yay!” Nicky’s voice rang out, unmistakable and filled with so much love and energy. The sound hit Rio like a wave, and her heart swelled. She couldn’t help but smile brighter, the sound of her son’s joy ringing in her ears. Nicky’s excitement was palpable, his pure joy echoing through the auditorium as if he was cheering for her alone.

 

Rio turned her head, and there, in the front row, was Nicky, bouncing in his seat, his little hands clapping with enthusiasm. His wide grin was infectious, and Rio’s chest tightened with emotion as she waved a little, like she had promised him. She caught a glimpse of Lilia beside him, clapping proudly, her eyes shining with tears of happiness. The sight of her mother, who had given so much of herself to raise Rio, filled her with gratitude. Lilia’s face was a reflection of everything Rio had worked for—the love, the dedication, the quiet moments of support.

 

The joy of the moment swelled within Rio, overwhelming her in the best way. Her family was here, surrounding her with love and pride, and she knew she had everything she needed in that moment.

 

With a final glance at Agatha, who stood watching her with the same pride and admiration, Rio straightened her shoulders, her heart soaring. Dr. Vidal—it had a certain ring to it, one she knew she would carry with grace, with humility, and with the knowledge that this was only the beginning.

 

Rio returned to her seat, her heart still fluttering from the moment on stage. As the ceremony continued, she listened to the names being called, but her mind kept drifting back to the powerful moments she had just experienced—the sound of Nicky’s excited cheers cutting through the applause, the weight of the doctoral hood resting comfortably on her shoulders and back, and the pride in Agatha’s eyes as she placed the hood on her. Every part of the ceremony felt surreal, a culmination of everything she had worked for, but also a reflection of all the love and support that had gotten her there.

 

The world felt like it had shifted ever so slightly, and she was anchored in this moment of joy, surrounded by her family, her friends, and the community that had nurtured her along the way. It was as if she was floating, everything else fading into the background.

 

Then, just as her thoughts began to settle, Alice’s name was called.

 

“Alice Wu-Gulliver.”

 

Rio’s attention snapped back to the present, and she instantly focused, her excitement bubbling over. She cheered loudly for her best friend, her voice carrying through the auditorium. Alice had been her constant companion throughout this journey, and seeing her friend up on that stage, receiving her degree in musicology, was a moment Rio would remember forever.

 

“Yay, Alice!” Rio called, her voice brimming with pride and joy for her friend. She waved enthusiastically, her hand above her head, making sure Alice could see her cheering from the crowd.

 

Alice smiled brightly as she took the stage, her gown flowing around her, and gave Rio a small wave. The connection between them was palpable, their bond forged through long hours of studying, shared laughter, and countless cups of coffee. Alice’s achievement was Rio’s as well, and the pride she felt for her friend was immense.

 

As Alice stood at the front, receiving her diploma and hood, Rio’s heart swelled again, this time with happiness for the journey that they had all completed together. It was a bittersweet moment, knowing that their time as students was ending, but also filled with anticipation for the new chapters that lay ahead.

 

The ceremony continued, but Rio’s mind stayed with Alice, with Jen, with Nicky, with Agatha, with Lilia and with the incredible sense of accomplishment that was shared between her and her friends.

 

Yes, it was an ending—an end to a long, hard-earned journey—but more importantly, it was the first step into a future that, for the first time in her life, felt entirely within her reach.

 

 

As Agatha watched Rio from her seat on the stage, she felt a profound mix of emotions swelling in her chest—pride, love, admiration. There had been so many moments where she had witnessed Rio struggle, grow, and overcome obstacles, but today was different. Today, Rio wasn’t just the student who had come to her with a thirst for knowledge; she was a woman who had become everything Agatha had always hoped she would be and more.

 

She wasn’t just a student anymore, not just the woman who had walked into her office with a notebook full of scribbles. Rio had grown into a mother, a fierce protector of Nicky, a woman who Agatha had fallen for harder than she even thought was possible, a partner who stood by Agatha’s side through every challenge, and a woman who had carved out a space for herself in a world that had once felt too big. Agatha had watched her blossom into someone who was equal parts strength and tenderness, someone who was capable of so much more than she had once believed possible.

 

As Rio sat there, her face glowing with pride, Agatha felt a deep, overwhelming sense of accomplishment swell within her. She had watched Rio grow, stumble, rise again—had been there every step of the way, offering guidance, challenges, support, and unwavering love when Rio needed it most. It had been a journey of transformation, not just for Rio, but for them both.

 

But now, in that moment, Agatha looked at Rio not as someone she had helped along the way, but as her equal, her partner in every sense. It was a quiet realization, one that settled deep in her chest, warming her from the inside out. They had come so far together, and now Rio stood as a reflection of her strength, determination, and brilliance—a force in her own right.

 

The love between them was immense—so quiet in its depth, yet loud enough to fill every corner of their lives. It had been forged in shared experiences, in challenges faced and conquered together, and in moments of pure, unrestrained joy. Today, more than any other, was a testament to everything they had built together: the life they had created, the family they had made, and the future that was now stretching out before them, wide and full of possibility.

 

Agatha’s heart swelled with pride—not just for Rio, for the woman she had become, but for the life they had built side by side. The love, the family, the future—it was all unfolding in this single, perfect moment.

 

She could see it all clearly now: all the paths they had walked, the hurdles they had overcome, and the countless victories—big and small—that had shaped them. And as she looked at Rio, standing so tall and proud, Agatha knew one thing with absolute certainty: no matter what lay ahead, she was more than ready to face it all.

 

And she would face it with Rio by her side, every step of the way.

 

 

When the ceremony finally came to an end, Rio found Alice and Jen, both of whom were already grinning from ear to ear. As soon as they saw her, they couldn’t contain their excitement and rushed over to her. Without a second thought, the three of them jumped around, laughing and cheering like little girls, their joy bubbling over.

 

“We did it! We actually did it!” Alice squealed, her voice high-pitched with excitement as she spun in a circle, her graduation gown billowing out around her like a cape. The sight was so pure, so unfiltered, that Rio couldn’t help but laugh, her own spirit soaring. Jen joined in, unable to resist the infectious energy of Alice’s antics. She broke into a little happy dance, her laughter spilling out, loud and contagious, and Rio couldn’t help but join them, her heart light and her cheeks aching from smiling so much.

 

“We’re Dr. Wu-Gulliver, Dr. Kale, and Dr. Vidal!” Jen shouted, still bouncing on her feet, her pride shining through with every syllable. The three of them looked at each other, the weight of their new titles settling in slowly, as though they had just unlocked a new level in a game they had been playing for years.

 

“I can’t believe it!” Rio exclaimed, her voice brimming with excitement. Her eyes were sparkling, reflecting the enormity of the moment. “We’ve come so far.” Her words felt like they had been years in the making, and now, standing there with her two best friends, they felt almost impossible to comprehend. But the truth was undeniable—they had worked for this. They had earned it.

 

They collapsed into a group hug, arms thrown around each other, laughing and holding on tight as though the world outside of that embrace didn’t matter anymore. It felt like all the weight of their accomplishments, all the sacrifices they had made, was finally sinking in. After all the sleepless nights, the stress, the self-doubt, and the relentless pursuit of something greater, they were here, together, with PhDs to their names.

 

“I’m so proud of us,” Alice said, her voice thick with emotion, her usual energy softened by the weight of her own pride.

 

Rio’s heart swelled as she took in the sight of her best friends—these two women who had supported her through the toughest of times, and who she’d supported in return. They had all walked this journey together, and now, they were standing on the other side, ready to take on whatever came next.

 

As they separated, Rio felt an undeniable pull toward her family, who had been waiting patiently at the entrance of the room. Her heart was still racing from the ceremony, her chest full of pride and excitement, but she was eager to see the faces that had been her constant support throughout this journey.

 

The moment she spotted them, her heart skipped a beat. Nicky, her beloved little boy, was the first to see her. His eyes lit up as he jumped to his feet and, with all the energy a six-year-old could muster, dashed towards her. Before she could take another step, he had practically launched himself into her arms, wrapping his small arms around her neck in an enthusiastic hug that knocked the wind out of her but filled her with overwhelming joy.

 

Rio laughed softly, lifting him effortlessly into her arms and holding him close. She could feel his heart thudding in excitement against her chest, a mirror to her own. Nicky beamed at her, his eyes wide with awe, and his little hands reached up eagerly to touch the doctoral hood resting on Rio’s shoulders, his touch gentle but filled with admiration.

 

“Mom, you did it!” Nicky exclaimed, his voice full of pride. “You’re the best! You’re Dr. Mommy!”

 

The title—Dr. Mommy—struck Rio deeply, and she smiled, her heart overflowing with joy as she kissed his forehead. She could barely contain her happiness—seeing her son so proud of her, so sure of her, made everything worth it.

 

With a wide, gleaming grin, Nicky reached into the pocket of his little dress pants and pulled out something he had made himself—a small diploma. It was drawn with crayons in a childlike scrawl, with squiggly letters that only a mother could decipher. Despite its simplicity, it was the most precious thing Rio had ever received. She held it close to her chest, tears welling up in her eyes as she looked at the love and effort he had poured into it.

 

“Thank you, my little love,” Rio whispered, her voice thick with emotion as she hugged him tighter, feeling the warmth of his small body in her arms. “This means everything to me.”

 

Lilia, who had been watching the exchange with tearful eyes, walked up and pulled Rio into a tight embrace, her hands gentle but firms around her. “I’m so proud of you, sweet girl,” Lilia murmured, her voice thick with emotion as she wiped away a stray tear. “Look at how far you’ve come.”

 

Rio squeezed her mother tightly, grateful for the unconditional love and support Lilia had always given her. Lilia had been the one constant in her life, the woman who had opened her heart and home to Rio when she needed it most. “I couldn’t have done it without you, Mom,” Rio whispered, her voice muffled by Lilia’s shoulder. “You’ve always been there for me.”

 

Just then, Rio felt a familiar presence behind her, and she didn’t need to turn around to know who it was. Agatha was standing there, radiating warmth and pride. Rio slowly turned toward her, her heart fluttering at the sight of her lover, who was now walking toward her with a purposeful stride. Without a word, Agatha reached out, pulling Rio close to her with a strength that grounded Rio completely. The comforting, steady embrace of Agatha’s arms wrapped around her like a shield, a place of sanctuary that only Agatha could offer. None of them cared if anyone saw them anymore. After all, Rio wasn’t a student anymore.

 

Agatha’s hand slid into Rio’s, their fingers intertwining in a quiet, intimate moment, before Agatha brought Rio’s hand to her mouth, kissing the back of It lightly. It was a simple touch, but it spoke volumes. It was their wordless exchange of gratitude, love, and deep connection. No words were necessary; they had already said everything with a glance, a touch, and a shared understanding.

 

The little family stood together, surrounded by love, each of them feeling the weight of the moment in their own way. Rio looked at Agatha, her eyes filled with love and gratitude, and in that moment, everything felt perfect.

 

*

*

*

 

Chapter End Notes

I had to take breaks while writing this because I was crying too hard. I’m going to be sobbing so loudly tomorrow when I post the final chapter.

But something still feels unfinished, doesn’t it? 💍 Next chapter, perhaps?

As always, your comments are the greatest gift.

Graduation Day - Part II

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

 

*

*

*

 

At the still point of the turning world. Neither flesh nor fleshless;

Neither from nor towards; at the still point, there the dance is,

But neither arrest nor movement. And do not call it fixity,

Where past and future are gathered. Neither movement from nor towards,

Neither ascent nor decline. Except for the point, the still point,

There would be no dance, and there is only the dance.

 

                  (T. S. Eliot. “Burnt Norton”. Four Quartets.)

 

 

After the grand graduation ceremony in the hall, the university’s sprawling gardens came alive with a festive, almost enchanting air for the PhD graduates’ garden party. The evening sun cast a warm, golden glow over the space, softening the edges of the vibrant greenery and adding an extra layer of magic to the scene. Classical music, the kind that seemed to float through the air like a gentle breeze, filtered through the trees, creating a serene and elegant backdrop to the gathering. Twinkling fairy lights hung like stars in the branches above, their soft glow illuminating the pathways and the guests below as dusk settled around them.

 

Long tables, each draped in crisp white linens, were lined with meticulously arranged displays of refreshments—an assortment of finger foods, sparkling drinks in delicate glasses, and trays of delicate desserts that looked too beautiful to eat. Platters of fruit, cheese, and pastries glistened under the ambient lighting, their colors vivid against the soft ivory tablecloths. The scent of freshly cut flowers from nearby vases mixed with the crisp evening air, adding to the sensory pleasure of the event.

 

The graduates, now wearing their hard-earned doctoral hoods, mingled with their families and faculty members, their faces flushed with pride and excitement. Conversations filled the air, a mix of gratitude, congratulatory words, and reflections on the journey that had led them all here. Laughter rang out, clear and light, blending harmoniously with the music. The atmosphere was one of camaraderie, of celebration for not just the academic accomplishments, but for the shared experiences that had brought everyone together.

 

Rio walked through the crowd, her graduation gown still draped over her green dress, the silky material brushing against her calves as she moved. Beside her were Agatha, whose presence radiated quiet pride; Lilia, beaming with maternal joy; and Nicky, full of exuberant energy, darted excitedly between the adults, his small feet barely touching the ground as he ran ahead, then paused to catch up again. His bowtie was a little crooked, but it only made his joy even more contagious. His laughter filled the air, a sound that Rio knew she would carry with her always, a symbol of the love that bound their family together. Alice and Jen, also in their black gowns, walked alongside them, still riding the high of the ceremony.

 

Rio felt a new kind of lightness in her chest—a mix of freedom and accomplishment. She was no longer a student, no longer tethered to endless drafts and looming deadlines. Instead, she stood here, surrounded by the people she loved, ready to celebrate not only the journey she had completed but the life she was stepping into.

 

The gardens stretched out before them in a scene of understated elegance. Graduates in their gowns and their families moved gracefully between the tables, some pausing to capture the moment in photos, others lost in conversations, reminiscing about their time at the university. The air was thick with the sweet scent of blooming flowers, a light breeze carrying the fragrance of freshly cut grass as it swept through the lush greenery. It was a perfect evening, as though the very world had conspired to mark the significance of the occasion

 

Rio glanced around, taking it all in, her heart swelling with gratitude. Today wasn’t just about a degree—it was about every step that had brought her here, every person who had supported her along the way.

 

Rio’s gaze swept across the garden, noticing the way her friends and family moved through the crowd, each of them carrying their own joy, their own sense of accomplishment. As they wandered further into the lush gardens, the sounds of laughter and lighthearted conversation enveloped them like a comforting blanket. The clink of glasses, the soft hum of music drifting from the nearby string quartet, and the occasional burst of laughter filled the air, blending into a symphony of celebration.

 

Rio’s attention was pulled towards Alice and Jen, who had snuck away from the crowd for a moment of fun. Their eyes sparkled as they each snatched a glass of champagne from a nearby tray, their faces lit with that familiar, carefree joy. Without a word, they shared a quick, silent toast, the moment as simple as it was pure. Rio felt a warm smile tug at her lips as she watched them. She joined in their laughter, feeling the last vestiges of the tension of the day slip away as her heart opened to the joy of it all. They had earned this. All of them.

 

The evening was young, and Rio knew, deep down, that this night—this celebration—was just the beginning. There was so much more ahead. The promise of the future, the excitement of new opportunities, and the comfort of knowing she had the people she loved most by her side. It was a moment of both reflection and anticipation, and Rio couldn’t help but feel that everything was exactly as it was meant to be.

 

Now that Rio was officially no longer a student, and Agatha no longer her professor, there was a shift in the air between them—one of freedom. For so long, their relationship had been one of secrecy, hidden away in the quiet corners of their lives, tucked behind closed doors and shielded by cautious glances and fleeting touches. It had been a delicate dance, each step measured and restrained, as they balanced the unspoken tension of their growing bond with the responsibilities of their roles.

 

But tonight—tonight, everything had changed. With Rio’s graduation, the final curtain had fallen on that chapter of their lives. No longer were they confined by the rules of student and professor, no longer bound by the formalities and restrictions that had once kept their feelings carefully tucked away. There were no more professional lines to toe, no more whispered conversations or stolen moments in the shadows. Tonight, they were simply two people who had been through everything together—the trials, the triumphs, the heartaches—and had come out stronger for it. The air between them hummed with the electricity of freedom, a heady mix of anticipation and the comfort of knowing that they could finally be who they truly were without fear of consequence.

 

For so long, they had kept the intensity of their feelings wrapped in the silence of their professional roles. But now, that silence could finally break. Tonight, there were no more walls between them, no more rules to follow. They could move freely, speak openly, touch without hesitation. They had crossed an invisible threshold, one that signified more than just the end of Rio’s academic journey. It was the beginning of something new—something entirely their own. No longer restrained by the roles they had played for so long, they were free to fully embrace the depth of their bond, to explore it in all its glory and its complexity.

 

Agatha and Rio moved through the gardens side by side, their connection now free to be as open as they wanted. Agatha’s hand rested lightly on Rio’s back as they walked, a gesture so subtle yet intimate, one that said without words, She is mine. Rio could feel the warmth of Agatha’s hand through the fabric of her dress, a grounding presence, one that made the world feel softer, more real. Rio glanced up at her, catching the faint shimmer of the fairy lights in Agatha’s hair, her dress catching the soft golden hue that spilled from above. Agatha’s eyes met hers with a smile that was at once tender and knowing, filled with pride and affection. It was a smile that carried so many quiet moments, hidden support, and the depth of their bond.

 

Rio felt the shift too, a lightness in her steps, a warmth spreading through her chest. There was no need to guard her feelings anymore. She could lean into Agatha as they walked, brushing their arms together, or laugh at something Alice said without worrying if her gaze lingered on Agatha too long. It was liberating, this new openness. It felt like shedding an old skin and stepping fully into the life they had built together.

 

“You know,” Rio said with a quiet laugh, glancing over at Agatha, “it feels a little strange, not having to hide.”

 

Agatha’s smile softened, her eyes flickering with a knowing affection. “I think it’s one of the best feelings in the world,” she replied softly, her voice almost a whisper in the evening air. “We deserve this.”

 

Rio smiled, her heart swelling with gratitude, as they continued their walk. “We do,” she agreed, her gaze drifting over the faces of their friends and colleagues gathered around. Alice, Jen, and Lilia were scattered throughout the crowd, chatting and laughing, their faces alight with the joy of the evening. Everything seemed to be unfolding exactly as it should.

 

As they passed a group of colleagues, Agatha’s hand slipped over Rio’s back again, a quiet reassurance that they were in this together. Agatha didn’t need to say anything; it was clear to anyone watching that their link was undeniable.

 

Rio caught the gaze of one of Agatha’s colleagues, a curious glance that quickly shifted away when she saw how Agatha’s hand remained on Rio’s back. There was no hiding now. Their bond was written in every glance, in every touch, in the subtle way they moved as one.

 

When they reached a nearby table, Agatha handed Rio a glass of champagne. As their fingers brushed, Rio’s pulse quickened. Agatha met her gaze, and for a moment, the world seemed to disappear. They had fought for this—had worked, sacrificed, and loved for this moment—and now, it was theirs.

 

Rio’s laughter bubbled up as Alice, who was talking animatedly nearby, caught her attention. “I’m going to need to keep an eye on you two,” Alice teased, her eyes twinkling with playful mischief. “I think everyone’s starting to notice.”

 

Agatha’s smile deepened, but her eyes never left Rio’s. “Let them,” she said, her voice low and steady, filled with the quiet power of their shared understanding. “It’s time for everyone to know.”

 

Rio felt the heat in her cheeks, but she didn’t look away. Instead, she reached out, her fingers brushing against Agatha’s hand in return, a silent affirmation of the love they no longer needed to hide.

 

As they moved from the refreshment table, Lilia approached with Nicky in tow, the little boy holding onto his grandmother’s hand with one of his and a half-eaten cookie in the other, crumbs falling onto the floor with each enthusiastic step.

 

Lilia’s eyes twinkled with a knowing glint as she came to stand beside them, a soft chuckle escaping her lips. “You two are practically glowing,” she teased, her voice light and playful, yet filled with affection. Her gaze flickered between Agatha and Rio, and the pride in her eyes was unmistakable. “It’s about time the world sees what I’ve known all along.”

 

Rio blushed slightly, but the grin tugging at her lips was unstoppable. “It feels… strange but good,” she admitted, her voice soft as she glanced up at Agatha. “Not having to hide anymore.”

 

Agatha’s hand, which had been resting gently by her side, moved then, slipping into Rio’s with the quietest of gestures. Her fingers interlocked with Rio’s in a seamless, natural way, as if it had always been meant to be like this. “It’s more than good,” Agatha said gently, her voice carrying a quiet certainty that made Rio’s heart flutter. “It’s exactly as it should be.” Agatha’s certainty became Rio’s anchor in that moment, reminding her that they had earned this. They had earned the right to be seen, to be loved without barriers.

 

 

Lilia was the picture of    the proud mother and bustled around with her camera in hand, determined to document every precious moment of the day. She waved Rio over with an excited gesture. “Come on, sweet girl, we need pictures to remember this! Stand right there, right under the lights!”

 

Rio laughed softly but complied, standing amidst the soft glow of the fairy lights. Her green dress flowed gracefully beneath her black graduation gown, her doctoral hood resting proudly on her shoulders. She posed for Lilia, a soft smile on her lips, her eyes sparkling with happiness.

 

“Perfect,” Lilia said, clicking the shutter. “Now, Nicky, go to your mom!”

 

At the sound of his name, Nicky’s small feet scurried across the grass, his bowtie still crooked and a few cookie crumbs dotting his shirt as he clutched the remnants of yet another treat. Rio, beaming, held out her arms, and Nicky, with a delighted laugh, practically threw himself into her embrace. She caught him easily, lifting him into her arms and holding him close, his small hands gripping the back of her neck as his grin grew wider. Rio gently brushed the cookie crumbs from his shirt, her fingers grazing over the soft fabric.

 

“Say cheese!” Lilia called from behind the camera, her voice laced with affection.

 

“Cheese!” Nicky said loudly, his giggles bubbling over as Rio kissed the top of his head. Lilia caught the moment perfectly, snapping a picture of her daughter and grandson that radiated love and joy.

 

Lilia lowered the camera, her smile soft but full of satisfaction. “This one’s going in the album,” she said quietly, her voice filled with a quiet pride. “Alright, now the two of you,” Lilia said, gesturing to Agatha and Rio.

 

Agatha stepped forward, slipping an arm around Rio’s waist. There was no need for words as they leaned into one another, a quiet moment of love and connection captured in the frame. Lilia smiled behind the camera, her gaze soft and proud.

 

“Now, the whole family,” Lilia said softly, her voice filled with warmth as she captured the intimacy between the couple.

 

Agatha extended her arm out, and Nicky stepped in front of them, leaning against their legs as they each draped a hand on his shoulders. The three of them stood together—a perfect family picture. Agatha’s protective presence, Rio’s radiant happiness, and Nicky’s boundless energy all harmonized in a way that felt complete.

 

“Wait, wait, now the girls!” Lilia said, ushering Alice and Jen into the frame.

 

The three graduates stood together, their black gowns matching but their personalities shining through. Alice cracked a joke, and all three burst into laughter just as Lilia clicked the shutter, capturing the candid, carefree moment.

 

Finally, Agatha took the camera from Lilia, her eyes glinting mischievously. “Your turn, Lilia. Get in there.”

 

“What? Oh no, no,” Lilia began, shaking her head.

 

“Don’t argue with me,” Agatha said firmly, but the smile on her lips made it clear she was enjoying this playful exchange. She gestured toward Rio, who was already smiling warmly.

 

Rio, her heart swelling with affection, reached for Lilia’s hand, gently pulling her closer. “Come on, Mom,” she said softly, her voice filled with the kind of warmth that made it impossible for Lilia to resist.

 

Lilia relented, standing beside Rio as Agatha framed the shot. The two women embraced, Lilia’s pride and Rio’s gratitude evident in their expressions. Agatha captured the moment, a picture perfect image of a mother and daughter whose bond had grown unshakable.

 

The impromptu photo session ended with everyone grinning, their happiness tangible in each picture. Rio glanced over at Lilia and Agatha, her heart full. These weren’t just photographs—they were memories, moments of love and celebration captured forever, and Rio knew those pictures would soon find their place on the walls of Lilia’s house, among all the other memorabilia of Rio’s teenage years and achievements as a young adult.

 

The group settled into the lively atmosphere of the garden party, the soft hum of classical music weaving through the chatter and laughter of the crowd. Rio found herself standing with Alice and Jen near one of the refreshment tables, their black gowns billowing slightly in the evening breeze.

 

“So, do you guys remember that time in the library when the Wi-Fi went down, and Jen almost had a meltdown trying to download her data?” Rio asked, a playful glint in her eyes as she watched Jen’s face change in anticipation.

 

Jen immediately groaned, slumping her shoulders dramatically, and threw one hand over her face as if trying to shield herself from the flood of memories. “Don’t remind me,” she muttered. “I was this close to throwing my laptop out the window. It was a disaster.”

 

Alice, who had been listening intently, doubled over in laughter. “And then Rio, in all her tech wizardry, swooped in with her magical hotspot, saving the day like some sort of tech goddess.”

 

Rio shrugged nonchalantly, though the mischievous grin tugging at her lips told a different story. “It wasn’t that dramatic,” she said, trying to play down her heroics.

 

“Oh, it absolutely was!” Jen insisted, leaning in with mock seriousness. “If it weren’t for you, I’d probably still be in that library right now, crying over corrupted files and a crashed system.”

 

Rio’s eyes sparkled with a sense of triumph, and she leaned closer to her friends, lowering her voice conspiratorially. “Okay, okay, but now I think I can finally admit something… I may or may not have borrowed that hotspot from the IT office when I went over there to try and convince the guy in charge to fix my laptop for free…”

 

Alice’s eyes widened in disbelief as she clutched her sides, her laughter bubbling over. “No! You didn’t! I can’t believe it. You, Rio Vidal, the rule follower, the academic purist, stole something from the IT guy? Oh my god, I’m dying!”

 

Rio only shrugged again, not even bothering to look guilty. “I mean, the situation was dire. And technically, I didn’t steal it. I just borrowed it. It was for the greater good, really.”

 

Rio didn’t even try to look contrite as the three of them dissolved into laughter.

 

Jen wiped away a tear from the corner of her eye, still chuckling. “I’ll never look at you the same way again. I mean, we all thought you were too good for rule-breaking. Turns out, we were wrong!”

 

Rio smirked, a spark of rebellion in her eyes. “You know what they say, sometimes rules are meant to be bent.”

 

“Come on, she was literally dating her professor the whole time, we knew she was a rule-breaker,” Alice said, patting Rio’s shoulder.

 

Meanwhile, Nicky flitted around the group like a little bundle of energy, his small bowtie bobbing as he moved. He had somehow managed to charm nearly everyone he met, asking endless questions about the party, the music, and why people wore funny fabric on their shoulders.

 

“Mom, why do you all wear these ribbons on your shoulders?” Nicky asked, tugging at Rio’s sleeve with his small hand, his gaze locked on the tassels of her doctoral hood, which swayed slightly as she moved.

 

Rio bent down to his level with a soft chuckle, her heart warming at the sight of his curiosity. “Those are called doctoral hoods,” she explained, adjusting the fabric gently. “It’s a special tradition for graduates like me. They represent all the hard work and studying we’ve done.”

 

Nicky’s brow furrowed in thought, his small lips pursed as he processed the information. After a beat, his face lit up with a new question. “Do you get to keep it?”

 

Rio nodded. “I do. Maybe I’ll let you try it on later.”

 

“Cool!” he exclaimed, spinning on his heels and darting toward Agatha, who was chatting with a few faculty members nearby. “Mama, why are there so many flowers here?”

 

Agatha looked down with soft eyes, indulging his curiosity. “Because it’s a celebration, and flowers make everything look beautiful, don’t you think?”

 

Nicky’s eyes lit up with understanding, and he nodded vigorously. “Yeah, like the one in Mom’s hair!” He grinned, pointing up at the delicate flower tucked behind Rio’s ear, the same one Agatha had placed there that morning.

 

Agatha smiled softly, her gaze drifting to Rio, who was still laughing with her friends. “Exactly like that.”

 

The evening continued in a joyful blur, the air filled with lighthearted conversations, the clinking of glasses, and the occasional burst of laughter. For Rio, it felt like the perfect way to cap off such a monumental day, everything felt easy and joyful.

 

Agatha lingered on the edge of the celebration, her sharp blue eyes following Rio as she moved through the crowd, her dress catching the fading sunlight. From the way Rio laughed with Alice and Jen to the way she crouched to answer one of Nicky’s endless questions, every movement of hers was full of life, joy, and the confidence that had blossomed over the years and that Agatha adored. Her lips curved into a small smile, a quiet but unmistakable expression of love.

 

Anyone paying attention would have seen it—the way Agatha’s gaze softened whenever it landed on Rio, the way her posture subtly relaxed as if her world felt right so long as Rio was near. Every so often, she caught herself staring too long, but she didn’t care. Not tonight.

 

A fellow faculty member, Dr. Spencer, stood next to Agatha, his glass of wine nearly empty as he glanced over at her with a wry smile. He had always known Agatha to be composed, a woman of quiet authority, but tonight, there was something different in the way her gaze lingered on Rio. His eyes followed her line of sight before he spoke with a teasing tone, “Dr. Harkness, you look especially proud this evening.”

 

Agatha shifted her attention to Dr. Spencer, a small, knowing smile curling on her lips. Her blue eyes were warm, but there was something deeper behind the surface, something that only those who knew her well might recognize. “I suppose I have every reason to be,” she replied softly, her voice carrying an almost private quality, as though the words weren’t meant for anyone else but herself.

 

Dr. Spencer raised an eyebrow, sensing there was more to the statement than the usual academic pride. He followed her gaze, noting how it was solely fixed on Rio. He couldn’t help but smile knowingly, having seen Agatha and Rio together often, but tonight, there was an added layer to their dynamic. It was the unspoken bond, the unguarded tenderness that had become so apparent between them.

 

“You’ve always been a bit of a hard one to read, Dr. Harkness,” he remarked with a teasing grin, taking another sip of his wine. “But tonight, it’s like I can see the weight of everything you’ve been holding back. It’s quite clear whose achievements you’re proud of.”

 

Agatha’s lips curved into a soft, almost imperceptible smile, a smile that was only for Rio. She glanced back at him, her posture relaxed, but her eyes still held that quiet intensity, the type that only came when she spoke of the people she truly cared for. “There’s a difference between being proud of someone’s achievements and being proud of who they are,” Agatha said, her voice low but firm, and there was a sincerity in it that made Dr. Spencer pause.

 

“Ah,” he nodded, his tone shifting from playful to understanding. “I see. It’s the kind of pride that goes deeper than any academic honor, isn’t it?” His eyes flickered back to Rio, who was now lifting Nicky into her arms as the little boy squirmed with excitement, pulling at her doctoral hood. Agatha’s smile widened at the sight, and Dr. Spencer followed the moment with a thoughtful hum.

 

“You’ve found your one, haven’t you?” he added, not just as an observation but as a statement of understanding.

 

Agatha didn’t respond immediately, her eyes softening as she continued to watch Rio. Nicky’s laughter echoed through the garden, and Rio’s infectious joy filled the space around them. Agatha’s heart swelled, and for a moment, the weight of everything—her achievements, her struggles, the years that had passed—seemed to settle into place, anchored by the woman she loved.

 

“I have,” Agatha said finally, her voice quieter now, almost a whisper. “And I’m proud of her, more than I ever thought I would be.” Her eyes shone, and though she remained poised as ever, there was a vulnerability in the words that Dr. Spencer caught.

 

“She’s everything,” Agatha added in a soft murmur, just loud enough for Dr. Spencer to hear.

 

The colleague took another sip of his drink, leaning back slightly, as if sensing the conversation had reached a quiet, unspoken end. “I don’t think anyone would question that,” he said, his tone thoughtful and more respectful than it had been before. He nodded toward Rio, who was now sharing a laugh with Jen, her energy bright and palpable. “Looks like you’ve got a good one there, Dr. Harkness.”

 

Agatha smiled at him, her expression both content and proud. “I know,” she said simply, the quiet certainty in her voice speaking volumes. She turned her attention back to Rio, feeling the warmth of the evening settle in her chest. 

 

“Every reason to be proud indeed,” she murmured softly to herself.

 

As the evening continued, Agatha moved through the crowd, greeting colleagues and students, her professional demeanor firmly in place. But she always kept Rio within her line of sight, her presence grounding her in a way that nothing else could.

 

When their eyes met across the garden, Rio gave her a radiant smile, one that sent warmth rushing through Agatha’s chest. She returned it with a subtle nod, her fingers twitching with the urge to reach out and hold Rio’s hand, to close the space between them.

 

Tonight, though, there was no need to hide. Agatha allowed her affection to show in the way her gaze lingered, in the small but genuine smiles she reserved just for Rio. Anyone watching would know that this wasn’t just a moment of professional pride for Dr. Harkness.

 

This was personal.

 

 

At some point, amidst the laughter and chatter, Agatha quietly slipped away. Her departure had been so seamless that even Rio, who was typically attuned to her partner’s every movement, didn’t notice right away. She was deep in conversation with Alice and Jen, the three of them reminiscing about late nights in the library and the endless cups of coffee that had fueled their final dissertations.

 

“…and remember when that one guy fell asleep so loudly, we had to move tables?” Alice asked, her voice bubbling with laughter. Jen leaned in, nodding in agreement.

 

“I swear it was like a foghorn!” she added, her tone filled with mock exasperation, though the laughter that followed made it clear she had no real complaints.

 

Rio chuckled, shaking her head at the memory. “I can’t believe we survived those nights. The amount of caffeine we consumed should be illegal.”

 

Rio laughed, shaking her head at the memory, but something tugged at the edge of her awareness—a sudden sense of absence. Her gaze darted around the garden, searching for the familiar figure of her lover. But the sleek black dress Agatha had been wearing, the one she looked so stunning in, was nowhere among the clusters of people.

 

Frowning slightly, she excused herself from the conversation. “I’ll be right back,” she said, her tone casual, though curiosity and a touch of concern were already building.

 

Alice and Jen exchanged a knowing glance but didn’t comment, letting Rio slip away to search.

 

She wandered through the garden, her eyes scanning the crowd. Agatha wasn’t near the refreshment tables or chatting with colleagues. Rio’s steps quickened slightly, though she told herself there was no reason to worry. Agatha had probably stepped away for a moment of quiet—it wasn’t unusual for her to do so in large gatherings.

 

Still, Rio couldn’t shake the feeling that something was different. Her search became more focused, her dress swaying around her legs as she weaved through the clusters of people, her mind turning over possibilities.

 

Where had she gone? And why hadn’t she said anything?

 

As Rio scanned the garden, trying to locate Agatha, a small voice broke through the haze of her thoughts. She turned just in time to see Nicky appear at her side, his tiny hands tugging insistently at the fabric of her gown. His face was illuminated by a grin so wide it seemed to stretch across his entire face, and his excitement was practically radiating off him like a burst of energy.

 

“Mom! Come with me!” he said, his voice bubbling with enthusiasm, an infectious cheer that Rio couldn’t help but feel. “It’s a surprise!”

 

Rio tilted her head, bemused by the intensity of his energy. “A surprise?” she asked, her voice soft with amusement as she crouched down slightly to meet his gaze. “What kind of surprise, little love? I need to find your Mama.”

 

Nicky shook his head vigorously, his small hands now tugging harder at her gown as if to pull her toward whatever awaited. “Nope! Not telling! You just have to come! And I know where Mama is !”

 

Before she could respond, Lilia stepped in from nearby, her expression soft but knowing. She gently placed a hand on Rio’s shoulder, her other hand reaching for the edges of Rio’s black graduation gown.

 

“Let me take this for you, sweetheart,” Lilia said, her tone calm but somehow filled with meaning. She slid the gown off Rio’s shoulders, revealing the entirety of the soft green fabric of her dress, which swayed lightly in the gentle evening breeze.

 

“Lilia, what’s going on?” Rio asked, her brow furrowing slightly, sensing something more was afoot than just the excitement of the evening. She handed over the gown, her fingers lingering for a moment as Lilia took it from her.

 

Lilia just smiled, her eyes twinkling with something Rio couldn’t quite place. “You’ll see,” she said, folding the gown over her arm. “Go on, darling. Nicky’s waiting.”

 

Rio glanced from Lilia to Nicky, who was practically vibrating with excitement, his tiny fingers already grabbing for Rio’s hand with determination. Still feeling a small twinge of uncertainty but trusting whatever was unfolding, Rio let herself be guided. Nicky was nothing if not persistent.

 

“Come on, Mom!” Nicky urged, his small fingers gripping hers tightly as he guided her through the garden, weaving between groups of graduates and their families. “It’s so cool! You’re gonna love it!”

 

Rio glanced back over her shoulder one last time, catching Lilia’s warm and encouraging smile as she watched them go. There was something unspoken in her expression, something that made Rio feel both reassured and more curious than ever. Whatever this was, it felt important. There was a sense of quiet intention behind it, and Rio found herself eager to uncover it.

 

Nicky led Rio through a winding path that grew quieter with each step, the lively hum of the garden party fading into the background.

 

“Where are we going, Nicky?” Rio asked, her tone gentle but teasing, as they walked through the garden, the sounds of laughter and conversation fading into the background.

 

Nicky only gave her a mysterious, sideways glance, his grin growing wider as he pulled her along. “You’ll see, Mom. You’ll see!” he said, practically bursting with excitement as he led her down a quiet path at the far end of the garden, the soft rustle of leaves overhead and the scent of flowers filling the air.

 

They emerged into a secluded section of the garden, a hidden oasis where the air felt still and sacred, carrying the faint, intoxicating fragrance of blooming flowers. The vibrant colors of the blossoms seemed to pulse with life—roses in rich shades of red and pink, lilacs in soft purples, and tulips in bright splashes of yellow and orange, their petals swaying gently in the breeze. Every corner was a painter’s palette, vivid and alive. In the center of it all stood a small fountain, its water softly bubbling, adding a peaceful, rhythmic melody to the serene atmosphere

 

Rio gasped, her steps faltering as she took in the breathtaking scene before her. The garden seemed like something plucked from a dream, a place where time slowed and the world outside faded away. The setting sunlight filtered through the canopy of trees, casting dappled patterns of light and shadow across the ground, and the soft rustle of leaves created a symphony of whispers. Everything about this moment felt perfect—almost too perfect, like something that could only exist in the quiet space between reality and fantasy.

 

“This… this is beautiful,” Rio murmured, her voice thick with awe, the words slipping from her lips in a hushed reverence. Her heart stuttered slightly in her chest as she gazed around, her mind still processing the beauty of it all. She could hardly believe this was real, this tranquil moment tucked away from the busy celebration that had been going on moments ago.

 

And then her gaze landed on Agatha, and everything stopped.

 

There, standing in the center of the garden, was the love of her life, holding a bouquet of purple and white flowers wrapped in greenery. The deep purples of the blooms contrasted against her elegant dark dress, and the whites seemed to glow in the soft light, their petals almost ethereal, like something touched by magic.  

 

For a moment, Rio was frozen, her breath catching in her throat. Agatha’s face softened when she noticed her, her smile blooming into something gentle yet full of profound emotion. 

 

“Agatha…” Rio whispered, her heart racing as the realization began to dawn on her.

 

Nicky tugged on her hand again, breaking her trance. “I told you it was a surprise, Mom!” he exclaimed, bouncing on his heels, clearly proud of his involvement.

 

Agatha stepped forward, bending down slightly to ruffle Nicky’s hair. “Thank you for helping, my little man,” she said softly, her tone filled with affection.

 

Nicky beamed, puffing out his chest proudly. “Did I do good, Mama?” he asked, looking up at Agatha with wide eyes.

 

Agatha’s smile deepened, a mixture of fondness and love in her expression as she leaned in, pressing a light, affectionate kiss to Nicky’s forehead. “You did perfect,” she replied, her voice thick with affection, her tone tender and assuring. “I couldn’t have done it without you.”

 

Agatha’s hand lingered on Nicky’s shoulder for a moment longer before she gently guided him toward the path that led back to the main gathering. “Now, why don’t you go back to Grandma Lilia?” Agatha suggested softly. “I think she’s waiting for you.”

 

Nicky’s eyes brightened at the mention of Lilia, and without hesitation, he turned to Rio, wrapping his arms around her for a quick, tight hug. “Okay! Have fun, Moms!” he called out as he pulled away, giggling as he ran off down the path, his little feet quick and light on the soft earth.

 

The garden grew quiet again and Agatha turned back to Rio.

 

Agatha took a step closer, the bouquet still in her hands. Her eyes never left Rio’s, and in that moment, Rio felt the weight of what was coming settle over her—a mix of anticipation, love, and overwhelming emotion.

 

Now alone in the quiet, magical garden, Agatha stepped closer to Rio, her movements slow and deliberate. Her hand reached out, fingers brushing against Rio’s before she took it fully, lacing their fingers together. Agatha’s touch was warm, grounding, and as Rio met her gaze, she felt a lump form in her throat. Agatha’s eyes were steady, deep blue pools of emotion that seemed to hold the weight of every unspoken word they’d shared over their time together.

 

“Rio, my love,” Agatha began, her voice low and steady, but tinged with vulnerability. She glanced at their intertwined hands before looking back at Rio’s face. “I’ve been thinking all day about how to say this, how to put into words everything I’m feeling right now.”

 

Rio’s breath hitched slightly, her lips parting as she watched Agatha, every word sinking into her chest.

 

“When I first met you,” Agatha continued, her voice softening, “I thought I knew what my life was—what it would always be. Controlled, predictable, comfortable.” She smiled faintly, her thumb brushing against Rio’s hand. “And then you came into my world like a tornado I never saw coming. You challenged me, frustrated me, and made me laugh more than I had in years. You brought light into corners of my life I didn’t even realize were dark.”

 

Rio’s eyes shimmered with unshed tears, her free hand coming up to cover her mouth as her emotions bubbled to the surface.

 

“I’ve watched you grow, not just as a scholar, but as a mother, a friend, and a partner,” Agatha said, her voice trembling slightly as her emotions crept in. “You are strong, compassionate, and brilliant. And standing here today, I feel like the luckiest person in the world, because I get to love you and be loved by you.”

 

Agatha paused, her own eyes glistening now as she steadied herself. “You’ve made me believe in things I thought I’d lost faith in. You’ve reminded me what it means to hope, to dream, and to build a life with someone.” She took a deep breath, her hand tightening slightly around Rio’s. “And I want to spend the rest of my life building that with you.”

 

Agatha’s voice softened further as she continued, her words deliberate and heartfelt, like she was laying bare every corner of her soul. “Rio, my darling, sweet, caring, fierce, Rio,” she said, her thumb brushing gently over Rio’s knuckles, “you’ve taught me so much—not just about love, but about what it means to live fully. You’ve shown me that life doesn’t have to be predictable to be beautiful. It can be messy, chaotic, and volatile, and still be the most extraordinary thing I’ve ever experienced. You are the most extraordinary thing I’ve ever experienced.”

 

Rio let out a shaky breath, her fingers tightening around Agatha’s as her chest swelled with emotion. Agatha smiled softly, her own tears threatening to spill over, but she pushed on, her voice steady even as it trembled with feeling.

 

“I’ve always been someone who thought strength was about control,” Agatha admitted, her eyes holding Rio’s. “But then you came in and taught me that real strength is letting go—letting someone in. You taught me that strength is in being vulnerable, in trusting someone so completely that you’re not afraid to fall because you know they’ll be there to catch you. You caught me, Rio. And I never want to let you go.”

 

Rio’s free hand trembled slightly as she reached out to touch Agatha’s cheek, her fingers grazing the soft skin there. Agatha leaned into the touch, her voice growing even softer, almost like a secret meant only for Rio.

 

“I’ve watched you love so fiercely—whether it’s your family, your friends, or your little dance students. You put your heart into everything you do, and you make the world a brighter, better place just by being in it. And somehow, you’ve given me the greatest gift by letting me stand by your side. You’ve let me see you at your strongest, your weakest, and everything in between, and I love every part of you.”

 

Rio was openly crying now, tears slipping silently down her cheeks as she looked at the woman in front of her, the woman she loved with everything she had. Agatha smiled gently, brushing a tear from Rio’s cheek with her thumb.

 

“I don’t just want to build a life with you, Rio,” Agatha said, her voice gaining strength as she poured her heart into her next words. “I want to build our life—a life where we never stop challenging each other, where we never stop laughing, and where we wake up every day knowing we chose each other, over and over again.”

 

Rio’s tears spilled over, her chest rising and falling with emotion. “Agatha…” she whispered, her voice shaky as her love for the woman standing before her threatened to overwhelm her.

 

Agatha gave her a small, almost bashful smile, her thumb brushing over the back of Rio’s hand one last time before she stepped back slightly. “There’s more,” she said, her tone soft but steady, as she reached into a hidden pocket of her dress and pulled something out.

 

Agatha shifted gracefully to one knee, her dark hair catching the soft glow of the garden lights as she revealed a small velvet box from her closed hand. The moment felt suspended in time, the gentle bubbling of the fountain the only sound accompanying the scene.

 

She opened the box with steady hands, revealing the most beautiful ring Rio had ever seen—a pear-shaped amethyst set in a delicate gold band, flanked by emerald clusters arranged like leaves. The design was elegant yet earthy, perfectly encapsulating both of their personalities.

 

Agatha looked up at Rio, her expression a mixture of vulnerability and quiet determination. Her voice, though steady, was thick with emotion as she spoke. “Rio Vidal, will you marry me?”

 

The question hung in the air, suspended in the stillness of the garden, its weight heavier than any ring could ever be. It was a question that carried not just love but an entire future—one they were both ready to step into, side by side.

 

Rio’s heart stopped for a beat, her breath catching in her throat. Tears welled in her eyes, blurring the vision before her as she stared at the ring, then back at Agatha. The sight of her, kneeling with such raw tenderness, the love and trust in her eyes—it was everything Rio had ever wanted and more. Her chest felt like it might burst from the sheer force of her emotions.

 

Without thinking, she pressed a hand to her mouth, stifling a sob, and when she finally spoke, her voice trembled with joy and disbelief. “Yes,” she whispered, the word feeling like a promise to both Agatha and herself, “a thousand times yes.” Then, unable to resist the playful spark that always seemed to exist between them, she added with a teasing grin, “Took you long enough.”

 

Agatha let out a soft, relieved laugh, her eyes glistening with tears of her own, and in that moment, Rio could see the weight of everything lifting, replaced by pure, unrestrained joy. With gentle hands, Agatha slid the ring onto Rio’s finger, its delicate design glinting in the soft light, a perfect match to the emotion that swirled between them. The world seemed to pause, to hold its breath, as they shared this moment—this promise—together.

 

Standing, Agatha reached for Rio’s face, pulling her close as their lips met in a kiss that spoke volumes—a kiss filled with love, joy, and the unspoken vow of forever. Rio’s hands came to rest on Agatha’s wrists as the kiss deepened.

 

Agatha, overcome with the exhilaration of the moment, wrapped her arms around Rio’s waist and, in one fluid motion, lifted her off the ground. She spun her around, the sheer joy of the action making Rio’s heart race, and the world seemed to tilt and spin with them. Rio laughed, her green dress flaring out like a soft wave in the wind, caught up in the motion. She clung to Agatha’s neck, her arms tightening instinctively as she reveled in the dizzying rush of happiness, her laughter mixing with Agatha’s in a harmony that felt almost magical.

 

When Agatha finally set Rio down, the ground beneath her seemed to momentarily shift, as if the euphoria had left her a bit unsteady. But Rio held on tight, her arms wrapping around Agatha as she pressed her forehead against hers, her chest still rising and falling with their shared breaths.

 

When they finally pulled back, both of them breathing heavily, their hearts racing. Agatha let out a soft, watery laugh, her thumb tracing Rio’s cheek. “You’ve just made me the happiest woman in the world,” she murmured.

 

Rio laughed through, the sound sweet and joyful, her arms still wrapped tightly around Agatha’s neck. “Funny,” she whispered, her voice trembling with joy, “I was just about to say the same thing.”

 

Agatha’s hands lingered gently on Rio’s waist, her thumb brushing against the soft fabric of her dress. They stood there for a moment, the world outside their bubble still and quiet, the soft sounds of the garden’s fountain filling the space as they caught their breath.

 

Rio smiled, her eyes sparkling with a mix of affection and wonder, and she whispered, her voice thick with emotion, “You really know how to make a day unforgettable, Dr. Harkness.” Her words were soft, but they carried a weight of sincerity, as if every moment of their time together had led to this.

 

Agatha chuckled, the sound warm and rich, and she pressed her lips briefly to Rio’s temple, her hands still resting on her waist, anchoring them both in the present. “For you, Dr. Vidal,” she replied with a playful glint in her eye, “I’ll spend every day trying.”

 

Her words were simple, but there was a depth to them, a promise that no matter where life took them, Agatha would always strive to make moments like this an everyday reality.

 

 

After a few moments alone, savoring the joy of their engagement, Rio and Agatha made their way back to the main party, their hands intertwined. It was as if the energy from the proposal lingered between them, a delicate thread of connection that neither of them wanted to break. Rio still held the bouquet Agatha had given her earlier, the purple and white blooms nestled in her arm like a precious keepsake. The flowers, now a symbol of the promise they had just made, seemed to glow in the soft light, the petals dancing with the same joy that filled Rio’s heart.

 

Her pulse still raced with the excitement of the proposal, and every step felt lighter than the last. She couldn’t help but steal glances at Agatha, whose face was glowing with a mix of pride, love, and a quiet, contented joy that made Rio’s chest tighten with adoration.

 

As they neared the main gathering, the sounds of celebration grew louder, the music and laughter drifting through the air like a warm embrace. But Rio felt as though she was walking in a world of her own—one that was quieter, more intimate. Everything seemed brighter, more vivid, as if their engagement had turned up the color of the world around them. She couldn’t stop smiling, the happiness blooming inside her like the flowers in her arms.

 

She glanced over at Agatha, her gaze softening. “This… this feels like a dream,” she murmured, her voice barely above a whisper but filled with the depth of her feelings.

 

Agatha’s smile widened, her eyes crinkling with joy. She squeezed Rio’s hand, her thumb brushing over the back of it in a comforting, loving gesture. “It’s real,” she said, her voice steady and filled with certainty. “And it’s just the beginning.”

 

Rio’s heart swelled at the words, the truth of them settling deep within her. Everything had changed, and yet, nothing had. They were still the same two people who had loved each other through everything—the challenges, the quiet moments, the chaos—but now, they were stepping into a new chapter, hand in hand, ready for whatever came next.

 

As they reentered the party, their arrival didn’t go unnoticed. Guests paused mid-conversation, their gazes shifting toward the couple, noticing the way Rio’s eyes sparkled with happiness, the way Agatha’s beaming smile could light up the entire garden. Their engagement was as evident as the glow that surrounded them. But in that moment, it didn’t matter. They didn’t need the validation of others. They had each other, and that was enough.

 

Rio lifted the bouquet slightly, her fingers brushing the delicate petals. “Thank you,” she said softly, her voice filled with emotion. “For everything.”

 

Agatha’s gaze softened as she looked at her now fiancée, her heart full of a love that words couldn’t quite capture. “You deserve everything, my love,” she whispered back, her voice thick with affection. “And I will spend my life giving it to you.”

 

As Rio and Agatha approached their family, the air around them seemed to crackle with anticipation, a shared excitement palpable in every step. Lilia, Nicky, Alice, and Jen were all waiting, their expressions a mix of knowing smiles and gleaming eyes. It was clear that the surprise had been carefully orchestrated by all of them, and as Rio glanced toward Nicky, she could see the barely contained energy radiating off him. He bounced on his heels, his excitement so evident it was almost contagious, his wide eyes locked on them as he shouted, “Did she say yes?!”

 

Rio’s face lit up even more, a smile so bright it seemed to light up the entire garden around them. She only raised her left hand, showing off the sparkling engagement ring now adorning her finger. The room seemed to pause for a second, the weight of the moment hitting everyone all at once.

 

The moment Rio held up her hand, their family erupted into cheers. Lilia’s eyes welled with happy tears as she stepped forward, wrapping both Rio and Agatha in a tight, emotional hug. “I’m so happy for you both,” she whispered, her voice choked with joy. Her hands cupped Rio’s face then Agatha’s for a brief moment, her gaze soft but steady. “You deserve all the happiness in the world.”

 

Alice and Jen were not far behind, their faces alight with joy. They didn’t waste a second before jumping into the celebration. Alice’s arms shot out to wrap around Rio, pulling her into a hug so tight it nearly lifted her off the ground. Rio let out a surprised laugh, her heart swelling with affection for the woman who had been her closest friend through it all. Alice’s voice was full of excitement as she pulled back just enough to look at Rio’s face. “I knew it! I knew you two were meant to be together,” she exclaimed, her grin infectious. “We’ve got to start planning this wedding right away! I’m thinking something big and beautiful, like you deserve. We’ll make it magical, Rio!”

 

Jen, with her usual cool demeanor, had a soft but wide smile on her face as she wrapped her arms around Agatha, pulling her into a bear hug that showed her genuine joy. “You two are perfect for each other,” Jen said, her voice full of warmth and sincerity. “I can already see it all—the flowers, the music, the atmosphere. It’s going to be stunning. I can’t wait to help make this day one for the books.”

 

Rio felt the embrace of her chosen family surrounding her, and it was overwhelming in the best way possible. Lilia’s proud, tear-filled expression, Alice’s infectious enthusiasm, and Jen’s practical yet heartfelt excitement were all reflections of the support and love that had defined their journey. Rio’s chest tightened with the knowledge that she wasn’t walking into this new chapter alone—she had an entire family who would be there every step of the way.

 

Nicky, who had been practically bouncing in circles around them, clapped his hands together, his little face beaming with pride. “You did it, Mama!” he exclaimed, looking up at both Rio and Agatha. “And Mom, you said yes!”

 

Rio’s heart fluttered at the sight of his excitement. She nodded, her voice thick with emotion as she gazed at Agatha, unable to tear her eyes away from the woman who had just become her fiancée. “Yes, sweet boy,” she whispered, her words barely escaping as her eyes softened with love. “I said yes.”

 

Nicky’s joy was infectious, and he jumped up and down with barely contained energy, his little hands flapping in the air. “You’re getting married! Best moms ever!” he cheered, clearly bursting with pride at being part of such an important moment.

 

Rio couldn’t help but laugh, bending down to hug Nicky tight. “I’m glad you’re happy, little love,” she said, planting a kiss on his forehead.

 

The air was filled with laughter, love, and joy as the group surrounded Rio and Agatha, offering their heartfelt congratulations. The weight of the moment settled in fully—this wasn’t just a celebration of an engagement, but a celebration of a family, of their journey together, and of everything they had ahead of them.

 

For Rio, standing there with Agatha, surrounded by the people they loved, she felt more complete than ever. The future, once uncertain and full of obstacles, now felt wide open, ready to be filled with all the love and happiness they had earned fair and square.

 

And as the applause and cheers continued, Rio knew one thing for sure: the next chapter of their lives was going to be beautiful.

 

Lilia’s eyes glistened with tears as she took a step closer to Agatha, placing a hand gently on her arm. “I just want to say,” she began, her voice soft but filled with emotion, “how grateful I am that you’re making my daughter so happy.” Her gaze shifted to Rio, who was still beaming, twirling Nicky around to the sound of the quartets. “I’ve seen how she’s changed, how much she’s grown, and it’s all because of you.”

 

Agatha, who had been soaking in the joy of the moment, met Lilia’s eyes. She could see the love and sincerity in Lilia’s gaze, and it touched her deeply. She’d always known that Lilia cared for Rio and for her so deeply, but hearing this now—so openly and full of warmth—moved her more than words could express.

 

Lilia continued, her voice trembling slightly. “I love you both like daughters, you know. You’ve both brought so much light into my life, and watching your relationship grow, watching it blossom into something so pure and beautiful… it’s an honor. An absolute honor to be a part of this.”

 

Agatha felt her heart swell, and she pulled Lilia into a heartfelt embrace. “Thank you,” she whispered, the weight of Lilia’s words filling her with gratitude. “I love her more than anything. I promise you, I’ll spend every day making sure she’s happy.”

 

Lilia nodded, hugging her tightly. “I know you will, Agatha. I know.”

 

As they pulled away from the embrace, Rio was magically there, standing beside them with a smile that could light up the world. She took Lilia’s hand in hers, squeezing it gently. “Thank you, Mom,” Rio said, her voice full of warmth. “We’re so lucky to have you.”

 

Lilia smiled back, wiping away a tear before it could fall. “And I’m lucky to have both of you,” she replied softly, pulling Rio into a tight hug once again. “You’re my sweet sweet girl.”

 

The moment felt timeless, full of love and the kind of deep connection that could only come from years of shared history. It was a moment Rio would carry with her forever—knowing she was surrounded by people who truly understood the depth of her relationship with Agatha, and who cherished the happiness they had found together.

 

The garden party carried on around them, the warm glow of the now set sun casting a soft light over the festivities. Laughter and music filled the air, the atmosphere light and joyful as the group celebrated together.

 

Nicky, still full of excitement, bounced around, asking questions and delighting in the love and attention from everyone. Alice and Jen chatted animatedly, already tossing out ideas for the wedding, while Lilia, with a proud smile on her face, stood by Rio and Agatha, her eyes never leaving them and their happiness.

 

Rio’s hand never left Agatha’s, the new engagement ring glinting under the lights. She leaned in close, resting her head on Agatha’s shoulder as they shared a quiet moment amidst the celebration. It was a moment of contentment, of feeling like they were exactly where they were meant to be. Their love was out in the open now, no longer hidden, and it felt like the world was finally catching up with them.

 

They all gathered around the tables, sharing a meal, exchanging stories, and savoring every moment of the evening. Lilia raised her glass in a toast. “To family, to love, and to new beginnings,” she said, her voice full of emotion. “May we continue to grow together.”

 

“Cheers!” they all chorused, clinking glasses.

 

As the stars began to twinkle above, and the last notes of the soft music floated through the air, Rio glanced around at the people she loved. Her heart swelled with happiness.

 

This was her family.

 

This was her life.

 

And as she squeezed Agatha’s hand once more, she knew that this was just the beginning of the most beautiful journey ahead.

 

Here they stood, hand in hand, their whole life in front of them, at the still point of the turning world.

 

 

 

F I N

 

*

*

*

 

 

 

Chapter End Notes

Well… here we are. The end of this journey. I’m crying as I write this because what a ride it has been.

Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, for all your support. Your comments have meant everything to me—reading them every day has brought me so much joy, more than I can ever put into words.

I’ve laughed and cried while writing this fic, and I can’t wait to keep going. Because this? This is not the end of Agatha, Rio, and Nicky’s story. Not even close. This fic is now part of a series called All Roads Lead to You, and the next installment is coming very, very soon (as in, it’s already written!). I would love nothing more than to see you there and hear your thoughts once again.
Little teaser: it will be short, but will cover a very important day...

As a little parting gift, I’ve put together a Spotify playlist for this story—filled with songs that inspired me, ones I love, and tracks that I feel truly capture the essence of these characters. If you’re interested, here’s the link! I hope you enjoy it.

https://open.spotify.com/playlist/5ZHMC5M1a2BFYKAoSWHIjx?si=6307e50cd2db4e92

I love you all. Truly.

See you soon.

Merci beaucoup, je vous aime tous, et cette histoire n’aurait rien été sans vous. 💜💚

Afterword

Please drop by the Archive and comment to let the creator know if you enjoyed their work!
